title: NEC AND CRAY RESOLVE DISPUTE

The agreement paves the way for NEC to sell its supercomputers in the United States for the first time in four years. Cray, which is based in Seattle, will have exclusive rights to sell NEC's SX Series line in North America and nonexclusive rights for the rest of the world. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: A New and More Active Life For Some Sedentary Old Letters
description: Back to the future. Michael Bierut of Pentagram, a design company, was asked to come up with a new logo for the New York Society Library, founded in 1754. He saw the solution, right, when he went to the library at 53 East 79th Street. The lettering, he said, was ''right outside their door, where there's a bronze plaque with the words 'The New York Society Library' inscribed in a raised lettering that no one would dare propose today.'' The plaque's idiosyncratic, handcrafted lettering was designed by Paul Manship, an American sculptor (1885-1966). The library's holdings include 17th-century science books, 18th-century fiction and new books. An annual subscription is $150. The public may read on the premises free; closed Sunday. ELAINE LOUIE

title: TYSON CHANGES TERMS OF OFFER FOR MEATPACKER
description: Tyson Foods, a poultry producer, said yesterday that it had halted the cash tender portion of its $4.7 billion offer to buy the meatpacker IBP because of a government inquiry into IBP's financial statements. Tyson said it would give IBP shareholders a combination of cash and stock after the transaction was completed instead of cash up front. The change may delay by two months or more Tyson's plan to create the nation's largest producer of chicken, beef and pork, analysts said. The transaction has been delayed four times since Tyson agreed Jan. 1 to buy IBP, after the Securities and Exchange Commission questioned IBP's accounting. The last extension was to expire yesterday. IBP plans to restate its earnings for the last two years, after finding misstatements and irregularities at its DFG Foods unit.

title: CURRENTS: ARCHITECTURE; In Guadalajara, a Project Is Shaped by 11 Hands
description: With the raising of a 300-foot-high Mexican flag last month, Guadalajara, Mexico's second-largest city, took a step toward becoming a mecca for new architecture. Jorge Vergara, the chairman of Omnilife, which distributes herbal supplements, picked 11 architects to create a business and cultural center that would include a headquarters for Omnilife. The planned center, to cost an estimated $460 million, will sport a children's museum by Philip Johnson, below; a ring by Thom Mayne of Los Angeles for cockfighting, a sport both legal and popular in Mexico; a hotel by Zaha Hadid of London; and buildings by Jean Nouvel and Coop Himmelblau. ''It will show us that the socialist project of centralized planning has been replaced by the cultural project that brings people together,'' Ms. Hadid said. First up, Enrique Norten's glowing convention center, above, which will house 60,000 conventioneers under a translucent energy-efficient roof. ''This will detonate a whole cycle of development,'' Mr. Norten said. ''For the 11 of us, it is a chance for a group of friends to have fun, to collaborate.'' AARON BETSKY

title: Big Earthquakes and Their Magnitudes
description: The magnitude of an earthquake is a measure of the amount of shaking. The first magnitude scale was developed by Charles F. Richter, a seismologist, in the 1930's. On his scale, each increase of 1 unit represented a 10-fold increase in the amplitude of the shaking. Thus, the degree of back-and-forth shaking in an earthquake measuring 7.3 on the Richter scale shakes is 10 times greater than one measuring 6.3.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SCHOLASTIC TO OPEN SOHO STORE
description: The Scholastic Corporation, the United States publisher of the Clifford the Big Red Dog and Harry Potter children's books series, will open its first retail store Monday at its new headquarters in SoHo. Besides books, the store will sell games, puzzles, CD-ROM's and stuffed animals based on characters in the company's books. Judy Corman, a company spokeswoman, said the 6,000-square-foot Scholastic Store would be different from theme stores, some of which have suffered lately. ''Warner has 1,400 stores around the country,'' she said. ''We only have one. They're more a novelty store. Our store is based on literacy, on children reading.'' Tara Bahrampour

title: A Sense of Place, A Spare Oeuvre
description: A colleague recently put me onto a remarkable reading experience, the collected short stories of Alistair MacLeod, a Canadian writer who has the talent of turning geography into a character. Something only the best can do, I think, without being mushy. Mr. MacLeod clearly has a distinctive literary voice -- a Canadian one. And in reading him you remember that there is such a thing as Southern literary sensibility and a Western sensibility in this country. I know that Alice Munro, the great Canadian short fiction writer, also has among other things a commanding sense of region. Still, I haven't read enough of the Canadian writers to know if they have collectively a distinct discernment or taste that feeds on their homeland.

Mr. Martino's distinguished career encompasses jazz, grim Expressionism, lapidary sensuousness, Serialism and a pared-down later style. Has he been the same man in all these disguises?

title: SLOWING SALES FOR EQUIPMENT MAKERS
description: A pair of computer equipment makers warned that quarterly results would not meet estimates because of slowing sales and a weakening economy. Elantec Semiconductor fell $10.88, or 35 percent, to $19.81 after the company, a maker of analog computer chips, said profit in the second quarter, ending in March, would be 20 cents to 22 cents a share instead of 38 cents. Sales are now expected to be 20 percent to 25 percent below the first quarter's $40.7 million. 3Com, a maker of computer-networking equipment, said that excluding reorganization and other costs, its operating loss in the quarter ending Friday will be $235 million to $245 million, wider than an earlier estimate of $80 million to $100 million. The net loss excluding those and other items like investment gains will be $135 million to $145 million, the company said.

title: Refashioning Bilingual Education
description: After a quarter-century of criticism from educators, politicians and parents, New York City's Board of Education has unanimously approved an overhaul of the school system's bilingual education program. The 7-to-0 vote has given Mayor Rudolph Giuliani the strong consensus he wanted to move forward with a long-overdue but inevitably unsettling change. Mr. Giuliani, who has already contributed $9 million, should now help find the balance of the $75 million that Schools Chancellor Harold Levy says he needs to put the program in high gear.

title: COST CONTROL AT MICROCHIP TECHNOLOGY
description: Microchip Technology, a maker of microchips for cars, appliances, computer equipment and security systems, said it would cut its work force by 12 percent, or about 400 employees, and trim production by 24 percent. ''We're seeing a slowdown across all segments of our business,'' Gordon Parnell, the chief financial officer, said. The company, based in Chandler, Ariz., has also deferred, from June 2002 to December 2002, the start of operations at a manufacturing plant it acquired last summer in Puyallup, Wash. Mr. Parnell said Microchip Technology expected to report sales of $161 million for the first quarter of 2001, off 15 percent from $190 million in the prior quarter. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: First, You Ooh and Aah. Then You Repair to the Gift Shop.

Most of the objects are in production; about 30 of them, including calculators, sleek swivel chairs and plastic desks on rollers, are for sale in the gift shop. The cube-shaped Caddy above, a foam desk organizer, has slots for pencils and letters; magnetic circles corral metal paper clips ($20). The foam Caddy below holds letters and pens ($22). Foam is ''so light and durable,'' said China Young, who with his partner, Jude Pauli of Loop Design in Manhattan, created the objects. At the MoMA Design Store, 44 West 53rd Street, (800) 793-3167.

title: Metro Business Briefing; COMMITMENT SOUGHT FROM CON ED
description: Northeast Utilities has given Consolidated Edison until tomorrow to formally commit to merger plans before it takes legal action against Con Ed for breach of contract. Northeast Utilities, Connecticut's largest electricity provider, said in a letter to Con Ed that it wanted ''reasonable assurances'' in writing that Con Ed would close the $3.8 billion merger deal once it received approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission, which could happen as early as this month. In a statement yesterday, Northeast Utilities said Con Ed had not responded to requests over the past two weeks to confirm its intentions. Shareholders of both companies agreed to the merger in April 2000, the release said. Con Ed said yesterday in a statement that it was reviewing prospects for the merger agreement in light of changes in the New England utility's businesses. Connecticut's attorney general, Richard Blumenthal, who has aggressively sought to scuttle the deal as bad for customers, the economy and the environment, said yesterday that the ultimatum from Northeast Utilities was ''a clear recognition that the deal is doomed.''

title: CANADA'S ECONOMY SLOWS
description: Canada's economy cooled in the fourth quarter, as the gross domestic product advanced at a 2.6 percent annual pace, compared with 4.5 percent in the third quarter. Real G.D.P. grew only 0.6 percent in the latest quarter, slightly below economists' expectations, after quarterly gains that have averaged 1.2 percent since mid-1998. The weakness was broadly based, as companies trimmed inventories and capital spending, and consumer spending and export sales slowed. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: Economic Scene; When it comes to cloning, social science has to catch up with genetic science.
description: THE field of genetics is moving at mach speed. In January, an international team of doctors announced plans to clone a human within 18 months. In February, two teams of researchers published a map of the human genome. While Wall Street frets over whether the discovery that the genome consists of ''only around 30,000 genes'' will limit the market value of genomics companies, the potential impact of genomics on the economy and society runs much deeper. Most fundamentally, cloning and genetic engineering could change the distribution of characteristics in the population.

description: ''Lenny Kravitz loves it,'' said Edward Baquero about the wine cellar at the Loft 30 Crosby Street, a luxury condominium building that opens this month near Grand Street in SoHo. Mr. Baquero and Stephen Touhey, of Landmark Development, renovated the 13 units, 12 of which have sold for $2 million to $8 million apiece. The one that remains on the market, a 4,200-square-foot loft, has a price tag of $3.3 million. The 2,500-square-foot wine cellar is an amenity for the owners (among them, Mr. Kravitz and Courtney Love). The storage space for wine, far left, ranges from 700 to 3,500 bottles. The taupe stucco tasting room, left, is 22 feet long and has a wood-burning limestone fireplace, an antique copper rinsing sink that doubles as a place to chill white wines, and a table that seats 16. The owners can use the tasting room for dinner parties, but they might have to picnic or call a caterer -- sorry, there is no kitchen. Lauder's businesses by American Muslim groups who disagree with his views about Israel misstated part of the name of a group that he serves as chairman. It is the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, not ''of Jewish American Organizations.''

title: Annual Drug Report Shows Coca Growth Increase
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Six years of intense American-backed anti-narcotics efforts in South America have redrawn drug trafficking patterns, but have failed to stem a yearly increase in the overall amount of coca being grown, the State Department acknowledged today.

title: GIANTS
description: Eric Studesville, an assistant coach with the Chicago Bears, was named the Giants' new running backs coach yesterday. The Giants also signed the free-agent punter Rodney Williams, whose professional experience is one season in the N.F.L.'s European league.

description: THE AMERICAS

title: Travel Tips From Readers
description: From scuba diving to road trips, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Hong Kong Holiday
description: It's a long way to go for a good deal and a tai chi lesson, but Continental Airlines' recent inauguration of nonstop service between Newark Airport and Hong Kong makes it a little easier to take. Pacific Delights sells a Hong Kong Kaleidoscope tour that features six nights in a choice of hotels and round-trip air fare on Continental, airport transfers in Hong Kong, hotel taxes and service charges and daily extras like tai chi classes. The packages cost $665 to $1,090 a person, based on double occupancy, depending on hotel selection (add $70 for Friday or Saturday departures). Using the Regal Kaitak Hotel, prices range from $665 to $740, depending on season; it's $830 to $950 in the Sheraton Hotel and Towers, and $1,070 to $1,090 if you stay in the Kowloon Shangri-La. There are daily departures March 1 to June 30. Call (800) 221-7179; Web site www.pacificdelighttours.com .

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CUTRONE, EDITH
description: CUTRONE-Edith. We extend our deepest sympathies to our leader and friend, Gustave H. Newman, and his extended family on the death of his beloved sister, Edith, a truly wonderful person. Our hearts and thoughts are with the Cutrone and Newman families. Any contributions in Edith's memory should be made to the United Cerebral Palsy of Greater Suffolk, Inc., P.O. Box 18045, 250 Marcus Boulevard, Hauppauge, NY 11788-8845, Attn: Development and Public Relations. The Lawyers and Staff of Newman & Greenberg

title: Fleeing Famine and War, Afghans Again Meet Death
description: HERAT, Afghanistan, Feb. 25  Three of Muhammad Uddin's sons froze to death along the narrow rim of the Sabzak Pass, where the elevation was steep and the truck tires could not hold. The snowfall was thick, the winds piercing. To one side was a yawning plunge. The eight families that had crowded into the vehicle's open flatbed thought it better to climb out and sleep on the wet ground than chance a mortal slide over the edge.

title: A Budget That Doesn't Add Up
description: WASHINGTON  On Tuesday evening, President Bush told Congress and the nation that "a time of blessing" calls for courage. Unfortunately, the administration sent Congress a budget plan that reflects the courage of a reckless gamble.

title: MARTHA STEWART LIVING NAMES CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER
description: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has promoted James Follo to chief financial officer, effective immediately, succeeding Helen Murphy. Mr. Follo, 41, who joined the company, in 1998, has been senior vice president for finance since 1999, a spokeswoman, Megan Stack, said. Ms. Murphy resigned to become chief financial officer of the Warner Music Group of AOL Time Warner.

title: Seasons of Squawks on the Crows' Calendar
description: When Lewis Spratlan won the 2000 Pulitzer Prize for music for Act II of his opera ''Life Is a Dream,'' which was performed only in concert, he assumed that some company would finally present a complete production of it. Though written in 1978, it was still unproduced. Inexplicably, no company has yet offered.

title: A Garden Vestige of the Paint-Splattered Hamptons
description: TALL cedar trees stand like gnarled sentinels at the entrance. A long lattice fence angles off in another direction, leading the eye away from the road and into a series of open-air rooms built by an artist who used landscape design, sculpture and architecture to create one of the most unusual settings in the Hamptons.

title: Vatican Rebukes a Theologian, but He Says He Can Work On
description: Two years after it began an investigation into accusations against him, the Vatican on Monday formally rebuked a Belgian Jesuit theologian, the Rev. Jacques Dupuis, over his writings. Obedient but unbowed, Father Dupuis said this week that he could ''in good conscience'' continue with his work.

description: To the Editor:

title: Booming New York Skirts Trend of Job Losses
description: Economic clouds may be gathering over much of the nation, but in New York City the jobs picture remains relentlessly sunny, according to new data from the State Department of Labor.

title: Republicans In the House Advance Plan For Tax Cuts
description: Acting swiftly to capitalize on President Bush's address to Congress, House Republicans put forward a $958 billion, across-the-board reduction in income tax rates today and said they would pass it through the House next week as the first stage of the tax cut.

title: Rangers Dominate Panthers
description: After receiving the news that Theo Fleury had begun rehabilitation as part of the National Hockey League's substance abuse and behavioral program, the Rangers turned in one of their most complete performances of the season last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Toile de Jouy Continues Its Merry March Forward
description: Toile wallpaper, of course. Certainly toile curtains and pillows. But now it seems the French country scenes of Toile de Jouy are everywhere, from tote bags to dressers. French Impressions of Greenwich, Conn., has imported a line of wood furniture decorated with 19th-century toile patterns painted on top or front panels. The collection includes a new Directoire chest of drawers, top, 36 inches wide and 66 inches high ($4,900), and a low Comedia chest, 49 inches wide by 35 inches tall ($3,900). Made by Provence et Fils in Gigean in the South of France, the furniture can be ordered in 14 custom color combinations at White on White, 888 Lexington Avenue (66th Street).

title: Investigating a Vote
description: The Justice Department has long been sensitive to the need to avoid putting a chill on voting activities in the course of investigating potential election-related crimes. The response to reports of a federal investigation into President Clinton's commutation of the sentences of four men, three of whom were from the village of New Square, N.Y., highlights the importance of preserving this principle.

title: Candidates for Governor Hold Fund-Raisers
description: New Jersey's two Republican rivals for governor held simultaneous fund-raisers on Tuesday night: an event in East Brunswick for Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco, and a New York City function for Bret D. Schundler.

description: A little puff of smoke went up over the Capitol the other night to signal: We have a president. His style holds the low key to the kingdom.

description: Walter A. Forbes, who built a small company into the huge Cendant Corporation, was an active participant in a fraud that resulted in the company's reporting more than $500 million in phony profits, the government charged yesterday.

description: Here in the heartland, where everything was supposed to be safe, the United States national soccer team lost two of its best offensive players to injuries early tonight.

description: President Bush today proposed a $1.96 trillion federal budget for next year that would cut taxes, increase spending on education, medical research and the military but scale back corporate subsidies, health care grants for poor areas, agricultural research and a host of other programs.

title: Bombay Journal; In Death, the Unlovely Vulture Is Sorely Missed
description: Up on Malabar Hill, in the midst of this teeming, polyglot metropolis, breezes off the Arabian Sea caress the bungalows of the rich and rustle into a 50-acre forest that has for centuries been the place where Parsis, followers of the ancient prophet Zoroaster, brought their dead to be devoured by vultures.

title: Second Clinton In-Law Says He Helped to Obtain Pardon
description: Former President Bill Clinton's brother-in-law Tony Rodham helped obtain a presidential pardon for a Tennessee couple last March over the objections of the Justice Department, Mr. Rodham and lawyers involved in the pardon said today.

title: Machinist Union at T.W.A. Objects to Merger With American
description: Complaining that American Airlines was not bargaining in good faith, the largest union at Trans World Airlines formally objected yesterday to a proposal by American to buy most of T.W.A.'s assets in bankruptcy court.

title: Report Tracks Crashes in City Involving Taxis and Livery Cabs
description: Taxis and livery cabs accounted for 16 percent of the automobile accidents that resulted in injuries in the city in 1999, according to a report by an independent consultant that was released yesterday.

title: Monument to the Filmless Future; In New Digital Arts Center, Hollywood Acknowledges Change
description: Robert Zemeckis made his way through the labyrinth of scaffolding and packing crates, steering clear of the ''Wet Paint'' signs and excusing himself as he passed through throngs of workers making the final touches on the Robert Zemeckis Center for Digital Arts at the University of Southern California. Outside, a tent was rising over the parking lot for the opening gala on Thursday evening.

title: China, Under Fire for Its Record, Ratifies Major U.N. Rights Pact
description: The government ratified an important United Nations human rights treaty today, even as its own rights record has continued to come under increasing international criticism and scrutiny.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IRVING, COLETTE GAY
description: IRVING-Colette Gay. Age 80. On February 26, 2001 at home in Southampton, New York. Wife of Alexander Duer Irving II. Mother of Alexandra I. Rush, Evelyn I. Leonard and Michael D.G. Irving. Sister of Anne G. Sharretts and grandmother of six grandchildren. A funeral service will be held at noon on Saturday, March 3, 2001 at St. John's Church in Southampton, New York. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Southampton Hospital.

title: BANK MERGER TALKS END
description: Abbey National broke off merger talks with the Bank of Scotland, citing the continued uncertainty posed by the Lloyds TSB Group, whose own takeover proposal for Abbey National is under investigation by British regulators. Abbey National has repeatedly rebuffed Lloyds advances, preferring instead to pursue a merger of equals with the Bank of Scotland. People close to Abbey National held open the possibility that discussions with the Bank of Scotland could resume should regulators block Lloyds from pursuing a deal. The collapse of the talks is a blow to the Bank of Scotland, which last year lost out to the Royal Bank of Scotland in its bid for the National Westminster Bank. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Making a Magic Kingdom
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Miscellany
description: * Creativeworks, St. Louis, opened an office in San Ramon, Calif., to be headed by two principals: Carol Dickinson, client services, and Sheldon Schachter, creative services.

title: ONLINE MANAGER ADDS CLIENTS
description: Participate.com, a Chicago company that manages online communities, said it had added four names to its client list. Three of the sites, AARP, Cummins and Mercury Interactive, are already active, while the company expects to have the fourth, Whirlpool, running by late 2001. They join a group that includes companies like Hewlett-Packard and Ace Hardware that helped Participate.com quadruple its revenue last year to $8.3 million. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

title: Helen R. Kaufman; Philanthropist, 84
description: Helen R. Kaufman, a philanthropist and community volunteer who was the widow of Irving R. Kaufman, a former chief judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York, died on Feb. 21 at her home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. She was 84.

title: Still With White Sox, Wells Awaits His Fate
description: Any day now, David Wells will learn if he will stay with the Chicago White Sox, or return to Toronto as the innocent bystander in the Mike Sirotka controversy and pitch for the Blue Jays again, or be sent elsewhere in yet another trade.

title: Metro Business Briefing; FLEETBOSTON TO SELL SUMMIT SITES
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation said on Tuesday that it would sell five Summit Bank branches in Atlantic County, N.J., to the Richmond County Financial Corporation to meet regulatory conditions for its acquisition of Summit Bancorp. FleetBoston won approval last month for its takeover of Summit. Richmond County, which owns Richmond County Savings Bank, said it would also buy two Fleet branches in Staten Island. Terms were not disclosed for either transaction. Richmond County owns First Savings Bank of New Jersey, Ironbound Bank and South Jersey Savings Bank.

title: Studios and Writers Guild Break Off Contract Talks
description: LOS ANGELES, March 1 - Negotiations broke down today between the Writers Guild of America and representatives of the leading Hollywood studios and television networks, making the prospect of a long-dreaded strike this summer much likely.

title: After Plane Crash, Deep Scars Change a Neighborhood
description: Kent Street, a crooked elbow of a street sandwiched between a cemetery and a faded commercial strip, was on the critical list well before a small plane crashed there in November 1999, killing all three people on the plane and a man on the ground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAWRY, SYLVIA
description: LAWRY-Sylvia. The Corinne Goldsmith Dickinson Center for Multiple Sclerosis at the Mount Sinai School of Medicine is deeply saddened by the passing of Sylvia Lawry. Mrs. Lawry was the undisputed leader and pioneer in thefight against multiple sclerosis. We shall all miss her greatly. Fred Lublin, Director George J. Gillespie, III and Clifford H. Goldsmith Co-Founders

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, SISTER MARIE.
description: WHITE-Sister Marie. A beloved member of the Sisters of Charity died Wednesday, February 28, 2001. Dear sister of Martin White. Also survived by her cousins. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY on Thursday from 1 to 8 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 9:30 A.M. at the convent with interment following at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, New York 10471

title: IRISH TOBACCO RESTRICTIONS
description: The Irish govern-ment announced wide-ranging plans for legislation to ban all tobacco advertising and sponsorship by the end of the year. The bill, to be presented to Parliament by June, will also propose raising the age for buying tobacco products from 16 to 18 and banning the sale of packets of 10 cigarettes and sales from vending machines. The health minister, Micheal Martin, said that smoking-related illnesses caused 7,000 deaths in Ireland each year. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: Challenger Says He's Set To Help Holyfield Retire
description: The challenger John Ruiz has waited patiently for his promotion to champion, believing that like any professional, Evander Holyfield must eventually parachute into his golden years and leave boxing to the next generation.

title: A 'Bat' Signal That Maps Whereabouts in a Networked Building
description: HARRY POTTER, the star of the children's book series, has a Marauder's Map, with tiny moving symbols that show the location of everyone in his school. It is very handy when he is out late at night solving mysteries and wants to avoid bumping into enemies.

title: Ambassador Tells of Embassy Bomb's Horror
description: There was carnage and rubble and smoke and blood, but Prudence Bushnell will always remember the rattling of a teacup.

title: Supreme Court Hears Case of Bible Study at Public School
description: The Supreme Court appeared generally sympathetic today to an evangelical group's argument that it had a constitutional right to offer Bible study and prayer as an after-school activity for young children on the same basis as any other activity held on the premises of an upstate New York public school.

title: Census Bureau Against Use of Adjusted 2000 Count
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  The Census Bureau today urged Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans not to adjust the 2000 population tally to make up for millions of uncounted Americans, effectively ending a contentious legal and political battle that had consequences for control of the House of Representatives after the 2002 elections.

title: ROBUST START FOR CHINA OIL
description: The China National Offshore Oil Corporation had a sparkling debut on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange, as its shares rose nearly 18 percent on their first day of trading. The company enjoyed a smaller opening-day bounce on the New York Stock Exchange. China National Offshore priced its shares last week, 17 months after the company had to cancel its first attempt at an initial public offering, partly because the price was too high. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Teaching Parents About Choices in Bilingual Policy May Be Tough, Educators Say
description: Educators who work with immigrant students are cautioning that the New York City Board of Education may have a hard time teaching parents about the choices they have to make now that the bilingual education system is being overhauled.

title: Sexual Violence as Tool of War: Pattern Emerging in East Timor
description: There is one happy thing one glorious thing -- in the shamed and broken life of Lorena Martins. Far from her family, hidden away from her neighbors, she lives in poverty in a tiny hillside house where the loud buzz of cicadas fills her loneliness.

title: A Desert In Bloom Is Worth the Wait
description: IT was all those warm rains in October, and then more at just the right time in February, that brought out the Mexican poppies, flowing like molten gold down this ancient volcanic mountain. Last week, the air smelled like incense from the brittlebush, whose mounds of soft gray-green leaves are covered with yellow daisy-like flowers, and the creosote, whose tiny gold flowers are just starting to open. Little rivers of sapphire-blue lupines meander along the paths.

title: Memo Feeds Concern That Exports to U.S. Help Burmese Junta
description: Myanmar, which has been governed by a military junta for more than a dozen years, is rapidly increasing apparel exports to the United States despite American economic sanctions.

title: Aides Say Clinton Ignored Pardon Advice
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Three senior advisers to President Bill Clinton told a House panel today that they had emphatically urged him to reject the pardon application submitted by lawyers for Marc Rich but had been overruled by Mr. Clinton, who decided to grant the pardon on his last night in office.

title: For TV and the Net, a Marriage Made in Vegas
description: FOR almost two years, KEEN-TV Channel 17, outside Las Vegas, was just another low-power television station broadcasting an unremarkable fare of old movies, public service announcements and local talk shows.

title: ROCHE'S PROFIT IS UP
description: Roche Holding of Switzerland said its profit increased 14 percent, to $3 billion last year. Its sales for the year were up 8 percent, at $16.4 billion, fueled by sales of its medical testing equipment, which were up 18 percent. Tests for detecting AIDS and hepatitis helped drive sales in contrast to stagnant results for drugs. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Nasdaq Stages Late-Day Recovery
description: Technology stocks rallied late today, leading a recovery across the market.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMATO, FULVIO ''JACK''
description: AMATO-Fulvio ''Jack''. 75. Passed away Thursday, February 15, 2001 in Houston, TX. Born in Brooklyn, NY to John and Fanny Amato, Mr. Amato was Vice President at Chemical Bank for 41 years. In his spare time he was actively involved in the Little League of Long Island, NY. He is survived by his wife Irene, son Robert Amato, M.D. and wife Patti; daughter Lenore Dweck and husband Sean; grandchildren Kyle, Zoe and Quinton and sisters Louise and Ardie.

title: Whitman Backs Clinton Rules Designed to Cut Diesel Pollution
description: The Bush administration has decided to let stand regulations imposed by President Bill Clinton that are intended to reduce substantially the pollution caused by diesel fuel and engines, officials said today.

title: Ex-City Adviser To Run Board At Daily News
description: The Daily News has appointed Richard J. Schwartz, a former aide to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani who then started a company that finds jobs for welfare recipients, as editorial-page editor.

title: John M. Gravitt, 61, a Pioneer In Lawsuits by Whistle-Blowers
description: John M. Gravitt, a former foreman for GE Aircraft Engines who made it easier for whistle-blowers and the federal government to win damages in fraud cases involving government contracts, died on Friday. Mr. Gravitt, who lived in Cincinnati, was 61.

title: The Timepiece for Those Who Long to Hear 'Play Ball'
description: There are a lot of useless gadgets out there, and no doubt some people would put the Game Time Schedule Watch in the same category. But with the opening day of the baseball season just around the corner, a watch that will display the schedule of your favorite baseball team is, for some people at least, almost a must-have.

title: His Perks and Power Gone, Clinton Faces Storm Alone
description: Bill Clinton walked into an AIDS fund-raiser at the Apollo Theater in Harlem the other night to a flicker of applause and recognition from the audience. His wife was in Washington, so Mr. Clinton's company for his night out consisted of Representative Charles B. Rangel of Harlem, the singer Roberta Flack, and a modest crew of Secret Service agents.

title: The Ups and Downs Of a Climate Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: The Return of Fuzzy Math
description: One day after outlining his lofty budget priorities to Congress, President Bush has delivered the decidedly down-to-earth numbers in the budget itself. They show more than ever that Mr. Bush's tax cut is to be financed by tapping revenues generated by Medicare, jeopardizing the future solvency of Social Security and cutting domestic spending programs. The precise cuts in housing, environment, job training, transportation, law enforcement and other areas were largely hidden even in Mr. Bush's budget, where they were blandly labeled as spending ''redirections.'' Congress must not accept this kind of assault on domestic spending in an era of surpluses. It will be up to moderate Republicans and Democrats in Congress to trim down Mr. Bush's tax cut to a reasonable size that does not distort the budget and introduce renewed risk of deficits if the surpluses are smaller than expected.

title: DUPONT TOLD TO PAY $12.3 MILLION FOR CHEMICAL DAMAGE
description: The DuPont Company must pay $12.3 million to an Ecuadorean shrimp-farming company because DuPont's Benlate fungicide damaged harvests, a jury in Florida said yesterday. The verdict stems from a lawsuit filed by Aquamar, the Ecuadorean company. Aquamar said that Benlate was used with other fungicides on banana plantations in Ecuador and that runoff from the combination poisoned shrimp. The ruling, in the 17th Judicial Circuit Court of Broward County in Hollywood, Fla., is the second verdict against DuPont, based in Wilmington, Del., in the issue in in the last three months. DuPont has paid about $1 billion to about 1,000 farms and nurseries that said the product had ruined their crops, plants and trees. Twenty-seven more cases brought by Ecuadorean shrimp farmers against DuPont await trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERGUSON, EDWARD M., JR.
description: FERGUSON-Edward M., Jr., DDS, 77, of WHB, died February 26, 2001, at Indian River Memorial Hospital, Vero Beach, Florida due to complications resulting from an auto accident. He was born July 8, 1923, in New Brunswick, New Jersey, lived in Massapequa and Westhampton Beach, New York. He moved to Vero Beach, Florida in 1998. He was a veteran of WWII, serving the US Army in Germany, graduated Holy Cross College in 1948, and NYU School of Dentistry in 1952. He had his dental practice in Massapequa from 1954 through 1998. He is survived by his loving wife of 47 years, Peggy, & children Ellen Finlayson (Fairfield, CT.), Edward M. Ferguson III (Los Angeles, CA), James M. Ferguson (Plainsboro, NJ), Anne Marie Bruno (Islip Terrace, NY), Charles M. Ferguson (Rockville Centre, NY), Frank M. Ferguson (Baldwin, NY), Margaret Rose Warren (New York, NY), John M. Ferguson (Westhampton Beach, NY), and eight grandchildren. Cherished brother of Sheila Thorpe and Jane Murphy. R.J. O'Shea Funeral Home, 94 E. Montauk Highway, Hampton Bays, Long Island. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday at 8:30 AM at Immaculate Conception R.C. Church, Westhampton Beach, N.Y. Interment Westhampton Cemetery. Family will receive friends Friday 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Van Gundy Gives Jackson Credit For Knicks' New Look on Offense
description: One of the Knicks' most impressive offensive performances this season went unnoticed Tuesday night amid the adulation for Patrick Ewing. Crisp ball movement, balanced scoring and frequent fast breaks marked the Knicks' 101-92 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: Venture in 401(k) Plans
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation has formed a partnership with Persumma Financial, a unit of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company that provides online 401(k) services. In a joint statement yesterday, the companies said the partnership would add a brokerage investment option to the Persumma 401(k), permitting participants to self-direct investments in individual securities through the Internet. Participants would also have access to Ameritrade's investment tools. The companies expect to start the service in the second quarter. Ameritrade is an online brokerage firm. Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance, doing business as MassMutual Financial Group, provides financial services.

title: Arturo Uslar Pietri, Novelist of Venezuela, Is Dead at 94
description: Arturo Uslar Pietri, a novelist and essayist whose literary career became enmeshed with modern Venezuelan politics, died on Monday at his home in Caracas. He was 94.

title: Landlord Is Charged With Arson and Murder
description: The owner of a Bedford-Stuyvesant brownstone where a ferocious fire killed a 13-year-old girl and injured 17 other people in July 2000 was charged yesterday with setting the fire to collect $435,000 in insurance money, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAVITZ, PHILIP B.
description: KRAVITZ-Philip B. Formerly of Great Neck, NY, resident of Tamarac, FL passed away February 26, 2001. Past Grand Chancellor of Knights of Pythias, past Mayor of Tamarac, past President of Great Neck Rotary Club, NY CPA for forty years, Professor of Accounting at Columbia University and Long Island University. Survived by beloved wife Dorothy, four loving children Eileen Brenner, Sharon Bloom, Gayle Hyams, Robyn Bennett, six grandchildren and two great-grandchildren.

title: PSION CANCELS SMARTPHONE PLAN
description: Under threat from the rival Palm and other hand-held computer makers, Britain's troubled Psion P.L.C., Europe's biggest palmtop manufacturer, canceled plans to build a smartphone combination of personal organizer and wireless telephone and said it would cut 100 jobs in a $16 million reorganization to offset losses and a probable fall in computer sales this year. Psion's stock fell 39 pence, to 115 pence. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Greenspan Says Tax Cuts and Retiring Debt Should Be Goals
description: WASHINGTON, March 2 - Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, reinforced his stance today that federal surpluses ought to be used to cut taxes. But he repeated his call for fiscal discipline, and he said lowering the national debt should also remain a goal.

title: More Tricks Up His Paw Than Just Rolling Over
description: The thing about dog movies is that they have a way of turning an audience into a bunch of arfing pooches. Not literally, of course. But fans of movies in which trusty intuitive dogs are a hundred times braver, smarter and more efficient than any human in getting the dirty job done (underline the word dirty) are the Hollywood laboratory equivalent of Pavlov's dogs.

title: Salary Cap Squeezes N.F.L.'s Big Names
description: A few years ago, Doug Flutie sat in his suburban Massachusetts home and said something that has always applied to his professional life. ''I don't know if anyone in the N.F.L. truly believes that I'm a good football player,'' he said. ''I'll always have to prove myself to N.F.L. teams, no matter how productive I am.''

title: Political Memo; Senator Clinton's New Plan Barely Whispers in the Din
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton took to the floor of the United States Senate this morning to unveil the first package of legislation she has authored in her young Congressional career: a wide-ranging plan to bolster the sagging economy of upstate New York.

title: An Opera Gig Of Her Own
description: Classical music fans know the Opera Orchestra of New York as an organization that provides the kind of opera they want but have a hard time finding elsewhere. For 30 years, two or three times a season, the conductor Eve Queler and her ensemble have presented concert performances of operas you might not have another chance to hear locally, from Meyerbeer's ''Huguenots'' (coming on April 23) to Wagner's ''Rienzi'' to plenty of lesser-known works by Donizetti (for example, ''La Favorita'' tonight and Wednesday, and the North American premiere of ''Marino Faliero'' next season).

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday tracing changes in the advertising industry over the last decade misstated magazine advertising revenue for 1990 and 2000. The 1990 figure was $6.9 billion (not $398.6 million), compared with $17.7 billion in 2000 (not $882.4 million).

title: Metro Business Briefing; HOME MORTGAGE FRAUD
description: Two more people have been charged with defrauding a federal home mortgage program by taking part in schemes that have left hundreds of brownstones in Harlem and Brooklyn facing foreclosure, the Manhattan district attorney's office said yesterday. Robert Dosch, 34, of Northport, N.Y., was accused in court documents of selling several brownstones in Brooklyn to a nonprofit organization in Midtown Manhattan called Homes for Families. The buildings were sold and then quickly resold at an inflated price -- a practice known as flipping -- under the 203(k) program, which is intended to foster homeownership in poor neighborhoods, officials said. The owner of Homes for Families, James Corbett, 32, formerly of Brooklyn, was accused of falsely claiming that the group bought the buildings with its own funds. The 203(k) program is available only to nonprofit groups and to buyers who intend to live in the homes. Both men have pleaded not guilty. Sixteen other people have also been arrested in the case. Terry Pristin

description: The governments of Azerbaijan, Georgia, Kazakhstan and Turkey signed a memorandum of understanding that will allow Kazakhstan's growing oil industry to participate in a 1,040-mile pipeline to be built from Baku, Azerbaijan, to Ceyhan on the Mediterranean coast of Turkey over the next three years. Analysts said the agreement made more viable the proposed one-million-barrel-a-day pipeline, favored by the United States over other proposed routes through Russia or Iran. A senior United States State Department officer, A. Elizabeth Jones, signed the agreement as a witness.

title: EMERY WORLDWIDE MAY BE FINED FOR SAFETY VIOLATIONS
description: The Emery Worldwide air-freight unit of CNF Inc. faces a possible $698,000 in fines proposed by the Federal Aviation Administration for safety violations. The civil penalties include $500,000 for 22 incidents in 1998 and 1999 in which the F.A.A. said Emery did not tell pilots they were carrying hazardous materials. A $105,000 fine was proposed over accusations of operating 13 flights in April 2000 without doing maintenance on an engine that failed in flight. The other $93,000 was for a suspected failure to follow a 1993 directive to replace a cockpit part. Emery has 30 days from receiving an F.A.A. notice to respond to the proposed fines.

description: Ben Stevenson, artistic director of the Houston Ballet for 25 years, has resigned from the post. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKWOOD, W. CARTER
description: LOCKWOOD-W. Carter. 79, beloved husband of May Louise (Lou) Lockwood of Lake Placid, died at the Adirondack Medical Center on February 27, 2001. Carter was born on July 20, 1921 in Washington D. C., the son of H. Winthrop and Mary Carter Mullikin Lockwood. He attended Dartmouth College class of 1945 before serving in the U.S. Army Air Corps. In 1965 they moved to Lake Placid and Carter became bursar of Northwood School. During the 1980 Winter Olympics, he served as Assistant Chief of Protocol. He was a former member of the Pine Valley Golf Club and the Lake Placid Club and at the time of his death belonged to the Ponte Vedra Club and the Marsh Landing Country Club both in Ponte Vedra Beach, FL. Besides his wife, Carter is survived by a brother Thomas Lockwood of Vero Beach, FL; three sons, Winthrop of Breckenridge, CO, Todd of Burlington, VT, and David of Manchester, NH; a son-in-law, Brownell Bailey of Denver, CO, and eleven grandchildren. A son, Herbert died in 1987 and a daughter, Frances Bailey died in 1989. A funeral service will be held Saturday, March 10, 2001 at 11:00 AM at St. Eustace Church in Lake Placid. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts may be sent to the W. Carter Lockwood Fund at the Adirondack Medical Center, Saranac Lake, NY 12983 or the Lake Placid Sinfonietta, PO Box 1303 Lake Placid 12946. For more information contact the Clark Funeral Home, Lake Placid.

title: Ex-Miss Florida Caught in a Time Warp
description: One reason initially promising plays often go wrong in the second act is that they seem to be constructed back to front: concluding events and the characters' fates are the first things fixed in the playwright's mind. As a result, the beginning of the play is devoted to establishing characters who, if they're well drawn, imply infinite possibilities for action but as the play proceeds are increasingly held hostage to the predetermined plot.

title: Taking Reality Shows to Their Ultimate Unreality
description: Trapped in a world that has to generate ratings, the cast members of a television series called ''The Contenders'' are the subject of the fake-umentary ''Series 7,'' Dan Minahan's glib and bleak comic take on reality shows. It's a treacherous path Mr. Minahan has taken; he is satirizing shows that many laugh at anyway, even while finding them compelling no-frills viewing. The target is so big that all he can do is strike glancing blows that don't mean much. The movie feels facile and blunt spirited.

title: KANA CUTS WORK FORCE
description: Kana Communications, a maker of customer relations management software, said yesterday that it had laid off 220 employees, or 20 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to cut expenses by $30 million to $40 million a year. The company said it was consolidating product development, revising its sales compensation structure and selling property. Jay Wood, its chief executive, said he would bring the company's staffing and structure into line with industry standards. Companies that develop the software that businesses use to manage customers have been badly hurt in the recent market downturn. Kana's stock, which once traded as high as $175 a share, rose 16 cents after the news, to close at $3.22. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Kosovo's Lawless Border
description: NATO is taking a realistic approach to a difficult problem along the border between Kosovo and Serbia. For months, armed Albanian separatists have exploited a three-mile-wide demilitarized zone on the Serbian side of the border as a staging area for attacks on Serbian police and civilians. Now NATO is prepared to start phasing out the zone, letting Serbian troops gradually return. But NATO rightly insists that Belgrade first carry out a set of political and military conditions designed to protect the rights of ethnic Albanian civilians living in the troubled border area. During his stopover in Brussels this week, Secretary of State Colin Powell expressed American approval ''in principle'' for this approach.

title: The Puget Sound Earthquake
description: By almost any standard, Seattle, Tacoma and the rest of northwest Washington escaped Wednesday's earthquake with damage that was only a fraction of what it might have been. This earthquake originated some 30 miles below the surface near Olympia, and its depth seems to have mitigated the force suggested by its magnitude, 6.8. Brick facades crumbled in older sections of Seattle, but the city's largest buildings rode out the shock as they were designed to do. Perhaps the most significant casualty over all was psychological, for what this earthquake brought home to the Puget Sound region was its seismic vulnerability, which is on a par with California's but which has only crept into consciousness during the past decade.

title: An Art Form Contemplates Its Navel With Extended Amusement

Artists have been investigating the nature of their medium in general at least since the French painter Maurice Denis wrote in 1890 that ''a picture -- before being a war horse, a nude woman or some sort of anecdote -- is essentially a surface covered with colors arranged in a certain order.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLATZER, HENRIETTE
description: GLATZER-Henriette. The American Group Psychotherapy Association mourns the passing of Dr. Henriette Glatzer, one of its most esteemed members. A former President and Distinguished Fellow of the Association, she was the first woman and the first psychologist to serve as its chief elected officer. Her seminal scholarly achievements contributed enorously to the advancement of the theory and practice of group psychotherapy. She will be sorely missed.

title: Album of the Week

When the band started in Japan in the early 1980's, it made music without a moment's peace: all shrieking vocals, clashing guitars and jerky tempo changes, an onslaught of brawny discontinuity. But on recent albums it has discovered the pleasures of sustained textures and hypnotic repetition.

The snowfall was thick, the winds piercing. To one side was a yawning plunge. The eight families that had crowded into the vehicle's open flatbed thought it better to climb out and sleep on the wet ground than chance a mortal slide over the edge.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SECURITY CHIEF NAMED
description: Bear Stearns announced yesterday that it had hired Raymond Kelly, the former New York City police commissioner and federal customs commissioner, to oversee global security. Mr. Kelly, left, began working yesterday in the newly created position, with supervision over everything from security guards to computer networks. Mr. Kelly, 59, was the commissioner of the Customs Service until Jan. 19, the day before President Bush was sworn in. He was New York's police commissioner under Mayor David N. Dinkins from August 1992 until January 1994, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appointed William J. Bratton to the position. Mr. Bratton, who was in town yesterday at the Silicon Alley 2001 conference at the Manhattan Pavilion discussing the threat of global terrorism involving the use of computers and information technology, is the president of his own New York City consulting firm. Wade, died yesterday at an assisted-living center in Dallas. He was 86.

title: U.S. Finds That Coca Cultivation Is Shifting Sharply to Colombia
description: Six years of intense American-backed antinarcotics efforts in South America have redrawn drug-trafficking patterns, but have failed to stem a yearly increase in the amount of coca being grown, the State Department reported today.

title: Bomb Explodes in Van, Killing Man in Israel
description: A taxi van exploded in northern Israel today after the police stopped it at a roadblock during a search for a terror suspect. As officers were checking passengers' identification cards, a bomb aboard was detonated, killing a man and wounding nine other people.

title: Innovative Designers Are Challenging Traditions : Spain's Stylish New Buzz
description: MADRID  Fashion has never been so hot in the Iberian Peninsula. From the glamour of Penelope Cruz through the noble tailoring of Miguel Adrover, Spanish has become an international fashion language.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRICKMAN, ALICE
description: BRICKMAN-Alice. 73, of Long Boat Key, Florida and Franklin Lakes, New Jersey. Died February 27, 2001. Alice was born September 9, 1927 in Brooklyn, New York. She was a graduate of New York University, and devoted her life to her family, friends and many philanthropic endeavors. Alice was a friend, companion and wife of Ed Brickman for 55 years. She was a loving wife, mother and grandmother and is survived by her husband Ed; her daughter Carol; her sons Alan, Ira and Eli; and her grandsons Joshua, David, Jesse, Robert and Eric. Funeral services will be held March 4, 2001, Sunday, 10:30 AM at Robert Schoem's Menorah Chapel, W-150 Rt. #

description: POHL-Henry. Of Scarsdale, NY on March 1, 2001. Dear husband of Elinor. Loving father of Jeffrey (Mara), Cathy (David), Alice (Christopher). Grandfather of Barbara, Martin, Rachel, Matthew, Emily and Sarah. Funeral services will be conducted privately. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions to the charity of your choice.

title: Oracle Says Earnings Won't Meet Forecasts
description: Executives at the Oracle Corporation, caught by surprise in the last week as one corporate customer after another delayed software orders, said yesterday that profits for the most recent quarter would fall short of expectations.

title: Combs Gives Little Ground on the Stand, and Defense Rests
description: The hip-hop mogul Sean Combs remained cool and ceded little ground during three hours of cross-examination yesterday, testifying in a packed courtroom that he did not have a gun during a Manhattan nightclub shooting on Dec. 27, 1999, and never offered his driver money to claim a gun recovered by the police as his own.

title: Residential Real Estate; New Rochelle Skyline Now Has a Skyscraper
description: From almost any vantage point in New Rochelle, N.Y., the new apartment building almost complete at 255 Huguenot Street stands tall, its 25 stories slicing into the horizon, visible everywhere.

title: Reuniting the Pieces of a Cathedral's Golden Past
description: If I had to name my favorite shows of the New York season so far, ''The Treasury of Basel Cathedral'' at the Metropolitan Museum of Art would come high on a short list. Its jewel-embellished gold and silver objects exist on some exotic outer fringe of beauty, where the crass and the ineffable meet. Together they have a cliffhanger of a tale to tell, as frustrating as it is uplifting. There is the rarity factor: almost none of the 75 works on view have visited the United States before. And I can't remember the last time I experienced anything quite like their single-minded incandescence in a local museum.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, MARION
description: GREENSTEIN - Marion, died peacefully on February 25 at home of Cancer, age 71. Devoted wife to late husband Jack. Beloved mother of Nina and David. Loving grandmother of Spencer, Harry and Jessie. We will always remember her abounding energy, enthusiasm and zest for living a full life. Memorial service Sunday, March 4, at 1:15 P.M., Central Synagogue, 123 E. 55 St, NYC. In lieu of flowers donations to: Hospice of Wake County, 919-828-0890.

description: Snubbing the Bank of Japan and the interest rate cut it announced yesterday, investors hammered Japanese stocks downward again today, with the benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index falling 1.57 percent, to 12,681.66, its lowest close in more than 15 years.

title: Pentagon Unveils Plans for a New Crowd-Dispersal Weapon
description: The Pentagon today unveiled what some military officials hope will become the rubber bullet of the 21st century: a weapon that uses electromagnetic waves to disperse crowds without killing, maiming or, military officials say, even injuring anyone slightly.

title: 'Sopranos': Blood, Bullets And Proust
description: THERE are exploding garbage trucks in the new season of ''The Sopranos,'' as well as an image of Tony lying on his kitchen floor in a puddle of blood. There are clips from the classic gangster movie ''The Public Enemy'' and a reference to a piece of capicola as Tony's Proustian madeleine, evoking memories of his boyhood introduction to violence. And there is a wake that is vicious, funny and finally sad in its heartbreaking honesty.

title: Paul D. Paganucci -- Dartmouth Official, 69
description: Paul D. Paganucci, a former vice president of Dartmouth College, died on Monday at his home in Hanover, N.H. He was 69. The cause of death was cancer, said his wife, Marilyn.

title: The S.E.C. Accuses 23 of Internet Fraud
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused 23 companies and individuals today of fraudulently using the Internet to pump up stock prices by more than $300 million and to raise $2.5 million from investors.

title: KAYDON BUYS ACE CONTROLS FOR $70 MILLION
description: The Kaydon Corporation, a maker of bearings, filtration products and seals, said yesterday that it acquired ACE Controls Inc. and ACE Controls International Inc., makers of industrial shock absorbers and valves, for about $70 million. The ACE companies, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., have more than $40 million in annual sales, Kaydon said. The deal will help Kaydon, based in Ann Arbor, Mich., diversify product lines. Kaydon makes engineered products for industrial, aerospace, medical and electronic equipment.

title: ATI TECHNOLOGIES SAYS DEMAND IS WEAK
description: ATI Technologies said its fiscal second-quarter sales would be less than forecast in January and its loss wider than expected because of slow computer sales and higher costs for memory chips. ATI, which makes graphics parts for computers, said in a statement that sales in the period that ended Wednesday were about $230 million. That brought its loss for the quarter, excluding acquisition-related costs, to 11 to 13 cents a share. ATI stock fell $1.03, or 19.6 percent, to $4.22.

title: Bush Leads Cheers And Avoids Criticism
description: Although President Bush's budget plan and proposed tax cut are certain to foster vigorous debate over the coming weeks, his two-day, five-state tour to promote them steered clear of tough questions.

title: Mideast Strife Spills Over Into Photo Contest
description: In the middle of all the despair over the great issues troubling the Middle East, supporters of Israel and the Palestinians are slugging it out on the Internet over the outcome of a little-known photo contest that includes a picture of a Palestinian boy huddling by his father moments before the boy was killed.

title: Banker Told to Submit Records
description: A federal judge has ordered the chairman of the Bank of New York Company, Thomas A. Renyi, to surrender telephone records, tax returns and credit card statements in a lawsuit by shareholders that accuses him and 18 other officials of roles in a money laundering scheme.

title: An Island Trio
description: In ''The Widow of St. Pierre,'' a stirring new film by the French director Patrice Leconte, Juliette Binoche, below, plays the enigmatic wife of the captain of a garrison on a windswept island off Canada. The arrival of a condemned man sparks a complex mix of emotions.

title: E.D.S. WINS CONTRACTS VALUED AT $350 MILLION
description: The Electronic Data Systems Corporation, a computer-services provider, said yesterday that it won about $350 million in contracts from an Australian telecommunications company and two Canadian railways. E.D.S. signed a five-year, $300 million contract to provide software maintenance for the Telstra Corporation of Australia. The company said it also signed a contract with the Canadian Pacific Railway, and extended one for three years with the Canadian National Railway Company. Terms of the railway contracts were not disclosed.

title: HEINEKEN INTERESTED IN BASS
description: The chief executive of Heineken N.V., Karel Vuursteen, reiterated an interest in bidding for the Bass Brewers unit that British regulators have ordered Interbrew N.V. to sell. The comments were delivered as Heineken reported that its net income for 2000 jumped a greater-than-expected 20 percent to 612 million euros ($565 million), compared with 516 million euros last year. Revenue grew 13 percent to 8.1 billion euros, compared with 7.1 billion euros a year earlier, driven by strong demand for Heineken and Amstel Light in the United States and last year's acquisition of Cruzcampo in Spain. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

description: Attorney General John Ashcroft urged Congress today to take up legislation that would end racial profiling, in which law enforcement officials consider a person's race or ethnicity in making traffic stops and conducting searches or other investigations.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO GAINS. The euro rose after reports showed manufacturing expanded in Europe last month and contracted in the United States. In New York, the euro settled at 93.17 cents, up from 92.41 cents on Wednesday.

title: Ending Curbs on Legal Services
description: In an important ruling upholding free speech rights under the First Amendment, the Supreme Court this week overturned a pernicious law passed by Congressional Republicans to handcuff and muzzle the lawyers who represent poor people in civil cases under the federally financed Legal Services program. By a 5-to-4 vote the court ruled that Congress violated the First Amendment in 1996 when it restricted the kinds of arguments that Legal Services lawyers may make on behalf of welfare clients. The restrictions were imposed as part of a compromise after Congressional Republicans came perilously close to eliminating the Legal Services program altogether.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report by The Associated Press on Dec. 24 about lawsuits over the cleanup of pollution at the Summitville mine in southern Colorado misstated terms of a settlement. The news agency reported on Wednesday that Robert Friedland, a Canadian businessman and a shareholder in the mine, agreed to pay $27.75 million in cash over 10 years, not $30 million. Part of the settlement is to be used for restoration of the Alamosa River system, not for victims of pollution.

description: A bus strike in Westchester County that affected about 50,000 riders was temporarily called off last night after one day, county officials said.

description: I'm not the only one who likes to watch ducks in winter. David Allen Sibley does, too, although our interests aren't exactly the same. I like ducks partly because I can't identify little birds. They're too fast, they won't sit still, and no matter how much I pore over the guidebooks, I always conclude that I'm looking at a sparrow.

description: After canceling nearly 130 flights to and from Kennedy International Airport Wednesday and yesterday morning, American Airlines said it had to scrap about 40 more yesterday afternoon as its mechanics resumed a work slowdown that the airline thought had ended by noon.

title: Internet Sale Yielded Clues In Slayings Of Professors
description: The authorities admit they are still stumped about a motive, but partial documents unsealed in New Hampshire today disclosed pivotal clues that led them to the Vermont teenagers charged with the killings of two Dartmouth professors. One of the teenagers recently purchased two knives on the Internet, the documents said, and his fingerprints matched some found in the professors' house.

title: KOZMO DROPS DOT-COM
description: Officials at Kozmo.com, the online World Wide Web delivery company, said yesterday that it removed the dot-com from its name last week. The company will officially remain Kozmo.com, but will do business under the name Kozmo. Last week, the privately held Kozmo, which started as an online delivery service in Manhattan and now operates in nine markets, said it would focus more on its telephone business and begin a paper catalog that would be sent to four million households. In December, Kozmo was profitable in New York, San Francisco and Boston. Also yesterday, an executive close to Kozmo said that several delivery people and office workers had been dismissed from the company's 50-employee Portland, Ore., office. Matthew Higgins, a spokesman for Kozmo, declined to comment on any changes in Portland except to say, ''We continually refine our operational staff levels either up or down.''

title: Technology Briefing
description: SOFTWARE KANA CUTS WORK FORCE Kana Communications , a maker of customer relations management software, said yesterday that it had laid off 220 employees, or 20 percent of its work force, as part of a plan to cut expenses by $30 million to $40 million a year. The company said it was consolidating product development, revising its sales compensation structure and selling property. Jay Wood, its chief executive, said he would bring the company's staffing and structure into line with industry standards. Companies that develop the software that businesses use to manage customers have been badly hurt in the recent market downturn. Kana's stock, which once traded as high as $175 a share, rose 16 cents after the news, to close at $3.22. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

description: Kerry Collins went to Hawaii in the days after the Super Bowl and avoided newsstands, the television and places where football might be a topic of conversation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRITCHLOW, MARY ELLEN
description: CRITCHLOW-Mary Ellen. Of Brooklyn Heights, NY, died on Tuesday, February 27, 2001, at NYU Medical Center in New York City after a brief illness. Born on October 27, 1947, in Saratoga Springs, NY, she was the daughter of Katharine B. Donnelly of Queensbury and the late John J. Donnelly. She was a 1969 graduate of the College of New Rochelle, after which she taught school at St. Gregory's School For Boys in the Albany area. In 1974 she received an M.A. in English Literature from Georgetown University in Washington, D.C., where she thereafter resided for the next six years, working for Haley, Bader & Potts, a communications law firm. In 1980 she was married to Charles H. Critchlow, a New York Attorney, and moved to Brooklyn Heights. During her two decades in Brooklyn Heights, Mrs. Critchlow was active in a number of community organizations including the Heights and Hill Community Council, a group serving the needs of Senior Citizens, where she served as President for several years and was a member of the Board. She was an active and sustaining member of the Junior League of Brooklyn and honored by them as Sustainer of the Year in 1997. She was a communicant at the Oratory Church of St. Boniface, where she taught Sunday School and, in more recent years, also attended services at Assumption Parish. Besides her mother and husband, Mrs. Critchlow is survived by two daughters, Katharine and Mary Elizabeth, both of Brooklyn Heights, and a brother, Frank N. Donnelly, his wife Karen and their sons John and Gregory, all of Atlanta, GA. A Mass of Christian Burial will be conducted at 10 AM on Monday, March 5, 2001, at St. Boniface on Duffield St, in Downtown Brooklyn. The wake will be held at the church on Sunday, March 4, from 7-9 PM. For further information please contact Jere J. Cronin Inc, 718-624-1398. Contributions in Mary Ellen Critchlow's memory may be made to Heights & Hill Community Council, 160 Montague St, Brooklyn, NY 11201 or to The Brain Tumor Foundation, 1350 Avenue of the Americas, Suite 1200, New York, New York 10019.

title: Rise Expected In Retirements By Teachers
description: As many as 7,000 New York City schoolteachers might retire between now and the end of the year, representing the largest single-year exodus in 10 years, the president of the teachers' union said yesterday.

It is R. H. Macy & Company, not W. H. Macy's.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Safety; Don't Touch That Dial: Even a Radio Distracts
description: AUTO safety experts and lawmakers are increasingly talking about the hazards of driving while using a cellular phone, but a survey by the AAA Foundation for Traffic Safety suggests that drivers do not really need phones to be distracted. The car's radio may be enough.

title: Tenor Withdraws From Met 'Nabucco'
description: Fabio Armiliato, the Italian tenor who was to sing the role of Ismaele in the Metropolitan Opera's new production of Verdi's ''Nabucco,'' opening Thursday, has withdrawn from the production, the Met said yesterday. Mr. Armiliato withdrew for personal reasons, a Met spokesman said. The tenor Francisco Casanova is to sing the role on opening night and on March 12, 16, 20 and 24. Gwyn Hughes Jones, from Wales, is to make his Met debut in the role on March 28 and sing the final performances, on March 31 and April 3 and 6.

title: On Party Lines, Panel Approves Lower Tax Rate
description: Voting along party lines, the House Ways and Means Committee approved the heart of President Bush's tax cut plan today and set up a vote in the full House next week.

title: Fuel Prices Rise and Business Slows in Turkish Crisis
description: Cihan Eroglu spends his days winding deftly through the erratic maze of Istanbul traffic on his motorbike for a courier service. On a good day he can earn $80, but these are not good days.

title: Hermann Field -- Wartime Prisoner and Novelist, 90
description: Hermann Field, who was imprisoned for five years by Communist authorities in Poland and who wrote two novels with his cellmate before his release in 1954, died on Feb. 23 at his home in Shirley, Mass. He was 90.

title: CORNING CUTS JOBS AFTER DEMAND SLUMPS
description: The large fiber optic cable maker Corning said it had laid off 825 employees from manufacturing centers in New York and Pennsylvania. The plants make equipment for optical communications networks. The company attributed the cuts to decreased customer demand in telecommunications. A Corning spokesman, Paul Rogoski, said there might be more job cuts, ''but nothing's on the boards right now.'' The layoffs came just two weeks after revenue growth projections for the division involved were cut to 50 percent from as much as 90 percent; last year's revenue was about $1 billion. Elizabeth Stanton (NYT)

description: Prosecutors argued today that the trial of Michael C. Skakel, who is charged with murder in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley, should be moved from Stamford to Bridgeport, a change that could widen the pool of potential jurors.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLARKE, RUTH HERZOG
description: CLARKE-Ruth Herzog. Died on February 27, 2001 at the age of 82 at Venice, Florida. She was born in New York City and lived and worked there before moving to Silver Spring, Maryland and Venice, Florida. She graduated from Hunter College and Katherine Gibbs School in New York City, working many years for BristolMyers Squibb Company before taking over her family's chauffeured limousine service, Herzog Cadillac Rental Service in New York City. She retired in 1988. She was an honorary member of the Madison Golf Club, Madison, New Jersey, active member of the Metropolitan Club, New York City, Columbia Country Club, Chevy Chase, Maryland, the Plantation Golf and Country Club and the Yacht Club in Venice, Florida. Survivors include her husband William H. Clarke of Silver Spring, Maryland and Venice, Florida and six step-children. Burial and services will be in Madison, NJ.

title: Stun-Gun Reality, Magnificent In Its Artifice
description: ANDREAS GURSKY'S giant photographs are so eye-poppingly gorgeous that in this world, where no good turn goes unpunished, even admirers feel compelled to react with suspicion and reserve. Anything so seductive, so automatically appealing to collectors, so skillfully altered via computer, as some of Mr. Gursky's photographs are to enhance their cinematic irresistibility, must be at least untrustworthy.

title: RAILWORKS GAINS 7 CONTRACTS WORTH $100 MILLION
description: The RailWorks Corporation said yesterday that it won seven contracts valued at a total of more than $100 million and completed the sale of a subsidiary, as the rail maintenance and equipment supplier seeks to rebound from a fourth-quarter loss. The contracts include electrical and mechanical work on transit projects in New York, Denver and Vancouver, British Columbia, as well as making railroad ties for United States and Mexican carriers. RailWorks, which is based in Baltimore, also sold FCM Rail to Dennis Gilstad, the former owner of a Detroit-based equipment-leasing unit. The price was not disclosed. The sale will let Railworks cut debt as much as $17 million, its chief executive, John Larkin, said.

title: GOOD GUYS TO LAY OFF WORKERS AND MOVE HEADQUARTERS
description: Good Guys Inc., an operator of consumer electronics stores in the West, said yesterday that it would lay off 450 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, and move its headquarters to cut costs. The job cuts include 125 sales and 300 sales-support positions. An additional 25 workers were laid off from its San Francisco-area headquarters, distribution and call centers. Good Guys will move its headquarters to the East Bay of San Francisco from Brisbane, Calif., a move that will reduce real estate costs by 50 percent.

description: Do the Right Thing' isn't the movie to end all movies about race relations," Spike Lee said the other day. Probably not, but almost 12 years after it was made his film still stands as one of the most vivid on the subject. For proof, one need only explore a first-rate new DVD special edition from the Criterion Collection .

Church, Pearl River, NY. Visiting will be held Saturday and Sunday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at the Wyman-Fisher Funeral Home Inc., 100 Franklin Ave., Pearl River, NY.

title: COCA-COLA EXPECTED TO REGAIN CONCESSION CONTRACT
description: Recapturing the contract that it lost 10 years ago, the Coca-Cola Company is expected to announce today that it has reached an agreement to become the exclusive soft drink of the nation's largest airports. Coke forged the deal, worth an estimated $35 million, with HMSHost, the company that runs the concession stands and restaurants at 60 airports in North America, including 18 of the 20 largest ones. Many of the Starbucks, Burger Kings and other franchise restaurants in airports from Miami to Chicago are operated by the company, formerly part of the Host Marriott Corporation, and they have been serving Pepsi for a decade.

title: A Fleet Of Boys' Daydreams
description: The deindustrialization of America in the late 20th century has given birth to a new field, industrial archaeology. The National Park Service, for example, is trying to identify, evaluate and preserve some of the country's important industrial artifacts: major factories and mills that are no longer in use.

title: Review/Fashion; The Mod Squad Saunters Back
description: Miuccia Prada, that most restless of designers, sent the fall 2001 season into a delicious panic today by skipping back to the era of felt crash helmets and high-waisted granny dresses. Could it be that the 1960's are upon us again?

title: 'Right Thing' On Special DVD
description: '' 'Do the Right Thing' isn't the movie to end all movies about race relations,'' Spike Lee said the other day. Probably not, but almost 12 years after it was made his film still stands as one of the most vivid on the subject. For proof, one need only explore a first-rate new DVD special edition from the Criterion Collection.

title: Ariel G. Loewy, 75, Expert On Biology of Blood Clotting
description: Ariel G. Loewy, a cell biologist who helped unravel the process of blood clotting, died on Feb. 13 at Bryn Mawr Hospital in Pennsylvania. He was 75.

description: After two weeks of public wrangling, Christopher Lydon, the host of ''The Connection,'' a public radio program with 400,000 listeners around the country, parted ways yesterday with WBUR, the Boston radio station that owns the program.

description: Four Brooklyn court employees were indicted yesterday on charges that they passed along criminal background checks to research companies in return for more than $1 million in payments, officials said.

title: A Man for Every Season and Just About Any Reason
description: When we first meet Darlene (Regina Cas), she is visibly pregnant and preparing to leave her home in a poor, dusty corner of Northeastern Brazil. ''God prevent your having a daughter,'' her mother says by way of farewell. Three years later Darlene returns home on the day of her mother's death, carrying her young son Dimas, the first of four she will bear, each with a different father, by the end of ''Me You Them.''

description: When the Electronic Privacy Information Center, an advocacy group based in Washington that loudly campaigns for Internet privacy and civil liberties, announced it had received a $1 million gift a few weeks ago, the money didn't come from a large corporation or private foundation. It came from someone who usually receives grants -- a law school professor.

title: J. P. MORGAN CHASE BUYS ADVANTA MORTGAGE UNIT
description: The Advanta Corporation, a provider of credit cards and insurance products, said yesterday that it completed the sale of its below-prime mortgage business to J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, the nation's leading residential lender, for more than $1 billion. Advanta, based in Spring House, Pa., said the sale converted a ''substantial amount'' of its book value to cash. Advanta said it would now focus on its more profitable business credit card division.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUPFERBERG, HERBERT
description: KUPFERBERG-Herbert. January 20, 1918-February 22, 2001. Senior Editor of Parade; lively Arts Editor of New York Herald Tribune; Overseas Press Club President; author of many books on music. Contributions to Friends of Mozart.

description: NAPLES  People here may drive fast, talk fast, think fast. Yet when it comes to clothes, Neapolitans know how to take their time.

description: The government made a swift retreat today from what had appeared to be a decision by President Kim Dae Jung to support President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in opposing the missile defense program backed by President George W. Bush.
