description: President Frederick Chiluba of Zambia came to power almost 10 years ago, unseating Kenneth Kaunda, who led the country out of colonial rule and stayed in office almost three decades.

title: ITALIAN FASHION: Many Yarns Spin a Revival in Calabria
description: CAULONIA, Italy  Dipped into the Ionian Sea on one side, and the Tyrrhenian on the other, the wild mountainous region of Calabria has long been sidestepped by development. Communication  and cooperative activities  are often difficult.

title: At 'Hannibal,' the First Attack Is in the Crowd
description: The dozen people in the audience for the 9 o'clock show at the Crown Majestic Theater on Wednesday night had paid to be frightened by Dr. Hannibal Lecter. Instead, they got Michael O'Niel.

title: Rangers' Difficult Task Is Now Doubly Tough
description: It was a quiet, relatively short practice for the Rangers at Rye Playland today, with no new devastating news to contemplate. But there was a trade, as the Rangers continued to try to salvage a season that has taken one blow after another.

title: Drawing Nigh: Votes for Oscar
description: Now comes crunch time for the Academy Awards. The nominations were announced on Feb. 13, and everybody has had a chance to digest them, rate the competition and build a strategy. Over the next week the official ballots will go out to the 5,600 members of the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences. If common wisdom holds true, the bulk of them will be filled out and returned to the academy within 10 days. So if filmmakers want to maneuver or make their case, either on behalf of their own films or to discredit a competitor, they will need to do it quickly.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Anyone who thinks Astoria is Greek needs to take a refresher course. Greek tavernas and pastry shops still dominate the neighborhood, especially near Ditmars Boulevard, but the rapidly changing ethnic mix that defines Queens has altered even this suburb of Athens. On the long block of Steinway Street that runs north from 30th Avenue, Egyptian and Moroccan immigrants have staked their claims, opening coffee shops, specialty food stores, pastry shops and restaurants. In the evenings a thick, sweet cloud of hookah smoke hangs in the air.

title: He's Homeless and Hears Voices, but He's Still a Hero
description: ''The Caveman's Valentine'' is a mystery with a twist. Its hero is the unhinged homeless Romulus (Samuel L. Jackson), a paranoid schizophrenic. He is thrust into trying to figure out what has happened to a missing friend who turns out to have been murdered, and he can't get anyone to believe the evidence he has found. That includes his daughter, Lulu (Aunjanue Ellis), one of New York's finest, who hangs her head in shame whenever he comes into view. ''The Caveman's Valentine'' features the ultimate unreliable narrator.

title: Sports of The Times; Fassel's Finished Basement
description: ON a Saturday morning during the football season, Jim Fassel is usually at Giants Stadium, but one week when the Giants had a bye, the coach was sitting in his kitchen. Suddenly he squinted, looked around and turned to his wife, Kitty.

title: Juries, Their Powers Under Siege, Find Their Role Is Being Eroded
description: The role of the American jury, the central vehicle for citizen participation in the legal system, is being sharply limited by new laws, court rulings and a legal culture that is moving away from trials as a method of resolving disputes.

title: Putin Heads Home, Having Left Modest Imprint on Asia
description: HANOI, March 2  After paying his respects to the embalmed body of Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam's revolutionary hero, Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin left for home today showing some satisfaction that he had re-established Russia as a player in Asia.

title: Bump-and-Run Rule Is Dropped
description: The XFL said yesterday that it was dropping its bump-and-run rule, which it instituted to add more hitting to its games, to inject more offense to its increasingly low-scoring games.

description: MELI-Theresa and Joseph. To my dear Mother and Dad, this year 2001, I celebrate your 100th birthdays and today, Happy 100th to you, dear Mother. You are always in my thoughts and with everlasting love in my heart. Miss you both. Lovingly remembered. Your son, Joey

Although not all of these 12 restaurants are strictly vegetarian, they reflect the variety of rewarding tastes that can be found in this fare. title: Wright Keeps Hofstra Winning
description: It was during a lull in basketball practice in the Hofstra University Arena on a recent morning. The men's head basketball coach, Jay Wright, stood beside a boy who had just hoisted a 15-foot shot at a side basket and swished it. The coach, in blue baseball cap and sweats, then pulled the 4-foot-6-inch youngster to him, stooped and kissed him on top of the head.

Hours later, the Nasdaq bosses sprang to life and made decisions that cost some traders lots of money but helped the very person whose error started the mess.

title: Corrections

It is all temperatures below -389 degrees (that is, minus 389) Fahrenheit, not 389.

title: Marc Rich Is Sent $137 Million New York Tax Bill
description: New York State moved yesterday to collect $137.8 million in state and city income taxes from the billionaire financier Marc Rich, saying his pardon by President Bill Clinton cleared the way for the state to pursue a two-decade-old debt, which is accumulating $20,000 in daily interest surcharges.

title: Flitting Through Dreams Of a Writer of the Occult
description: The prolific science fiction writer Philip K. Dick once called a story ''I Can Dream It for You Wholesale,'' which was eventually made into a film that bore the most minimal of resemblances to it: ''Total Recall.'' ''The Gospel According to Philip K. Dick,'' an affectionate and prosaic documentary on Dick's life and contributions, might as well be called ''I Can Dream It for You Cut-Rate.''

title: Once Again, Binoche Battling Provincials
description: The French director Patrice Leconte is a filmmaker with talent to burn, and often he has been content to do just that. His movies, which run the gamut from sex comedy (''Les Bronzs'') to psychodrama (''Monsieur Hire'') to costume pageant (''Ridicule''), glow with a suave, adaptable incandescence that often provides more dazzle than illumination. They have a tendency to look better than they actually are, like last year's fluffy, Felliniesque ''Girl on the Bridge,'' or worse, like the off-key but fascinating ''Ridicule.''

title: Vehicle Sales Held Strong Last Month
description: American consumers continued to flock to car dealerships in February despite the economic slowdown, producing another unexpectedly strong month for auto sales.

title: Mrs. Whitman Stands Firm
description: Christie Whitman has begun her tenure as administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency in fine fashion by upholding a set of vitally important clean air rules imposed by her predecessor, Carol Browner. The rules are aimed at eventually reducing pollution from diesel-powered trucks and buses by more than 90 percent. Environmentalists have described the rules as the biggest step toward healthier air since the removal of lead from gasoline in the 1970's. Buses and heavy-duty trucks account for just 6 percent of all miles driven in the United States, but they cause much of the smog and at least half the soot in cities like New York, where the health benefits will be greatest.

title: Illness Strikes A 'Rigoletto' Lead
description: The baritone Mark Delavan was ill and unable to appear in the title role in the New York City Opera's production of Verdi's ''Rigoletto,'' which opened the company's spring season last night. Taking his place was Gaetan Laperriere, who sang the role in November when Rhoda Levine's production was introduced. A spokeswoman for City Opera said that Mr. Delavan might sing tomorrow afternoon and fully expected to recover in time for the third performance on Thursday and his remaining performances through March 23.

title: BANK OF MONTREAL EXPANDING CHICAGO-AREA BUSINESS
description: The Bank of Montreal, Canada's fifth-largest bank, is expanding the business of its Chicago-based Harris Bank unit with the $220 million purchase of First National Bank of Joliet, in Joliet, Ill. With First National's 18 branches, Harris Bank will have 149 retail locations in the region. Shareholders of First National are being offered about $72.50 in cash or Bank of Montreal shares. The purchase is expected to be completed in August. Bank of Montreal bought Harris Bank in 1984 and is currently the seventh-largest foreign bank in the United States.

title: Robin Hoods of Cyberspace: A Philosopher Examines the Difference Between Good and Bad Hackers
description: It can sometimes seem as if the number of people who have speculated on the social implications of Linux, the free computer operating system collectively engineered by thousands of programmers worldwide, exceeds the number of people who have actually used Linux itself. Ever since the open-source software movement entered into the public consciousness in the late 90's, we've been awash in prophesies about the end of the Windows era and the birth of a less proprietary digital age. Together, the emergence of open-source software and the related Napster music file sharing system constitute the most significant technological development since the arrival of the World Wide Web.

title: The Supreme Court v. Balance of Powers
description: Most Americans believe that politics should not be part of Supreme Court jurisprudence. But the Supreme Court is unavoidably a political as well as a legal institution. And the current Supreme Court has a definite political agenda -- one devoted chiefly to reallocating governmental power in ways that suit the views of its conservative majority.

It does a nice job with the changing fashions, too, and is brazen enough to recreate some of the era's most famous photographs (John-John nibbling on Mom's pearls, Jackie relaxing outdoors in that sleeveless yellow-and-white-checked dress). ''Jackie, Ethel, Joan: Women of Camelot,'' a two-part film tomorrow and Monday nights on NBC, makes life in Washington, Hyannis Port, Skorpios and suburban Virginia look beautiful. Beyond that, it's pretty much business as usual.

The loving husband of 50 years to Joan (Quinn) Bardes, and son of the late George F. and Mary (Gowlan) Bardes. John was a long-time resident of Elmont, NY and of Enfield, CT for the past 10 years. He was a graduate of Manhattan College Class of 1950 Engineering School, and was a retired Major with the US Army Reserve. Besides his beloved wife Joan, John was the beloved father and father-in-law of John and Mary Ann Bardes of Boca Raton, FL, Elizabeth and Dr. John Vomero of Ludlow, MA, Margaret and James Rochford of Guilford, CT, Joan and Vincent Pisciotta of Massapequa, NY and devoted grandfather of Sean and Patrick Bardes, Kathryn and Peter Vomero, David, Megan and Quinn Rochford, Michael, Kevin, Stephanie and Kelly Pisciotta. Enfield, CT (Exit 48 off I-91, East on Rt. 220 1- 1/4 miles), followed by a Mass of the Resurrection at 11:30 am in St. Martha's Church Enfield, CT. title: N.J. Basketball Hopeful Lifts Spirits of Blighted City
description: CAMDEN, N.J., March 1  He had approached the record with an elegant flurry of dunks and 3-point shots, and as Dajuan Wagner stood at the free-throw line, the overflow crowd at Camden High School rose to its feet. He was 1 point from becoming New Jersey's career-leading scorer. He sank the free throw and later tossed the ball to his relatives. As usual, his mother, Lisa Paulk, sat intently with pad and pen to record the efforts of her son, for whom points have piled up this winter like snow.

title: Mexico Seeks Lower Fees On Funds Sent From U.S.
description: The money sent home by Mexicans who work in the United States -- $8 billion or more a year, by most estimates -- puts food on the tables and clothes on the backs of millions of families. But millions of dollars a day disappear in the process.

title: Robert McGinnis, 73, Founder Of Sociology Center at Cornell
description: Robert McGinnis, a Cornell University sociologist who founded and directed its Institute for Social and Economic Research, died Feb. 22 at a hospice in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 73 and lived in Ithaca.

title: Greenspan Urges Caution on Spending and Tax Cuts
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, urged Congress today to be cautious in parceling out tax cuts and spending increases, warning that the projected federal budget surplus should not be considered money in the bank.

title: Huskies Hoping To Make Amends
description: While gathered in a hotel room near Philadelphia, the Connecticut women's basketball team monitored its top competition in a roundabout way. This was two weeks ago, the night before UConn played at Villanova, and Maria Conlon was on a cell phone with her mother, who was watching Notre Dame on television. With her mother's help, Conlon relayed the play-by-play to teammates around her.

title: Submarine Conducted Only a Brief Surface Check, Board Says

title: DAEWOO TRIAL STARTS
description: Four of 34 Daewoo group executives and accountants on trial for fraud and other charges admitted that they had altered the books at the Daewoo companies of South Korea. One of the four, Chun Joo Bum, former president of the Daewoo Electronics Company, said Kim Woo Choong, the Daewoo group founder and chairman, now in hiding abroad, had ordered false bookkeeping to keep the group from collapsing. Park Chang Byung, a former vice president of Daewoo Electronics, said Mr. Kim wanted the books to show the company had a surplus of 41 billion won in 1997. The four testified on the first day of the trial involving accounts totaling more than 41 trillion won ($32.5 billion). Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Two Days After Earthquake, the Effects Linger and the Costs Grow
description: Many streets and roads in western Washington looked almost as good as new today, two days after enduring the worst earthquake to hit the Pacific Northwest in half a century. But the State Capitol buildings here remained closed, traffic to Seattle-Tacoma International Airport was still stymied, landslides were still a threat and the damage from the quake, estimated at $2 billion, is likely to have lasting effects, state and federal officials said today.

title: Sneaking Classical Bits Into a Mix
description: Growing up in Philadelphia, Benny Golson played the piano in his early teenage years. His ambition, before switching to the saxophone and becoming one of the best improvisers in the history of postwar jazz, was to be a concert pianist.

title: Childs, Still Stunned, Adjusts to the Raptors
description: Chris Childs danced on the border of bitterness when asked today about his trade from the Knicks, but he did not shy away from thoughts of vindication when talking about the imminent visit of his old team Sunday.

title: PITCHERS' DUELS
description: Roger Clemens and David Cone aren't teammates anymore, but they share a resolve. One refuses to grow up; the other refuses to give up. Reports by Pat Jordan and Buster Olney in The Times Magazine.

Dozens of invitations were extended to Roman Catholic churches and schools across Queens, but only a handful were even acknowledged. Finding a priest from Queens willing to give the opening invocation has been an impossible task.

description: Early in the second period a fan wandered from his seat in Madison Square Garden with the Rangers and the Pittsburgh Penguins tied at 1-1. A couple of minutes later Pittsburgh was up by three goals.

title: AMERITRADE, ONLINE STOCK FIRM, NAMES CHIEF
description: Ameritrade Holdings, the online brokerage firm based in Omaha, has chosen Joseph Moglia, a senior vice president with Merrill Lynch & Company, to be its chief executive, people at Merrill Lynch said. Mr. Moglia oversees sales of stocks and other securities, including exchange-traded mutual funds, through Merrill's network of 14,000 brokers. People within Merrill said they had believed that Mr. Moglia might leave the firm after he was passed over a year ago when E. Stanley O'Neal was named to run the brokerage operation. Spokesmen for Ameritrade and Merrill declined to comment. An announcement of the hiring, first reported yesterday by the Dow Jones News Service, is expected next week. Patrick McGeehan (NYT)

Maybe it was the memory of a year ago, when everyone who expected Adelphi to advance to the N.C.A.A. Division II playoffs was wrong.

title: Salvadorans Illegally in U.S. Are Given Protected Status
description: President Bush agreed today to allow as many as 150,000 Salvadorans to remain in the United States for up to 18 months to help El Salvador recover from a series of devastating earthquakes earlier this year. Most of the Salvadorans are in this country without legal visas or work permits.

description: Federal safety regulators criticized Consolidated Edison tonight for falling behind in routine repairs and improvements at the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor, but concluded that the plant was safe over all.

description: A city maintenance worker died yesterday when he was sucked into a 20-inch-wide drain that he was unclogging at the bottom of the nearly empty Jerome Park Reservoir in the Bronx, the authorities said.

title: Mutual Funds Ask N.Y.S.E. for Rule Change
description: In the latest complaint related to the stock market's transition to decimal stock quotes, the mutual fund industry has asked the New York Stock Exchange to make it easier for large investors to trade stocks.

title: U.S. FOODSERVICE AGREES TO BUY MUTUAL WHOLESALE
description: U.S. Foodservice, the second-largest United States food distributor behind the Sysco Corporation, agreed to buy the closely held Mutual Wholesale Company for an undisclosed amount to expand into areas of Florida. Mutual Wholesale, based in Lakeland, Fla., distributes food and related nonfood items to customers in central and south Florida. It has annual sales of about $300 million, U.S. Foodservice's treasurer, Robert Gillison, said. U.S. Foodservices, based in Columbia, Md., is a unit of Koninklijke Ahold. It operates through about 55 distribution centers in the United States.

description: Using an untested legislative weapon, Senate Republicans plan next week to try to repeal a far-reaching set of rules on workplace injuries that have been fiercely opposed by business groups.

title: ROLLS-ROYCE HAS RECORD ORDERS
description: The British aircraft-engine maker Rolls-Royce announced that it had record orders worth $13.1 billion at the end of last year and reported a 15 percent rise in net income before exceptional charges, sending its shares up 12 percent, their biggest one-day jump since October 1999. The stock ended up 11 percent, at 212.75 pence. Both Boeing and Airbus Industrie use engines made by Rolls-Royce. Net income for 2000 was 337 million ($490.42 million), compared with 94 million a year earlier. The 2000 figure excludes 120 million in one-time charges. Alan Cowell (NYT)

description: Angry mountains and devastating floods have long been central to the folklore of the Nisqually Indians of Puget Sound and the Mount Rainier area.

Seton Hall compiled a 19-8 record, going 10-6 in the Big East Conference. The Pirates received their first berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament since 1994, then won two games to reach the final 16.

title: Sehorn Re-Signs With the Giants For $36 Million
description: A free agent on the open market for less than a day, Jason Sehorn signed a six-year contract with the Giants last night worth $36 million. Sehorn, perhaps the team's most popular and athletically gifted player, also received a $10 million signing bonus.

title: More Problems and Fewer Clients; Consulting Firms Are Hurting, Along With the Economy
description: At McKinsey & Company, consultants are trying to make the best of the current slowdown in business. While the firm has more experts available to work on projects than it did last year, according to Peter Walker, manager of the New York office, it has fewer new projects from clients. As a result, he said, McKinsey's younger associates are spending more time on internal and pro bono work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTON, SYDNEY C.
description: WINTON-Sydney C. Died March 1, 2001, at the age of 92. Beloved brother of Irma Goldfein. Father of Naomi Schwartz, Joel and Ann. Grandfather of Andrew, Jeffrey and Gregory Winton, Heidi Resnick, Gary Schwartz and greatgrandfather of David and Daniel Winton, Rachel and Sarah Winton, Alicia Winton, Benjamin Schwartz, and Jordan Resnick. Sydney was born in NYC, attended Townsend Harris High School, City College and Columbia Law School. He graduated in 1929 and was co-editor of the Columbia Law Review. He practiced law in NYC for over 50 years and was a senior partner in Botein Hays Sklar. He died peacefully in his home. Graveside services at Montefiore Cemetery on Sunday, March 4, 2001, at 10 AM. Family will sit shiva at his home afterwards.

title: Corrections

title: Napster to Start Blocking Access to Protected Music Files
description: In a concrete sign that Napster is at last succumbing in the face of huge legal obstacles, the company said today that it would begin this weekend, for the first time, to prevent users from exchanging some copyrighted songs online.

description: The governors of Maryland and Virginia are openly fighting over a major public works project that offers the ultimate in Washington Beltway politics.

title: 2 Endocrinology Groups Raise Doubt on Earlier Onset of Girls' Puberty
description: Two professional societies representing endocrinologists have issued a statement saying that despite the conclusion of a widely noted study, it is not yet established that girls typically enter puberty earlier today. The groups urged that girls who appear to be starting sexual development at a young age see a specialist as soon as possible.

title: KODAK HALTS STOCK REPURCHASES SO IT CAN TRIM DEBT
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it had stopped repurchasing stock so it could accelerate the repayment of debt and make acquisitions. Kodak said it had been spending about $1 million a day to buy back shares since Dec. 12, when the company lowered profit estimates because of slowing film sales. In the fourth quarter, Kodak bought back $445 million in stock, or about 10 million shares. The company, based in Rochester, is trying to maintain its leadership in film sales while investing in digital photographic technology.

title: PENNEY IS PLANNING TO CUT NUMBER OF ITEMS IN ITS STORES
description: J. C. Penney plans to cut the number of items offered in its stores by 15 percent this year as the company, which is trying to reverse a slump in earnings, focuses on fewer goods that yield better profits. The company, the No. 2 department store chain, will carry 95,000 items this year, down from 112,000 in 2000 and 134,000 in 1999, said Vanessa Castagna, chief operating officer for stores, catalog and Internet. Penney, based in Plano, Tex., like its larger rival, Sears, Roebuck, is trying to eliminate clutter from its stores and give more shelf space to the most popular products. The move is expected to help reduce the amount of slower-selling goods left over at the end of each season and attract more shoppers.

title: An Earthquake Puts a Political Career on Firmer Ground
description: AT 10:56 a.m. on Wednesday, Paul SchellPaul Schell was precisely four minutes away from starting a difficult news conference, this one in response to Mardi Gras mayhem on the Seattle streets that had left a young man dead, dozens of people injured and the sort of disturbing image that he never thought would be an emblem of his mayoralty: the police firing tear gas and rubber pellets to disperse a crowd.

title: City Loses Another Round In Mentally Ill Inmates' Suit
description: New York City must arrange continuing mental health care for inmates who are released from city jails until a lawsuit on the matter is decided, a state appeals court ruled yesterday.

title: Sky Watch: Planets in a Heavenly Ballet
description: Planets are very much in the fore these days, especially with three of them now putting on shows as prominent evening luminaries. Over in the western sky at dusk, Venus continues to glow brilliantly, while much higher, Jupiter and Saturn remain lovely sights in close proximity to the ruddy star Aldebaran and the Hyades star cluster. The heavenly ballet continuously being performed by these wandering stars has played a crucial role in the celestial lore of all peoples.

title: Blaming Raytheon Deal, Contractor Warns of Bankruptcy
description: Washington Group International, among the nation's largest construction companies, said yesterday that it might seek bankruptcy protection if the Raytheon Company did not refund a portion of the price that Washington paid for Raytheon's building and engineering unit.

title: SOUTH KOREAN ECONOMY STABILIZING
description: South Korea's finance minister, Jin Nyum, said government programs had rescued the country from the 1997-1998 economic crisis. Mr. Jin praised restructuring efforts on a day in which the Korean stock index fell 3.23 percent, closing at 559.44, while the over-the-counter Kosdaq fell 6.21 percent to 71.99. Having achieved basic changes, Mr. Jin said, the government would let market forces determine the fate of heavily leveraged companies and banks. His remarks, at a news conference, responded to criticism of government approval of rollovers of loans for several large companies and fresh loans for Hyundai Engineering and Construction. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: William Bittman, 69; Won Hoffa Conviction
description: William O. Bittman, who won a conviction against the Teamsters leader James R. Hoffa as a young federal prosecutor and became one of Washington's best-known lawyers, died on Thursday at his home in Potomac, Md. He was 69.

title: High-Tech Snooping
description: The Fourth Amendment's ban on unreasonable searches was crafted by the Constitution's framers to create a barrier against government intrusions on Americans' privacy. An important case argued recently in the Supreme Court tests the continued vitality of that protection in the face of high-tech snooping devices that make it increasingly possible to monitor activities inside a person's home without any physical intrusion.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of the first, second and third days of Id al-Adha, the Islamic Feast of Sacrifice, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Germany Quietly Builds Alliance With Israel
description: TEL AVIV, Feb. 25  Avi Primor, a former Israeli ambassador to Germany, travels regularly to the United States to tell American Jewish groups how good Israeli-German ties have become. "Their reaction," he said, "is often one of shock, pain and indignation. They want to preserve Germany in their minds as a negative nation."

title: Doctors' Suit Vs. H.M.O.'s Can Proceed
description: In a pivotal ruling on 20 wide-ranging lawsuits challenging the business practices of health maintenance organizations, a federal judge in Miami rejected motions by the insurance companies yesterday for dismissal of the suits. The ruling allows the plaintiffs to go forward, pursuing their claims that eight of the largest companies broke their contracts with doctors and unjustly enriched themselves at the doctors' expense.

title: Britain, the Isle of Contagion
description: On the roads leading to the tiny island of Anglesey, just off the coast of Wales, men have been laying down mats soaked in disinfectant, to ward off the spread of infection. Country pathways across Britain are cordoned off; sacks filled with garbage and mail lie lopsided at intervals along rural roads. Parks, forests and the gateways to farmhouses are bolted and barred, many displaying hastily erected ''No Entry'' signs. The normally idyllic British countryside has effectively been closed off.

title: Holyfield Has Something To Prove in Ruiz Rematch
description: As their first bout headed toward a controversial 12-round decision, John Ruiz recalled whether age had finally softened Evander Holyfield's punches. Staggered briefly in the middle rounds, Ruiz figured he had taken Holyfield's best shots and suffered nothing more than a bee sting.

description: A livery-cab driver was shot and critically injured by a robber last night in the Bronx, the police said.

description: As a child, Julia Jefferson did not know that her family was believed to be directly descended from Thomas Jefferson. But her father knew. And he kept it a secret.

title: Architects Compete on Site Near U.N.
description: Five architectural teams have been chosen to compete for the design of a nine-acre site on the East River just south of the United Nations headquarters. The site is being developed by FSM East River Associates, a partnership between Fisher Brothers and Sheldon H. Solow.

title: National News Briefs; Delay in Indictment Of Man Accused as Spy
description: Prosecutors have agreed to delay the indictment of Robert Philip Hanssen, the Federal Bureau of Investigation officer accused of spying, while defense lawyers have agreed not to challenge the government's request to keep Mr. Hanssen incarcerated before trial.

title: SBC COMMUNICATIONS TO CUT JOBS AT TELECOM UNIT
description: SBC Communications Inc., the No. 2 U.S. local-telephone company, will cut an unspecified number of jobs at its SBC Telecom unit to reduce expenses, an SBC spokesman, Selim Bingol, said. The unit, which sells services outside the company's traditional territories, which are in the Southwest and Midwest, has offices in New York, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities. On Thursday, SBC said it expected to earn 50 cents to 53 cents a share this quarter. The average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial is 59 cents.

title: Donors and the Rich Pardon
description: It turns out Bill Clinton himself was Marc Rich's most forceful lobbyist within the White House. Only Mr. Clinton knows whether his recurring interest in the case and his decision to pardon Mr. Rich were in any way colored by donations or the promise of contributions to his presidential library and to the Democratic Party by Mr. Rich's supporters. Mr. Clinton has said that money was not a factor and that he had decided the case solely on its legal and foreign policy merits. But information and testimony collected by Congressional committees strongly suggest that Mr. Rich's legal team certainly thought some of the Democratic Party's biggest contributors could be powerful allies in their quest for a pardon.

title: Racing Association in Fierce Fight to Own City OTB Parlors
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is nearing a decision on the sale of New York City's off-track betting parlors to a private enterprise, a campaign promise he made eight years ago, his aides say.

title: Relief on the Streets of Westchester as Bus Service Resumes, for Now
description: Bus service in Westchester County returned to normal today as striking drivers and mechanics suspended their one-day strike and resumed contract negotiations with management.

title: For the Democrats, A Surplus of Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Obliterating History in Afghanistan
description: Since taking power six years ago, Afghanistan's fundamentalist Taliban movement has brought a whirlwind of destruction. Now it is waging war on the country's cultural heritage, blowing up treasured statues from Afghanistan's pre-Islamic past. These include two monumental Buddhas carved from rock cliffs 14 centuries ago.

title: Creating an Old World Eden, Drifting Through Styles
description: If Brecht and Weill were fond of la dolce vita, or if Hoagy Carmichael had been smitten with the tango, they might have turned out something like Paolo Conte, the Italian songwriter who performed on Monday night at the Beacon Theater.

title: U.S. Free of Disease for 70 Years, but Some Call Its Return Inevitable
description: Although the United States has not had an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease since 1929, some veterinary virologists believe that it is only a matter of time before a slip in agricultural hygiene or a tourist who flouts customs regulations reintroduces this highly infectious virus into American livestock.

title: Bush's Charity Plan Is Raising Concerns For Religious Right
description: President Bush's plan to funnel government money to religious charities is generating unlikely criticism from some conservative Christian leaders who had promoted the idea for years but are now voicing reservations about putting it into effect.

title: Deadline Past, NBC Remains In Talks to Keep 'Frasier'
description: Talks between NBC and Paramount Television for a renewal of the hit comedy series ''Frasier'' reached an impasse yesterday, but the remaining issues are still expected to be resolved, one executive involved in the negotiations said last night.

title: INFOSTRADA SALE UNCERTAIN
description: The British mobile phone company Vodafone Group said it was continuing discussions with Enel S.P.A., the Italian utility, in light of the Italian government's condition that Enel sell 5,500 megawatts of generating capacity if it is to complete its purchase of Infostrada, the Italian telecommunications company. Enel agreed to buy Infostrada from Vodafone in October. The conditions imposed by the government could derail the deal or result in a renegotiation of the 11 billion euro ($10 billion) price, analysts said. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Queens Ferry Sails Into the Sunset
description: It's not often that people cry on a ferry ride, but yesterday a close-knit group of commuters did just that as they mourned the passing of ferry service between Long Island City in Queens and Manhattan.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: KRAFT FOODS INC., Northfield, Ill., the largest branded food company in the world, said that it had acquired Socit des Cafes Ennasr, a privately held company and the leading producer and marketer of roast and ground coffee in Morocco, to help reach the growing North African beverage market. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Death Is Ruled Homicide
description: Detectives are investigating the death of a Bronx nursing home resident in December as a homicide, the police said yesterday.

title: Russian Prosecutors Now Say Chechen Field Held 48 Bodies
description: Russian prosecutors said today that 48 bodies had now been uncovered in a mass grave just outside Chechnya's capital, Grozny, a town controlled by Russian soldiers in daylight and Chechen guerrillas at night.

title: G. W. Wheelwright III, 97, Dies; Co-Founder of Polaroid
description: George W. Wheelwright III, a co-founder of the company that eventually became the Polaroid Corporation, died on Thursday at the Marin Convalescent Center in Tiburon, Calif. He was 97.

title: Article 2001030391533035625 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Corrections
description: A theater review on Thursday about ''Valerie Shoots Andy,'' a play about the shooting of Andy Warhol in 1968, misidentified the Manhattan site of the Warhol Factory, where the attack occurred. It was then at 33 Union Square West, not on East 47th Street.

title: Buddhas of Bamiyan: Keys to Asian History
description: The archaeological site of Bamiyan, about 100 miles west of Kabul in Afghanistan, is set in a broad, flat valley flanked by high stone cliffs. It's a place of open fields and sky, with a long, rich history that scholars are just beginning to understand.

title: Corrections
description: An article in House & Home on Thursday about wildflowers in Arizona misstated Dr. Liz Slauson's position at the Desert Botanical Garden in Phoenix. She is the director of research, not the director.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Greenspan Urges Caution On Size of Income Tax Cut

title: Shares Bounce Around After Early Sell-Off
description: The stock market had a wild ride yesterday, with the three major indexes plunging at the opening bell and then rebounding strongly to post modest gains. Then, like an athlete tiring near the finish line, the rally lost its steam in the late afternoon.

title: Weekend Will Clear Up Some Big East Questions
description: The Rutgers and the Seton Hall men's basketball teams will enter their season finales today with uncertain futures. Seton Hall, which began the season with dreams of a run to the Final Four, is staggering to the finish line, hoping to simply gain a berth to the Big East tournament. Rutgers, whose expectations were far lower than those of its New Jersey neighbor, has had a dreadful season nonetheless. The Scarlet Knights' only highlights came at the expense of the Pirates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, FLORA GELLER
description: FRIEDMAN-Flora Geller. On March 1, 2001. Beloved wife of Arthur. Devoted mother of Larry, Barbara and Deborah. Cherished grandmother of Diane, Robert, Melanie, Rachel & Trevor. Loving great-grandmother of David, Krystal and Daniel. Funeral services Sunday, 10 AM, at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer Memorial Chapels, Queens Blvd. and 76th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Article 2001030393167354594 -- No Title
description: March 2, 2001

title: A Journey in French Repertory With Exotic Ports of Call
description: The Philadelphia Orchestra continues in great form. Its concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday was again glorious, in repertory very different from the previous month's Missa Solemnis: French music of the 20th century, conducted by Vladimir Ashkenazy. Under his encouragement, the playing was superb at the start and just got better.

title: For the Democrats, A Surplus of Advice
description: To the Editor:

title: Studies Point Up Racial Discrimination in Special Education
description: Black students are three times as likely as white students to be labeled ''mentally retarded'' or ''emotionally disturbed'' and put in special education classes, where they are less likely to end up with high school diplomas or a quality education, according to a set of studies released yesterday.

title: Women in India
description: To the Editor:

title: Geologists Puzzle Over What Failed To Shake
description: Though they cautioned that they were working with less than two days' data from Wednesday's earthquake here, scientists are already saying that they are finding evidence of much less shaking and damage than they might have expected, even from a temblor so deep.

title: Religion Journal; Church Leaders Gather in a Divided Communion
description: The area around Hendersonville, N.C., is known as a tourist-friendly place, nestled in the Appalachian Mountain foothills. But since yesterday, it has also been the site of a high-level religious meeting, as the heads of the 38 churches that make up the Anglican Communion gathered at an Episcopal Church retreat center.

title: Darkness in Afghanistan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROLL, EMILY DAVIS
description: CROLL-Emily Davis. On March 1, 2001. Of Washington, D.C., formerly of New York, N.Y. Beloved wife of the late Joseph D. Croll. Mother of Emily Croll. Grandmother of Alexander Croll Zink and Julianna Colton Zink. Friends may call at Joseph Gawler's Sons, 5130 Wisconsin Ave at Harrison St NW, Washington DC on Monday, March 5th 4-7PM. Family graveside service will be held at the Oak Hill Cemetery, 3001 R St, NW, Washington, D.C. Tuesday, March 6th, 10:30AM. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Holton-Arms School, 7303 River Road, Bethesda, MD 20817.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FREIBERG, SAM
description: FREIBERG-Sam. March 17, 1909March 3, 1996. Sam Freiberg was a decent, honorable man who treated people with dignity and respect. Five years after his death, we still mourn our loss but remain thankful for all the years he was with us. His fortunate family and many friends.

title: Nets Falter in Fourth Quarter as Road Skid Reaches 11
description: The long winter away from home continued in a foreign country for the Nets tonight. Tied with the Raptors at the start of the fourth quarter, the Nets sat back as the high-flying All-Star Vince Carter soared for 13 points and his teammates charged the basket for 17 rebounds in the final quarter alone.

title: A Founding Father and His Family Ties
description: As a child, Julia Jefferson did not know that her family was believed to be directly descended from Thomas Jefferson. But her father knew. And he kept it a secret.

title: U.S. COURT RULING LETS CABLE GIANTS WIDEN THEIR REACH
description: A federal appeals court struck down a set of regulations today that had prevented the nation's largest cable companies from growing larger and broadcasting more of their own shows. The panel found that the rules had violated the companies' First Amendment rights to reach new audiences and to control their programming.

title: JOHNSON & JOHNSON BUYS BABYCENTER FROM ETOYS
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday that it bought the BabyCenter Inc. Web site from eToys Inc. for $10 million. EToys had said on Monday that it planned to file for bankruptcy within the next five to 10 days. Etoys, an Internet retailer, said it would close down its eToys.com Web site about March 8 and intended to sell its assets, including the three-year-old BabyCenter. Johnson & Johnson already operates a number of sites for parents of young children, including Yourbaby.com. BabyCenter has won awards for its Web site and services, Johnson & Johnson and eToys said.

title: The Feuding Of Celebrities Is Old News
description: THIS is one of those never-told-before stories, the result of rummaging through newly discovered archives. Present events in New York make it timely.

title: Couple Testify to an Attack By a Mob in Central Park
description: Two French newlyweds told a jury yesterday how their New York honeymoon came to an abrupt end when they were separated and attacked by a mob while strolling through Central Park.

title: WORLD BRIEFING
description: ASIA

title: Dispute on Russian Tests Divides Nuclear Experts
description: For half a decade, Russia has conducted what it says are nonnuclear tests under the ground of an Arctic island, as the United States says it does beneath the Nevada desert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILBERT, LEON
description: KILBERT-Leon, Dr. Of Miami Beach, FL and Bayside, NY. Passed away on Friday, March 2, 2001. He was beloved husband to Liz. Devoted Dad to Michael, Enid, Diane, Dick, Danny and Kim. Loving grandfather to Alicia, Greg, Jonathan, Staci, Peter, Rachel and Cameron. He will always be remembered for his kindness, gentle nature and love for his family and friends. Services Sunday, 11:00 AM, March 4, at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. at 76 Rd. Interment Wellwood Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: PG&E REFINANCES DEBT WITH A LOAN OF $1 BILLION
description: The PG&E Corporation refinanced its debt with a $1 billion loan from the General Electric Capital Corporation and Lehman Commercial Paper Inc., according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The loan proceeds and other PG&E cash were used to pay $501 million in commercial paper, including $457 million that had gone into default, the filing said. PG&E also said it paid $434 million in borrowings under lines of credit and $116 million to stockholders as of Dec. 15, 2000, for a dividend in the last quarter of 2000. PG&E had missed commercial paper payments in recent weeks to conserve cash. Gov. Gray Davis of California is negotiating with PG&E and its utility, the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, for its transmission lines as part of a broader plan to keep them out of bankruptcy.

title: Greenspan Urges Caution on Spending and Tax Cuts
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, urged Congress today to be cautious in parceling out tax cuts and spending increases, warning that the projected federal budget surplus should not be considered money in the bank.

title: California Agency Challenges Energy Bills
description: Power generators overcharged by $555 million for electricity sold in California in December and January, the manager of the state's power-grid system asserted in asking federal regulators to investigate.

title: Stanford Tops U.C.L.A., Avenging Loss Earlier This Season
description: For the third time in 13 months, U.C.L.A. faced the same assignment: knock off top-ranked Stanford. At stake was control of the race for the Pacific-10 title and momentum heading into the N.C.A.A. tournament later this month. The Bruins, who had prevailed on the previous two occasions, were confident they could make it three in a row.

title: Countering the Bush Tax Plan
description: Democrats endured a bitter demonstration last week of what it means to control neither Congress nor the White House. On Capitol Hill and across the country, President Bush promoted his theme that ''the people's money'' should be refunded as tax cuts. Republican Congressional leaders meanwhile were trying to pass the tax cut first and worry later about the budget cuts to pay for it. Democrats must respond by emphasizing the tax plan's recklessness and pushing their alternatives more forcefully.

title: A Wish for Eminem
description: To the Editor:

title: Poet With an Edge at Maxwell's
description: The beat-punk poet Jim Carroll is probably best known for his 1978 book ''The Basketball Diaries,'' which became a film starring Leonardo DiCaprio and was said to have inspired aspects of the school shootings in Columbine, Colo. But Mr. Carroll is more than a sensational headline. He's a songwriter (his grim 1980 hit ''People Who Died,'' was his most popular recording), a short story writer, diarist, novelist and a spoken-word performer. His themes include the dark landscape of his past heroin use, life in the underbelly of New York's Lower East Side and growing up Catholic. On Saturday, he will be performing a spoken-word show -- with a dash of performance art -- at Maxwell's in Hoboken. Robbie Woliver

title: Oil and Blasphemy
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERRMANN, HENRY W.
description: HERRMANN-Henry W. 90, loving husband of Alice, devoted father of Phyllis and Evie, adored grandfather of Scott and Amy, beloved son of the late Oscar and Rena Herrmann and affectionate brother of the late Dorothy Adams. Passed away on February 27, 2001 in Rocky Hill, CT. He was an enthusiastic member and president of the Babylon, Long Island Board of Education and a lifetime member of New York State Masonic Lodge #

title: Feb. 25-March 3; 13 Die in Britrail Wreck
description: Britain experienced the fourth fatal accident on its railways in four years when a London-bound early morning passenger train collided with a freight train, killing 13 people and injuring 70. Unlike the earlier incidents, the crash was not traceable to lapses by the beleaguered operating companies, but it still shook the flagging confidence of a riding public that has seen efficiency, punctuality, service and safety decline since the privatization of British Rail in 1996. The collision occurred after a Land Rover veered off a highway and ended up on the mainline track just as the high speed train was approaching. Its cars derailed and jackknifed into the path of the onrushing freight train. Warren Hoge

title: The Medical Bill Collectors
description: To the Editor:

title: N.J. LAW; Cars in a Backyard Lead to Days in Court
description: There was a time not too long ago when Rebecca Vares-Ebert presented local officials with cookies -- chocolate chip pecan ones -- rather than lawsuits.

title: INVESTING WITH/Lawrence R. Creatura; Clover Small Cap Value Fund
description: SCALING a Himalayan peak is much like investing, said Lawrence R. Creatura, who also has climbed mountains in Mexico, Kenya and the Canadian Rockies.

title: Amtrak at Issue
description: To the Editor: Regarding Margaret Murphy's letter about her unfortunate train trip (''Long Acela Trip,'' Feb. 11), I feel obliged to point out that Ms. Murphy had her experience on the Acela Regional, not the high-speed Acela Express.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Neighborhood Report pages last Sunday about the conversion of an old gatehouse at West 135th Street and Convent Avenue into a performance space credited it erroneously with a record. It is not the highest point in Manhattan; the highest point in the natural landscape is in Bennett Park, at 265 feet above sea level, near West 185th Street and Fort Washington Avenue.

title: BMW and Mercedes Are Expecting; the Babies Will Visit America
description: BMW and Mercedes have thrived in the United States by cultivating upscale images, but they have sized and priced their cars out of the reach of many young people. Last week, both companies confirmed plans for cars aimed at young Americans -- but that could chip away at the brands' carefully nurtured exclusivity.

title: Trio of Bisques That Can Be Creamy Without Cream
description: SAY bisque and immediately, unconscionable quantities of cream and mellowing chunks of lobster or some mushrooms comes to mind. But to be creamy, a bisque does not require cream.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Westchester Medical Center referred incompletely to the appointment process for its 15-member board. The governor and the County Legislature make appointments; the county executive only recommends three members. Ten are selected by the County Legislature, and one each by the State Senate majority leader and the Assembly speaker.

title: A 'New Fresco' Show Of Geometric Paintings
description: AS an artist, Paolo Corvino is a soulful chameleon. His creations, inspired by things like a photograph of a rainy evening in Paris or a childhood experience, are as unpretentious as they are impulsive.

title: After Cabby Shooting, Council Accused of Foot-Dragging on Safety
description: The attack on a livery-cab driver who was shot and critically wounded Friday night might have been prevented if a bill requiring tracking devices for the cabs had not stalled in a City Council committee, the head of a drivers' group said yesterday.

title: Health Care for All
description: To the Editor:

title: The Quirks of Behavior, as Part of Economics
description: In ''Following the Money, but Also the Mind'' (Feb. 11), Louis Uchitelle discussed the increasing influence of behavioral economists -- those who say economics should do more than assume that people act with rational, unemotional self-interest. The article drew varied responses from many readers. A sampling follows.

title: Milhous Rock
description: ELVIS AND NIXON

title: A $28 Million Campaign to Make a Nice Park 'Glorious'
description: Children squeal. Dogs bark. People jog. It is, in short, not a bad park. In fact, Carl Schurz Park, which runs along the East River from 84th Street past Gracie Mansion at 90th Street, is quite a nice park.

title: BackTalk; The Numbers Say It Ain't So, Bobby
description: This Oct. 3, baseball will mark the 50th anniversary of arguably the greatest moment in sports: Bobby Thomson's home run, a three-run shot in the last of the ninth inning of a playoff game that completed the amazing comeback of the New York Giants, pronounced dead two months before. But recent disclosures have left less to celebrate. The Giants may have stolen the 1951 National League pennant with a telescope and a buzzer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIPS, ALBEN
description: PHILIPS-Alben. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Alben Philips, associated with The Times from 1962 until 1982.

title: Isles Hit Bottom With Loss to Tampa Bay
description: The Islanders burrowed back to the bottom of the National Hockey League tonight by losing to the Tampa Bay Lightning, 6-0. Islanders Coach Butch Goring, who had been able to slap a happy face on most of the previous 39 losses, stamped this one, in front of 12,542 spectators at Nassau Coliseum, as the official low point of a long-lost season.

title: Iraqis Who Look Back in Anguish
description: Most days, Hamza Jabbar comes to this silent, deserted border crossing to sit, and remember. From where he rests, on a concrete plinth bearing a benign portrait of Saddam Hussein, he can see across a rusting barrier to abandoned customs sheds and down a heavily potholed road that leads to Kuwait.

title: Nike in Indonesia, Through a Different Lens
description: AROUND our house, there were two big stories in the footwear business recently: Critics of Nike again walked all over the company because of conditions in Indonesian factories. And my son got new sneakers for $7.

title: He Captured The Soul Of Silence
description: SOMETIMES the new sensation in the art world can be an old master. Just look at Johannes Vermeer, whose pictures of tranquil housewives have recently come into vogue. In 1995, in one of the most belated tributes in art history, Vermeer was given his first museum retrospective, which was seen in Washington and The Hague. In its wake, acts of homage keep proliferating; they include at least three novels and an opera from Amsterdam at Lincoln Center last summer (''Writing to Vermeer'') in which the artist's comely wife belted out songs about art, love and the toxic effects of wet varnish.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Times Magazine last Sunday with an article about Lamont Wilder, who spent most of his childhood in foster care, misstated his age and the timing of the scene. He was photographed just after he entered Astor Home for Children, not just before, and he was 7, not 12.

title: NEWARK PLANE CRASH
description: The city of Newark and about 20 residents of a neighborhood struck by a small plane the day after Thanksgiving 1999 will receive $2 million from the pilot's estate under a legal settlement announced last week. The pilot of the single-engine plane, Itzhak Jacoby of Bethesda, Md., died along with his wife and their 13-year-old daughter, and the trail of flaming wreckage damaged 18 buildings and injured 27 residents, including a 59-year-old man who died 45 days later. An investigation by the National Transportation Safety Board blamed mechanical trouble and Mr. Jacoby's use a barbiturate used to treat migraine headaches. Under the settlement, a panel of retired Superior Court judges will decide how to divide the money, said Shay Deshpande, the assistant corporation counsel for Newark. Kirsty Sucato

title: PLAYING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD
description: WASHINGTON SQUARE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARIEL, ROBERT A. PH.D.
description: ARIEL-Robert A. Ph.D. Born May 30, 1951, NYC. Died February 7, 2001, at St. Vincent Hospital, NYC. Beloved son of Josephine Virnig Stannard, Rosemount, MN, and the late Irving M. Ariel, M.D., NYC; cherished stepson of Raymond Stannard; dear brother of Paula Stannard, Chicago, IL, Catherine Stannard (and husband David O'Brien), Ann Arbor, MI, and Martha Johnson (and husband Charles), Farmington, MN; cherished nephew of Lillian Ariel Malzman, Honolulu, HI, and of Dr. Morris (and wife Opal) Virnig, Owensboro, KY, Dr. Hildegard Virnig, Caledonia, MN, and Dr. Norman (and wife Kathleen) Virnig, St. Cloud, MN; stepson of Ingegard Angerer Ariel, NYC, and stepbrother of Mark (and wife Corinna) Angerer, Stuttgart, Germany. He is also survived by longtime family friends, the Herb and Phyllis Zarrow family, Fair Lawn, NJ, and by many other relatives and friends. Dr. Ariel graduated from Dartmouth College with an A.B. in Chemistry in 1973. As a Marshall Scholar at Balliol College, Oxford University, he earned an M.A. in Physics and Philosophy. He subsequently earned a Ph.D. in Finance from MIT, and a Ph.D. in Philosophy from the Univeristy of Minnesota. Dr. Ariel was an Assistant Professor of Economics and Finance at Baruch College, City University of New York, where he had taught since 1986. Much of his research focused on identifying seasonal patterns in stock prices. He was a longtime member of the Baruch Faculty Senate and, as a leader in the faculty, was an expert on the college and university budget. Robert was charming, brilliant and loving; a gracious son, brother and nephew; a remarkable friend, scholar, colleague and teacher. Robert's interests ranged from the sciences to music, and he especially enjoyed listening to and singing Handel's ''Messiah.'' He will be geatly missed and remembered forever. A memorial service for Dr. Ariel will be held at Baruch College, Conference Center Room 750, 151 E. 25th St, NYC, on Thursday, March 8, 2001, at 12:25 PM. In lieu of flowers, memorials are preferred to the Baruch College Fund, Baruch College, 17 Lexington Ave, Box D-0901, NYC 10010; the Rudolph Steiner School, 15 E. 79th St, NYC 10021; or the St. Vincent Hospital Spiritiual Care Department, St. Vincent Catholic Medical Center, 170 W. 12th St., Spellman 117, NYC 10011.

title: Zappa's Legacy Lives On
description: Frank Zappa's musical legacy lives on in performances by tribute bands such as Project/Object, a Red Bank-based band that plays music composed and played by Mr. Zappa during each of the vastly different phases of his musical life.

title: We're Doing Battle Right and Left, Colombia Insists
description: As President Andrs Pastrana shops in Europe and America for more aid, he wants the world to know that his government is committed to fighting his country's right-wing paramilitary groups, not just its leftist rebels.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, HELEN S.
description: FRANK-Helen S. On February 25, 2001, in Boston, MA. Age 88. Resident of Needham, MA., formerly of Westchester County, N.Y. Wife of the late Martin Frank. Mother of David Freund of New York City and Elizabeth Fideler of Framingham, MA., and the late Susan Lamb and John Freund. She is also survived by five grandchildren and five great grandchildren. She earned an Ed.D. from Teachers College and practiced psychotherapy for twenty years. Donations to Gillette Center for Women's Cancers, Massachusetts General Hospital, 100 Blossom St, Boston, MA 02114.

title: Feb. 25-March 3; Mardi Gras Gone Wrong
description: In such unlikely cities as Philadelphia, Austin, Fresno and Seattle last week, grim-faced police officers dodged beer bottles thrown byyoung, drunken crowds celebrating Mardi Gras. Fights broke out, stores were looted and hundreds of people were arrested. In Seattle, one 20-year-old man, who was somehow struck in the head, died.

title: Pinot Gris Debut
description: The Lenz Winery and Alsace-style dry gewrztraminer have been synonymous since 1983. Now, with his first pinot gris, a spare '98, Eric Fry, the winemaker, has broadened the portfolio's Francophile character.

title: Painstakingly Restored, a Torah Will Return Home
description: The Torah was 150 years old and had survived the Holocaust in Hungary. After World War II it was brought to Honduras and treasured by a small Jewish community, la Comunidad Hebrea de Tegucigalpa, about 35 families of native Honduran Jews, American expatriates and Israelis. But during Hurricane Mitch in 1998 it was buried in three feet of mud and all but destroyed.

title: Still Dreaming the Rock 'n' Roll Dream
description: ALL Andy Zwerling wants is for everyone to have the chance to hear his music. That's all. In this he's no different from thousands of other independent-minded souls who labor to get their work out to an audience that, they're sure, is out there, and who in the last couple of years have harnessed the anarchy of the Internet in an attempt to reach it. Few of them, however, have Mr. Zwerling's tenacity: he's been at it for nearly 30 years.

title: Bugs Among the Blooms
description: There will be three ''great gardens'' at this year's Philadelphia Flower Show, which starts today and continues to next Sunday. One is an Egyptian Garden, one is an area showing the effect of European gardening in America and the third is a neighborhood, with homes, a playground and a creek. That last one may not sound so grand, but it is aimed at keeping all the show-stoppers healthy without endangering the people who admire them. The focus of the 80-by-100-foot exhibit is ''integrated pest management,'' environmentally friendly ways to avoid both pests and pesticides. The Rutgers Cooperative Extensions in New Jersey, Delaware and Pennsylvania are among the organizers. Clare Liptak of Rutgers will be there by the talking Volkswagen bug painted as a ladybug and manipulating puppets of a ladybug, a lacewing and a dragonfly, which eat bugs gardeners don't want. She says she will talk about pest management but won't do funny voices.

title: Why Is He on Top? He's a Tyson, for One
description: JOHN H. TYSON may be this state's latest comeback kid.

title: Giuliani Internalized
description: James Traub (Feb. 11) seems to suggest that New Yorkers have paid a great price to be able to enjoy a stroll down a freshly scrubbed Times Square. I say we've got a bargain.

title: Giuliani Internalized
description: I was born in New York Hospital, grew up in and around the five boroughs and lived here during the 70's (groan!). Today, I'm a frequent visitor to New York for business and pleasure. I have thought about moving back to the Big Apple, but I have one nonnegotiable requirement: Rudy Giuliani must remain mayor forever.

title: Unbreakable Blossom
description: LILLIAN GISH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, DR. JEFFREY SCOTT
description: LEVIN-Dr. Jeffrey Scott. Of Boulder, CO on February 4, 2001. He is survived by his parents, Herbert and Corinne Levin of California.

title: XFL May Let Teenagers Opt To Turn Pro
description: As the XFL's television ratings plummet and as doomsayers continue to predict the league's imminent downfall, Michael Keller, the XFL's vice president for football operations, continues to plan the league's future on the field. And one idea he and the XFL are contemplating could supply a dramatic surge of talent next season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, GERALDINE
description: SCHNEIDER-Geraldine. Beloved aunt to many nephews and nieceums.

title: They Want to Marry a Millionaire
description: LILY BART, the ambivalent fortune hunter of ''The House of Mirth,'' the book and now the movie, had more scruples than were good for her. Too refined to marry for money alone, she renounced great wealth and ended her days in squalor, shunned or forgotten by her friends.

title: Benefits of Corporate Names
description: To the Editor:

title: Midweek Salsa Fever
description: Paris Hilton wasn't there. Neither was Monica Lewinsky. And, no, Mark Ronson wasn't spinning. All of which meant absolutely nothing to the sweaty crowd at Nell's last Wednesday night, during the weekly salsa dance party called Cubansoul, when a limber couple looking as if they had stepped out of ''Saturday Night Fever,'' from blow-dried hair to open shirts, cleared the floor and worked their gravity-defying moves.

title: 'Don't Call Me Actor,' says a Nominee for Best, Um . . .
description: TO prepare for the role of the Cuban writer Reinaldo Arenas, the Spanish actor Javier Bardem learned to walk his walk, to speak with his Cuban accent, to kiss a man as if he meant it. And on a hot Mexican afternoon a week before shooting began, he sat himself down to learn how to type.

title: CELL PHONE BAN
description: Almost eight months after becoming the first municipality in New Jersey to make it illegal to use a hand-held cell phone while driving, Marlboro last week began erecting signs warning drivers of the ban. Some 50 signs are being posted on state Routes 9, 18, 34 and 79 as well as a score of county and local roads. Drivers will have a 30-day grace period until the police start giving out summonses that can result in up to $250 in fines. George James

title: Writer on the Road: Heading West
description: I believed I had packed all the proper gear for a road trip between Billings, Mont., and Los Angeles: laptop, cell phone, Loomis four-piece fly rod, Browning 12-gauge shotgun, bathing suit, boogie-board, down coat, cross-country skis. It was my intention to reach Las Vegas in two days' time, and join up with my wife and three children at the Paris Hotel for New Year's Eve and what was modestly being billed as the largest display of fireworks on the planet; thence, rocket due west to the Pacific.

title: Watching the Fed, and Selling Anew
description: Dashed hopes of an imminent Federal Reserve rate cut left stock market investors running for cover as companies continued to roll out profit warnings last week.

title: Stretching the Ideas Of Animal Imagery
description: THE focus is not animals, insists John I. Russell, executive director of the Brookfield Craft Center. Nor, he says, is the center's current show about art that looks like animals.

title: Hofstra Gets By Struggling Vermont
description: It is normally the offense that makes Hofstra go. But on an afternoon when its weapons kept misfiring, the top-seeded Pride relied on defense today to advance to the semifinals of the America East tournament. With eighth-seeded Vermont missing the basket from near, far and the foul line, Hofstra came away with a 68-55 victory at the University of Delaware's Bob Carpenter Center.

title: Corrections

Dickerson, who has adopted a more aggressive approach toward men who threaten their wives, referred incorrectly to his questioning of victims about the appropriate punishment for their abusers. It occurs in court, not in his chambers.

title: Word for Word/Hip-Hop Feuds; When the Rap Is Mightier Than the Sword
description: WITH Sean (Puffy) Combs, one of the most musically mild rappers of his generation, on trial for gun possession after a nightclub shootout and with members of Lil' Kim's entourage involved in a gun battle last week, one longs for the days when rap seemed innocent, when a diss was just a diss between rival rappers and not an invitation to a shootout.

description: John Shelton Reed, a sociologist of the South, once wrote that Atlanta is what a quarter of a million Confederate soldiers died to prevent.

title: An Expensive View Of Mir's Flaming End
description: If all goes as planned, the Mir space station will leave orbit within the next two weeks, beginning its final performance. As it enters the atmosphere, a group of scientists and tourists hope to be in a plane about 300 miles away, watching the station's fiery disintegration.

title: Programmed to Defy Corruption
description: ONCE upon a prime time, men like James T. West from ''The Wild Wild West,'' Alexander Mundy from ''It Takes a Thief'' and Illya Kuryakin from ''The Man From U.N.C.L.E.'' made television crime-busting seem like the best job in the world. They were smart and funny, never agonized over their actions and were dashingly handsome.

title: Emergency Room Doctors Protest New Limits on Ambulance Crews
description: Emergency room doctors in New York City are protesting a new Emergency Medical Service policy that prohibits a common practice among ambulance crews: taking some patients directly to specific departments of hospitals and bypassing emergency rooms altogether.

title: A Registered Nurse In the Very Next Seat
description: American Airlines has begun a program to help sick people who are able to fly but might need a nurse's help. Under the plan, offered on only a few flights now, the patient is accompanied by a registered nurse from American's roster for an hourly fee of $90. The patient buys two one-way tickets at either the first-class or full coach fare, with a 30 percent discount for both seats.

title: Illustrator's Alchemy Makes Everyday Life Into Works of Art
description: Jorge Colombo ducked into the Strand Bookstore just as the snow began to fall and roamed the aisles, his eyes darting about in search of the perfect subject. He passed a bearded man in a plaid coat. He watched, for a moment, a tattooed girl in tight jeans. Neither would do.

title: Some Bisques Can Be Creamy Without Cream
description: SAY bisque and immediately, unconscionable quantities of cream and mellowing chunks of lobster or some mushrooms comes to mind. But to be creamy, a bisque does not require cream.

description: KUPFERBERG-Herbert. January 20, 1918-February 22, 2001. description: The presidents of Columbia University and New York University, two of the most popular colleges in the country in recent years, have told their trustees that they plan to step down next year.

description: FOR more than a century the companies and eras have come and gone in the Over-the-Rhine neighborhood. First were neighborhood merchants from Germany, then rope makers, brewers and slaughterhouses.

description: Pat Jordan (Feb. 11) has drawn a superb psychological portrait of Rick Ankiel Jr. Jordan gives us enough of Ankiel's family background to sense what his conflicts are and to suspect that this gifted youngster is more likely to get the help he needs from a psychoanalyst than a pitching coach.

description: Q -- I have noticed a derelict but well-executed triumphal arch largely subsumed in the Gallo Auto Body Works at Broadway and 215th Street. In its ruined state is reminds me of the Roman antiquities one chances upon in Italian towns. What is the history behind this artifact, and what fate awaits it? . . . Robert Pierpont, Manhattan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, MAX
description: GREEN-Max. Born in Newark, NJ, in 1903, died March 1, in Hightstown, NJ. Advertising executive and marketing consultant. Devotee of the arts, a special way with words, a special way with people, jogger, brown belt, equestrian, mentor and family man, clearly with a zest for living. Loving companion for 71 years to his beloved wife Flossie. Father to Jerry, Judy and the late Rosemary. Grandfather to Serena, Adriana, Laurie, Andrea and Claudia. Great-grandfather to Renata, Marisol, Liana, Benjamin, Tansy and Sarafina. He will be so missed.

description: My stockbroker executes trades for the private client accounts of a nationally known and highly successful mutual-fund manager. My broker will often tell me what stocks the fund manager is buying for those private accounts. Should he be offering me this advice? Is it O.K. for me to listen? -- Anonymous

title: Landlord's Reduction In Services
description: Q -- I have always understood that tenants who choose not to buy when a building goes co-op are entitled to the same services they received in pre-co-op days. In our case, the services included having our blinds washed and floors waxed whenever we had our apartment painted. We recently had a paint job and when I requested that the blinds be washed, our superintendent informed me that both services were discontinued when the building went co-op. Are these services that a co-op is allowed to discontinue? . . . Alice Fleming, Manhattan.

title: Amtrak at Issue
description: To the Editor: While I am also a frequent critic of Amtrak's service and pricing, a recent report in the Business Day section of The New York Times gives some perspective. Deutsche Bahn, one of the European rail services so admired by Americans, has been operated by the German government at an annual loss estimated at $2 billion. This is in contrast to Amtrak's attempt to operate without subsidy within the next few years. So, unless we demand the restoration of federal subsidies for Amtrak, and insist on paying European tax rates to finance it, we will have to be tolerant of what we have.

title: Taking a Cruise
description: To the Editor: I am writing about ''More Variety, Flexibility in Shipboard Dining'' by Edwin McDowell (Correspondent's Report, Dec. 31). I disagree that most, if not all, passengers would prefer casual dining, the absence of a dress code and a variety of ethnic restaurants.

title: IN BRIEF: Environment; LOANS FOR WATER RESOURCES
description: The state will provide a $37.7 million short-term interest-free loan to help Westchester finance projects to enhance the quality of local water resources and to protect the Hudson River and Long Island Sound. The money will be used to upgrade sewer and wastewater systems across the county. In 1997, the county began an effort to automate all of its sewer district plants and the financing will go toward plant upgrades in Port Chester, Ossining, Peekskill, New Rochelle, Mamaroneck, Yonkers and North Yonkers. Elsa Brenner

title: Katharine Emmet and James Peterson
description: SOME New Yorkers are easy to classify. You see a six-foot-plus beauty running into the Cond Nast building and just know she's a model who never needs a ladder or a date. Katharine Temple Emmet, on the other hand, is difficult to classify. She speaks her mind, bluntly sometimes and whimsically at other times.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALSH, H. ROBERT
description: WALSH-H. Robert. Of New York, N.Y. Age 76. Beloved father of Meredith W. Walsh and Eliot W. Walsh. Brother of Francis X. Walsh. Passed away Wednesday, February 28, 2001. Born in Milton, MA., Mr. Walsh was a graduate of Harvard Univesity, Class of 1946. He served in the U.S. Army in Germany during WWII, attaining the rank of 1st Lt. Upon his graduation from Harvard, he received a Fulbright Scholarship to the Sorbonne in Paris, France. He then went on to earn a Master's Degree in Business from Columbia University. Bob spent his entire career at the advertising firm Young & Rubicam, Inc. in New York City where he ultimately became Senior Vice President and Director of the Strategy Board. He retired in 1987 and resided in Clinton, CT. and Palm Beach, FL. Memorial services will be held at the Church of Saint Thomas More, 65 E. 89 St, N.Y., N.Y. at 10:30AM on Thursday, March 8th. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in his name to SpenceChapin, 6 E. 94 St, NY NY 10128.

description: MENTASANA-Salvatore. We at Reliable Press regret the passing of our loyal and dedicated colleague and our friend.

description: DRILLING-Dena (Daisy Rubin) of Jamaica Estates and Hollywood, FL died March 1 at 88. Beloved mother of Ronald, Kenneth and Steven. Loving grandmother to Deborah, Cynthia, Tiffany, Bruce, Michelle, Willow and Michael. Great grandmother of four. She will be missed by all those privileged to have known her. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, on Saturday, March 3rd, 7-9PM with services to be held on Sunday, March 4 at 11:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81St. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Federation of Broward County, 8358 West Oakland Park Blvd., Fort Lauderdale, Florida 33511.

title: For the Devils, Help Is on the Way
description: WEST ORANGE, N.J., March 3  The Devils got a lift from two returning players Friday night when Petr Sykora and Jason Arnott came back and helped secure a 7-3 victory over Carolina. Now the Devils will get more help when Scott Gomez, another integral part of the Devils' offense, returns Sunday against Tampa Bay after missing five games with a back problem.

title: SOAPBOX; Moving Out, Moving On
description: WE decided to sell the house in Dobbs Ferry; after 32 years we decided it was time. It began as a glimmer -- the roads around our Hudson River village had become a snarl; our overgrown deer-scorched garden was proof that we weren't doing a good job of looking after things; and worse yet, we'd become the old people on the street -- it wouldn't be long before someone would ask to help us cross the road.

title: Late Innings; David Cone Refuses To Give Up
description: Many star ballplayers are blessed to reside in oblivion, where there are no ramifications and there is no fear of failure, a place where you are unencumbered by the shackles of perspective. But David Cone sees the dark side. He recognizes all the obstacles, the impossibilities; little wonder that he briefly considered a career as a sportswriter. He is near the end of a long career, and he fully comprehends the inflexibility of time. The body stiffens, small muscular tears lengthen, the fastball slows, the slider betrays. Cone lost 14 of 18 decisions with the Yankees last season and allowed almost seven runs per game, about twice what he permitted in previous seasons. He volunteers the ugly numbers like a court reporter listing indictments. Cone does not have to hear the whispered words to know what people are saying, that he is finished.
