description: THE HACKER ETHIC

title: It's a Documentary Posing as a Web Site
description: Silicon Alley meets New York arts scene. Picture Projects does not merely design Web sites or create documentaries. It produces combinations of both.

title: Marriage, Ghosts, Adultery And Lies
description: THERE'S a good idea for a play lurking somewhere in ''Dreamhouse,'' a comedy by Darrah Cloud now getting its world premiere at the Centenary Stage Company here. The trouble is, this core concept at times has a lot in common with the ghosts in Ms. Cloud's script: just when you think it's going to manifest itself, it vanishes again.

title: A 'Sopranos' Secret: Given the Choice, We'd All Be Mobsters
description: AROUND 11 o'clock tonight, I promise you, it'll start up again -- the fury, the bitterness, the great howling hurt. To you, it's entertainment. To us, it's the reopening of a culture skirmish that started 30 years ago, when Mario Puzo and Francis Ford Coppola created ''The Godfather'' and its sequel, then spread when Martin Scorsese kicked in ''Goodfellas,'' the success of which only set the stage for the current provocation: the new season of ''The Sopranos.'' This is seen as quite possibly the most degrading and dangerous spectacle yet, if only because it goes into unsuspecting America's living rooms, over and over, and will soon be in the neighborhood of 40 hours long -- our ''Berlin Alexanderplatz'' of shame.

title: New Orleans Beat
description: To the Editor: About ''Keeping the Beat in New Orleans'' (Jan. 14): I would like to mention a wonderful jazz club, the Tin Roof Cafe, at 532 Frenchmen Street, just down the block from Snug Harbor, which Stephen Kinzer mentioned. The Tin Roof features traditional jazz led by a wonderful clarinetist, Jack Maheu. The ambience at the Tin Roof is perfect for enjoying New Orleans music.

title: From Cash to Stocks and Back, Based on the Calendar
description: I MUST confess that I was skeptical two decades ago, when I started monitoring a stock market timing model that looked too good to be true. According to that model, beating the market was as simple as being invested in stocks on the days when the market has historically gone up the most and remaining in cash at all other times.

title: WINTER COLOR
description: IN this time between the snowy season and the growing season, you probably have a strong urge to brighten up your living space. Before you rush to the florist, take a look outside. While the flowers have yet to show their faces, there are a host of colorful branches available for cutting.

title: A Doctor's Specialty Is Exorcising Demon Rum
description: How many drinks are too many? That question has been debated since the discovery of yeast.

title: The Beat, With a Samurai Twist
description: Taiko is the ancient art of Japanese drumming, which uses an array of different sized drums, the largest weighing 900 pounds. Kodo Drummers, an ensemble that combines drumming with athletics and the spirit of the Samurai, has toured the world since the group's formation in 1981. Based on Sado Island, a center of Japanese culture, the drummers take their name from a Japanese word that means heartbeat. The Kodo Drummers will perform at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center on Friday. Karen DeMasters

description: The hothouse of New York wine criticism spawns one of America's most astute journals, the International Wine Cellar, now in its 95th issue.

I would like to point out that the organization responsible for this is Creative Time, which has been commissioning adventurous public art projects for nearly 30 years.

title: Where Have You Gone, Joan Blondell and Fay Bainter?
description: THE year was 1936; the Oscars were a decade-old affair, working their way up from what was, in essence, a fancy-dress bash and awards ceremony thrown by Louis B. Mayer. To quiet the grumbling from the Actors Guild, and to spread the favors around, Frank Capra, head of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences that year, instituted the supporting actor and actress categories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEHLMAN, MADELYN B.
description: MEHLMAN-Madelyn B. The New York City Law Department mourns the passing of our beloved friend and colleague, Madelyn Mehlman. Her keen mind and kind spirit graced us all and will never be forgotten. Our sincerest condolences to her loving family.

description: Charly Baumann, a German-born trainer of big cats, died on Jan. 24 in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived. He was 72.

title: Corrections
description: The Your Home column on Jan. 28, about replacing old windows, misstated the range of a measurement used to indicate how much solar heat a pane transmits. The ''solar heat gain coefficient'' ranges from 0 to 1, not 0.085 to 0.05. The column also misstated the way the coefficient expresses a window's properties. A window with a low coefficient is better at blocking heat than a window with a higher coefficient. A reader's letter questioning the figures was received on Feb. 24.

title: Editorial Observer; A Bit of Perspective on the Dot-Com Backlash
description: It was five years ago this month that I first got on the information superhighway, a term folks used back then without actually blushing. I can recall the sense of accomplishment I felt upon logging on. I might have considered dashing off ''What hath God wrought'' in an e-mail to someone, the words Samuel Morse telegraphed to his partner back in 1844. But that night I did not yet know anyone's e-mail address. Truth be told, I hadn't a clue what to do once I was online.

description: HOW does a script evolve from an idea to a movie? The New York Times asked six writers to talk about the process that led them to winning Academy Awards for best original screenplay. They are:

title: Treasures From Smithsonian
description: A traveling exhibition, ''Treasures From the Smithsonian American Art Museum,'' opens at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick today. The show features 52 works by such painters as Mary Cassatt and Thomas Wilmer.

title: Giuliani Internalized
description: As a native New Yorker who left town rather than watch what Rudy would do to the city, I agree wholeheartedly with the Brooklyn residents who realized, eight years too late, that the lives of ordinary New Yorkers (especially the less fortunate) ended up suffering in favor of big business and tourism.

title: Gipper Meets 'Survivor' As G.E.'s Image Hardens; PCB Battle Tests a Venerable Tradition
description: One of the more upbeat theories of postmodern capitalism is that nice companies will eventually finish first. In a market of instant information, where perception and image are increasingly linked to stock prices, investors will reward the environmentally green and the socially conscious because such companies have fewer potential liabilities, or so the thinking goes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOPKINS, OLIVE V.
description: TOPKINS-Olive V. Died February 27, 2001 at 87. Sister of Dr. Paul and the late Matthew. Beloved aunt of Phyllis, Jane, Madeline, Robert, Elyse and Vicki. Cherished great aunt. Olive was a treasured friend to countless people. She will be remembered and missed for her unwavering patience, kindness and generosity.

title: A Specialist in Planning Trips To the Australian Outback
description: Life has never been easier for Westchester residents with a taste for Australian adventure: in a single day you can test drive a Subaru Outback at Rye Subaru, have some ribs at the Outback Steakhouse in White Plains and still be home in time for the CBS series ''Survivor: The Australian Outback.''

title: Silk Stocking District Embraces Time-Honored Blue-Collar Tactic
description: The six-story, 24-unit walkup at 340 East 62nd Street, between First and Second Avenues, houses many young tenants who pay rents from $1,100 to $2,400. For 74 days, those renters have gone without gas because a serious gas leak was discovered there just before Christmas and Con Edison service was cut for safety. Unable to cook and feeling ignored by Sky Management, which runs the building, seven tenants fired back last month with a venerable working-class tactic: a rent strike.

title: Lights, Camera, Dormitory!
description: Purchase College is building a new dormitory and the world is watching. Well, at least it could be. Visitors to www.purchase.edu/dormcam will find live scenes of the work in progress: a 47,160-square-foot dorm that will house some 180 students.

title: Jrgen Jr., and It's Not a Car
description: Jrgen E. Schrempp, the embattled chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, now has a good reason to think about something other than a turnaround for Chrysler. He is preparing for his next adventure in fatherhood. When Mr. Schrempp was host of a dinner last Tuesday night at the international automobile show in Geneva, he spent most of his time discussing the merits of disposable diapers and other baby topics. His wife, Lydia Deininger, is due to deliver around the end of March. Mr. Schrempp, 56, has two grown sons from his first marriage. Guests at Mr. Schrempp's table reported that his enthusiasm about the new baby was so strong that he was one of the last to leave. Edmund L. Andrews

description: What is gambling, after all, if not a num bers story with dollar signs and lots of zeros? These days, Indians have a rich tale to tell. There are 195 tribes operating 309 tribal casinos, poker rooms and bingo parlors in 28 states.

title: Is This the End for the SAT?
description: Richard Atkinson, president of the University of California system, recently observed a classroom of 12-year-olds using analogies to extend their mastery of English. Dr. Atkinson realized that these children were preparing for the SAT. They should not have to take the test for another five years. But some students will take it at 12 and then over and over again until it's ''for real.''

title: When Every TV Show Is a Rerun
description: Everyone, it seems, has an explanation for the sudden spate of so-called reality shows like ''Survivor,'' ''Temptation Island'' and even the new XFL football league. They are cheap to produce, they satisfy a voyeuristic urge, they have the frisson of authenticity. But these programs are flourishing for a possibly more significant reason: We are experiencing a deep crisis in narrative.

title: For a Garden Renovation, Radar That Sees 100 Years Ago
description: No structure has been as important to Cape May's revival than the Emlen Physick Estate, a three-story residence built on Washington Street in 1878. The house had been abandoned and was to be demolished when a group of preservation-minded residents persuaded the city to buy it in 1973 and made it the centerpiece in festivals and tours that sparked interest in New Jersey Victorian resort architecture. Last September, the Mid-Atlantic Center for the Arts, which coordinates tours and manages restoration and is housed in the estate, was given $97,651 to begin restoring the landscape. Michael Zuckerman, director of the center, discussed the restoration and its methods.

title: Deficit Hits Waterbury and Residents Try to Cope

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; 'Give Me Rapture and Bliss'
description: Not what love is but what love does: that's the subject of Mary Jo Bang's lush new book of poems, LOUISE IN LOVE (Grove, paper, $13). Bang's book is a verse novella that caroms here and there but essentially revolves around a certain Louise, based loosely on the silent film star Louise Brooks, and a cast of Scott- and Zelda-like characters, including Louise's sister Lydia, her lover, Ham, and various other sybarites. So it helps if you're in the throes of amour as you read -- or at least have memories, preferably fond ones, of a state of mind in which cause and effect seem not to exist and the things of this world are constantly rearranging themselves into startling new combinations. In one poem, the name ''Charlotte'' turns into ''Charcot,'' who was Freud's teacher, and then ''charcuterie,'' and indeed these poems do have the febrile jumpiness of Freudian dreamscapes, not to mention the paintings of Bosch, Dali and Tanguy, whom Louise praises, just as she damns the Northern European school as ''Sterile takes / on quotidian twilight.'' (''Give me rapture and bliss, she told Ham.'') As Bang says in her acknowledgments, she borrows lines from two of literature's world-class emotional athletes, Keats and Woolf, but in its incandescent giddiness the book seems closer to John Ashbery's ''Girls on the Run'' and Peter Klappert's neglected masterpiece ''The Idiot Princess of the Last Dynasty.'' The great melter of boundaries, love is a marvelous tool in this poet's hands, for ultimately it dissolves time itself, so that the end of ''Louise in Love'' is ''the end / that is no end at all but is more like an endless beginning.'' David Kirby

Yet, a day earlier, federal appeals court judges in Washington excoriated Thomas Penfield Jackson, the judge who ordered the breakup of Microsoft, for giving interviews about the case both during and after the trial. This contrast may be perplexing.

title: Lives; Quantifiably Normal
description: I probably shouldn't be telling you this. But I can't keep quiet now, not after hearing Francis Collins sing. The director of the National Human Genome Research Institute was onstage with his band, the Directors, celebrating the sequencing of the human genome. The band plays oldies refitted with gene-related lyrics. Nerdy good fun, right? Then they got to Del Shannon's ''Runaway,'' sung from the perspective of one anonymous donor whose DNA was sequenced. ''I'm a walkin' through the genes/Don't know what all this means/No one else knows that it's me/Behind that G and T.'' I swear Collins was staring right at me as he sang, ''And I wonder, wo-wo-wo-wo-wonder.''

title: High-Beam Smiles, Installed at Home
description: For people who don't have the time for lengthy in-office tooth-whitening treatments, or who just don't like dentists, two at-home alternatives have been introduced. Go Smile, developed by Dr. Jonathan Levine for the Esthetic Whitening Centers of Manhattan, releases an active liquid carbamide peroxide gel -- a whitening agent -- through a tiny vacuum ampule. The user breaks the ampule and squeezes the gel onto a brush tip. It is then applied to the fronts of clean teeth, and rinsed off after three minutes. For long-term effects, the center recommends using Go Smile four times a day, for three weeks. A box of 120 ampules will sell for $120 at www.ewhiten.com in mid-March. For a quicker cosmetics shortcut, Joey New York has Opti Brite, a line of lip pencils ($16) and lipsticks ($17, both at Henri Bendel) containing ''blue botanicals,'' natural dyes in shades like cornflower and safflower, to create the illusion of whiter teeth.

title: Late Innings; Roger Clemens Refuses to Grow Up
description: Roger Clemens is big: 6-4, 240 pounds. He comes from a big state, Texas. He drives a big car, a Chevy Suburban, known as the Texas Cadillac. He lives in a big house, a 16,000-square-foot red-brick minicastle that is a child's fantasy. There are two or three big-screen TV sets in almost every room. There are video games, a sports memorabilia room, a gym and a movie theater with leather seats and animal heads on the walls, and barely a book anywhere. The mansion sits on three acres in the Houston suburbs and is surrounded by a two-mile running track; an enormous heated swimming pool; a large poolside guest house; and a 7,000-square-foot gymnasium with a basketball court, pitcher's mound, batting cage, bleachers and a video-game room. It is the kind of house and property that Tom Hanks would have loved if he had been a Texas country boy and a major-league pitcher with five Cy Young Awards to his credit instead of a New York City toy-company executive jumping on a trampoline in his SoHo loft in the movie ''Big.''

He pulled a slim volume titled ''Desperate Characters'' from the shelf and sat down to look it over. The author's name was Paula Fox. The story -- a ruthless, elegant portrayal of the social paranoia of a bourgeois Brooklyn couple named Sophie and Otto Bentwood -- mesmerized Franzen, so much so that he didn't stop reading until he reached the end. Soon after, he called a bookstore to order a copy of his own; to his dismay, he was told it out was of print.

title: This Little Piggy
description: Goodbye Big Mouth Billy Bass, the singing fish. Farewell robot dog. The animal trinket of the moment is the Naughty Pig, an inch-and-a-half-tall pink plastic key chain that pushes out (and retracts) an odorless brown blob at the rear when squeezed. Yes, the pig is tacky, but it is nonetheless prominent in a popular MTV promotion spot. Not surprisingly, perhaps, the Naughty Pig has also become a favorite among staff members at the Los Angeles headquarters of the animated television show ''South Park.''

title: Delivered to the Door, Wherever the Door Is
description: WALK into the local video store and ask for the film ''Koyaanisqatsi'' and you will likely get a blank stare in response -- even if you have managed to pronounce it correctly. Walk into Best Video in Hamden and ask for the film and they will tell you they have it. Chances are, however, they will also tell you to try back later because it is currently being rented to someone in another time zone.

title: The Quirks of Behavior, as Part of Economics
description: In ''Following the Money, but Also the Mind'' (Feb. 11), Louis Uchitelle discussed the increasing influence of behavioral economists -- those who say economics should do more than assume that people act with rational, unemotional self-interest. The article drew varied responses from many readers. A sampling follows.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-04-01: Point of Purchase; Dog Star
description: When Lara Jo Regan, a photographer in Los Angeles, adopted the tiny, odd-looking stray she found five years ago, she thought he'd make a nice pet. Which is to say, she was thinking old school. But as she noticed the crowds of admirers he attracted, she began to ponder how his ''nuclear cuteness'' could be marketed on the Web. Now Regan has struck a deal that could make her a multimillionaire and Mr. Winkle -- already a multimedia star - into next Christmas's must-have toy. Here's how it happened.

title: Antwerp
description: I'd heard that Antwerp, less than 40 miles north of Brussels and Belgium's second-largest city, was considered one of the hippest spots in Europe. With London prohibitively expensive and Prague pass, it had become, I was told, a favored haunt of the young and beautiful, the fashionable and fabulous, a magnet for aspiring artists and haute couture hopefuls. It was information that gave me -- pulling 40 and unambiguously unhip -- pause. Good food, I thought, but a lot of self-consciously bad haircuts. In anxious preparation for my trip, I bought black pants and cut off my hair.

title: A day trip, along the coast or inland, to England's past
description: Beverley and Whitby are easy day trips from Kingston upon Hull or York, made easier by driving rather than taking public transportation. Usually there are regular direct trains from London's King's Cross Station to York and Hull; tickets are about $36 to $138 round trip, at $1.45 to the pound. Trains to Beverley or Whitby change at Middlesborough and rates vary greatly. Rail Information: (44-16) 1236-3522 or www.railtrack.co.uk . But on Wednesday, the service was disrupted by a rail accident in North Yorkshire. Travelers from London to York must take a bus from Doncaster north; those to Kingston upon Hull must change trains in Doncaster. The disruption is expected to last at least through this week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINTON, SYDNEY C.
description: WINTON-Sydney C. Died March 1, 2001, at the age of 92. Beloved brother of Irma Goldfein. Father of Naomi Schwartz, Joel and Ann. Grandfather of Andrew, Jeffrey and Gregory Winton, Heidi Resnick, Gary Schwartz and greatgrandfather of David and Daniel Winton, Rachel and Sarah Winton, Alicia Winton, Benjamin Schwartz, and Jordan Resnick. Sydney was born in NYC, attended Townsend Harris High School, City College and Columbia Law School. He graduated in 1929 and was co-editor of the Columbia Law Review. He practiced law in NYC for over 50 years and was a senior partner in Botein Hays Sklar. He died peacefully in his home. Graveside services at Montefiore Cemetery on Sunday, March 4, 2001, at 10 AM. Family will sit shiva at his home afterwards.

Recently transformed from a forbidding place of fouled water and huge tankers into an open space that dwarfs Central Park, the harbor would seem to have everything.

title: Over World Protests, Taliban Are Destroying Ancient Buddhas
description: The Great Buddhas of Bamiyan priceless artifacts that 800 years ago survived the wrathful cannon fire of Genghis Khan -- are being steadfastly destroyed bit by bit with hammers, spades and explosives, Afghanistan's Taliban militia stated officially today for the first time.

title: Ecuador and the Galpagos
description: Metropolitan Touring of Ecuador has cut $100 off its 2000 prices for its 7- to 11-night packages that combine a cruise to the Galapagos Islands with a tour of Quito. Hotels in Quito, which is known for its Spanish Colonial art and architecture, include the Radisson Royal, Hilton Colon and J.W. Marriott. The Galapagos segment -- which can last from three to seven nights -- includes all meals during a voyage on the 90-passenger Santa Cruz and a naturalist guide. Prices range from $598 to $2,090 a person, based on double occupancy. Air fare is extra. These are low-season rates, good March 16 to June 14, Sept. 1 to Oct. 31 and Nov. 21 to Dec. 20. Call (800) 527-2500; Web site: www.ecuadorable.com .

title: Exuberance Is Rational
description: I was not surprised to learn of Richard Thaler's theory that we are not entirely rational when making choices about how we spend money (Roger Lowenstein, Feb. 11). If our actions were indeed always rational, then the industries of marketing and advertising to exploit our emotions would not exist. The surprise is that so many others in the world of economics do not take Thaler's ideas seriously.

title: Found in a Country House, a 'Curator's Dream'
description: AFTER 20 years at the National Gallery in London, Dr. Dillian Gordon, the curator of early Italian paintings, had had all too many experiences looking at mystery works. When Richard Carlton-Jones, a specialist in old masters at Sotheby's, phoned last winter asking her to consider another old Italian picture discovered under the stairs of a country house, she tried to put him off so that she could go home to pack for a trip to Italy the next day.

We've spent a few nights in town so I can see his apartment and meet some friends, but now we're off to visit two islands in the Indian Ocean, Lamu and Zanzibar.

title: The Worst Killers Were Unseen
description: ONE hundred sixty years ago, health care on Staten Island meant a family doctor who traveled by horse and buggy. The shift to today's system is outlined at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences in the exhibition ''From House Calls to Hospitals.'' Running simultaneously is ''Epidemics on Staten Island,'' which uses public health documents, prints and original correspondence to chronicle outbreaks of typhoid, tuberculosis, cholera, smallpox and malaria. The image shown above, from The Daily Graphic of Sept. 3, 1878, shows health officers examining arriving shipboard passengers for infectious disease. If the passengers were found to be ill they were transferred to the local quarantine station.

title: Airport Tower Rises Again, Temporarily, After Quake

And with that, officials struggling to recover from the earthquake on Wednesday said today that they hoped to have the busy airport running soon at 90 percent of its normal level.

title: The Nation: Miracle Workers; Let Them Eat Microchips
description: EVEN as George W. Bush settles into his role as the nation's pre-eminent Republican, fissures are showing in the conservative movement. In his campaign Mr. Bush signaled his dissatisfaction at the frosty word ''conservative'' by tacking on a ''compassionate'' at every opportunity, but he has lately run up against unapologetic champions of capitalism, who are propounding a triumphalist message. They are more in the tradition of Ronald Reagan or even Barry M. Goldwater than of the elder George Bush, yet with a futuristic spin.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: EDWARD ALBEE is having a great season at age 72 (73 next week), with his newest work, ''The Play About the Baby,'' driving theater critics wild with praise (well, most of them). But his masterpiece is WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF? (1966), which shocked Broadway audiences in 1962 with its raw language and emotions. It's the portrait of a bad marriage, demonstrated during one night of vitriol in a small college town. Mike Nichols, the film's director, pulled an Oscar-winning performance out of Elizabeth Taylor as the crude, disillusioned, braying middle-aged daughter of the college president. She can't forgive her husband for not having the right career stuff. Richard Burton, magnificent as always, is her spouse, a weary, hostile, ungracious history professor who is never going to head the department. George Segal and Sandy Dennis are the new young marrieds on campus and the lead characters' guests for a late-night get-together that turns ugly and more revealing than anyone meant it to be. Burton and Taylor were practically newlyweds (married in 1964) at the time -- Saturday at midnight on TCM.

title: A Political Food Fight

title: A Mound Of Troubles
description: Sigmund Freud wrote a paper in which he singled out a type he called ''characters wrecked by success.'' What was psychologically behind this wreckage, Freud suggests, was the unconscious ambivalence toward one or another parent. In Ankiel's case, his father looms, it seems, in every pitch. And I would suggest that Ankiel's coming undone on the mound is virtually a testament to how unconsciously responsible he feels for his father's troubles.

title: Taking a Cruise
description: To the Editor: As an experienced sea cruiser I believe the worst new wrinkle in shipboard travel is the different dining room venues. We have found that the best times and best friendships are nurtured only when the same table groups meet at dinner to go over the day's activities -- whether on board or at various ports of call. But sadly on some cruises with dining room options we either wind up eating alone at a single table or having our friends trying to seek us out hurriedly to make reservations together.

title: Mediterranean and Turkish Are the Lure
description: THERE aren't many restaurants that charge as little as $8.95 for a dinner entree and throw in entertainment as well. Yet that's exactly what takes place every Friday and Saturday night at the modest, homey Koch'M Family Grill, at 205 Hempstead Turnpike in West Hempstead (516-505-7634), where patrons watch the exotic gyrations of a Middle Eastern belly dancer while munching on Mediterranean and Turkish main courses like kofte or doner kebabs ($9.95), stuffed cabbage ($8.95) and lamb shank, lamb stew, chicken and adana kebabs ($10.95).

title: Feb. 25-March 3; Powell Abroad
description: On his first swing abroad as secretary of state, Colin L. Powell said he won agreement from Arab nations to tighten military and financial sanctions against the Iraqi leader, Saddam Hussein, in exchange for a loosening of civilian sanctions. This recipe was welcomed with various degrees of warmth by Arab leaders unsettled by the popular outrage on their streets over the suffering of ordinary Iraqis. Of course, Baghdad denounced the policy and continued to demand an end to all sanctions. And Republicans may ask General Powell if he is going soft on Mr. Hussein at a hearing on Capitol Hill this week. Jane Perlez

description: WHAT is to be done with the operas of Giuseppe Verdi? One hundred years after his death, they dominate the repertory around the world. Yet casting them is a headache, and staging them may be an even greater headache. Apart from ''La Traviata'' (1853) and the final Shakespearean masterpieces, ''Otello'' (1887) and ''Falstaff'' (1893), most Verdi is next to impossible for modern audiences to take at face value. description: It was a moment worthy of a James Bond movie: the Pentagon unveiled a weapon that uses electromagnetic waves to disperse crowds -- without causing injuries. The experimental weapon, which is at least five years from deployment, can create a burning sensation -- hot enough to cause a person to jump in pain -- without searing the skin or damaging internal organs, the Pentagon contends. Military officials hope to use the weapon on peacekeeping missions and for defending American embassies and military bases overseas. James Dao

But the community of actors appearing in Jessica Hagedorn's play didn't spring up overnight. It has been cultivated in large part by the Ma-Yi Theater Company, the 12-year-old Off Off Broadway group specifically devoted to developing plays about the Filipino-American experience.

Then he told hand-picked crowds in five states that even after the tax cut, $2 trillion of debt reduction and new spending for education and the military, ''there's still money left over.'' Democrats called the plan a ''shell game'' that would short-change not only domestic needs but also hard-won budget solvency, but Republicans pushed the plan through its first Congressional stop, the House Ways and Means Committee. On the Acela Express 2150 from New York to Back Bay in Boston, the service was excellent, the food was outstanding, far better than anything I have had on an airline, and the train left and arrived on time. title: On a High Note

His name was Alessandro Moreschi, and he sang for the Vatican, which well into the 19th century employed a number of such singers. You can hear Moreschi on some scratchy recordings made in 1902 and 1904; he sounds a little like your grandmother -- thin, quavery and not always on key. The legendary castrati like Farinelli and Caffarelli must have sounded better. Their voices made them the rock stars of the 18th century, singers of tremendous fame and wealth, for whom composers like Handel wrote some of their flashiest and most glamorous operatic music.

For a short time, life is a playground, not a battlefield. The days seem longer and more languid, the sun brighter and the stars more sparkly. Have you seen these ads? Over a speedy montage of verdant rice paddies, smiling Asian kids and kindly third-world doctors, a caring voice describes something called golden rice and its promise to ''help prevent blindness and infection in millions of children'' suffering from vitamin-A deficiency. This new rice has been engineered, using a daffodil gene, to produce beta-carotene, a nutrient the body can convert into vitamin A. Watching the pitch, you can almost feel the moral ground shifting under your feet. For the unspoken challenge here is that if we don't get over our queasiness about eating genetically modified food, kids in the third world will go blind.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; And Ye Shall Know Them
description: The New York graphic design studio Chermayeff & Geismar has been creating trademarks since 1960, including some of the country's most ubiquitous corporate logos: the NBC peacock, the Mobil trademark with the red O, the Chase bank octagon and the three east-facing heads of PBS. TM: Trademarks Designed by Chermayeff & Geismar (Princeton Architectural Press, $40) is a chronological selection of the studio's work by its partners, Ivan Chermayeff, Tom Geismar and Steff Geissbuhler. Each design is given a full page without explanatory captions, working drawings or even examples of the trademarks that were replaced. The effect is somewhat misleading. Logos evolve, and these are no exception. The NBC peacock emblem, for instance, was not actually originated by Chermayeff & Geismar, but adapted in the 1970's from a commercial broadcast in 1956 to show off the network's new color technology. Similarly, some of the logos presented here as stand-alone works of art might have been more helpfully pictured in their natural habitat, among rival company insignia, where they gain meaning and status from a shared visual language. As this book illustrates, Chermayeff & Geismar played a significant role in the development of corporate identity -- only in the latter half of the 20th century did corporations begin diligently applying a single badge to every manifestation of their business. By omitting context, however, this book encourages the reader to simply marvel at the design studio's proficiency. And that is only half the story. Peter Hall

Both require planning, attention to detail, teamwork and an appreciative audience, but that's as far as it goes. In this age of individual self-expression and self-realization, I think we want to believe that whatever we do is worthy of some kind of honor. The irony is that with so many demanding attention, there are fewer of us left in the stands to actually cheer.

title: Food; Fear of Frying

We are guilty about sex, guilty about working too hard and making too much money, guilty about invading other countries (sometimes) and mostly, guilty about wanting to eat fried food. Well, we should be guilty about having sex -- it's a terrible thing to do with free time when we could be working harder. We should also be guilty about working too hard, because that means we don't have time for a leisurely lunch in Luxembourg. And we should be guilty about invading other countries; otherwise, we'd invade them all. But the good news is that we no longer have to feel guilt about our sneaky liaisons with fried food.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius, by Dave Eggers. (Vintage, $14.) The author lost both his parents to cancer in a span of 32 days, leaving him at 21 to raise his 8-year-old brother. After moving to California from the Midwest, the two embarked on a ''campaign of distraction'' that blended antic, slacker freedom with traditional parenting methods. His intensely self-conscious, often hilarious memoir, which was chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, includes a new appendix correcting and updating the original. ''Eggers's real achievement is to provide a counterweight to what Ian Frazier once called 'the encroaching Hefty bag of death,' and to write about it, in our age of irony, with genuine, unsentimental poignancy,'' Sara Mosle wrote here.

title: Rockies by Rail
description: To the Editor: A question about rail travel in your Q & A column ''Rockies By Rail'' (Jan. 21), referred the reader to Rail Travel Center in Brattleboro, Vt. That company is a rail tour operator and while it will sell its own tours and others, it does not organize individual train trips. As an ardent fan of travel by train, I use an agency across the river in New Hampshire, Ascutney Travel, 46 Tremont Square, Claremont, N.H. 03743, (800) 872-4674. It specializes in train travel all over the world and while it books rail tours, it will sell individual train and ferry tickets and customize a tour to suit one's interests and needs.

title: Kappabashi Dori
description: The words ''too many dishes'' make absolutely no sense to me. My crockery-buying proclivities have amazed and more than occasionally dismayed my traveling companions -- especially when they were enlisted to help carry the bundles. So imagine my delight at having a day to myself on Kappabashi Dori, the Tokyo street where restaurant owners go to stock up on knives, bento boxes, plastic food and all the cunning, heterogeneous cups, bowls and saucers that serve forth a Japanese meal. With a few exceptions, customers don't have to buy in bulk, so I could buy or not, merrily poking around in its focused, jampacked shops, with no one asking pointed questions about how many miso bowls or sake cups one Western household could absorb.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT RATE
description: While the nation's unemployment rate continues to climb, New Jersey's continues to fall. The state's jobless rate in January fell 0.2 percentage points to 3.6 percent, its lowest monthly rate since March 1970, according to figures released last week by the New Jersey Department of Labor. The figures, however, did not reflect recent corporate layoffs, such as those by Lucent Technologies, based in Murray Hill, which is letting go 10,000 workers -- 1,500 of them in New Jersey. Nonetheless, in a week when the economic news nationally was mostly bad, labor analysts were cheered by the fact the state's unemployment rate for the 13th consecutive month had fallen below the national rate, which was 4.2 percent in January. George James

Consider the passions over the enfranchisement of blacks and slaves after the Civil War, the granting of women's suffrage, the passage of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, and the lowering of the voting age to 18 from 21 to match the draft age during the Vietnam War. In each case, the country was moved, eventually, by its self-image as the guardian of the ideal of enfranchisement.

The telephone never stopped trilling and, four days after she was nominated as best supporting actress for her performance as the artist Lee Krasner in the film ''Pollock,'' every available surface was crowded with enormous floral arrangements from producers, agents and industry honchos. The bowl of beautiful pink roses and lavender sweet peas was from Winona Ryder, whom Ms. Harden doesn't even know. Taped to the front door and over the mantel were full-color trade-paper ads congratulating her. Perhaps Ms. Harden was feeling self-conscious about the wall art. She got up from her brown leather couch and began pulling down the makeshift banners.

Twenty paces later, fat raindrops began falling and I scurried under the wooden eaves of a tiny refreshment shack.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOKANSON, BEN A. CAPTAIN
description: HOKANSON-Ben A. Captain. Retired Master Mariner and Commodore of the Grace Line Fleet, died on Wednesday, February 28, as a result of a heart attack, he was 91. Born in Munkfors, Sweden on May 5, 1909 Captain Hokanson's education on a square rigged Swedish naval training vessel led to his emigration to the United States in 1928. He served his newly adopted homeland at sea, in the U.S. Merchant Marine and the United States Naval Reserve, for the next 47 years. He worked his way from ships carpenter to Captain and Commodore of the Grace Line Fleet, the largest merchant fleet of the United States registry. Commissioned a Lt. Commander during World War II, he served in the both the Atlantic and Pacific theaters on numerous supply and troop convoys. He served as Convoy Commodore at the invasion of Casablanca, and received shrapnel wounds at Linguyan Gulf during the invasion of Okinawa. Captain Hokanson enjoyed carpentry, sailing and gardening, however his greatest pleasure came from reading and a love of learning. As a student of current affairs and history, he immersed himself daily in newspapers as well as books in English, Spanish and Swedish. He was well versed on many subjects, and fluent in eight languages. For 63 years he documented his daily observations on life at sea, the weather, world events and human nature. Married to Helen Eleanor Slaby of Washington, PA in 1939. He is survived by his sister Ingrid Rydman of Honigen, Sweden, his daughter, Jean Christina, of Everett, Washington, son John, of West Palm Beach, FL, and son Charles of Collegeville, PA. A viewing will be held from 1 PM to 2 PM on Sunday, March 4, 2001, at the Whitting Funeral Home, on Glen Cove Ave. in Glen Head, New York.

title: How They Crunch the Oscar Numbers
description: Oscar voting is a two-tiered system: First, the nominating ballots go out to the 5,685 members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, each of whom has been admitted to the academy on the basis of past credits. The entire membership, consulting a list of eligible pictures, nominates in the best picture category, but only actors nominate actors; directors, directors; sound technicians, sound technicians. For each category, members write down the names of their five favorites in order of rank. These ballots are returned to Pricewaterhouse, where each category is counted by a team of two accountants using a system that assigns more weight to first- place votes than to second-place votes, more to second than to third, and so on. The figures are then reviewed two or three times. The five top vote-getters in each category become the nominees.

title: I Scream, You Scream: Consumers Vent Over the Net

title: A Hymn To England's Divinity
description: BEGINNING on Thursday, at Avery Fisher Hall, Colin Davis and the New York Philharmonic will continue their journey into the land of Elgar with one of the composer's biggest works, the oratorio ''The Dream of Gerontius.'' This will be the first Philharmonic performance of the work, which has been around for more than a century, a fact that is not too surprising, given the general lack of interest here in Elgar's music until recently and the special qualities, musical and thematic, of this particular piece. When it was new, in 1900, ''Gerontius'' barely survived even on home territory, in England.

Just the right size for a public that consistently shows mistrust of ''government'' but strong support for individual government programs. A careful middle ground.

title: Blooms Under The Volcano
description: IDEALLY, a visitor seeking out the gardens of the Big Island would start with the volcano, for that is where all the elements originate -- soil, topography, even weather, with clouds dumping rain on the volcano's windward side and dissipating before they reach the lee. Thanks to the volcano, Big Island gardens, as I discovered on a trip in late January, cover the entire spectrum of cultivated tropical landscape: orchid-studded jungle perpetually glazed by rain; barely cool black lava desert where gnarled kiawe trees grow alongside flamboyant bougainvillea; upcountry fields fringed by breadfruit trees and hibiscus. In the green world, everything depends on your height and position on the volcano, or rather family of volcanoes: 13,796-foot-high Mauna Kea, only slightly lower Mauna Loa, and actively smoking and spewing Kilauea.

title: Feb. 25-March 3; Congo Inches Toward Peace

The two support rebels fighting the government, and the hope is that the government's allies, Angola, Zimbabwe and Namibia, will reciprocate. title: How They Crunch the Oscar Numbers
description: Oscar voting is a two-tiered system: First, the nominating ballots go out to the 5,685 members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, each of whom has been admitted to the academy on the basis of past credits. The entire membership, consulting a list of eligible pictures, nominates in the best picture category, but only actors nominate actors; directors, directors; sound technicians, sound technicians. For each category, members write down the names of their five favorites in order of rank. These ballots are returned to Pricewaterhouse, where each category is counted by a team of two accountants using a system that assigns more weight to first- place votes than to second-place votes, more to second than to third, and so on. The figures are then reviewed two or three times. The five top vote-getters in each category become the nominees.

title: Dolphin Study Program Isn't All Work, No Play

The Blackbird-Oceanic Society Field Station, which opened in January on Blackbird Cay, 32 miles southeast of Belize City, is run by the Oceanic Society, a conservation organization. Participants in the society's eight-day dolphin project, available year-round, help monitor the behavior of the more than 100 free-ranging dolphins in the warm, exceptionally clear waters surrounding Blackbird Cay and the mangrove- and beach-fringed Turneffe Islands.

The revocation, which prohibits him from working for a casino for at least five years, was for deceiving his employers and gaming regulators, not for having a gambling problem, James Hurley, Casino Control Commission chairman, said in a written statement. After admitting in 1995 that he was addicted to gambling, Mr. DiBartolomeo was allowed to continue working though prohibited from gambling, but instead racked up at least $389,000 in gambling debts, Mr. Hurley said. A centripetal force in muscular entertainments like ''Romper Stomper,'' ''L.A. Confidential,'' ''The Insider'' and this year's leading Academy Award contender, ''Gladiator,'' he has made a reputation playing characters who are as likely to suffer bruising unhappiness as to dole it out. And he's done so without a hint of irony. Even when wearing a wolf skin and a skirt, and voicing a Hollywood call to battle not heard since Samson and Victor Mature, Mr. Crowe, nominated two years running for best actor, keeps a straight face. ''Unleash hell'' may be the war cry of Maximus, the extravagantly martyred Roman general he plays in ''Gladiator,'' but it isn't a stretch to think it's that of Mr. Crowe as well.

Unesco, the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York and a leading Islamic scholar in Cairo were also among those begging the Taliban not to carry out their threat to the Bamiyan statues and other Buddha images in museums across the country. The Taliban had pledged to preserve them as important treasures from the country's pre-Islamic past -- and a part of the whole world's artistic and religious heritage -- but a religious figure in Kabul ordered them destroyed. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAGHER, C. SHEILA
description: MEAGHER-C. Sheila. Of New York City, on February 27 at age 75, after a long illness. She was born in Brooklyn, NY, daughter of the late Peter W. and Julia Sullivan Meagher and sister of the late Monica M. Brinson. She was a graduate of St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn, NY. Sheila enjoyed a long career in the insurance industry which culminated in her appointment as the first female Assistant Vice President of Johnson & Higgins. She is survived by her sister, Margaret M. Lundebjerg of West Hartford, CT, and brother, Peter W. Meagher, Jr. of Maui, HI, seven nieces and nephews, and eight grandnieces and nephews. A memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, March 24th at 11 AM, at the Church of the Epiphany, 239 E. 21st St, NYC. The internment will be private. For those desiring, memorial contributions may be made to: St. Joseph's College, Brooklyn Campus Alumni Scholarship Fund, 245 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11205.

He had been relegated to drawing portraits of people on subway trains in sketchbooks partially because he had nowhere to paint. title: Can Aristide Govern in Haiti?
description: When President Jean-Bertrand Aristide took over Haiti last month, he was a different man from the popular priest who swept into office only a decade ago. Mr. Aristide is not the only one who has changed. The country has descended deeper into poverty, and Mr. Aristide, who was never popular with the moneyed elite, has also managed to turn some of his staunchest allies -- the intellectual left -- into bitter enemies. They have vowed to make his five-year term difficult, if not impossible. But if Mr. Aristide is to be successful, he must find a way to please groups with seemingly conflicting interests, and his tenure will be defined by how well he manages to appease Haitians living abroad, foreign leaders and the Haitian elite.

description: WINTON-Sydney C. Died March 1, 2001, at the age of 92. Beloved brother of Irma Goldfein. Father of Naomi Schwartz, Joel and Ann. Grandfather of Andrew, Jeffrey and Gregory Winton, Heidi Resnick, Gary Schwartz and greatgrandfather of David and Daniel Winton, Rachel and Sarah Winton, Alicia Winton, Benjamin Schwartz, and Jordan Resnick. title: Glimmerings of a Congo Peace
description: Congo's civil war has included so many moving parts and so many players acting in bad faith that it has been difficult to imagine a peaceful settlement. A peace accord signed in 1999 failed to arrest fighting that has drawn in six neighboring countries and claimed some 1.7 million lives. But recent developments offer tentative grounds for hope that the major belligerents may finally believe that peace is in their interest. It is for that reason that the United Nations Security Council wisely agreed last month to a plan for withdrawal of all foreign troops from Congo that could set the stage for a long-delayed U.N. peacekeeping mission.

Maier clocked 1 minute 28.58 seconds, beating countrymen Hannes Trinkl and Stefan Eberharter by 0.06 and 0.84 seconds, respectively. Christoph Gruber of Austria, Maier's closest super-G rival, dropped out of the race after a fall, leaving him 174 points off the lead with the season-ending race in Are, Sweden, scheduled for Wednesday.

title: Mines Maim the Ultimate Civilians: Animals
description: It was grazing time, a break from the heavy labor of rolling logs through the forest along the heavily mined Burmese border, and four huge elephants and a baby were lolling among the succulent bamboo.

title: Tired of the Same Old Jokes? So Is This Festival
description: Forget those traditional stand-up jokes about the wife, the kids and of course the mother-in-law. A wave of comedy that is personal, off-center and unpredictable is stirring a new generation of comedians.

title: Rockies' Hampton, the Education Pitcher, Is Sticking to His Story
description: As Mike Hampton talked in the family bullpen yesterday along the right-field line, 1-year-old Griffen kept running at him in attack mode. His father repeatedly scooped him up deftly like a ground ball and slung him over his shoulder. This was play time for Griffen Hampton. The younger of the Hamptons' two sons, he is a few years away from reaching school age, so he will not immediately benefit from the decision his father made to work in Colorado.

title: Lowe Group and Havas Reorganize Top Offices
description: The Lowe Group in London and New York and Havas Advertising in Paris are reorganizing operations.

title: Any Way You Look at It, The Story Is Not Pleasant
description: Few works of fiction have explored the relative and elusive nature of truth with such force as ''Rashomon,'' a tale of sex and death first told in stories by Ryunosuke Akutagawa, made into a classic film by Akira Kurosawa in 1950 and turned into a Broadway play in 1959 by Fay and Michael Kanin. Under the taut direction of Tisa Chang, the Pan Asian Repertory has mounted a commendable revival that is all the more striking for its simplicity.

title: Sports of The Times; Tiger Woods Joins Golf's 'Disaster Club'
description: TIED for the lead in the Dubai Desert Classic yesterday, Tiger Woods watched his tee shot on the 18th hole soar to the right and skid into the sand among some palm trees near a pond.

title: Creator of 'X-Files' Lifts His Profile
description: Throughout his career, Chris Carter, creator of Fox's ''X-Files,'' has kept a low profile, maintaining the sort of mystique that is common to the enigmatic characters of his hit science fiction series. Until now.

title: N.C.A.A. Bid At Stake, Iona Plays Canisius
description: Iona forward Dyree Wilson said that Monday, March 5, was the only date he had entered on his Palm Pilot before the season. He knew the occasion: the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference championship game.

title: Critical Path Says Problems Were Limited to One Quarter
description: The new management of Critical Path, an Internet software company, said late last week that the questionable accounting practices that left its reputation in tatters were largely confined to its fourth-quarter sales in the United States.

title: Census Figures May Give City A Bonus Prize
description: When detailed results of the 2000 census come surging out of Washington this month in a river of numbers that will flow for several years, planners for New York City cautiously expect, the city's population count will turn out significantly higher than estimates suggest.

title: Critic's Notebook; Fireworks or Fallbacks for a New River City?
description: Lightning struck the skyline twice last week. Two bright flashes lit up the future of architecture in New York. First came the announcement that Arquitectonica, the Miami-based firm, had been hired to design a set of residential high-rises for Queens West, the mixed-use waterfront development across the East River from the United Nations headquarters. Then came the news that five teams of architects would be competing to create a master plan for the development of the nine-acre Con Edison site, just south of the United Nations.

title: 'Seinfeld' Star Planning Pilot With NBC
description: In an unusual deal based on an unusual format for a TV series, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, one of the stars of the NBC comedy hit ''Seinfeld,'' will make a pilot for a new comedy for NBC that, if made, could spur changes in the traditional economics of a television series and the scheduling of the network prime-time season.

title: Ailing Camby Out Another Game
description: Marcus Camby watched the Knicks' 98-88 loss to the Toronto Raptors from the training room, where he received electric stimulation treatment for his painful back spasms. Camby, who missed his second straight game, said he hoped to play in Tuesday's home game against Indiana, but he sounded discouraged.

description: To the Editor:

title: Compressed Data; Judges Use Laptops In Microsoft Appeal
description: Last week, while lawyers for the Justice Department and the Microsoft Corporation presented their oral arguments in the appeal of the antitrust case against the company, the judges hearing the appeal used laptop computers to communicate with their clerks and to study legal documents during the proceedings.

description: Hector Camacho, one of boxing's biggest draws in his prime, was arrested early yesterday at an East Harlem nightclub on a charge of cocaine possession, the police said.

description: An article on Saturday about a couple's testimony on the violence in Central Park after a parade last June misstated the name of the event. It was the National Puerto Rican Day Parade, not the Puerto Rican National Day Parade.

description: An American evangelical relief group that is using private donations and United States government money to help victims of two earthquakes has blurred the line between church and state as its volunteers preach, pray and seek converts among people desperate for help.

description: A year ago this month, voters here made history by sweeping the Nationalist Party out of power for the first time in 55 years -- or, at least, so they thought.

title: A Narrow Energy Bill
description: Give Senator Frank Murkowski this much. He has offered the first major bill in a decade aimed at overhauling the country's energy policies. But the Alaska Republican's 300-page measure is not by any stretch a blueprint for a measured policy that balances responsible development with energy conservation. Despite some nods toward energy efficiency, it is essentially an oil driller's bill. The larger danger is that it could serve as a template for the cabinet-level task force appointed by President Bush to devise a comprehensive national energy strategy. That panel, which is led by Vice President Dick Cheney, an oilman himself, is already disposed to honor Mr. Bush's campaign pledge to sweep away regulatory impediments to new exploration. If the panel endorses Mr. Murkowski's approach, environmentalists and their Congressional allies should be ready for a protracted and difficult struggle on Capitol Hill.

title: Amid Memories of No. 3, Gordon Finishes No. 1
description: Lines formed 10 deep around the Dale Earnhardt merchandise trailer today as fans continued their patient vigil to buy anything adorned with the No. 3 of Earnhardt's black Chevrolet Monte Carlo. A prerace flyover by three jet fighters, not the traditional four, from nearby Nellis Air Force Base was done in Earnhardt's honor.

Grady, the second-seeded team, advanced to the semifinals next Saturday at St. John's. Sammy Mejia, the P.S.A.L.'s leading scorer, had a game-high 28 points for Roosevelt. Brandon Lilly

The bridge equivalent is a uni-table, or one-table duplicate game, and there have been several recent sightings of this remarkable creature.

description: If you think public radio is a civilized world, you will be comforted by the topics on the online message boards of ''The Connection,'' an erudite radio talk show owned by the Boston station WBUR-FM. Online, the show's listeners revisit program topics like ''The History of Zero,'' ''Minimalist Music'' and ''Ayn Rand: The Virtue of Selfishness.''

title: PIRELLI UNIT GETS OLYMPICS NETWORK CONTRACT
description: A telecommunications systems unit of Pirelli Sp.A. has signed a $125 million contract to build an underwater optical fiber network for Silk Route Holdings. The system, which will allow the 2004 Olympic Games to be broadcast over the Internet, will link Athens to Crete and Northern Italy, Pirelli said. Branches to Southern Italy, Slovenia and Crotia are also expected. As a subcontractor, Siemens AG will provide technology that routes and protects the initial volume of traffic carried by the system, Pirelli said.

description: WASHINGTON, March 5  The Library of Congress was ordered today to fix fire safety violations that threatened treasures like a Gutenberg Bible, Thomas Jefferson's personal library and 30,000 recordings on cylinders that predate phonograph records.

title: DAEWOO TO REOPEN PLANT
description: Daewoo Motor said yesterday that its plant in the Pupyong district of Inchon, about 20 miles west of Seoul, would resume production Wednesday despite union threats to stop it. A spokesman said the bankrupt company anticipated violence by the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions but counted on police to protect the facilities. The company laid off 1,750 workers last month after suspending production at the plant while selling off inventory. The union said members would surround the plant, keeping its 7,000 remaining workers from entering, unless the company reinstated those who lost their jobs. Don Kirk

description: In his first move to put a more personal stamp on the program department at NBC, Jeff Zucker, president of NBC Entertainment, named Jeff Gaspin executive vice president for programming yesterday, putting him in charge of movies, program strategy and what is now known as alternative series.

title: Drug's Effect On Brain Is Extensive, Study Finds
description: Heavy users of methamphetamine -- a highly addictive stimulant that can be made at home in the kitchen sink -- are doing more damage to their brains than scientists had thought, according to the first study that looked inside addicts' brains nearly a year after they stopped using the drug.

title: Guns in Young Hands
description: The school shooting in suburban San Diego yesterday that killed 2 students and wounded 13 students and adults was clearly the worst since the Columbine High School massacre in April 1999. But there have been others. Last February, for example, a first grader in Michigan killed a 6-year-old classmate, and in May a 13-year-old in Florida killed a teacher. The episode also follows a disturbing sequence of near-disasters that have been averted because students kept their eyes and ears open and summoned up the courage to alert police to the possibility of a shooting. Sadly enough, there appear to have been warning signs in the San Diego case that were not taken seriously.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISAACSON, H. HARDING COLONEL
description: ISAACSON-H. Harding Colonel. Died February 26, 2001, in Lenox Hill Hospital, Manhattan, in his 80th year. The New York Society of Military and Naval Officers wishes to express its deepest sympathy for the loss of our Quartermaster, Col. H. Harding Isaacson, who gave his utmost in the service of his country during WWII and as an active member of the military and veteran community within New York State up to the day of his death. Col. Isaacson distinguished himself in WWII flying 30 missions over occupied France and Germany in a heavy bombardment group that was awarded the Croix de Guerre by the French government after the war period. After being discharged from the Army Air Corps in 1945, Col. Isaacson continued his military career in the US Air Force Reserves, where he served for 5 years, and the New York State Guard where he served as an officer for many years in the 9th Regiment. Some of his most serious contributions to the military and veteran community in New York State were made as a colonel in the Veteran Corp of Artillary of the State of New York, which is the honor guard of the Governer of New York, and as commander of his American Legion Post in Sayville, Long Island. Col. Isaacson received numerous federal, state and foreign military medals and awards throughout his extensive military career. Col. Isaacson is survived by his lovely wife Janet, one nephew and two nieces. To them The New York Society of Military and Naval Officers extend our deepest sympathies. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, March 8, 2001, at 2pm at The Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, corner of East 90th St and 5th Ave, Manhattan. May the soul of this brave and beloved soldier rest in peace. Major Daniel King, President Col. Jerome Richard, Treasurer

title: Cinnamon Reef Resort, Anguilla
description: This one will work for travelers with hearty appetites. The Cinnamon Reef Resort, a 22-suite hotel on the Caribbean island of Anguilla, is rebating up to $700 a person in air fare expenses (maximum of two guests to a room) for anyone booking a Villa suite at $425 a night, double occupancy, for seven nights. The stay must be completed by April 4, and the room rate does not include 18 percent in tax. The $700 reimbursement is in the form of a food and drink credit posted on the guests bills on arrival. The credit is good for all meals, bar drinks and wine with dinner. Guests who cannot stay a week get a credit of $100 a night. And guests who use frequent-flier mileage to acquire their ticket also are eligible. The rates include use of watersports equipment; rooms are fan-cooled. Call (800) 223-1108 or book through a travel agent.

title: NEC WILL USE AMD CHIPS IN FOREIGN PC'S
description: Advanced Micro Devices said yesterday that the NEC Corporation would use AMD's Athlon and Duron processors in the PowerMate DT commercial desktop computers. In a press release, AMD said the PowerMate DT would initially be aimed at large corporate and government markets in Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands. The deal could be a major step in AMD's effort to gain legitimacy with corporate PC buyers, who have shunned its products in favor of those using Intel chips.

title: When Slaves And Currency Were One; Interpreting the Images of Toil That The Confederacy Used on Its Money
description: Without a magnifying glass, it is difficult to see the faces on the slaves as they harvest cotton and hoist overflowing baskets to their shoulders. Minutely engraved on the tattered currency of the old South, the images are faded and smudged, and their message has languished in the vaults of collectors.

title: ARTHUR ANDERSEN ANNOUNCES NAME CHANGE
description: The accounting firm of Arthur Andersen announced yesterday that it dropped its first name, capitalizing on an arbitration decision last year that both separated it from its consulting arm, Andersen Consulting, and required Andersen Consulting to stop using the Andersen name. Andersen Consulting has called itself Accenture since Jan. 1. Jonathan D. Glater

title: The Victims in Indonesia's Pursuit of Progress
description: The recent bloody fighting in Borneo makes compelling copy. The violence seems savage, the context exotic. Yet the killings, with at least 400 dead in the past two weeks, are not as remote as they might seem. The Madurese migrants being attacked by the indigenous Dayak people of Central Kalimantan Province are scapegoats for the failed economic and social policies that Indonesia, with American support, has followed for far too long.

title: Young Suspect's Mother Asks, 'Oh, God. Why?'
description: She spoke calmly and gave terse replies to a reporter's questions about her son, saying she had talked just briefly today with the boy's father, from whom she is divorced, and had heard only that there had been a shooting at Santana High School.

title: Now, Choices in Heart Bypass Surgery
description: Coronary bypass surgery to circumvent clogged arteries that feed the heart has, since its inception in the 1960's, brought relief from crippling chest pain and significantly prolonged life for millions of people.

title: A Hard-Working Spacecraft Leaves Its Handlers Beaming
description: For a spacecraft that did not follow its script -- it was almost lost twice, then missed its destination on the first pass and finally arrived a year behind schedule -- NASA's NEAR Shoemaker spacecraft has far exceeded expectations.

title: Afghans Reject Appeals to Spare Statues
description: The leader of Afghanistan's ruling Taliban movement said today that the world had been making an unnecessary ''drama'' about the campaign to destroy the country's statues, including two huge and ancient sculptures of Buddha.

title: Missouri Set To Execute Retarded Man
description: With the mother of the two sisters who were his victims asking that his life be spared because of his youth and mental deficiencies, Antonio Richardson is scheduled to be executed on Wednesday morning by the State of Missouri. He was 16 at the time of his crimes and has been classified as mildly mentally retarded by experts.

title: Soriano's Inspired Play Opens Yankees' Eyes to Possibilities
description: All Alfonso Soriano needs, one of his former managers once said, is a clear sense of direction. Tell him what it will take to make the big leagues, and he will do what you ask and he will do it well. Yankees Manager Joe Torre gave Soriano his mission statement last week, and since then, Soriano has been the team's best player in camp and is forcing his way into consideration for a major league job.

title: On the Sled Trail, the Dogs Never Doze
description: Unseasonably warm weather and a lack of snow postponed Alaska's Iditarod sled dog race this year, but here in the northern tip of Maine, temperatures hovered around 20 degrees below zero for the start of the Can Am Crown 250, known as the Iditarod of the East. On Saturday morning, a record field of 27 mushers and 320 dogs crowded Meadow Lane off Main Street here.

title: Lowe's to Test Appliances
description: The Lowe's Companies, which sells such appliance brands as Maytag and Whirlpool, said today that it would test sales of the Viking Range Corporation's high-priced stoves and refrigerators to attract more affluent customers. Lowe's will begin selling the appliances by special order at Lowe's stores in Las Vegas this month. They will be sold in conjunction with SunWest Appliance Distributing of Tempe, Ariz., Lowe's said. Viking stoves are sold for $2,700 to $8,500, said Dale Persons, Viking's vice president for market support. Lowe's, based in Wilkesboro, N.C., trails Sears, Roebuck & Company in United States retail appliance sales. Lowe's shares rose 5 cents, to $57.15.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, CLIFFORD COLMER
description: NELSON-Clifford Colmer. Died on Saturday, February 24, 2001 in Tempe, AZ. Born on November 1, 1914 in Jersey City, NJ, he was graduated with a BS from Trinity College in Hartford, CT. He also held an M.A. from Columbia University, and LLD from Lawrence University and an LHD from Trinity College. During WWII he served in Military Intelligence, Fort Dix, NJ and in Military Government in Europe. In 1945 he taught English and Comparative Literature at Columbia University until, in 1954, he became an officer of the American Assembly, a public affairs education organization founded at Columbia in 1951 by Dwight Eisenhower, when he was president of Columbia. The American Assembly periodically held national meetings at Arden House, its conference center in Harriman, NY and published authoritative books and reports of recommendations for governmental policy on issues of national concern. Mr. Nelson helped to establish a network of educational conferences in the U.S. and abroad with more than 125 institutions, chiefly colleges and universities, and once with the British Museum. In 1963, he succeeded Henry M. Wriston as president of the American Assembly and held that post until his retirement in 1979. From 1960, he was a member/director of the Public Affairs Committee, Inc., publisher of Public Affairs Pamphlets, and for years served as its chairman. He was also for years a member of the Council on Foreign Relations and the Century Association. His children, Nikki Neysa DiFranks, Eamon George Nelson, Dana Tecla Nelson, and his grandson, Frederick Locke Crabbe, IV, survive him. Also surviving are his stepdaughters, Callie Angell and Alice Angell. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, Saturday March 10, 2001 at 1 PM.

There seemed to be two kinds of interpretation on offer in Sir Colin Davis's all-Mozart program with the New York Philharmonic on Thursday evening at Avery Fisher Hall. But perhaps the first, an oddly cautious account of the Symphony No. 25 in G minor, was more a matter of warming to the occasion than an expression of artistic prerogatives.

description: Prime Minister-elect Ariel Sharon put the final elements of his unity government together today as police officers stood guard throughout the country in a state of high alert, braced for a repetition of the terror bombing that killed three Israelis and wounded scores more in a coastal city on Sunday.

description: After negotiations that spilled over past an original deadline, and at one point came close to breaking down, NBC and Paramount Television announced an agreement today that will keep the hit show "Frasier" at NBC for three more years.

title: VIACOM SAYS A TOP EXECUTIVE IS STEPPING DOWN
description: Viacom, owner of the CBS television network, said its chief financial officer, Fredric Reynolds, would step down to take another post that will let him spend more time with his family in Southern California. Mr. Reynolds will help Viacom's president, Mel Karmazin, find a successor as chief financial officer, a spokesman, Carl Folta, said, and will assume a new executive position for the New York-based company on the West Coast. He will report to Mr. Karmazin. Mr. Reynolds had been chief financial officer at Westinghouse, CBS and then Viacom since 1994. Mr. Reynolds, 50, joined Viacom last year when it acquired CBS, which had been acquired by the Westinghouse Electric in 1995. Analysts said Mr. Reynolds had been a key figure in the conversion of Westinghouse from a maker of industrial machinery into a television and radio broadcaster.

title: CHINA SHARES SURGE AGAIN
description: China's foreign-currency denominated B shares rose by their daily 10 percent limit for the fourth consecutive trading day. The market's trading volume increased tenfold from Friday as more people began parting with their shares, suggesting that the remarkable rally may be nearing its peak. A lack of sellers last week kept the market's trading volume unusually low. The government set off the rally by lifting a ban on domestic investors in the hard-currency stock market, which had been reserved for foreigners. Craig S. Smith

title: Judge Orders Napster to Police Trading
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 6  A federal judge has ordered Napster to curb the exchange of copyrighted music on its Internet service, a ruling that threatens to cripple the company and to undermine the activities of millions of people who flock to Napster each day to freely copy songs.

description: James A. Rhodes, a four-term Republican governor of Ohio who was known at home as a builder and booster of his state but remembered nationally more for sending onto the Kent State University campus the national guardsmen who killed four students there, died on Sunday at the Ohio State University Medical Center in Columbus, the city where he lived. He was 91.

title: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC BUYS CATHETER INNOVATIONS
description: The Boston Scientific Corporation said yesterday that it had bought Catheter Innovations Inc., its fourth acquisition in three weeks, as the medical-device maker expands its product line to boost revenue. Boston Scientific, which is based in Natick, Mass., did not disclose terms. The company has been seeking to increase sales after its market share for medical devices called stents dropped to about 17 percent from about 30 percent in 1999. The addition Catheter Innovations, a closely held company based in Salt Lake City, will increase Boston Scientific's presence in the $500 million market for intravenous delivery products, the company said.

Chelsea Interactive, whose parent, Chelsea Property Group, operates Timberland outlet stores in the United States and Japan, will create an e-commerce site for the Timberland, Mountain Athletics and Timberland Pro brands. The cost was not disclosed. Chelsea Interactive, based in New York, was created in July to help retailers save money and time developing Internet sites. It operates sites for brands like Nike's Cole Haan and Liz Claiborne's Elisabeth. Chelsea Property, in Roseland, N.J., is one of the nation's largest developers of factory outlets, which include Woodbury Common Premium Outlets near New York City.

The switches are expected to be installed by the end of the current year, and will boost calling capacity while reducing equipment and operating costs, according to Nextel.

title: Just Too Saintly for His Own Good
description: The Manhattan Ensemble Theater is a brand-new SoHo-based company with the stated mission of dramatizing classic novels. For its inaugural offering, its founder and artistic director, David Fishelson, has chosen ''The Idiot,'' based on his own adaptation of Dostoyevsky's 1868 novel about the saintly epileptic Prince Myshkin and his ultimately tragic engagement with a society that has lost its moral compass. A revival of sorts -- Mr. Fishelson first staged it in 1992 at the Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater, and he has engaged the same actor, John Lenartz, in the title role here -- the production makes the company's serious ambitions clear, and it doesn't shy from the complexities of rendering a long and intricate narrative in stage time and space. With 15 actors in 25 roles, and 15 scenes spread over three acts (and two intermissions) it clocks in at over three hours.

His handshake and the twinkle in his eye were unforgettable. He will be sorely missed by his sons Marvin and David, his daughters-inlaw Judith and Dee, his grandchildren Laura, Hilary, Mark, Bradley and Kimberly, their spouses Mark Fishman, Todd Smedley, Lisa Nierenberg and Max Gild and by his great grandchildren Daniel, Rachel, Andrew, Ryan and Amanda. description: A 15-year-old high school freshman whose threats about taking a gun to school were apparently shrugged off as not serious opened fire at his campus in this San Diego suburb this morning, the authorities said, killing 2 fellow students and wounding 13 other people in the worst episode of school violence since the shootings at Columbine High School in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLAUER, SAMUEL
description: BRESLAUER - Samuel. Suc cumbed to illness after a fruitful life of over 95 years on early Sunday morning, March 4, 2001. Mr. Breslauer was born in 1904 in Manchester, England and immigrated as a boy to the U.S. with his family, residing in Brooklyn. He is the last of seven siblings, five sisters and one brother. Mr. Breslauer was a Master Electrician and an Electrical Contractor for most of his life retiring at age 89, a period close to 70 years in the business as S. Breslauer Electric. He maintained one of the oldest electrical licenses in the city of New York. During his active business life he was one of the Founders of the Association of Electrical Contractors of Greater New York, a trade association representing Local 3 Union Contractors. He served in various capacities including a term as President. Mr. Breslauer's communal and civil activities included membership in the Knight of Pythias, where he held various offices including Chancellor Commander and was a member of the Grand Lodge of New York State. His good work included support of numerous organizations serving the Jewish and general communities. He is survived by his wife Ruth of over 45 years, and children of his first wife; son Joel C. Breslauer and daughter-in-law Miriam, their son Keith M. Breslauer, his wife Lauren, their children Arianna and Sophia; and a daughter Mrs Susan Nelson, her husband Eugene, their children Terry Nelson and her husband Michael Morrolla, Lisa Nelson and Robin with her husband Norman Weinbaum, their children Stephanie and Matthew. Funeral services were held at I. J. Morris at 12:15PM on March 5th with interment at Beth David Cemetery.

title: CHILEAN CURRENCY FALLS
description: The Chilean currency weakened to a record low but stocks rose after the central bank cut its benchmark lending rate on Friday to the lowest level since 1986, the second reduction in 10 days. Lackluster consumer spending helped slow economic growth to a 15-month low in December amid continued high unemployment. Unemployment has stayed above 8 percent for more than two years. The bank cut overnight rates to 4 percentage points above inflation from 4.5 percentage points on Friday after the government reported that monthly consumer prices fell in February for the first time in two years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COWEN, DAVID, M.D.
description: COWEN-David, M.D., 93. On March 5, after a short illness. Professor Emeritus of the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, the Presbyterian Hospital, and was associated with both Lenox Hill Hospital and the New Jersey Veterans Hospital. He was an internationally known neuropathologist and published over seventy papers during his 50-year career. He was President of the American Association of Neuropathologists and received an award in 1979 for his dedication and contributions to neuropathology. A kind, gentle, and quietly humorous man, he will be missed by all who knew him. He is survived by his nephew Robert Cowen, Jr., and seven grand nephews and nieces. Services will be private.

description: Florida seems to be on the verge of eliminating chads of all descriptions. The now infamous Votomatic punch-card voting system in that state will be retired in favor of a uniform statewide system if the State Legislature approves a set of worthy proposals delivered to Gov. Jeb Bush by a bipartisan task force. Electoral flaws are not unique to Florida, as we observed yesterday in urging Gov. George Pataki to appoint a ballot reform commission in New York. But Florida is now seeking to transform itself from being the chief example of the old system's problems to becoming a model of modernization. We hope the Florida Legislature will seize this opportunity, enact the recommendations and thus prod other state capitals and Washington, where a greater sense of urgency on election reform is needed.
