James River, based in Suffolk, Va., owns First Colonial Bank, James River Bank/Colonial, James River Bank and State Bank. The transaction would add 27 branches and $516 million in assets to First Virginia's 376 branches and $9.5 billion in assets. First Virginia is based in Falls Church, Va.

title: A Visit by South Korea's Leader
description: Tomorrow's meeting between George W. Bush and South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, will be more than ceremonial. Mr. Kim, the first Asian leader to meet with President Bush, has devoted himself to encouraging a thaw with Communist North Korea. Though the ultimate success of this effort is still uncertain, considerable progress has been achieved, symbolized by the meeting between the South Korean president and North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il, last June. But unless the White House assures Kim Dae Jung of continued American support for his northern policies, his chances of ending more than a half-century of military confrontation between the two Koreas could evaporate.

Both companies make software for managing customer relations, human resources, sales support and marketing efforts. Robert Kugel, an analyst at FAC Equities, also reduced his earnings estimate for PeopleSoft, citing corporate skittishness when it comes to investing in software during an economic slowdown. PeopleSoft shares ended the day down $3.13, to $23.94. After losing 20 percent of their value on Friday, Oracle shares were stable yesterday, ending the day up slightly. Andrew Zipern

description: FROST-Joan Alice. Of Woodstock, CT, formerly of Wilton, CT, died on February 17, 2001 at The Tandet Center in Stamford, CT. She was 85 years old. She was born in Paignton, England, and was the younger daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W.J. Matthews, of Worthing, Sussex, England. She was a Second Officer of The Womens Royal Navy during World War II, and was previously married to Flight Lt. J.J. Hamilton, RAFVR, who was killed in World War II in 1941. She married Frederick W. Frost in 1946, and they moved to Nod Hill, in Wilton, CT, in 1952. She was active in The Wilton Garden Club both as an exhibitor and as a judge. They moved to Thompson, CT, in 1988. She is survived by two sons, and daughtersin-law, Jeremy and Joan M. Frost, of Fairfield, CT, and Christopher Frost, and Colleen Aurori, of Redbank, NJ, as well as nephews, nieces, and their offspring in England and Australia. Funeral services and burial will be private. title: French Fries
description: French fries are a very particular case of deep-frying in that they have to be fried twice, once at a low temperature and then at high temperature. The reason is another example of the time/temperature ratio. In the beginning you want to cook them slowly or else the outside will burn before the interior is cooked, so you start at a relatively low temperature. Then you want to blast them with heat to blister the exterior for a beautifully crisp potato: high heat, short period.

title: FORMER DAEWOO EXECUTIVE CHARGED
description: Kim Woo Choong, former chairman of the Daewoo group of South Korea, was charged with a number of crimes that investigators said were committed before the collapse of the conglomerate in mid-1999. Seoul prosecutors issued a warrant for his arrest and asked the help of Interpol in finding him abroad. Mr. Kim, who fled Korea after creditor institutions took over the group's companies, is believed to have been spending most of his time in France and Germany but has also been reported in Morocco and Sudan. The prosecutor's office said he had ordered his subordinates to alter records to obtain loans of nearly $10 billion. He is also accused of transferring more than $20 billion to overseas accounts. Don Kirk

title: OFFICE SUPPLY CHAINS REPORT QUARTERLY LOSSES
description: Two leading office supply chains posted fourth-quarter losses yesterday and said the slumping economy had hurt sales. Staples, the No. 2 chain behind Office Depot, said it lost $112 million, or 23 cents a share, in the quarter, down from a profit of $119 million, or 26 cents, a year earlier. Sales increased to $3.1 billion from $2.6 billion. Excluding one-time charges for investment write-downs, Staples earned $94 million, or 21 cents a share. OfficeMax lost $85 million, or 76 cents a share, down from $23 million, or 20 cents a share. Sales rose to $1.4 billion from $1.3 billion. Excluding one-time charges from store closings and inventory liquidation, OfficeMax lost $13.2 million, or 12 cents a share. Both companies blamed the slowing economy for the shortfall and said spending on initiatives eroded profit further.

title: GERMAN JOBLESS RATE IS UP
description: Germany's Federal Labor Office said the unadjusted jobless rate rose to 10.1 percent in February. The unexpected increase of 19,400, or 0.1 percent, from January to a total of 4.11 million people unemployed was explained by an extended seasonal downturn caused by unusually cold weather. Optimistic about German labor markets' further recovery, the Labor Office president, Bernhard Jagoda, said he expected average unemployment for 2001 to be 3.6 million to 3.65 million. Some economists, however, saw the figures as further evidence of a slowdown already evident. Petra Kappl

title: Great Caesar's Ghost! Where's My Anchovy?
description: A FEW weeks ago, I had an exceptionally good Caesar salad at 44 & X Hell's Kitchen. It looked like a regular Caesar, except for the Parmesan crisp that replaced the croutons. And it tasted like a classic, too: a fresh mix of romaine, lemon, garlic and cheese. As is usually the case these days, there were no anchovies on top, and I didn't miss them. My husband did and asked for some, but our waiter returned to the table, apologetic. ''I'm sorry, but we don't have them in the kitchen,'' he said. Really? Not even for the dressing? Unheard of. Or was it?

title: FIBER OPTIC COMPANY STOCK FALLS AFTER SALES WARNING
description: Shares of New Focus fell 11.2 percent yesterday after the company reduced its sales forecast for the year and cut 330 jobs. The stock fell $2.38, to $18.88, a share. The company, based in San Jose, Calif., makes parts used in fiber optic equipment. It said late Monday that it had scaled back production after customers canceled orders. Sales may total $170 million to $190 million this year, down from an earlier forecast of $240 million, the chief financial officer, William Potts, said. First-quarter revenue will be $38 million to $41 million, the company said. New Focus said it would lay off 260 employees at its Shenzhen, China, plant and 70 workers in the United States.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TETERBORO FLIGHT DISPUTE
description: Indigo L.L.C., a Chicago-based charter-flight company, has been accused by a New Jersey congressman of violating rules limiting Teterboro Airport to nonscheduled flights, by operating two daily flights to Chicago. Representative Steven R. Rothman, whose district includes the airport, in Bergen County, asked the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Federal Aviation Administration to review the flights and to ground Indigo if necessary. Indigo's president, Matthew G. Andersson, said the company's two daily flights to Chicago from Teterboro on eight-seat jets were legally charters that he said were ''able to be shared by small groups of people.'' title: Metro Business Briefing; HAMILL AT DAILY NEWS
description: Pete Hamill, columnist and former editor in chief of The Daily News, will rejoin the newspaper as a columnist and correspondent next month, officials there announced yesterday. Mr. Hamill wrote a column for The Daily News from 1977 to 1979, wrote ''Tales of New York'' for two years during the 1980's and served seven months as the newspaper's editor before being replaced in October 1997. He has been a staff writer for The New Yorker since then. Daily News officials said Mr. Hamill was recruited back by The News's current editor in chief, Ed Kosner, who was one of Mr. Hamill's first editors, at The New York Post. Mr. Hamill has covered, among other events, the Vietnam War, the conflict in Northern Ireland, the civil rights movement and major sports events. The New York Times announced yesterday that it had hired Jim Dwyer, a Daily News columnist, as a reporter. Mr. Kosner said that he had been talking to Mr. Hamill about returning months before Mr. Dwyer said he was leaving.

description: WALSH-H. Robert. Of New York, N.Y. Age 76. Beloved father of Meredith W. Walsh and Eliot W. Walsh. Brother of Francis X. Walsh. Passed away Wednesday, February 28, 2001. Born in Milton, MA., Mr. Walsh was a graduate of Harvard Univesity, Class of 1948. He served in the U.S. Army in Germany during WWII, attaining the rank of 1st Lt. Upon his graduation from Harvard, he received a Fulbright Scholarship to the Sorbonne in Paris, France. He then went on to earn a Master's Degree in Business from Columbia University. Bob spent his entire career at the advertising firm Young & Rubicam, Inc. in New York City where he ultimately became Senior Vice President and Director of the Strategy Board. He retired in 1987 and resided in Clinton, CT. and Palm Beach, FL. Memorial services will be held at the Church of Saint Thomas More, 65 E. 89 St, N.Y., N.Y. at 10:30AM on Thursday, March 8th. His work as a trade union leader and political activist in Chile resulted in a three year imprisonment after the 1973 coup. His death is a loss to the labor movement and to progressive politicals here and in his native Chile. Deepest sympathies to his wife, Beatrice, his six children and ten grandchildren. Services will be private. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM on Sunday, March 11 at the New York Joint Board, 31 West 15th Street, New York City. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEIN, HOWARD GLEN
description: HEIN-Howard Glen. President and Co-Founder of the distinguished furniture, textile and accessories firm of Randolph & Hein, Inc. based in New York, Los Angeles and San Francisco, suffered a heart attack and died peacefully in his sleep Friday, February 23rd, 2001 in Los Angeles, CA. Howard was a native of Lodi located in California's Central Valley, an area also claiming as native sons legendary design icons, Michael Taylor and Jed Johnson. After attending Auburn Academy in the State of Washington and the University of San Francisco in California, where he served as President of his class at both institutions, Howard saw combat during the Korean War while in the U.S. Army. In 1971 Howard joined with Randolph Arczynski in forming a small refinishing and restoration business in San Francisco that quickly expanded to include furniture and textile collections renowned for their extraordinary quality and style. Messrs. Arczynski and Hein's unique design vision has had a significant impact upon the world of interior design and has made Randolph & Hein a respected leader in the international design community. Howard is survived by his sister, Lola Garcia, brother, Ellsworth, and three nieces, Allison, Colleen and Laura, residing in CA. A Memorial Service celebrating Howard's life will be held at San Francisco's Grace Cathedral atop Nob Hill on Wednesday, March 7th, at 2 PM. Charitable contributions honoring Howard may be made to: D.I.F.F.A., 8687 Melrose Ave., Suite M-48, Los Angeles, CA 90069, (310) 652-6601.

Having already engaged the veteran Swiss theater director Benno Besson to oversee a new production of Mozart's ''Zauberflte'' at the company's smaller house, the Palais Garnier, he suddenly faced a problem when the director of a new Bastille Opera production of Johann Strauss Jr.'s ''Fledermaus,'' also scheduled for the end of 2000, dropped out. So he turned to the French actress, screenwriter, playwright and director Coline Serreau, best known in the United States as the writer and director of the French film ''Three Men and a Cradle,'' remade by Hollywood into ''Three Men and a Baby.''

title: The Full Gel, Curlers and Cream Rinse
description: Paddy Breathnach's ''Blow Dry'' has the curious distinction of being the third more-or-less-British hair-care comedy to be released in this country in the last year or so, following Barry Levinson's ''Everlasting Piece,'' about a pair of Belfast toupee salesmen, and ''The Big Tease,'' last winter's sham documentary about an indomitable Scottish coiffeur triumphing in the cutthroat hair-cutting world of Los Angeles. That film, memorable for Craig Ferguson's gleeful Gaelic camping, was advertised as ''Rocky With Curlers.'' ''Blow Dry,'' which tethers the inherent ridiculousness of competitive hairdressing to earnest kitchen-sink sentimentality, might be described as a cream-rinsed ''Billy Elliot,'' or as ''Terms of Endearment'' with split ends.

description: Bibliofind, an online service that searches for rare and out-of-print books, has taken part of its service offline after disclosing a four-month hackers' spree that left 98,000 user names, addresses and credit card numbers exposed. description: Santana High School reopened here today as it offered its 1,900 dazed students counseling, warm embraces and a light schedule to inch them back from the emotional wounds they suffered when 2 schoolmates were killed and 13 other people were wounded in a shooting on Monday.

title: Parkinson's Research Is Set Back By Failure of Fetal Cell Implants
description: A carefully controlled study that tried to treat Parkinson's disease by implanting cells from aborted fetuses into patients' brains not only failed to show an overall benefit but also revealed a disastrous side effect, scientists report.

description: Fooling Freesias

title: Behave or Face a Diamond Ban, Security Council Tells Liberians
description: The Security Council voted unanimously today to bar all diamond exports from the West African nation of Liberia if the country does not stop supporting a rebel army that has ravaged neighboring Sierra Leone. The embargo and a ban on travel by Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, will take effect on May 7 if the council's demands are not met.

title: Tokyo Court Moves Harshly Against a Credit Suisse Unit
description: TOKYO, March 8  In the first Japanese criminal conviction of a bank in memory, the district court in Tokyo today found Credit Suisse Financial Products guilty of violating securities regulations and attempting to thwart government investigators looking into the matter. The charges involved products sold to Japanese clients that were meant to conceal losses.

title: DAEWOO CLOSING UNITS
description: The Daewoo Electronics Company, one of the Daewoo group of companies that were taken over by creditors in mid-1999, is shutting down 8 of its remaining 62 overseas operations. The company said it was reducing operations in South America and the former Soviet Union as part of an overall restructuring program. Daewoo Electronics suffered a net loss last year of 988 billion won ($750 million) while sales declined 16.6 percent, according to Yonhap, the South Korean news agency. Don Kirk

title: No More Store Mirrors
description: To the Editor:

title: McDonald's Game Coming to Garden
description: The McDonald's high school all-American game will be played at Madison Square Garden next March, a person familiar with the discussions confirmed yesterday. The plan, first reported by Newsday on Tuesday, is to play a doubleheader, with an inaugural women's game.

title: Metro Business Briefing; AREA ECONOMIC GROWTH CONTINUES
description: The economy continues to grow in the New York region, while conditions are less rosy in parts of the Midwest, according to a report released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Board. The condition of New York's economy remains ''generally favorable, with growth continuing at a moderate pace,'' according to the report, known as the Beige Book, which the Fed issues eight times a year. While Manhattan's housing market ''appears to be retreating from the extraordinary levels seen through most of last year,'' commercial real estate construction and leasing in the region and residential real estate construction and sales outside the city are still robust. Nationally, much of the recent economic slowdown has been concentrated in areas with a lot of manufacturing. Leslie Eaton

description: To the Editor:

title: World Wrestling Sticking With XFL
description: World Wrestling Federation Entertainment is not abandoning its partnership in the XFL with NBC, Linda McMahon, the company's president, said yesterday.

title: Threats of School Violence
description: Monday's shooting at Santana High School in Santee, Calif., provides graphic evidence of the importance of encouraging students and adults to report threats they may overhear. In recent weeks, students in Kansas, Colorado and Cupertino, Calif., averted potential massacres by tipping authorities to suspicious behavior by their peers. In Santee the opposite happened. Several schoolmates and one adult who heard Charles Andrew Williams discuss plans to bring a gun to school dismissed the whole thing as improbable. No one informed school or law enforcement authorities. On Monday morning Mr. Williams opened fire with a .22-caliber pistol, killing 2 people and wounding 13.

title: NEW CENSUS SHOWS HISPANICS ARE EVEN WITH BLACKS IN U.S.
description: The Hispanic population in the United States has grown by more than 60 percent in the last decade, pulling it into rough parity with blacks as the largest minority, early data from the 2000 census show.

description: To the Editor:

title: Wiring the City: Humans Won't Do
description: MANHOLE 465 is a ''good hole,'' the crew says, cleaner than most and surprisingly free of roaches. I am standing at the bottom of the 12-foot-deep shaft, straddling a narrow channel of greasy, gray water that courses between my high-water boots. Sitting complacently in the channel is a long, thin robot on wheels: the Sewer Access Module, or SAM. The robot is far more comfortable in this dank environment than I am. For one thing, it's waterproof. Also, SAM doesn't have a nose.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 23 about presidents' relatives who became embroiled in scandals and investigations misidentified a relative of John Adams who was nominated as superintendent of the Stamp Office, prompting accusations of nepotism. He was Joshua Johnson, not Jackson, and he was the father-in-law of John Adams's son John Quincy Adams. He was not the son-in-law of John Adams.

title: The Newest Palm Adds Muscle to a Familiar Look
description: With its stylish shape, interchangeable faceplates and $149 price tag, the m100 was Palm's entry into the low-end hand-held market. Now it is getting a makeover. The new m105, which will sell for $199, has the m100's telltale shape and faceplates. But it bulks up to eight megabytes of memory instead of two, has a cradle for connecting to a computer instead of the m100's simple wire and comes with Internet access software that had to be purchased separately on the older model.

title: SATELLITE RADIO PROVIDER SECURES FUNDS
description: Sirius Satellite Radio is expected to announce today that it has secured a $150 million loan from Lehman Brothers, people close to the company said. Sirius, which plans to compete with XM Radio to provide satellite radio broadcasts to automobiles in the United States, originally sought the loan last year, but it was delayed until Sirius could show that its technology worked properly. Sirius recently increased its offer of stock options to Lehman in an apparent effort to pave the way for completion of the financing agreement, which will carry an interest rate of about 10 percent. With the loan and the sale of $230 million of stock last week in a transaction that was also managed by Lehman Brothers, Sirius has about $470 million on hand, easing concern over the company's financial situation, people close to the company said. Simon Romero

title: Intel Warns Sales to Fall Below Expectations
description: Providing perhaps the strongest evidence yet of the deepening difficulties at technology companies, the Intel Corporation warned late today that its revenues would fall about 25 percent in the current quarter from its previous quarter.

title: House Joins Senate in Repealing Rules on Workplace Injuries
description: Moving with unusual speed, the House voted narrowly tonight to repeal new workplace safety regulations, just a day after the Senate voted to rescind the same rules.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: GASOLINE RISES. Gasoline rose on concern that an unexpected shutdown at a New Jersey refinery would keep supplies low. In New York, gasoline for April delivery rose 2.44 cents, or 2.7 percent, to 91.64 cents a gallon.

title: Hot Trading In B Shares Chills Rapidly For Chinese
description: The rally in China's small market for stocks denominated in hard currencies evaporated today. Speculators who poured into the market last week began pulling out, following the lead of long-term investors, who began selling on Tuesday.

title: EARNINGS AT TOYS 'R' US BEAT EXPECTATIONS
description: Toys ''R'' Us Inc. said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit rose 6.8 percent as it redesigned stores, improved customer service and kept more top-selling items in stock for the holiday season. Net income in the quarter, which ended Feb. 3, rose to $251 million, or $1.23 a share, compared with $235 million, or 98 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Sales fell 4.5 percent, to $4.8 billion from $5 billion. Analysts had expected the company to earn $1.22 a share, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. The company expects a per-share profit of $1.43 in 2001, meeting analysts' estimates. The company also said that John Eyler, the chief executive, would replace Michael Goldstein as chairman. Mr. Goldstein will remain as a director.

title: Strapped States Try to Recover From Spending
description: The State of Missouri was feeling generous. The economy was booming; tax dollars were pouring in and legislators decided to use some of the money to expand a modest program that gave a stipend to grandparents acting as foster parents to their grandchildren.

title: Ralph's Career At UConn Is Over
description: A medical test yesterday morning confirmed the bad news for the Connecticut women's basketball team. Shea Ralph, the Huskies' all-American spark plug, has a torn anterior cruciate ligament in her left knee, and her college career is over.

title: PARIBAS'S PROFIT RISES
description: BNP Paribas, France's biggest bank, said fourth-quarter earnings rose 67 percent, helped by the takeover of the investment bank Paribas in 1999 and cost savings from more than 2,300 job cuts. Net income rose to 726 million euros ($679 million), from 436 million. The bank did not give fourth-quarter earnings per share. The Paris-based bank's profit, helped by managing corporate bond sales, grew faster than that of its European competitors.

description: NINE blocks from the prestigious Art Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue last week, where works of art ranged from thousands to millions of dollars in price, Crate & Barrel on Madison Avenue had a Mark Rothko for sale for $499, framed.

title: Battle Erupts on Paper's Quest For Earnhardt Autopsy Photos
description: A battle over The Orlando Sentinel's effort to examine photographs of the autopsy on the auto-racing idol Dale Earnhardt is pitting several news organizations and some First Amendment advocates against thousands of angry Nascar fans, who find the request ghoulish and intrusive. The critics fear that although The Sentinel says it will not publish the pictures, they will end up on the Internet.

description: SIDNEY GURALNICK could soon be a hero to every driver who has hit one of the teeth-jarring potholes that blossom on America's roads each year like the pox.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROBERTSON, JOHN KROHN

He was born January 28, 1972 in Brooklyn, NY, a son of Archibald Francis Robertson, Jr. and the late Marilyn Joan Schwartz Robertson. John was a 1989 graduate of St. Ann's High School in Brooklyn, NY, and he attended Bowdin College in Maine, the University of Texas at Austin, TX, and Hunter College in NY. He had worked in advertising at the New York Philharmonic and was a volunteer at the Metropolitan Museum of New York. He was a very loving son and brother who loved people, music, literature and the arts. In addition to his father, he is survived by his brother, A. title: Paper to Make Hotels Memorable
description: Who remembers bland hotel wallpaper? To change that, Laurinda Spear designed Palmrail, right, and three other vinyl papers: Wave, Rain and Bamboo. Palmrail will turn up in hospitality suites and the gym in the Westin New York at Times Square, opening next year, which her firm, Arquitectonica, is designing. ''Pattern adds another level of life to a room,'' Ms. Spear said. The designs are $11 to $15 a yard to the trade only at Wolf-Gordon, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street).

title: Some Big, Big Plans For a Little Mountain
description: They used to call this hilly countryside the Ice Box of New Jersey. Unspoiled and largely undeveloped, but only a 90-minute drive from New York City, the area lured entrepreneurs of every ilk. That included Hugh Hefner, who 35 years ago fashioned one of his Playboy Clubs in the wooded bluffs nestled along the New York State border.

description: He says that he is just an ordinary teenager, that there is nothing remarkable about William Rafael Sanchez. Yet the details of his life paint a different picture.

title: Economic Scene: Forget Net Taxes. Forget Sales Taxes Altogether.
description: The proposed Bush tax cut is getting all the attention, but another tax issue has recently reappeared in the halls of Congress: the thorny problem of how to collect sales taxes on the Internet. A three-year moratorium established by the Internet Tax Freedom Act of 1998 expires in October, and the states are urging Congress to resolve this longstanding issue.

title: Questions Arise Over Verniero's Role in Profiling Inquiry
description: Through the years of arguments over racial profiling in New Jersey, a persistent question has been exactly when Peter G. Verniero, the former attorney general and now a State Supreme Court justice, learned that the state police under his authority were singling out minority drivers for traffic stops.

title: Plan to Tie Tax Cut to Surplus Gains; G.O.P. Tries to Stop It
description: A proposal gained steam in the Senate today to make long-term tax cuts contingent on continued projections of large budget surpluses, but Republican leaders acted to block a direct vote on this proposal in the House of Representatives.

title: A Kettle That Will Heat Water And Warm Hearts
description: A new electric kettle from Philips is eye candy for the countertop. The 10-cup kettle reaches a boil in 7 minutes 40 seconds, pours cleanly and has a plump jelly bean look that makes it the iMac of kitchen appliances. There are drawbacks: like other coffee pots and kettles, this one has calibrations that bear no resemblance to reality (the kettle holds about 7 1/2 cups, not 10). And although it is billed as cordless, the base has a cord; the kettle can be removed from the base. Nonetheless, for $40, it's a fetching way to arrive at a boil. At Target stores: (888) 304-4000 or www.target.com. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: Tips by Students Result In Arrests at 5 Schools

title: GENETIC CHIPS ARE FLAWED
description: A large maker of gene chips used in drug research, Affymetrix, said yesterday that it had found flaws in one line of products and offered replacements. The company found errors in data taken from mouse genes used to design one type of its gene chips, glass wafers with DNA fragments affixed to their surfaces. Replacing the defective chips may cost up to $4 million, the company said.

He wore a pink oxford shirt with an open collar, jeans and a brown belt that matched his brown loafers. Outside, a blizzard blanketed his new county-owned car. His dog, a cockapoo, whimpered at his heel.

title: Passing Time on Internet Watching Clocks Go By
description: Clocks tick away on computers, telephones and hand-held organizers, but our obsession with time is much older than the chip. The Museum of Science and Industry in Chicago offers a selection of 30 clocks on its Web site (www.msichicago.org/exhibit/time

title: For Trump's Models, It's Beauty Under Glass
description: When Peter Guzy, a partner at Asfour Guzy Architects in Manhattan, designed the offices of T Management, a modeling agency at 91 Fifth Avenue owned by Donald Trump, he tried to create an open, inclusive atmosphere.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Tuesday about layoffs of teachers in Manhattan School District 3 misidentified the school where a parent said a full-time third-grade teacher had been dropped. It was Public School 163, not 166.

title: REPORT DETAILS ONLINE FRAUD
description: A report released yesterday by the Internet Fraud Complaint Center said that online auction fraud led the list of complaints the center referred to law enforcement agencies during its first six months of operation. Of the 20,014 complaints the center received between May 8 and Nov. 8 last year, 6,087 were referred to enforcement agencies across the country for further investigation. Of those referrals, 64.1 percent involved auction fraud, 22 percent involved problems with nondelivery of merchandise or payment, and nearly 5 percent involved credit and debit card fraud. The complaint center is operated jointly by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the National White Collar Crime Center. Its report is online at www.ifccfbi.gov. Susan Stellin

title: Frank H. Johnson, 88, Pioneer In Direct-Mail Marketing, Dies
description: Frank H. Johnson knew the truth about today's intelligent readers: they rebel against condescension and have scant time to waste. This pioneer of direct mail invented what became known as the Johnson Box, an enticing paragraph just before a letter's salutation that efficiently and pleasingly synthesized the sales pitch to follow.

title: Ergonomic Programs That Pester Users To Take Those Breaks
description: RON GOODMAN had been working as a computer programmer for more than a decade when his wrists began hurting. Within three months, the pain was so bad that it was difficult to hold a coffee cup, and within six months it had spread to his elbows and shoulders.

title: World Business Briefs
description: ASIA NTT DOCOMO SELLING BONDS NTT DoCoMo , Japan's dominant mobile phone operator, attracted strong interest from bond traders and investors in a 180 billion yen ($1.52 billion) debt issue to help finance a push into overseas markets. The issue, only one month after the carrier's record 800 billion yen ($6.74 billion) new-share offering, exposes the high costs facing DoCoMo as it promotes new wireless phone technology. (Reuters)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, MORLEY G.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''He is tough and difficult but at least he knows what he wants and we know what he wants.''

title: A Little E-Mail (Or a Lot of It) Eases the Workday
description: IN the Internet age, office workers aren't limited to regaling their co-workers around the water cooler with stories about the weekend. E-mail and instant messaging technologies make it possible for office workers to maintain daily contact with friends and family during the workday all over the country and, time zones allowing, all over the world.

title: Pittsburgh Surprises Notre Dame
description: Notre Dame wanted to win. Pittsburgh had to win. Notre Dame wanted to make watching Sunday's N.C.A.A. selection show more satisfying by rampaging through the Big East tournament. Pittsburgh wanted to surprise everyone in this tournament and sneak its way into the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: LAYOFFS PROTESTED IN CHINA
description: More than 1,000 workers protested layoffs at the Shanghai Tyre and Rubber Company in an industrial suburb of Shanghai but were dispersed by the police. Such protests are becoming more common in China as the state cuts subsidies and banks cut off credit for money-losing government-owned enterprises like Shanghai Tyre, and they are likely to spread after China enters the World Trade Organization and competitive pressures increase. Zeng Peiyan, above, the head of China's State Planning Commission, said that he expected bankruptcies to rise after the country joins the W.T.O. Craig S. Smith

title: Taking Inspiration From the Streets Of Norway and Paris
description: Pia Myrvold, a Norwegian artist who lives in Paris, has designed a fashion collection called Cybercouture. In her first New York show last month, her cotton textiles were patterned with photographs of architectural details drawn from Paris, New York and Bergen, Norway. title: Roll 'Em, Digitally, On a Disc
description: TO video nerds everywhere, the 1993 news report landed like a punch to the gut: according to various studies, the videotapes that store life's memories demagnetize, causing visible deterioration, in as little as 15 years. Sure, you can take the important tapes to a commercial duplication service every decade or so. But copying a standard analog tape (like a VHS or 8-millimeter cassette) substantially degrades the quality. No matter how high-tech a videographer you've been, your grandchildren may wind up learning about the important moments of your life by listening to you reminisce.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOFRE, ERNESTO
description: JOFRE-Ernesto. UNITE mourns the untimely passing of an important leader of our union on March 5. Manager of the Amalgamated Northeast Joint Board and recently elected an International Vice President, Ernesto was an organizer, a political activist, a trade unionist of high principle and commitment. His work as a trade union leader and political activist in Chile resulted in a three year imprisonment after the 1973 coup. His death is a loss to the labor movement and to progressive politicals here and in his native Chile. Deepest sympathies to his wife, Beatrice, his six children and ten grandchildren. Services will be private. A memorial service will be held at 2 PM on Sunday, March 11 at the New York Joint Board, 31 West 15th Street, New York City. Jay Mazur, President Bruce Raynor, Secretary-Treasurer Edgar Romney and Ed Clark, Executive Vice Presidents

title: After a Shooting
description: High school students in Littleton now have a new excuse to get out of class for a few extra minutes: the lockdown drill. My school had its first last year. While most students sat quietly in locked classrooms, a few teachers responded to simulated crises, like a student injury. It's one of many new features of life in Littleton since the Columbine High shootings of 1999. Most people have tried to move on, but some aspects of our lives have changed forever.

title: PROFIT FALLS AT ASHANTI
description: The Ashanti Goldfields Company, which was close to bankruptcy in 1999, said 2000 profit fell 54 percent as less reliance on prearranged sales cut the price the company received for its metal. Net income excluding one-time items for the year fell to $30.5 million, or 27 cents a share, from $66.1 million, or 59 cents a share, a year earlier. The fall in profit came even as Ashanti increased production to a record 1.74 million ounces and cut costs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, JEAN CAMPBELL

Beloved wife for 41 years of the late Cranston Jones; loving mother of Baird of New York City, and Abigail of Beverly Hills, CA. Good humored mother-in-law of Jeff Mandell and cherished grandmother of Alexander and Juliana. She was born in St. Johnsbury, VT. and graduated from Radcliff College in 1944. She was a writer and Beauty Editor of Seventeen Magazine. She loved art, flowers, children and chocolate. We will miss her very much. Memorial service on Friday, March 23 at 3PM at the Cosmopolitan Club, 122 East 66 St.

title: Corrections

His idea of fun is making marzipan or dill pickles or a sour cherry pie with a lattice cream-cheese crust. Out shopping, he relishes a fresh fig or a white peach -- ''definite banana notes'' -- and begs to buy a ''weird bird'' like squab or poussin. A poppy seed cake, a Mongolian hot pot, a pear clafoutis -- such is the stuff of my son's dreams.

''We're in a significant economic downturn,'' Broadcom's chief executive, Henry Nicholas, said at an investment conference presentation this week. ''The visibility is very poor.'' Broadcom is the latest maker of communications chips to scale back earnings expectations, citing the slowing United States economy. More Broadcom customers delayed orders last month, and one of its biggest, the 3Com Corporation, canceled a contract, the company said. title: Taking Sides in Afghanistan

For Muslim fundamentalists, like the Taliban of Afghanistan, the jahiliyya didn't end in the seventh century. They see modern times as a constant affront to the purist principles that God ordained. The tolerance of traditional Islam, which in Central Asia and the Indian subcontinent even made its peace with polytheists and idol worshipers, is as foreign to them as the secular principles of Western civilization.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CONNECTICUT PRODUCTIVITY

The study, released Tuesday, credited the state's educated work force and number of jobs in the technology and research sectors for manufacturing productivity that ranked behind only Washington, Massachusetts and Maryland. Last year, Connecticut ranked seventh. But only Louisiana and Hawaii had higher manufacturing costs than Connecticut, which has high taxes and high medical and energy costs, the report said. Paul Zielbauer

He went on to do graduate work at the University of Berlin and Yale University. He had a long career in the New York City school system as a teacher and administrator. During World War II he served with the Department of the Navy. Mr. Berger is survived by his devoted wife of 64 years, Mrs. Gertrude M. title: TRW TO REDUCE ITS WORK FORCE BY 1%
description: TRW Inc., the No. 2 maker of airbags, said yesterday that it would eliminate 1,000 jobs at the company's automotive unit, or about 1 percent of its total work force, to cut costs as carmakers reduce production. TRW will take a $40 million charge to pay for the job cuts in the first quarter, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Eliminating the jobs may lower employee expenses by about $40 million a year, analysts said. About 64 percent of TRW's sales, which totaled $17.2 billion last year, came from automotive parts, and the remainder from space and military products. The jobs being cut are all salaried positions.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INCREASES INVESTMENT IN ARGENTINA
description: The Philip Morris Companies agreed to pay about $220 million to increase its stake in Massalin Particulares S.A., Argentina's biggest cigarette maker. F.T.R. Holdings S.A., a unit of Philip Morris, is buying a 30.93 percent interest in Massalin Particulares from Reemtsma Cigarrettenfabriken G.m.b.H. of Germany, raising its holding in the company to 94.67 percent. After completing the deal, which is subject to certain conditions, F.T.R. plans to make a public offering for the remaining 5.33 percent traded on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange, Massalin Particulares said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBROF, ALFRED
description: DOBROF-Alfred. The Board of Directors, Residents and Staff of the Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale mourn with profound sorrow the loss of Alfred Dobrof, beloved husband of our dear friend and colleague Rose. We extend our heartfelt codolences to the entire Dobrof family on the loss of a husband, father and grandfather. The Hebrew Home for the Aged at Riverdale

title: Tribute to a Hairdo: Immortalizing the Mullet
description: EAT your hearts out, fashion plates: your expensive hairdos don't make it on the Internet. Sure, occasionally a designer or a male model pays homage to the king of hairstyles, but he's just borrowing it from the real people.

title: Economic Scene; Forget taxing Internet sales. In fact, just forget sales taxes altogether.
description: THE proposed Bush tax cut is getting all the attention, but another tax issue has recently reappeared in the halls of Congress: the thorny problem of how to collect sales taxes on the Internet. A three-year moratorium established by the Internet Tax Freedom Act of 1998 expires in October, and the states are urging Congress to resolve this longstanding issue.

title: Dancers' Brooklyn Fixer-Upper
description: Ten years ago the Mark Morris Dance Group was in Brussels, cast in an improbable role as the national dance company at the Thtre Royal de la Monnaie. It was not a match made in heaven: Belgian dance fans, wedded to their beloved Maurice Bjart, bridled at the brashness and irreverence of the American choreographer, who mocked their traditions and even their queen's hairstyle. Newspaper headlines told Mr. Morris to go home; audiences booed performances minutes after the curtain went up.

title: In America; Cruel and Unusual
description: Antonio Richardson had already eaten what was supposed to have been his last meal. Now he was waiting, frightened, in the prison cell with the gray walls and the telephone at the Potosi Correctional Center in Potosi, Mo., about 65 miles southwest of St. Louis.

title: Wily, Tireless, They Seek The Denizens of Bold Type
description: Arnaldo Magnani paced outside the Fifth Avenue restaurant. He looked around for other photographers. He checked and rechecked his camera batteries.

title: Essay; Storm Of Hype
description: The TV weatherpeople flew into a blizzy. ''The East's worst storm in 50 years'' was predicted in a tone of confident panic. Phrases like ''three feet of snow'' were bandied about as weathercasters in front of jerkily moving radar maps explained with certitude how the winter storm would stall, lashing the region for days.

title: PURCHASEPRO REAFFIRMS ESTIMATES
description: Shares of PurchasePro, an operator of business-to-business World Wide Web marketplaces, rose 14 percent yesterday after the company said that it stood by its previously stated earnings estimates. On Tuesday, the company said it would acquire BayBuilder, a business software company, for $15 million in stock and cash, an announcement that prompted questioning by analysts. Christopher J. Benyo, PurchasePro's senior vice president for marketing, said BayBuilder's products would complement PurchasePro's offerings. Although far from its peaks of last year, when it traded as high as $82, PurchasePro gained $1.44 yesterday, to close at $11.69. Andrew Zipern

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLUME, RICHARD
description: BLUME-Richard. Physicist. On March 4, 2001. Formerly of Alexandria, Virginia. Survived by his sister, Florence Most of Deerfield Beach, Florida.

title: Vetoing New York's Voters
description: New York's City Council is perilously close to thumbing its nose at the city's voters. A near-majority of the Council has apparently decided that voters were wrong when they agreed -- twice -- to impose strict term limits on New York's elected officials. Wiser heads at the Council should sideline this self-serving rebellion and spike the bill that would overturn term limits, perhaps when the Council's committee on government operations meets today.

title: Defense Lawyer Challenges Idea That Sub Crew Rushed
description: The civilian lawyer for Cmdr. Scott D. Waddle, the captain of the submarine Greeneville, sought today to undercut damaging testimony about the submarine's collision with a Japanese fishing vessel, suggesting that the captain's actions had been reasonable and had fallen within acceptable Navy standards.

title: Tax-Cut Fever in the House
description: Speaker Dennis Hastert's haste to ram a sweeping income tax cut through the House today is an effort to create momentum, if not a stampede, for President Bush's entire $1.6 trillion tax cut among conservative Democrats and wavering Republicans. But with his strongarm tactics Mr. Hastert is demonstrating that this tax cut will not stand close scrutiny. By pushing for an excessive tax cut that is overly generous to the wealthy before passing a budget -- before even receiving a specific budget proposal from the White House -- Republican leaders are saying, ''Vote now and think about the consequences later.''

title: BUSH TELLS SEOUL TALKS WITH NORTH WON'T RESUME NOW
description: President Bush told President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea today that he would not resume missile talks with North Korea anytime soon, putting aside the Clinton administration's two-year campaign for a deal and the eventual normalization of relations with the reclusive Communist state.

title: Eagles' Pumpkin Now a New Carriage
description: Jeffrey Lurie bought the Philadelphia Eagles in 1994 and remembers sitting in his office at Veterans Stadium talking on the phone with the then mayor of Philadelphia, Ed Rendell. A mouse ran across Lurie's feet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAISHOFF, RUTH SALTZMAN
description: TAISHOFF-Ruth Saltzman. The National Board of Hadassah, WZOA, mourns the death of Ruth Saltzman Taishoff, our esteemed colleague. May her memory be for a blessing. Bonnie Lipton, National President

description: Priceline.com, the online company that lets customers bid to buy discount airline tickets, hotel rooms and other items, is extending its last-minute booking feature to all of its travel services.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET ORIGINAL `INCUBATOR' PULLING PLUG Idealab , once a prominent builder of Internet businesses, is closing its Silicon Valley "incubator," company officials said yesterday. The company, based in Pasadena, Calif., will continue to support the three companies that operate out of its Palo Alto, Calif., offices. Idealab executives said the 33 employees of the incubator would be offered jobs at one of the three Palo Alto companies but no new companies would be started. The move is a sign of how times have changed in the Internet industry. Idealab, which offered promising start-up companies money, advice and services in return for an ownership stake, helped get concerns like CarsDirect.com, HomesDirect and eToys off the ground. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRESTHUS, ROBERT V. GRANNING
description: PRESTHUS-Robert V. Granning. Political scientist, educator, author; born St. Paul, February 25, 1917. Date of death February 23, 2001, Carmel, CA. B.A., University of Minnesota, 1940, M.A., 1941; Ph.D., University of Chicago, 1948. 1951 - 56, professor, political science, Cornell University; professor, chairman, Department of Political Science, York University, Toronto, 1967; university professor, York University, 1969-82; research director, UN Institute of Public Administration, Ankara, Turkey, 1954-55. Author: Men at the Top: A Study in Community Power, 1964, Public Administration, 6th edition, 1975, Elite Accomodation in Canadian Politics, 1973. 1986, Editor: Administrative Science Quarterly, 1956-66, Behavioral Political Science series. Served with USNR, 1943-46, PTO. Ford fellow, 1959; Social Science Research Council fellow, 1950, 6364; research fellow Canadian Council, 1968-72.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHANDLER, GEORGE A.
description: CHANDLER-George A., 71. Of Princeton, N.J. on Tuesday, March 6, 2001 in Princeton. Husband of Sally Topping Chandler. Father of Nancy Koglmeier of Ohio, Elizabeth Bell of N.J., David of Illinois and James of N.Y.C. Memorial service Saturday 2P.M. Trinity Church, 33 Mercer St., Princeton, N.J. Memorial contributions to the Dale Laboratory Parkinson's Research Box M-2900 Neurology, Duke University Medical Center, Durham, N.C. 27710.

description: A Brooklyn boy was run over and killed by a school bus on his second birthday yesterday, moments after his mother had given the bus driver a symbolic religious gift. The driver did not realize that he had hit the child and continued on his route, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, PAUL
description: KOHL-Paul. Loving husband of the late Rhoda Kohl. Father of Ken and Vicki. Proud grandfather of Lindsay, Stacey and Spencer and father-in-law of Myrna and Peter. Died as a result of a stroke at Palm Beach Gardens, Florida on March 6, 2001. Mr. Kohl spent almost 50 years as a general contractor in New York managing the family operated Herbert Construction Company. As a member of the ''Greatest Generation'', Master Sargent Kohl served proudly in the U.S. Army, participating in the envasion and liberation of France. Mr, Kohl's charitable works included support of numerous organizations serving the Jewish and general commmunities. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island Friday March 9 at 10AM. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawm, Long Iland. In lieu of flowers, a donation to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIERENBERG, BENJAMIN
description: NIERENBERG-Benjamin. Died in his sleep on March 3 at the age of 96. His wife of 55 years Pauline, predeceased him in 1987. Formerly a resident and businessman in Jamaica Estates, he retired to Englewood and Sarasota, Fl. Ben was caring and generous, a vigorous man and an incisive thinker. His handshake and the twinkle in his eye were unforgettable. He will be sorely missed by his sons Marvin and David, his daughters-inlaw Judith and Dee, his grandchildren Laura, Hilary, Mark, Bradley and Kimberly, their spouses Mark Fishman, Todd Smedley, Lisa Nierenberg and Max Gild and by his great grandchildren Daniel, Rachel, Andrew, Ryan and Amanda. Funeral planned for Thursday March 8th at 11:30AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th St. & Amsterdam Ave. Due to weather conditions, please check by calling 212-362-6600. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Kobernick House, 1955 North Honore, Sarasota, FL. 34235.

title: The French-Asian Hybrids of Vietnam
description: I LOVE Vietnam,'' said Evan Cole, an owner of ABC Carpet & Home. ''It is an Asian country with French style.'' In fact, Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, used to be known as the Paris of Asia. As Vietnam moves toward normal trade relations with the United States, American retailers are preparing to import Vietnamese products.

title: Corrections
description: An Arts Abroad article on Feb. 28 about the problems of financing Berlin's three opera houses gave an erroneous number from the conductor Daniel Barenboim for the marketing department of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra. The organization says 12 people are on its marketing staff -- in contrast to the Staatskapelle, which has none -- and that people in related Chicago areas like communications bring the total to 40, not 80.

title: Work Rules Rebuffed
description: The House voted narrowly to repeal workplace regulations, a day after the Senate did the same. President Bush is expected to sign the bill to revoke rules issued late last year by President Bill Clinton, who said they would reduce injuries from repetitive motions on the job.

title: Ice Falling From Bridges Delays Traffic for Hours
description: The warm sun that winter-weary New Yorkers were waiting for created a traffic nightmare yesterday, as thawing ice fell from the cables of five local suspension bridges, forcing lane closures and hours of delays that lasted into the evening rush.

title: Sharon Takes Reins in Israel; Vows Security
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon wore his new persona as the tough but benevolent grandfather of a nervous nation when he took office tonight, forgoing any lofty promises of peace and prosperity in the face of a deepening conflict with the Palestinians.

title: Syracuse Stops UConn On Shumpert's Hot Start
description: Preston Shumpert has a tattoo running along his skinny left arm that spells out ''Mr. Shumpert'' from below his shoulder to his elbow, a salutation that was quite appropriate last night. Shumpert deserved all the respect that goes with the title as he scorched everyone except Connecticut's mascot in steering Syracuse to an 86-75 victory in the first round of the Big East Conference tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Bidding Adieu To a Friend
description: It's hard to forgive an author of serial novels for killing off a popular character. Every time a favorite is rubbed out or dies of illness it baffles readers and fetches up ineffable emotions not only of sadness but also of anger. And if you think this is not serious stuff, well, when Hercule Poirot died in the summer of 1975 this paper ran a front-page obituary of the great Belgian detective, the only time it knowingly noted the death in a formal article of someone who never existed.

title: Poll Watch: Parents Often Blamed in School Shootings
description: The disturbing picture of an expressionless adolescent boy, shackled and being led by the police to be arraigned for the murders of his peers has now gone from the aberrant to the familiar. School shootings have happened often enough that there is a basis for comparing one to the others. People, sadly, have come to expect them.

title: AIDS DRUG BATTLE DEEPENS IN AFRICA
description: An Indian maker of generic drugs asked South Africa today to give it the right to sell eight AIDS drugs currently available only from their patent-holding multinational companies at high prices.

title: Bitter End Yacht Club in Virgin Gorda
description: Sailing enthusiasts may want to consider an offer from the Bitter End Yacht Club, an 89-unit resort on the Caribbean island of Virgin Gorda. The Caribbean Adventure Package cuts rates by $100 a night for the period April 16 to 30 for stays of five nights or longer. The Bitter End is known for its sailing program, and the package includes use of the boat fleet. It also includes accommodations, three meals a day, airport transfers, daily excursions and a champagne sunset sail. Contact (800) 872-2392 or visit www.beyc.com .

description: LUTIN-Vivian. On March 6 after a long, compassionate life. Devoted wife of Sidney, loving mother of Marjorie and Mark and beloved grandmother of Daniel, Josh, Doug and Rob.

title: INSURER SEEKS TO AVOID MP3 CLAIM
description: Adding to the online music industry's bad week, MP3.com learned that its insurance company had moved to avoid paying MP3.com's settlements with record labels. The Westport Insurance Corporation filed suit in a federal court in Manhattan this week, saying that MP3.com willfully violated copyright law by distributing copyrighted music. Deliberate violations of the law, Westport said, render MP3.com's insurance policy null. According to the lawsuit, MP3.com submitted claims totaling $5 million. Westport refused to pay the claims, arguing that MP3.com misrepresented its business practices, broke the law and negotiated settlements with the record labels without Westport's consent. A spokesman for MP3.com, which has set aside $170 million to settle similar disputes, declined to comment on the lawsuit. Chris Gaither

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the destruction of ancient statues of Buddha by the Taliban, the militant Islamic movement that rules Afghanistan, referred incorrectly to an earlier effort to destroy them, in Genghis Khan's time. He did not use cannon fire; cannons were not developed and used in warfare until many decades after his death, in 1227.

title: For Analog Camcorder Owners, Easy Way to Convert to Digital
description: To make home movies on a computer, a digital camcorder is usually considered a must. What if you're one of the millions with an analog camcorder? (Remember, you lugged it around Disney World.) You probably don't want to spend $1,000 or so for a digital model.

description: Albert Belle's power-packed but troubled career is over, a baseball friend of the Baltimore player said last night.

title: T.W.A. Accepts an Offer For a Takeover by AMR
description: Trans World Airlines accepted a takeover bid yesterday from the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, after AMR increased its initial offer by $242 million, to $742 million.

title: Metro Business Briefing; DEAL FOR BARBIZON HOTEL
description: Melrose, the latest hotel group to enter the New York market, is buying the Barbizon Hotel on the Upper East Side for $100 million, according to real estate executives. Melrose, a division of the Berwind investment group, recently signed a contract to buy the Barbizon, on Lexington Avenue at 63rd Street, from Ian Schrager Hotels. The hotel, which once had 655 tiny cubicles, has been renovated many times and now has 306 rooms. The deal was first reported in The Wall Street Journal. Built in 1927, the neo-Gothic Barbizon was originally a women's hotel. In more recent years, it has operated as a full-service hotel. Charles V. Bagli

title: A-List Alternatives to Hamptons Hulk
description: IT was a guest list that would have done any style-conscious hostess proud: Michael Graves, aglow from his success designing inexpensive housewares for Target; Sir Richard Rogers, once the enfant terrible of the Pompidou Center, now a British knight; Gisue and Mojgan Hariri, Iranian sisters with an affinity for sensual materials; Charles Gwathmey, architect to Steven Spielberg and Jerry Seinfeld; and relative newcomers like Marwan Al-Sayed, whose winglike polyvinyl roof for a house in Phoenix won him instant fame.

title: Mr. O'Neill's Alcoa Stock
description: Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill's decision not to divest himself of more than $90 million in shares and options in Alcoa, the aluminum maker, is as puzzling as it is disturbing. Mr. O'Neill is the only member of President Bush's senior economic team not to sell his holdings or place them in a blind trust to avoid potential conflicts of interest. But what seems particularly odd is that Mr. O'Neill brings to government a history of personal rectitude and sensitivity to matters of ethics and appearance.

title: Magic Turns Light Into Life
description: GENIUS does not flourish in a vacuum. That's the simple lesson vividly conveyed by ''Vermeer and the Delft School,'' an alternately tousled and crystalline show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It includes 15 paintings by Vermeer -- nearly half of the 35 works firmly attributed to him -- along with paintings, drawings and prints by a host of other artists and a smattering of decorative objects and books.

title: Leslie C. Quick Jr., a Pioneer in Discount Stock Brokerage, Dies at 75
description: Leslie C. Quick Jr., who provided investors with the chance to trade stocks at discounted prices and then earned a reputation as a leading supporter of Roman Catholic charities in the New York area, died yesterday at the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, according to his son, Thomas. He was 75.

title: Metro Business Briefing; REPORT NOTES EXPORT STRENGTH
description: Exports are increasingly important to New York's economy, according to a report to be released today by goTrade New York, a business group promoting international trade. The group calculated that New York State exported more than $27 billion in services like financing, accounting and consulting in 1999, supporting about 400,000 jobs. The state also exported more than $43 billion in merchandise -- including machinery, chemicals and food -- which the group said accounted for 473,000 jobs. Leslie Eaton

title: Fanning the Flames of Fame, and Basking in the Glow
description: The movie ''15 Minutes'' asks the question: is there a line between cynicism and nihilism? This morbid thriller is a cross between Billy Wilder's ''Big Carnival'' (which dug a fresh, new grave for media jackals and the exploitation they shovel) and ''The French Connection.'' It's fleet-footed, merciless entertainment. But the mixture of laughs, bathos and brutality is a big turnoff.

title: CORN DOGS SAID TO CONTAIN BANNED CORN
description: An environmental group said yesterday that vegetarian corn dogs made by the Kellogg Company contained StarLink corn, a bio-engineered corn that is banned for human consumption. The group, Greenpeace, asked the Food and Drug Administration to recall the product. Greenpeace officials said it had commissioned laboratory tests on the corn dogs packaged under the Morningstar Farms label; the corn dogs were purchased in Baltimore. A spokeswoman for Kellogg said the company had been notified about the tests done by Genetic ID of Fairfield, Iowa, which identified StarLink in taco shells last fall. Kellogg notified the F.D.A., the spokeswoman said, and has sent samples of the corn dogs to an independent laboratory. In a letter, Greenpeace urged the F.D.A. to seize the corn dogs and to seek penalties if Kellogg did not cooperate.

title: WILLAMETTE, TARGET OF A TAKEOVER BID, SETS MEETING

In a letter to Willamette shareholders on Feb. 27, Weyerhaeuser said that the Willamette board delayed the annual meeting so that shareholders could not be heard. One takeover defense tactic is that only three of Willamette's nine directors are up for re-election each year at the shareholders meeting. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCALLISTER, DONALD H.
description: McALLISTER-Donald H. A former Partner, Managing Director and, most recently, an Advisory Director of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, died on March 6, 2001, in Orlando, Florida. Mr. McAllister was born March 21, 1925 in New Haven, Connecticut. The son of Harold C. and Carolyn H. McAllister, he was raised in Manchester, New Hampshire. He graduated from Dartmouth College in 1946 and received an MBA from the Amos Tuck School of Business Administration in 1948. Mr. McAllister served in the U.S. Navy in the Pacific Theater during the Second World War. Following graduation from Amos Tuck, Mr. McAllister worked for R. P. Burroughs Co., an insurance broker, before returning to Asia with the Navy in 1951 and 1952, during the Korean Conflict. In 1953 Mr. McAllister joined Morgan Stanley & Co.'s corporate finance department, specializing in the consumer and oil service industries. Mr. McAllister was elected a Partner in 1963, a Managing Director in 1970 when the company incorporated and an Advisory Director in 1990. He played an important role in founding the firm's equity and research departments. Mr. McAllister lived in Greenwich, Connecticut and is survived by his wife, Katherine; his son Donald, Jr., his daughter-in-law, Ellen, and grandsons, Donald III and Edward McAllister; his daughter, Wendy; and his son, Malcolm and his daughter-in-law, Diddle. A memorial service will be held Tuesday, March 13, 2001, at 11:00AM at the Round Hill Community Church, Round Hill Road, Greenwich, Connecticut. description: ''A Family Album: Brooklyn Collects,'' a big, uneven but often transcendental grab bag of an exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum of Art, celebrates collectors of art or antiques who live in or come from Brooklyn. Eighty-six collectors of all stripes lent some of their prized possessions for this grand, wildly pluralistic grouping of more than 300 works.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SELLING THE DESKS
description: Urban Box Office, the Manhattan Internet company founded by George Jackson, the late Motown Records executive, has asked a federal judge to approve a plan that would help it emerge from bankruptcy protection. The company wants to use $410,000 in net proceeds from the sale of furniture and other office equipment and $380,000 it expects from the sale of fixtures to cover its operating expenses. The company is paying $125,000 back to its investors, which include J. P. Morgan Chase & Company and Flatiron Partners, a venture capital fund in Manhattan. Flatiron, in turn, is returning $75,000 to Urban Box Office to defray the costs of a lawsuit against the company.

title: School Official Says Budget Imperiled Jobs
description: The president of a an Upper West Side school district that narrowly averted laying off dozens of teachers this week said that the district's budget problems were partly due to a substantial cut by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the City Council to the city's Board of Education.

title: Devils Crank Up Offense For Former Coach's Return
description: Jacques Lemaire returned to Continental Arena as coach of an opposing team for the first time and the Devils wanted to impress their former defensive master. Lemaire led the Devils to their first Stanley Cup in 1995 with the now-famous neutral zone trap, but tonight the Devils put their offense on display in a 6-2 victory over the expansion Minnesota Wild.

title: Hyundai Electronics to Be Renamed Hynix
description: Seeking to distance itself from the troubles of its sister companies and its own battered image, Hyundai Electronics Industries said today that it would scrap the Hyundai name and go by Hynix Semiconductor instead.

title: Our Dependence on Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: Public Interests; A Taxing Debate
description: The House passed a tax-cut bill yesterday. We're well on the way, in the words of Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill, to ''putting more money back into the hands of people who will buy homes and cars and bigger homes and bigger cars.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Margaret Riker Harding -- Educator, 68
description: Margaret Riker Harding, an educator who spent 44 years on the faculty of the Brearley School in Manhattan, died March 3 at her home on the Upper West Side. She was 68.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: AUTO RACING

title: Corrections
description: The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, about a new digital camcorder that records on DVD RAM discs, misstated their size. The diameter is eight centimeters (a little over three inches), not eight millimeters.

title: Religion Prize Won by Priest Much Involved With Science
description: The Rev. Arthur Peacocke, a Church of England priest and theologian who holds a doctorate in physical biochemistry, will receive the Templeton Prize for Progress in Religion, one of the world's largest monetary awards.

title: Foreign Affairs; Macho On North Korea
description: Pay attention to the brouhaha at the White House Wednesday, when President Bush shot down the hopes of President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea that the Bush team would quickly resume negotiations with North Korea. This episode highlights the fine line between a tough, effective foreign policy and a tough, ineffective foreign policy, and it raises the question: On which side of that line does Mr. Bush plan to reside?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TIRSCHWELL, SYLVIA
description: TIRSCHWELL - Sylvia. Loving wife of the late Alex. Mother of Perry, Joel, and Susan, grandmother of Mark, Cathy, David, Carolyn, Eric, Carmel, Peter, Robert, Matthew and Stephanie. Proud great-grandmother of Jessica, Max, Ellie and Benjamin. Died March 8, 2001. Services at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre on March 9 at 10AM.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAUTERBACH, LILLIAN M.
description: LAUTERBACH-Lillian M. On March 7, 2001 in her 97th year. Beloved wife of the late John. Devoted mother of Lynn and Donald. Cherished grandmother of Sandra Lynn. Reposing at LLoyd Fuenral Home, 39th Avenue at 215 Street, Bayside, NY. Service Sunday 2PM. Funeral Monday 9AM. Visitation Saturday 2-5PM and 7-9PM and Sunday 2-5PM. In lieu of flowers, donations to The Church On The Hill Memorial Fund, 167-10 35 Avenue, Flushing, NY 11358.

title: Minorities Changing Landscape of New Jersey
description: The population of New Jersey fanned out into the state's booming midsection and its coastal counties during the 1990's, according to the first detailed numbers from the 2000 census, which were released yesterday. The figures sharply illustrate the degree to which diversity is transforming the state's suburbs while immigration has helped breathe new life into several of its cities.

title: Unemployment Rate Holds Steady at 4.2% in February
description: Buoyed as usual by the service industry, the economy created more jobs than expected last month, which helped keep the nation's unemployment rate unchanged at 4.2 percent for February, according to Labor Department figures released today. But the hemorrhage of factory jobs continued.

title: 3 Men Are Charged With Fraud In 1,100 Art Auctions on EBay
description: Three men accused of trying to sell an abstract painting for $135,805 on the eBay auction Web site last year were indicted yesterday on charges of taking part in a bidding ring that cost hundreds of art buyers a total of $450,000.

title: He's Macho but Can't Write. He's Shy but Can. Perfect.
description: ''Hit and Runway'' is a case of the emperor's old clothes: drab, sentimental rags that desperately want to be something else. The picture starts with the title being typed onto a computer screen that fades into a gray, rainy day when Alex (Michael Parducci) is attending his father's funeral with his family. Alex is forced to work at the family restaurant by his older brother, Frank (John Fiore). But Alex has bigger plans.

title: Berry Grower Signs Pact With Workers
description: Capping a four-year drive to unionize California's strawberry workers, the United Farm Workers signed its first contract yesterday with a strawberry grower.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOBROW, EMMA
description: BOBROW-Emma. Passed away on March 7. Loving mother of Edwin (Gloria), David (Terri). Loved grandmother of Mark (Isabelle), Amy and Julie and loved sister Rosalind Lehrhaupt. Contributions to the Alzheimer's Association are welcomed.

title: A Hushed but Vital Issue: Thurmond's Health
description: The 17-foot bronze statue of Senator Strom Thurmond behind the State Capitol here depicts him striding southward with vigor and purpose, and that is precisely how South Carolina's leading officials prefer to imagine him in Washington these days.

title: Court Orders Inquiry Into '99 Gucci Stock Deal
description: The battle between two French billionaires for control of Italy's fabled Gucci fashion house entered a fresh round today after a Dutch court ordered an investigation of a deal Gucci struck with one of the billionaires, Franois Pinault, to thwart the unwanted advances of the other, Bernard Arnault.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: 'Tokyo Joe' Settles Suit With S.E.C. Over Web Site
description: Yun Soo Oh Park, owner of an Internet investing site that was one of the hottest sources of stock picks on the Web, has settled a civil complaint brought last year by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Get to Troubled Kids Before They Start Shooting
description: To the Editor:

title: A Setback in Parkinson's Research
description: Yesterday The New England Journal of Medicine published the disheartening results of a careful study to determine whether fetal nerve cell transplants can help patients with Parkinson's disease. For most patients receiving the treatment, there was virtually no change, and for some of the younger patients there was a tragic deterioration, an unpredictable intensifying of their symptoms due to the growth of the fetal nerve cells in their brains. Worse yet, the damage appears irreversible.

title: S.E.C. Is Said To Investigate Amazon Chief
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating stock sales by Jeffrey P. Bezos, the chairman of Amazon.com, in early February just before a Wall Street firm released a negative research report on the company, according to a person close to the matter.

title: A Connecticut Colony That Radiated Sunshine
description: Improbable as it sounds today, the top-scale suburb of Greenwich, Conn., once harbored a bohemian art colony, though mildly bohemian to be sure. From around 1890 to 1920, the rural byways and bucolic settings of the Greenwich area known as Cos Cob served as summer camp, school and stomping ground for a group of artists whose predominant mode was American Impressionism.

title: After the Nicknames
description: President Bush's victory in Congress today may have come at a cost. The bitter House debate on the first phase of his tax cut and the near party-line vote that followed made it harder for Mr. Bush to argue convincingly that he would make good on his signature pledge to change the partisan tone in the nation's capital.

title: Car Tips From Readers
description: From what's the best pre-owned luxury car to whether it's worth it to buy an Oldsmobile, readers share their insights and answer fellow readers' questions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEL, SONJA
description: SPIEL-Sonja. Passed away on Wednesday, March 7, 2001 after a heroic battle against a very lengthy illness. Beloved wife of 45 years of Norton, our esteemed colleague on the Advisory Board of the Queens College Center for Jewish Studies. Devoted mother and mother-in-law of four sons and three daughters-in-law: David and Lori, Saul and Michele, Michael and Alyssa and Jonathan. Cherished grandmother of Sarah, Melanie, Shira, Ari, Lauren and Jamie. May the entire Spiel family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem, and may the family know no further sorrow. Advisory Board of the Queens College Center for Jewish Studies Arthur A. Anderman, Chair Prof. Benny Kraut, Director

title: CREE SHARES DROP 31% AFTER A WARNING ON PROFIT
description: Shares of Cree Inc. fell 31 percent yesterday after the company, which makes light-emitting chips for cellular telephones and car dashboards, said its fourth-quarter profit would not meet forecasts. Cree's shares fell $7.94, to $17.50. Increasing competition and slowing demand are hurting Cree, the company said. The company now expects profit of 14 cents to 16 cents in the quarter ending June 24, a spokeswoman, Fran Barsky, said. The company was expected to earn 20 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The American people had a victory today. The American family had a victory today. The American entrepreneur had a victory today.''

title: The Living Is Sleazy Under the Shanghai Moon
description: Wang Xiaoshuai's ''So Close to Paradise,'' which opens today at the Screening Room, has some of the gamy, brutal melancholy of a classic Hollywood tough-guy B picture. Set on the margins of Shanghai's underworld, it follows Dong Zi and Gao Ping, two migrants from the countryside, through a perpetual twilight of sleazy nightclubs and petty thuggery. Dong Zi (Shi Yu), honest and nave, ekes out a menial living on the docks, carrying heavy loads on a pole balanced on his shoulders. Gao Ping (Guo Tao), as his friend's slightly awed voice-over narration describes him, has adopted the ways of the city, smoking filtered cigarettes, dressing in dark suits and eschewing hard work in favor of small-time criminality.

title: DEADLINE FOR DAEWOO BID
description: South Korea's commerce and industry minister said that General Motors had until the end of April to decide if it wanted to buy the Daewoo Motor Company. If G.M. fails to make an offer by then, the minister, Shin Kook Hwan, said, the company's creditors would seek another solution in a merger with another Korean or foreign manufacturer. The company, bankrupt with debts of more than $10 billion, sought to make itself attractive to potential buyers last month by dismissing 1,750 workers from a plant, setting off protests that appeared to have faded yesterday.

title: Science and Surpluses
description: When President Bush spoke to Congress and the nation on Feb. 27, he outlined three cardinal goals: a $1.6 trillion tax cut, a first-class education for every child and a restructured military that confronts emerging post-cold-war threats. The next day, he announced a budget that jeopardizes the nation's ability to achieve any of these truly laudable goals.

title: Corrections
description: The Safety column of the Automobiles section on March 2 about the complexity of car radios misstated the surname of the editor of Mobile Entertainment magazine, who complained about the profusion of controls. He is Mike Mettler, not Metter.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Ninette de Valois, Royal Ballet Founder, Dies at 102
description: Dame Ninette de Valois, the founder of England's Royal Ballet and a major British choreographer, died yesterday at her home in London. She was 102.

title: House Passes Waterbury Bailout Bill
description: Facing a Wednesday deadline to prevent Waterbury from sinking into bankruptcy, the Connecticut House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved a bill this evening to create a board of overseers to take financial control of the city and alleviate its roughly $50 million in debt.

title: CELERA DEAL LIFTS LYNX THERAPEUTICS
description: Lynx Therapeutics Inc. shares rose $1.88, to $11.94, after the company said it would provide the Applera Corporation's Celera Genomics unit with genetic information for its databases. Celera, the company that published its analysis of the human genome last month, fell 64 cents, to $38.26. The two companies said the agreement would bolster their database businesses. Celera will integrate Lynx data, which helps researchers understand gene functions, with its database. In turn, Lynx will analyze genetic data provided by Celera, incorporating those findings into the Lynx database.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET CNET WARNS OF LOWER SALES The online infor- mation company Cnet Networks said yesterday that first-quarter revenue would be lower than expected and that it would probably lose $5 million to $12 million for the period. The announcement came a month after the company said it was cutting 190 jobs or 10 percent of its work force. Cnet estimated that revenue for the quarter ending March 31 would be $75 million to $80 million. It previously had issued revenue guidance of $86 million to $92 million. Its shares fell $1.13, or 10.7 percent, to $9.44. (AP)

title: Admiral Says Sub Captain Did Not Act Criminally
description: After chronicling a series of errors contributing to the collision between the submarine Greeneville and a Japanese trawler, an investigating admiral said today that he did not believe the submarine's captain, Cmdr. Scott D. Waddle, had acted with criminal negligence.

title: N.H.L. and U.S.O.C. Disagree on Drug Policy
description: Officials from the National Hockey League and the United States Olympic Committee spent yesterday offering their blueprints for an ideal drug-testing policy, but emerged with issues that, if left unsettled, could dilute the star power of the United States hockey team.

title: Polishing Public Profile of U.N. Is a Job for a Novelist
description: AT night and on weekends, Shashi Tharoor, whether in Singapore or Geneva or his East Side apartment in Manhattan, has sat typing into the morning's early hours.
