title: Chinese Leader and Parents in Dispute Over School Explosion
description: China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, faced off today against angry parents of children who were killed in a rural schoolhouse explosion this week by contradicting their account of what caused the blast.

title: PHILIPPINE INTEREST RATES CUT
description: The Philippine central bank cut key interest rates half a point to shore up the economy, saying slowing inflation and a stronger peso paved the way for the decision. At its weekly policy meeting, the bank cut the benchmark overnight borrowing rate to 10.5 percent and the key overnight lending rate to 12.75 percent, effective Monday, the central bank governor, Rafael Buenaventura, said.

title: North Korea's Failures
description: To the Editor:

title: Waxing Philosophic, and Just Waxing, in 9-Hour Term-Limit Hearing
description: A testy, defensive City Council invited the public into its ornate City Hall chambers yesterday to hear opinions on a bill to repeal Council term limits, evoking a volcano of passionate and sometimes angry testimony that raised fundamental questions about the nature of democracy, the civil rights movement and the limits of power in New York City.

title: Are Share Buyers That Dumb, or Are Systems That Bad?
description: THE world of stock trading has changed drastically in the last five years, with electronic markets sprouting like weeds. The electronic communications networks, or E.C.N.'s, have differing approaches and different rules, in some cases directly contrary to the rules that traders have taken for granted for years.

title: Big Contractor Sues Raytheon in the Sale of a Unit
description: Washington Group International, one of the nation's largest construction companies, said yesterday that it had sued the Raytheon Company, accusing it of misrepresenting the financial condition of a construction and engineering unit that Raytheon sold to Washington Group.

title: The Mets Take Aim But Miss Their Mark
description: Add Gary Sheffield to the list, and the easiest reaction would be to question, even criticize the Mets for their winter failures. They coveted three free-agent pitchers -- Mike Hampton, Mike Mussina and Denny Neagle -- as well as a pitcher who was on the trading block, David Wells, and they snared none of them. They desired Alex Rodriguez and Johnny Damon and flirted with Sheffield and captured none of them.

title: Tension, Passion and Sass,  la Franaise
description: Selfless maternal devotion has rarely been etched on the screen with the wrenching force of Ariane Ascaride's portrayal of a Marseilles fishmonger in the French director Robert Gudiguian's masterpiece ''La Ville Est Tranquille'' (''The Town Is Quiet''). Ms. Ascaride's character, Michle, is a wiry, weather-beaten woman in her late 30's with clipped blond hair whose husband walks out on the family, leaving her to care for her hopelessly heroin-addicted daughter and baby grandchild.

title: Spring in Italy
description: It's not a lot, but every dollar helps. On all departures from April 11 to May 31, Insight Vacations is taking off $50 a person on vacation packages to Italy that include air fare, on Alitalia. The trips range in length from 9 to 17 days. The prices per person, based on double occupancy, range from $1,499 for a nine-day countryside tour of Tuscany, Umbria and Lazio to $1,749 for a 17-day Country Roads of Italy itinerary. Besides air fare from New York, the rates include first-class accommodations, daily buffet breakfast, a few dinners, airport transfers, guides and coach transportation. The latest date to reserve and pay is April 30. For brochures and tour details: (888) 562-0111 or www.insightvacations.com . To reserve, see a travel agent.

title: PHONE SALES SLOW
description: Alcatel S.A., a leading phone equipment maker in Europe, said its first-quarter sales growth would lag last month's 25 percent forecast amid ''sharply lower'' handset sales. The division that makes handsets will also post a loss in the quarter, but the company's total telecommunications operations should match last year's first-quarter profit of 79 million euros ($74 million). Shares of Alcatel fell 4.5 percent, or 2.15 euros, to 45.39 euros.

Shapiro of Weston, MA. Loving brother of Anne Bornstein of Brookline, MA., & the late Arthur Shapiro. Dear grandfather of 10 grandchildren. Cohen of Marblehead, MA. Expressions of Sympathy in his memory may be donated to the Good Samaritan Hospital Critical Care Unit of Palm Beach, FL., Massachusetts General Hospital Cardiology Dept., Boston, MA or Beth Israel Deaconness Hospital of Boston, MA or the Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Boston, MA. or the Jewish Rehabilitation Center of Swampscott, MA.

title: Metro Business Briefing; BANK TO CROSS HUDSON
description: Commerce Bancorp, the holding company for a New Jersey-based bank that stays open on Sundays, plans to open 30 branches in Manhattan to directly challenge J. P. Morgan Chase & Company and Citigroup. Commerce said it would open its first two New York City branches this year, one in Midtown and another on the Upper West Side.

title: Pataki Ally Takes Control of State's G.O.P.
description: William D. Powers, the longtime chairman of the New York Republican Party, passed the gavel today to his successor in a ritual that mixed nostalgia for past Republican victories with vows to re-elect Gov. George E. Pataki next year.

title: BARRETT RESOURCES REJECTS SHELL OFFER
description: The Barrett Resources Corporation, the Denver-based natural gas producer, rejected a $1.8 billion unsolicited takeover bid from the Royal Dutch/Shell Group yesterday. The board said, however, that it planned to explore ''strategic alternatives, including seeking proposals from a number of qualified parties,'' including Shell. For its part, a Shell spokesman said the company was disappointed and added, ''We're considering our options.'' Shell had previously said that it would proceed with its offer regardless of a rejection by Barrett's board, by starting a proxy fight for control of Barrett. Shares of Barrett rose slightly yesterday before Barrett announced it rejected the offer. Barrett's shares closed at $61.22 a share, above Shell's offer of $55.

title: Barber Signs Six-Year Deal
description: Nearly a week after he agreed to terms on a new six-year, $25.2 million contract, the Giants' Tiki Barber found his way to Giants Stadium yesterday to sign the deal.

title: New Census Figures Complicate the Redrawing of Districts
description: For decades, New Jersey's census results followed a postwar rule: the cities lose people, the Republicans win legislative seats. But this year's results are more complicated, as the state's old Democratic cities held their own in population while sending enough people to the fastest-growing and semirural counties to dilute their Republican character.

title: The F.A.A.'s No-Bids Proposal
description: A competitive and transparent bidding process for government contracts is an important means of ensuring that public needs are met in the most cost-effective manner by the most qualified enterprise. Thus it is disturbing that the Federal Aviation Administration, as reported this week by Matthew Wald of The Times, is proposing to forgo its usual competitive bidding procedures and instead simply designate the Lockheed Martin Corporation to upgrade a computer system crucial to the nation's air traffic control network. The choice is open to debate on the merits and raises an apparent conflict of interest, given that Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta is a former Lockheed vice president, and the man expected to become his deputy, Michael Jackson, was an executive of a Lockheed subsidiary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAKUBOVITZ, JEROME R.
description: JAKUBOVITZ-Jerome R. Beloved husband of Joan, devoted brother of Dr. Norman Javitt and Helen Smolen, loving father of Beth (Bob Chiger), Debra (Tim Fletcher), Bruce (Julie Sherman), and Donna (Donald Spector); cherished grandfather of Michele, Andrea, Jordan, Elliot, Robyn, Aaron, David, Daniel, Sara, Gary and David; brother-in-law, uncle, friend and respected business leader. Board member of Hebrew Hospital Home, Boys Town Jerusalem, Stern College Yeshiva University, JNF, Bronx Science Alumni Association, past president Appraisal Institute, MAI. Your generosity and devotion to religious, secular and professional organizations will help provide opportunities and improve the quality of life for generations to come. The example you set is an inspiration to us all and you will live in our hearts always.

title: Florida Youth Sentenced to Life for Beating Death
description: AFlorida judge sentenced a 14-year-old boy to life in prison without parole today for the murder of a 6-year girl, rejecting the boy's contention that he was merely playing at professional wrestling when he killed her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERECHT, DR. J. FRED
description: GERECHT-Dr. J. Fred, passed away on March 2, 2001. He was a research chemist at Colgate Palmolive Company for 38 years and an Adjunct Professor of Chemistry at Rutgers University for 18 years. His wife Agnes, daughter Mary Anne Bemis, son-in-law Mel Bemis and granddaughter Melissa Bemis, survive him. He has donated his remains to Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. In lieu of flowers please make a donation to the Polytechnic University, Brooklyn, NY.

title: In Heartland, Bush Savors His Victory On Tax Cut
description: The movie ''Fargo'' featured a debt-ridden Minnesota salesman whose plan to kidnap his own wife went desperately astray. In the real Fargo today, a different salesman came tromping through the snow. He was awash in surplus money and optimistic that his plan to slash taxes would meet a far better fate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRACKA, PETER JR.
description: STRACKA-Peter Jr. Of Somers, N.Y. and Bonita Springs, FL passed away on March 7 in Florida. He had been a longtime resident of Sleepy Hollow and Ardsley. He was born in Johnson City, NY to Peter and Helen Stracka on May 16, 1934 and was a graduate of Cornell University where he was a member of Theta Xi Fraternity. He later served in the U.S. Army in Germany. He was an owner and president of Baitinger Electric Co., Inc. and had also been employed by Graybar Electric Co. and Kennedy Electric Co., all of New York City. He was a member of the New York Building Congress, the Independent Electrical Contractors Assn., the Eastern Electrical Wholesalers Assn. and the Jovian Electric Club. At the time of his death he was a member of Heritage Hills Country Club and Spanish Wells Country Club. Previously he had been a member of Sleepy Hollow Country Club and Leewood Golf Club. He is survived by his wife, the former Joan (Joby) Kelly and two children, Peter Stracka III of Hawthorne and Kristin Stracka McSpedon of Ridgefield, CT, two grandchildren, Ryan and Julia McSpedon and a sister, Dorothy Rosinsky of Binghamton, NY. Friends may call at the Dwyer Funeral Home, Tarrytown on Sunday, March 11 from 2-4 pm and 79pm. A funeral Mass will be held at Transfiguration Church, Tarrytown at 11:30 AM on Monday, March 12 followed by interment at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. In lieu of flowers the family has requested donations to the HCM Program of St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital c/o Mark Sherrid, M.D., 1000 10th Avenue, Room 3B30, New York, New York 10019.

A memorial service will be held at Poly Prep, 9216 7th Avenue, Brooklyn, on April 28th, 2001 at 4PM. In lieu of memorial tributes, the family requests contributions be made to Poly Prep.

title: Bronx Man Charged In Shooting of Cabby
description: A 20-year-old Bronx man has been arrested and charged with attempted murder in the shooting and robbery of a livery-cab driver on Friday night, the police said.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Owning and Leasing; More Buyers Put Money on the Table
description: NOT long ago, when stock prices were soaring and discount lease deals were easy to find, it seemed almost foolish to pay cash for a car -- and hardly anyone did. In 1998, cash-paying customers fell to a historic low of less than 4 percent of car and truck buyers.

title: Buoyed by Service Industry, Jobless Rate Holds Steady
description: Buoyed as usual by the service industry, the economy created more jobs than expected last month, which helped keep the nation's unemployment rate unchanged at 4.2 percent for February, according to Labor Department figures released today. But the hemorrhage of factory jobs continued.

title: Ally of Icahn in T.W.A. Bid Acknowledges Ticket Stake
description: An investment group backed by the financier Carl C. Icahn sweetened its offer for Trans World Airlines yesterday, and its leader, the investment banker Brian Freeman, admitted that he stands to gain from a controversial ticket-selling contract that Mr. Icahn holds with the troubled airline.

title: Addenda: AT&T Wireless to Begin a Review
description: AT&T Wireless, which is to be spun off by the AT&T Corporation , said yesterday that it would begin a review for its account, which has been handled for the last three years by the San Francisco office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications . Billings were estimated at $400 million.

title: They Agree on One Thing: Barak Was All Wrong
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, a veteran hawk, and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, an inveterate peacemaker, would not seem to be on the same page -- or even the same bookshelf -- when it comes to dealing with the Palestinians.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A County Sprouts Residents, Not Crops
description: Karl Hammerdorfer, a lifelong resident of Somerset County, does not need dense columns of population figures to tell him what he already knows: he lives in the most rapidly developing place in New Jersey. Poised midway between New York and Trenton, this once sparsely settled county grew by 23 percent in the last decade, adding 55,818 people for a population of 297,490, according to Census Bureau numbers released today. title: Album of the Week: 'Nothing Personal,' Delbert McClinton
description: DELBERT McCLINTON: "Nothing Personal" (New West). The grain in Delbert McClinton's voice was built up the old-fashioned way: 40 years of singing in roadhouses and honky-tonks. Having grown up in the down-home musical crossroads that is Texas, he soaked up blues, country, gospel and rhythm-and-blues without worrying about particular pedigrees. Mr. McClinton, 60, has also had plenty of time to observe love lost and found. In the 13 songs on "Nothing Personal," all of which he wrote or helped write, lust and heartbreak continue their endless roundelay, and Mr. McClinton sings with humor and grit, whether he is celebrating an all-night tryst or ruefully recalling how "my ship came in and she sank it." He is more eccentric and existential writing without collaborators, sketching people in trouble in "Desperation" and offering strategic advice in "Nothing Lasts Forever." Although Mr. McClinton hasn't always sounded comfortable in a recording studio, this time he romps through the songs, especially when his band adds New Orleans to the beat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUICK, LESLIE C. JR.
description: QUICK-Leslie C. Jr., 75, on March 8, 2001, of North Palm Beach, FL and Aspen, CO, formerly of Laurel Hollow, NY. Wall Street visionary and philanthropist, founded Quick & Reilly, the first New York Stock Exchange member firm to offer discounted commissions to individuals and one of the nation's leading brokerage firms, expanding the business to include one of the largest specialist firms on the New York Stock Exchange, a major clearing and execution firm, and a NASDAQ market maker. An ebullient, dynamic and charismatic leader of the firm that bears his name, Mr. Quick was also highly esteemed for his philanthropy and leadership abilities in charitable, religious and civic causes. He was past Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Fairfield University and served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Alfred E. Smith Foundation; the Dana Farber Hospital in Boston; founder and member of the Board of Directors of The Inner City Scholarship Endowment Fund in New York City as well as board member of the Gregorian University in Rome, Italy. Additionally, Mr. Quick served as Chairman of the Board of St. Francis Heart Hospital and on the advisory council of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, TN. He was a Trustee of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories. Mr. Quick was a Knight of Malta, Knight of the Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity of the Archdiocese of New York. Mr. Quick graduated from Pennsylvania Military College, now Widener University, in 1950, and served as Chairman of its Board of Trustees. Widener awarded him an honorary doctorate in business administration in 1990 in recognition of his many accomplishments and achievements. He also received an honorary Doctorate of Law from Fairfield University. He was patron of both St. John Chrysostom School in Manhattan and St. Anselm School located in the Bronx. Mr. Quick is survived by wife of 50 years, Regina, children Leslie III, Thomas, Peter, Christopher, Mary Pedersen, Nancy Gibson, and Patricia Quick, 24 grandchildren, and a brother, Herbert. He was predeceased by his grandson, Raymond Crile Quick. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York City, on Monday, March 12, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Leslie C. Quick Inner City Scholarship Endowment Fund, c/o Quick & Reilly, Inc., 26 Broadway, New York, NY 10004.

title: Losing Momentum on Korea

title: DOW JONES AND AT HOME TO HALT INTERNET VENTURE
description: Dow Jones & Company and At Home will shut down their Work.com Internet joint venture on March 31. The companies said yesterday that the decision was made because of the current decline in online advertising spending and the challenges of getting more financing. The companies said the majority of Work.com's 113 full-time employees in Redwood City, Calif., and in New York would be leaving the company next week. The others will remain for a various time periods to assist in the orderly phase-out of the company and its relationship with vendors and partners.

title: A New Look at Race in America
description: Throughout this month, the Census Bureau is releasing state population figures by race and ethnicity. Categories in 2000 are not directly comparable with those in 1990 because the 2000 questionnaire was the first that allowed people to choose more than one race. Figures for states listed here were made public yesterday.

title: A Tale of China's Harsh and Secretive Justice
description: SHANGHAI, March 10  When Qiu Xuanming's body arrived at the crematory from the execution ground last June, his brother recognized it by the clothes it wore. Mr. Qiu's head, which had been shot in the back at close range, was a tightly wrapped ball of white gauze, but the clothes were the same he had worn at his final court hearing a little more than an hour before.

description: A Florida boy convicted of murdering a 6-year-old girl when he was 12 was sentenced today to life in prison without the possibility of parole. It may be the first time a life sentence has been given for a crime committed at so young an age.

title: SULZER'S PROFIT FALLS
description: The Swiss medical and industrial technology company Sulzer reported its net income fell 19 percent to $128 million in 2000, mainly because of restructuring costs. Otherwise, the net income last year rose 39 percent, with net sales growing 4 percent. The company plans to spin off Sulzer Medica A.G., in which it holds a majority stake. Sulzer Medica, whose sales rose 14 percent last year, will be spun off, probably by August, after the company's refusal of a takeover offer by the Swiss venture capital firm, InCentive Capital. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, GERALD, PH.D.
description: COHEN-Gerald, Ph.D. The Estelle and Daniel Maggin Department of Neurology at Mount Sinai School of Medicine deeply mourn the passing of Dr. Gerald Cohen, a famous biochemist in the field of Parkinson's Disease. Dr. Cohen joined the staff of Mount Sinai in 1973 and helped introduce the concept of oxidative stress in neurodegenerative diseases and Parkinson's Disease. He was also an expert in alcohol toxicity. A prolific writer, he authored over 250 scientific publications. He received numerous awards including a Javits Award for excellence in scientific research, and honors from the Oxygen Society. His most cherished prize was an Award for Scientific Journalism. He will be remembered for his sharp mind and dedication to research by colleagues and students. We extend our condolences to his wife, Dorothy, and his son, Kevin. C. Warren Olanow, MD, Professor and Chairman, Deparment of Neurology

title: South Korea Contractor Is Ordered To Liquidate
description: In a sign of a toughening stance against deeply indebted companies, a court today ordered the liquidation of the Dong Ah Construction Company, a major international contractor and South Korea's second largest behind Hyundai Engineering and Construction. The court rejected a proposal by the company that it be put into receivership instead.

title: Family Rejoices for a Found Son, but Still Grieves for a Lost Childhood
description: Twenty years ago, an empty house in Queens first told Anthony Russini that his 15-month-old son was gone. No one answered the door. The grass was thigh high. Barry and Judith Smiley had disappeared with the boy.

title: Lobsterman Shot in Dispute Between Boats
description: A lobsterman was shot in the stomach on Thursday off the New Jersey coast during a gun fight involving two boats in a poaching dispute, the authorities said.

title: Marbury Unleashes Verbal Tirade at Ward
description: The animosity that Stephon Marbury once held toward the Knicks' point guards may not be dead. As the players walked off the court tonight after the Nets' 96-83 victory, Marbury began shouting at Charlie Ward.

title: Eros and Its Dizzying Masks
description: It seems cruelly perverse when Scottie, Jimmy Stewart's character in Hitchock's 1958 film ''Vertigo,'' imposes a makeover on Judy, a lower-class shop girl. In this variation on the Pygmalion tale, he forces her to wear a particular gray suit. She dyes her hair and wears it precisely as he commands. And when she first appears to him in her new form, she seems cloaked in a desirous haze, a sculptured reincarnation of the stunning Madeleine, Scottie's lost love, who, he thinks, plunged to her death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, EDWARD WILLINGHAM
description: COOK-Edward Willingham. Died peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida on Thursday, March 8, 2001, aged 78. Mr. Cook also resided in Gloustershire, England. Philanthropist, war hero, business and civic leader in Palm Beach, England and in his original hometown of Memphis, TN. Mr. Cook was the son of Brigadier General Everett R. Cook, a World War I fighter ace and Phoebe Willingham Cook. Mr. Cook was born June 19, 1922. In January 1942, Mr. Cook enlisted in the United States Air Force. By this time, in his early 20's, Mr. Cook was a major and was awarded the Bronze Star and the Air Medal with four oak leaf clusters. After graduating from the Hotchkiss School and Yale University, he entered the commodities business where he was the leader in the development of the huge grain shipment to Russia in the mid 1970's. He was Chairman and Chief Executive Office of Cook International 1964-1995; a director of First Tennessee Corp., Memphis 1969-1988; chairman of First Presidential Bank, Innovations Group Plc., U.K. 1987-1994; general partner, Palm Beach Capital 1987-1995; chairman Mid-South International Agricenter, Memphis 1979-1982; member of the Cotton Advisory Commission 1964-1968; member of the Executive Committee of the National Council for U.S.-China Trade 1973-1978; member of the President's Export Council 1973-1979; and, director of the Chicago Board of Trade 1974-1976. He was Chairman of the Memphis-Shelby County Airport Authority 1968-1981 and a member of the Southern Cotton Association (past president), the Cotton Council of America (board of directors 1962-1965), American Cotton Shippers Association (past president). Mr. Cook founded the Alexis de Tocqueville Society in Palm Beach and received their award of merit. He was a member of the Memphis Country Club, Memphis Hunt and Polo Club, Links (New York City), Union Club (New York City), Everglades Club, Bath and Tennis Club (Palm Beach, Florida) and Boodles (London). He is survived by his wife, Patricia L. Cook, and his children Edward W. Cook, Jr. of Sarasota, Florida; Everett R, Cook, II of New York, NY; Barbara C. Brooks Jones of San Francisco, CA; Mark W. Cook of Palm Beach, FL and Patricia Kendall Cook of San Francisco, CA; and his five grandchildren. His sister, Phoebe Cook Welsh of Houston, TX also survives him. A service will be held in Palm Beach, Florida on Sunday, March 11, 2001 at 2:00PM at Bethesda-by-the-Sea Church. A memorial service will be held in Memphis at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mr. Cook's memory to: Hospice of Palm Beach, 5300 East Avenue; West Palm Beach, Florida 33407-2387.

title: Into a Trance, to Relive Wartime Defiance
description: ''Now there is no enemy,'' the ensemble cries toward the end of ''Resistance.'' But before an old believer can gasp ''Say it isn't so, Living Theater,'' the great survivor Judith Malina corrects the innocents around her: there is indeed an enemy, but to find it you must learn to read the future.

title: Army Rangers Gather to Fight Beret Order
description: Three former Army Rangers have marched into Washington in advance of a rally on Saturday where former Rangers, their families and supporters will gather to protest an order that black berets, the Rangers' distinctive headgear, will be worn by all of the service's 480,000 active-duty soldiers and officers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAKUBOVITZ, JEROME R.

Jerry's contribution to the real estate appraisal community and the Appraisal Institute was tremendous, but his personal guidance and friendship will be most missed. Jerry inspired a whole generation of New York's real estate professionals with his hard work and achievements. He also was a patient teacher who shared his own vast knowledge of real estate and this city, and in that role enriched our lives. We will miss his stories and his counsel. We extend our deepest sympathy to Jerry's family and share with them warm remembrances always.

title: Injured Knee Forces Piazza To the Bench

title: Documents Shed New Light On C.I.A.'s View of Soviets
description: Just three days after Cardinal Karol Wojtyla of Cracow became Pope John Paul II in 1978, the Central Intelligence Agency predicted that the installation of the first Polish pontiff would lead to political instability within Poland and the erosion of the Soviet Union's ability to control its Eastern European empire, according to newly declassified C.I.A. documents.

title: LOUDCLOUD, INTERNET CONSULTANT, GAINS ON DEBUT DAY
description: Shares of Loudcloud Inc. rose in their first day yesterday after the company, an Internet consultant founded by the Web pioneer Marc Andreessen, twice reduced the asking price for the stock to find buyers for its $150 million initial offering. Loudcloud, the first Web-based company to complete an initial public stock offering in six months, rose to $6.16 after the company sold stock at $6 a share Thursday night. Five months ago, Loudcloud wanted as much as $12 a share. The 18-month-old company has lost more than $100 million and has been selling its key products, Opsware and Smart Cloud, for just six months. While the company has orders worth $120 million, some investors said they were not willing to bet on a business forecasting losses until 2003.

title: USFREIGHTWAYS PLANS TO MAKE DEEP JOB CUTS
description: The USFreightways Corporation, the second-largest operator of regional trucking companies in the nation, said yesterday that it planned significant job cuts and expected first-quarter profit to miss analysts' estimates because of the economic slowdown and bad weather. Shares of the Chicago-based company, which mainly carries shipments from multiple customers in each trailer, fell $3.81, or 11 percent, to $30.32 on the Nasdaq. USFreightways has been hurt as companies cut orders and factory employment. The company said first-quarter results would be below forecasts because of lower revenue and volume in several units, including freight forwarding and logistics.

title: Green Puts Nader, a Mentor, At a Distance for Campaign
description: Mark Green, the New York City public advocate and a protg of Ralph Nader, has moved to distance himself from the man he describes as his mentor, declaring that Mr. Nader will not come to New York to campaign on his behalf in the mayoral race. Mr. Green said Mr. Nader shared much of the blame for Al Gore's loss to George W. Bush last year.

title: U.S. Makes Arrest of Milosevic A Condition of Aid to Belgrade
description: The United States has told the new democratic government in Belgrade that if it expects American aid to continue, it should arrest and imprison former President Slobodan Milosevic by the end of March, and at the same time should assist in transferring to The Hague at least one person indicted on war crimes charges, senior Western officials said today.

title: AMERITRADE EXPECTS LOSS AS INVESTORS BALK
description: The Ameritrade Holding Corporation, the fifth-biggest online brokerage firm, said yesterday that it expected to lose 3 cents to 6 cents a share from brokerage operations in the second-quarter as individuals shun online stock trading. As stocks have tumbled, investors have lost their appetite for trading online, hurting online brokers. The company previously expected to earn as much as 2 cents or lose as much as a penny from its brokerage business. The company said its customers made an average 114,000 trades a day in February, down 15 percent from January. New account openings slowed to 39,000 from 43,000 in January. The firm narrowed its expected loss from OnMoney, a wholly owned subsidiary, to 4 cents from 5 cents. In all, Ameritrade expects a second-quarter loss of 7 cents to 11 cents.(Bloomberg News)

title: Mr. Sharon's New Course
description: With the installation of a national unity government in Israel under the leadership of Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, Mideast diplomacy has entered a period of diminished expectations. Ambitious proposals for a final peace agreement between Israelis and Palestinians have been taken off the table, and Mr. Sharon has made plain that he favors a more incremental approach to reducing tensions. But if Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, is willing to end the violence, he may find Mr. Sharon to be an unexpectedly pragmatic negotiating partner.

title: How Dot-Coms Joined the Old Economy
description: Yahoo's decision this week to hire a new chief executive just as the company reduced its first-quarter revenue estimates seems yet another sign of the demise of Internet business. But despite the collapse in value of dot-com companies, the Internet itself is still a growing force in the business world. The gloom about its prospects has distracted us from a simple reality: The Internet isn't a business sector, it's a technology, and even as dot-coms shrink or vanish, the skills they have fostered are moving inside traditional companies.

description: Nearly two months after he pledged to loosen the state's strict mandatory sentencing laws for drug offenders, Gov. George E. He also wants to reduce the state parole board's authority to grant early release from prison.

title: Ditched Lover Gets On With the Show
description: The new teenage comedy ''Get Over It'' may be halfhearted, but it's not entirely without heart, most of it supplied by its adorable central couple, Kirsten Dunst and Ben Foster. If the film is a tad slow-witted, it's not entirely witless, thanks mostly to Martin Short (playing a fluttery, egomaniacal high school drama teacher) and William Shakespeare, whose comic romance ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' supplies a showstopping -- well, at least movie-ending -- bit of musical business.

title: Team Adventure Sails on With a New Goal in Mind
description: AT SEA, SOUTH ATLANTIC, March 9  Sailing around the world takes one to remote regions of this planet, especially if you are attempting a circumnavigation via the three great capes  Good Hope, Leeuwin and the Horn. Our voyage has carried us past these rocky outposts, and we are on the final leg, on our way back up the Atlantic. As I write this, we are sailing in light airs, 700 miles east-southeast of Rio de Janeiro and searching for the easterly trade winds. This milder, gentler weather is a sharp contrast with the relentlessly fierce gales of the Southern Ocean.

title: JERSEY'S LARGEST UTILITY AGREES TO CHILE DEAL
description: The Public Service Enterprise Group, the owner of New Jersey's largest utility, agreed to pay $460 million for stakes in two power distributors in Chile, where electricity demand is growing at three times the pace of growth in the United States. Public Service said it would pay $29.98 a share for 94 percent of Sociedad Austral de Electricidad S.A., 31 percent above its last-traded price. It also will pay $10.88 a share for about 14 percent of Empresa Elctrica de la Frontera, which does not trade. The Chilean forestry giant Copec offered the stakes in a private auction. With the acquisition, Public Service will become one of Latin America's top distributors with 3.6 million customers in the region.

title: Latin Nightmares
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brain Too Young for Good Judgment
description: This week's shootings at Santana High School in California led quickly to now-familiar attempts to explain the seemingly unexplainable in terms of culture and circumstance: violent entertainment, a lack of accountability for deviant behavior, broken homes. While each of these issues may play some role in the tragedies of school shootings, to understand what goes wrong in the teenagers who fire the guns, you have to understand something about the biology of the teenage brain.

title: McCall Casts Doubt on Plan To Repair Nassau's Finances
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall warned today that Nassau County's four-year fiscal recovery plan could fall more than $108 million short and chided the county for what he called its ''troubling budget practices.''

title: Over World Protests, Taliban Are Destroying Ancient Buddhas

title: Contagion and Confidence
description: Foot-and-mouth disease and bovine spongiform encephalopathy, better known as mad cow disease, are radically different kinds of illnesses. Foot-and-mouth disease, which last appeared in the United States in 1929, is an old agricultural enemy -- endemic in much of the world, highly contagious, debilitating to young animals, but seldom harmful to humans. Mad cow is caused by an agent whose existence was largely undreamed of until a few years ago -- an abnormal protein called a prion. Mad cow is not contagious, but it is invariably fatal to animals and, in the form of the new variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease, to humans infected by it.

title: An Ailing Rigoletto and a Hidden Door
description: In the theater, certain roles are jinxed, and Mark Delavan's Rigoletto seems to be one of them. A pillar of the City Opera ensemble, Mr. Delavan recently made a successful jump across the plaza to the Met as Amanasro in ''Aida''; all the more reason to await his Rigoletto, scheduled to open City Opera's spring season. Illness, however, forced him to cancel the first night on March 2, and not until the third performance, on Thursday, did he feel well enough to go on. As the crippled jester, he was an imposing physical and vocal presence, but he became increasingly gruff, so much so that by the time he got to the duet with his daughter, Gilda, his voice failed him altogether. He bowed out at intermission, to be relieved by Gaetan Laperriere, who has been singing the role since last fall.

title: CANADIAN JOBS DECLINE
description: The number of working Canadians dropped in February, even though the unemployment rate was unchanged at 6.9 percent, providing further evidence that the economy has slowed more quickly than expected. The loss of almost 24,000 jobs last month, the worst monthly performance in four years, surprised economists who had expected an increase of 10,000 jobs after January produced almost no additions to payrolls. Part-time workers and men under age 24 suffered most during February, and manufacturing was notably weak. In the first two months of this year, manufacturers have cut 32,000 jobs, after adding 73,000 in the last five months of 2000. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: VIVENDI'S PROFIT GROWS
description: Vivendi Universal said its profit rose 60 percent last year, bolstered by gains in its phone services and utility divisions. Net income rose to 2.3 billion euros ($2.15 billion), from 1.4 billion euros in 1999, the company said. The chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, bought the Seagram Company, owner of the Universal Music Group, for $30 billion last year, betting the combination of music, films, television and the Internet would lift profit. The company said it was very confident it would meet its goal for sales and profit growth between 2000 and 2002. It expects sales in media and communications to rise 10 percent a year and earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortization to increase 35 percent annually between 2000 and 2002.

title: Starters to End On
description: Why fill up on bread when you can ruin your appetite on . . . the appetizer? Whether to compensate for rising meal prices or to contrast with the trendy amuse-bouches that come out compliments of the chef, appetizer portions seem to be expanding. Not merely larger versions of the same old starters, these oversize first courses differ from the traditional cold seafood and bland salads in using heavier ingredients, sauces and exotic garnishes. At Olives (201 Park Avenue South), Todd English offers super-starters like truffled beef tartare on olive oil mashed potatoes with crispy potato gaufrettes, truffle vinaigrette and the yolk of a quail egg and, above, chargrilled squid and octopus with its own side salad. When Sushi Samba opened its second restaurant this winter, at 87 Seventh Avenue, the owners increased the appetizer portions: seared yellowfin tuna with orange segments grew from five to seven pieces of tuna; fire-roasted calamari with quinoa salad went from one piece of calamari to two and a half.

title: Lives; Role Reversal

Six weeks later, the three of us sat in a recovery room at the hospital taking turns holding our son, DJ. Some adoptive parents abuse pronouns (''our son,'' ''my child'') to establish possession; it's as if they're saying, ''Our child now, not her child anymore.'' But doing an open adoption means embracing the ''most plural'' definition of every plural pronoun, at least where your child is concerned. When I say ''our'' son, his mother is included. We may be DJ's full-time parents, but she is his parent, too, and stealth-hostile pronouns can't change that.

The entire Boys Town Jerusalem family mourns the loss of a very special friend, wife of our esteemed Board member, Gil Aronowitz, who considered our students ''her'' boys. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOD, ELSIE HUNTER,
description: WOOD-Elsie Hunter, 92. Passed away quietly on Wednesday morning, February 21st, 2001, after complications from a fall. She had been a resident of Kendal-Crosslands Communities, a Quaker sponsored retirement community in Kennett Square, PA, for the past twelve years. Elsie Hunter Wood was born Gladys Eileen Symmons on May 28, 1908 in Swansea, Wales, and was the last surviving of ten children. Elsie, as she was known throughout her long life, emigrated to the United States to enter a nurses training program after World War I. She became a naturalized citizen after meeting & marrying Paul Edward Hunter, a textile executive active in various credit industry associations. They raised a family of four children in Port Washington, N.Y. Ed Hunter died suddenly of a heart attack in 1953. After raising and educating her children, Elsie moved to be near her sister, Edith Jonker, in East Hampton, Long Island. There, she met and married a local architect, Richard C. Wood. He built a house for them behind the Maidstone Arms. Homes designed by Mr. Wood were especially known for their placement and views. He retired in 1988 and they moved to Kendal-Crosslands where Mr. Wood died a year later. Mrs. Wood was cremated and her remains will be put to rest at the family plot in Port Washington at the Nassau-Knowles Cemetery. A memorial service is planned at the Manhasset Congregational Church Sunday April 22nd. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests tax deductible contributions be made to the Crosslands Reserve Fund, which assists elderly residents in financial need. Mrs. Wood is survived by her four Hunter children; Sally, who lives in New York City; John, a croquet enthusiast who lives in Westport, CT; Peter, a real estate broker in Orleans, Cape Cod; and Paul who is retired and lives in New Hampshire. She had numerous grandchildren and great-grandchildren, and is also survived by three stepchildren, Peter Wood, Patricia Asch and Sky Wood.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUICK, LESLIE C. JR.
description: QUICK-Leslie C. Jr., 75, on March 8, 2001, of North Palm Beach, FL and Aspen, CO, formerly of Laurel Hollow, NY. Wall Street visionary and philanthropist, founded Quick & Reilly, the first New York Stock Exchange member firm to offer discounted commissions to individuals and one of the nation's leading brokerage firms, expanding the business to include one of the largest specialist firms on the New York Stock Exchange, a major clearing and execution firm, and a NASDAQ market maker. An ebullient, dynamic and charismatic leader of the firm that bears his name, Mr. Quick was also highly esteemed for his philanthropy and leadership abilities in charitable, religious and civic causes. He was past Chairman of the Board of Trustees of Fairfield University and served as a member of the Board of Directors of the Alfred E. Smith Foundation; the Dana Farber Hospital in Boston; founder and member of the Board of Directors of The Inner City Scholarship Endowment Fund in New York City as well as board member of the Gregorian University in Rome, Italy. Additionally, Mr. Quick served as Chairman of the Board of St. Francis Heart Hospital and on the advisory council of St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in Memphis, TN. He was a Trustee of Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories. Mr. Quick was a Knight of Malta, Knight of the Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem and a member of the Cardinal's Committee of the Laity of the Archdiocese of New York. Mr. Quick graduated from Pennsylvania Military College, now Widener University, in 1950, and served as Chairman of its Board of Trustees. Widener awarded him an honorary doctorate in business administration in 1990 in recognition of his many accomplishments and achievements. He also received an honorary Doctorate of Law from Fairfield University. He was patron of both St. John Chrysostom School in Manhattan and St. Anselm School located in the Bronx. Mr. Quick is survived by wife of 50 years, Regina, children Leslie III, Thomas, Peter, Christopher, Mary Pedersen, Nancy Gibson, and Patricia Quick, 24 grandchildren, and a brother, Herbert. He was predeceased by his grandson, Raymond Crile Quick. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Patrick's Cathedral, New York City, on Monday, March 12, at 10am. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Leslie C. Quick Inner City Scholarship Endowment Fund, c/o Quick & Reilly, Inc., 26 Broadway, New York, NY 10004. QUICK-Leslie C., Jr. The President and Trustees of Fairfield University are deeply saddened by the death of their longtime colleague, friend and benefactor, Leslie C. Quick, Jr. Mr. Quick was the immediate past Chairman of the Board of Trustees and a member of the Board from 1982 through 1995. A dedicated Trustee, Mr. Quick was committed to Fairfield's mission as a Jesuit and Catholic university and strongly supported various University projects, including the arts. In 1990, with his generous support and leadership, the University constructed and dedicated the Regina A. Quick Center for the Arts named for his beloved wife, which continues to benefit students and the wider community each day. Mr. Quick was the father of three Fairfield University graduatesThomas, Christopher and Mary and a daughter-in-law, Eileen Manning Quick. Fairfield University was honored and blessed by the friendship and commitment of Mr. Quick and, by its conferral of an Honorary Doctorate on him in 1999, proudly made him forever an alumnus of the University. QUICK-Leslie C., Jr. The Gregorian University Foundation in the United States and the Pontifical Gregorian University Consortium in Rome mourn the loss of the Foundation's Vice Chairman, Leslie C. Quick, Jr. His inspiring leadership, his extraordinary generosity, his wise counsel and his warm friendship have endeared him to his fellow board members and to the faculty and students in Rome for whom he cared so deeply. We have loved him much and we will miss him greatly. We extend our love and deepest sympathy to Jean, who shared his life for 50 years, to his beloved children, Leslie III, Thomas, Peter, Christopher, Mary, Nancy and Patricia, and to his 24 grandchildren. Peter P. Mullen, Chairman William R. Grant, Vice Chairman Rev. Eugene O'Brien, S.J., Pres. Rev. Franco Imoda, S.J. Rev. Robert O'Toole, S.J. Rev. Hector Vall, S.J. QUICK-Les. We the D'Urso Family feel privileged to have known Les Quick as a special friend. Les' extraordinary generosity of heart in helping so many worthy causes was beyond measure. We in the Archdiocese of New York have been truly blessed to have known this great giant! As an outstanding husband and family man, Les will be greatly missed, not only by his family, but by his friends as well. We trust that he is now in the embrace of our Lord and his blessed mother who will say, ''Well done, our most faithful servant!''. With a heavy heart, Florence D'Urso and her family send their profound sympathy, dearest love and prayers to his lovely wife Regina and her dear family. QUICK-Leslie C., Jr. The residents, staff, and Trustees of Terence Cardinal Cooke Health Care Center mourn the loss of our great friend, supporter and benefactor, Leslie C. Quick, Jr., and we extend our deepest sympathies to his family. Mr. Quick was a major force in the establishment of an endowment fund that supports all volunteer programs at the Center. In addition, Mr. Quick provided ongoing support to many of the Center's programs and services that benefit disabled children, the elderly, and people with chronic illnesses. The spirit of his commitment to the Center will always be with us, and his family will remain in our prayers. QUICK-Leslie C., Jr. A man whose life represented the best of what man can strive for. He embraced life to the fullest, adored and cherished his family to the utmost and always sought and succeeded in doing the right thing. His wisdom and spirit has brighten the life all those lucky enough to have crossed paths with him. Our deepest sympathy to his loving family. With love and respect, Catherine and Fred Adler

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Mankind Won't Last
description: Science fiction, it is often said, reveals more about the time in which it was created than about the future it imagines. With that in mind, the tales in Arthur C. Clarke's COLLECTED STORIES (Tor/Tom Doherty, $29.95) are best appreciated not as adventures set on places like the surfaces of Mars and Jupiter -- though they are sometimes that -- but as products of the cold war. Clarke began writing shortly before World War II, and he consistently infused his work with both an optimism about technology and a fear of its misuse; the atomic bomb looms large over this book's 900-plus pages. That balance of dread and wonder is Clarke's hallmark, and it's what made his (and Stanley Kubrick's) screenplay to ''2001: A Space Odyssey'' such a deft fable -- after all, what's the HAL 9000 computer if not our collective technophobia personified? Clarke himself, however, was often a maddeningly unsubtle writer. His early stories for pulp magazines like Astounding Science Fiction are, well, pulpy -- formulaic, wooden tales turning on a science factoid and featuring a human race threatened by aliens, atomic hubris or (too often) our future insect masters. His skills did improve by the end of the 1960's -- when he all but abandoned the short story -- though technology and its discontents remained his obsession. In ''Improving the Neighborhood,'' a fable published in Nature magazine in 1999, Clarke makes humanity blow up the earth yet again. Cold war or not, Clarke wants to remind us, we're always a hair's breadth away from engineering our own ruin. Mark Athitakis

The market is now dominated by electronic devices like stun guns, stun batons, stun shields and stun belts -- nonlethal devices that are used by law-enforcement officials all across this country. Amnesty International has provided the following sample of recent products and manufacturers or exporters. The human rights group is careful to note that none of these companies are involved in the production or export of torture equipment -- merely that this type of equipment has been used for torture, and that its trade should be more closely regulated.

title: In Vienna, Art Opens A Window
description: I'VE never been quite sure what Old World charm is -- but whatever it is, I'm not very susceptible. It had been many years since my last visit to Vienna, and as I headed downtown from the airport, I was steeling myself for the oversize portions of Sacher torte, Strauss and Austro-Hungarian imperial razzmatazz. The taxi driver was taciturn. Beyond the car window, the city outskirts were a misty gray forest of petrochemical refineries. Not too much Old World charm there. Fine. I could live with that.

title: In the War on Gibberish, a New Investor Ally
description: DURING the bull market of the 1990's, great towers of Babel, like the one in the biblical region of Shinar, were erected by much of corporate America. From these towers spewed the spin on company performance or prospects that was needed to support swollen stock prices.

title: The Once And Future Oporto
description: OPORTO bills itself as a ''vintage destination,'' and perhaps the heavy-handed tag is inevitable, given its dozens of ancient port lodges, where the city's famous fortified wine is still blended and stored, and a charming old town declared a Unesco World Heritage site. But along with its past glories the city offers modern attractions, thanks to an ambitious building and restoration program planned to coincide with Oporto's reign, shared by Rotterdam, as European City of Culture 2001.

title: Brotherly Tradition, From Collar to Cuff
description: IT was a typical Tuesday afternoon at Joseph's Hairstyling, a nondescript salon with barber pole, four chairs and, yes, back issues of Playboy on the windowsill. And typically, the appointment book was filled with corporate chairmen and chief executives.

title: 'Freaks and Geeks': The Honest Agony Of Embarrassment
description: OLD sitcoms never die -- they just move to cable, where they surface at odd intervals forevermore. The nice thing about this two-tiered system of programming is that it occasionally allows those of us who don't live on the cutting edge of popular culture to catch up with how the hipper half lives. So I paid attention when my friend Laura, a graduate student from Chicago who specializes in Victorian literature but also keeps close tabs on the doings of people like P. J. Harvey and Conan O'Brien, called to tell me that the Fox Family Channel was running two episodes of ''Freaks and Geeks'' back to back every Tuesday night, and that I absolutely had to tune in.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAVENTHOL, HENRY
description: LAVENTHOL-Henry ''Hank'' 73. Died peacefully at home of cancer, February 21. He graduated from Yale University with a BA in fine arts, and later studied in Italy and France. Hank was a gifted painter who worked in many other media, including photography. He was a master printer, specializing in multi-plate color etching. Some critics considered him a surrealist. Hank, however, preferred to think of his work as dealing with fantasy realism. Mr. Laventhol is written up in Benezit, the definitive international directory of artists, and Who's Who in America. He exhibited his work throughout the U.S. and Europe. He was a gentle, kind man with a fine, broad mind, well versed on many subjects and possessed a keen sense of humor. A world traveler who enjoyed practicing his language skills. He loved music and was a knowledgeable opera buff. He is survived by his loving Dutch-born wife and soul mate, Josay, nee Weitjens, of 36 years; a brother, Richard Laventhol; a sister Susan Siegel; nieces Alison Laventhol, Madeleine Welp, and nephews Gary Druckman and Philip Welp. He was loved by many for his fine character and for his work that brought poetry, translated into images, into people's lives. Donations may be made to AmeriCares, 161 Cherry Street, New Canaan, CT. 06840 www.americares.org

According to the International Committee of the Red Cross, more than 7,000 disappeared and are presumed dead.

title: Constellation Prize
description: The run on PlayStation 2's was understandable; the craze for Barbie in-line skates made perfect sense. But a hot telescope? So it seems. When Orion introduced its Skyquest XT4.5 last fall -- the first Dobsonian scope with advanced features designed to be user-friendly enough for ages ''8 to 88'' -- the scope promptly sold out. And this month, as the telescope reappears on retail shelves at $279, toy and camera stores seem to be having trouble keeping it in stock. According to Karl Wong, the manager of Zittles, the toy department at Zitomer Pharmacy on Madison Avenue and 76th Street, the store received a shipment of them last week, and within days, it had sold all but one. ''It's simple enough for children to operate,'' Mr. Wong said, ''but fancy enough for their parents.'' Mr. Wong attributes its appeal to parents seeking an alternative to the rock 'em, sock 'em world of action toys and video games. ''People are trying to find something good for their kids to watch that doesn't involve violence or joysticks,'' he said. ''And, hey -- the sky's a classic.''

title: Children's Books; Mabel, the Night and the Music
description: The evening of their gala dancing party, young Mabel's caring parents scurry about, mindful of including her, whenever possible, in the preparations. She ''blew bubbles in the bath while Mama dressed up and Papa tied his dancing shoes.'' Eventually, though, Mabel is lovingly tucked into bed and that is supposed to be that. But, as Amy Hest's words and Christine Davenier's illustrations in MABEL DANCING (Candlewick, $15.99; ages 4 to 8) tell us so charmingly, like so many children left out of grown-up fun, Mabel feels forlorn, ''alone in the night.'' Hearing the music from the party ''floating up the stairs,'' she creeps to a perch at the top of the staircase and watches the ''papas in bow ties'' and ''mamas, too, in swirling gowns.'' It's only a matter of time before Mabel has danced her way down the stairs and ''in the bright party light . . . spinning past the guests . . . floating through the rooms.'' The ball they are giving may be glamorous, but Mabel's parents are down-to-earth and utterly captivated by their little girl. They love seeing her dance, and encourage her to take a deep bow in her red nightgown and yellow cape (a blanket). Best of all, Papa asks her to dance with him and Mama, and the three of them ''danced away in the velvet light.'' Eventually, they dance ''up and up the stairs,'' and Mabel is finally, happily, put to bed for the night. A dreamy, evocative portrait of parental love as it's supposed to be: all-encompassing and unconditional. Betsy Groban

title: Women Who Work at Home
description: Well before ''A League of Their Own,'' there were women playing baseball. There were organized teams in the 1860's, for example, and the Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center in Little Falls has an 1868 newpaper's front page to prove it. It is part of an exhibition called ''The American Sportswoman: a Tribute to Ladies in Baseball,'' which also displays photographs (among them one of a pitcher named Jackie Mitchell, who struck out Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig in a 1912 exhibition), programs, posters and other artifacts. The exhibition runs to April 29. To mark Women's History Month, the museum will also show a documentary film, ''Running Down a Dream,'' about the basketball career of a girl from stardom at a Long Island high school to her decision to attend the University of California at Los Angeles. The showing will take place 7 p.m. Tuesday, and the filmmaker, Leandra Reilly Lardner, will speak afterward. The Yogi Berra Museum and Learning Center, 8 Quarry Road, Little Falls, (973) 655-2377, www.yogiberramuseum.com, is open Wednesdays through Sundays from noon to 5 p.m. Admission is $4; $2 for students.

title: His Lyrics Made It to Broadway, Now His Songs

But even though he commanded great respect for his innovative lyrics to ''A Chorus Line'' -- the longest-running show in Broadway history until ''Cats'' surpassed it several years ago -- Kleban wanted to be recognized as the prolific composer he was. The problem: his songs never made it to Broadway. Not until now, that is, when ''A Class Act'' -- a show about what he really ''did for love,'' to quote his lyric from ''A Chorus Line'' -- opens tonight at the Ambassador Theater.

title: The Claritin Effect; Prescription for Profit
description: It had been yet another miserable, nose-dripping, red-eyed spring a couple of years ago, when I finally went to see an allergy specialist. I've been battered by seasonal allergies all my life but relied on family doctors and, more recently, ''primary-care physicians'' for relief. In a kind of a pharmaceutical version of playing catch with Dad, my father and I shared his hay-fever pills when I was growing up. They were smooth, round yellow tablets, etched with a tiny red corporate symbol that was as delicate as a Chinese ideograph. At a time before people routinely gobbled down a half dozen medicines a day, those pills held a kind of mythic power for me, not only because they could make the misery of allergies disappear but also because they were prescription drugs -- inherently more powerful, more inaccessible, more special.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-11-01; A Hazard of Good Fortunes

And why not declare victory? By almost every measure, life in the United States today is the best it has ever been: ever-rising living standards; rising life expectancy and falling rates of disease; low unemployment; declining rates of crime, pollution and poverty; low risk of war; unlimited supplies of just about everything; personal freedom never greater. This is America's Golden Age.

title: Crystals Cling On
description: The fashion world may be declaring the two-year-old Swarovski crystal trend dead, but the public isn't listening. For shine-seekers who just can't get enough, new options continue to pop up. Last month, Swarovski, the Austrian crystal company, added Body Gem, a line of real gem body tattoos, to its Crystal temporary tattoos collection. The colorful droplet-size gemstones -- peridot, amethyst, blue and white topaz, garnet and citrine -- are backed with adhesive that is activated by body heat. The gems are supposed to stay in place for up to three days, even after bathing, and are reusable ($36 for a set of three, $65 for a mixed assortment of five, at www.gem.net). For a more professional application, crystal body tattoos and bikini waxes are now being offered for $85 at the Completely Bare salon (764 Madison Avenue at 65th Street) and for $65 at Soho Sanctuary (119 Mercer Street). And next month, Noir, known for creating crystal designs, will open Shop Noir at 246-248 Mott Street. It will sell the look in the form of crystal-studded nude thongs, starting at $30. Anyone with a preferred brand of lingerie can bring in her own thongs to be embellished, for $25 and up. All of the lingerie must be new, though -- with tags still attached. KARI HASKELL

title: Advertisements for Themselves
description: In their low-slung Denver living room last fall, Robert Schneider and Hilarie Sidney were talking about what it means for musicians to sell out. Robert sat on the carpet, jittery and animated under a wisp of sandy hair; his wife, Hilarie, who was eight months pregnant with their first child, offered cookies. The day the Beach Boys sold ''Good Vibrations'' for a soft-drink ad, they agreed, was one of betrayal and ruin. ''That was the Beach Boys at their wildest and most psychedelic,'' Robert says. ''For a long time after that, it was hard for me to take the song out of the Sunkist commercial.''

title: QUICK BITE/Newark; A Cornucopia for Carnivores
description: Fancy restaurants might try to impress with cheese carts or Caesar salads made tableside. But those pale next to the spectacle at Brasilia, a Brazilian barbecue spot in the Ironbound district of Newark. Although there is a large menu, loyal customers have only one thing on their minds when they enter this sprawling cafeteria-style place: the rodzio de churrasco, an all-you-can-eat procession of charcoal-grilled meats. After a warm-up trip to the salad bar, the fun begins. Your waiter slips a card with the number of rodzio eaters in your party onto a tall silver stand, and in seconds the first of an army of servers arrives. ''Beef?'' he asks, brandishing a two-foot-long skewer of sirloin, which he then slices onto your plate. Steps behind him is another server with a skewer of pork, and another with a skewer of chicken. Soon your plate is piled high with sirloin, ribs, chicken, pork, bacon-wrapped turkey, leg of lamb, spare ribs and a variety of sausages. Then there are the sides of rice and beans, fried plantains and bananas, French fries and so on. Don't expect any tangy red barbecue sauce. While the chicken and pork are marinated overnight, the beef is simply seasoned with salt. ''We let the charcoal and smoke do the rest,'' said the owner, Ademir DeSouza. The price of this never-ending feast is $16. That's a bit higher than the normal Quick Bite tab, but considering the cost per bite (if you're a light eater, what are you doing here?) it's a steal. When you're done, the waiter lowers the green flag, signaling that for you, the show is over. Dessert? Dare you. Gretchen Kurtz

Graduated AB from Williams College in 1950 and LLB from Columbia in 1953; clerked on the U.S. Court of Appeals, District of Columbia, practiced corporate law in Cleveland until 1961 when he joined the Kennedy administration to work on Peace Corp legislation. He was Director of Peace Corp Operations in East Africa '61-'63, and Associate Deputy Director in Washington '63-'64. At Columbia, he served as General Counsel to the Executive Committee of the Faculty formed in '68 to handle the serious student demonstrations, as Law School Vice Dean '73-'76, Acting Dean '76-'77, Director African Law Center, Director Center for Law and Economics. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, EDWARD
description: COOK-Edward Willingham. Died peacefully at his home in Palm Beach, Florida on Thursday, March 8, 2001, aged 78. Mr. Cook also resided in Gloustershire, England. Philanthropist, war hero, business and civic leader in Palm Beach, England and in his original hometown of Memphis, TN. Mr. Cook was the son of Brigadier General Everett R. Cook, a World War I fighter ace and Phoebe Willingham Cook. Mr. Cook was born June 19, 1922. In January 1942, Mr. Cook enlisted in the United States Air Force. By this time, in his early 20's, Mr. Cook was a major and was awarded the Bronze Star and the Air Medal with four oak leaf clusters. After graduating from the Hotchkiss School and Yale University, he entered the commodities business where he was the leader in the development of the huge grain shipment to Russia in the mid 1970's. He was Chairman and Chief Executive Office of Cook International 1964-1995; a director of First Tennessee Corp., Memphis 1969-1988; chairman of First Presidential Bank, Innovations Group Plc., U.K. 1987-1994; general partner, Palm Beach Capital 1987-1995; chairman Mid-South International Agricenter, Memphis 1979-1982; member of the Cotton Advisory Commission 1964-1968; member of the Executive Committee of the National Council for U.S.-China Trade 1973-1978; member of the President's Export Council 1973-1979; and, director of the Chicago Board of Trade 1974-1976. He was Chairman of the Memphis-Shelby County Airport Authority 1968-1981 and a member of the Southern Cotton Association (past president), the Cotton Council of America (board of directors 1962-1965), American Cotton Shippers Association (past president). Mr. Cook founded the Alexis de Tocqueville Society in Palm Beach and received their award of merit. He was a member of the Memphis Country Club, Memphis Hunt and Polo Club, Links (New York City), Union Club (New York City), Everglades Club, Bath and Tennis Club (Palm Beach, Florida) and Boodles (London). He is survived by his wife, Patricia L. Cook, and his children Edward W. Cook, Jr. of Sarasota, Florida; Everett R, Cook, II of New York, NY; Barbara C. Brooks Jones of San Francisco, CA; Mark W. Cook of Palm Beach, FL and Patricia Kendall Cook of San Francisco, CA; and his five grandchildren. His sister, Phoebe Cook Welsh of Houston, TX also survives him. A service will be held in Palm Beach, Florida on Sunday, March 11, 2001 at 2:00PM at Bethesda-by-the-Sea Church. A memorial service will be held in Memphis at a later date. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in Mr. Cook's memory to: Hospice of Palm Beach, 5300 East Avenue; West Palm Beach, Florida 33407-2387.

title: Ideals Made of Paper and the Impact of the Unbuilt

But the borders between segments are exceedingly porous. And Part 2 is clearly the heart of the show. Titled ''Perfect Acts of Architecture,'' it is a selection of paper architecture, unbuilt or unbuildable projects by Peter Eisenman, Bernard Tschumi, Rem Koolhaas, Thom Mayne and Daniel Libeskind. To these, the curator, Jeffrey Kipnis, adds furniture by Scott Burton, movie title sequences by the Los Angeles firm Imaginary Forces, and a full-scale gallery installation by the architect Greg Lynn and the painter Fabian Marcaccio, which was created for the show.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Making the World Anew
description: Jacob Lawrence (1917-2000) was a consummate storyteller, and during his 65-year career he painted vivid narratives, ranging from sweeping historical epics to intimate vignettes of daily life. Lawrence's vast output is aptly captured in THE COMPLETE JACOB LAWRENCE (University of Washington, $150), a two-volume set that documents more than 900 of the artist's paintings, drawings and murals. Essays track Lawrence's life and evolution, including his precocious beginnings in Depression-era Harlem and his becoming, in 1941, the first black artist represented by a major commercial gallery. Lawrence's ability to negotiate the demands of both the art world and the black community is also explored, along with his balancing acts between abstraction and figuration, personal expression and social commitment. While the surface of Lawrence's work remained fairly constant over the decades -- bearing a trademark style of flat shapes, bold color and rhythmic patterns -- his art was informed by diverse sources and beneath the bright facade lay a strong sense of injustice at the suffering caused by discrimination and poverty. Although his works focused on the plight of black Americans, most notably in series like ''The Life of Harriet Tubman'' and ''The Migration of the Negro,'' Lawrence sought to address ''the struggle of man to always better his condition and to move forward.'' As one of the essays argues, this larger human aspiration is best expressed in Lawrence's paintings devoted to the theme of builders, a subject that engaged him from the mid-1940's until the end of his life. This was also an image that mirrored Lawrence's own constructive endeavor: a figure striving to refashion the world through creative labor. Suzanne Ramljak

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHL, PAUL

Died as a result of a stroke at Palm Beach Gardens, Florida on March 6, 2001. Mr. Kohl spent almost 50 years as a general contractor in New York managing the family operated Herbert Construction Company. As a member of the ''Greatest Generation'', Master Sargent Kohl served proudly in the U.S. Army, participating in the envasion and liberation of France. Mr, Kohl's charitable works included support of numerous organizations serving the Jewish and general commmunities. Funeral services will be held at Gutterman's Funeral Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island Friday March 9 at 10AM. Interment at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pine Lawm, Long Iland. In lieu of flowers, a donation to a charity of your choice would be appreciated. KOHL-Paul. It was your strength, loyalty, honesty, enormous generosity and commitment to family that we will remember and miss most. The special bond you had with your grandchildren Lindsay, Stacey and Spencer was truly wonderful. We love you and will think of mother and you often. You leave much to be proud of and we are proud to be your living legacy. Ken, Myrna, Spencer Kohl

title: Breaking the Sacred
description: The high valley of Bamiyan, where the Taliban are currently vandalizing the priceless statues of Buddha, has long been venerated as a holy site. Certain places have always been felt to be especially close to the divine world, because of some exceptional feature which seemed to speak of ''something else.'' In Bamiyan, it was probably the extraordinary beauty of the landscape. Enclosed by the towering, snowy mountains of the Hindu Kush and Koh-i-Baba, the valley itself is lush and green, filled with clear, cold streams. A community of Buddhist monks settled there more than 1,500 years ago and eventually carved out from the rock face of the mountains hundreds of cells and shrine halls, which they decorated with rich wall paintings.

As he sat on the beach, what he read made him angrier and angrier. Finally, he jumped to his feet and began walking up and down the sand, shouting to his wife: ''You gotta see this! For Charles Baudelaire, the Parisian ragpickers were poets who found inspiration in the city's teeming, trash-filled streets. Eugne Atget photographed their hovels, cobbled together from odd scraps of tin and lumber. Later, Picasso's Cubist collages, incorporating bits of newspaper and packaging, helped usher in the art of the 20th century.

title: Tightening the Belt

They are of many types, from wide leather versions to 1950's-style elasticized belts that cinch the waist. There are decorative belts defining a high waist in a French Empire look, and even an offbeat shoulder belt. One woman enlivened her mink coat with a wide leather belt, while a woman in a trench coat marked a low waist with a gold-embroidered belt. These women are ahead of the curve as designers in New York and Europe unveil their collections for next winter, where the belt is creating a fresh silhouette.

title: March 4-10; Annan May Meet Taliban

Mystery hangs over the statues' fate: the Taliban have not allowed outsiders to travel to the town, a two-day drive to the west of Kabul. Mr. Annan may meet Taliban officials in Pakistan, the first stop on a 10-day trip, where he may also discuss the future of the fugitive sponsor of terrorism, Osama bin Laden. Barbara Crossette

title: DONATIONS FOR ATHLETES
description: The Camden School Board will discuss a report investigating donations made to Camden High School's basketball program by the Nike shoe company and a Philadelphia sports promoter. The donations came to light last week as Camden, last year's state basketball champion, started the defense of its crown. Camden's coach, Glen Jackson, admitted that Nike had outfitted his team in its athletic wear and that Jeremy Treatman, through his Scholastic Play-by-Play Network, has provided the team with expenses and lodging at tournaments he promoted in Memphis, Philadelphia and Trenton. Mr. Treatman also said he gave cash donations of unspecified amounts to the Camden basketball program. Though the state interscholastic athletic association has said such payments are not necessarily against its rules, the Camden School District wanted to investigate whether they were against school board policy. title: The Nation: Over a Barrel; New Gun Control Politics: A Whimper, Not a Bang

Unlike in 1999, when Democrats reacted almost immediately to the massacre at Columbine High School in Colorado with demands for tough new gun restrictions, there were few calls to action. Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, one of Washington's most aggressive gun control proponents, simply suggested a voluntary ''code of ethics'' for gun owners and their families.

The Greeneville hurried through crucial maneuvers -- including a periscope search -- in order to return to Pearl Harbor on schedule, he said. But he said that he had uncovered no evidence that the captain, Cmdr. Scott D. Waddle, had ignored warnings of a collision or otherwise acted negligently. Steven Lee Myers

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TROSTEN, WILLIAM S.
description: TROSTEN-William S. Age 73. Of Austerlitz, N.Y. and New York City. Died of cancer on March 6, 2001. He was born in New York City, attended public schools there, and served in the U.S. Army during W.W. II. He worked for the American Jewish Committee for approximately forty years, retiring as its Associate Director. In 1989, together with the late Theodore Ellenoff, a past President of the American Jewish Committee and a leading New York attorney, Mr. Trosten co-founded The Armonk Institute, an American Jewish organization. The Armonk Institute seeks to improve American-German relations by focusing on post 1945 Germany in order to promote better understanding between Americans and Germans, and overcome historic stereotypes. Mr. Trosten served as President of The Armonk Institute until his death. His achievements were recognized by such German oranizations as the Friedrich Ebert Foundation, the Konrad Adenauer Foundation, the Atlantik Bruecke and several German universities. In 1990, the then president of the Federal Republic of Germany, Richard von Wiezaecker, bestowed upon Mr. Trosten the Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit. Mr. Trosten had been married to the late Eugenie S. Trosten, who died in 1999. A brother, Leonard M. Trosten of Savanah, GA., and other family members survive him. A memorial service will be held at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St on March 19th, 11:30AM. Contributions in Mr. Trosten's memory may be sent to The Armonk Institute, c/o Douglas S. Ellenoff, Secretary, Suite 1900, 370 Lexington Ave, New York, N.Y. 10017.

title: Voting First, Debating Later

title: AIDS Drugs for Poor Nations
description: The past week has brought surprising progress toward making AIDS drugs more affordable in poor nations. The most significant development was an announcement by Merck, which makes two of the most widely used -- and costliest -- antiretrovirals used in triple therapy for AIDS. The company will lower the drugs' prices in poor countries to a tenth of their first-world price. There were also developments on low-cost generic AIDS drugs. Cipla, the Bombay-based generic drug manufacturer, which a few weeks ago offered to sell triple therapy at $600 a year to poor nations, has now said it will ask South Africa for a license to sell eight antiretrovirals there. In addition, Hetero Drugs, another Indian generic drug maker, has announced that it will offer triple therapy for $350 a year.

description: The fight to reform the nation's flawed and uneven death penalty system resumed in Congress last week with the introduction of a bill aimed at reducing the risk of executing innocent people. The bipartisan Innocence Protection Act of 2001 would address the problem of incompetent lawyering in death penalty cases by establishing new national standards for the representation of capital defendants, and by providing resources to help meet them. It would also require the preservation of biological evidence -- for example, hair fibers -- that could later prove crucial to an appeal, and guarantee federal and state death-row inmates access to DNA testing if that could help exonerate them.

title: A Healthy SAT Debate
description: The SAT will be taken by two million people this year and is required for admission at the vast majority of of the country's four-year colleges and universities. The test has dominated the admissions process for more than half a century and is likely to do so for decades to come. Even so, administrators at some selective colleges have discarded the SAT, on the grounds that it distorts the educational process and screens out minority students and others who perform perfectly well in college. Defenders of the test range from those who see it as a vital yardstick in a time of grade inflation to those who view it as a flawed but necessary component of the sorting process and the true believers who see it as a sacred index revealing everything one needs to know about an individual. Given the confusion, the emerging debate about how best to use the SAT is a healthy and potentially useful development.

title: When Not to Grasp at a Cure

Although drugs helped for a while, the disease proved unrelenting as cells in his brain died and he was deprived of dopamine, an essential chemical.
