title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILIPS, ALBEN
description: PHILIPS-Alben. Career newspaperman known to his friends and colleagues as Bill or Flip, died of natural causes February 16, 2001. He was raised and died on East 15th Street in Manhattan. He was 89. Essentially a self-taught man, he was hired by the New York World in the 1930's. In 1941 he joined the Daily Mirror as a Copy Editor. During his tenure at the Mirror, he also taught journalism courses at Long Island University. Nineteen years later, he became a member of the foreign and then metro copy desk at The New York Times, again for nineteen years. He was a staunch union man and a shop steward for the Guild while at the Times. In 1979 he spent a year in Paris working for The International Herald Tribune before returning to New York. He then continued copy editing at India Abroad until he was 85. A lifelong automotive enthusiast, Mr. Philips authored two books in the late 1950s for Arco/Fawcett about small cars, predicting America's enbrace of the compact, as well as many feature articles on a variety of subjects for various publications. In addition, he was a gifted musician able to play several instruments. In fact, his first job as a journalist was music critic for a small chain of newspapers in upstate New York. A lingering case of Tuberculosis from his youth kept him out of World War II, his greatest regret. Above all, Bill Philips was a kind, gracious, empathetic, cultured, nurturing man with a wonderful S.J. Pearlman/ Monty Python sense of humor. He is survived by a son and daughter, Binky and Dezanne, his wife Ruth Gray, his daughter-in-law Susan, his granddaughter Eleanor, his brothers Henry and Eliot, his sister Shirley and many nieces and nephews who will all miss him for the rest of their lives. Memorial service will be announced at a later date.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SHIP CARGO RISES
description: Shipping is booming in New York Harbor, according to data released yesterday by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Imports and exports rose almost 10 percent when measured by tonnage, and by 13.5 percent when measured by dollar value, in 2000 compared with 1999 figures. Car imports surged by more than 12 percent, but auto exports dropped by 25 percent; still, the port remains the busiest auto handler in the nation, the Port Authority said. China was the port's biggest export market last year, while Italy was the largest source of imports. The figures include shipping at Port Newark and Port Elizabeth in New Jersey, Red Hook in Brooklyn, Howland Hook in Staten Island and the New York Passenger Ship Terminal in Manhattan. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

The big chorus speaks first from his bedside, and then transforms itself into heavenly hosts and threatening demons from below. Angels lead the man's soul along his path.

But the result, published this week, showed that patients get no benefit on the whole, at least from the treatment in its present form.

title: The Hale-Bopp Show
description: Comet Hale-Bopp, which put on a spectacular show passing through the inner solar system in 1997, is still acting much like a comet  throwing off dust and gas  despite being 1.2 billion miles from the sun. Recent photographs from the European Southern Observatory in Chile (Hale- Bopp is now visible only by telescopes and only in the Southern Hemisphere) show that it still has a long coma and tail, signs that it is still shedding. This is unusual for a comet so far from the sun; experts are not sure why this is, but they suggest that the large size of Hale-Bopp's nucleus has something to do with it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOCKHART, GEORGE R.
description: LOCKHART - George R., 71. Passed away Friday, March 9, 2001. He will live on always in the hearts of his loving wife Inez Kirby, daughter Mariko Lockhart, her husband Cesar Torres and mother Etsuko (Eppie) Lockhart, his grandchildren Jorge and Natalia, & his sister Edith Schultz. He was predeceased by his son Aaron. Born in Panama City, Panama on March 30, 1929, George Lockhart grew up in Chicago. He graduated from the University of Illnois and received a Master's in Social Work from Columbia University. After serving in the U.S. Army, he embarked on a lifelong career in social services, including Program Management of the Lower Eastside's University Settlement House and Directorship of Pioneer Youth Camp. George Lockhart went on to a tenured professorship in the Graduate School of Social Work at Adelphi University. Recognized as a highly imaginative and unassumingly brilliant master teacher and scholar, George Lockhart won the profound respect, admiration and recognition of his colleagues. His commitment to social work and his focus on community organizing are a noble legacy that lives on in the countless social workers he taught and nurtured. A gifted musician, George brought music into the lives of all he touched. A celebration of his life will be held on Saturday, March 17, 2001 at 2:30PM at the Friend's Meeting House, 15th Street & Rutherford Place (between 2nd and 3rd Avenues) in Manhattan. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, a donation to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

The company will take a charge of 40 million ($58.7 million) this year and 20 million ($29.3 million) next year, said Trevor Slack, IMI's finance director. Most of the cuts will come in the United States and Germany, as IMI shifts production to China and Mexico. title: US UNWIRED TO SELL 173 COMMUNICATIONS TOWERS TO SBA
description: US Unwired said yesterday that it would sell as many as 173 communications towers in the Southeast to the SBA Communications Corporation for about $54.1 million, the companies' second transaction this year. SBA exercised its option to buy the towers for $313,000 each in the second quarter, US Unwired said. US Unwired, which provides mobile-phone service, will lease space on each of the towers for $1,500 a month, with rate increases of 4 percent each year, US Unwired said. US Unwired is based in Lake Charles, La.

title: So Little Time for Poetry During a Roller Coaster Ride
description: Daniel Barenboim is a storyteller, not a poet. He's a storyteller because the pieces he conducts have a dramatic motion; they are always emphatically going somewhere. But he's not a poet because he doesn't stop to bring details into a sharper focus: a phrase, the nuance of a single tone, the kind of perfection that can make an audience hold its breath.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSBARD, SOPHIE (MAROZ)
description: GROSSBARD-Sophie (Maroz). On Monday, March 12, of Canton, MA, formerly of New York City. Born in Wabash, Indiana, on September 24, 1908, where she graduated from Wabash College. She received her Master of Social Work degree from Columbia University. She worked and taught lifelong in New York City as a social worker for the Department of Public Welfare. Involved in many progressive social causes, primarily focused on helping the poor. Married for 64 years to the late Hyman Grossbard, Professor Emeritus, Columbia University. They had no children. She played a singular role and remains a beloved role model for her many nieces and nephews in the USA, in Israel and in France. Funeral arrangements are private. Donations to the Lown Cardiovascular Foundation, 21 Longwood Avenue, Brookline, MA 02446-5239. For information Levine Chapel, Brookline.

title: Corrections

For 20 years enjoyed working at Westchester Community College. A memorial service will be held at Temple Beit Hayam, Palm City, FL., Thursday, March 15, at 11:30 A.M.

title: Running Again, McGreevey Says He'd Fight Corruption
description: With the Democratic nomination all but locked up, Mayor James E. McGreevey of Woodbridge made his candidacy for New Jersey governor official yesterday, declaring that he would end what he called eight years of ''corruption and cover-ups'' in Trenton.

title: For Rensselaer Polytechnic, a Record-Setting Gift With No Strings Attached
description: An anonymous donor has given Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., $360 million, believed to be the largest single gift ever to a university in the United States, the institute announced yesterday. Unlike most large gifts, it comes with no strings attached on how it may be used.

title: California G.O.P. Courts Superhero

description: The electronic signs inside Amtrak's brand-new Acela Express train yesterday morning read ''welcome aboa.'' I was hoping this was a good thing. I was hoping it meant that the Amtrak people were in too much of a hurry to finish the thought.

title: What Tests Can't Fix

The students receive shamefully low math and reading scores on mandatory state exams. And politicians and business leaders condemn the schools as dysfunctional.

description: In an attempt to heal a relationship that had seemed beyond repair all spring, Los Angeles Dodgers outfielder Gary Sheffield apologized tonight to the team chairman, Bob Daly, in a lengthy meeting that also included Sheffield's new agent, Scott Boras.

title: TAIWAN BANK MERGER
description: The Finance Ministry ordered the state-run Bank of Taiwan, the Land Bank of Taiwan and Central Trust of China to merge, forming a lender with $122 billion of assets and control of a fifth of the banking industry in Taiwan. The government canceled plans to merge the lenders last year because of concerns about job reductions. It tentatively revived the plan last month and will combine the banks by early next year, after giving assurances to workers that they will not be laid off, Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said.

title: MICROSOFT AND EBAY FORM BROAD ALLIANCE
description: Microsoft and eBay said yesterday that they had entered into an alliance under which eBay's auction Web site would adopt some of Microsoft's software and Microsoft would make eBay's auction listings available on some of Microsoft's sites, like MSN. EBay has been a major customer of a Microsoft competitor, Sun Microsystems. EBay's chief executive, Meg Whitman, said her company would continue to use Sun computers and software for the company's back-end computing operations. Analysts said the strategic relationship was the first of a series of deals by Microsoft as it tried to start its Internet initiative, .Net. John Markoff

description: An errant 500-pound bomb dropped by a Navy fighter over Kuwait today tore apart an observation post filled with military personnel, killing six and seriously wounding three others, American military officials said.

title: Where There's Less Smoke
description: Almost six years ago New York's City Council passed a smoking ordinance that cleared the air in most public restaurants but made unfortunate exemptions for smaller restaurants and for the bar areas of larger eating establishments. Now, with growing concern about the hazards of secondhand smoke and the realization that restaurants could survive and even thrive without ashtrays, the Council is finally ready to shift smokers out of the city's eateries altogether. Smokers would be allowed to smoke only in closed smoking rooms at restaurants, in nightclubs and taverns where food is not the main draw or on the sidewalks outside.

Grandfather of David and Laura Paradise, Abraham and Abigail Fisher & Naomi Zikmund-Fisher, also seven great-grandchildren. Family requests donations to James C. and Charlotte Paradise Scholarship Fund or James C. Paradise and Maurice McCracken Fund, both at Greater Cincinnati Foundation, 200 West 4th Street, Cincinnati, OH. 45202.

title: Tales of High Living and Berluti Boots Regale Dumas Trial : The Gang That Accessorized

A rhinestone's throw away from the Carrousel du Louvre, judges and some members of the public (courtroom passes are hotter tickets than collection invites) are being regaled with tales about the lifestyles of some racy characters who looted the giant Elf oil company in the early 1990s.

title: Sports of The Times; The Legend Of 'The Line' In Las Vegas
description: IN his heyday as the nation's most respected oddsmaker, dozens of gamblers gathered at the Churchill Downs Sports Book in Las Vegas every Monday morning in the pro football season to watch Bob Martin chalk the next Sunday's point spread on a blackboard: -6 next to the Oakland Raiders, for example, or +2 1/2 next to the Minnesota Vikings.

title: For 7 Million People in Census, One Race Category Isn't Enough
description: Nearly seven million people say they belong to more than one race, a small, largely youthful generation of multiracial Americans in an increasingly diverse country, data from the 2000 census show.

title: SONY, TOSHIBA AND I.B.M. WORKING ON CHIP
description: Fighting the tide of retrenchment in the technology industry, Sony, Toshiba and I.B.M. announced a joint project yesterday to research and develop a ''supercomputer on a chip'' for extremely fast network processors to be used in a range of consumer electronics devices. The companies said they would invest more than $400 million in the project over the next five years and that it would be based at a development center at I.B.M.'s complex in Austin, Tex. The companies hope the new chip will power consumer devices that will be more powerful than I.B.M.'s Deep Blue supercomputer, operate at low power and provide access to the broadband Internet at ultrahigh speeds. Susan Stellin

title: Minnesota Health Plans to Standardize Treatments
description: Five health plans that cover almost every resident of Minnesota will announce today that they are supporting standard treatment and prevention procedures for 50 common ailments like lower back pain, high blood pressure, diabetes and bladder infections.

title: To Boos and Hisses, Feisty Mayor Shares His Ideas With Teachers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was booed with gusto yesterday by educators packing a ballroom in Brooklyn as he called for vouchers and charter schools but not pay increases that would put New York City teachers' salaries on a par with those in the suburbs.

title: MARCHFIRST'S TOP OFFICERS RESIGN
description: MarchFirst, an Internet consulting firm based in Chicago, said yesterday that Robert F. Bernard, its chairman and chief executive, and two other executives had resigned. The company has had numerous problems and has laid off 1,500 workers in the last four months. Its stock price has plunged from a one-time high of more than $52 to close down another 12.5 percent yesterday, at 98 cents. The company said that in addition to its chief executive, the chief operating officer, Thomas R. Metz, and the executive vice president, Joseph Bong, had resigned. Steve Pollema, executive vice president for global operations, was appointed president while the company seeks a new chief executive. Andrew Zipern

title: Napster Blocks Users From Trading Files On 26,000 Songs
description: Napster said today that as part of a court order issued one week ago, it has blocked users from trading 115,000 music files corresponding to about 26,000 songs whose copyrights are owned by the major record labels. But the company asserted its progress in blocking the exchange of copyrighted files online has been hindered because the record companies have not themselves fully complied with the court order.

title: Nostalgia Could Prove to Be Hofstra Seniors' Big Enemy
description: Norman Richardson's most vivid memory of the season is not the indoor parade that broke out in Hofstra Arena after he and his teammates beat Delaware on Saturday for an automatic berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: American Women Struggle
description: The women's national team is experiencing conflicts with clubs for the first time, and its results reflect that. With a number of important players committed to their teams in the new Women's United Soccer Association, which begins play next month, the national team has primarily used young players to produce a 1-4-1 record in its past six games.

title: The Big City; Workers Vote With Wallets On Job Safety
description: WHEN Congress rescinded new ergonomics regulations last week, Democrats and union leaders said it was a victory for business at the expense of labor. Actually, it was more like a victory for workers' wallets at the possible expense of their bodies.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN DECLINES. The political and economic turmoil in Japan caused the the yen to drop to a 20-month low against the dollar. In New York, the dollar settled at 120.38 yen, up from 119.70 on Friday.

title: SCRIPPS SAYS FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS WILL DISAPPOINT
description: The E. W. Scripps Company, owner of Home & Garden TV and The Rocky Mountain News, said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would be less than forecast because of reduced advertising sales. The company said it expected to earn 30 cents to 35 cents a share. It had forecast per-share earnings of 35 cents to 45 cents, and earned 45 cents a share a year earlier. It was expected to earn 39 cents a share by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Opposition Complains of Abuses in Ugandan Presidential Voting
description: Voting today in Uganda was far more peaceful than the last few weeks of campaigning but, at least here, problems lingered: Felix Hakiza, holding his 4-year-old son by the hand, showed up this afternoon to vote for president only to find that someone else had done it for him.

title: Scientists Test Hallucinogens For Mental Ills
description: Hallucinogenic drugs like LSD and peyote -- derided as toys of the hippie generation -- are increasingly drawing the interest of neurologists and psychiatrists who want to test the idea that they may be valuable tools in treating a range of mental disorders.

title: SINGTEL BID FOR OPTUS
description: Singapore Telecommunications has offered $8.8 billion, half in cash and half in stock, for Optus, the Australian unit of Cable and Wireless, according to an executive who is involved in the transaction. If accepted, the offer, which is the equivalent of $2.30 a share, would be the biggest takeover in Australian history. Other bidders have expressed serious interest in Optus, but an offer from Vodafone Pacific, has been held up by an antitrust review; the offer by Singapore Telecommunication poses no antitrust issues, regulators said. Becky Gaylord

title: Finland Reels Over Skiers' Drug Scandal
description: The systemic doping of Finland's most elite athletes might not have been discovered but for a misplaced medical bag packed with syringes, needles and drugs used to manipulate blood-cell counts.

title: Court Files Show Skakel as Troubled Youth in 70's
description: In an affidavit last year seeking an arrest warrant for Michael C. Skakel in the 1975 killing of Martha Moxley, the state's lead investigator said he had obtained evidence that Mr. Skakel once tried to jump off the Triborough Bridge after saying ''that he had done something very bad, and that he needed to get out of the country, and that he had to kill himself.''

title: The New Treatment Cheney Did Not Get
description: Doctors caring for political leaders and celebrities often become embroiled in medical controversies over how they did -- or did not -- treat their patients. Some debates reflect the many ways to treat certain ailments successfully. Still other disagreements involve outside doctors who become public second-guessers for reasons like ego, rivalry, promoting a specialty, or marketing a product or technique they helped develop.

title: Old and New Classics Meet With Pollini in Charge
description: Maurizio Pollini's Perspectives series of concerts, a Carnegie Hall initiative, is nearing its end: last Tuesday came the first of three programs being given off-campus at the 92nd Street Y, and when these are over, only Mr. Pollini's final recital will be left. It is hard, though, to be regretful. The series will live on as a continuing stimulus to thoughtful mixed programming, and these last concerts are proving just too full of strong, lively music-making to be scenes of melancholy.

title: Wandering Trendless, But Offering A Moral Riff
description: Between the last Pantera studio album and the new one, ''Reinventing the Steel,'' heavy metal completely reconstituted itself. The anxious rap-metal of Korn and Limp Bizkit exploded and became mainstream. The comfortable-with-itself Pantera, whose slow, fat riffs can be traced back to Led Zeppelin and further still to the blues of Muddy Waters and Jimmy Reed, risks becoming an early-90's anachronism.

Its music flipped that image, producing the kind of rush that comes when you turn upside down and all the blood drains from those nether regions into your head.

title: SPRINT AND SUN JOIN TO OFFER INTERNET SERVICES

Under the deal, Sun will become a preferred vendor of technology like server computers to Sprint. Sun's Internet technology and Sprint's Internet network will make a strong combination, Keith Paglusch, president of Sprint's E-Solutions group, said in a news release scheduled for distribution today. It is called truffled egg toast, and innocently enough, it begins with a simple slice of bread. But there could be nothing more voluptuous about its filling: creamy melted fontina over barely cooked eggs, and a hit of truffle oil, all ooing together when you dig in.

The plan is good for 20 destinations and over 180 hotels in Florida and 16 destinations and more than 90 hotels in Colorado, Utah and the Lake Tahoe area. Participants must also buy Delta Vacations Travel Protection Plan, and other restrictions apply. Call (800) 755-4224. Rates quoted will include the kids free air fare.

Alltel, a telecommunications and information services company based in Little Rock, Ark., has a majority equity stake in the joint venture, called Alltel Core Banking Solutions. The agreement is consistent with I.B.M.'s strategy to divest itself of industry-specific software businesses, a spokesman said. I.B.M. will be a minority shareholder and will handle sales and marketing for the venture, which will be based in London and will initially focus its Internet banking business on Germany and France. ''There are currently fewer Internet banking customers in Western Europe than in the U.S., but the market is expected to grow significantly by 2005,'' said Mike O'Malley, product manager for Internet banking for the new venture. In Sunday's deciding game, the Catamounts trailed by 1-0 going into the third period but were able to score two power-play goals. The Golden Knights scored on their next power play to force overtime. PATRICK SHARP scored the game winner at 9 minutes 4 seconds for his 12th goal of the season. It's got to be the biggest goal of my career, Sharp said. It means we get to keep playing toward our ultimate goal.

Newman of Binghamton, N.Y. and Patricia A. Saunders of New York. She is also survived by grandchildren Kate Newman, Thomas Newman, Sarah Murphy, Mary Newman, John Newman and James Newman and by Paul Saunders, M.D. and Michael Saunders. She was devoted to her great-grandchildren Jessie and Thomas Harrelson, Christopher, Erin and Jane Murphy and Emily Joy, and to her nieces Evelyn Buckley, Noreen Parrish, Loretta Chebba, Dolores Byrnes and Edna D'Amico and their children. Her friends, many of whom called her ''Newmie'', enjoyed her easy smile, her sense of humor, her interest in them and in her city, her cooking and her warm hospitality. description: Dexia, one of Belgium's largest banks, agreed to pay 3.3 billion euros ($3 billion) for the closely held Artesia Banking to bolster insurance sales and expand its banking network 50 percent. Dexia will offer 17.9 million new shares to buy 99.5 percent of Artesia from Arcofin, a Belgian financial holding company.

title: The Struggles Continue for Safin, Last Year's Wonder
description: Marat Safin's recurring on-court meltdowns this season have sabotaged the steps he made toward stardom last year. But in his coach-of-the-month search for a mental tweaking, he recently turned to the sedate and savvy Swede Mats Wilander.

title: Bear Takes Breather In a Market Rebound
description: The Nasdaq composite index climbed nearly 5 percent, back above the 2,000 level, as many of the stocks that led the market down on Monday helped lift it up a little yesterday. The other main stock gauges also retraced some of the ground they lost on Monday.

description: By REBECCA S. WEINER

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JACOB DDS.
description: MILLER-Jacob DDS. Born Bronx, NY, 1928. Graduated University of Pennsylvania School of Dentistry 1950. Served as Captain, U.S. Air Force 1952-1954. After 25 years in dentistry Dr. Miller took great pride in guiding his sons as Treasurer/Comptroller of Drybranch Inc. for over 20 years. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Arthur, Howard and Susan, father-in-law of Sheryl, Joan and Dan. Loving grandfather of Lauren, Danny, Rachel, Benjamin, Ethan and Carly. Dear brother of Edith Geisinger. Service Wednesday, March 14, 1:45PM at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Exp, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: People
description: * David Murphy, president at the Irvine, Calif., office of Young & Rubicam Advertising, part of the Young & Rubicam unit of the WPP Group, was promoted to a new post, chief executive at the Y.& R. operations in Irvine, overseeing Burson-Marsteller, Impiric, Landor Associates and Media Edge as well as Y.& R. Advertising. He will also continue as managing partner, overseeing the account of the Lincoln Mercury division of the Ford Motor Co.

title: As the Disease Marches On, Britain Dooms More Animals
description: LONDON, March 14  The confirmation of 27 new cases of foot-and- mouth disease today brought the total in Britain to 232 and prompted Prime Minister Tony Blair to order an intensified slaughter of animals in areas directly affected. He also said the government should consider easing restrictions caused by the disease in economically hard hit regions that are free of the virus.

description: KERN-Mary Griffin on March 13, 2001 of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late Joseph F. Kern. Loving mother of Joseph F. Jr., Peter H., Thomas G., Mary E. and Christopher J. Cherished grandmother of Joseph F. III, Margaret, Peter Jr., Ryder, Reed, Cameron, Griffin, Courtney, Caroline, Jack and Hope. Dear sister of Dominic B. Griffin, Jr. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City 7-9 PM Wednesday and 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 11 AM Friday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the Winthrop Diabetes Education Center, 259 First Street, Mineola, NY 11501 appreciated.

title: Employees Accuse Zale Jewelry Chain Of Sex Harassment
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission filed a federal lawsuit yesterday charging the Zale Corporation, the nationwide jewelry chain, with repeated sexual harassment of female employees at its store in a Long Island mall.

title: Reconnecting With the Spirit Of a Departed Poet; An Anthology and Conferences Celebrate James Merrill's Work
description: James Merrill did not have to teach, write book reviews or, like Wallace Stevens, work for an insurance company to support his poetry. Because of his wealthy, patrician background -- his father was Charles Merrill, a founder of the stock brokerage firm now known as Merrill Lynch -- he was free to devote himself to his calling. For his poetry, he won all the major prizes, including the Pulitzer, the Bollingen and two National Book Awards.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HENNESSY, RAYMOND J.
description: HENNESSY-Raymond J. The New York Stock Exchange community mourns the loss of our valued friend and respected colleague, who served as our Vice President, Member Firm Regulatory Development and Services. For two decades, Ray distinguished himself throughout the securities industry with his commitment to excellence and his tireless work to strengthen the integrity of the equities markets. His warmth, professionalism and wise counsel will be greatly missed. The thoughts and prayers of the entire Exchange community are with the Hennessy family.

title: THE CHEF
description: WHEN I first started cooking, in college, I thought following a recipe was like following a math problem. These days it's almost the opposite -- I know you can always get more than one result. My hope with this series is that you take my recipes and make them your own.

title: A Bill to Wall Off Medicare Revenue Fails
description: In a preview of what is likely to be a recurring budget battle this year, the Senate today blocked an attempt by Democrats to restrict Congress's use of surplus Medicare revenues for a tax cut or general government spending.

title: Delta Air Lines Now Expects to Post Loss for the Current Quarter
description: Delta Air Lines said today that it expected a loss of as much as $110 million this quarter instead of the profit that analysts had forecast because business travel fell as the economy slowed and flights were eliminated.

title: De La Hoya Trusts New Trainer
description: Oscar De La Hoya has boxed professionally for nearly nine years and has won five titles in four weight classes. But he now believes he never trained correctly.

description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Deserted by His G.O.P., Nassau Executive Won't Run Again
description: Tarnished by the fiscal crisis afflicting Nassau County, lagging in opinion polls and abandoned by his fellow Republicans, Thomas S. Gulotta, who has been the Nassau County executive since 1987, announced today that he would not seek re-election in the fall.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO DROPS. The euro fell as accelerating French and German inflation raised concern the European Central Bank will not cut interest rates soon. In New York, the euro settled at 91.42 cents, down from 92.80 cents.

title: Accounts
description: * Clear Channel Internet Group, Los Angeles, part of Clear Channel Communications, to AG Worldwide, New York, and its interactive division, Surge Interactive, to handle the first consolidated assignment to develop creative, brand, content and marketing strategies for Web sites like SFX.com and for Web sites of Clear Channel radio stations like WHTZ-FM, New York (Z-100), and KIIS-FM, Los Angeles. Billings have not been determined. AG is part of the Interpublic Group of Companies

title: INDONESIAN GAS SHUTDOWN
description: The Indonesian subsidiary of Exxon Mobil suspended its operations and evacuated its staff from its operations in the province of Aceh, after the military announced an offensive against separatist rebels. The shutdown involves three natural gas pumping fields, said Julia Tumengkol, a spokeswoman for the company in Aceh. ''It is not a safe environment for us to work,'' she said. Islamic insurgents want a separate state in Aceh, an oil-rich province on the northern tip of Sumatra. The shutdown is the latest blow to Indonesia's faltering economy; the rupiah has fallen to a 30-month low against the dollar. Seth Mydans

title: Transportation Chief Supports Fees to Ease Airport Crowding
description: Secretary of Transportation Norman Y. Mineta said today that he favored charging airlines more for flights at the most congested hours as a way to spread out the traffic and cut delays, although that might make fewer seats available at the times most customers want to fly.

title: A Weak Link, But You Still Want to Cheer
description: One of the few rah-rah moments in human history that remains untarnished by any direct connection to a war or some other catastrophe was the Apollo 11 moon landing in July 1969. As Neil Armstrong took his famous small step onto the moon's surface, the world held its breath and shared a rare sense that the human race, for all its flaws, was moving ahead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOTTFRIED, VERA G.
description: GOTTFRIED-Vera G. Formerly of Hallandale, FL, and Buffalo, NY, died peacefully on March 13, 2001, four days after her ninetyfourth birthday. Loving & devoted mother of Judith Murray Agisim, and son-in-law Leslie, cherished grandmother of Taylor, pre-deceased by her husband Charles Gottfried. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at Elmlawn Mausoleum, Buffalo, NY, at 1 PM on Thursday March 15, 2001. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate donations to The National Emphysema Foundation, 15 Stevens Street, Norwalk, CT 06856.

title: Credit Suisse Says Profit Was Up 11% Last Year
description: Though its own stock has been buffeted by recent market turbulence, the Credit Suisse Group said its asset management business is weathering the storm. The group reported that profits in 2000 were strong and that it was not worried about this year despite what it said would probably be ''a more challenging environment.''

title: McCall Criticizes Pataki's Plan on Toxic Cleanup as Risky
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall today attacked Gov. George E. Pataki's plans to weaken standards for toxic cleanup and to shift the burden for that work away from the industries that create the pollution.

title: Funny Name, Versatile Vegetable
description: JERUSALEM artichokes are nothing like the real thing. Unlike the big green globes starting to come into markets from California right now, they grow underground and look it, with a nubbly skin and buff color. They have no heart, just sweet flesh. They need no trimming and tweaking; you can even eat them raw. And they have a finite season, one that is just winding down.

title: CABLE AND WIRELESS CUTS JOBS
description: Cable and Wireless said it would cut 4,000 jobs in the next 12 months to help reduce costs as margins erode in its Internet business because of falling prices in the United States and Japan. In the United States ''certain market prices for Internet connectivity have reduced by up to 50 percent per annum,'' and in Japan international voice prices have declined 40 percent the last 10 months, Cable and Wireless said. The company said it would take a charge of 950 million ($1.3 billion) this year for improving its network and focusing its operations on business customers.

description: The Up Side of Down

title: CANON'S SHARES SURGE
description: Shares of Canon advanced nearly 1 percent after analysts got positive guidance from the company. The president, Fujio Mitarai, told analysts that Canon's group sales increased 10 percent in the first two months of 2001, compared with the same period in 2000. Last month the company reported a 90 percent increase in group net profit for 2000; it now expects profit to rise by 32 percent and sales by 12 percent in 2001. Miki Tanikawa

title: Our Towns; No Comfort In Words For Victim Of Abuse
description: FOR Paul Doyle, there was something hollow in the caring words that church officials offered last week in settling sex abuse claims they had long fought.

description: As Zhang Youlian wept in the dirt courtyard surrounded by towering peaks, her tears spoke to her year of calamities.

title: HYUNDAI TO SELL SHARES
description: Hyundai Electronics Industries said it hoped to raise $1 billion by selling new shares to foreign investors. Hyundai Electronics Industries' president, Park Chong Sup, said it must pay $1.5 billion in debts due this year. Battered by the glut in semiconductors and the decline in technology stocks in the United States, Japan and elsewhere, Hyundai Electronics stock fell 12 percent yesterday, the worst among big South Korean companies. Don Kirk

title: How Bill in Senate Would Add Hurdles To Erasing of Debt
description: For many Americans among the more than one million debtors whose financial troubles are expected to drive them into bankruptcy next year, the route to a fresh financial start would be far more complicated under a bill that is now before the Senate and appears likely to become law.

title: MAIL-WELL SAYS QUARTERLY PROFIT WILL MISS FORECAST
description: Mail-Well said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would miss estimates because the slowing economy had reduced orders for printing. Mail-Well, a commercial printing company that produces brochures and annual reports, said earnings would be 7 cents to 9 cents a share. The company said it had been expected to earn 25 cents. Mail-Well, based in Englewood, Colo., said it had reduced its work force by 5 percent this year as part of a previously announced plan to cut costs. Officials plan to close 11 plants and offices and are reviewing other operations. The company's stock fell $1.41, or 22 percent, to $5.04.

description: THE Trial of the Century goes to the jury today.

title: Baghdad Journal; Uncle Sam's Embassy Sitter (and Lightning Rod)
description: As diplomatic assignments go, Krzyzstof Bernacki's new job is about as improbable as they come. The 44-year-old Polish envoy had just arrived last month when he paid a courtesy call on the protocol chief of Iraq's Foreign Ministry, only to find himself in a diplomatic cul-de-sac over the American bombing of Iraqi radar communications sites near Baghdad a few days before.

title: Phil Berger, 58, Sportswriter and Author
description: Phil Berger, a sportswriter, author and screenwriter, died on Monday at his home in Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 58.

title: Make Russia a Better Neighbor
description: American economic and security interests in the former Soviet Union are fundamentally linked. An economically stable Russia, integrated into the Western economy, would be far less likely to want to damage Western interests or dominate its neighbors, like Georgia, Ukraine and Moldova. Stable and prosperous neighbors would in turn support Russia's new generation of political and business leaders who seek success in the global market through domestic economic reform.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BATTAGLIA, AUGUST J.
description: BATTAGLIA - August J. RIP March 14, 1973. Loving and beloved husband, father, grandfather-remembered always with love.

title: Police Say Student Brought Bomb to School
description: A New Canaan High School sophomore who brought a homemade firebomb to school on Monday was arrested and charged with reckless endangerment and with five counts each of manufacturing a bomb and possessing an explosive device, police and school officials said today.

title: London's New Wave Caters to Individual
description: LONDON  Alexander McQueen and John Galliano may have put London on the style map and marked it as a creative capital of fashion, but now there's a new generation of designers rising up in the city and heading for the bright lights. These designers, not all of them young, are independent and strikingly individualist, and they are making a distinct mark on an industry ruled by megabrands with their offbeat approach.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about Gastronomica, a new food journal, misstated its sponsorship. It is supported by the International Association of Culinary Professionals and Copia: the American Center for Wine, Food and the Arts -- not by the American Institute of Wine and Food.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARKMAN, JEFFREY
description: STARKMAN-Jeffrey. Jeff, you were more than a trusted colleague, and more than a loyal friend. Your achievements at the law firm of Weitz & Luxenberg were only overshadowed by the deep relationships you cultivated and the multitude of friends you accumulated-a measure of a man for all to emulate. How can I enumerate all that you've done? You developed product identification for New York asbestos cases, thereby helping thousands of victims to attain just compensation for their injuries. You helped prepare the most greviously ill asbestos victims for their day in court, with the utmost compassion and respect. You were responsible for ongoing communications with thousands of asbestos victims, making sure they were effectively advised of their rights under law. You were the curator of the important ''Days of Shame'' exhibit, which chronicled the World War IIera disbarment of German-Jewish attorneys and jurists, which led to their eventual reinstatement to the New York State Bar. You originated and administered the annual Weitz & luxenberg outing, enabling the diverse members of our growing firm to get to know each other better. You even had the time to provide T-shirts and other apparel for numerous Luxenberg and Arbisfeld family retreats, and not to mention logistical support for many synagogue use events and our firm's baseball team. Jeff, you always had time for me, the firm, my family, our communityfor assignments that spanned the weighty to the seemingly trivial. Everything you undertook was completed with a smile. Over the past year, you showed me what true courage was all about, and how to make the most out of life. I will forever treasure our friendship and miss you with all my heart. Randi, Elizabeth and Jacqueline join me in wishing your dear Annie, and your bereaved mother and family, comfort and strength through the difficult days ahead. We love you, buddy! Arthur M. Luxenberg

title: BRAZIL'S INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT IS UP
description: Brazil's industrial output grew at its fastest pace in 11 months in January as growing consumer demand prompted companies like Volkswagen and Toyota Motor to increase production. Output grew 11.2 percent from the period a year ago, up from a revised level of 7.1 percent growth in December, the government said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ADELE
description: FELDMAN-Adele. The Directors, Campers and Alumni of Camp Robindel for Girls in New Hampshire are deeply sadden by the passing of Adele Feldman. As one of the Founders, she and her late husband, Paddy along, with Eli and Fanny Robinson touched and enriched the lives of many young women during her tenure 1951-1977. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her daughter Bette Zorn, grandsons Michael and Matthew and the entire family. Camp Robindel for Girls Ann and Nat Greenfield Owners and Directors

title: Brazil Postpones Its Beef Dreams
description: This was supposed to be a stellar year for Brazil's cattle industry. Calf birth rates are up. Mortality is falling. Productivity is at an all-time high. With about 165 million head, Brazil has the largest commercial herd of cattle in the world. And in the last decade, the country has gone from being a net importer to the world's third-largest exporter of beef, behind only the United States and Australia.

description: Othella Harrington has spent most of his time in New York sitting on the bench, wondering if the Knicks acquired him for his cheerleading or scout-team skills. But in one six-minute stretch last night, the all-but-forgotten forward showed that he could make strong game-time contributions.

description: A Premium for Peak Flights

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBER, LUCIA (NEE SCHWADRON)
description: LEBER-Lucia (nee Schwadron). Age 83, of Whitestone, New York, died peacefully March 10, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Arthur, mother of Dr. Mark, mother-in-law of Vivian and grandmother of Jessica, Stephanie and Rebecca. She was a survivor of the horrors of World War II. She was a staunch supporter of the Technion and Jewish education and values. She will be missed and loved forever. Burial at Mount Hebron Cemetery. Shiva will be at son's home in Roslyn, Long Island through March 18. Donations may be given to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NY, NY 10032.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about efforts to gain clemency for Lionel Tate, a Florida 14-year-old sentenced to life imprisonment for killing a 6-year-old girl, misidentified the court to which the conviction will be appealed. It is the Fourth District Court of Appeals, a state court in West Palm Beach -- not the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which is in Richmond, Va.

title: Cooks, Start Your Woks
description: STIR-FRIES are fast, but they are not necessarily simple. Because the full flavors of slow cooking do not have time to develop in stir-fries, it is tempting to add too many ingredients to the wok, muddying the flavors you produce. Worse, most home stoves cannot maintain the extreme heat you need to stir-fry everything at once.

title: Images of Unspeakable Horror Stir Voices to Debate
description: The harrowing photographs taken during the liberation of Nazi death camps in early 1945 played a central role in convincing the world of the existence of a Nazi killing machine. Over time, however, many of these same images of skeletal survivors and mounds of bodies came to assume an iconographic quality, speaking generically for the Holocaust but with little emphasis on how, when, where and by whom they were taken.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 24 about diplomatic maneuvering by Israelis and Palestinians on the eve of a trip to the Middle East by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell quoted incompletely from a remark about Jerusalem by Ariel Sharon, Israel's prime minister-elect at the time. In a speech on Feb. 22 to American Jews, Mr. Sharon prefaced the remark -- ''Jerusalem is holy to Jews, Christians and Muslims, but it was promised to the Jews'' -- by saying that Pope John Paul II said that to him when the two men met in 1999. The Vatican said the two had held a private conversation of which it has no record.

title: Two Comptroller Candidates Try to Make No. 3 Job Visible
description: On an almost daily basis, the two Democratic candidates for New York City comptroller wander from one political function to another, hoping to entice any who will listen to pay attention to the race for the city's No. 3 job.

title: Terrorism Trial May Keep to Narrower Focus
description: Federal prosecutors opened their case today against an Algerian man accused of transporting bomb-making equipment into the United States from Canada in the trunk of a rented car 15 months ago.

title: New Foot-and-Mouth Cases Prompt Britain to Intensify Slaughter
description: LONDON, March 14  The confirmation of 25 new cases of foot-and-mouth disease brought the total in Britain to 230 and prompted Prime Minister Tony Blair today to order intensified slaughter of animals in directly affected areas and consideration of easing of restrictions in economically hard-hit regions that are still free of the virus.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INGERSOLL-RAND CO., Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said it had acquired Taylor Industries, Des Moines, to expand its refrigerated equipment business. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Syria, Despite Criticism, Seems Likely to Win Security Council Seat
description: Syria appears highly likely to be elected to a rotating seat on the Security Council this year, diplomats said this week. The Syrians would replace Bangladesh in a seat that is alternated among nations in the General Assembly's Asian regional bloc, which includes the Middle East.

title: Bush, in Reversal, Won't Seek Cut In Emissions of Carbon Dioxide
description: Under strong pressure from conservative Republicans and industry groups, President Bush reversed a campaign pledge today and said his administration would not seek to regulate power plants' emissions of carbon dioxide, a gas that many scientists say is a key contributor to global warming.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Trenton fraud trial of Robert E. Brennan, a former penny-stock financier, misstated the given name of an assistant United States attorney on the case. He is Paul Weissman, not Phillip.

title: Yugoslavia's Troops Return to Zone Bordering Kosovo
description: TRNAVA, Serbia, March 14  NATO today allowed the Yugoslav Army and special police back into a zone bordering Kosovo that has become a haven for Albanian gunmen. The gunmen's attacks are spreading to Macedonia and alarming the West.

title: The Boss: Calm in Crisis Is in My Blood
description: In Chinese the word crisis is translated as "dangerous opportunity." When things get bad, I become supercreative and superdetermined. The road has been bumpy the last couple of months, but the worse the situation is, the calmer and cooler I get. I get that from my mother.

description: Morton Downey Jr., whose loudmouthed manner and sneering, smoke-in-your-face approach to guests on his television show gave him a wildly popular, albeit short, career as a national talk show host in the 1980's, died on Monday in Los Angeles. He was 67 and lived in Los Angeles.

title: A Chicken, Not a Snake, Tempts in New Eden
description: TO walk into the Garden of Eden near Union Square is to enter an unspoiled vision of produce and prepared foods. Each red pepper is beautiful enough to have been polished before being piled just so. Each chicken, turning slowly on the rotisserie, is browned to a crisp. Aromas entice.

title: Housing Group Seeks Lower-Cost Rentals
description: A coalition of mayors, labor unions, bankers and real estate brokers asked the Bush administration today to change Federal Housing Administration rules to encourage construction of apartment buildings for the millions of families who pay over half of their income in rent.

title: Metro Business Briefing; NEW JERSEY VACANCIES RISING
description: The retail vacancy rate for northern New Jersey's major shopping corridors inched up in 2000 from the year before, according to a survey by R. J. Brunelli & Company in Old Bridge, N.J. The company predicted a sharper increase in vacancies in the coming year as a result of recent bankruptcies. The company reported the rate at 2.7 percent last year, up from 2.6 percent in 1999, along Routes 4, 10, 17, 22, 23 and 46. Richard J. Brunelli, the company's president, said that the rate is still about half the national average, and he noted that the total amount of retail space in the area increased by about 400,000 square feet, while vacancies rose by only 34,000 square feet. He warned, however, that bankruptcies by large retailers including Bradlees and Grand Union could cause a spike in 2001. Steve Strunsky

title: Edward T. Tait; Federal Official, 80
description: Edward T. Tait, an expert on antitrust and corporate law who was executive director of the Securities and Exchange Commission and a member of the Federal Trade Commission during the Eisenhower administration, died on March 3 in Chestertown, Md., where he lived. He was 80.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO (SACKOWITZ), BARBARA
description: SHAPIRO (Sackowitz)-Barbara. Her valiant heart failed on March 12. Wife, mother of 4, mother-inlaw, beloved ''Nanny'' to 7 grandchildren, proud great grandmother, respected dealer in antiquities for over 4 decades, W.W. II vet, redoubtable bridge player, predeceased by Ben. Died with the dignity and grace that marked her 80 years of life after a short illness. She had the opportunity to bid a loving farewell to her family. She remains in the hearts of her family and her friends for her infectious laugh, her cheery optimistic spirit & her warm, all-embracing heart. A woman of strong principles, she fought bigotry and racial discrimination when it was dangerous to do so. Interment private.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PAPA JOHN'S OPENS IN HARLEM
description: New York City's first Papa John's pizza franchise officially opened in Harlem this week in a converted garage at Lenox Avenue and 145th Street, a commercial strip that has yet to attract the high-profile retailers that are flocking to 125th Street. Financing for the new $400,000 store was provided by the Neighborhood Franchise Project, a partnership between Deutsche Bank and a nonprofit agency, the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, that seeks to bring national companies into low-income neighborhoods. The new pizza parlor employs 25 people, a large number for a store that is only 1,500 square feet, said Karen A. Phillips, the chief executive of the Abyssinian Development Corporation, which helped get the project off the ground. Another Papa John's will open in June at 111th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard. Papa John's International, based in Louisville, Ky., has about 2,500 outlets. Terry Pristin

title: Retail Sales Declined 0.2% In February
description: Retail sales fell 0.2 percent in February after surging a month earlier, government figures showed today.

title: Dow Closes Below 10,000 on Fears of Global Slowdown
description: The stock market fell sharply today, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping below 10,000 for the first time in five months, as investors grew increasingly concerned about the global reach of the economic slowdown.

title: Yeshiva U. President to Quit After More Than 25 Years
description: Norman Lamm, the president of Yeshiva University in Manhattan for the last 25 years and one of the longest-serving university presidents in the United States, announced yesterday that he would step down in August 2002.

title: A Stressed-Out Cop With a Comic Edge
description: When the typical television hero takes a self-destructive course, you know it's temporary: on ''N.Y.P.D. Blue'' Andy Sipowicz will stop drinking, and on ''E.R.'' John Carter will be hauled off to drug rehab. But that's just drama. Mike McNeil, the chain-smoking, pill-popping, philandering hero played by Denis Leary on ''The Job,'' is the comic and possibly more realistic version of a stressed-out New York City detective.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUDLUM, ROBERT
description: LUDLUM-Robert. The partners and staff of Marcum & Kliegman LLP mourn the death of our dear friend and client, Robert Ludlum. He will be missed by all of us. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

title: Cards' Ankiel Gets Back Into Strike Zone
description: While the Yankees' Chuck Knoblauch has struggled to overcome his throwing problems this spring, a player with a similar problem, the St. Louis Cardinals' Rick Ankiel, made a strong exhibition-season debut today.

description: The Philadelphia Inquirer, which buttoned down its expenses with an employee buyout last fall, is now pulling back on its long-term strategy to create local news sections that would serve as a ''paper within a paper'' in the Pennsylvania suburbs.

title: CLUB MED PROFIT WARNING
description: The shares of Club Mditerrane fell 19 percent after it cut its profit forecast. The chairman, Philippe Bourguignon, dropped a promise to deliver sales and profit growth of 10 percent or more this year. It was the second time in six months that Club Med indicated that growth was falling short of expectations. Mr. Bourguignon blamed events including Arab-Israeli violence, typhoons in Japan and new sales taxes in Australia for discouraging bookings, but analysts cited tumbling stocks and consumer confidence in the United States and Japan.

title: UCONN PLAYER GETS EQUIVALENT OF PROBATION
description: Marcus Cox, the University of Connecticut player who was arrested for marijuana possession on Feb. 22, was granted accelerated rehabilitation, the equivalent of a one-year probation, by the Tolland County Superior Court in Vernon, Conn., yesterday on a charge of having interfered with a police officer.

title: Enis Signs With Browns
description: Curtis Enis is getting a chance to restart his football career not far from where it began. Enis, a running back who failed to live up to expectations during three seasons with the Chicago Bears, yesterday signed a one-year contract with the Cleveland Browns.

title: NOVELL NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: The software concern Novell Inc. said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Eric Schmidt, left, will give up the latter position. He will be replaced as chief executive by his counterpart at Cambridge Technology Partners, Jack Messman. Mr. Messman is currently a Novell board member. Mr. Schmidt said that in addition to remaining as Novell chairman he would become the chief strategist. Both companies, which announced on Monday that they would merge in a $266 million deal, have struggled in the last year in the face of declining sales. But Mr. Schmidt said he believed that the resulting merged company would give Novell the opportunity to grow in new markets. ''The new story is around solutions and mobility and the Internet,'' he said. ''Our intent is to go more toward a solutions model.'' John Markoff

description: It was trumpeted on the cover of Business Week as a beacon for corporate America and hailed by none other than the conservative columnist George F. title: CISCO CHIEF SAYS OUTLOOK IS GRIM
description: The head of Cisco Systems said the company's sales have continued to slow, registering no increase in February. ''We're seeing no turnaround in terms of orders,'' John Chambers, the chief executive of Cisco, a networking company, said at an investment conference sponsored by Merrill Lynch. Describing the near-term outlook as grim, Mr. Chambers said, ''There's no question -- we got knocked on our tails.'' One of many new-economy bellwethers hurt by the slowdown in technology spending, Cisco said last week that it intended to eliminate as many as 5,000 jobs, or 11 percent of its full-time work force. Cisco shares rose $2.56, or almost 14 percent, to close at $21.38 yesterday, but Paul Johnson, an analyst with Robertson Stephens, said the gain was market related and had nothing to do with Mr. Chambers's comments. Andrew Zipern

title: G.E. SAYS PROFITS WILL INCREASE AT LEAST 10% THIS YEAR
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its profit would rise in 2001 by at least 10 percent and that the savings from its planned purchase of Honeywell International would be greater than previously estimated. The company said its earnings were ensured by an order backlog of more than $44 billion in turbines, aircraft engines and other expensive equipment that is financed and serviced over years. Shares of General Electric rose $2.73, to $42.33 a share. The company said it expected to meet analysts' first-quarter per-share profit estimates of 30 cents, the average forecast of analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call.

title: Exploring Remedies in Rural China
description: Dr. Fang Jing, wearing an apron depicting the female body over her own, greeted the women who had squeezed into the village's meeting room. And as babies played on the floor, Dr. Fang cheerfully discussed conception, pelvic infections and how to prevent sexually transmitted diseases and AIDS.

title: LOW-INCOME WEB SURFERS PROLIFERATE
description: People with low incomes using the World Wide Web at home accounted for the fastest-growing online group over the last year, Nielsen/NetRatings said in its Internet ratings report for February. The number of home Web users with annual incomes of less than $25,000 a year rose 46 percent to 6.3 million in February 2001, compared with 4.3 million a year earlier. Those earning $50,000 to $74,999, the largest segment of the online population in both years, had the second-highest rate of increase during the year, up 42 percent to 30.4 million in February 2001. The $25,000-to-$49,999 group had the third-highest rate of increase, rising 40 percent to 26.4 million Web users. Allison Fass

Monroe with Joe DiMaggio or Arthur Miller -- both of whom Mr. Shaw counted as friends; Monroe standing over a subway grate with her white skirts billowing, a shot that would become one of the most reproduced photos of the century, an American pop icon.

title: CKE WILL SELL ITS TACO BUENO UNIT FOR $72.5 MILLION
description: CKE Restaurants Inc., which owns the Hardee's and Carl's Jr. hamburger chains, agreed to sell its Taco Bueno subsidiary to the closely held Jacobson Partners for $72.5 million. Taco Bueno has 125 quick-service restaurants in Texas and Oklahoma. The transaction is expected to close by the end of May, CKE said. Jacobson is a New York-based investment company. The sale will help CKE as it focuses on reviving sales and reducing debt at Hardee's, CKE said.

His Devils had just defeated the Phoenix Coyotes to win their ninth consecutive game, a franchise record, solidify their hold on first place in the Atlantic Division and maintain a tie with Ottawa at the top of the Eastern Conference.

description: After half a century of seeing its population dwindle as people abandoned the core of the city and moved to the suburbs, Chicago has finally rebounded, census figures released today show.

title: WATSON SUES BRISTOL-MYERS SQUIBB OVER ANXIETY DRUG
description: Watson Pharmaceuticals Inc. said yesterday that it had filed a lawsuit in federal court contending that the Bristol-Myers Squibb Company had illegally blocked Watson's generic version of the anxiety drug BuSpar. The lawsuit comes a day after a rival, Mylan Laboratories Inc., won a court ruling against Bristol-Myers that could clear the way for Mylan to sell its generic version of BuSpar. Watson, which lost an earlier suit on the matter, is seeking triple damages and injunctive relief, the company said. Judge Ricardo Urbina of United States District Court for the District of Columbia ruled on Tuesday that the Bristol-Myers patent on BuSpar should be removed from the Food and Drug Administration's list of valid drug patents. Bristol-Myers says it believes the patent is valid, a spokeswoman, Nancy Goldfarb, said.

title: As the Disease Marches On, Britain Dooms More Animals
description: The confirmation of 27 new cases of foot-and-mouth disease today brought the total in Britain to 232 and prompted Prime Minister Tony Blair to order an intensified slaughter of animals in areas directly affected. He also said the government should consider easing restrictions caused by the disease in economically hard-hit regions that are free of the virus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMMONS, ELIZABETH RICHARDSON
description: SIMMONS-Elizabeth Richardson. Of Hilton Head Island, SC died Monday March 12 at the Hilton Head Medical Center & Clinics. Born January 31, 1928 in Manhattan, NYC. She is the daughter of J.W.M. Richardson and Elizabeth Smith ''Bunny'' Richardson of Natchez, Mississippi, and Ardsleyon-Hudson N.Y. She graduated from Chapin School NYC and Westover School, Middlebury, CT. The Simmons built their first vacation home in Sea Pines in 1968, and moved from Atlanta to become permanent residents in 1980. Mrs. Simmons is recognized as a needlepoint expert. She has achieved prizes in formal and informal flower arrangement contests at flower shows. A lifelong garden enthusiast, she is at the time of her death serving as President of the Plantation Garden Club. Elizabeth is survived by her husband Grant Simmons; a son Henry Darlington III and Henry's wife Curry, and their two children Meredith Elizabeth and Michael Henry Darlington; a daughter Elizabeth ''Beth'' Darlington; and a daughter Victoria Darlington Yoder, wife of Glenn Yoder III, all living in Charlotte, N.C. with a granddaughter Sarah Yoder and grandson Glenn Yoder IV. Elizabeth is also survived by three step children: Allison Simmons Prouty and Leslie Simmons Lee, both residents of Greenwich, CT and Grant Simmons III of New Albany, OH; and step grandchildren Annabel Prouty, Thomas Lee, and Leslie Sarah Lee. A memorial service will be held at All Saints Episcopal Church, Hilton Head Island, SC. The time of the memorial service will be 2:30 P.M. Friday March 23, 2001. Memorial contributions may be made to Westover School, P.O. Box 847, Middlebury, CT 06762-0847.

description: CSFBdirect, Credit Suisse First Boston's online brokerage operation, plans to dismiss 150 employees, or 10 percent of its work force, and close its New Jersey call center to trim expenses as investors reduce trading on the Internet. CSFBdirect is the latest brokerage company to show how a collapse in technology stocks is rippling through the industry. The call center being closed, where customer service representatives take client orders and help manage their accounts, is in Parsippany, N.J. The company will still have three call centers. The online brokerage firm plans to take a one-time charge of $9 million in the first quarter. The firm expects to save $11 million a year through the job cuts.

description: Many people first encountered the 3.5-inch diskette on the original Apple Macintosh computer. So perhaps the clearest symbol of its decline is the absence of floppy disk drives on Apple's current offerings. But Panasonic and Imation think there is still life in the humble floppy. The key to its resuscitation, they hope, is a new drive that can change any standard diskette into a high-capacity storage disk of sorts.

title: Corrections
description: A transcript in Science Times on Tuesday for an interview with Dr. Thomas Pringle, an expert on mad cow disease, rendered a word incorrectly in his response about what he eats. He said he avoided canned tuna because it could have bovine casein, not ''bovine casings.''

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Presidential Blurb

title: ANOTHER BEEF IMPORT BAN
description: Citing a high possibility that foot-and-mouth disease could spread throughout Europe, South Korea became the fifth country to forbid the import of fresh meat from hoofed animals from all 15 European Union nations. The United States, Australia, Canada and New Zealand have imposed similar bans. The statement said the ban would not apply to processed, sterilized foods and would be lifted as soon as there were no signs of the disease anywhere in the European Union. Don Kirk

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHENENKO, JEAN
description: CHENENKO-Jean. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Loving mother of Sandra Malinak, Norman and Doris Chenenko and Elaine and Samuel Glicksman. Cherished grandmother of Jonathan, Steven, Ricky, Joni, Richard and Charles. Adored great-grandmother of Nathan, Jason & Emily. Devoted sister of Robert and Fannie and the late Philip, Minnie and Harry. Services Friday 11AM at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue.

title: INTEL POSTPONES IRISH EXPANSION
description: The chip-making giant Intel said yesterday that it would lay off 1,400 construction workers and postpone the expansion of its west Dublin chip production site in order to save on costs. The $2 billion expansion, heralded last June as the largest foreign investment in Ireland, will now begin operations in 2003, rather than later this year. Brian Lavery

title: THALES INCREASES SALES
description: Thales, the French military electronics company, said revenue in 2000 benefited from acquisitions, although one-time charges related to those purchases caused a decline in net income for the year. The acquisitions of Racal Electronics of Britain, ADI of Australia and Thales Samsung of South Korea contributed 1 billion euros ($915 million) to revenue, which totaled 8.6 billion euros, up 25 percent from the year earlier. Net income declined 27 percent, to 201 million euros. Suzanne Kapner

title: No Floating, No Stinging: Ali Extends Hand to Frazier
description: When Muhammad Ali heard Joe Frazier's name mentioned yesterday, he feigned deep sleep.

title: 60-Second Clock Proposal Is Put on Hold
description: A few months ago, radically new lacrosse rules seemed about to be put in place for this season. Forget them. They have been delayed a year, maybe more.

title: B Market Rebounds In China
description: Chinese investors, bucking the global sell-off in equities, have resumed avidly bidding up the prices of the country's hard-currency Class B shares, which they have been free to own for just two weeks.

title: GARDEN Q.& A.
description: Trophy Fern

title: Storage Space, Cubed
description: SOME of the most stylish modular storage systems start with simple cubes, which can be grouped to sit on the floor, mounted to a wall or lined up on a shelf.

title: Firm Tries to Save Trade Center Deal
description: Vornado Realty Trust made a last-ditch effort yesterday to complete a $3.25 billion deal to gain control of the World Trade Center in Lower Manhattan.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS CLOSING CALIFORNIA FACTORY
description: Texas Instruments Inc., whose chips run two-thirds of the world's cell phones, said it would close a semiconductor plant in Santa Cruz, Calif., and lay off the 600 workers there. Texas Instruments, which is based in Dallas, said it would offer a small percentage of the employees other positions within the company.

title: Toronto Firm Chosen to Renovate Tiffany Flagship Store
description: Paloma Picasso, Elsa Peretti and Jean Schlumberger are designers one commonly associates with Tiffany & Company. Yabu Pushelberg is not.

title: Holy Cross Gives Kentucky a Scare
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 15  Five minutes. That's what Coach Ralph Willard wanted from his Holy Cross team today. Five minutes. If the Crusaders could avoid a flop-sweat collapse in the opening minutes against heavily favored Kentucky, they might have a chance to win the first round of the East Regional.

title: Economic Scene; Tax cuts are in the air, and both political parties have their heads in the sand.
description: THE new economy is temporarily dead on Wall Street, but Washington is acting as if it did not even know it ever existed. The Republicans are setting the antediluvian tone with a tax-cut proposal and a new budget that almost completely ignore vast changes in American life the last 25 years. But the Democratic response is almost as unenlightened. It is as if we are being led by a bunch of 19th-century lawmakers.

title: Essay; The Sinking Sun?
description: Stock markets are slumping because the world's second-largest economy has admitted that it is near collapse and shows no sign of knowing what to do.

title: Stockpiles Rose At Businesses In January
description: Stockpiles of unsold goods rose more than expected in January as sales stalled, a government report showed today, signaling that manufacturing may be slow to pick up in coming months.

title: Current and Former Xerox Employees File Bias Charges
description: Eighteen former and current sales representatives for the Xerox Corporation are filing charges with the United States Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, contending that they were discriminated against on the basis of race, according to the lawyers representing them. Eleven of those complaints were filed yesterday.

title: Guideline for Online Brokers Expected Soon
description: What constitutes an investment recommendation when it comes from an online brokerage firm? After more than a year of deliberations, securities regulators will try to answer that question.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOBOTKA, RENATO
description: SOBOTKA-Renato. Of Kew Gardens and Southampton, NY. Died on March 14 at the age of 87. The former director of the NYC Housing Authority's Design Department. He was the solid foundation on which our family was built and the moral and ethical compass to which we all turned in times of need. He is survived by his beloved wife, Ann, his children Michael and Barbara, and his grandchildren, Eric, Kathy and Davy. The family will receive visitors on Friday 1-9 P.M. at Michael's house in Jamaica Estates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, ALICE
description: WEBER-Alice. Of Hollywood, FL., formerly of Verona, New Jersey. On March 13, 2001. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Benjamin Weber. Beloved mother of Lawrence (Judith) and Ethel. Cherished grandmother of Daniel (Adi) & Jeffrey (Stacey). Loving great grandmother of Harrison, Perry, Allyn and Benjamin. Service Friday, March 16th, 12N, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOLTZER, STEVEN
description: BOLTZER-Steven. Of NYC, on March 13th, 2001. Loving son of Carol and Joseph C. Boltzer. Beloved brother of Joseph W. and Jeffrey Boltzer. Funeral service Saturday, 10 AM, at St. Mary's Church, Pompton Lakes, NJ. Cremation private. Friends may call Friday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at Richards Funeral Home, 4 Newark-Pompton Turnpike, Riverdale, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite charity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGOWAN, HOWARD B.
description: McGOWAN-Howard B. Life's perhaps the only riddle that we shrink from giving up. Thanks for all the good times. Sincere condolences to Agnes. Kathy Bloom

title: Bush Defends Emissions Stance
description: Defending his reversal of a campaign pledge, President Bush said today that ''an energy crisis'' that threatened the nation's economic health caused him to decide not to try to regulate power plants' emissions of carbon dioxide.

title: An Archive Preserves The Look of Old Ireland
description: Half of all Dubliners may be under 30, but the old Dublin has not been forgotten. The Irish Architectural Archive (a charitable company established in 1976) collects and preserves material relating to Ireland's architecture and makes its treasures available -- like the historic photo of Dublin, right, seen through an old viewer. The reading room is open to all researchers, including filmmakers looking for Irish locations. The archive also produces publications like ''Drawings From the Irish Architectural Archive,'' around $15, plus shipping, which can be ordered online at www.archeire.com/iaa.

description: To the Editor:

description: KERN-Mary Griffin on March 13, 2001 of Garden City. Beloved wife of the late Joseph F. Kern. Loving mother of Joseph F. Jr., Peter H., Thomas G., Mary E. and Christopher J. Cherished grandmother of Joseph F. III, Margaret, Peter Jr., Ryder, Reed, Cameron, Griffin, Courtney, Caroline, Jack and Hope. Dear sister of Dominic B. Griffin, Jr. Visiting at the Fairchild Chapel, Franklin Ave at 12th Street, Garden City 7-9 PM Wednesday and 2-4 and 7-9 PM Thursday. Mass of Christian burial St. Joseph's Church, Garden City 11 AM Friday. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to the Winthrop Diabetes Education Center, 259 First Street, Mineola, NY 11501 appreciated.

title: New Feud For Knicks, Courtesy Of Childs
description: It is certain there will be no video montage celebrating his five seasons with the Knicks. And a standing ovation from the fans is unlikely. Chris Childs might even receive boos when he returns to Madison Square Garden on Thursday night for the first time since being traded to the Toronto Raptors on Feb. 22. Loud, clamorous, deafening boos.

description: MARAN-Murray. We love and miss you and hope you are having a wonderful time with Frieda and Susie and winning show bets at the great Aqueduct in the sky. Larry and Andy

title: Major Decision on Term Limits Is Too Close to Call
description: The City Council's contentious effort to end term limits faces an important test today with a committee vote on whether the measure will be considered by the entire Council. As of late yesterday, the vote appeared too close to predict.

title: New Plants Needed to Avert Power Shortages, a State Group Says
description: The rule-making organization for New York State's electricity market warned yesterday that New York would face a dire energy squeeze over the next few years unless new power plants were approved by the state this year. And although that message was not new -- a group of New York City business leaders made much the same point earlier this year -- the messenger definitely was.

description: For Palm and Handspring, it's the start of the spring offensive. Both are firing off new products in their battle to dominate the hand-held computer market.
