description: Mohegan Sun, a casino and entertainment center in Uncasville, Conn., said yesterday that it had named four finalists in a review for its account, with billings estimated at $20 million.

title: Everything Looks Good With Green
description: Emerald green is the color of the season in home furnishings. ''Green is turning out to be the neutral of this decade,'' said Leatrice Eiseman, the director of the Pantone Color Institute in Seattle. Ms. Eiseman notes that Kelly green is replacing the ubiquitous chartreuse, which was popular in the last decade. The International Contemporary Furniture Fair, to be held in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York from May 19 to 24, will have pieces upholstered in bright greens, from Sweden, Denmark, Norway, the Netherlands and Italy. The F-Seat (above) by Thomas Eriksson for the Swedish company Offecct will be available starting in May at Totem Design, 71 Franklin Street, for $2,750. MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPREN, SYLVIA (LEVENSON)
description: ALPREN-Sylvia (Levenson). Unstoppable and unforgettable. Full of life, courage and generosity. Loving wife of the late Bernie Alpren. Mother of Paula Dragutsky and Margie (Bram) Jelin. Proud grandmother of Nancy (Mitch) Moss, Sandra, Eric and Ben Jelin and great grandmother of newborn Hillary Moss.

title: A Race for Red-Suit Tricks (and for Titles)
description: The American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals begin today in Kansas City, Mo., and eight major titles will be decided. Chief among these is the Vanderbilt Knockout Team Championship, which starts on Sunday. The Spring Nationals overlap with the conclusion of the North American Pairs Championships, for which players have qualified at grass-roots level in three categories. Flight A ends tonight, and Flights B and C will be played on March 24 and 25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, CARL E.
description: HORN-Carl E., 63, of Evanston, IL, March 11. Husband of Carol Linne, stepfather of James and Ryan Powell, twin brother of Louise (Ed) Sierocki, uncle of John (Karen) Szillat, and Christine (John) Messerschmidt, uncle of Michaele and Sarah. Memorial service Saturday, March 24, at 10AM at the Bond Chapel, University of Chicago, 1025 East 58th Street, Chicago, IL. Interment private. Memorial contributions may be made to LSSI, Family Connections, 1850 West Garfield, Chicago, IL 60609.

title: Bush Visit Sets Off Church-State Debate
description: As President Bush stopped here today to meet a youth group that he held up as a model of the church-sponsored programs he wants to help, a crowd outside held a lively debate that mirrored the national dialogue about whether government and religion should be so cozy.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Bulletin Board column of the Education page yesterday about the resignation of Trinity College's president misstated the length of service of an earlier president, Tom Gerety. It was five years, not two.

title: Optical Needle May Extend the Surgeon's Gaze Into Living Tissue
description: THINK of it as a needle that can see. Scientists at M.I.T. have developed a miniature microscope -- a tiny stainless steel tube with a pointed tip that can pierce tissue and organs and then use ultrafast optics to take a detailed look around.

title: MINING COMPANY PARES OUTLOOK
description: Joining a long and growing list of European companies voicing concern about the slowdown in the United States economy, Anglo American, the world's largest mining company, tempered its outlook for this year, even as it reported that profit in 2000 surged 26 percent. Anglo American, which is in the process of a bid to privatize De Beers, the diamond miner and trader, said profit for the year totaled $1.9 billion, compared with $1.5 billion a year earlier. Sales grew 7 percent, to $20.6 billion, compared with $19.2 billion the previous year. Suzanne Kapner

title: Do-It-Yourself Stock Trades Drop as Fast as the Markets
description: Throughout the stock market boom of the last several years, the airwaves were flooded with ads promoting the trading of stocks over the Internet as the fast route to easy riches. They depicted a world where tow-truck drivers owned their own islands, teenagers had helicopters and nobody needed a stockbroker's advice any more.

title: A Great Escape tor Boston College
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 15  For all 40 minutes tonight, Boston College faced the prospect of the biggest upset of the college postseason against a team that had no experience in the N.C.A.A. tournament and even less fear of the Big East champion.

description: President Bush has made an initially favorable impression on the American public, according to several recent nationwide opinion polls. But his tax cut proposals have begun to provoke controversy.

description: In 1973, the artist Forrest Myers bolted 42 aluminum bars to 42 steel braces on a blank wall overlooking Broadway and Houston Street. New Yorkers have been wondering ever since.

description: The good news, Nassau County Republicans were saying today, is that County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta has decided not to run for re-election, clearing the way for them to run their own candidate for his post. The bad news, they lamented, is that the county's mighty Republican machine is now more a memory than a reality.

description: To the Editor:

title: Even Reproductions of Georgian Style Have a Great Following
description: With the booming Irish economy, nicknamed the Celtic Tiger, lovely Georgian houses no longer sell for a song. But now the Irish can buy reproductions of Georgian furniture by Kindel, an American furniture company in Grand Rapids, Mich. Over 15 years, Kindel has reproduced 22 pieces in its Irish Georgian Society collection, but it opened a showroom in Ireland only two years ago.

title: Japan's Affair With Bay Area
description: SAN FRANCISCO  This is what the Japanese are discovering about the San Francisco Bay area: It almost feels like home. Home without the kinks of societal and corporate pressures, frenetic pace (and damnable cost) of living. Home plus leafy tree-lined streets and trolley cars and coffee that comes in stupendously large cups.

title: ATP Says It Is in No Danger
description: Mark Miles, the chief executive of the ATP, offered reassurances today that the men's tour was not in danger even though its 10-year, $1.2 billion deal with the financially troubled marketing firm ISL is headed toward collapse.

title: The Burden of Containment
description: The effort to contain foot and mouth disease has created a nightmarish reality: pyres of farm animals in Britain and France, the abrupt closing of trade borders around the world, a sense of grief and panic among farmers and confusion among consumers. Although foot and mouth disease is not widespread in Europe, the mere presence of this highly contagious pathogen forced the swift slaughter, incineration and burial of some 200,000 farm animals in Britain and France in the past month and led the United States this week to ban imports of animals and animal products from the European Union. It was a sad but necessary step.

It's happened before. There was, for example, ''The Pink Panther,'' then ''The Return of the Pink Panther,'' then ''The Pink Panther Strikes Again.''

title: Fire in Central Newark Cuts Power and Routs Office Workers
description: An underground explosion and electrical fire sent smoke billowing into a downtown office building here today, injuring 16 people, forcing the evacuation of thousands of office workers, cutting power to hundreds of businesses and shutting down much of the city's center.

title: Albany Reports Many Students Haven't Passed Math Regents
description: Almost half of the first group of New York City students required to pass the Regents mathematics exam had not yet succeeded by last fall, even though many are scheduled to graduate this June, according to state data released yesterday.

description: Alex Rodriguez walked onto the field to stretch with his teammates as Derek Jeter took batting practice tonight, and the theme from ''Friends'' played on the public-address system, coincidentally.

description: Anxious investors won a modest reprieve from the week's heavy selling as the Dow Jones industrial average nudged back over 10,000 today, modestly buoyed by sharpening hopes for an interest-rate cut next week to revive the weak economy.

description: Alarmed by fears of new troubles in the United States and Japan, European stock markets fell sharply today but then recovered slightly after American markets did not perform as poorly as had been expected.

title: Bush Plans to Visit China in October
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Administration officials said today that President Bush intends to make a state visit to China in October, but the White House held off on an official announcement of the visit even though Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji prematurely mentioned it in Beijing.

description: Helen Beling, a sculptor, died on Monday at a nursing home in Bandon, Ore. She was 87.

Loving & devoted mother of Judith Murray Agisim, and son-in-law Leslie, cherished grandmother of Taylor, pre-deceased by her husband Charles Gottfried. She will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at Elmlawn Mausoleum, Buffalo, NY, at 1 PM on Thursday March 15, 2001. title: Mr. Bush Reverses Course
description: President Bush's decision not to regulate emissions of carbon dioxide, the main global warming gas, does more than betray a campaign promise. It embarrasses the administrator of his Environmental Protection Agency, Christie Whitman, angers the Europeans and creates needless headaches for his secretary of state, Colin Powell. It also undercuts some of his natural allies in the energy industry who have been willing to go out on a limb in favor of a more aggressive strategy.

title: Truck-Choked Border City Fears Being Bypassed
description: Inside the storage warehouse of Exim Forwarding, the fruits of the North American Free Trade Agreement are stacked in every corner. There are pallets with American motor oil awaiting shipment to Mexican retailers, a bundle of Mexican wire on its way to a manufacturer in the United States, a truckload of Canadian wood veneer headed to Mexico for cutting and smoothing.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: WACHOVIA CORP., Winston-Salem, N.C., a banking company, said it had agreed to buy the closely held Hamilton Dorsey Alston Co., an insurance broker in Atlanta. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Turkey Offers Plan to Revamp Ailing Banks
description: Moving to stabilize the crisis-racked economy and attract more international aid, Turkey's new economic minister said today that the government would take limited steps to revamp the country's troubled banks.

title: New York City Population Surges Upward, Census Says
description: Bolstered by a huge influx of Hispanic residents, New York City's population grew by 685,714 people over the last decade, surpassing 8 million people for the first time and cementing its place as the most populous city in the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAND, LEONARD, M.D.
description: BRAND-Leonard, M.D. The faculty and staff of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague Dr. Leonard Brand. Dr. Brand served the medical center for more than thirty years, contributing greatly to medical education, research, and practice. He was an outstanding educator, clinician and researcher who will be particularly remembered by the countless students and residents he trained. Dr. Brand was Professor Emeritus of Clinical Anesthesiology at the time of his death. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Brand family.

title: Scientist Wins Prize for Work on Cancer Gene
description: Dr. Arnold J. Levine, president of Rockefeller University, yesterday was named the first winner of the $500,000 Albany Medical Center Prize in Medicine and Biomedical Research for his discovery of a gene that normally protects against cancer but fails when a tiny change occurs in the gene. It is the richest American medical prize.

title: Better From Blue

title: BASF'S PROFIT IS MIXED
description: BASF said its operating income was up 15 percent, to 3.4 billion euros ($3.1 billion), in 2000. The result was better than forecast by analysts and by the chief executive, Jrgen Strube. Sales climbed 22 percent, to 35 billion euros, but net profit rose only 0.2 percent, to 1.24 billion euros. Mr. Strube said last year was difficult for the chemical business, but he anticipated an upturn in 2002. Petra Kappl

title: Big Board to Augment Stock Pricing Display
description: The New York Stock Exchange, concerned that the transition to decimal stock pricing has diminished the market's transparency, said yesterday that it planned to adjust the market displays available to brokerage firms to indicate whether significant numbers of shares are available to buy or sell within a few cents of the current market.

title: Tiny Infrared Printer for Users Of Tiny Hand-Held Computers
description: The paperless office may still be something of a pipe dream, but at least the printers are getting smaller. The Pocket Printer A6, made by SiPix Inc., measures 5.85 inches by 4.25 inches and is less than an inch thick. The unit weighs a mere 14 ounces, even when loaded with paper and batteries, and is expected to be in retail stores next month.

title: Sir A. F. Tuke, 80, Ex-Chairman of Barclays
description: Sir Anthony Faville Tuke, head of Barclays Bank from 1973 to 1981, died on March 6 in England. He was 80.

Nonetheless, most Americans say they essentially believe his explanation for the last-minute pardons that have shadowed his exit from public life.

title: TOP YAHOO SALES EXECUTIVE LEAVING
description: Yahoo Inc. announced yesterday that Anil Singh, the company's chief marketing executive, will retire in May. The announcement comes less than a week after Yahoo announced that its chief executive, Timothy Koogle, would step down and disclosed that its first-quarter financial results would miss analysts' forecasts. Mr. Singh, 42, went to work at Yahoo in 1995, when the company had only 20 employees. He is credited with championing online advertising when electronic commerce was a virtually untested concept. The company said Mr. Singh, above, was resigning to spend more time with his family. Yahoo, which is based in San Jose, Calif., has not named a replacement. Laurie J. Flynn

title: Amid Much Anticipation, A Bouquet of Art Songs
description: The collaboration between the bass-baritone Thomas Quasthoff and the young German pianist Justus Zeyen is good news for art song enthusiasts. Before their remarkable recital on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, people were lined up outside hoping to get a returned ticket to this sold-out event. Mr. Quasthoff and Mr. Zeyen work together with palpable sympathy and shared insight, and their performances of Schubert's autumnal ''Schwanengesang'' songs and two Brahms groups, including the affecting ''Four Serious Songs,'' were deeply rewarding.

title: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL TO MISS THIRD-QUARTER ESTIMATE
description: Kimball International Inc., which makes office furniture and electronic parts, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter earnings would miss analysts' estimates and that it had laid off 600 workers since January, citing slow demand for durable goods. The company, which is based in Jasper, Ind., expects to earn 16 cents to 20 cents a Class B share for the period ending March 31. Kimball was expected to earn 29 cents by analysts.

title: CLOROX SAYS ITS PROFIT WILL FALL SHORT OF FORECASTS
description: The Clorox Company said yesterday that its annual profit would be less than already reduced forecasts because of higher energy costs and declining sales of Glad bags, STP fuel additives and its namesake bleach. Fiscal 2001 profit will fall to $1.60 to $1.63 a share in the year ending June 30 from $1.75 a year earlier, Clorox said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected the company to earn $1.72 a share. Clorox, which cut forecasts three months ago, said sales would fall this year, and rising costs and higher advertising spending would hurt results in the first half of fiscal 2002, as well.

title: BRITANNICA CUTS BACK ONLINE
description: The online encyclopedia Britannica.com said it would dismiss 68 of its 220 United States employees beginning this week. The Web site, which offers free information from the print version of Encyclopaedia Britannica, has not shown a profit since it was introduced in October 1999. The latest cuts add to numerous executive departures and 84 layoffs since November. A company spokesman, Tom Panelas, said plans called for more fee-based services to ''achieve profitability by some time next year.'' The layoffs will not affect Encyclopaedia Britannica Inc., also owned by Encyclopaedia Britannica Holding. Elizabeth Stanton

title: Metro Business Briefing; THEATER SEEKS REVIVAL
description: The mayor of New Haven, John DeStefano Jr., said yesterday that the city would take steps to save the historic Shubert Theater, which is struggling with a deficit estimated at $1.5 million. At an afternoon news conference, Mr. DeStefano said that the city, which owns the building in downtown New Haven, has been contacting theater operators nationwide about taking over the Shubert and that he had formed a committee of community leaders to consider the theater's future. Mr. DeStefano said he would not provide a $1 million bailout that had been requested by the theater's operators, but he insisted that the city would not allow the theater to close. Built in 1914, the Shubert is known as the birthplace of many Broadway hits, including ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' and ''My Fair Lady.'' David M. Herszenhorn

title: Metro Business Briefing; OFF THE AIR
description: SNET Personal Vision has received permission from the Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control to shut down its cable television operations in the state, state officials said yesterday. SNET is expected to close its cable service, which operates in 26 towns, by the end of the summer, said Beryl Lyons, a spokeswoman for the department. Personal Vision has about 30,000 customers in Hartford, Fairfield and New Haven Counties. SNET, the former Southern New England Telecommunications Corporation, is a subsidiary of SBC Communications Inc., the telecommunications giant based in San Antonio. State officials said SNET would be required to pay $50 to each customer to get cable service elsewhere. SBC has been moving out of the cable business to concentrate on its telephone, wireless and Internet operations. Jayson Blair

title: RECUSAL IN MICROSOFT CASE
description: The federal judge who ordered the breakup of Microsoft last April has said that he will not preside over a class-action racial discrimination suit filed against the company. Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson of the United States District Court in Washington was randomly assigned the case in January; seven current and former black Microsoft employees say the company discriminated against African- Americans in evaluations, compensation, promotions and wrongful termination. Judge Jackson, who cited the company's appeal of the landmark antitrust lawsuit as the reason for recusing himself, took one last shot at Microsoft, saying the company had an ''institutional disdain for both the truth and for rules of law that lesser entities must respect.'' A Microsoft spokesman said Judge Jackson's decision to step aside was an appropriate one. Microsoft has accused the judge of being biased and of committing substantive errors in the government's antitrust lawsuit.

It hit the north end, exposing rosemary and other cool-loving plants to the elements; luckily, they were fine. So were the banana shallots in the cold frame, which was smashed to bits. ''They're hardier than I thought,'' he said.

title: Metro Business Briefing; RADIO STATIONS SOLD
description: Citadel Communications Corporation, the sixth-largest radio broadcaster in the United States, said it would sell three Atlantic City radio stations and the rights to operate another to the Millennium Radio Group in a $19.4 million cash deal. The stations being sold are WFPG-FM, WPUR-FM and WFPG-FM. WKOE-FM will be run by Millennium under an operating agreement. Citadel agreed to be acquired by Forstmann Little & Company of New York in January. Millennium is a new partnership between the Swiss bank UBS AG's UBS Capital Americas unit and Mercury Capital Partners. Citadel's stock, which is traded on the Nasdaq, dropped 1.5 percent to $24.31 by the end of trading yesterday. Jayson Blair

title: DIRECTOR ENDS CONFLICT
description: Thomas Middelhoff, left, the president and chief executive of the German media group Bertelsmann, will resign as a supervisory board member of Vivendi Universal, the French media and utility group. Mr. Middelhoff had been a board member of Vivendi since May 1999. The two media companies are competitors in a growing number of areas, but are also believed to be negotiating closer ties and joint ventures. Oliver Herrgesell, a spokesman for Bertelsmann, said the companies wanted to clarify their boundaries. ''They are trying to say they don't want a conflict of interest,'' he said. Petra Kappl

title: The Pitfalls of Forgiving, In a Spanish Tale of David

In ''Los Cabellos de Absaln'' (''Absalom's Tresses'') he tried to turn a great biblical story into classic Greek tragedy, and he came astonishingly close to that goal. (He has to share a bit of the honor with another Spanish Golden Age master, Tirso de Molina, since he borrowed part of one act from a work by him.)

description: Van der Moolen Holding N.V., the Amsterdam stock exchange's largest market specialist, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Scavone, McKenna, Cloud & Company for $60 million, expanding its share of New York Stock Exchange business. Van der Moolen expects the purchase, which will strengthen its position as the Big Board's No. 5 market specialist, to be completed in about two months, a spokesman, Tom Schram, said. Scavone acts as a market specialist for 56 of the stocks listed on the New York exchange.

Barnesandnoble.com lists 36 books about Shackleton available for purchase, and more are on the way. Three recent documentaries about his 1914-16 expedition have been shown (or shortly will be), and a television drama is in the making, starring Kenneth Branagh.

The company also said it might try to meet demand for the drug, a bleeding-disorder treatment, by adding capacity at its plant in Thousand Oaks, Calif. Baxter, based in Deerfield, Ill., told investors in New York that the company would spend $2 billion from 1995 to 2005 to increase sales in its BioScience unit. The company seeks unit sales growth of at least 20 percent a year, to $12 billion in 2010, from $2.5 billion in 2000.

title: TAX SYSTEM SAID TO BE VULNERABLE
description: Government investigators tapped into the computer system of the Internal Revenue Service during last year's tax season, exposing security flaws that could have allowed hackers to view and even alter information on electronically filed tax returns, according to a Congressional report. The General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress that investigates government operations, criticized the tax agency for lax encryption and inadequate password protection. The I.R.S. and investigators said that no outside attacks had occurred. In addition, the G.A.O. found, the I.R.S. refunded more than $2 billion to taxpayers who filed electronically without properly authenticating their returns. The agency withholds refunds when paper returns are not signed.

title: Blasts in China Leave at Least 18 Dead

title: Hold the Euphemisms: It's a Hate Word
description: ''The N-Word on Trial for Manslaughter'' is the blaring newspaper headline in the two-hour season finale of ''Any Day Now.'' This Lifetime series about two friends who grew up together in Birmingham, Ala., -- Rene (Lorraine Toussaint), a black single lawyer, and M. E. (Annie Potts), a white wife and mother -- has grown stronger over its three seasons, examining the complexities of interracial love and friendship, including the hidden or unconscious biases that plague even the most genuine of these relationships. Now, with television language changing quickly to reflect the rude realities of life, this thoughtful, provocative drama examines how racial slurs function in society, how insidiously they creep into common use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, AMES H., JR.
description: RICHARDS-Ames H., Jr. Died March 14, 2001 of heart failure at his home at Long Close Road, Stamford, CT. He was 82 years old. Born in Stamford and a lifelong resident, he was educated at Yale College and Yale Law School. He re-wrote the Planning and Zoning chapters of the Stamford City Charter; was instrumental in the joint acquisition of Mianus Park by Stamford and Greenwich, and the acquisition of Fort Stamford. He was the first president of the Fort Stamford Society and had served on the Stamford Conservation Commission. A veteran of World War II, Mr. Richards served on two aircraft carriers and participated in the invasion of Morocco in 1943. He worked for many years for Felmont Oil and its affiliate, Case, Pomeroy, in New York City. He was a member of the Yale Club of New York City, the Yale Club of Stamford, and was a former member of Woodway Country Club. He is survived by his wife, Janice Teufel Richards; four sons: Peter, Alden, Van and Christopher; a daughter, Virginia Perrakis; and ten grandchildren.

title: SUEZ POSTS STRONG RESULTS
description: Shares in the big European conglomerate Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux S.A. of France soared after the company reported stronger-than-expected growth of revenue and earnings last year. The group, which said it would be known officially in the future as Suez, reported that operating profit rose 37 percent to 3.78 billion euros, or $3.4 billion, on revenue growth of 36 percent to 34.6 billion euros. Net income rose 32 percent to 1.9 billion euros, or 10.03 euros a share. Shares in Suez had taken a beating in recent weeks after failed attempts to acquire or merge with the industrial gas group, Air Liquide S.A., to strengthen Suez's industrial services activities as a complement to its core businesses of water and waste management, electricity generation and telecommunications. Suez shares climbed more than 5 percent, after falling 18 percent so far this year. John Tagliabue (NYT)

title: COSMETICS SITE DELAYED

Gloss.com was a leading retail beauty site when Este Lauder bought it last April for an undisclosed sum. The company said it still intended to revive gloss.com as a portal for sales of Este Lauder lines as well as competitors' products. Plans now call for testing the site this summer and starting operations in the fall of 2001, in time for Christmas sales. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing; GROCERY STORE CLOSING
description: A popular grocery store on the Upper West Side is closing after 10 years and is expected to be replaced by a Victoria's Secret lingerie store, real estate sources said yesterday. Kabir Abdullah, the assistant manager of the grocery store, Broadway Farms on Broadway and 84th Street, said that the store's lease was about to expire and that the owners could not afford the higher rents now being asked along Broadway. ''If you're a chain store, it's a different story,'' Mr. Abdullah said. Many Upper West Side residents have complained that upscale retailers like Coach Store and Godiva Chocolatier are edging out neighborhood services. Victoria's Secret opened an 18,000-square-foot store at Broadway and 67th Street in November, but company officials would not confirm yesterday that a deal had been struck for the 84th Street site. Terry Pristin

title: Album of the Week
description: DELBERT McCLINTON: -- ''Nothing Personal'' (New West). The grain in Delbert McClinton's voice was built up the old-fashioned way: 40 years of singing in roadhouses and honky-tonks. Having grown up in the down-home musical crossroads that is Texas, he soaked up blues, country, gospel and rhythm-and-blues without worrying about particular pedigrees. Mr. McClinton, 60, has also had plenty of time to observe love lost and found. In the 13 songs on ''Nothing Personal,'' all of which he wrote or helped write, lust and heartbreak continue their endless roundelay, and Mr. McClinton sings with humor and grit, whether he is celebrating an all-night tryst or ruefully recalling how ''my ship came in and she sank it.'' He is more eccentric and existential writing without collaborators, sketching people in trouble in ''Desperation'' and offering strategic advice in ''Nothing Lasts Forever.'' Although Mr. McClinton hasn't always sounded comfortable in a recording studio, this time he romps through the songs, especially when his band adds New Orleans to the beat. JON PARELES

He can do so only by opening up his country's constricted political process, rooting out high-level corruption and extracting Uganda from the war in Congo.

title: Foreign Affairs; Digital Divide or Dividend?

But every time we connect one of these native villages, I feel that a little of my native Eskimo culture is lost. So, I have a question: Isn't the digital divide actually a good thing?''

title: To the Manner Born? Nein, but Fitting In: Handel Goes Native for a Mini-Opera
description: For nearly two centuries, George Frideric Handel was best known as the composer of ''Messiah,'' an English-language oratorio. But Handel, of course, was a native German, and he seems to have spoken English with a strong accent his whole life. Many people have praised his settings of English; but Jane Glover, a conductor who specializes in Baroque opera, has some reservations. When he was setting English texts, ''he often made absolute howlers,'' Ms. Glover said in a recent interview. ''Whenever I can, I try to help him out. He would hate to have got it wrong.''

Marriott. Thayer now owns 19 hotels, although this is the first in New York. The Rihga, which has 504 suites and opened in 1990, was owned by the Rihga Royal Hotel Group of Osaka, Japan. The Japanese company nearly sold the hotel last September to Strategic Hotel Capital for more than $200 million. But Strategic ultimately decided against the deal. Charles V. Bagli

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET TAX SYSTEM SAID TO BE VULNERABLE Government investigators tapped into the computer system of the Internal Revenue Service during last year's tax season, exposing security flaws that could have allowed hackers to view and even alter information on electronically filed tax returns, according to a Congressional report. The General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress that investigates government operations, criticized the tax agency for lax encryption and inadequate password protection. The I.R.S. and investigators said that no outside attacks had occurred. In addition, the G.A.O. found, the I.R.S. refunded more than $2 billion to taxpayers who filed electronically without properly authenticating their returns. The agency withholds refunds when paper returns are not signed. (NYT)

Under the terms of the agreement, Intuit will purchase Compaq equipment, technology and services to run its Web sites and Compaq will advertise on Intuit's Web sites, including Quicken.com. Compaq also agreed to bundle Quicken financial software on its personal computers to generate additional revenue for Intuit. The announcement comes on the same day that Intuit shares fell sharply after disclosing an outlook for slower-than-expected 2001 revenue growth, while Compaq announced job cuts and warned that its earnings would fall short. title: INTUIT SAYS ITS PROFITS WILL FALL SHORT OF FORECASTS
description: Intuit, the maker of personal-finance software, said yesterday that revenue in its third quarter and 2001 fiscal year would miss forecasts because of sluggish sales of its QuickBooks software and slower Internet advertising. Intuit's shares dropped $12.44, or 29 percent, to $29.81, after the company said sales in the period ending in April would be $425 million to $450 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call had expected sales of $467.5 million. Demand for the company's QuickBooks software for small businesses is lagging because many customers upgraded last year to avoid potential problems related to the Year 2000 computer bug, Intuit said.

title: Review/Fashion; Tom Ford Gets in Step At Saint Laurent, And It's the Habanera
description: In the barrage of kisses and kudos that enveloped Tom Ford after a stirring Yves Saint Laurent show on Wednesday, he looked momentarily perplexed when asked if this was his Carmen collection. It was a reference not only to the Spanish blouses and flaring taffeta skirts he had sent out but also to Mr. Saint Laurent's 1976 collection based on the Bizet heroine.

title: Saving Comrade Ryanovich: Same War From a Different Perspective
description: Three years ago Steven Spielberg's ''Saving Private Ryan'' was justly hailed as a breakthrough in war-movie realism, a harrowing immersion -- particularly in its early battle scenes -- in the brutal chaos of combat. But if Mr. Spielberg established a new standard for a venerable film genre, he also took a deliberate step backward, restoring to the war movie some of the grandeur and romance it had lost in the decades after Vietnam.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS BLASTS HIT GIANT OIL RIG A pair of explosions before dawn yesterday on the world's largest offshore oil platform, operated by Petrobras in the Campos Basin about 78 miles off the Brazilian coast, left one worker dead and nine missing. Calling the situation "grave," the president of Petrobras, Henri Phillipe Reichstuhl, said the 40- story platform, which produces 80,000 barrels of oil a day, was listing heavily and could capsize. Petrobras has suffered a series of costly oil spills in recent months, and labor unions say 81 workers have died in industrial accidents on Petrobras projects since 1998. Larry Rohter (NYT)

title: HUGE BANK WRITE-OFF IN JAPAN
description: Sanwa Bank Ltd. and two merger partners said that they would double their write-offs of bad loans and post a loss of 223 billion yen ($1.85 billion). The three -- Sanwa, Tokai Bank Ltd. and the Toyo Trust and Banking Company, which will combine to form UFJ Holdings Inc. in April -- will write off 1.1 trillion yen of bad debt; they had previously forecast a combined profit of 162 billion yen for the year ending March 31.

title: INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED IN EUROPE
description: The European Central Bank kept interest rates unchanged, leaving the key minimum bid rate at 4.75 percent. The central bank's widely expected decision was mainly based on current inflation rates still above 2 percent in the euro zone. Most analysts, citing growing evidence of an economic slowdown in the euro zone, expect the central bank to lower the key rate by the end of next quarter. Petra Kappl (NYT)

title: ZALE PLANS REDUCTION IN ITS STORE-OPENING PROGRAM
description: The Zale Corporation said yesterday that it would open 40 stores in 2002, half as many stores as planned in its next fiscal year to cut two-year capital spending by as much as 38 percent in the face of slower sales. Zale, the owner of Bailey Banks & Biddle, Zales and other jewelry chains, will reduce spending to $80 million to $90 million this fiscal year and to $50 million to $60 million in 2002, the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. It had planned to spend $210 million in the two-year period, according to an earlier filing.

title: Drill Away, Say Alaskans, Who Know Which Side Bread Is Oiled On
description: ANCHORAGE, March 15  Last fall, every man, woman and child in Alaska received a $1,963.86 check from the state  the annual dividend paid from the royalties the state receives for the huge oil operations in the vast North Slope fields along the Arctic Ocean. There is no income tax here, no state sales tax, again courtesy of the oil revenues, which financed 84 percent of the state budget last year.

title: Council Members Assail Plan To Let Edison Run 5 Schools
description: Nine members of the City Council attacked a proposal yesterday that would turn the management of five low-performing public schools over to a private company. They said that the company and Board of Education officials had not kept parents well informed about the process and had not given them any real choice.

title: INCHON AIRPORT TO OPEN
description: South Korean officials agreed that the new international airport at Inchon would open on March 29 as planned for all international flights in and out of the Seoul region. The president of the government-owned Inchon International Airport Corporation, Kang Dong Suk, said a phased opening, recommended by a consulting firm, in which flights were transferred gradually from Kimpo Airport, midway between Seoul and Inchon, 30 miles to the west, would cause confusion for both travelers and airlines. He denied that the baggage system was inadequate, saying tests had insured that bags moved smoothly 99.8 or 99.9 percent of the time. In the few cases where they failed, he said, they were retrieved manually. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Ego Bashing And Scandals As Paris Picks A New Mayor

The company held assets of 8.2 trillion yen at the end of December, while inventories were worth 1.1 trillion yen.

title: IRISH INFLATION IS UP
description: Inflation in Ireland, where rapid economic growth and an expansionary budget have drawn criticism from other European nations, ticked up to an annual rate of 5.3 percent in February after having fallen steadily from 7 percent in November. Housing prices were a major cause; they have risen 26.4 percent in the last year. Opposition parties and labor leaders called for reinstatement of price controls, but economists predicted that inflation would fall to 3 percent or less by 2002 without them. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: ENBRIDGE, CANADIAN OIL CONCERN, EXPANDING IN U.S.
description: The Canadian oil and gas distributor Enbridge Inc. is expanding its pipeline holdings in the United States with the $350 million purchase of Midcoast Energy Resources Inc. of Houston. Midcoast's $250 million of debt will also be assumed by Enbridge. Based in Calgary, Alberta, Enbridge operates the main pipeline carrying oil from Alberta to markets in eastern Canada and the midwestern United States. It is also the largest distributor of natural gas in Canada. Midcoast has oil and gas pipeline systems in the Gulf Coast and the Midwest. Enbridge expects to complete the $27-a-share purchase this summer.

title: Stravinsky as Show Business
description: Jonathan Sheffer's concerts with his Eos Orchestra are typically meant to engage the eye as well as the ear, and in the case of his all-Stravinsky program on Thursday evening at the Ethical Culture Society, that meant turning a group of works composed between 1914 and 1918 into an evening of theater pieces. The fact that the music was composed in the shadow of World War I, and included ''L'Histoire du Soldat,'' gave the program a useful (if false) theatrical unity. Christopher Alden's staging (with costumes by Fabio Toblini and lighting by Adam Silverman) had a military theme, with a perverse touch: both the licentious love songs of ''Pribaoutki'' and the barnyard allegory, ''Renard,'' were performed by singers in military fatigues, but the Soldier in ''L'Histoire du Soldat'' wore a spiffy acquamarine suit and tie.

title: A Pint for St. Patrick in the New Ireland
description: Twenty-five years ago, Dublin was the dullest place on earth to spend St. Patrick's Day -- the feast of this patron saint who first came to Ireland as a slave in the fifth century. (He escaped to the continent of Europe, the story goes, became a priest and then for some reason returned to the land of his slavery and converted us all to Christianity.) His feast day, coming as it did in the middle of Lent, was much welcomed by those of us who had given up chocolate, beer or the smokes. Because the simple truth was that to us St. Patrick's Day did not count as part of Lent. It would have been an insult to the national patron not to have celebrated his day properly. The thing was, that those for whom celebration involved alcohol were in a bit of a quandary: The public houses and bars just did not open in Ireland on St. Patrick's Day.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SWEENY, ARTHUR JR.
description: SWEENY-Arthur Jr. On March 15, 2001, in Stamford Ct, age 94. Formerly of Pleasantville, N.Y., he was born in New York City, January 6, 1907, son of Arthur Sweeny and Elizabeth Ann Marshall. He was schooled at the Horace Mann School, '24, Harvard College, '28, and Columbia University, '32. He was a Professor of Organic Chemistry at Hunter College for 30 years and at Lehman College for 14 years, where upon his retirement, he was named Professor Emeritus and an annual lecture series was endowed in his honor. He also served Grand Marshall of both Hunter and Lehman Colleges. He was predeceased by his beloved wife, Bailey Gordon Patterson. He is survived by his two sons, Arthur III of Colchester Vt and Bradley Patterson of Rye, N.Y., four grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Services will be at Christ Church, Rye, N.Y. at 11 AM, Monday, March 19. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Horace Mann School, Alumni Office, 231 West 246 Street, Riverdale, New York 10471.

title: New York City's Population Peak
description: The first burst of census data from the year 2000 offers cause for optimism in New York City. The numbers show the city as an inviting metropolis, no longer a victim of flight and urban decay. After losing its population mostly to the suburbs and the South in the mid-1970's and early 1980's, the city began to register signs of renewal with the 1990 census. Now, in the latest round of counting, New York has broken the eight million mark, surpassing its historical peak in population of 30 years ago. The census has finally registered what any New Yorker knows firsthand from crowding into the subways or competing for an affordable apartment. America's largest city, benefiting from a decade of sustained immigration and a solid economy, is officially booming.

title: Poles and the Jews: How Deep the Guilt?
description: On July 10, 1941, 1,600 Jews, nearly the entire Jewish population of the Polish village of Jedwabne, were murdered by their Polish neighbors. Some were hunted down and killed with clubs, axes and knives; most were herded into a barn and then burned alive. Although the slaughter was not a secret, publicly the Nazi occupiers were blamed. A monument in Jedwabne (pronounced yed-VAHB-nay) declared: ''Place of martyrdom of the Jewish people. Hitler's Gestapo and gendarmerie burned 1,600 people alive, July 10, 1941.'' But last May, Jan T. Gross, a historian at New York University, published ''Neighbors: The Destruction of the Jewish Community in Jedwabne'' in Poland. The book, which will be issued in the United States in April, documents the massacre by Polish villagers in gruesome detail. In a country whose people think of themselves as wartime victims, not villains, it set off a storm of debate in corner shops, cafes and classrooms, and among the country's political and church leaders. Some Poles have continued to deny Polish responsibility; most have tried to wrestle with the country's history of anti-Semitism and questions of collective guilt. Jozef Cardinal Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, and President Aleksander Kwasniewski have publicly asked for forgiveness, and on Thursday the Jedwabne memorial was removed. Adam Michnik is a dissident and historian who spent six years in prison under the postwar Communist regime, served as an adviser to the Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and is now editor-in-chief of Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's largest daily newspaper. He wrote this article for The New York Times, and it was translated from the Polish by Ewa Zadrzynska.

title: The Final Freedom
description: Should I lie or tell the truth? Is my marriage vow binding? Ought I give in when temptation calls? To whom are my obligations strongest? To answer such questions, Americans have traditionally relied on time-tested moral rules, usually handed down by a supreme being, that command obedience and punish defiance. Now we live in an age of moral freedom, in which individuals are expected to determine for themselves what it means to lead a good and virtuous life. We decide what is right and wrong, not by bending our wills to authority, but by considering who we are, what others require and what consequences follow from acting one way rather than another.

description: J. K. Rowling has always bristled at suggestions she may have borrowed ideas and characters for her "Harry Potter" books. Now, as previews of the first Harry Potter film are shown in theaters and Harry Potter toys, clothes and trinkets invade stores, Ms. Rowling has been confronted with perhaps the strongest challenge to her authenticity  the re-emergence of a 1980's book with some characters and words remarkably similar to those in her story about the boy wizard.

title: Jonathan Lebed's Extracurricular Activities
description: The S.E.C.'s failure to discuss the specifics of the trading that it alleged was illegal is troubling. If, in fact, Lebed was engaging in an Internet-enhanced version of pump and dump, it ought to be relatively simple to show the temporal correlation between the Internet postings (the pump) and Lebed's sales (the dump). Apparently, the S.E.C chose not to answer this question when Lewis asked it.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-18-01; Life After Wartime
description: Maybe it was the sight of James Gandolfini, of Tony Soprano fame, playing a gay mobster in the recent movie ''The Mexican'' that really brought it home to me. Is the culture war over or what? No one in the movie theater I went to seemed to bat an eyelid at this icon of Italian masculinity being gay -- and so far as I know, we've even been spared any hand wringing from the religious right on the matter. Odd, isn't it? It wasn't that long ago, after all, that any straight actor playing a gay character would have been news. And it wasn't that long ago that we were all being rushed to the barricades to defend or attack any number of other hot-button social topics -- abortion rights, gay visibility, pop-culture trash, affirmative action, the war on drugs -- and not only as separate political issues but as a contest for the very soul of the country. Almost overnight, though, the energy seems to have seeped out of these conflicts. While there are still plenty of inflammatory moments, and plenty of opportunities for dissent, the crackle of cultural gunfire is now increasingly distant.

title: A Nazi Cloud Hangs Over a Painting on Loan to Yale
description: THE French artist Gustave Courbet (1819-1877) is known as the ''father of 19th-century Realism.'' Unlike many of his contemporaries, he was a vernacular artist, specializing in paintings that reflected the grandeur and elegance of the French countryside. His knack for subtle satire can be seen in ''Le Grand Pont'' (1864), in which the majesty of nature dwarfs an aristocratic young girl crossing a bridge on a donkey. Right now, this work is at the center of a controversy that might just appeal to Courbet's sense of the absurd.

title: Don't Spray It, Play It
description: The days of being besieged by what Jerry Seinfeld called perfume Nazis may finally be over. While fancy perfume boutiques and department store counters have switched from spritzing shoppers to handing out scented strips of paper, an even higher perfume technology is now available to the public. In the Jo Malone store, which opened Friday at Broadway and 23rd Street, a ''scent booth'' allows customers to sample fragrances without worrying about scent clinging to their clothes, fingers or, worst of all, nostrils. The scent station, in an enclosed corner of the store, is outfitted with a 42-inch touch-operated screen with two steel nozzles and speakers beneath. Shoppers can choose from a selection of 11 scents in 121 combinations in categories like Citrus, Spicy and Heavy Floral. At the touch of a button, a 15-second video plays as the nozzles release a gentle infusion of fragrance -- 10 percent oil and 90 percent air. Two large vents then whisk away the scent before it can settle. Although the music and videos are slightly hokey (sudsy shower scenes for Citrus; seductive body-cream massage for Heavy Floral), the scent booth experience offers a moment of free aromatherapy at its quickest -- and least annoying.

title: When Alzheimer's Strikes Early
description: GREGG RICE, as he was, had a bushy black beard and a perfect sense of where he stood. A professor of biology at Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, Mr. Rice had a deep and abiding interest in his field. Living nearby in Hastings, he carved out time to car-pool his young daughters and, at night, stayed fit by playing basketball at the same local high school where his wife, Laura, taught English.

description: When Senator Frank H. Murkowski of Alaska, the chairman of the Natural Resources Committee, introduced his broad energy proposal, he made sure to publicly thank, by name, the many lobbying groups who helped shape the bill.

description: Perhaps the closest that the songwriter Hoagy Carmichael ever came to angling greatness was his appearance with Humphrey Bogart in ''To Have and Have Not.'' But, alas, while Bogey played the hard-boiled charter-boat captain Harry Morgan, fervent chaser of blue marlin and Lauren Bacall, Carmichael contentedly stayed portside, preferring the piano seat to the fighting chair.

description: THE St. Patrick's Day season in the United States has its accepted customs, from the deconstruction of the meanings behind a simple parade to the All Things Irish come-ons that dominate public television. But a new tradition has joined the old: the Sinn Fein national tour, in which the best and brightest of the Irish Republican Army's political wing fan out across the country to tap political, spiritual and financial support.

description: EVERY March, the pregnant females of little Mexican brown bats migrate up from central Mexico to raise their young in caves or old mine shafts, barns and even attics in North America. About 20 million spend the spring and summer in Bracken Cave, the world's largest bat colony, halfway between San Antonio and Austin, Tex.

description: WITH her distinct musical phrasing and mastery of diverse styles, Risa Steinberg possesses qualities that not all dancers are born with. Since she left the Limn Dance Company in 1982 and began a solo career, she has reinvented herself as an interpreter of the modern-dance pioneers Isadora Duncan and Doris Humphrey and of contemporary choreographers like Ann Carlson and Mark Morris. But judging by a recent rehearsal, even a veteran must practice.

title: On a Bike in Cuba
description: To the Editor: Sandra Blakeslee describes in vivid detail the contrast between those amenities used exclusively by tourists, like the ''immaculate'' Royalton Hotel, and those reserved for Cubans, who find themselves in decrepit, grimy and depressing conditions. She does so in a nonchalant way, as if it is a normal thing and no one should find it objectionable or the least deplorable.

description: IN 1980, Julia Meech, an associate curator of Japanese art at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, set out to study the history of Japanese print collections at the museum: when and by whom they were given or sold to the museum. As an art historian, she suspected that the information was probably documented in hundreds, perhaps thousands, of entries in the card catalog on Asian art that chronologically detailed every acquisition the museum had made over the last century.

description: Odd-lot investors, the small-fry who buy or sell fewer than 100 shares, have a reputation for doing the wrong thing. And odd-lotters who short the market -- sell borrowed shares in hopes of profiting from a decline -- are supposedly the worst.

description: AFTER foot-and-mouth disease was discovered on a farm east of London in February, the scourge rampaged across Britain and, as the alarms spread, drastic measures were imposed by European governments to prevent its spread across the Continent.

title: Relationships; A Fitness Fanatic
description: When I first met Cody Franchetti at a dinner party in Midtown Manhattan a year ago, he was wearing a four-button navy blue suit made of hopsacking, a fabric that he received from his friend Nicola Bulgari, who had in turn purchased it from Fred Astaire's former tailor. Franchetti is 6 feet 1 inch tall and has the comportment of someone to whom fate has shown considerable largess. Several months later at a smaller dinner, he was chatting amiably with Harrison Ford. As it happened, Franchetti had recently shown the actor and his family around Rome, his native city. That night, Franchetti was wearing a suit of houndstooth, with pants loose-fitting and pleated, roped shoulders almost imperceptibly raised.

title: The Nation; The Law of Unintended Consequences
description: THOMAS M. DAVIS 3RD, the Virginia congressman who runs the House Republicans' re-election effort, is a canny practitioner of politics. So it should be no surprise that even as the Senate stands on the threshold of a far-ranging debate on the campaign finance law, Mr. Davis can already see how the political parties might circumvent Senator John McCain's drive to ban them from accepting large, unregulated contributions -- just as so many earlier reform efforts have been circumvented.

title: Couple Resign Arts Posts to Move to Miami
description: LAURA CALZOLARI, director of the Music Conservatory of Westchester, and Howard Herring, executive director of the Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts, have announced their resignations. The couple, who are husband and wife, will be moving to Miami, where Mr. Herring will become president and chief executive officer of the New World Symphony as of May 1. Ms. Calzolari, who will leave her job on June 30, said she would explore other interests.

title: Nascar Revs Back Up After Earnhardt Death
description: THE death of Dale Earnhardt, the fabled stock car driver, last month was a blow not only to his fans but also to companies that are tied to motor sports. Shares in the dominant racetrack companies, the International Speedway Corporation and Speedway Motorsports plummeted in the days just after Mr. Earnhardt's crash at the Daytona International Speedway in Florida.

title: A Prophet Of Gesture Who Got Theater Moving
description: THE International Theater School of Jacques Lecoq is artfully ensconced behind a labyrinth of nondescript courtyards in the bustling commercial center of Paris's 10th Arrondissement, not far from the Gare du Nord. The drab metal door at 57 rue Faubourg St.-Denis gives no hint of providing access to one of the most influential theater training programs of the last half century -- a school of clowning, improvisation and commedia dell'arte whose graduates have collectively redefined the boundaries of physical theater for their generation. The building's unusual history is evoked by the sounds of shrieking, howling and grunting that echo through the corridors as students prepare for their lessons.

As editors of Harden's Guides, including ''London Restaurants 2001,'' we would like to say that on dining generally, his cost comparisons are shaky. title: March 11-17; Bankruptcy Rules Toughened
description: A campaign by credit card companies and banks, backed by millions in political contributions, proved successful. The Senate passed a bill that will make it harder for people to erase their debts in bankruptcy. The House has already approved its own version. And while President Clinton vetoed similar legislation, President Bush has signaled he will sign it. Campaign-finance-reform groups were quick to point out that credit card companies and banks were among the largest corporate supporters of Mr. Bush's campaign. Philip Shenon

title: The American Risk in Japan
description: We have often seen how the fate of the American economy cannot be divorced from global markets, and how even a spark abroad can create a fire at home. In 1987, for example, the stock market crash was precipitated in part by a dispute between Washington and Bonn over interest rates and trade. In 1998, a financial crisis that began in Thailand ultimately spread until it forced a dramatic bailout of one of America's largest hedge funds -- a rescue that prevented an implosion of many American banks. Now Japan is the trouble spot that ought to keep us up at night.

title: Performance Art; Old Masters, New Mistresses
description: Does anything irritate a guy more than the V.I.P.-room blues? He's got the car, the suit and the status, but a monkey with a clipboard can still make him feel small. In London, where a man is defined by his club memberships, nothing dents his credibility more than two little words: ''Application denied.'' So last June, when rumors circulated among the city's Bright Young Things of a club running a ''Don't call us, we'll call you'' policy, all of hip young London salivated. The target? Affluent singles with a taste for the finer things in life. But this was neither a New Establishment media haunt, like the Groucho Club, nor a decadent salon for the Champagne set, like Home House. The chosen few are founding members of Sotheby's New Collectors Club.

title: At British Museum, Africa Is Back

Then, with the area around the Reading Room cleared of books and the entire courtyard turned into a stunning covered plaza, visitors gained access to the museum through any of three neo-Classical porticoes. One set of doors, though, remained closed, with only the sound of construction suggesting that more would soon be revealed.

description: In vino veritas. In wine there is truth. That has been said for nearly 2,000 years. Pliny the Elder is generally given credit for the thought.

title: Re-Inventing Edison's Old Neighborhood
description: WEDGED between the stately opulence of Llewellyn Park and the increasingly troubled town of Orange is Tory Corner, a jumble of two-family homes, faded factory buildings and mom-and-pop businesses that line Main Street in West Orange. It is also home to the Edison National Historic Site, the laboratory where Thomas Alva Edison worked for 44 years. Until his death in 1931, Edison lived at Glenmont, his Llewellyn Park estate, which is also open to the public.

title: Behind Battier And Williams, Top-Seeded Duke Move On
description: The pre game embrace was long and heartfelt Mike Krzyzewski wrapped his arms around Quin Snyder, his former player and assistant coach, near halfcourt before he sent his Duke Blue Devils out against Snyder's Missouri Tigers. title: Great Alzana, Who Mocked Danger and New York Law on the High Wire, Dies at 82

title: Who's That Peering Out Of the Grid?
description: THE Wexner Center for the Arts, now 10 years old, marks Peter Eisenman's unofficial transition from theorist to practicing builder. Eisenman, a New York architect, had built several small projects before this, including houses and a fire station in Queens, but he was mainly known as an educator, critic, agitator and minence noire of the avant-garde. With the Wexner, the public gained an opportunity to discover how well the theories stood up. The center's anniversary is an occasion to revisit the building and the issues raised by it.

title: The Lower Keys: Hold the Margaritas

If everyone there treats you as if you've been closing the place every night for the last eight years, you're in the Keys.''

title: The Sweet Life
description: With spring and summer brightening the horizon, we feel inclined to put aside serious endeavors and devote ourselves to la dolce vita. After all, the clothes that paraded down the runway this season seem better suited to Carnaval in Rio than going hand over hand up the corporate ladder. If you want to dress for success, hold off until autumn. For now, loosen up a little. Give in to some lighthearted urges. But don't forget the ascot.

title: Driesell-Versus-Maryland Matchup Turns Into a Terrapins Rout
description: Fifteen years after Lefty Driesell was forced out of his job as coach at Maryland, he showed up with his latest team, the Georgia State Panthers, with hopes of upsetting his former team today in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament's West Regional.

title: Testing the Virtual View From a Mock Airport Tower
description: Newark Airport will be getting a new, 335-foot-high control tower in November 2002. But before the construction started in 1999, Federal Aviation Agency engineers and air traffic controlers who would be working in the tower wanted to make sure nothing would block their view. To find out, they went to the Airway Facilities Tower Integration Laboratory at the F.A.A.'s William Hughes Technical Center at Atlantic City International Airport. There, using mockups of a cab, or tower interior, plus panoramic photographs or coumpter-generated images on six-foot-high wrap-around display panels, computer scientists and electrical engineers can simulate the view from any airport control tower, including air traffic and weather conditions. The virtual Newark tower is a 240-degree photographic image that includes Elizabeth, Newark, New York City and Newark Bay and the turnpike bridge. Bill Vaughan, the supervisory electronics engineer who manages the laboratory, talked about his operation.

description: Figuring the average investor would rather curl up with a good book than an annual report, I.B.M.'s corporate communications team and its outside consultants decided to cast Big Blue's Year 2000 report as a ''no-holds-barred story of one year in the life of a company.''

title: Writing in the Shadows
description: In Henry James's story ''The Middle Years,'' an artist says: ''We work in the dark -- we do what we can -- we give what we have. Our doubt is our passion and our passion is our task.'' But those words apply to readers, too, for we read in the dark when we encounter a real work of art; we can never know where it will take us. What a shame that so much of the time now, before we're allowed to be alone with a book, we've seen it blanketed in press releases, reviews and dust-jacket testimonials that tell us what to think. By the time I got to W. G. Sebald's books -- what does one call them? meditations, elegies, mutations grown from memoir, history, literary biography and prose poetry -- they had already been canonized. Important critics and novelists had certified their greatness, using even the m-word -- masterpiece.''

title: The City and Residents Joust Over Blame in Sewer Mess
description: For the last two months, 10 homeowners on a block of Beach 25th Street have been struggling to remove sewage that has been seeping into their basements. They ran rubber hoses to pump out the water and used lots of store-bought disinfectant.

title: Few Want To Be Seen With Image Of Clinton
description: He may still be able to draw speaker's fees in the tens of thousands of dollars, but few along Pennsylvania Avenue are willing to pay six bucks to be seen with former President Bill Clinton.

title: Disneyland Shuttle To Universal Studios
description: Tourists who want to segue from Mickey Mouse at Disneyland to, say, the Mummy's Cave at Universal Studios Hollywood can now catch a free round-trip shuttle bus from Anaheim to Universal City. They must buy full-price tickets to Universal Studios ($43 ages 12 and older, $32 ages 3 through 11) at the AirportBus terminal at 1415 Manchester Avenue, adjacent to Disneyland.

title: Where New Jersey Lives
description: Over all, New Jersey's population grew quicker in the 90's than in the previous decade and faster than those in New York and Pennsylvania. Its population grew 7.38 percent, to 8.41 million. The fastest-growing county was Somerset.

title: The Drums Make Way For a Voice
description: IF the name Kodo rings a bell (or clangs a cymbal or strikes a gong), it may summon visions of lithe, well-muscled, hyperactive Japanese men, clad in colorful costumes or scant loincloths, pummeling all manner of drums and other percussion instruments. That, at any rate, is what audience members will mostly find when Kodo, at once a bastion of tradition and a hotbed of novelty, plays this evening at the Performing Arts Center at Purchase College in Purchase, N.Y., and on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall.

title: More Carry, Less Cash
description: For the last few years of the handbag timeline -- from Gucci bamboo to Prada bowling -- the only way to own a fabulous pocketbook was by emptying your wallet. This season, whether due to a tottery economy or just a much-needed dose of common sense, retailers are offering handbags with high brand appeal at less than half the price of the status staples.

title: Great Adaptations (We Just Weren't Told They Were)
description: FINANCIAL statements in Hollywood are fluid things, changing with the tides of interpretation; but screen credits are like the fossil record, fixed and unchallengeable. This is all you need to know if you've been puzzled by the nomination of ''O Brother, Where Art Thou?'' for the Oscar for best screenplay from an existing source. Embedded in the opening titles of the film, like a calcified trilobite, is the statement that ''O Brother'' is based on ''The Odyssey'' of Homer. And so, to the Hollywood mind, it is.

title: Man, 21, Is Charged in His Grandmother's Murder
description: A 21-year-old Long Island man has been charged with murder in the death of his grandmother, who was found stabbed more than 30 times in their family's apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: Racing Against Time and Putting Life in Perspective
description: Are race-car drivers athletes? Does sitting in a car for three hours in 150-degree heat traveling 180 miles an hour match the skills of running 26.2 miles in four hours? After having run three marathons in the last 16 months, including Boston last April 17, the day after he drove in the Talladega 500, Michael Waltrip knows the answer.

title: Thompsons' Road Ends With North Carolina
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 17  Nineteen years ago, the father was on the sideline and his 16-year-old son was in the stands, seated behind the Georgetown bench. The Hoyas played the 1982 national title game that night in the Superdome and John Thompson III saw his father, then the Georgetown coach, display one of his best moves as a coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SEITENBACH, MAX
description: SEITENBACH-Max. Of Forest Hills, NY on Thursday, March 15, 2001 in his 85th year. Beloved husband of Ilse. Devoted father of Irwin and Ron and daughter-in-law Lori. Adoring grandfather of Justin and Johanna. Mourned by his sister Bertha and brother Edgar. Services will be held on Sunday, March 18 at 10A.M. at Parkside Memorial Chapel, 718-896-9000.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASS, ABRAHAM H.
description: LASS-Abraham H. March 16, 2001 at age 93. Educator, writer. Husband of Sylvia Cole Lass. Father of Janet Gotkin and Roger Lass. Services Monday, March 19 at 1 PM, Forest Park Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Rd., Queens.

title: Corrections
description: A sports column last Sunday about the former basketball star George Mikan and his influence on the game misstated the result of a 1950 game between the Fort Wayne Pistons and Mikan's team, the Minneapolis Lakers. The Pistons, not the Lakers, won the game, 19-18, by holding the ball to neutralize Mikan. It was the lowest-scoring game in National Basketball Association history and helped lead to the introduction of the shot clock.

title: P. J. Tanz, Brian Slomovitz
description: Philippa Jessica Tanz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alfred Tanz of New York, was married last evening to Dr. Brian Matthew Slomovitz, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Jay Slomovitz of Westfield, N.J. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated at the Plaza in Manhattan.

description: To the Editor:

title: Just Why Is a Republican Making Verniero Squirm?
description: For such a young man, Peter G. Verniero has made a lot of serious people angry.

title: In Tenafly, $1 Million Gift Buys Dissension
description: Some residents in this upscale Bergen County town know what they would like George Prussin to do with his own million dollars.

title: Political Briefing; A Republican Bastion Wanes in California
description: If ever proof was needed that the Democratic Party is on a roll in California, here it is:

title: TAX REVENUE
description: State tax revenue totaled $53 million in February, 3.5 percent below estimates, mainly because of lower corporate and inheritance taxes than projected. The state treasury department said that in a budget of $20 billion, a $53 million shortage in one month was not significant. State revenue for the first eight months of fiscal year 2001 came to $13 billion, which was $52 million below the expected total. Anne Ruderman

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Feb. 25, about a quest for coffee in Panama, misstated the unit of measurement for the distance between Tocumen International Airport in Panama City and the Marco A. Gelabert Airport at Albrook. It is 25 kilometers (15.5 miles), not 25 miles.

title: Prokofiev and the Might-Have-Beens
description: ALTHOUGH the Metropolitan Opera performance of Sergei Prokofiev's ''Gambler'' under the indefatigable baton of Valery Gergiev tomorrow evening is billed as a Met premiere, New York operagoers with longish memories may recall an earlier production of the work on that prestigious stage. Back in July 1975, it was one of the featured novelties in the Bolshoi Theater's now legendary guest season, dazzlingly staged by Boris Pokrovsky on a set designed by Valery Leventhal, which plotted the whole action on a gigantic metaphorical roulette wheel that seasickeningly revolved at crucial moments.

title: Marlene Hollander, Reid Horovitz
description: Marlene Hollander, the daughter of Beatrice Hollander of Riverdale, the Bronx, and the late Morton Hollander, was married last evening to Reid Horovitz, the son of Marlene Horovitz and Dr. Zola Horovitz of Boca Raton, Fla. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

description: TABLA ***

title: Sports of The Times; As Eagles' Hopes Die, Bell Relives The Finish
description: TROY BELL saw it as a trip home to Minneapolis, not just a trip to the Final Four. All he had to do was keep playing with the same audacious feel.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about the difficulty of improving the accuracy of various kinds of statistics numbers misidentified a county in California that recently spent $14 million for new voting machines. It is Riverside County, not Sequoia.

title: Fine Print; Broadway Brummells
description: You don't hear the word ''bachelor'' much anymore. Despite the divorce rate, we continue to calculate our domestic opportunities with the certain knowledge that two can live more cheaply than one.

title: Givers Unmasked
description: March 8: The Hispanic Federation held its annual awards dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was attended by 900 and raised more than $1 million for the work of the 70 health and human services agencies that make up the federation.

description: Waterston as Lincoln

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUBE, JOSEPH
description: DUBE-Joseph. Park Surgical mourns the loss of one of the original Dube brothers. Loving husband, brother, father, grandfather, great grandfather, uncle and friend. His trusted advice will be sorely missed. Park Surgical

description: To the Editor: We recently traveled with friends and wound up in London. We looked forward to dinner at Gordon Ramsay.

description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York.

title: A.T.M.'s in Japan
description: To the Editor: Regarding the letters about A.T.M.'s abroad (Jan. 21): Finding an A.T.M. in Japan that can be used without an account at a Japanese bank has long been very difficult, even for those of us who can cope with Japanese instructions. The only sure bet in Tokyo has been an A.T.M. at a Citibank office.

title: Colonel's Trial Puts Russian Justice to Test
description: It was late last March 26 that a Russian Army colonel, Yuri D. Budanov, and three soldiers left an encampment outside Chechnya's capital, Grozny, and pointed their armored personnel carrier south into the village of Tangi, then east on to a lane.

title: March 11-17; Battleground: Judges
description: With Bush aides embarked on an intensive search to fill many vacant federal judgeships, the administration has begun moving to end the American Bar Association's longstanding role as a semi-official screening panel for judicial nominees. Conservative Republicans have long complained that the bar association has displayed a liberal bias in evaluating prospective judges.

title: Winning Chenin Blanc
description: Paumanok Vineyards ''owns'' Long Island's chenin blanc franchise. As a longtime fan of this grape's Loire and California styles, I always look forward to Paumanok's newest version. The zesty 2000 is a winner.

title: Lonely at the Top
description: THE MOUNTAINS

title: Thanks, I Needed That: Learning to Like Being Jolted
description: FOR many years, the phrase ''dance theater'' made me want to run as fast as I could in the other direction.

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week
