description: To the Editor:

title: Jonathan Lebed's Extracurricular Activities
description: Of the two, I wonder who was the greater innocent -- Jonathan's bewildered father, Greg Lebed, or the S.E.C. chairman, Arthur Levitt?

title: Cellular Metastasis
description: David Brooks's amusing article on obsessive cell-phone users (Feb. 25) reveals a gap in the English language. We need a word for those who talk on them, conspicuously and excessively, especially in public or while driving. How about ''yappies''?

title: Everything Old Is New Again
description: INVITE Joan Berkey to your house and she'll want to see the basement and the attic first because, as she says, ''that's where a house shows its age.''

title: Like Father, Like Son
description: Had Lamont Wilder been in a divorce court, his child-support payments would have been based on his assets and income, subject to a decrease if they went down or an increase if they went up. To arbitrarily assign him the welfare debt his girlfriend incurred on behalf of his child and then deny him ''a student loan, a regular driver's license or even a real barber's license'' is ensuring his continued impoverishment.

title: Positive Lessons From a Tax Return
description: THE last thing most people would probably want to do after filing their income tax returns is to pull out those documents and study them. But many financial professionals advise their clients to do just that; they see the tax return as a road map for improving your financial condition in the current year.

title: Full-Court Press by Robots, for Engineering
description: AT the driver station behind a glass partition, Steven Ellinghaus and Randy Earle maneuvered their joysticks. On the playing field in front of the Farmingdale High School students, SCAG -- an acronym for Second Chance at Glory -- a robot that looked like an upright vacuum cleaner zipped across the carpet only to get stuck midfield by the dividing rail. Steven and Randy veered SCAG to the right, then the left, unable to move him to the other side. Suddenly, EInstein, a low-slung robot built by the Red Jammers, East Islip High School's robotics team, charged right across the seesawing midfield ramp. As Bryan Prosek worked its remote controls, EInstein grabbed a large neon ball and placed it on a seven-foot goal. Then the robot pushed the goal onto the pivoting bridge, balancing it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STICKNEY, RICHARD WARREN
description: STICKNEY-Richard Warren. 81 years, of Somers, NY, formerly of New Canaan, CT. Husband of Margaret. Brother of John T. Stickney of Honolulu, HI, and Patricia Stickney of NYC. A decorated captain of the US Army during World War II. He was wounded at the Remagen Bridge after being one of the first soldiers to cross it. He received the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart and the Air Medal. Funeral services at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY, Monday, 11 AM. Interment Arlington National Cemetery.

title: Easy Part For Florida Is Playing The Game
description: Last Nov. 1, the Florida basketball players were told to gather at the O'Connell Center on the Gainesville campus. When the locker room doors shut that evening, the Gators realized who was not there: Coach Billy Donovan.

title: Traffic Woes on Eastern Parkway, A 'Highway With Stoplights'
description: A father gripped his son's outstretched arm with his right hand while holding the boy's small red backpack in his left as the two crossed Nostrand Avenue at Eastern Parkway one winter afternoon. The man waited on the median of the intersection as traffic sped along the parkway. When the signal changed to Walk, he proceeded across with his son, looking three times at the stopped traffic to make sure they could cross safely.

title: After a Plane Crash, Celebrating Life
description: IF you survive a plane crash, what happens next looks and sounds a lot like your funeral. People can't believe you are alive, so they do and say the sorts of things usually reserved for occasions too late for you to enjoy. It's wonderful.

title: Expert Advice: Focus on Profit
description: LYNN E. TURNER, the chief accountant at the Securities and Exchange Commission, has a name for the questionable financial figures that are increasingly common in corporate press releases. He calls those announcements that include so-called pro forma numbers that do not tell the whole story to investors ''E.B.S.,'' or ''Everything but Bad Stuff'' releases.

title: Companies at Career Fair Seeking Technology Workers
description: The Westchester Information Technology Cluster and the Westchester County Association will hold a technology career fair on Tuesday from 5 to 8 p.m. at The Landmark at Eastview in Tarrytown.

title: March 11-17; Take That, Jesse Ventura
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger for governor? California Republicans, recalling the political success of another star, are trying to talk the Terminator into running next year. They hope his fame and deep pockets can rebuild a party that has all but self-destructed with infighting over abortion, gun control, the environment and other issues. Meanwhile, Democrats have seized the governor's office, all but one cabinet post, control of the state legislature, both Senate seats and 32 of 52 House seats. Only in Hawaii and Maryland are Democrats more dominant. Mr. Schwarzenegger says he is giving the idea some thought. B. Drummond Ayres Jr.

title: After Seven-Year Siege, An End to Strip Club?
description: AT the Diamond Club, a strip club here, bargain hour runs from 10 to 11 p.m.

title: The Nation; Migrants Take Their Chances on a Harsh Path of Hope
description: THE border between Mexico and the United States has always been semipermeable, and most of the holes have been in or near urban areas along the border. But increased vigilance and improved technology have allowed the United States Border Patrol to establish control of these crossing points. Would-be migrants, who faced risks like homicide and road accidents in urban areas, are now taking their chances along more remote and treacherous parts of the border, and deaths from exposure are rising.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NASH, N. RICHARD
description: NASH-N. Richard. The Nash familyh invites friends of N. Richard Nash to a celebration of his life (1913-2000), Monday, March 26, at 6 PM, at Manhattan Theater Club, 131 West 55th St; for information, 617-547-7377.

title: Julie Sherman, Jason Whitney
description: Dr. Julie Carol Sherman, a daughter of Irene Sherman and Dr. Michael Sherman of Owings Mills, Md., was married last evening to Jason Ryan Whitney, a son of Cheryl Whitney of Freeport, N.Y., and Bruce Whitney of Oceanside, N.Y. Rabbi Mitchell Wohlberg officiated at the Woodholme Country Club in Baltimore.

title: Playing the River Angles, and the Anglers
description: To live in Riverdale has long meant having to view the Hudson River from a distance because of the Metro-North railway tracks, which run along the river.

description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Suspect Sought In China Blasts; Toll Is at 108
description: The death toll in four coordinated explosions that shook a central Chinese city early Friday rose to 108, while the investigation into the blasts has apparently focused on a resident of one of the destroyed buildings who is already wanted for murder.

title: Tropical Punch; FIESTA WEAR
description: It's time to take a break from monochromatic shirts and ties and head for Puerto Rico, where the salsa and merengue rip full tilt until dawn.

title: March 11-17; Uganda Re-elects Leader
description: Yoweri Museveni was re-elected president of Uganda by a landslide, though his victory appeared to come at some cost to his reputation. The man who brought Uganda, with its singularly violent history, back to peace was accused of running a campaign of low-level violence and harassment. His opponent, Kizza Besigye, once Mr. Museveni's doctor, said the voting itself was rigged and has called for a new election. Independent monitors said some manipulation was likely, but not enough to change Mr. Museveni's win. Ian Fisher

title: New Smoking Law Will Leave Workers Gasping
description: To the Editor:

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Chances of a Lifetime By Warren Christopher. Lisa Drew/Scribner, $26.

title: A Million Nods to the Emerald Isle's Soul
description: Green carnations sprouted from men's chests, painted shamrocks adorned women's cheeks and a dog or three wore green kerchiefs as a million or so people lined Fifth Avenue yesterday to watch 200,000 marchers celebrate New York City's 240th annual St. Patrick's Day parade.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF there's a moral in Pedro Almodovar's ALL ABOUT MY MOTHER (1999), which won the best foreign film Oscar, it's that you can't judge a single mom by her cover. The film begins with tragedy. On his 17th birthday, Manuela's son Esteban (Eloy Azorin) is hit by a car and killed while trying to get an actress's autograph. Three weeks Madrid for Barcelona to look for Esteban's father. This leads her to, among others things, a reunion with an old transvestite-hooker friend and a job as a famous stage actress's personal assistant. Both ''All About Eve'' and ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' play important roles in Manuela's story. And who's that radiantly beautiful, young, pregnant non? Penelope Cruz. Proving once again what an eye Mr. Almodovar has for star presence -- Tuesday at 10 p.m. on Cinemax.

title: RACETRACK CONVERSION
description: The Garden State Park racetrack in Cherry Hill will be converted into a $500 million housing, office and retail center. Realen Properties of Berwyn, Pa. plans to put up 1,500 town houses, a million-square-foot corporate center, retail and restaurant space and parking garages on the 220-acre property, which will continue to be known as Garden State Park. Half the town houses will be designated for the elderly, holding down potential student population that would tax the local school system. Garden State Park, which opened as a racetrack in 1942, will hold its last thoroughbred racing season starting next month. Robert Strauss

title: Habitats/Colts Neck, N.J.; After Day in Penn Station, Home to Horse Country
description: EVERY weekday morning, Tommy Michos leaves his new eight-bedroom house with the dolphin fountain in front and takes the train to Penn Station. While the other commuters run off to catch cabs or subways, Mr. Michos never leaves the station. He spends the day there, working in his three restaurants.

title: Love, Loneliness and Jerry Lewis
description: MY father often returned from work near midnight. He turned on the hall light and came to sit at the edge of my bed. I pretended for a time to be asleep, and he pretended to think I was. He called me a kidder and we laughed. He turned the covers from my legs and placed a hand on the bottom of one foot and then the other -- measuring my bones.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PETERSON, MARION A.
description: PETERSON-Marion A. 79, formerly of West Nyack, NY. Died on March 16, 2001. She was predeceased by her husband Richard J. Peterson in 1999. She is survived by three sons, Richard Peterson of Falls Church, VA, Charles Peterson of Pittsburgh, PA, and Robert Peterson of Scotch Plains, NJ; eight grandchildren; one sister, Kathleen Sussingham; three brothers, Frank, Gerald and Joseph Cohane. Reposing Hawthorne Funeral Home, 21 Stevens Ave., Hawthorne, NY, Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral mass Monday, 12 noon, St. Francis of Assisi Chapel at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Interment following. In lieu of flowers, donations in her memory to St. Anthony's Church, Nanuet, NY.

title: A Push To Unplug D.C. Power
description: FOR most people, direct current (D.C.) comes from batteries, and alternating current (A.C.) is usually supplied by energy companies that distribute it over power grids to homes and businesses. But D.C. power is actually still delivered to thousands of buildings in Manhattan to run things like elevators and water pumps designed before A.C. became readily available in the late 1920's.

title: H. Gordon Skilling, 89, Expert on Czechoslovakia
description: H. Gordon Skilling, a Canadian expert on Czechoslovakia who aided and encouraged dissidents there when it was a Communist state, died on March 2 at his home in Toronto. He was 89.

title: The Flavors of Turkey at a Bargain
description: FRESH ingredients, bold flavors, home-style cooking, a small, simple menu, astonishingly low prices and no credit cards make the new Kebabi Musiki Professional Kebab House, at 1844 Deer Park Avenue in Deer Park (631-586-7750), the most Turkish and genuinely ethnic spot on the Island. Its owner Orhan Yegen told us, ''I cook Turkish food the way it's done in Turkey, the best it can be.'' (The music on Saturday nights is more of the same, the real thing.)

title: Losing Her Sight But Not Her Vision
description: MURIEL HARRIS knows her colors by heart, but no longer by sight without a little help. In the basement studio of her home here, big numbers and words on a flip chart correspond to big tabs dangling from tubes of acrylic paint. No. 45, for example, is iridescent gold.

title: Vanessa Low, Eric Mendelson
description: Vanessa Thea Low, the daughter of Cynthia and Stanley Low of Cresskill, N.J., was married yesterday evening to Eric Craig Mendelson, the son of Susan and Herbert Mendelson of Carle Place, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Alder officiated at the University Club in New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZELTNER, EDYTHE M.
description: ZELTNER-Edythe M. On March 16, 2001 at age 83. Beloved wife of the late Paul. Loving mother of Ina, Richard, Peter and Molli. Adoring grandmother of nine and great-grandmother of one. Dear mother-in-law of Diana, Linda and Willem. Devoted sister of Herbert and Edgar. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, March 18, 11:30 AM. Interment Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Crohn's and Colitis Foundation of America, Inc., 386 Park Avenue South, NY NY.

title: Josephine Hull
description: To the Editor:

title: Blind Spot
description: FOR many subway riders an underground run is sheer, unadulterated fun, whether they're heading for work, the dentist or a movie. For 65 years, I have been one of them. And one of the greatest pleasures of our subway ride, the front window, is going the way of the rattan seat.

title: Lack of Parking Helps Keep Co-op Prices Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Norway Rallies To Beat U.S. Women
description: Norway scored three unanswered goals in the final 17 minutes, all after their star midfielder Hege Riise had entered the match, coming from two goals down to defeat the United States women, 4-3, in the fifth-place match at the Algarve Cup in Quarteira, Portugal.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TICINETO, JOSEPHINE C.
description: TICINETO - Josephine C. On March 16, 2001. Beloved wife of Felix. Loving mother of Virginia Steppe and Patricia T. Clough. Devoted grandmother of Daniel Steppe, Alissa and Kevin Maples and Christopher Clough. Beloved brother of Paul Travia. Fond great-grandmother of Anabelle Maples. Reposing at the Harden Funeral Home of Bayside, Northern Blvd. at 209th St. Funeral mass Monday, 10:00 AM, Mary's Nativity R.C. Church. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery.

title: Plunge in Stocks Colors Debate on Size of Fed Rate Cut
description: The Federal Reserve will meet tomorrow to decide how much to cut interest rates in an effort to revive the economy just when a falling stock market seems to have the power to bring on a recession.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REIFEISS, BRUCE C.
description: REIFEISS-Bruce C. Of Marco Island, FL, formerly of Dallas, TX, and Westchester County, NY. Director of Real Estate Research Planning and Development for JC Penney Co. Survived by his wife Monica, his children Christopher, Kirsten and Jeffrey, his brother Robert and his wife Mary Reifeiss. Funeral Tuesday, 12 noon, at the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home, 2 Maple Ave., White Plains, NY. Interment Kensico Cemetery. Friends may call at the funeral home Monday evening, 5-9 PM. Memorial contributions to Hospice of Naples, 1095 Whippoorwill Lane, Naples, FL 34105; or Marco Lutheran Church Building Fund, 525 North Collier Blvd., Marco Island, FL 34145.

title: State Considers Fingerprinting Teachers
description: HE's been teaching for 26 years, but Robert Austin said he wouldn't hesitate to submit to fingerprinting and extensive checks of his background to determine whether he is fit to be trusted with working in a public school.

title: Age of Unreason; GRAYBOY
description: Recently, I found myself in the checkout line at Urban Outfitters, waiting to pay for a pair of combat fatigue cargo pants, when I noticed something very unsettling. There among the chain wallets and pleather wristbands, peeking out from just above the second button of my opened shirt, was a gray chest hair. And with lightning clarity the following realization came to me: If you are old enough to have a gray chest hair, you're probably too old to be shopping at Urban Outfitters.

title: The Orchestra's Field Marshal
description: THE rituals of a symphony orchestra concert soothe like Grandmother's mint tea. As the audience awaits the music amid the cacophony of players tuning up, the house lights dim and the concertmaster emerges from the wings. The unknowing assume he is the conductor, and join in the polite applause.

title: Going Back for Seconds and Feeling Content
description: TIME out for one of our periodic visits to restaurants we have enjoyed in the past. Revisiting seems opportune if a chef has left or if a restaurant has changed hands or menu.

title: Therapy for Dot-Com Survivors
description: 'HI, I'm Jen, and I'm an entrepreneur. I work 72 hours a week.'' Pause. ''Sometimes I feel totally, utterly alone, like I'm on a rickety old bridge connecting huge gorges in an Indiana Jones movie. It's nice to know there are other people out there who feel the same way I do.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZ, HAROLD
description: HERTZ-Harold. Survived by Sally, his loving wife of 55 years; devoted father of Robert, Madeline, William and son-in-law Vincent Gagliardi and devoted grandfather of Eric, Bryan, Kevin, Corey, David, Justin and Daniel, and greatgrandfather of Rain. Our loving memories of his warmth, love and passion for living will help to sustain us. Memorial on Friday, March 23rd, 10:00AM at: Inn of Great Neck, 30 Cutter Mill Road, Great Neck, NY 516-773-2000.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Warp and Woof Of Identity Politics for Pets
description: BERKELEY is famous for pet causes. So it's probably not surprising that this city -- home of The Bark, a magazine on modern dog culture -- recently adopted an ordinance in which pet owners are officially no longer pet owners but pet owner/ guardians.

title: POSTINGS: First Major Residential Conversion in 15 Years; Rentals for Downtown Newark
description: After sitting vacant for a decade, one of Newark's big old office buildings is to be turned into rental apartments, providing the city's downtown with its first major residential conversion in 15 years.

title: Mr. Corzine's Broken Promise
description: Senator Jon Corzine's membership on the Senate Banking Committee gives the freshman New Jersey Democrat a chance to protect vital interests of his state and the Northeast region. But it also puts Mr. Corzine in a position to shape important legislation affecting Goldman Sachs, the big financial company he once headed and in which he still holds shares valued at close to $300 million. Mr. Corzine should be taking decisive steps to address an obvious conflict-of-interest problem, by either transferring to another Senate committee or, preferably, speeding up his divestiture of Goldman stock.

title: Thank You, 'Saturday Night Live,' for Firing Me
description: PEOPLE who know the events of the Bay of Pigs will not be surprised to read that when Peter Askin and I decided to write a movie about it, we made it a farce. In fact, it was always our hope that Paramount would advertise the film with the line, ''At last! A comedy about the Bay of Pigs.''

title: 3 Students Beaten In New Jersey Dorm
description: A student has been arrested in connection with a bloody Friday night attack on three fellow students at Monmouth University in West Long Branch, N.J., officials said. The victims were attacked in a dormitory room by about a dozen men armed with a hammer, a rod with a metal ball and the car anti-theft device known as ''the Club.''.

title: The Post-Sharpton Sharpton
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton was wandering the halls of the Dirksen Senate Office Building in Washington, his hair combed neatly behind his ears, a three-piece, pinstriped suit hanging loosely from his bulbous frame, a cell phone to one ear and an aide at his back. This was a hearing day for President Bush's cabinet nominees on Capitol Hill, so the halls of the Congressional office buildings were bustling with television crews and reporters, which Sharpton had anticipated, and they all rushed over as soon as they saw him, which Sharpton had also anticipated. Another news conference done, this one denouncing John Ashcroft's nomination to be attorney general, Sharpton turned back up the hallway when he, quite unexpectedly, found himself chest to chest with Gen. Colin L. Powell, there for his confirmation hearings to become the nation's first black secretary of state.

title: Private Sector; Building a Bridge on the Fairway
description: At first glance it might seem curious that former President George Bush would attend an event honoring Jackson T. Stephens, the biggest Democratic power broker in Bill Clinton's home state. But Mr. Stephens, a self-made billionaire investment banker and philanthropist, is financing a cause that transcends politics: golf.

title: Ambitious Dogs Get More Than a Walk
description: BIANCA LAPORTA is always looking for spare plumbing parts, sawhorses and dryer exhaust funnels. The treasures she finds have an unlikely destination. She uses them to build obstacle courses for dog agility competitions.

title: Finding A Tranquil Side of Capri
description: ON our first morning in Capri, I stepped onto our sunny terrace, looked beyond our yellow-splashed lemon tree to a blue-green sea, and immediately felt as if I had stepped into a frame of ''Enchanted April.'' In this 1992 fairy-tale movie, several unhappy, chilled Englishwomen, fleeing the rainy gloom of London, open the shutters of their Italian villa to an astonishing flood of sunlight and lush greenness. The promise of romance floats in the air almost as tangibly as the lacy swaths of wisteria.

title: From Miami, Memorable Food and Prices
description: NEW YORK, San Francisco and New Orleans have long been at the center of America's culinary world. Now, a number of other cities share that distinction. One of the rising stars is Miami, with its explosive nuevo Latino cuisine. Miami Grand, a creative new restaurant in Rockville Centre, could make waves even among the trendsetters in Miami's South Beach.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the International Datebook listing on March 4, about an underwater Easter egg hunt in Destin, Fla., has become outdated. The sponsor has gone out of business, and the event, scheduled for April 14, will not be held.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  POTTER, HAROLD (HAL)
description: POTTER-Harold (Hal). January 23, 1932 to March 17, 1992. Remembered with love every day. Joyce, Seth, Robert, and Warren

title: Aspen Mountain: A Holdout No Longer
description: Snowboarders will take their place alongside skiers on Aspen Mountain in Colorado on April 1. That is the day the resort, one of the few holdouts in the United States, ends its ban. At the same time, adult lift tickets will be reduced to $29 from $65 a day between March 31 and April 22; there is a minimum purchase of two days' worth of tickets, and they must be ordered by Thursday. During this period, called Spring Jam, the ski area will also offer live music and D.J.'s at outdoor aprs-ski parties.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-18-01; What They Were Thinking: The Day After
description: A portfolio of images taken outside Santana High School in Santee, Calif., on March 6, the day after Charles Andrew Williams opened fire, killing two and wounding 13 others.

title: Behind the Big Numbers, a Million Little Stories
description: THE 2000 census hangs numbers on what many New Yorkers already know from the streets: the pulse of the city, and perhaps its future, lies in the boroughs outside Manhattan.

title: BEHIND THE WHEEL/2002 Ford Explorer; Once a Truck, Always a Truck
description: HIGH, wide and rugged, big sport utility vehicles seem invincible. But their vulnerability became all too obvious last month when my family and I left our retreat in the Sierra Nevada foothills to head up Interstate 80 for a day of skiing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCCUTCHEN, RICHARD J. ''DICK''
description: McCUTCHEN-Richard J. ''Dick'' of Clinton, CT. At age 76, of 24 Partridge Lane died March 3, 2001. He was the husband of Gerda Mahncke McCutchen. Known professionally as ''Dick McCutchen'' he was a writer/producer of television news and award winning documentaries, including an Emmy nomination in 1967. He worked at all major television networks and also produced films for the March of Dimes and the Save the Children Foundation. He retired in 1991, moved to Clinton, Connecticut with his wife of 50 years. He was born in Tarrytown, New York, March 1, 1925, a son of the late Clarence and Lillian E. Johnson McCutchen. He leaves in addition to his wife a daughter Mrs. Matthew J. (Kim C.) Haudenschield of New York, a brother John McCutchen of Milford, CT. and a granddaughter Julia T. Haudenschield. He was predeceased by a daughter Susan Amy McCutchen. A memorial service will be held Saturday, March 31, 2001, 11 AM at the United Methodist Church in Mamaroneck, New York. For information contact Oak Grove Cremation Service, West Haven, CT.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Individual investors got hooked on equities. It went too far, and they came to think that equities were riskless.''

title: Satyrs, Slaves And Monsters In the Colors Of Childhood
description: THE childhood activity of coloring is beneath notice for most artists, but not for John Bankston, whose paintings and drawings evoke a world of cyberfiction, slave narratives, fairy tales and leather-bar fantasies played out inside the lines of a coloring book.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERTRAM, PAULINE MEAGHER
description: BERTRAM-Pauline Meagher. On Saturday, March 3, 2001 of Vero Beach, FL. Born in Greenwich, CT. June 27, 1927. Member of Riomar Bay Yacht Club. Devoted mother of Anne Bertram Endler, Caroline Bolling Bertram, Morgan Bertram, Colin Bertram, Digby Bertram and Madelaine Bertram Osborne. Also survived by brother Richard Hayes Meagher, nieces and nephews Elizabeth Meagher Bartram, Susan Smithers Dukehart, Pauline Rice, Dorothy Meagher, Marcia Meagher, Richard Meagher, and a great niece and great nephew. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Lung Association and the Humane Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, MAURICE JOHN, COLONEL, U.S.A.R. (RET.)
description: WARD-Maurice John, Colonel, U.S.A.R. (Ret.). Died peacefully in his sleep early Saturday morning, March 17. Born in Donegal, Ireland. He came to this country as a young man. He served as an officer in the Corps of Engineers in the European theater in World War II, and was on active duty during the Korean War. He graduated from Command and General Staff College at Fort Leavenworth, Kansas. He was a professional engineer with a B.S. and M.S. degrees from Columbia School of Engineering. He was with NASA, private industry and later with the Small Business Administration. He is survived by his wife Evelyn. Beloved brother of Dr. Joseph, Patrick, and Maureen Micek, and thirteen nieces and nephews. His brother Raymond predeceased him. We will always remember his quiet strength and gentle manner. Viewing at Fred McGrath's in Bronxville, Monday, 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Joseph's Church, Tuesday, 11 AM, followed by interment at Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Contributions to a charity of your choice would be appreciated.

title: Samuel Shapiro; Business Executive, 83
description: Samuel Shapiro, who presided over a company that responded to the fast-food appetite of consumers by churning out containers for Big Macs at McDonald's, popcorn at movie theaters and Hagen-Dazs ice cream at supermarkets, died on March 8 at a hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 83.

title: Article 2001031891591531034 -- No Title
description: March 16, 2001

title: Walking the Chickens
description: HERE'S TO YOU, JESUSA!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAVITZKY, EDITH
description: SAVITZKY-Edith. Of Lake Worth, FL and New Hyde Park, NY. Died March 16. Beloved wife of Abraham Savitzky. Born in New York City, her love of husband, children and grandchildren was the center of her life. Choosing family over a promising opera career, she enriched the lives of all who knew her by her beautiful singing, quick wit, ready humor, her deep compassion and understanding. She is survived by son Robert, daughter Judy Roth and grandchildren Gregory Travis and Diana, Amanda and Steven Savitzky. Services to be held at Sinai Chapel, 12 noon Monday at 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadow, NY. She will live in our hearts forever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RETTER, BETTY
description: RETTER-Betty. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a widely respected member of the Jewish community, beloved wife of Marcus; mother of Daniel, Alan, and David; and sister of Lea (and Leon) Eisenberg, YU Guardians; Mary Schreiber; and Margot Pollak. Mrs. Eisenberg, honorary Board chairman of our Stern College for Women, was founding secretary of the Board and served as vice chairman and chairman. We extend our heartfelt condolences as well to grandchildren, great-grandchildren and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Robert M. Beren, Chairman, Board of Trustees Yeshiva University

title: The Ties That Bind New York To Wall St.; Roiling Market Revives Debate Over Economy
description: Stock market meltdowns have a lot of unpleasant consequences: fortunes lost, retirements ruined, college funds flattened, stock brokers unemployed. But for New Yorkers, there's another, annoying one: political posturing.

title: The Future Won't Be As Good As It Was
description: TRILLIONS of dollars in household wealth has vanished in the sickening stock market fall of the past year. College education funds have been pounded and plans for early retirements probably pushed back as a result. But apart from some finger-pointing and gallows humor in investing chat rooms, investors seem commendably stalwart about the pain they have endured in this bear market, the worst in Nasdaq's history.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAULE, QUENTIN
description: MAULE-Quentin. Yes, I most certainly do love and cherish you always with all my heart and soul. Your David

title: Article 2001031891481179488 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: DataBank; Bear Market Becomes a Reality
description: The bear is out of hibernation.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: WAY OUT THERE IN THE BLUE: Reagan, Star Wars and the End of the Cold War, by Frances FitzGerald. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $17.) This account of Ronald Reagan's hugely expensive Strategic Defense Initiative, chosen by the editors of the Book Review as one of the best books of 2000, is both a journey into the politics and technology of nuclear diplomacy and a withering inner history of the Reagan administration. The kicker is that the dream of an antimissile defense system still has life today. The author ''clearly, eloquently and engagingly'' describes ''obscure and complicated events,'' Alan Brinkley wrote in these pages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, FRANKLIN D.
description: ROSENBLATT-Franklin D. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Lief, loving father-inlaw of the late Melinda, adoring grandfather of Andre Charles who knew him as Pop Pop, and dear brother of Arthur, died on March 16, 2001. Born in Riverdale to the late Harry and Helen Rosenblatt, he was raised in Brooklyn. He studied nine years at night while holding two jobs to become a civil engineer in his own firm, and was noted for many innovative structural achievements including the design of the Venezuelan Pavilion at the 1965 New York World's Fair. A caring person who helped many others, always without fanfare, he was a true humanitarian. This special man will be sorely missed and fondly remembered by his family, his friends from his school days, and his friends from both the Berkshires and New York City. Service Monday, 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Business Diary: Big Blue's 2000 Report Offers a Novel Account
description: Figuring the average investor would rather curl up with a good book than an annual report, I.B.M.'s corporate communications team and its outside consultants decided to cast Big Blue's Year 2000 report as a "no-holds-barred story of one year in the life of a company."

title: In Yonkers, Authentic Chinese Cuisine
description: A RESPECT for culinary innovation has long been part of cultural tradition in China. In this respect then, Hunan Village offers authentic Chinese cuisine. It was the first of the county's Chinese restaurants to break from the ubiquitous cornstarch-thickened-canned-vegetable school of cooking and to offer, instead, unusual dishes that excite the palate. We welcome the too few other restaurants that have followed suit, and are equally pleased to report that Hunan Village still ranks high among them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, BENJAMIN A.
description: COOK-Benjamin A. On March 16, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Fay Moss Cook. Brother of Edy Barron of Pembrook Pines, FL, brother of the late Joseph and Jack. Uncle, great-uncle and great-great-uncle. He lived his life the way he wanted to and his trademark was eloquence. WWII veteran, North African Campaign, and member of the Masons. Longtime resident and merchant of Lynbrook, LI. Graveside service today, 2:30 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY.

title: Private Sector; A Lawyer's Dot.Com Self-Defense
description: Robert Shapiro, one of O. J. Simpson's defense lawyers, has gone from high-profile criminal litigation to high-technology document production.

title: Slinky Inky Jeans
description: Recently, Marc Jacobs declared Sofia Coppola his muse. Not entirely shocking news, considering that Ms. Coppola, filmmaker, photographer, sometime model and daughter of Francis Ford Coppola, had posed in advertisements for his handbags. At a show of his Marc line last month, the designer's paean to Ms. Coppola was a pair of blue jeans customized by Geoff McFetridge, the graphic artist who designed the distinctive handwritten titles for Ms. Coppola's 1999 film ''The Virgin Suicides.'' For the Marc jeans, Mr. McFetridge, 29, used a simple ballpoint pen to make doodles of mushrooms and other motifs and to write phrases that evoke the evanescence of a teenage crush, like ''I Love Bobby'' with the name crossed out. The drawings are upside down -- as if they had been absent-mindedly added by the wearer in, say, fifth-period detention.

title: March 11-17; U.S. Bans European Meat
description: After foot-and-mouth disease had spread from Britain to France, the United States banned meat and animal products from the European Union. Agriculture officials were quick to soften the blow: favored imports, like most cheeses and cured hams, are exempt, since they are prepared in a way that kills the virus. As American officials stepped up vigilance at ports of entry, some European farmers complained of a double-whammy: their beef is already outlawed here because of mad cow disease. Christopher Marquis

title: Personal Business; 529: Advanced College Savings Plans for Families
description: WITH five children ranging in age from 2 to 12 and a $380,000 mortgage, Peter and Lisa Fatianow of Highlands Ranch, Colo., would seem hard-pressed to stay on top of their monthly bills, let alone set aside money for college.

title: Letters
description: RUSSELL CROWE

title: Up Riverside, Trump's Road Goes; Where It Stops, Nobody Knows
description: The freshly laid road to Trump Place now runs from 67th to 70th Streets, but where it will end up is anyone's guess. Worried about traffic congestion, local officials, community groups and the Trump Organization are wrangling over the options.

title: History and Predictions On Initial Stock Offers
description: BOTH good and bad news emerges from a historical review of the market cycle as it relates to initial public offerings.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAYLOR, GUY
description: TAYLOR-Guy, 1919-2001. Age 81, a widely known symphony conductor, died in Edmonds, Washington on March 5th, 2001. Formerly music director of the Nashville Symphony, the Phoenix Symphony, and the Fresno Philharmonic Orchestras, his work was instrumental in bringing those organizations to the major, or near-major, status they now hold. As a guest conductor, he appeared in every region of the United States as well as in Canada, Mexico, Puerto Rico, the Philippines, Great Britain, Germany and Czechoslovakia. Mr. Taylor retired to Edmonds in 1989, where he has written two books -a comprehensive family history and a book of professional memoirs. Mr. Taylor was trained principally at the Juilliard School of Music in New York, where he was married in 1947 to a fellow student, pianist Renee Lifton. Other training included private study, classes and symposia with Dimitri Mitropoulos, Eugene Ormandy, Pierre Monteux and George Szell. His early studies were as a violinist with Ottokar Cadek in his native Alabama. In addition to his wife, Renee, Mr. Taylor is survived by a son, Eric Taylor, of Stockton, California, and a daughter, Ellen Taylor, of Seattle, Washington; two granddaughters, Megan Taylor of Stockton and Hannah Dalglish of Seattle; and three step-grandchildren, John Taylor of Stockton, Pablo Dalglish of Seattle, and Gabriel Dalglish of Sao Paulo, Brazil.

title: Healing From Executive Trauma
description: Any company that wants money from Evercore Partners had best pass Rick Thoman's three-part test: Its culture must not require quick, extensive change. It must not be in the throes of upgrading 20th century products for 21st century uses. And, there must be no vagueness whatsoever about management's roles and responsibilities.

title: A Visionary Who Put The English on Toe
description: THE Royal Ballet was anything but royal at its beginnings in 1931, when Dame Ninette de Valois, who had not always been Ninette de Valois and who was not yet a Dame, presented a small group of dancers at a people's theater in London.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 25 about living in West Harlem referred incompletely to the area's school jurisdiction. Community District 5 covers only part of the area; most of it is within District 6. In addition, the boundaries for West Harlem shown on the map with the article differed from those in the text. The map should have shown the southern boundary as 132nd Street, not 135th, and the northern edge as 153rd Street, not 155th.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDOUX, LOUIS PIERRE
description: LEDOUX-Louis Pierre. On March 17, 2001, 88 years. Born August 1, 1912, in Cornwall-on-Hudson, NY. He graduated from Gunnery School in Washington, CT, and Harvard, Class of 1935. He was President of the family company, Ledoux and Co., a metalurgical laboratory. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Joan F. Ledoux, and his daughter Jeanne-Nicole Ledoux. The funeral will be in Cornwall-on-Hudson; details will be announced.

title: Trying to Explain the Male Psyche
description: WHILE coaching his son's second-grade soccer team during a game here two years ago, Alon Gratch learned quite a bit about himself. His son's team was losing and his son Jordan, then 8, began to cry.

title: In the Region/Connecticut; Corporate Shift to Close Stamford's Whitney Branch
description: UNLESS a band of angels with deep pockets appears before March 31, the 20-year-old Stamford branch of the Manhattan-based Whitney Museum of American Art will close for lack of funds -- a serious setback for a city that has labored to create an urbane cultural image.

title: Lives; Jet Set and Match
description: There are quite a few things that did not necessarily make it into the 21st century. One of them is the Concorde. The other, undoubtedly, is the playboy -- the difference between the former and the latter being that the former is far more likely to make a successful comeback. Yes, that suave, perma-tanned guy who regards the pursuit of women, the driving of Ferraris and the playing of polo as an occupation in itself, that immaculately groomed, trilingual charmer who has all his Hilditch & Key shirts sewn to his underwear (for a smooth crotch-to-waist line) and who never ever gets up before midday, yes, that guy, I'm afraid, has all but been driven into extinction.

title: To Our Readers
description: Starting next week, the suggested newsstand price of The Times on Sundays will increase to $3 in the New York region. The change reflects increased costs of paper, production and distribution. Monday through Saturday prices are unaffected.

title: A Bright Blend From Oregon
description: Blend chardonnay, gewrztraminer, Mller-Thurgau, muscat canelli, pinot blanc, pinot gris, smillon, sylvaner and white riesling, and what emerges?

title: Food; Accidental Lamb
description: In the small upstate town where I live on the weekends, the people who work tend to work several jobs. The librarian who issued me a copy of ''Spoon River Anthology'' on a recent morning, for example, called me to report trail conditions while working for the park service in the afternoon. Later that evening, she took my dinner order at the town tavern. She is also a correspondent for the nearest newspaper, a weekly that is published in the flatlands, 15 miles down the winding western face of our town on the hill.

description: Best Bet

description: I was reminded of a Garrison Keillor radio skit in which he said that cellular phones are less about communication than about ''announcing one's progress through the world.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOGAN, CATHERINE MARIA SR.
description: LOGAN-Catherine Maria Sr. Sister Catherine Maria Logan, beloved member of the Sisters of Charity, died Thursday, March 15, 2001. Survived by her nephews. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark Street, Yonkers, NY on Sunday from 1 to 8 p.m. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 9:30a.m. at the convent with interment following at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471

title: A Chill in the Water to Greet Trout Fishermen
description: New York State's trout season opens April 1 and it looks as if stream conditions will be far from ideal in many areas. That will not deter those hardcore anglers who will stand waist deep in frigid water for hours to take part in a ritual that also celebrates winter's demise.

title: Footnotes
description: Resources, references and the back story behind the story.

description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

description: At first glance it might seem curious that former President George Bush would attend an event honoring Jackson T. Stephens, the biggest Democratic power broker in Bill Clinton's home state. But Mr. Stephens, a self-made billionaire investment banker and philanthropist, is financing a cause that transcends politics: golf.

title: Jennifer Bell, Steven Fishman
description: Jennifer Ann Bell, a daughter of Gloria and Sanford Bell of Bloomfield, N.J., is to be married today to Dr. Steven Jay Fishman, a son of Judy and Joel Fishman of Liberty, N.Y. Rabbi Charles Davidson will officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Students Take On Whooshing Traffic
description: Every year for as long as Aria Grillo can remember, children and cars have collided at the same time of day -- just after 11 a.m. -- and in the same spot, West 17th Street, outside the New York City Lab School between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. The first incident she saw as a seventh grader in 1995.

title: QUICK BITE/Jamesburg; Giant Pancakes and Warm Welcomes
description: The arrow pointing south at Railroad Avenue and Willow Street in Jamesburg points southward away from the downtown area. It also points right to Lisco's Country Cafe, just a few feet away. The four-year-old cafe is run by John Lisco, from Jersey City, who had been a truck driver for 25 years, and his wife, Patti, a former restaurant employee and a Jamesburg native. Each of the 16 tables in the cafe is decorated with a floral arrangement, and the menu offers breakfast and sandwiches; the specialty is ''giant pancakes,'' 10 inches in diameter. On the walls or on tables of their own are items like plaques, handmade dolls and embroidery. Mrs. Lisco calls them crafts -- and she should know: she made many of them herself. Some are there for show, others for sale, none more than $4 or $5 (sometimes less, for children who need something for Mom). On a recent Saturday morning, Mrs. Lisco jumped up to hug and kiss customers, many of them regulars from the array of communities for the elderly that dot the area. As the sole cook, John Lisco spends most of his time at the open grill, with sporadic forays over to the cash register, as his wife hops from table to table, laughing, joking and kibbitzing. ''We want to make them feel like they're home,'' said Mr. Lisco. One of the ways they do it is by taking pictures of guests and mailing them on. Some visitors say Lisco's is reminiscent of someplace else. Like Laurie Brickman from Westchester County, who said, ''This reminds me of so many little places in Vermont.'' But who needs New England when you've got New Jersey? Norm Oshrin

title: Article 2001031891806218129 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: On the Edge of a Time Gone By
description: WITH an abrupt jog to the left, the trail climbed out of a gray-green olive grove and opened onto a staggering expanse of steep, rugged coastline and turquoise sea. Moments before, the footwide stone path had been benign and well behaved. Now it flung itself into thin air, following a cliff-side ledge a hundred feet above hard surf. I flattened my body against solid mountain and tried to reckon with the roiling ocean crashing recklessly onto the jagged rocks below.

title: SOAPBOX; The 20-Year Itch
description: TWENTY years ago a new President preached tax-cutting as though it were religion, got what he wanted and had -- among other things -- a direct impact on the race for governor of New Jersey. We can only hope history doesn't repeat itself.

title: A Red Sets a Standard
description: Louis Jadot sets a high standard for Beaujolais shippers, as its fleshy '99 Chteau des Jacques Moulin--Vent shows. When decanted 24 hours before serving, this reserved red strikingly reflects its granite and manganese vineyard.

title: Colleagues in the 70's, Lawyers Reunite at Firm
description: In the late 1970's, Ann Galvani helped David Boies successfully defend I.B.M. in antitrust proceedings. This month, she again joins forces with Mr. Boies as a member of his Armonk law firm, Boies, Schiller & Flexner.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for JOHN F. WELCH JR.; Dominate Markets, But Cast a Wide Net
description: MORE than 15 years ago, John F. Welch Jr., the General Electric Company's chairman, came up with a then-radical idea: If you don't have a shot at being No. 1 or No. 2 in your business, get out. It was the reason he sold G.E.'s mining and housewares businesses and strengthened its financial businesses. And it helped turn G.E. into a profit powerhouse.

title: So, What Now for Investors?
description: In Money & Business today, eight stock market experts look ahead and offer advice to investors; in the Week in Review, a look back at the financial lessons of the last decade.

title: Devils Complete Comeback in Overtime, Extending Winning Streak to 10 Games
description: Two streaks collided in the northwestern outpost of the National Hockey League tonight and only one of them survived, at least partly. On great ice, in a sophisticated hockey city, before an audience that appreciated almost everything except the conclusion, the Devils rallied for a 6-5 victory in overtime over the Edmonton Oilers.

title: Dina Weiss, Scott Linfoot
description: Dr. Dina Ellen Weiss, the daughter of Sharon and Allen Weiss of Hauppauge, N.Y., was married last evening in Bethpage, N.Y., to David Scott Linfoot, the son of Joyce and David Linfoot of Dundas, Ontario. Rabbi Howard Buechler officiated at Carlyle on the Green, a restaurant in Bethpage State Park.

title: F.C.C. Rejects Plea By Viacom to Drop Limit on Audience
description: Viacom Inc. has lost a bid to suspend rules limiting a broadcaster to 35 percent of United States viewers through its own television stations, a restriction the company exceeds and must meet by May 4.

title: For American Indians, a Common Classification
description: AREPORT by the United States Department of Education shows that, despite a steady decline in the number of Connecticut students in special education, the state still ranks among the top in the nation for the percentage of American Indian children in such programs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, DAVID
description: SCHNEIDER-David. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of David Schneider, associated with The Times from 1967 until 1982.

title: Williams's Production Is Worth The Wait
description: A hitter's head is littered with thought, drawn from dog-eared pages of mental notes. He knows from scouting reports what the pitcher likes to throw, what the pitcher wants to throw when he is ahead in the count, or behind in the count. He remembers what the pitcher threw the last time they faced each other -- was it back in June? -- maybe a backdoor slider that nipped the outside corner for strike three.

title: A Message, but No Admission Fee
description: Growing up on the streets of Trenton in the 1960's helped the Christian entertainer now known only as Carman (his last name was Licciardello) develop an aggressive, no-nonsense attitude. That attitude, sharpened by a couple of years at the Bordentown Military Institute, has led him to challenge the music industry by staging concert extravaganzas in large arenas where he lets everyone in free. His current tour takes him to Madison Square Garden in Manhattan Thursday. He also stars in a movie, ''Heart of a Champion,'' about a boxing minister, which he produced and directed, and has issued an album with old hits and new songs. He calls it all ''one massive evangelistic outreach.'' Of his free concerts, Carman said, ''Does a pastor charge a person to come to church on Sunday?'' Karen DeMasters

title: Gyula Obersovszky, Samizdat Star, Dies at 74
description: Gyula Obersovszky, a Hungarian writer and journalist who was prominent in the 1956 revolt against Soviet forces and became an early practitioner of the underground writings known as samizdat, died on Thursday in a Budapest hospital. He was 74, and was being treated for a heart ailment.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH/Christina Perrin; Friends of a Fashion
description: THE thermostat must have been turned up Tuesday night at Boughalem, a little bistro on Bedford Street. ''Oh, you are so hot!'' the actress Mariska Hargitay told Christina Perrin, a designer of sexy, often sequined, women's wear.

title: Bad Times for I.P.O. Funds
description: Mutual funds that invest in initial public offerings seemed like a good idea a few years ago when the I.P.O. market gilded companies that were barely more than bullet points on a napkin. Now the glint has gone.

title: CELL PHONES AND DRIVING
description: A majority of New Jerseyans would back a ban on the use of hand-held cell phones while driving, according to a Quinnipiac University poll released last week. Eighty-six percent of registered New Jersey voters surveyed in late February and early March said they would support state legislation banning the practice while 12 percent said they would not. Even cell phone users favored a ban, 83 percent to 15 percent. A bill introduced last year that would impose a fine of up to a $250 on a driver stopped for another violation but found to be using a cell phone while driving has stalled in the Legislature. George James

title: A Barrymore In the House
description: Hidden by hedges and pine trees, the old three-story Victorian house at 2405 Hammett Avenue in Fort Lee was once the home of a teen-aged John Barrymore and his father, the actor Maurice Barrymore. They lived there from 1890 to 1904. Young John is said to have given his first public performance at a benefit his father organized to raise money for a new firehouse for Fort Lee. Another family owned the home until 1998, when it was bought by a developer it who plans to demolish it. Two weeks ago, the Fort Lee Borough Council issued an order temporarily preventing preventing the demolition. Members of the Fort Lee Film Commission and the Fort Lee Historical Society plan to ask the council at its meeting on Thursday to have the town to buy the home and preserve it. Supporters say they have contacted the actress Drew Barrymore, John Barrymore's granddaughter, asking for a letter to aid their cause. Margo Nash

title: Along a Nature and Garden Trail

As Bermuda was one of the few island clusters in the world without a native population, early botanic observers had the opportunity to record flora untouched by human habitation before the 17th century -- with the exception of the occasional shipwrecked crew that either perished or stayed on shore long enough to build a ship out of cedar and sail on.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Now, Take My Lemon
description: It was barely a year ago that Dave Eggers burst into the spotlight with ''A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius,'' his oversized, self-conscious and showstopping memoir about raising his young brother after the deaths of their parents. Trailing him onto the stage came McSweeney's, the idiosyncratic literary quarterly and Web site he was producing out of a famously messy Brooklyn apartment. McSweeney's lacks the mainstream appeal of Eggers's memoir: it was, and remains, an incubator for abstruse, droll, often satirical bits of writing. Now come the first two works of fiction from the new McSweeney's book imprint. Like the magazine, the novels are handsome, smartly written and deeply eccentric. Consider LEMON (McSweeney's, $16.50), Lawrence Krauser's first novel, which tells the story of Wendell, a corporate memo writer who, after his girlfriend leaves him, becomes obsessed with a lemon. He notices the fruit lying in the foyer of his apartment building, picks it up, pockets it and soon finds himself mooning over it, bathing with it, taking it to work, rescuing it from a colleague's cup of tea and, perhaps inevitably, making love to it. He tapes it to a seesaw and he and the lemon ''ride for hours, then fall to the grass and lay in its rustling till daybreak.'' Krauser, who is a playwright, has interspersed scenes of Wendell and his lemon with elegant ruminations on the cultivation of lemons and descriptions of contemporary cubicle life. His prose is immaculate; his premise, patently ridiculous. This book is odd, exquisite and trivial, like a drawing on a Ping-Pong ball or an etching in a bar of soap.

description: Even as the Bush administration still celebrates the House's passage of the core of its tax-cut plan, it is increasingly apparent that the country needs an alternative to President Bush's proposed 10-year, $1.6 trillion cut -- one that is fairer, more prudent and more likely to stimulate the economy.

title: Delivering Something Real To 'Ally McBeal'
description: THE Golden Globe that Robert Downey Jr. won for ''Ally McBeal,'' and the loving reception that met him when he accepted it in January, allowed the show-business community to display its support for him in the midst of his legal and drug troubles. And though it's gratifying that the prevailing tone toward Mr. Downey these days is sympathetic rather than snide, the focus, understandably, has gone off his acting.

title: Jonathan Lebed's Extracurricular Activities
description: Instead of denigrating Lebed, the S.E.C. should retain him as a consultant.

title: Reckonings; The Money Pit
description: So this contractor is renovating your house. Funny how he got the job: you checked the wrong box on a confusing form, and the judge -- a close friend of the contractor -- ruled that you were stuck. Anyway, though you told him that your priority was replacing your leaky roof, he insists that first he wants to put in a luxurious powder room.

title: How They Got To Sesame Street
description: ''Nobody really remembers what children's television was like before 'Seasame Street,' '' said the anchor Harry Smith, harking back to the 1960's. ''It was a bit of a wasteland.''

title: Inside the Arctic Circle, an Ancient People Emerge
description: They are the indigenous people of Europe, a tribe that spent centuries quietly keeping to themselves in the dark and frozen expanse across the continent's roof but who are now raising their voices to get the attention of the people who live below.

title: A Higher Calling
description: Prepaid calling cards for sale at supermarket checkout counters have been common for years. But now, for the first time, the cards are getting religion.

title: The Pawn Looked Tasty. Who Knew It Was Poison?
description: Everybody guffaws when a great player makes a terrible blunder on his 12th move. ''How could it happen,'' ''Extraordinary,'' you hear whispered by spectators knowledgeable enough to see that a catastrophe is occurring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, ELISE (SILBERBERG)
description: RUBINSTEIN-Elise (Silberberg). Age 96. March 16, 2001, peacefully. Treasured wife of the late Samuel. Deeply loved mother of Ruth, Harry and Jean, Esther and Albie, beloved ''Nanny'' of Erica and Madeline, Moira, Felicia and Simone, Mark and Amy, and great-grandmother of eight. Cherished aunt of Dr. Henry and Rosie Baum, and Dr. Arye and Charlene Rubinstein. Lisa, you were a woman of valor, and a great joy...the love around which our family universe revolved, and the best cook in the world. Each of us will carry you in our hearts forever. Graveside services will be held Sunday, March 18, 11 AM, at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pine Lawn, NY.

title: POSTINGS: At Queens College Next Sunday; Annual Expo About Co-ops
description: The Federation of New York Housing Cooperatives is scheduled to hold its 44th annual Expo -- a series of seminars and a trade show -- next Sunday in the Student Union Building at Queens College.

description: Museums/Institutions

title: Woods Is in Position To Possibly End 'Slump'
description: Tiger Woods has not won a tournament this year, but if some people think that is a slump, he won't acknowledge it.

title: A Sweetheart of a TV Mom, Flaunting That Alter Ego
description: KATHIE LEE GIFFORD suggested that we meet for breakfast at the Trump International Hotel on Columbus Circle. She arrived, on time, in size 2 jeans, with her hair in a casual updo. The hotel's celebrity chef, Jean-Georges Vongerichten, was in the back of his restaurant Nougatine filming a pilot for a series that might end up on PBS.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIGHT, EDWARD
description: LEIGHT-Edward. His family and many friends mourn his death, and celebrate his life. Artist, children's book illustrator (The Harriet Series), designer, bon vivant, beloved uncle, decorated veteran of W.W. II, Oscar-pool winner, and a man of elegance, wit and style. His life touched us. Contributions can be made to the World Wildlife Fund, 1250 24th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20037.

title: Notre Dame Back on Track After Hot Shooting in Victory Over Xavier
description: The Big East season had ended with a thud for Notre Dame, three straight losses that not only brought into question the Fighting Irish's prospects for the N.C.A.A. tournament, but also their ability to shoot the ball. Yet as their shots blistered the nets against Xavier on Friday, they looked so cool and loose that they could have easily been standing in some suburban driveway, aiming at a basket hanging over the garage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEDER, JOHN FRANCIS, CAPTAIN UNITED STATES NAVY (RETIRED)
description: LEDER-John Francis, Captain United States Navy (Retired). On Friday, March 9, 2001, at The Halquist Hospice Center in Arlington, VA., after a valiant battle with cancer. John F. Leder, devoted son of the late Jon B., and Mary (McKinney) Leder, beloved brother of Mary, Thomas and Kenneth Leder, and Jane Horn, dear brotherin-law of Marge & Peg Leder, and Walter Horn, also survived by fourteen loving nieces and nephews. Friends may visit at EverlyWheatley Funeral Home, 1500 West Braddock Road, Alexandria, VA, on Tuesday, March 20, 2001 from 10 to 11:15 A.M. A Mass of Christian Burial will be offered at Blessed Sacrament Catholic Community, 1427 West Braddock Road, Alexandria, VA, at 12 noon. Interment to follow 2 P.M. at Arlington National Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be made to Hospice of Northern VA, or Blessed Sacrament School Building Fund.

title: March 11-17; Balkans Fighting Worsens
description: NATO let Yugoslav troops and special police back into a small part of a buffer zone they were banned from at the end of the 1999 Kosovo war, a signal of confidence in Belgrade's new democrats. But it was also a sign of NATO's inability to stop the flow of arms and Albanian militants into Serbia proper, or into Macedonia, where an outbreak of fighting by ethnic Albanians is on the verge of breaking out into outright war. Insurgents are trying to claim parts of Macedonia that are overwhelmingly Albanian, and the population is quickly dividing between Slavs and Albanians, just as in Kosovo. Steven Erlanger

title: How Did They Value Stocks? Count the Absurd Ways; Those Lofty 'New Economy' Measures Fizzle
description: IT has now become painfully clear, and last week's gyrations only added more proof, that Wall Street is a different place than it was even a short time ago. A brutish, bearish market has brought with it deflated hopes and new realities.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about living in Watchung, N.J., included a town official's erroneous estimate of the deer population. The density, according to an estimate by a different official, Mayor Anthony Addario, is 80 deer per square mile, not per acre.

title: Out of New Jersey, Into Africa
description: J. Michael Fay was born and raised in Plainfield and still considers it home, but he is just as much at home in previously uncharted areas of African forest in the Republic of Congo and in Gabon. Mr. Fay, who works for the Wildlife Conservation Society out of the Bronx Zoo, spent 15 months trekking across 1,200 miles of uncharted forest through central Africa to catalog animals and plants, some never before recorded, and to map unsurveyed land. His party had to hack its way through dense forests and at times was able to make only 60 steps an hour. The trek is chronicled in a three-part series in National Geographic magazine and will be featured on ''National Geographic Explorer'' on CNBC television tonight at 8 p.m. Karen DeMasters

title: Sports of The Times; Zimmer's Memoirs of a Baseball Lifer
description: IN managing the Yankees to four World Series championships in five seasons, Joe Torre has had to make thousands of decisions. When to bring in a relief pitcher. When to steal or hit-and-run. Much more often than not, he made the correct decision. But even before he put on a Yankee uniform in 1996, he had to make a decision.

title: Kansas Hits the Boards and Knocks Out Syracuse
description: DAYTON, Ohio -- So much for second-guessing Kansas in the second round.

description: As most people are pulling on leather jeans in black or brown, the leaders of the leather pack have moved on to chrome. Uptown, Anna Wintour, the Vogue editor, far left, matched a silver leather skirt to a chinchilla jacket for a modern slant. Among the downtown gallery crowd, the artist Tom Woodruff, right, was a standout in silver leather. One man, bottom left, stitched his own coat from foil.

title: Mexico's New Leader Vows to End Longstanding Impunity for Torture in Justice System
description: Torture, a tool used in Mexico for centuries, must now end, says the new president, Vicente Fox. But his advisers say it will require radical changes in the justice system, from lowly patrolmen to the high courts.

title: A Serving Wench in Staten Island
description: Though she works as an illiterate Irish maid born in 1830, Meghan Klages wants you to know that she drives a 2000 Volkswagen Beetle, has tattoos and thinks of Tuesday night as ''Buffy night.'' That would be ''Buffy the Vampire Slayer,'' the television show, you would need to explain to Brigid Clarke, the maid Ms. Klages portrays at a historical village in Staten Island. Oh, and television is a demoniacally omnipresent conveyance of sound and moving images. Like puppet theater, but with people.

title: Lives: Jet Set and Match; The Young and the Gutless
description: For years the culture's most prized discoveries were those people whose careers had somehow been cut short just at the moment of breakthrough. That was the cue for critics and the public to sit up and take notice, as thwarted potential was always more interesting than a fully realized life. The artist Jean-Michel Basquiat was one of the last to receive this kind of attention, perhaps a high watermark of the old live-fast-die-young paradigm.

title: In the Region/Long Island; Demand Increases for Factory-Built Houses
description: WHEN their son P. J. was born eight months ago, Paul and Nancy Tchinnis found their small one-bedroom apartment in North Babylon had suddenly become very crowded.

title: Percussion and Piano in Rare Duo
description: DESTINED to come together by accident: 1: Titanic and iceberg, 2: Tony and Maria, 3: the classical pianist Emanuel Ax and the flashy percussionist Evelyn Glennie, whose theatrical concerts feature show-biz lighting, spangled fashion and astonishing sounds. When the unlikely pair come together for a recital Saturday, listeners in Purchase are in for an earful of surprises.

title: A Tour de Paris, With Pedals and Bell
description: UNTIL recently, the idea of riding a bicycle in Paris struck me as being about as sensible as entering a Vespa in a monster truck rally. Given the sheer intensity of Paris traffic, not to mention the French driving style, braving the boulevards on the fragile frame of a bike seemed a sure way to end up sideswiped or mangled.

title: Macedonian Forces Dig In Against Albanian Rebels
description: Army and police troops took up positions today in the center of this city, the country's second largest, to fire on ethnic Albanian rebels in the surrounding hills for a fourth consecutive day, leaving the streets mostly deserted and shops closed.

title: March 11-17; Switch on Carbon Dioxide
description: Just as environmentalists had begun to give President Bush credit for being willing to tackle global warming, he reversed a campaign pledge to seek to regulate power plants' emissions of carbon dioxide, a gas seen as a major contributor to the warming of the environment. Mr. Bush said a crackdown could lead to a surge in electricity prices, compounding what he referred to for the first time as an ''energy crisis.'' Environmentalists were also disappointed by administration signals that it would not fight lawsuits that seek to overturn Clinton administration rules putting a third of national forests off limits to development. Douglas Jehl

title: Corrections
description: The front-page contents listing in Arts & Leisure today misstates the page number in some copies for the article about Tom Stoppard's plays. It is on Page 7.

title: Appearances; Cutting Edge
description: Where does a guy go to get his hair cut? A hair salon? Doesn't it seem strange to see a guy in a ''beauty parlor''? He looks so out of place there. It's like seeing a guy in a girls' bathroom. How did he get there, anyway? What, did his wife send him? Men don't belong in a beauty salon. They belong in a barbershop!

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, DIANE STONE
description: BERNSTEIN-Diane Stone. Beloved wife of Bernard. Passed away March 17 peacefully. She was 92 years old. She is survived by her sister and brother and her two daughters Lois and Adele and seven grandchildren. Services today at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 11:30 AM.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Joey Gabriel on Feb. 25 in Fashions of The Times, Part 2 of The Times Magazine, with an article about fashionable women in stylish rooms, was printed in mirror image. It appears correctly below. In addition, the credit was incomplete and partly erroneous. The photographer was Nan Goldin and the styling was by her and David Armstrong, not by Mimi Lombardo. Hair and makeup were by Joey Gabriel.

title: The Way We Live Now: 3-18-01: The Ethicist; Clearing the Bar
description: I am a lawyer who in 1991 pleaded guilty in federal court to conspiring to defraud a bank. My license was suspended, I paid a fine and I spent three months in house detention. I have since been readmitted to the practice of law, although I now devote 90 percent of my time to business consulting. Must I disclose my conviction to my clients? What about when my work involves financial matters but not the practice of law? Anonymous

title: March 11-17; Hip-Hop Mogul Acquitted
description: A seven-week trial that entwined the plodding machinery of Manhattan State Supreme Court and the expensive flash of hip-hop profiteers ended when a jury found Sean (Puffy) Combs not guilty in a case stemming from a 1999 shooting that injured three. He was accused of firing a gun inside a Manhattan nightclub after being insulted, and of possessing the gun later found inside his Lincoln Navigator. A Combs protg who was accused of firing wildly in the club was found guilty of five charges. Outside the courthouse, and before banks of cameras and reporters, Mr. Combs thanked God and his mother.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAWKINS, EVELYN BYRD
description: HAWKINS-Evelyn Byrd. Died on March 13, 2001 in her 95th year. Wife of the late Dexter C. Hawkins. Mother of Evelyn B. Patterson, Eliot D. Hawkins and Alice C. VanTuyl (correction). Grandmother of eight and great-grandmother of nine. Funeral service Monday, at 11 AM, at St. James Episcopal Church, Madison Avenue at 71st Street, NYC. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Central Park Conservancy, 14 East 60th Street, New York City 10022, ''in memory of Evelyn Hawkins''.

title: Fix Proposed for Abuse Tracking System
description: A child welfare tracking system that has been widely criticized as flawed, several years late and hugely over budget can be fixed, according to a report released Friday by a private company hired to evaluate the project.

title: Crime
description: EXILE (Carroll & Graf, $25) reads like a slap in the face -- and a kick in the ribs and a fist in the stomach and all the other body blows that the abused women in Denise Mina's novels accept as their due in life. Like its powerful predecessor, ''Garnethill,'' the story is set in a rough neighborhood of Glasgow where drunken men beat their wives, hopeless wives neglect their children, and angry children grow up to perpetuate the brutalizing cycle of poverty, despair and violence. ''I feel as if I'm grieving for everything,'' says Maureen O'Donnell, a veteran of this domestic war zone who works in a battered women's shelter to ward off the self-destructive demons of her own grim childhood.

title: Pretty Larceny; TO CATCH A THIEF
description: In a homage to Cary Grant, Thomas Jane plays it dangerous and elegant. Catch him next month stealing bases, not jewels, in the HBO film '61*.

title: A Room With Vroom
description: For those who want to take their chances driving on the left side of the road, the Colonnade Town House Hotel in London offers a way to do it in style. Its Drive on the Other Side package includes four nights in the 43-room hotel, two days' use of a 1960's sports car and a brief driving lesson. Car choices, all standard shift, include a Jaguar 420G, a Triumph TR4A and a Porsche Speedster. The package costs $1,686 for a room, at $1.50 to the pound, and $1,941 for a suite, plus V.A.T. The hotel is in the Little Venice area of London; it opened in 1999; (44-207) 286-1052; www.etontownhouse.com.

title: Salvadorans Seek Rebirth In Quakes' Grim Aftermath
description: Like an odd valley cutting through a neighborhood, almost nothing remains of the heart of Las Colinas, part of a suburb of San Salvador, the capital. An earthquake on Jan. 13 set loose a wall of dirt in Las Colinas that obliterated block after block.

description: Japanese Art in Pleasantville

title: Bolshoi Without the Toe Shoes
description: The Bolshoi Orchestra was founded the same year the United States declared its independence and has been performing in concerts around the world since then. Still, it did not tour North America until 1993. It is now in the middle of a 30-city tour of the United States and Canada, and will perform works by Tchaikovsky, Mussorgsky, Verdi and Shostakovich at the Community Theater in Morristown on Thursday. The 300-member orchestra, best known for accompanying the Bolshoi Ballet, Theater and Opera companies, is led by its music and artistic director, Mark Ermler. Karen DeMasters

description: Less than two minutes had been played before Geno Auriemma shed his charcoal-gray jacket and sternly crossed his arms, as if the time had arrived to do some serious coaching.

title: Ideas & Trends; AIDS Groups Revive A Fight, and Themselves
description: IT was difficult not to hear echoes of the past when members of Act Up, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, staged a ''die-in'' last week outside the headquarters of the Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America here. The props -- cardboard tombstones, chalked body outlines -- were familiar. Only the rallying cry, ''medication for every nation,'' was new.

title: Streetscapes/Kingsbridge Road and Grand Concourse in the Bronx; Poe's Last Home, 1810's Cottage That's a Museum
description: WHAT a battle it was, to save Edgar Allan Poe's house. But unlike the recent unsuccessful attempt to preserve the house at 85 West Third Street in Greenwich Village where the author once lived, this one happened a century ago -- and it successfully preserved the writer's last residence, Poe Cottage in the Fordham section of the Bronx.

title: Lives; My Friend, the Spy
description: We were pallbearers on opposite sides of a polished wooden coffin. An odd couple, really; a spy catcher and a spy writer. Between us, inside the heavy box on that September morning in 1996, was the spy who brought us together.

title: And Stretch Two Three, Laugh Two, Three...
description: Move over, Cindy Crawford. There's a new exercise video in town, and its famous bodies are, well, rather round. Which is just fine for toddlers, say nutritionists, who stress that a moderate amount of body fat is necessary for proper brain development. What isn't O.K. is obesity, a problem now affecting some 25 percent of the nation's children. Itsy Bitsy Entertainment is working to remedy that with ''Teletubbies Get Up and Go! First Annual Exercise Day,'' intended to show the value of physical activity. More than 30,000 preschools have received the curriculum and a half-hour interactive video that can be seen on Tuesday at 11 a.m. on Channel 13. Kenn Viselman, Itsy Bitsy's hairman, also hopes the program will counter an image problem created by marketing ''Teletubbies'' toys at both Burger King and McDonald's last year. ''I'm not sure a 2-year-old will see the benefits of exercise,'' he said, ''but he will see that exercise is fun.''

title: A Special Play Area Gets a Face Lift
description: Playground for All Children, the nation's first public playground for disabled youngsters, is getting its first makeover since its creation in 1983. The playground, one of six of its kind in the city, sits on a 3.5-acre lot at the southwest section of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park. The play areas have smooth paths and hills -- no steps of any kind -- for children in wheelchairs. Swings and slides are set at a lower level, and the jungle gym makes sounds so that blind children can also navigate it.

title: On a Bike in Cuba
description: To the Editor: Sandra Blakeslee's charming description of bicyling in the eastern end of Cuba is accurate. For those who wish to visit the island legally, I recommend Global Exchange Tours. I am a member of the board of Global Exchange, a nonprofit organization licensed to provide social and cultural exchanges to countries including Cuba and Iran.

title: Private Sector; Muggles From Earlier Time Haunt Hogwarts Express
description: J. K. Rowling has always bristled at suggestions she may have borrowed ideas and characters for her ''Harry Potter'' books. Now, as previews of the first Harry Potter film are shown in theaters and Harry Potter toys, clothes and trinkets invade stores, Ms. Rowling has been confronted with perhaps the strongest challenge to her authenticity -- the re-emergence of a 1980's book with some characters and words remarkably similar to those in her story about the boy wizard.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORNELL, RITA
description: CORNELL-Rita. Beloved wife of the late Frederic. Devoted mother of Myra Plonsky, Julian Cornell and Barbara Chavez. Cherished grandmother of Laurence. Reposing Sunday, March 18th, 2-5 and 7-9 PM, at A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, 1380 New York Avenue, Huntington Station, New York (631-423-2185). title: Delivery Route
description: THIS is a restaurant review, but it may remind you of those almost-too-good-to-be-true articles meant to put a human face on the newest census data. Immigrant striver comes to New Jersey, opens ethnic restaurant in virgin territory in the suburbs, wows the critics, succeeds beyond wildest dreams. Throw in a couple of John le Carr plot twists, and you have the story of Siam Garden.

title: A Great Winter for Car Washes
description: ON a recent morning, cars lined up at the Thornwood Exterior Car Wash despite predictions of rain. They were crusted with the brown, salty dirt of winter, their windshields coated with grime.
