description: DONALD TRUMP'S plan for a golf course in northern Westchester is drawing criticism as a threat to the water supply of Mount Kisco.

title: Fresh Young Outlook
description: For those looking for the antidote to Eminem and his overcast view of the world, some musical sunshine might be in order. An irreverent new-wave pop band from Seattle, the Young Fresh Fellows, has been making goofy, hook-filled music since the mid-1980's. Known for their often lighthearted mix of satirical send-ups of teenage angst and attempts at indie-rock greatness, their music often comes close to what a pop song should be: hooky, melodic, memorable and fun. They perform Thursday at Maxwell's in Hoboken. Robbie Woliver

title: Commercial Property; The Office Market Is Feeling the Economic Jitters
description: JITTERS from the gyrations of the stock market and the uncertain economic outlook for the country appear to be finding their way into the market for office properties in New York, real estate executives report. They say that the pace of leasing deals has slowed as prospective tenants reassess their space needs and that properties outside the central business district in Midtown have seen an erosion in pricing.

title: Braiders Out of Africa With a World of Woes
description: WHEN Aminata Dia immigrated to the United States in 1992, she had dreams of attending college and studying business management. For a month, she was a student at Columbia University. But she dropped out for financial reasons.

title: March 11-17; Pall on Russia-Iran Link
description: Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, may have hoped to garner some international credit for drawing Iran out of isolation by staging the first visit of an Iranian leader to the Russian capital since Iran's 1979 revolution. Instead, Mr. Putin's declaration that Russia would renew arms sales to Tehran, whose leaders are believed to be supporting international terrorism, cast a pall over the hoped-for diplomatic achievement.

title: No Quit In Rangers, But No Plan For Future
description: While they remain mathematically in contention for a playoff spot, the Rangers, who dropped 11 games under .500 after their 2-1 loss to the Philadelphia Flyers today, have not been part of the chase for nearly a month.

title: An Upbeat View, But for How Long?
description: Despite a weakening economy and a volatile stock market, most small business owners were optimistic about the future last month, and a growing number of them planned to spend more to expand, a recent survey showed.

title: Still Life With Thumbtacks
description: Unframed art has long been popular with struggling artists low on funds and with galleries started on a shoestring. But this winter, art without borders hit the big time, turning up in such mainstream spaces as the Whitney Museum of American Art (the Sol LeWitt retrospective), the Andrea Rosen Gallery (the Wolfgang Tillman show) and the Armory Show. In lieu of frames, art is hung with masking tape, metal clips or even thumbtacks, often weighted at the bottom corners to prevent curling. ''Unframed art definitely isn't about saving money anymore,'' said Thomas Delavan, co-founder of the Gramercy Art Fair and an art adviser to Bankers Trust Private Banking. ''It's about achieving a pared-down presentation -- the art world meets Helmut Lang. Art and fashion have intermingled for so long, it makes sense that the whole unfinished seams, clean-scrubbed-face fashion model sensibility would spill over into galleries.''

title: 'Post Rock' Hipsters Look Back To Fusion

Since its inception in 1992, Tortoise has made fiercely experimental rock music; its music is so up to date, in fact, that it's usually called ''post-rock.'' It is hard to call what the band performs pop songs: there are no vocals, no easily digestible hooks, not even memorable song titles. Tortoise's music is new and weird, and hipsters love it.

title: Other Side of the Mountain

''I'm whispering to try to fool myself into thinking I'm supposed to be there at 1.'' Sure enough, she showed up at 1:35, but the conspiratorial aside was revealing in two ways. First, like the air of cheery bonhomie in the voice, the casual theatricality is typically Southern -- not for nothing did McWhorter achieve what she terms ''the platonic ideal of white Birmingham girlhood,'' the presidency of the elite high school sorority Theta Kappa Delta back in 1969. And second, she does, it seems, have a thing about time, as evidenced by the 19 years it took her to write what she first envisioned as a modest memoir about her hometown and its horrific role in civil rights history.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Leonardo's Fingerprints
description: Pietro C. Marani's LEONARDO DA VINCI: The Complete Paintings (Abrams, $85) places its subject firmly in his historical context so that we can understand just how profoundly he transformed it. According to Marani, co-director of the restoration of Leonardo's ''Last Supper'' and a professor of art history at the Politecnico di Milano, it was Leonardo's new pictorial representations of movement and perspective, informed by scientific observations and the study of classical sculpture, that propelled the early stirrings of the Renaissance into the full flowering of the High Renaissance. Marani convinces untrained eyes that the slight twist of a torso, the subtle dilation of pupils, the rose-colored reflection of light from a red velvet sleeve, all signal enormous artistic triumphs. In ''Mona Lisa,'' for example, Leonardo's talents allow us to ''see blood flowing beneath the subject's painted skin and lips that tremble in a mobile face whose muscles contract slightly in the beginning of a smile. He achieves the miraculous description of nature, depicted as it comes into being.'' This lavish book contains 200 color plates, including enlargements in which it is possible to see Leonardo's very fingerprints in the paint. These fingerprints illustrate his unconventional techniques, but they also show how deeply Marani knows his subject and how completely this book introduces its readers to Leonardo. Douglas A. Sylva

Dr. Caldicott is the 2001 occupant of the Laurie New Jersey Chair in Women's Studies at Douglass College, part of Rutgers University. This semester, she is teaching a course on ''Women and Activism'' to 26 undergraduates at the Institute for Women's Leadership. Her latest book, ''The Coming Nuclear War,'' will be published in September by the Free Press. Dr. Caldicott will present a public lecture based on the book at the Douglass College Center in New Brunswick, at 5 p.m. Thursday. The free lecture will be preceded by a reception at 4 p.m. Karen DeMasters

description: Vladimir Frolov, the press attach in the Russian Embassy here, abruptly left for Moscow last week, his second tour of duty in the United States unexpectedly cut short.

title: Relieved, Combs's Lawyer Basks in Victory
description: Sean Combs is not available for comment. He has left for a vacation to parts unknown, his publicist said.

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 5 about the involvement of former President George Bush and other leading Republicans in the Carlyle Group, a private equity firm based in Washington, referred incorrectly to a cruise and dinners Mr. Bush attended in Saudi Arabia last year. Neither King Fahd nor any Saudi officials participated in those events, which were arranged by local Saudi businessmen.

title: Bookstore On Gay Life Is a Victim Of Tolerance
description: Older men remember it as one of the first places where they could find the titles that really meant something to them. Young men and women talk about how the books on those shelves answered their questions and helped them shape their identities.

title: In America; A Way to Find the Bad Cops
description: The New York City Police Department was aided in its crackdown on crime by Comstat, the widely praised computer tracking system used by police commanders to monitor crime trends and assess the performance of individual precincts.

title: Compressed Data; Shoulders Shrugged Over Dot-Com Woes
description: For many Americans, watching Internet companies trip and fall is more an entertainment rather than a cause for pain or sorrow. That is the conclusion of a quick poll taken in February by the Pew Research Center for People and the Press.

title: In Search of Buying Opportunities
description: Coming off one of the worst weeks in stock market history, Bob Olstein, who runs the $600 million Olstein Financial Alert Fund, is not letting the debacle dissuade him from buying some stocks.

title: City's Population Changes Are on Vivid Display in Queens
description: The red brick row house on 97th Street in East Elmhurst, Queens, is empty. The owner, an elderly African-American woman, has moved to South Carolina. This past weekend, the front door was open and Joe Busuttil and Beatriz Cardona from ERA Rock Realty were holding an open house.

title: Conservatives Savor Their Role As Insiders at the White House
description: For many conservatives, the heady days of the first Reagan administration were as good as it gets. Until now.

title: U.S. and Japan Make Pledge to Collaborate on Economy
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  President Bush and Japan's weakened prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, met today to discuss joint strategies for restoring growth to the world's largest and second-largest economies, but ended the session with a vague commitment by Japan to confront its huge banking problem and not to seek a short-term solution by boosting exports to the United States.

title: Richly Blended Wins Gotham, but Never Mind the Roses
description: Realism is usually in short supply this time of year. The Kentucky Derby is less than seven weeks away, close enough that most trainers with able-bodied 3-year-olds are intoxicated by Derby fever. But not Ben Perkins Jr. He knows what he has: a fast horse, but probably not Derby material.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDFRANK, EMMA PEARLIN
description: GOLDFRANK-Emma Pearlin. 82, of lymphoma, at home in Mamaroneck, NY, March 17, 2001. Loving and beloved wife of Tom. Mother of the late Fred and his wife Tory Ettlinger. Grandmother of Nicholas. Mother of Edward and Janice. Sister of Leonard Pearlin and Gerrie. Aunt to several including Gina Pearlin and Susan Maume. She was a school psychologist in Westchester for 25 years and had many loving, intimate and often mentoring relationships with friends, associates and family, before, during and after her professional career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBLATT, FRANKLIN D.
description: ROSENBLATT-Franklin D. Beloved husband of Florence, devoted father of Lief, loving father-inlaw of the late Melinda, adoring grandfather of Andre Charles who knew him as Pop Pop, and dear brother of Arthur, died on March 16, 2001. Born in Riverdale to the late Harry and Helen Rosenblatt, he was raised in Brooklyn. He studied nine years at night while holding two jobs to become a civil engineer in his own firm, and was noted for many innovative structural achievements including the design of the Venezuelan Pavilion at the 1965 New York World's Fair. A caring person who helped many others, always without fanfare, he was a true humanitarian. This special man will be sorely missed and fondly remembered by his family, his friends from his school days, and his friends from both the Berkshires and New York City. Service Monday, 10 AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Plunge in Stocks Colors Debate on Size of Fed Interest Rate Cut
description: The Federal Reserve will meet tomorrow to decide how much to cut interest rates in an effort to revive the economy just when a falling stock market seems to have the power to bring on a recession.

title: Gulf Arab States Prepare a Bailout to Assist Arafat
description: JERUSALEM, March 19  Persian Gulf oil states are tossing a lifeline to the financially foundering Palestinian Authority in the form of a $300 million aid package. This will make Arab donors the Authority's chief source of budgetary support for the first time.

title: Mississippi River Cruises
description: The American Queen is offering discounts of up to 54 percent in certain stateroom categories on three springtime Mississippi River cruises that focus on gardens. A seven-night cruise leaves from New Orleans for Memphis on April 6, a six-night cruise sails in the opposite direction on April 13 and a five-night cruise beginning and ending in New Orleans leaves April 19. Passengers should ask for offer code 11H, which applies to cabins ranging from outside deluxe to inside staterooms. Fares per person, based on double occupancy, are $1,095 for five nights, $1,295 for six nights and $1,495 for seven nights. These include all meals, but air fare and land tours to the gardens are extra. Availability is limited and other restrictions apply. Gardens visited will include Windrush Gardens in Baton Rouge, Monmouth and Rosalie Plantations in Natchez, Miss., and Afton Villa Gardens in St. Francisville, La. Among the lecturers will be Jim Wilson of the television show "The Victory Garden" and Holly Shimuzu, chief horticulturalist for the United States Botanical Gardens. Contact (800) 543-1949 or www.deltaqueen.com . Book through a travel agent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHLANGER, ESTHER B.
description: SCHLANGER-Esther B., 91, died peacefully in her home on March 17, 2001. ''Petey'' was an exceptional teacher of biology at many New York City high schools. After retirement from the classroom, she worked regularly with birds at the American Museum of Natural History and was an active member of the League of Women Voters. She leaves her son Jeff, daughter-in-law Anne, grandsons Raphael and Jordan, great-grandchildren Mikolo and Zoe, and nieces and nephews around the country, along with friends and colleagues grateful to have shared her vivid clarity, throrough care for everything in life and her sustaining love.

title: Economic Calendar
description: MONDAY: None

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAISER, ROBERT SCHULER
description: KAISER-Robert Schuler. 51, on March 17, 2001, of Hoboken, NJ. Beloved husband of Kati Hahn Kaiser. Loving father of Rhapsody and R. Buckminster. Cherished son of Robert and Irmgard Kaiser of Hilton Head, SC. Brother of Richard P. of Danville, CA, Ann Louise Fish of LaGrange Park, IL, and Barbara K. Herbert of Chatham, NJ. In lieu of flowers contributions to complete Bob's documentary on Broadway Scenery can be sent to the Robert Kaiser Documentary Film Fund, 47 Emerson Rd, Glen Rock, NJ, 07425-2323. A gathering to honor Robert Kaiser will be held between 1 PM and 4 PM, Tuesday, March 20, 2001, at 606 Adams St, Hoboken, NJ.

title: Furor Over an Artists' Haven; Sculpture Center Plans to Move, Shedding Students and Studios
description: In a city where everything seems to come by the dozen, the Sculpture Center remains unique. Tucked inside a former coach house at 167 East 69th Street in Manhattan, the center operates what artists say is the city's only school and studios devoted exclusively to sculpture.

title: An Antic Take on St. Patrick With Sexily Slinky Snakes
description: ''The St. Patrick Pageant'' promised to be a rich mixture of history and legend, spiced with both sanctity and irreverence. Instead, it was like an Irish stew with too many ingredients.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KENDALL, DELIA
description: KENDALL-Delia. Of Tuckahoe, NY, on March 17, 2001. Wife of Thomas. Mother of Corey and Joseph. Daughter of Felipe and Berta Calo. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM, Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial, Annunciation Church, Crestwood, on Wednesday, March 21, at 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Delia Kendall to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 1275 York Ave, Dr. Larry Norton, Box 351, NYC 10021.

title: BUSH DUE TO MEET CHINESE ON ISSUES CRUCIAL FOR TIES
description: As President Bush prepares this week for his first meeting with a senior Chinese official, his administration faces two decisions on military issues that could quickly put the United States on a collision course with Beijing.

title: Reviving the Japanese Economy
description: The White House pointedly scheduled today's visit by Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan ahead of a visit by one of China's top diplomats to register the importance of Washington's alliance with Tokyo. As it turns out, the meeting could scarcely be better timed. Mounting financial problems in Tokyo are adding to the anxieties unsettling America's stock markets. After a decade of economic stagnation in Japan, Mr. Mori and his politically battered Liberal Democratic Party seem to lack the will and the imagination to set a course for recovery. Americans once worried about seemingly invincible Japanese competition. Now Washington needs to help reverse Japan's economic decline.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUTTERMAN, CEIL GOLDSTEIN
description: PUTTERMAN - Ceil Goldstein. Passed away on March 16, 2001. She was the beloved wife of Milton, mother of Arlene and Richard, grandmother of Avery and Tyler and sister of Ed Goldstein. She was a good friend to many, loved by all who knew her for her kind and sharing soul, her strength and courage which helped her through 14 years of suffering from Carcinoid Syndrome of the liver. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, March 20, at 11 AM, at Agudath Sholom Synagogue, 301 Strawberry Hill Ave, Stamford, CT. Charitable contributions may be made to the Carcinoid Cancer Foundation, 1751 York Ave, NY, NY 10128 in her memory.

title: Slow Start and Rumors Don't Derail U.C.L.A.
description: One is perhaps the most revered coach in college basketball; the other is the embattled coach at one of the most revered programs in the game. Mike Krzyzewski speaks in measured tones about getting his Duke players to ''believe in something bigger than themselves.'' Steve Lavin slips into an amused staccato delivery when asked what it is like to be the U.C.L.A. coach: ''A gigantic dartboard. A big piata that's going to get whacked. A punching bag.''

description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: New Economy; Beyond file-sharing software, the music industry faces business challenges that may be even more daunting.
description: IN a remarkable example of the way the Internet changes everything -- including presumptions about property rights -- the nation's major music companies were busy last week compiling lists of songs that they would prefer not be stolen.

title: Big Media v. Freelancers: The Justices at the Digital Divide
description: For scholars, the electronic archives of contemporary journalism are a mother lode of history. For publishers and database owners, they are valuable intellectual property. But for a group of angry freelance writers, these archives are a legally dubious bazaar where their wares are peddled without their consent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, ROSALIND
description: JACOBSON-Rosalind. The Western Wall Heritage Foundation deeply mourns the passing of an extraordinary woman. ''Roz'' was beloved by anyone privileged to know her. Through her generosity, she established the Rosalind Jacobson Audio-Visual Center at the Western Wall Tunnels Complex in Jerusalem. Her generosity has enabled hundreds of thousands of visitors to the Tunnels to learn about their past, present and future. To Alvin, Anita and the entire family, we offer our heartfelt condolences. Ingeborg Rennert, Chairperson Sandy Eisenstat, President Joseph Yogi Loshinsky, Exec. V.P.

title: Piazza Steps Gingerly Into the Games of Spring
description: The ball glanced off Rob Sasser's bat and dribbled up the third-base line, and Mike Piazza gingerly moved out of his crouch. The injured Piazza took a few small steps toward the roller before Manager Bobby Valentine screamed, ''Easy, Mike!'' Valentine did not want Piazza to risk damaging the bruised bone in his left knee by chasing a 30-foot bleeder in a minor league game. When Piazza stopped, Valentine said, ''Thank you,'' and exhaled.

description: American television has done it again: taken a successful British series, cast it with beautiful Hollywood actors and copied it in all the wrong ways. It's not that ''First Years,'' which has its premiere on NBC tonight, is a terrible show. It's well paced, occasionally bright and has some visual appeal. But its weaknesses were so avoidable.

description: On a recent snowy day in New York, Carl Lennertz struggled in vain to program his stereo, laughed out loud on the subway at a new book by the humorist Joe Queenan, walked across town to buy his 9-year-old daughter a book by Lemony Snickett and pretended to throw snowballs at pedestrians using hands-free mobile phones. Then he sat down and recounted all of it in a public e-mail message to thousands of independent bookstores all over the country.

That will be 150 minutes of ''Nightline,'' three minutes more than the entire film. But that includes the commercials.

title: Air Force Proposes Plan to Help Boeing With Sale of Planes
description: In a twist to the Pentagon's growing efforts to bolster the defense industry, the Air Force has devised an ambitious plan to help Boeing, the world's biggest commercial jet producer, sell a version of its latest jumbo military transport plane to private cargo companies.

description: Abraham H. Lass, an educator and writer whose books, articles and 40 years as an unorthodox teacher and outspoken principal made him one of the New York City school system's best-known personalities, died on Friday night at his home in Fresh Meadows, Queens. He was 93.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPBELL, MARK A.
description: CAMPBELL-Mark A. Of New York City on Friday, March 16, 2001. Devoted son of Phyllis (nee Lotz) and the late Matthew J. Loving brother of Judy Campbell and Paul Campbell. Also survived by three nieces and two nephews. Mr. Campbell, who lived most of his life in NYC, worked as a General Manager for N. Peal on 56th Street for the last ten years. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral Tuesday, 9 AM, at the Madison Memorial Home, 159 Main St, Madison, with Funeral Mass at 10 AM, at Christ the King Church in New Vernon. Interment St. Peter's Cemetery, Staten Island. Visitation Monday 2-4 PM, and 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers contributions to the Kathryn Stanley Scholarship Fund at Drew University in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Wabor Pains As Comedy? Now, Bweathe
description: Early in ''Momma,'' Siobhan Fallon's one-woman show at the Atlantic Theater Company, there's a moment of trepidation for the audience. The proceedings get off to a sluggish start, and it seems as if ''Momma'' might become a mere rehash of all those jokes about ovulation and epidurals that have been floating around since childbirth became dinner-table conversation.

title: The Scientist's Story
description: NEW HAVEN  I once helped create a drug that could enable millions of people to lead better and longer lives. At Yale University's pharmacology laboratory, my late colleague Dr. Tai-shun Lin and I developed d4T, an antiretroviral drug that now forms part of a "cocktail" used by people with H.I.V. and AIDS. The patent was held by Yale, which licensed it to Bristol-Myers Squibb for development. At great expense, Bristol-Myers took d4T through the necessary trials, then brought the drug to market under the name Zerit.

title: Second Trial of New Yorker Jailed in Peru Is Set to Open
description: Five years ago a military court here condemned Lori Berenson, a former M.I.T. student and the daughter of two New York City college professors, to a life sentence on charges she was involved in a terrorist plan to seize the Peruvian Congress and take its members hostage.

description: Jim Baen would hardly seem an advocate of electronic publishing. He says derisively that he is ''not sure it's legal to actually make money in e-publishing.''

title: 2nd Billing Suits Feingold Fine, When It's 2nd to McCain
description: I CALL him my commander on this thing,'' says Senator Russell D. Feingold, ready once again to play Sancho Panza, riding behind Senator John McCain as the quixotic Arizona Republican tilts at the political money establishment.

title: Boston Symphony Finds Fascination in the Familiar
description: An orchestra's character is like a pervasive gene. Across decades of changing personnel and different conductors the elements endure, often hidden but waiting for the right conditions to re-emerge. Bernard Haitink conducted the Boston Symphony in familiar music at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night, and in the process reminded us that the inherent grace and elegance of this distinguished orchestra has survived its recent history intact. This was not just one more performance of Brahms's Second Symphony but an exercise in dignity, controlled passion and unfailing good sense.

title: CBS Faced a Twin Challenge During the Final Minutes
description: In the final minute of Penn State's 82-74 upset victory over North Carolina in the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament yesterday, CBS twice made a risky decision to leave the game during the action to cut to the end of the Notre Dame-Mississippi game.

title: Japan's Economy Lurks Low on Agenda as Bush and Prime Minister Prepare to Meet
description: Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan arrived here this afternoon for his first, and likely last, encounter with President Bush, as both Japanese and American officials acknowledged that they had made virtually no progress on drafting a joint statement to reassure world markets that Japan had a firm plan in place to restore economic growth.

title: At Van Gundy's Request, Jackson's Swagger Returns
description: Last week, Mark Jackson gave Coach Jeff Van Gundy just what he wanted: chutzpah.

title: A Mark Morris Mix That's All His Own
description: Mark Morris will probably always be controversial. Is his work art or galumphing? The program presented by the Mark Morris Dance Group on Thursday night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music suggests that Mr. Morris's choreography is both simultaneously.

title: Study Cites Illness in Alumni Of Schools on Industrial Sites
description: While being treated for leukemia seven years ago, Kim Tolnar, a 1983 graduate of River Valley High School near Marion, Ohio, was contacted by another woman who had attended the same school in the late 1980's and was battling the same disease.

title: It's Oscar Time
description: Each year, in a little-heralded awards ceremony, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences presents special Oscars to the real unsung heroes of the movie industry: the average moviegoers who had to endure the previous year's films, sometimes paying as much as $10 a ticket, plus parking, to do so. At this year's ceremony, hosted by Joe Piscopo and Mr. T. at a Ramada Inn near Los Angeles International Airport, Special Oscars for Outstanding Achievement in Moviegoing went to:

title: E-Commerce Report; Finally, some self-service sites are providing detailed answers when customers ask precise questions.
description: WHEN they were not promoting the now-laughable myth of ''first mover advantage,'' early e-commerce proponents proffered the idea that self-service Web sites could essentially run themselves, with little or no overhead.

title: On the Front in Macedonia: A Show of Rebels' Tenacity
description: LAVCE, Macedonia, March 19  Half a dozen young men, most in camouflage uniforms and carrying Kalashnikov rifles, ducked behind the wall of a house in this deserted village today as sniper fire whizzed overhead. A rattle of automatic gunfire sounded from below.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHIRRELL, BARBARA PILLIOD
description: SHIRRELL-Barbara Pilliod. Of Bedford Hills, NY, 71 years old, died on March 16. Wife of Robert. Mother of Ann (Mac) Rand of Katonah, NY, and Sarah (Earl) Carlin of Millbrook, NY. Grandmother of Robert, E. Scott and Hanna. Sister of Mary P. Enard of Westfield, NJ, and Dr. James P. Pilliod of Belmont, NH. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY, Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service at St. Joseph of Arimathea Episcopal Church, Elmsford, NY, Tuesday, 1 PM. Interment private.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, PAUL
description: LEVIN-Paul. Age 85, on March 17, of Manhasset, NY, and Fort Lauderdale, FL. Beloved husband of the late Renee Levin. Devoted and cherished father of John, Claudia Romig and Barbara. Loved by granddaughter Jamie Rose and son-in-law Ben Romig. Loving brother of Stanley Levin and the late Alvin Levin, and dear brother-in-law to Audrey Levin, Ellie Bragar and the late Etta Levin. Loved deeply by his family and friends for his commitment, spirit, principles and sense of humor. Born in Brooklyn, NY; proud WWII veteran; built a successful business, Manhassett Casuals; had a passion for tennis and charting the stock market. Rest in peace, we love you.

title: Albanian War Cry Rises Half a World Away, in Staten Island
description: The Ideal Night Club, a haunt of ethnic Albanian migrs from the Balkans on Midland Avenue in Staten Island, was flush Saturday night with several hundred eager men preparing for war. Most wore black leather jackets and had short, razor-edged haircuts. The air was thick with the acrid odor of cigarette smoke under pink, blue and green neon lights. Waiters in blue shirts and ties hustled drinks to the tables.

title: A Soul's Torture Reverberates From 17th-Century Letters
description: In 1665 a French cavalry officer stopped at a convent near Beja, Portugal, and apparently had a brief affair with one of the nuns there. After he returned to Paris, the nun, Marianna, wrote him anguished letters professing, as love letters often do, both her undying passion for him and her anger at him for leaving her, often almost within the same breath.

title: Connecticut Population Shifts Toward New York
description: Fairfield County, with its verdant suburbs, flourishing economy and troops of New York City-bound commuters, became the most populous county in Connecticut in the 1990's, according to figures from the 2000 census released yesterday. The data suggest that Connecticut's center of gravity is shifting away from its traditional focal point, Hartford.

title: Drug-Sentencing Battle in Albany
description: With last week's unveiling by Assembly Democratic leaders of their proposal to reform New York's harsh Rockefeller-era drug laws, the fight for serious drug-sentencing reform has been joined in Albany. Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and his colleagues did not summon the courage to address reform until Gov. George Pataki spoke out on the issue. But they have now produced a stronger and more promising package than the governor's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANDELBAUM, HERBERT
description: MANDELBAUM - Herbert. On March 17, 2001. Devoted husband of Ruth. Loving father of William and Rose Beth. Brother of the late Theodore Mandelbaum and Ada M. Rosen. Services Monday, 10 AM, at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. Donations in his memory can be made to Hadassah or Temple Isaiah of Great Neck.

title: Village People

For Stephen Pickover, a freelance opera director who works for the Metropolitan Opera and the Riverside Opera, the answer was the pre-war neighborhood of Washington Heights in Upper Manhattan. In fact, parts of Washington Heights, particularly above 181st Street, are sometimes referred to as the "Opera Ghetto" because of the large number of singers and musicians living there.

title: Metro Matters; Familiar Lines Of Battle In School Vote
description: TWENTY-ONE years ago, Mayor Edward I. Koch decided to close Harlem's Sydenham Hospital and replace it with new, neighborhood clinics. The hospital was in terrible shape. But it had become a heavily charged symbol in Harlem, and that, combined with the mayor's frayed relationship with the city's black community, stalled and almost toppled his plan.

title: Role of Stock Market In Economy Reflected In Dabate on Rate Cut
description: The Federal Reserve is preparing to decide tomorrow how much to lower interest rates in an effort to revive the economy, and that has many on Wall Street lobbying for a cut of three-quarters of a percentage point, or even more, to stop the sell-off in stocks. But other experts argue that a half-point cut is enough for an economy that, apart from the market, still has considerable strengths.

title: Met Is Ready to Rejoin Lincoln Center Redevelopment Under New Rules
description: After its two-month secession over complaints of being ignored by Lincoln Center's leadership, the Metropolitan Opera has agreed to rejoin the center's $1.5 billion redevelopment project under new rules that would give it a far larger say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TRANTUM, ADRON P. (ADE)
description: TRANTUM-Adron P. (Ade). Died in his sleep on March 13, 2001, at Indian River Estates of Vero Beach, Florida. Adron was born on November 8, 1904, the son of Cleveland Adron Trantum and Lottie Pauline Dewey. He is survived by his sister Mary Alice Higgins of Asheville, North Carolina, and brother Leland Trantum of Southbury, Connecticut; and predeceased by sisters Emily Gates and Elizabeth Denham Roth. Adron leaves four children, Martha Lee Cooper and her husband Victor C. of Vero Beach, FL; Rhona Jean Beltz and her husband R. Judson of Latrobe, PA; Kathleen Joan Riester and her husband Frederick C. of Selkirk, New York; and Tad Trantum and his wife Lynda Ann of Hendersonville, TN; thirteen grandchildren and five great-grandchildren. Adron was predeceased by his wife of 42 years, Kathleen Simpson Trantum, in 1981, and by his wife of 17 years, Peggy Jarvis Trantum, in 1999. Adron was born in Jamestown, New York, and spent his early years in Hagerstown, Maryland, and Ingold, North Carolina. He attended Columbia University and obtained his degree at Pace College in New York City. In the summer of 1929 Adron joined The Investors Management Company, now part of the American Funds, in Elizabeth, New Jersey. He retired from the same firm as senior portfolio manager in 1968. In 1941 Adron and Kathleen moved to Ridgewood, New Jersey, where their family was raised and their children graduated from Ridgewood High School. He was a Decaon of the West Side Presbyterian Church. Adron and Kathleen spent the first five years of their retirement in South Yarmouth, Massachusetts, before moving to Vero Beach, Florida, in 1972. Following Kathleen's death, Adron and Peggy married in 1983. Adron, Peggy and their late spouses had first met in 1949, so when they lost their life's mates, their union and love for each other was natural. It was an inspiration for their families and confirmed that life does not end with the loss of a spouse. Their enjoyment of life together should be a reminder that life can begin at eighty! Adron's time with us was filled with career achievement, caring, and laughter. Above all, his legacy is his devotion to Kathleen and Peggy, his children, and his extended family. All who knew him miss him. Donations in his memory may be made to VNA Hospice of Indian River County, 1111 36th Street, Vero Beach, FL 32960. Interment will be at George Washington Memorial Gardens in Paramus, New Jersey, at the convenience of the family.

description: The Trans World Entertainment Corporation said yesterday that it would rename its 730 mall-based stores, which operate under several names, and take a charge of 26 cents a share against this year's earnings as a result. The company said its Record Town, Camelot, The Wall, Disc Jockey and other stores would be given the name ''fye,'' shorthand for ''for your entertainment,'' by the end of the year. The change will cost about $40 million. The company's free-standing Coconuts, Strawberries and Specs stores will not be affected. Trans World, based in Albany, N.Y., said the name change, the result of an 18-month study, would help attract more customers and increase efficiency in its advertising and marketing. The company said it expected the name change to increase earnings in 2002.

title: CHARGE FOR COMPUTER SERVICES COMPANY
description: Computer Sciences Corporation, the No. 3 computer-services company in the United States, will take a fiscal fourth-quarter charge of $100 million to $150 million for the 700 to 900 job cuts announced Friday, the chief executive Van Honeycutt said. Fiscal fourth-quarter sales will be about 2 percent less than expected, and the company expects fiscal 2002 earnings of $2.50 to $2.60 a share, Mr. Honeycutt said yesterday on a conference call. The company was expected to earn $2.60, the average estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Financial/First Call. The shares of Computer Sciences, which is based in El Segundo, Calif., rose 30 cents, to $33. The stock sank 40 percent Friday after the company announced the job cuts and reduced its profit outlook.

title: Officials Had Profiling Data Before Shooting, Trooper Says
description: Almost three years after the New Jersey Turnpike shooting that helped turn racial profiling into a national issue, high-stakes hearings began here today with testimony by state police officials who said the attorney general's office knew for years before the shooting that racial profiling was a common practice in traffic stops and searches.

title: ECONOMIC GROWTH IN THAILAND
description: Thailand's economic growth increased at an annual rate of 3.1 percent in the fourth quarter from a year earlier, though the economy is losing momentum this year as falling exports stifle investment and manufacturing. The economy grew 0.9 percent from the previous quarter, seasonally adjusted, compared with a revised 0.5 percent increase in the third quarter, the government said. For all of 2000, the economy grew 4.3 percent. Growth in exports, however, which make up more than one-third of Thailand's gross domestic product and pulled the economy out of a 1997-1998 recession, is set to slow by half this year.

title: VITAL SIGNS: REGIMENS; Clot Drugs? Check. Diet Advice? Check.

title: Metro Business Briefing; RESPONSES TO MERGER
description: Fewer than half of J. P. Morgan Chase & Company employees said customers welcome the merger that created the second-largest banking company in the country, according to a poll conducted in December and January. The poll was done by J. P. Morgan Chase, which was formed in December when Chase Manhattan bought J. P. Morgan & Company for $32 billion. The survey measured responses to 37 statements, including ''customers view the merger as a positive event.'' Only 40 percent had a favorable response to that question, according to results obtained by Bloomberg News. Asked if the merger will result in a stronger company, 82 percent answered favorably. About 16,000 of the 90,000 employees responded. The company also conducted focus groups and interviews. Employees will be polled again in May.

title: Ukraine's Tribulations
description: Last November a farmer in Ukraine found the headless body of Georgy Gongadze, an Internet journalist who had accused President Leonid Kuchma of corruption. A few weeks later Mr. Kuchma's former bodyguard released tapes made before Mr. Gongadze's death that allegedly feature Mr. Kuchma discussing various ways to get rid of the journalist, including having him kidnapped. The tapes also include discussions from 1999 between Mr. Kuchma and his aides about using the prosecutor, militia and tax inspector to pressure journalists and the managers of state farms and factories to help re-elect him in November of that year. Mr. Kuchma charges that the Gongadze tape was electronically doctored, and he seems likely to survive the political crisis that has resulted. But the scandal has provided a glimpse of the abuses of power and corruption that have stunted Ukraine's development as an independent nation.

title: YORK HOLDERS WOOED AFTER COMPANY REBUFFS MERGER
description: Shareholders of the York Group, a maker of coffins and bronze memorial plaques, have received an unsolicited offer from Wilbert to buy their shares for about $50 million to bolster Wilbert's funeral business. Wilbert is the closely held parent of Wilbert Funeral Services, a leading burial vault company. Wilbert owns about 14 percent of York's shares outstanding, making it the company's largest stockholder. The $6.50-a-share offer is 39 percent higher than York's closing price of $4.69 on Friday. Wilbert said it wanted to buy shares directly from holders because York was unwilling to discuss a merger. Wilbert, based in Chicago, is also offering to swap shares in the proposed merged company for York shares for those who do not want cash, said Bill Forsberg, vice president of Wilbert Funeral Services.

title: ELECTRONICS MANUFACTURER IS TRIMMING 8,200 JOBS
description: The Solectron Corporation, a manufacturer of electronics, said yesterday that it was cutting 8,200 jobs, a more than 10 percent reduction, because demand is falling. The company plans to take a $300 million to $400 million charge for the work force reduction and to reconfigure factories, a spokesman, Kevin Whalen, said. Many of the jobs were cut the last two weeks. The company had 79,000 employees at the end of its second quarter ended March 2. Net income for the second quarter rose 26 percent, to $121.9 million, or 18 cents a share, from $96.7 million, or 16 cents, in the year-earlier period, the company said. Sales rose 85 percent, to $5.42 billion, from $2.92 billion.

title: SYNGENTA'S PROFIT RISES

The Swiss-based company, formed last November by a merger of the agrochemical activities of AstraZeneca and Novartis, reported that its 2001 sales were down because of depressed commodity prices, bad weather and farm crises that are disrupting deliveries in Europe. The chief executive, Michael Pragnell, is looking for an acquisition to shore up Syngenta's position as the third-biggest maker of seeds behind DuPont and Monsanto. Elizabeth Olson

title: Metro Business Briefing; TESTIMONY AGAINST EX-FINANCIER
description: An executive with an overseas financial management company testified yesterday that he handed Robert E. Brennan, the 57-year-old former penny stock promoter, an envelope containing 30,000 British pounds sterling in a London hotel on Oct. 27, 1998. The witness, Ian Plummer, managing director of the Valmet Group's office on the Isle of Man, in the Irish Sea, said a woman offering the password ''slush'' was to collect the money, the equivalent of $50,124, in late 1998. But she failed to appear in the hotel lobby, Mr. Plummer testified. He said his office then instructed him that Mr. Brennan would arrive with another password, ''the big ugly one.'' The testimony was offered in support of one of the 13 charges of bankruptcy fraud and money laundering against Mr. Brennan, who is on trial in Federal District Court in Trenton. Prosecutors say the money came from the sale of $4 million in municipal bearer bonds that he is accused of illegally failing to report on a 1995 bankruptcy petition. During cross-examination, Mr. Brennan's lawyer, Michael Critchley, contended Mr. Plummer was watching movies in his room at the time he says he turned over the money, a claim that Mr. Plummer denied. Robert Hanley (NYT)

title: Woman of Many Genres, Not to Mention Speeches

The Zags did it the way they always do -- by surprising everyone but themselves. All proved effective as Kansas, Temple and Gonzaga reached the Round of 16 in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Now what?

title: Jets Sign Receiver From the Vikings
description: For a year under two different coaches and general managers, the Jets have been on a quest to find a big receiver to replace Keyshawn Johnson. Yesterday, the Jets signed the latest and perhaps most promising prospect: Matthew Hatchette, who for four seasons played in the prodigious shadows of Randy Moss and Cris Carter in Minnesota.

title: Schrder Joins Debate, Taking Side of Pride In Germany
description: Chancellor Gerhard Schrder joined a heated debate today over whether Germans have the right to feel national pride, declaring himself ''a German patriot, who is proud of his country.''

title: Australians Hail Merger Of 2 Miners
description: Investors and analysts in Australia reacted jubilantly today to the proposed merger of BHP and Billiton, driving shares of BHP up sharply.

description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks End Sharply Lower After Fed Cuts Rates
description: After weeks of anticipation and prognostication, investors were disappointed today after the Federal Reserve finally delivered the interest-rate cut that they had sought.

title: The Week in Science: Startling Reverberations
description: The most startling science news of the week were reverberations from the Bush Administration's decision to abandon a campaign pledge to regulate carbon dioxide, the waste gas that contributes to the global warming of the climate. The decision damages Christie Whitman, the former New Jersey governor who is now administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, since she had been talking up the campaign statement as if the Administration had meant what it said. She is now following the party line.

title: On Tape, Tense Aides Meet After Reagan Shooting
description: A newly revealed tape recording made in the hours after President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981 portrays tense conversations among government leaders, concern over the location of a Soviet submarine, and a search for a spare nuclear code ''football'' that was kept in a closet.

title: Addenda: Vanity Fair Gets a New Publisher
description: Louis Cona, the publisher of InStyle magazine in New York, part of the Time Inc. division of AOL Time Warner , resigned yesterday to become the publisher of Vanity Fair magazine in New York, part of the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications . Mr. Cona, who had been publisher of InStyle for five years, succeeds Peter King Hunsinger, who last week was named executive vice president and chief marketing officer of Conde Nast.

title: McMahon and Knight: Tough Interviews
description: There has been a lot of chatter about whether Bob Costas or Vince McMahon got the better of their smash-mouth tte--tte on the XFL last Wednesday during HBO's ''On the Record With Bob Costas.''

description: Following are excerpts from yesterday's Senate debate on campaign finance by Senators John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Mitch McConnell, Republican of Kentucky, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACK, BEATRICE BODIN
description: ZACK-Beatrice Bodin, 86, of NYC. Died on March 17, 2001 in Baltimore, MD. For 60 years, beloved wife of David Zack. Devoted mother of Dr. Brian Zack (and wife Virginia August) of Princeton, NJ and of Dr. Donald Zack (and wife Dr. Ellen Okun) of Baltimore, MD. Cherished grandmother of Rebecca, Ian and Daniel Zack of Princeton, and of Rachel, Elizabeth and Andrew Zack of Baltimore. Private memorial service. She will be deeply missed.

title: One Actor, Two Stories and the Burden of Memories
description: What should we call this two-part show, performed by a single actor, David Margulies, on an almost entirely propless and setless stage, without an original or even an adapted script and essentially without even a title? A play? No. A recitation? That's a little diminishing. A reading is closer, but it isn't precise.

title: Few Plaintiffs Opt Out of Coca-Cola Discrimination Settlement
description: A $192.5 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit that accused the Coca-Cola Company of racial discrimination cleared a potential hurdle yesterday when only 23 members of the class chose to opt out.

title: DiFrancesco Is Expected to Oppose Meadowlands Mall Plan
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco is expected to announce on Tuesday that he is opposed to a vast mall that its developers hope to build in the Hackensack Meadowlands, according to those involved in the discussions.

title: THE CENSUS: Connecticut; Connecticut Population Shifts Toward New York
description: Fairfield County, with its verdant suburbs, flourishing economy and troops of New York City-bound commuters, became the most populous county in Connecticut in the 1990's, according to figures from the 2000 census released yesterday. The data suggest that Connecticut's center of gravity is shifting away from its traditional focal point, Hartford.

title: F.D.A. Seeks More Data From Corixa On New Drug
description: The Corixa Corporation, which is racing to be the first to market a drug that delivers radiation directly to cancer cells, has hit a roadblock. The company said yesterday that the Food and Drug Administration had asked for more information about the drug's safety and effectiveness.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, BERNARD N.
description: LOEB-Bernard N. Devoted husband of the late Sally, friend of Janet, beloved father of Barry, & Denise. Cherished grandfather of Brian and Megan. Services today at 2 P.M. at New Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, LELAND S.
description: BROWN-Leland S., 92. Of Bedford, New York. Died peacefully at home on March 17. Loving husband of Mary Murray Brown, who predeceased him by only one year. title: John Ardoin, 66, Music Critic and Author
description: John Ardoin, the music critic for The Dallas Morning News for more than 30 years and the author of four authoritative books on the life and work of the soprano Maria Callas, died on Sunday in San Jos, Costa Rica, where he lived. He was 66.

title: Edward T. Rogowsky, 60, a City Planner
description: Edward T. Rogowsky, one of 13 members of the New York City Planning Commission, died of a heart attack Sunday night as he got into a car at Kennedy International Airport on his return from a Florida vacation.

title: Corrections
description: The lottery listing on Friday and Saturday misstated the numbers drawn in Thursday's New York Take 5. They were 16, 18, 28, 29, 34.

description: Salvador Dali had a cold. But he dashed off his painting in less than two hours. It was February 1965, and Dali, the Spanish Surrealist with the waxed mustache and the nose for publicity, was wintering at the St. Regis in Manhattan with his wife, Gala, and their pet ocelot.

description: Right around this time two years from now, if everything goes as planned, two of New York's busiest subway lines will have gained something: about 155 futuristic new trains, fully in operation, purring down the Lexington and Seventh Avenue tracks like some kind of interplanetary zephyrs.

title: Opponents Find There's No Comfort Zone Against Temple's Matchup Zone
description: Temple's surprising success in the opening rounds of the South Regional in New Orleans this past weekend was a testament to the beauty of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Take an otherwise unspectacular team with a freakish quality, throw it against major college programs and watch the chaos.

title: VERIZON GIVES LUCENT $5 BILLION CONTRACT
description: Verizon Wireless, the nation's largest wireless telephone company, said it would pay Lucent Technologies $5 billion over three years to provide telecommunications equipment and services for Verizon's planned high-speed wireless network. Verizon, based in Bedminster, N.J., is racing Sprint PCS to become the first United States company to unveil the third-generation network, known as 3G, which is expected to allow fast, continuous Internet connections for notebook computers, handheld devices and mobile phones. Lucent, based in Murray Hill, N.J., which lost 85 percent of its stock value in the last year, said the agreement was its largest wireless contract ever. Its shares gained $1.98, nearly 20 percent, to close at $11.97. Chris Gaither

description: WHEN peering into the backroom machinations of boxing, it is important to remember the latest teachings of that eminent pugilistic philospher Don King.

title: AMOCO GETS CONTRACT
description: China has picked BP Amoco over its rivals the Exxon Mobil Corporation and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group to build the country's first liquefied natural gas terminal, worth as much as $600 million, the official New China News Agency said. China plans to start building the terminal, which would have an annual capacity of three million tons of liquefied gas, in the second half of 2002 and complete it by the end of 2005. BP will take a 30 percent stake in the project while a group of companies, led by the China National Offshore Oil Corporation, will hold the rest.

description: People using Web sites to help them lose weight do better when the site talks back, a new study has concluded.

title: Foreign Affairs; Policy Free-for-All
description: Two months into the Bush administration's term, its foreign policy has still barely taken shape. In part this is because many of the administration's key sub-cabinet officials are still not in place to grind out its new policies. But don't be fooled by that. It's also because three major fault lines run through the prospective Bush foreign policy. Pay attention to these fault lines. They could widen into chasms very soon.

title: TOURNAMENT RATINGS DOWN FOR CBS
description: Through the first four days of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament, CBS is averaging a 5.2 preliminary national rating, down 9 percent from last year.

description: WASHINGTON, March 20  President Bush and Prime Minister Ariel Sharon of Israel held what both called friendly and frank discussions today. Afterward, Mr. Bush reiterated that the United States wants to help the Israelis and Palestinians achieve peace, but that it cannot force a peace upon them.

While Torre portrayed the switch as a temporary trial, it is highly unlikely Knoblauch will return to second base regularly in the foreseeable future.

title: SERVICE UNIONS MERGE
description: Four German labor unions representing service workers agreed to merge to create the world's largest union, with 3 million members. The new union, Ver.di, unites unions representing government and transportation workers; bank and insurance industry employees; media and publishing; and the postal service. It eclipses Germany's huge metalworkers' union, IG Metall, which has 2.7 million members and had until now been the world's biggest union. But both big unions have lost influence in the last decade, as German companies have shifted hundreds of thousands of jobs out of the country to reduce costs and increase their flexibility. Edmund L. Andrews

Plants in India and Poland may become independent through debt-for-equity swaps, the company said.

description: AIRSPAN NETWORKS, Sunrise, Fla., named Peter Aronstam chief financial officer. He had previously been vice president for customer finance at Nortel Networks.

title: Blasts Add to Petrobras's List of Woes
description: With its largest offshore oil platform still listing after a series of deadly explosions last week, Brazil's state-owned oil company, Petrleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras, is struggling to ease the damage to its bottom line and to the international reputation it has painstakingly built.

title: Vatican Radiation? Body Snatchers? This Is Italy?
description: Italian public life always seems on the brink of falling into the Fellini-esque. Lately, it has tumbled right over. The minister of the environment has threatened to cut off power to the Vatican's radio station, while an episode of a satirical television show, appropriately named ''Satyricon,'' has turned the already venomous Italian election campaign into a boiling caldron of network resignations, defamation lawsuits and television boycotts.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL DROPS. Crude oil fell on expectations that weakening demand will leave refiners well supplied, even after OPEC cut production. In New York, crude oil for April delivery fell 59 cents, or 2.2 percent, to $26.15 a barrel.

Mr. Cona, who had been publisher of InStyle for five years, succeeds Peter King Hunsinger, who last week was named executive vice president and chief marketing officer of Cond Nast.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOOTTON, PHILIP H. JR.
description: WOOTTON-Philip H. Jr. On March 17, 2001. In Stamford, Ct. Age 82. An innovative Life Magazine editor and later a rancher in Colorado, Mr. Wootton was a 1940 Cum Laude Yale graduate in Economic Geology and Editor of Yale Scientific Magazine. He was born September 12, 1918 in New York City to Philip Henry Wootton and Anna Irving. In the mid 1950s, as Assistant Managing Editor, Mr. Wootton lead a team of Life editors and reporters who developed the concept of special issues and serials that underpinned the magazine's growth in the post-war, pre-television years. As Executive Editor in 1961 to 1963 among many other projects, he oversaw the Life Magazine special on the assassination of John F. Kennedy. Later, as Associate Director of research and development, he concentrated on multi-media development and contractual relations with broadcast and television companies. In 1971 Mr. Wootton purchased Singing River Ranch in Red Wing, Colorado. With his wife and family, Mr. Wooten ran the guest and cattle ranch for seven years. He sold the working half of the ranch in 1977 and retired, building a small cabin and barn nearby. Mr. Wootton was a longtime former member of the Woodway Country Club, a member of the Country Club of New Canaan, a former Board member of the New Canaan Nature Center and assisted regularly at Pegasus, a therapeutic riding program for the handicapped. Mr. Wootton's survivors include his wife of 58 years Marie Core Duffy Wootton of New Canaan, CT., two sons Philip H. III of Monroe, CT, William R. of Marlboro, VT., two daughers Constance Wootton Nichols of New Canaan, CT., and Elizabeth Ann Core Wootton of New Haven, CT., three nieces and a nephew and eight grandchildren: Justin, Peter and James Wootton; Russell and Clara Wootton; Elizabeth and Katharine Nichols, and Marina Wootton. A private interment will be followed by a memorial Mass at 11AM Saturday, March 24, at St. Thomas More Church, Middlesex Road, Darien, CT. Donations in memory of Mr. Wootton may be made to Waveny Care Center, Farm Road, New Canaan, CT. 06840 or to the New Canaan Volunteer Ambulance Corps, South Avenue, New Canaan, CT. 06840.

title: Shares Gain After Losses; Investors Await Fed Action
description: After a week of steep losses, stocks rose yesterday as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's expected move to reduce interest rates.

title: When Mir Descends
description: When the Mir space station was launched on Feb. 20, 1986, its name, which means ''peace,'' was an overture of sorts in a still-suspicious time. As it turned out, the spaceship went on to embody peace in practice, becoming a place where more than 100 humans have lived high above Earth, slightly more than half from the former Soviet Union and the rest from more than a dozen other countries including the United States.

title: Sailor Admits Not Reporting Japanese Boat
description: The petty officer on the nuclear attack submarine Greeneville charged with tracking nearby vessels testified today that the ship's sonars showed several times that the Japanese trawler Ehime Maru was within close range before they collided. But he said that he failed to notice all the readings, and that he did not notify the submarine's captain even when there was evidence of a problem.

description: Cygnus Ensemble

description: Bobby Jones's chances of making the Mets' 25-man roster to open the season were eliminated today when a magnetic resonance imaging test showed that Jones, a left-handed reliever, has rotator cuff tendinitis.

title: Newspaper Publisher Quits to Protest Profit Goals
description: Jay T. Harris, the chairman and publisher of The San Jose Mercury News, announced yesterday that he was quitting his posts and warned his corporate bosses at Knight Ridder that their profit targets for the financially squeezed newspaper risked ''significant and lasting harm to The Mercury News as a journalistic enterprise.''

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Two drug wholesalers plan to merge in a $2.4 billion stock deal.
description: IN a deal that will probably attract regulatory scrutiny, the AmeriSource Health Corporation and the Bergen Brunswig Corporation, the nation's third- and fourth-largest drug wholesalers, said yesterday that they had agreed to merge in a $2.4 billion stock deal.

title: Lectures vs. Laptops
description: Something alarming happened in my contract law class. I asked that laptop computers be used only for note taking, and my students went ballistic.

title: Trial Opens Over Scuffle At Airport
description: When a passenger was charged with hurling an airline gate agent to the floor nearly two years ago at Newark International Airport, breaking his neck, the case was denounced as a disturbing outbreak of ''air rage,'' the violent response to air travel delays and overcrowding. But today, as the passenger went on trial here, both the prosecution and defense insisted otherwise.

title: Devils Rally to Push Streak to 11 Games
description: For the last four victories of their 11-game winning streak, the Devils have marched like a conquering army, prevailing through the desert, across the prairie and up the mountains. Now, they head home to New Jersey for three games, beginning with the Rangers on Wednesday night. The defending Stanley Cup champion Devils are due to lose sometime, but who will beat them -- and how?

title: Teenagers Find Health Answers With a Click
description: Emily Davison, a 12-year-old seventh grader at the Trinity School in Manhattan, used to think she was overweight. Recently, she changed her mind. Emily didn't lose a single pound to change her attitude.

title: Greek Antiquity Echoes In a Debussy Flute Work
description: Maurizio Pollini has been particularly inventive in the programming for his Perspectives series, presented by Carnegie Hall but residing two weeks recently at the 92nd Street Y. In the first two of his three concerts at the Y, he presented chamber music, some requiring his services as a pianist, some played by members of two guest ensembles, the Accardo Quartet and the Ensemble Wien-Berlin. Those programs brought together old and new, but for sheer historical sweep neither touched the closing program, offered on Wednesday night. Included was music as early as Greek chant that may have been composed around 400 B.C. and as recent as Luciano Berio's ''Altra Voce,'' composed in 1999.

title: DIAPER MAKER IS BOUGHT BY HONG KONG COMPANY
description: The Drypers Corporation, a diaper maker that filed for bankruptcy protection last year, said yesterday that DSG International of Hong Kong had bought its North American assets for $38.5 million. DSG said its United States subsidiary, Associated Hygienic Products, acquired Drypers's assets in Ohio, Washington and Texas. Drypers officials said last month that they would sell the company at auction under a plan approved by a bankruptcy court judge in Texas.

title: The Phoenician Resort
description: Things start to heat up in Phoenix -- literally -- long before summer hits the rest of the country. So the Spring Value Rate offered by the Phoenician, a deluxe resort in Scottsdale, Ariz., may represent the last gasp before you start gasping for real. From April 8 through 20, rooms start at $395, plus tax and tip, and children 17 or under stay free when sharing a room with an adult. description: Leaders of the State Assembly and Senate unveiled dueling budget wish lists this afternoon, highlighted by sharply divergent numbers on aid to education.

description: Extending their knowledge of some of the earliest life on earth, scientists believe they have figured out what one group of bacteria was feasting on 3.5 billion years ago.

title: Parents Slowly Start Voting on Privatizing 5 New York City Schools
description: Parents of nearly 5,000 children at five public schools began casting ballots yesterday in a two-week election that will decide the immediate future of school privatization in New York City and could greatly affect the fortunes of Edison Schools Inc., the country's largest private operator of public schools.

title: MYCFO BUCKS TREND WITH NEW FINANCING
description: Proving that capital for online financial-services has not dried up completely, myCFO Inc. said it had rounded up another $45 million from private investors at a per-share price that raised the value of the company 31 percent. An Internet-based advisory service for multimillionaires, myCFO has received $90 million in three rounds of capital raising from a group that includes the Northern Trust Corporation, the venture-capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers and Netscape Communications co-founder Jim Clark. The company, based in Mountain View, Calif., said it had 310 clients who are worth a combined $44 billion and who pay annual fees to myCFO of at least $25,000 each. Mr. Clark said in a statement that myCFO ''recommended that I get out of stocks last summer, and it's saved me an enormous amount of money.'' Patrick McGeehan

title: Prosecutor Details Corruption Case Against Suffolk Sheriff
description: In painstaking detail, a Suffolk County prosecutor today sketched out an intricate corruption case against the county sheriff, Patrick A. Mahoney, and his former top deputy, saying they used the county jail as the unofficial headquarters for Mr. Mahoney's political campaigns and sought money for plum assignments, better pay and promotions.

title: SONERA IN DEAL WITH VODAFONE
description: Finland's Sonera telecommunications company said it would add a potential 11.6 million customers to its Zed mobile phone business under a deal with Vodafone of Britain. Zed, which Sonera said was available to 50 million mobile-phone users in Germany and to Powertel subscribers in the United States, uses local-call text messaging to enable mobile phone users to receive games, television guides and a range of entertainment information. Zed and Vodafone did not give financial details of the deal but said they would share revenues. Alan Cowell

title: Metro Business Briefing; LONG ISLAND LOCATION FOR FAIRWAY
description: After nearly three decades as an Upper West Side institution, Fairway is opening its first market outside the city in mid-April. The 50,000-square-foot store, on the site of a former Grand Union supermarket in Plainview, on Long Island, will have the warehouse feeling of the five-year-old Fairway wholesale market on 133rd Street and 12th Avenue, but will also offer a full line of groceries and specialty foods, said Howard Glickberg, one of Fairway's owners. Mr. Glickberg said Fairway had no immediate plans to branch out further. Fairway recently spent $6.5 million to buy property adjacent to its wholesale market, with an eye toward adding a bakery and more space for parking and storage. Terry Pristin

A professor at Harvard Medical School and director of the surgical research laboratories at Children's Hospital in Boston, he created a new field of medicine and challenged orthodox thinking about cancer treatment.

title: McLEODUSA BUYING INTELISPAN

McLeodUSA will pay 0.03 share of Class A common stock for every Intelispan share, or 35 cents based on Friday's closing price, according to a statement from the companies. That is 2.6 percent less than Intelispan's price Friday.

title: American Guides China in Revamping of Market
description: SHANGHAI  James Liu is an American. That is not surprising until you consider what Mr. Liu does: he helps run the Shanghai Stock Exchange . He is the exchange's executive vice president, working to reshape China's state-dominated equity markets into a true capitalist tool.

title: MBNA TO BUY CREDIT CARD BUSINESS IN BRITAIN
description: Extending an aggressive campaign to expand in Britain, the MBNA Corporation, a credit card company, has agreed to buy the credit card business of Abbey National, a major mortgage lender, which is facing an unwelcome takeover bid from the Lloyds TSB Group. MBNA will pay $414 million for the business, $65 million more than book value, under a five-year revenue sharing agreement. MBNA will develop new cards with the Abbey National brand and run the business. Abbey National has about 500,000 credit card holders, a 1.3 percent market share. MBNA has about 7 percent. Alan Cowell

title: Our House Wasn't Dirty Enough?
description: Back in the 1980's, when my husband and I found out that our two sons had asthma, we assumed our slobbish ways were to blame. Dust balls and cat dander were the big crimes then, and we were guilty on both counts.

title: Austrian School Drama: Crucifix Meets Ramadan
description: If you seek a snapshot of the future of Europe, take a look at the sixth-grade class in the Selzergasse school here: four nationalities are represented, only three children have parents born in Austria, and 10 of the 20 pupils are Muslim.

title: AIRBUS SHAREHOLDER LESSENS ITS LOSS
description: The European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, the main shareholder in Airbus Industrie, said its loss narrowed in 2000 to 909 million euros ($816 million), compared with 1.05 billion euros it would have lost last year if it had existed. Profit before interest, taxes and currency hedging rose 11 percent, to 1.4 billion euros, compared with 1.26 billion euros a year ago. Sales increased 7 percent, to 24.2 billion euros. Formed in July through the merger of three European companies, EADS said it expected a 15 percent jump in sales and earnings before interest taxes and depreciation in 2001 from cost savings and increased orders at Airbus, which rivals the Boeing Company in the market for jumbo aircraft. EADS shares fell 5 percent, to 21.74 euros. Suzanne Kapner

The mill will supply a joist-making plant that is under construction, said Nucor's chief financial officer, Terry Lisenby. Nucor expects the purchase to close this month.The purchase will increase Nucor's steel-bar production by 400,000 tons a year.

title: CORNING WILL MISS PROFIT FORECAST

The company said the revision was based primarily on lower expectations for the telecommunications segment amid the current economic slowdown. Even so, Corning expects 2001 revenues in the range of $8.2 billion to $8.5 billion, up 15 percent to 20 percent over 2000 revenues of $7.1 billion. Corning said it had not changed its first-quarter pro forma earnings expectations of 28 to 31 cents per share. Shares of Corning closed at $25.20, up $2.02. Susan Stellin

title: In the New Physics, No Quark Is an Island
description: ''The universe,'' the poet Muriel Rukeyser once wrote, ''is made of stories, not atoms.'' This being the science section, you might be tempted to regard that statement as a predictable humanistic rant against cold scientific reality. For the last 300 years, after all, the story that physicists have been telling us is that the shifting shape of the world is made exactly of atoms, irreducible and indestructible nuggets of existence, bouncing around according to Newton's and a few other simple laws.

title: The Turbine Mess
description: The Pataki administration presumably had the best of intentions in January when it approved the construction of 10 new gas-fired turbines in six locations in New York City. The California energy crisis had raised questions about the city's generating capacity, so it seemed prudent to provide a cushion against summer shortages that could lead to big price increases. But with each passing day it becomes increasingly clear that in its zeal to get moving, New York State ignored sound governmental processes. It cut regulatory corners and exploited a loophole in state laws to dodge full environmental reviews. According to state legislators, it has also been reluctant to share the underlying analyses governing its choice of sites, including an ''environmental justice analysis'' showing that nearly all the generators would be built in poor neighborhoods that already suffer from air pollution.

These are regarded by the faithful not as the work of stone carvers, but as signs of the departed master's presence. The flowers scattered over them are offerings of devotion. Of such footprints, the Buddha is reported to have said: "In the future, intelligent beings will see the scriptures and understand. Those of less intelligence will wonder whether the Buddha appeared in the world. In order to remove their doubts, I have set my footprints in stone."

description: They always came as a package, whether as 2-year-olds curiously eyeing a basket that their father had hung on the bedroom wall or as 22-year-olds leading No. 2-ranked Stanford to its third straight Pacific-10 title. With games nearly as identical as their looks, the twin brothers and towers, Jason and Jarron Collins, developed into the best front-court tandem in college basketball, an imposing pair difficult to separate even in opponents' scouting reports.

title: Robert L. Clare Jr., 86; Ran Wall St. Law Firm
description: Robert L. Clare Jr., a corporate lawyer who played a critical role in the growth and international expansion of the Wall Street law firm of Shearman & Sterling, died on Sunday at his home in Annandale, N.J. He was 86.

title: Moscow Says Remarks by U.S. Resurrect 'Spirit of Cold War'
description: Russia today accused two senior officials of the Bush administration of making ''openly confrontational'' statements by labeling Moscow as an ''active proliferator'' of dangerous weapons technologies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'DWYER, TRACY LYONS
description: O'DWYER-Tracy Lyons. March 20, 2001, at the Cabrini Hospice in New York. Tracy. You made an amazing difference to everyone whose life you touched. Not only those who were your friends but the many others whose talents you nurtured. We shall always remember your spirit, your courage and the very special person you were. We will never forget you. We will never forget your love. Phillip, Jill, Jenny, Allie, Nancy, Patti, Marvin, L.B., Paula, Marilyn, Beverly, Kaye, Lila, and the hundreds of others who loved you as you passed their way.

title: President of Mexico Does Not Stand on Ceremony
description: It happened fast, out of the spotlight, on a roadside in southern Mexico: President Vicente Fox used the power of his office to try to change a life.

title: ADVICE ON DAEWOO
description: Jeffrey Jones, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in Korea, called on the committee of creditors running the bankrupt Daewoo Motor to simply hand General Motors the keys. ''The value is declining every day,'' he said. ''We would be better off having someone take over that company, even if it means giving it away,'' because resolving its fate would bolster confidence. A spokesman for Pohang Iron and Steel denied reports that his company was considering a takeover of Daewoo if G.M. failed to bid for it. Don Kirk

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEE, JAMES T.
description: YEE-James T. The Staff and Board of The Independent Television Service (ITVS) mourns the loss of the former Executive Director, James T. Yee, who passed away on March 17, 2001, in Piedmont, CA, after an eighteen month battle with cancer. Yee, a long-time crusader for plurality in public television and an advocate for independent media producers, was the Executive Director of ITVS from 1994 through 2000, and The National Asian American Telecommunications Association (NAATA) from 1981 to 1994. He was a trusted ally, a formidable but fair adversary to those who dragged their feet in the campaign to diversity the images seen on American television and a seasoned producer who received a National Emmy Award for ''aka Don Bonus.'' We send our deepest condolences to his wife, Betty Quan Yee, children, Jane and Liam Lee, his brother, Calvin Yee, and sisters, Diane Weirck, and Geraldine Eng, and their families. Memorial contributions may be sent to: James T. Yee Mentorship Program, NAATA, 346 9th Street, San Francisco, CA 94103. A Memorial Service will be held Friday March 23, 2001 at 10:30 A.M. at Chapel Of The Chimes, 4499 Piedmont Avenue, Oakland, CA. Judy Tam, Actng Exec Dir David Liu, Dir Prog Devlpmnt

title: Facing a Deficit, Suffolk's Chief Urges an Increase in the Sales Tax
description: Facing a year-end budget deficit of $35 million caused by lower-than-expected sales tax revenues for the last quarter of 2000, the Suffolk County executive today called for the county to raise its sales tax by a quarter of a percentage point.

description: In a victory for United Parcel Service, the European Commission ruled today that the German postal service illegally used profits from its monopoly in delivering letters to subsidize its prices for business parcels and other packages.

title: Richard Harwood Dies at 75; Policed The Washington Post
description: Richard Harwood, who brought the determination and cunning of a combat marine to reporting and editing and, finally, to policing his own newspaper for editorial missteps, died of lung cancer on Monday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 75.

description: KINDERGARTEN has long aimed at developing social, emotional and verbal skills to enhance later academic success, especially for children who do not attend quality preschools. But now, hoping to raise scholastic performance, some districts require all kindergartners to sit through as much as two hours of daily reading drills.

description: Although the Suffolk County sheriff is charged with campaign corruption, his lawyer told a jury today that he was on trial for another reason: a political feud with the county district attorney.

description: A new phase in the hardware wars will start today when Sun Microsystems introduces four server computers that upgrade its midrange Serengeti line to run on the company's new UltraSparc III processors and new Solaris 8 software operating system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURNER, ALICE E.
description: TURNER-Alice E. of Manhasset, NY passed away on March 19, 2001. Born Alice Frail on December 19, 1925 in Flushing, NY. As a young girl she was a fine athelete who excelled in track and swimming competition. Upon graduating Bayside High School in 1944 she became a stewardess for TWA. She later went on to United Airlines and became the first secretary for the Airline Pilots Association. She was married in June 1950 & is survived by her devoted husband James and four children; John, Jeanne, Claire & Andrew to whom she taught many valuable lessons and who will miss her dearly. She is also survived by her older sister Mary Hay of Norwalk CT, and ten grandchildren. In repose at the Fairchild Funeral Chapel, 1570 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, New York, Wednesday 3-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass 10 AM Thursday at St. Marys Church in Manhasset. In lieu of flowers contributions in her memory can be made to Maryknoll Fathers and Brothers C/O Father Peter LeJacq-Reference Alice Turner, P.O. Box 305 Maryknoll, NY 10545.

title: Macedonia Gives Rebels an Ultimatum
description: The government issued an ultimatum today to the rebels who occupy the hills above this city, ordering them to surrender or withdraw in 24 hours, or face being wiped out.

title: I End Each Day Empty-Handed
description: I read in a magazine that postal carriers are more healthy than people from other professions because they walk outside so much. That's true, but the job takes its toll. One day, when a teenager opened the door for a package, his dog jumped me and bit me in the thigh. The wound wasn't all that bad, and I just kept delivering the mail.
