title: Court Says Hospitals Cannot Drug-Test Pregnant Women Without Consent
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  More than a decade ago, at the height of the crack cocaine epidemic, a public hospital in Charleston, S.C., began to test the urine of some pregnant women and to turn any evidence of cocaine use over to the police.

title: English Village Butchery Blamed for Mad Cow Deaths
description: LONDON, March 21 - A report into five deaths from the human form of mad cow disease in the same English village concluded today that the cause was a traditional local method of slaughter that permitted brain matter from diseased animals to contaminate cuts of meat.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE SOLA, MORALES, IGNASI
description: de SOLA-MORALES-Ignasi. The Museum of Modern Art notes with sadness the death of Ignasi de Sola-Morales. From 1978-1986 Mr. de Sola-Morales worked very closely with the Museum's Department of Architecture and Design on the reconstruction of Mies van der Rohe's 1929 German Pavilion in the city of Barcelona. He was a widely respected architect, critic and teacher and his contributions to architecture will be long remembered. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director Terrence Riley, Chief Curator of Architecture and Design The Museum of Modern Art, NY

title: Oil Rig Sinks; Some Leaking Is 'Inevitable,' Official Says
description: After five days of frantic efforts to keep it afloat and recover the bodies of nine workers left onboard, the world's largest offshore oil platform sank into the South Atlantic this morning.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about the AIDS epidemic in South Africa referred incompletely to World Trade Organization rules that may permit countries to violate patents, a step that could result in cheaper AIDS drugs. The rules allow such action in circumstances of extreme urgency as well as in national emergencies.

title: Oscar, Master of Suspense; Some Top Categories Are Just Too Close to Call
description: An Oscar season that began late last year in uncertainty, then gradually gained something resembling focus, is coming down to the wire in renewed uncertainty, with the potential for surprises in almost all the major categories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEHRER, SAMUEL

title: This Fish Adores Salt
description: THERE is a big difference between salt cod and salted fresh cod. Salt cod, traditionally made to preserve the fish without refrigeration or freezing, has a texture completely unlike fresh cod. Because it is dried, the fish must be soaked for nearly a day before cooking, both to rehydrate it and to remove the excess salt.

title: The Possessions Go, The Memories Stay
description: MADELINE PHILIPS'S life has gone through many aesthetic phases. In the 1950's, there was the matching monogrammed bath-towel phase (a must). In the 60's, it was the olive-green phase, in which she swaddled the living room and dining rooms entirely in olive green, including the piano (which she painted). But no phase, past or present, could have prepared her for the next one: the 11-by-18 phase.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: CRUDE OIL FALLS. Crude oil declined after the Federal Reserve's interest rate cut was seen as too small to increase demand. In New York, crude oil for May delivery fell 34 cents, or 1.3 percent, to $26.12 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, LELAND S.
description: BROWN-Leland S., 92. Of Bedford, New York. Died peacefully at home on March 17. Loving husband of Mary Murray Brown, who predeceased him by only one year. Mr. Brown is survived by his sister Alberta Brown of Santa Barbara, Cal; two children, Morgan S. Brown of Louisville, KY., and Janet B. Jussel of Bedford, four grandchildren, Sarah B. Robbins, John S. Bradbury, Jr., Catherine M. Jussel and David S. Jussel, and one great grandchild, Henry Robbins. Contributions to The Trustees of Reservations, Chappaquiddick Committee, Box 2106, 18 Helen Avenue, Vineyard Haven, MA. 02568-2106.

title: A Filmmaker's Look at a World of Waste Not, Want Not
description: Forget ''Chocolat.'' The most seductive food movie right now is Agns Varda's documentary ''The Gleaners and I,'' playing at least through Tuesday at Film Forum in SoHo.

title: Retirement
description: AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, has a powerful reputation and more members than Canada has citizens. Yet there are signs that it is losing its edge.

title: The Road to the Final Four; Heaven Is a Spot on the Bench For Little-Used Duke Seniors
description: Over their four-year careers at Duke, J. D. Simpson and Ryan Caldbeck have been part of the following: a 129-15 record, four regular season Atlantic Coast Conference titles, three conference tournament titles and an N.C.A.A. men's basketball championship game.

title: Skull May Alter Experts' View Of Human Descent's Branches
description: Paleontologists in Africa have found a 3.5 million-year-old skull from what they say is an entirely new branch of the early human family tree, a discovery that threatens to overturn the prevailing view that a single line of descent stretched through the early stages of human ancestry.

title: An Impresario's Passions, Gratified
description: THE last -- just ask him -- of the red hot impresarios, Sid Bernstein, the dumpling-esque promoter who takes credit for importing Beatlemania to America 37 years ago, opens the door of his apartment clad only in his baby blue skivvies. Visualize a genial, gray-haired Tweedle Dum, or Dee, lurking in the near buff in a high-rise hallway: it's a striking sight, one for which Mr. Bernstein, 82, apologizes as his publicist shrieks, ''Sid, you're naked!''

description: AFRICA

description: DUFFNEY-Don A. March 9, 2001. Suddenly in Ormond Beach, FL. Husband of Margaret (Maher) and brother of Louise Clawson. Burial in Otsego, MI.

title: Even Poor Say Life Improved In Last Decade, Survey Finds
description: Even New Yorkers who did not benefit financially from the city's surging economy in the late 1990's became more satisfied with their neighborhoods, according to a survey to be released today by the Columbia University School of Social Work.

title: A Partnership Worth Preserving
description: SHANGHAI  With the election of a new American president, Sino-American relations often go through a period of adjustment and the testing of limits. When China's deputy premier, Qian Qichen, and President George W. Bush meet tomorrow, their primary task will be to reach agreement on the general framework for bilateral relations in the coming four years.

title: Some Advice on Getting Advice
description: AN imminent hanging, Samuel Johnson wrote, concentrates the mind wonderfully. So does imminent retirement, with a difference: the issue is not saving one's neck but living out one's days in reasonable comfort after the weekly paycheck is gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAINEN, JACOB
description: KAINEN-Jacob. The Katarina Rich Perlow Gallery is saddened by the sudden loss of our artist and friend whose distinguished career in the art spanned over 70 years working til the very end. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Ruth, his sons and family.

title: Peasant Food From a Kitchen Inspired by a King
description: Top chefs flaunt their fancy state-of-the-art French ovens and stoves, but in their hearts many long for a simpler time, when cooking and baking meant brick ovens and not an inch of stainless steel. That could explain the number of celebrity chefs who have visited Peasant, a year-old restaurant in a former garage at 194 Elizabeth Street (Spring Street) on the edge of Little Italy. There, Frank DeCarlo, above, the chef and a co-owner, has installed a handmade brick oven, grill, rotisserie and cooktop with tandoor-like wells, all of which use wood and charcoal as fuel.

title: Infamous Killer in Everywoman Guise
description: Inspired by the Snyder-Gray case, a murderous love trial that transfixed the nation in the 1920's, Sophie Treadwell's 1928 play, ''Machinal,'' mines middle-class tragedy from the headlong pace and dehumanization of the machine age.

title: Syracuse Lacross Hopes to Bounce Back
description: When this season began, most people in lacrosse thought the best men's college team would be Syracuse, a perennial powerhouse. The Orangemen were that until this past Saturday, when they were upset by Johns Hopkins, 11-10, at Syracuse's Carrier Dome.

title: Argentina Calls on Ex-Economics Chief to Halt Slide
description: Scrambling to keep Argentina from plunging further into recession and political disarray, President Fernando de la Ra cast aside more than a year of austerity policies and called on Domingo Cavallo, the country's economic hero of the early 1990's, to come to the rescue.

title: Nursing Home Workers in Connecticut Conduct a One-Day Walkout
description: About 4,500 nursing home workers staged a one-day strike today at 40 homes throughout the state, demanding higher staffing levels and wages. But some of the strikers said they were uncertain whether their employers would allow them to return to work Wednesday.

title: Safety Harbor Spa
description: It's easier to relax when you're spending less money -- that seems to be the principle behind a 20 percent discount on the introductory spa package at Safety Harbor Resort and Spa, on 22 acres overlooking Tampa Bay. The three-night package includes accommodations, three meals for each night's stay and one 25-minute massage per guest for each night. There's also unlimited access to the resort's 50,000-square-foot spa, fitness classes and daytime tennis. The rates are $525 a person, based on double occupancy, through March 31 and $470 a person, double, April 1 to 30. Availability is limited and 17.5 percent taxes and service charges are extra. Contact (888) 237-8772 or www.safetyharborspa.com .

title: Colleges Try Distance Learning Off Campus
description: As universities grapple with the challenge of incorporating e-learning into their educational offerings, many are discovering that the technology is better suited to students outside their traditional audience of 18-24 year olds.

title: String of Empty Aprils Cannot Kill the Dream
description: The game had been over for about an hour, it was late in the afternoon, and the spacious clubhouse was empty of any other Mets. But Bubba Carpenter was still clinging to a bat and still sweating as he awaited his next lonely session of batting practice. He was playing baseball for another day and he did not want it to end, a perfect metaphor for his nomadic career.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOUTHGATE, ANNA F.
description: SOUTHGATE-Anna F. Of Manchester, Massachusetts, died on Sunday, March 18, after a short illness. She was 71 years old. Mrs. Southgate was for many years a director of the Barringer Crater Company, and she wrote a history of the Meteor Crater discovered in Arizona by her grandfather. The publication will be released later this year. For 20 years, she was also a gallery instructor at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston. She was born Anna F. Hart in Philadelphia in 1929, and grew up in Princeton, N.J., attending Miss Fine's School, and later graduating from Smith College with honors in 1950. She is survived by her husband, Richard W. Southgate of Manchester; 4 children, Richard W. Southgate Jr. of Essex, Mass, Sarah Barringer Gordon of Philadelphia, Rebecca Southgate of Paris, France, and Jay Southgate of Marshfield, Vermont; and six grandchildren. There will be a small family gathering, but in accordance with her wishes, there will be no public service. The family asks that in lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to either the Hospice of the North Shore, the American Friends Service Committee, or the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston.

title: As Savings Go Up, Worries Go Down (A Little)
description: THE number of Americans saving for retirement has jumped sharply in the last few years, a recent New York Times poll has found. And while a majority of those questioned worry about setting aside enough money, anxiety on the subject appears to have eased, at least a bit.

title: Quarterly Net Is Down 13% At Goldman
description: The Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that its net income fell 13 percent in its first quarter, but the decline was less than Wall Street analysts had been expecting given the difficult operating climate.

title: Long Up for Sale, Insurer May Have a New Owner Soon
description: When Prudential of Britain agreed last week to buy American General, the big Texas life insurer, for $26.5 billion, the deal left the Liberty Financial Companies, a modest-size asset-management company in Boston, out in the cold.

title: Foes of Bush Rule on Family Planning Take a New Tack
description: A bipartisan group of legislators announced today that they were adopting a new strategy in the effort to overturn the Bush administration's restrictions on international family planning assistance.

The change in household spending was adjusted for price changes, and the change in bank lending excluded loans to financial institutions and the central government.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE CLARIANT STARTS YEAR SLOWLY The chemical manufacturer Clariant said its sales were off to a weak start this year, and that it planned to focus on its core business. The company's net profit for 2000 was down 14 percent, hurt by the cost of buying BTP, a British drug-ingredients producer. Clariant, a Swiss company that sells deicers for runways and ingredients for the drug Viagra, said it would cut 800 jobs at its Hoechst specialty chemicals business by 2002, sell a pigments plant and outsource 500 service jobs. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: A Moroccan Outpost in the Shadow of the Port Authority
description: BEYOND Lotfi's, a theater district old-timer, and one or two others, Moroccan restaurants have been as rare as starry nights in Manhattan. But in the last year several new ones have opened, including Le Souk in the East Village, Sago on the Lower East Side and Tagine near the Port Authority Bus Terminal. While the East Village and the Lower East Side have authentic bohemian credentials, both neighborhoods are in metamorphosis, as art galleries and boutiques redecorate the streets. The new Moroccans downtown reflect their neighborhoods' heightened sense of style.

title: They Make the Case on Capitol Hill for the AARP
description: JOHN ROTHER of AARP may be Capitol Hill's most high-profile lobbyist on retirement and aging, but there are others whose grass- roots constituencies, fund-raising abilities or command of the issues can also capture lawmakers' attention. Asked to name the top advocates, experts and Congressional staff members mentioned these nine most frequently:

title: The Reforms a Tax Cut Ruins
description: President Bush has had notably little to say about one major loser in his budget proposal: serious Social Security reform. He has done worse than just kick the ball down the road by recommending a Social Security Commission. As his tax cut depletes the general revenue surpluses, it depletes the chances for any president or Congress in the near future to pass long-lasting reform.

title: Documents Allege Abuse of Nuns by Priests
description: Confidential Roman Catholic Church reports written over a period of seven years allege numerous cases of sexual abuse of nuns by priests and a failure by church leaders to discipline the clerics who were involved.

title: Study Links Estrogen Use to Cancer Risk
description: Women who took the hormone estrogen after menopause for 10 years or more starting in the 1970's or early 1980's had a higher risk of dying from ovarian cancer than women who did not use it, a study has found.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZACK, BEATRICE BODIN
description: ZACK-Beatrice Bodin, 86, of NYC. Died on March 17, 2001 in Baltimore, MD. For 60 years, beloved wife of David Zack. Devoted mother of Dr. Brian Zack (and wife Virginia August) of Princeton, NJ and of Dr. Donald Zack (and wife Dr. Ellen Okun) of Baltimore, MD. Cherished grandmother of Rebecca, Ian and Daniel Zack of Princeton, and of Rachel, Elizabeth and Andrew Zack of Baltimore. Private memorial service. She will be deeply missed.

title: Feeling Lethargic Is Common, But Check the Cause
description: Problems like worrying, confusion and loss of appetite are common in old age, but the cause is not always obvious. It can be emotional, physical or a combination of the two, and a professional evaluation can ease your mind more than you may think. People with memory problems, for instance, may fear they have Alzheimer's disease, but depression is a much more likely cause.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, ALEXANDER E.
description: ROSENTHAL-Alexander E. The Directors, Officers, and Staff of GNY Insurance Companies mourn the loss of their esteemed Chairman and dear friend. Alex Rosenthal joined the company in 1934 as a lawyer, and rose rapidly in the company to become its Chairman of the Board and CEO. He was a skillful leader who served our companies with distinction for over 66 years, and was singularly responsible for our great success. He was a compassionate and caring person deeply involved with the welfare of our employees. We shall miss his judicious counsel in our midst. He leaves a void that shall deeply affect us all. We extend our deepest sympathy to his dear wife Beatrice and his sons Richard and James. Warren W. Heck, President

title: LIBBEY WILL TRIM PRODUCTION AS EARNINGS MISS TARGETS
description: Libbey Inc., a leading maker of glassware, said yesterday that it would reduce production at plants in the United States and at a joint venture in Mexico and that its first-quarter earnings would be below analysts' estimates. The company said it was selling fewer products to some industrial, export and retail customers and had been hurt by higher energy costs. Its chief financial officer, Kenneth Wilkes, said the company would reduce the number of hours that its plants operate. He would not say if there would be layoffs. Libbey, based in Toledo, Ohio, said it expected net income of 24 cents to 28 cents a share in the first quarter. It was expected to earn 41 cents in a Thomson Financial/First Call survey.

title: Of Social Security and Saving
description: CONGRESS has embarked on a great debate over the future of Social Security and Medicare. In the next few years, politicians, health policy experts, actuaries and lobbyists will dissect scores of proposals of mind-numbing complexity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGOWSKY, THE HON. EDWARD T.
description: ROGOWSKY-The Hon. Edward T. The staff, faculty and friends of the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development deeply mourn the loss of our friend, colleague and collaborator, Ed Rogowsky. Ed was an inspiration and mentor to generations of students at Brooklyn College and at the City University of New York where he won their love, loyalty and admiration by his humor and intellect. His friendship knew no boundaries and he sought to befriend, help and educate everyone. He brought insight, integrity and clarity into New York's political community. He inspired all those who had the opportunity to serve with him on the NYC Planning Commission since his appointment in 1990. Brooklyn, where he was born and lived; New York which he loved, studied, wrote about and served; and the world are far better places because Ed cared and played a role in trying to make them better. Ed was a father, grandfather, a loving partner to Peter and part of many extended families, including our own. He will be missed. Rudy Bryant, Associate Director Ron Shiffman, Director

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGGIN, BERNICE L.
description: MAGGIN-Bernice L. At the age of 85. Formerly of Great Neck, L.I. Devoted wife of the late Judge Sherwood Maggin. Beloved mother of Bruce and Jackie Maggin, and Walter and Ellenbeth Yoser. Cherished grandmother of Benjamin, Daniel, Mary Ellen, Susannah, Elisabeth, Allison and Jonathan. Great grandmother of Rebecca, Adam, Julie and David. Loving sister of Dolly and Jay. Services Friday, March 23nd at Temple Beth El, 5 Old Mill Rd, Great Neck, L.I. title: My Underwood, Forever
description: Recently my old black Underwood Standard, model S, vintage 1941 typewriter crashed. What happened was this: The ribbon stalled, and the keys drilled holes where it stopped. The ''n'' hit above or below the line, the ''a'' and the ''q'' jammed, the ''s'' wandered -- so finally I just abandoned it. We'd been hitched for 37 years, ever since its predecessor, a twin, melted in the fire that gutted my family's apartment.

title: In Austin, Bush's Coattails Bear Precious Crumbs
description: GEORGE W. BUSH is the third Texan to occupy the Oval Office in the last 40 years, following his father (whose Texas credentials were often questioned because of his Connecticut Yankee antecedents) and Lyndon B. Johnson (whose Texas credentials were as impeccable as Sam Houston's). So it goes without saying that he eats barbecue. That's what Texas pols do, the same way Boston pols eat clam chowder.

title: 2 Quandaries Facing Bush
description: Hardly a day goes by at the White House without President Bush warning of the two urgent national afflictions that have defined his first two months in office: a ''sputtering'' economy whose growth has ''stalled'' and an ''energy crisis'' that threatens to spread beyond California.

title: Taming the Wild Horseradish
description: Fresh horseradish, pretty potent stuff, is increasingly popular among chefs. But grating it can be a challenge. Some chefs are now using Microplane graters and zesters. With these, the root is easily transformed into a feathery cloud of sharply flavored wisps.

title: From Second to Left
description: Every manager, every coach, every player in baseball pays homage to the fundamentals, to hitting the cutoff man, advancing the runner and so forth. But some fundamentals are more fundamental than others, and among them is the act of throwing a baseball. Kids find their way into the game by playing catch, and though the rhythm of throwing changes as a player matures, the feel of the underlying movement and release has deep roots in the body's memory. To lose that feel is to lose something profound and by its nature inarticulable. That is what Chuck Knoblauch, the Yankees' second baseman, has been struggling with for three seasons. Knoblauch's problem throwing the ball to first base probably originates in unwanted consciousness -- the awareness of trying to do what he has done almost unconsciously for so many years.

title: Justices Rule S. Carolina Must Clarify Jury Orders
description: The Supreme Court rebuked the South Carolina Supreme Court today for failing to heed the message of a 1994 decision that jurors in death penalty cases must be informed that a defendant who receives the alternative sentence of life without parole will in fact never be released from prison.

title: Was Your Nest Egg Scrambled? Time to Diversify Your Omelet
description: THE great American nest egg is getting scrambled. A year ago, when the Nasdaq index started tumbling, it looked as if individual investors would lose nothing more than the pile of fun money they had built up in technology stocks. By now, of course, it has become clear that real money is at stake: recent 401(k) statements have been the worst crop in years.

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET YAHOO FILLS A TOP POST Yahoo Inc. said yesterday that Gregory G. Coleman, who most recently worked as a top executive at Reader's Digest, would become its executive vice president for North American operations. In the newly created position, Mr. Coleman will be responsible for sales, marketing and client service, as well as Yahoo's consumer and programming initiatives. He will join the company in late April and report to Jeffrey Mallett, Yahoo's president and chief operating officer. At Reader's Digest, where he was senior vice president, Mr. Coleman oversaw all advertising, circulation, production, customer service and financial initiatives for the magazine division. Several top executives have left Yahoo recently, including Anil Singh, its chief marketing executive, and Timothy Koogle, its chief executive. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAMPANELLA, JOSEPH
description: CAMPANELLA-Joseph. Age 94 of Elmira, New York, died on Monday, March 19, 2001 at St. Joseph's Hospital. Joseph, also known as ''Joe Cappi'' & ''Campy'', was born in Bari, Italy, February 3, 1907. He emigrated to New York City at the age of 5. Joe is survived by his loving wife of 60 years, Dorothy Iacovelli Campanella; sons, Lewis J. Campanella of Syosset, NY, Peter F. Campanella of Elmira, with wife Monica and their two children, Christopher and Jennifer. Friends are invited to St. Margaret's Church, 80th and Juniper Valley Road, Queens at 11:00AM on Friday, March 23, 2001 for a Prayer Service. Interment will follow in St. John's Cemetery, Queens. Joe was a Big Band Leader, Entertainer and Restaurateur, who brought happiness to many throughout his life. He grew up in Manhattan, NY where he became an entertainer and a Big Band Leader known as ''Joe Cappi and his Orchestra of Millionaires''. While in New York City Joe also served as Assistant to the Deputy Mayor. Subsequently he moved to Port Washington, NY where he opened and operated a wellknown restaurant called Campy's. Campy retired to Boyton Beach, Florida and then to Elmira, NY, where he continued to entertain his personal friends telling them to ''Be Happy with Cappi''. Joe was a wonderful, loving and beloved husband, father, father-in-law, grandfather and family man. In all respects, Joe was a great American. In lieu of flowers, donations in Joseph's memory may be directed to the Nursing Education Fund, C/O St. Joseph's Hospital Foundation, 555 E. Market Street, Elmira, New York 14901.

title: CONSULTANT ANNOUNCES CUTBACKS
description: Xpedior, an Internet consulting company, said yesterday that it would close four offices and lay off 300 employees, or 42 percent of its work force. The cutback follows two previous rounds of layoffs that reduced the work force of about 1,400 by half. The Chicago-based company will close offices in New York, Dallas, Denver and San Jose, Calif., and reduce staff at its Alexandria, Va., office. The company said Anthony Capers, its president, and two other top executives, Mark Hansen and Robert Whitehead, had resigned. Dean Dranias, a spokesman, said the company had enough cash to cover its operating costs only through June 30 and was considering its alternatives. ''We're in a planning stage,'' Mr. Dranias said. Xpedior also said it expected to be declared in default on loans from Comerica Bank. title: The Fed and the Stock Market
description: The Federal Reserve cut its key short-term interest rate by half a percentage point yesterday for the third time this year, hopeful that lower borrowing costs will help avert a recession by encouraging businesses to invest more and consumers to spend more. Wall Street was disappointed that the Fed did not cut the rate more aggressively, and traders unloaded stocks late in the day, driving the market averages down. The Fed's refusal to cut rates further was widely interpreted as a reluctance to use its monetary powers to prop up faltering stock prices. But the central bank also sent a signal that it was willing to step in with further rate cuts soon, if needed, and that it was cognizant of the emerging interdependence between moves in stock prices and the ''real'' economy.

title: Reckonings; Half a Loaf
description: It could have been the one-two punch that turned the world economy around. On Monday the Bank of Japan met to set monetary policy in the world's second-largest economy, amid hopes that last year's disastrous decision to raise interest rates would be decisively reversed. Yesterday the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee met to set interest rates for the world's biggest economy, amid hopes that it would act decisively to stop the slide in America's economic growth.

title: China Comes Calling
description: Tomorrow's White House visit by China's top-ranking diplomat, Qian Qichen, offers President Bush an opportunity to set a constructive course with Beijing. Few international relationships are as important, and as complex, as that between the United States and China. Vital issues of economics, trade and security are intertwined, along with compelling human rights concerns. As the 21st century unfolds, Beijing's advance to the front ranks of global power assures that all of these issues will take on ever greater significance.

ICP Vortex makes devices that speed up access to data on Internet-based storage systems.

title: EARNINGS AT NIKE PLUMMET 33% IN THE LATEST QUARTER
description: Nike, the biggest maker of athletic shoes, said yesterday that its fiscal third-quarter profit fell 33 percent. Net income fell to $97.4 million, or 35 cents a share, from $145.3 million, or 52 cents, in the period a year earlier. Sales in the quarter ended Feb. 28 were little changed at $2.17 billion. ''To say the third quarter is disappointing to us is an understatement,'' its chief financial officer, Donald Blair, said in a conference call. Nike, based in Beaverton, Ore., said it would earn 60 cents to 65 cents a share in the current quarter. Last month, the company said its earnings would miss expectations because flawed distribution software caused products to be delivered late or not at all.

The proposals have raised concerns among environmentalists because diesel generators pollute much more than even coal-burning power plants.

Vin and Sprit will spend $742 million, in part to buy 49 percent of a joint venture with Fortune Brands, to be called Future Brands, which will distribute Absolut in the United States. It will also take a 10 percent stake in Fortune's Jim Beam bourbon division. Clariant, a Swiss company that sells deicers for runways and ingredients for the drug Viagra, said it would cut 800 jobs at its Hoechst specialty chemicals business by 2002, sell a pigments plant and outsource 500 service jobs. He will join the company in late April and report to Jeffrey Mallett, Yahoo's president and chief operating officer. At Reader's Digest, where he was senior vice president, Mr. Coleman oversaw all advertising, circulation, production, customer service and financial initiatives for the magazine division. Abating inflation allowed the central bank to cut rates a quarter-point, to 5.75 percent, in February. Suzanne Kapner

title: Give Edison a Try

The voting, which will continue until March 30 by phone, mail and the Internet as well as in person, has provoked intense and sometimes bitter debate, dividing parents, educators, politicians and community leaders. Despite the uncertainties of this decision and Edison's disputed record in other school districts around the country, we hope the parents in New York vote for the Edison proposal. It offers at least some hope for improvement in five schools whose performance has been abysmal.

title: Metro Business Briefing; OFFICIAL TO CONSIDER STADIUMS
description: Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco of New Jersey yesterday asked Lewis M. Eisenberg, chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, to look into professional sports arenas in the state. Mr. Eisenberg will study the financial viability of a proposed stadium in downtown Newark and consider possible uses for the Continental Airlines Arena, which the stadium would replace, Mr. DiFrancesco said. Mr. Eisenberg will also consider future sports-related development projects to satisfy legislators in South Jersey. The announcement comes a day after Mr. DiFrancesco publicized his opposition to building a shopping and entertainment complex in the New Jersey Meadowlands that environmentalists have long opposed. Political leaders in Bergen County, however, favor the $1 billion mall, known as Meadowlands Mills. On Tuesday, Mr. DiFrancesco said he would work with the developers to build the mall elsewhere in Bergen County, perhaps in East Rutherford, where the arena now stands. Andrew Jacobs

''By combining our event information and ticketing transaction capability with AOL's unparalleled audience, we substantially increase our ticketing distribution network,'' John Pleasants, chief executive at Ticketmaster, said yesterday in a statement. AOL Moviefone, which says it serves one in five moviegoers, hopes to extend its reach by offering one-click sales of movie tickets to users of Citysearch guides, while Ticketmaster's Match.com will become the main AOL forum for personal ads. Shares of Citrix, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., fell $2.13, or 10.7 percent, to $17.69. Shares of Sequoia, based in Columbia, Md., gained 53 cents, or 10.6 percent, to $5.53. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: WIRELESS GIANTS PLAN GAMES STANDARD
description: Ericsson, Motorola and Siemens said yesterday that they would work together to develop a games standard for wireless communications devices. At conferences in San Jose, Calif., and Hanover, Germany, the three companies released a plan to allow developers to create a broader range of game content on one standard platform. ''Right now, developers spend too much time writing their own game platforms,'' said Tim Krauskopf, a vice president at Motorola. title: To Shop for Modern Houses With a Leg Up From a Mouse
description: On eBay you can bid on modern house plans, but you usually can't find modern houses. For that, you can go to www.emodernhomes.com, where you can window-shop for houses all over the country and indicate your interest via e-mail. Last week a Paul Rudolph house, above, on Casey Key near Sarasota, Fla., was listed for $2.2 million. (It has since sold.) Offerings range from a 6,000-square-foot midcentury house with original fixtures and furnishings, a separate artist's studio and a writer's cottage in East Patchogue, N.Y. ($285,000), to a 1955 glass-walled house in Los Angeles with a landscaped yard and a pool ($995,000). In addition to listings, emodernhomes.com offers the names of architects and interior designers skilled in remodeling modern houses. The site was established by Scott Cheverie of Cape Cod, the founder of Echoes, a quarterly magazine about Modernism. Realtors and individual sellers pay a onetime fee of $100 to place an ad with photos and contact information; designers and architects pay $25 a month to advertise their businesses. Mr. Cheverie says he exercises quality control, evaluating the architecture and services offered. The site currently carries a remodeled 1939 house in Diamond Head, Honolulu, top ($6.9 million), and a 1969 house in Palm Springs, Calif., above, by William Cody, a pioneer in desert Modernism, decorated with Saarinen furniture in the dining room, rear, and Arthur Elrod bar stools and Joe Colombo furniture in the living room. Courtney Newman, the owner of the house, has a vintage furniture store in Palm Springs called Modern Way. The Cody house is available for $479,000, but the furnishings are extra.

Service and interment are private. Donations may be sent to The Hebrew Home For The Aged at Riverdale, 5901 Palisade Avenue, Bronx, N.Y. 10471

title: The SAT Is a.) Good b.) Bad c.) Both
description: To the Editor:

title: JUSTICES, 6-3, BAR SOME DRUG TESTS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that hospital workers cannot constitutionally test maternity patients for illegal drug use without their consent if the purpose is to alert the police to a crime.

title: Murmurs in Baghdad Of a Weakened Boss
description: Even if little has changed in the way Saddam Hussein maintains control, growing numbers of Iraqis now risk whispering their hatred of him. And in two interviews in the past 15 days, senior officials have even spoken of his eventual death.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: Pakistan Detains Party Leaders Ahead of Rally
description: The police in Pakistan detained more than 20 leaders of political parties today, and since Monday have arrested hundreds of party workers, according to politicians and human rights lawyers.

title: Hearings Start in Suit Over Graham Legacy
description: Hearings began on an appropriately vivid note yesterday in the suit brought by the Martha Graham Trust against the Martha Graham Center of Contemporary Dance in Federal District Court in Manhattan. The suit seeks to prevent the center from using the Graham name and alleges trademark infringement and other damages to the trust, which licenses Graham's dances.

title: 'I' Before 'E,' Forever
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Steeler Wants His Mementos
description: Dennis Winston has a plea: Whoever has his old Pittsburgh Steelers helmet, he wants it back. He also wants returned the Steelers jerseys he wore in two Super Bowls (No. 53, if that helps), the Rolex watch he got for playing with the Arkansas Razorbacks in the Cotton Bowl and the most valuable player trophy he received from the New Orleans Saints.

title: Helen Bevington, 94, Wry Author, Professor and Tireless Tourist
description: Helen Smith Bevington, a poet, essayist, English professor and tireless tourist who roamed the world in search of her own Shangri-La, died on Friday at the home of her son, David, in Chicago. She was 94.

title: Albany Panel Fails to Resolve an Impasse on Health Bill
description: ALBANY, March 21  A bipartisan legislative committee that was impaneled to reconcile the sharp divisions between Republican and Democratic versions of a women's health bill has dissolved without an agreement. Chief among the sticking points is a provision that would require insurers to cover contraceptives, a provision that the Roman Catholic Church bitterly opposes.

title: Mother Nature And Her Children
description: Lava

title: Not-So-Simple Reasons for Dropout Rate
description: Three weeks ago, when New York City school officials announced a two percentage point rise in the dropout rate for the second year in a row, they blamed the state's tough new graduation requirements and the city's own decision to stop the automatic promotion of students in the lower grades.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Article 2001032290647529657 -- No Title
description: March 22, 2001

title: Councilman Ends Effort to Repeal Term-Limit Bill
description: The effort to repeal term limits for City Council members came to an unceremonious end yesterday, as the councilman who had been orchestrating it quietly announced that he would not try to resurrect the repeal bill after its narrow defeat in a committee last week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGOWSKY, EDWARD T.
description: ROGOWSKY-Edward T. The Board, staff and members of the Empire State Pride Agenda mourn the passing of Edward T. Rogowsky, political activist, scholar and public servant. Ed served his city and his country with distinction. He was a leader in the campaign to elect Bill Bradley President of the United States and helped to elevate and change the national discussion of the rights of lesbians, gay men, bisexuals and transgender people and their families. We offer our deep condolences to his partner, Peter McGarry, to his sons and grandson and to his enormous circle of family and friends. Duffy Palmer, Co-Chair Jeff Soref, Co-Chair Matt Foreman, Exec Director

title: Study of Chemicals in Americans Shows Encouraging Trends
description: The most comprehensive study yet of the levels of potentially harmful substances in Americans has some encouraging findings, and sometimes surprising ones.

title: China Asserts U.S. Scholar Confesses Security 'Crimes'
description: BEIJING, March 22  A government spokesman said today that Gao Zhan, a United States-based sociologist who has been held incommunicado since Feb. 11 for unspecified "activities damaging state security," had openly confessed her crimes. But the spokesman, Sun Yuxi of the Foreign Ministry, refused to say what she had confessed to, only noting that the investigation was continuing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLENNON, CHARLES E.
description: GLENNON-Charles E. Of New York City died on March 18, 2001. He is survived by his sister Patricia Stroffolino, also survived by two nieces & one nephew. Reposing at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral services will be held at the Funeral Home, Friday at 11AM. Interment private.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about a murder suspect in New Jersey who was killed in a gun battle with the police referred incorrectly in some copies to the Bergen County official involved in a jurisdictional dispute with the Hackensack police chief about the case. It was the county prosecutor, not the sheriff.

title: Israeli Official Is Found Guilty On Sex Charges
description: Yitzhak Mordechai, a former defense minister and transportation minister, was convicted today of committing ''indecent acts'' against two women subordinates. The court said that Mr. Mordechai had tried to use force to molest the women.

title: Home or Away, the Devils Just Continue Winning
description: So much for the home-ice letdown.

title: A New Online Spot to Gather To Find a Game or Analyze One
description: Video game players may soon have a new one-stop game destination online. It will demonstrate, distribute and sell games, provide a forum for people to discuss them, match up players and even help game designers develop games.

title: Environmental Abyss
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sensible Tax on Fortunes
description: Critics have cited both moral and economic objections to the estate tax, and eliminating it is a key component of President Bush's $1.6 trillion tax cut package. Those with moral objections have a point. People who accumulated wealth have at least a limited moral right to distribute it as they wish. It's far less clear, however, that recipients of such bequests have a corresponding claim of right to receive them without taxation.

title: OWENS-ILLINOIS TO SELL ITS MONEY-MANAGEMENT UNIT
description: Owens-Illinois Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Harbor Capital Advisors money-management business to Robeco Groep of the Netherlands for $490 million to reduce debt while preparing to pay asbestos claims. Owens-Illinois, which makes glass containers, is selling units that do not fit with its packaging business as it deals with health-damage claims from people exposed to asbestos products it once made and with the $5.85 billion in debt it had as of Dec. 31. The sale of Harbor Capital, the money manager for the Owens-Illinois family of mutual funds, along with other asset sales and insurance settlements, is expected to reduce the debt by about $700 million through June, the company said.

title: The Orangemen Hope to Rebound
description: When this season began, most people in lacrosse thought the best men's college team would be Syracuse, a perennial powerhouse. The Orangemen were that until this past Saturday, when they were upset by Johns Hopkins, 11-10, at the Carrier Dome in Syracuse.

title: RUSSIAN DIPLOMATS ORDERED EXPELLED IN A COUNTERMOVE
description: In a retaliatory move, the Bush administration has ordered a number of Russian diplomats to leave the country in the wake of the arrest last month of an F.B.I. agent on charges that he spied for Moscow for more than 15 years, American officials said today.

title: Taking the Greeneville Case to Trial
description: The Navy's public inquiry into the collision between one of its nuclear submarines, the Greeneville, and a Japanese fishing trawler has produced enough evidence of errors and oversights by the Navy crew to warrant a court-martial proceeding. Such a step, the military equivalent of a criminal trial, would establish whether the submarine's captain and other crew members should be found liable for the loss of nine passengers on the Japanese vessel.

title: Partial Blame Put on Mother For Son's Fall From Train Car
description: A report released yesterday by the state's Public Transportation Safety Board concluded that at least part of the blame for the death of a 3-year-old boy who fell from an open subway door last December belongs with his mother, who investigators said was not supervising her son closely enough.

title: Ojeda Can Begin to Look Ahead Only by Getting Back to Baseball
description: Sure, there are moments when he thinks about what happened to him and two friends on a black lake in central Florida during a spring training that seems so long ago and yet does not. The moments drift in and out of his life, the mental sneak attacks that those who have experienced death up close could understand. Sometimes, these moments linger and sometimes they dissolve. Mostly, Bobby Ojeda forces himself to focus on the future. He has suffered enough.

title: Suddenly on the Radar in Hollywood's Stratosphere
description: LAST week Leelai Demoz, a not-so-famous actor who levitated into Oscar territory on his first try at producing, found himself back in Los Angeles, a place he'd gladly abandoned after a mid-90's campaign for acting work failed to make his star rise in proportion to his ambitions. But this time around, he was the toast of the town.

title: A Downloading Hazard
description: To the Editor:

title: Levy Seeks 21% Increase for Schools
description: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy proposed a $2.4 billion increase yesterday in the $11.4 billion budget for the city's public schools, with much of the money earmarked to provide more hours and days of instruction to children in 618 low-performing schools. The budget request met with immediate skepticism from City Hall, where the mayor was calling for spending cuts.

title: Justice, While Not Blind to Celebrity, Is Not Exactly Dazzled, Either
description: Depending on who was watching, the sight of the hip-hop impresario Sean Combs -- Puffy to his fans -- striding out of a Manhattan court building a free man last Friday was either a triumph or a travesty.

title: The DopeWars Fantasy
description: To the Editor:

title: Visit Is First by Foreign Warship to New Base : Singapore Welcomes U.S. Aircraft Carrier
description: SINGAPORE  Amid increasing turmoil in Indonesia and other parts of Southeast Asia, Singapore, a small island state that has made itself prosperous through trade, is holding out a welcome mat for the United States in the hope that it will help to stabilize the region, Singapore officials and analysts say.

title: A Question Unasked
description: There was a great deal at stake when Cmdr. Scott D. Waddle made the surprise decision to testify here on Tuesday about how the submarine he commanded, the Greeneville, accidentally sank a Japanese fishing trawler while surfacing last month.

title: Developer Daughters, Born to Build
description: FIVE of New York's most powerful real estate developers gathered for a photo shoot one morning last week on a rooftop balcony at the Waldorf-Astoria. Lisa Silverstein, Amy Rose and Laurie Zucker had seen their children off to school. Beth Rudin DeWoody had already sat through a seminar associated with her charity work. Shari Goodstein had sipped a mochaccino at Starbucks, psyching herself up for the day ahead.

title: In America; A Bogus Race Issue
description: There have been a few stories in the press and some persistent behind-the-scenes chatter suggesting that Alan Hevesi, the city comptroller, who formally announced his candidacy for mayor on Tuesday, has a problem with African-American voters.

title: At Blooper Sites, the Fun Is in the Details
description: THE movie ''Titanic'' is known for having one of the heftiest production budgets in filmmaking history. But visitors to movie-mistakes.com, the Nitpickers Site and other sites dedicated to spotting gaffes in movies also know that ''Titanic'' includes a boatload of continuity and factual errors. Of the 1,375 movies listed at movie-mistakes.com, ''Titanic'' has the highest number of spotted mistakes, with ''The Matrix'' close behind.

title: LUCENT MAY PULL SHARE OFFER
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. may shelve the $6.5 billion initial offering of shares in its Agere Systems unit, Lucent's vice chairman, Ben Verwaayen, said. The Agere offering, which had been scheduled for yesterday, was postponed early in the day as Lucent sought investors. Now a decision on whether to proceed at all will be made next week, Mr. Verwaayen said. ''The week in which we will have a decision on the I.P.O. either way will be next week,'' he said. Agere is seeking to sell 500 million shares at $12 to $14 each.

title: Renovations Go Ahead, But Hold the Gilt
description: NORM ABRAM, the tool-belted sage of ''This Old House,'' has decided to hold off on building a new workshop in his own backyard in Carlyle, Mass.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page chart yesterday showing the effect of recent interest rate cuts on consumers misstated the average monthly payments on a $250,000 30-year fixed-rate mortgage, using the figures for a $125,000 loan instead. Last summer, when the rate was 8.5 percent, the payment was $1,922 a month, not $961. The payment now, with a rate of 7.02 percent, is $1,667, not $833.

title: Poor County Feels Domino Effect of Energy Crisis
description: Imperial County, located on the border with Mexico, has plenty of problems, but energy is not one of them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASALS, TONY
description: CASALS-Tony. Cherished friend for 25 years. You will be sorely and deeply missed. Barry G.

title: Rivalry Hits Road For Terps And Hoyas
description: The first time Georgetown and Maryland flirted on a basketball court was during the 1907-8 season and Georgetown won, 58-3. The last time they tangled was during the 1993-94 season and Maryland won in overtime, 84-83.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Boeing's Corporate Base To Move Out of Seattle

title: BROADCASTER WARNS ON PROFIT
description: Europe's biggest broadcaster, the RTL Group, warned that softening market conditions for advertising sales in 2001, combined with the effect of revamping its Pearson Television North America unit, would probably keep profits flat. The tempered outlook was delivered as the company, which agreed last month to be acquired by Bertelsmann of Germany, reported that profit in 2000 fell by 61 percent but met analysts' expectations. RTL is based in Luxembourg. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: RESIDENTIAL SALES
description: MANHATTAN

title: Article 2001032293254807743 -- No Title
description: It has made us forget the earthquake all of a sudden.

description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Big Victory for Employers

title: Bridge Official Announces Olympic Test
description: The focus of attention at the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals here on Tuesday night was not on the Vanderbilt Knockout, in which all but one of the top teams survived, but on the wider world. The president of the World Bridge Federation, Jos Damiani, announced in Paris that bridge would be a demonstration sport at the Winter Olympic Games in Salt Lake City next February.

title: China Asserts U.S. Scholar Confesses Security 'Crimes'
description: BEIJING, March 22  A government spokesman said today that Gao Zhan, a United States-based sociologist who has been held incommunicado since Feb. 11 for unspecified "activities damaging state security," had openly confessed her crimes. But the spokesman, Sun Yuxi of the Foreign Ministry, refused to say what she had confessed to, only noting that the investigation was continuing.

title: The Era of Showgirls Is Leaving Las Vegas
description: Marlene Maynard heard it all in a career in sequins and six-inch heels, but no one had ever called her a goddess before.

title: Ruling Likely to Bring Changes to Many Jobs
description: For a decade, companies have been wary of the growing propensity of employees to bring discrimination lawsuits and have been seeking a way to avoid jury trials and the risk of large damage awards.

title: 3Com Reports a Quarterly Loss and a Cost-Cutting Plan
description: Reporting narrower quarterly losses than expected, the 3Com Corporation announced a cost-cutting plan today that seeks to save $1 billion a year but that also means the demise of the company's short-lived kitchen-countertop Internet device.

title: Corrections
description: The Lessons column on March 7 about nonacademic steps to improve achievement among low-income students referred imprecisely to efforts by health centers in St. Louis to minimize lead poisoning. The centers have been testing children for lead for years, not just recently. Their aides have recently started visiting homes of children with high lead levels to reduce contact with lead from sources like peeling window sills.

title: Poles Who Killed, Poles Who Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: Foot-and-Mouth Disease Now Reported in Ireland
description: DUBLIN, March 22  Ireland confirmed its first case of foot-and-mouth disease today, in a herd of sheep on a farm on the border with Northern Ireland.

title: Purdue Pharma Has New Agency
description: Purdue Pharma said yesterday that it had named Della Femina, Rothschild, Jeary & Partners in New York, owned by top managers and the Omnicom Group, as the agency of record for its Senokot laxatives and Betadine antiseptic brands, as well as for all over-the-counter new-product development. Billings were estimated at less than $15 million.

title: An Incongruous Matchmaker, Cross-Indexing the Real World
description: What do Prince Charles, John Cleese, Salman Rushdie and Tom Stoppard have in common?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERMAN, HENRY
description: BERMAN-Henry. 95, left us March 11, 2001. He arrived at 7, on Ellis, from London, then to New Bethlehem, PA, Persia, The Arctic, and finally New York, meeting his life love, Tuni. His gaze often shifted to the invisible. From the first crystal radios, tapping the ether, to Carl Zeiss microscopy, and the continent contained on a glass slide. Finally, to the blues and stripers, under the Fire Island surf, into which he will soon return. Those he touched include, Harry, Sarah, Ben, Boobie, Sissy, Fran, Carl, Bernice, Susan, Harry, Buff, Milton, Cole Porter, David Smith, and Dorothy Dahner, and his loving family, Zeke, Laura, and Lilly.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about small technology companies in New Jersey that are hiring thousands of workers laid off from Lucent Technologies misstated the year of a merger between Northrop and the Grumman Corporation, which laid off thousands of workers on Long Island in 1990. It was in 1994, not 1990.

title: Palm Offers 2 Models That Are Built to Grow
description: This week, Palm announced that it was revamping its V line by adding two new models, the m500 ($399) and the m505 ($449). Both have the look of the V line, but only the m500 has the familiar green screen -- the m505 is a color unit. The new units come bundled with several new programs, including DataViz's Documents to Go, which lets the user edit Microsoft Word and Excel files on the hand-held.

title: Canada Could Adopt a Proposal to Silence Annoying Cell Phones
description: OTTAWA -- THE Canadian government is considering changing its laws to allow restaurants, theaters, hospitals and other private companies to silence cell phones by jamming radio signals. If Canada goes ahead with lifting the current prohibition on such jamming devices, it will step into the forefront of the movement to restrict cell phone use.

title: BlackBerry Pagers Get An Update on Updates
description: As if users of Research In Motion's BlackBerry two-way pager don't already check their devices for new e-mail with compulsive regularity, R.I.M. has given them another reason to feed an addiction: wireless scheduling.

title: Metro Business Briefing; DOUBLECLICK CUTTING JOBS
description: DoubleClick, an online advertising agency based in Manhattan's Silicon Alley, announced yesterday that it planned to lay off 10 percent of its work force as a part of a restructuring of its business in the United States. The company plans to eliminate about 190 of its more than 1,900 positions worldwide. The company said the cuts would be made to eliminate duplication in sales units, and in response to an advertising slowdown in Europe. The company said it expected to have 1,850 employees at the end of the second quarter because it planned to acquire other firms. Jayson Blair

title: Poles Who Killed, Poles Who Saved
description: To the Editor:

title: Terror Suspect Held Secretly For 4 Months
description: A new suspect in a global conspiracy to kill Americans abroad has been held secretly in New York City for more than four months since his arrest in Africa last fall, court records show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REED, BARBARA FERENBACH
description: REED-Barbara Ferenbach, 83. Of Wilmington, DE., and Point O'Woods, New York, formerly of Ridgewood, NJ, loving wife of Dr. Howard L. Reed. Survived by two sisters, her identical twin Martha Anderson, and Ruth Dunbar Pence; her children, Harry Reed, Sally Skey, Judy Reed Smith, Philip Reed and BJ Reed, and her eight grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Point O'Woods Community Church, Point O'Woods, NY 11706.

title: CYPRESS COMMUNICATIONS WILL TRIM ITS WORK FORCE
description: Cypress Communications Inc., a seller of telephone services and Internet access, said yesterday that it would lay off 200 workers, or half of its work force, as part of its plan to become profitable in the second half of 2003. Cypress will take an unspecified charge related to the cuts, which are expected to be completed by midyear, the company said in a statement. Cypress, which is based in Atlanta, said it would continue to offer its voice and data services in the Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston and Southern California markets, while offering only data services to customers in Seattle.

title: Corrections
description: Apicture caption on Friday with an article about the effect of foot- and-mouth disease on tourism in England misstated the reason an agricultural event in Cheshire was canceled. It was because of the discovery of the disease in Cheshire, not around the Lake District, which is in a different part of England.

title: A Happy Home Requires a Roof
description: Hollywood has occasionally shown how a house can drive people crazy, from ''Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House'' (1948) to ''The Money Pit'' (1986). ''Life as a House,'' which has just completed filming, demonstrates that building a house can also bring people together. Kevin Kline, left, plays an out-of-work architectural model maker who re-establishes his relationship with his family (especially his son) by building a Greene & Greene-style bungalow on a spectacular clifftop site in Palos Verdes, Calif. For the film, which will open later this year, the actors had to be taught some building skills. Mr. Kline will be seen bolting roof beams; Kristin Scott Thomas, playing his ex-wife, drills four-by-fours.

title: U.S., Cautious on Mad Cow, Seizes Flock of Sheep
description: The federal government today seized 234 sheep suspected of carrying a variety of mad cow disease and said it would soon take possession of a second such flock, of about 140 sheep.

title: Who's the Guy Who Ordered the Bloody Mary on the Rocks?
description: Even if high camp is not your style, ''Bat Boy,'' the musical that opened yesterday at the Union Square Theater, may very well make you laugh. It's remarkable what intelligent wit can accomplish, even within an outlandish frame. Derived from a dubious tabloid story about the discovery, in a West Virginia cave, of a creature who is half boy, half vampire bat -- it must be the first theatrical show to cite in the program a licensing agreement with The Weekly World News -- the show is a tongue-in-cheek Gothic morality tale bent on revealing the bat in all of us and urging us to ''Know your Bat Boy/Love your Bat Boy/Don't deny your beast inside.''

title: Accounts
description: * The Home Service Store, Atlanta, which offers home improvement and repair services, to CPS Direct, Boston, to handle its direct marketing campaign, which had been handled by Michael Meyers & Associates, Chicago. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

title: An Impending Test for Reform
description: The McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform bill has survived the first three days of what promises to be two perilous and profoundly important weeks of debate over the way money is raised and spent on federal election campaigns. The Senate has accepted two amendments, neither of which threatened the fragile coalition supporting McCain-Feingold, and rejected a worker and shareholder protection amendment yesterday that would have virtually guaranteed the bill's ultimate defeat. But other amendments are on the way -- some from senators who genuinely hope to strengthen the bill and others from those who hope to sabotage it. One of these, which could arrive on the Senate floor this week, is particularly worrisome to the bill's supporters and will reveal whether some senators who say they favor reform are feigning or sincere.

title: Childs Play
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Corruption Trial That Enthralled the French Comes to an End
description: The corruption trial of a former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, his former mistress and five other defendants ended today, after Mr. Dumas's lawyer scathingly attacked the prosecution's case, saying it was built on distortions.

title: Lo Khe Journal; A Folk Tradition Fades, but the Melody Lingers On
description: Late at night, when the silence of the village and the emptiness of her damp stone cottage become too deep to bear, Pham Thi Mui begins to sing -- familiar songs of her ancestors that transport her back into what seemed a time of certainty.

title: Economic Scene; Americans' waistlines have become the victims of economic progress.
description: EVER alert for trends that threaten Americans' health, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recently reported some bad news. Only about a quarter of the population is getting enough exercise, and that percentage barely budged from 1990 to 1998. The media may be full of beautiful, fit bodies, but neither those images nor the pleading of health experts is having much effect. Most Americans seem content to stay on the couch. The result is ever greater obesity.

title: STEEL ALLIANCE IN CHINA
description: China's top three steel makers have agreed to an alliance that will include joint ore purchases and future equity crossholdings to try to cut costs and increase competitiveness against foreign steel companies. Officials for the companies said the agreement could eventually lead to a merger. In terms of assets, the three companies, the Baosteel Group of Shanghai, the Beijing-based Shougang Corporation and the Wuhan Iron and Steel Corporation, are already among the biggest steel makers in the world. Craig S. Smith (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  GITTLEMAN, IRWIN
description: GITTLEMAN-Irwin. Sorely missed and always lovingly remembered. Kid Sister, Phyllis

title: U.S. Gyrations of Little Effect On Many Asian Stock Markets
description: Stock markets in Asia largely shrugged off the Federal Reserve's cut in interest rates and the sharp fall in American stocks that followed, suggesting that the region is becoming somewhat inured to daily developments in the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, AARON
description: SOLOMON-Aaron. Died March 15, 2001 at the age of 93. Graduate of City University 1932 with a BS degree; from Columbia University School of Social Work 1946 with an MS degree. He valued his long career in social service agencies as an executive, activist, group and community worker, in Lynn, Mass, Philadelphia, PA and NY. On retirement he continued his professional involvement as a volunteer at Cabrini Hospital's Outreach Program for the Elderly and in Chelsea community programs, where he resided. He is survived by his wife Victoria Tabeek, his son Richard Allen and his wife Grace, and a granddaughter Amelia. He touched the lives of many and will be greatly missed.

title: Bush Ends A.B.A.'s Quasi-official Role in Helping to Pick Judges
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  As expected, President Bush this afternoon ended the quasi-official role of the American Bar Association in evaluating candidates for federal judgeships.

title: To the Divas Who Put the D in Divine
description: Christine Andreas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCOIS, THEODORE V., S.J., PH.D.
description: FRANCOIS-Theodore V., S.J., PH.D., on March 19, 2001. Beloved son of the late Theodore V. Francois, Sr. and Sylvia Francois. Brother of Thomas and Luz Acevedo, Christine Adderly. Cousin of Patricia Robinson, Yvette Preston, Joseph and Alexander Francois, Suzanne and Anthony Froix. Reposing at Holy Rosary RC Church, 141 Chauncey St., Brooklyn, NY, Friday, March 23, 2001, 2PM-8PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Holy Rosary Church, Saturday, 9:30AM. Interment Shrine of North American Martyrs, Auriesville, NY.

title: American Is Guiding A Market For China
description: James Liu is an American. That is not surprising until you consider what Mr. Liu does: he helps run the Shanghai Stock Exchange. He is the exchange's executive vice president, working to reshape China's state-dominated equity markets into a capitalist tool.

title: Giuliani, Citing Economy, Seeks Cuts in Agency Budgets
description: Citing the slowdown in the national economy, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he had instructed city agencies to prepare to cut spending over the next 15 months by as much as $500 million, a belt-tightening he said might prove unnecessary but was prudent given Wall Street's recent troubles.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a Brooklyn man who was charged in an elaborate fraud scheme and accused of stealing credit card numbers from the restaurant where he worked misspelled its name in some copies. It is Zaytoons, not Vay Toons.

title: The Pig's Unpenned, After 35 Years
description: Next year, the Academy Awards will move to a new theater at Hollywood Boulevard and Highland Avenue in Hollywood. Tomorrow, in another sign that the old neighborhood is being revived, the Pig 'n Whistle bar and restaurant, left, is reopening. Before it closed 35 years ago, it had been patronized by Spencer Tracy, Buddy Rogers and Shirley Temple, who ate the sundaes. Right next door is the Egyptian Theater, also recently restored. The 5,000-square-foot Pig 'n Whistle, built in 1927, has the dark, cozy opulence of its era. Its new owner, Chris Breed, who is also an owner of the Sunset Room in Hollywood, spent $1.5 million restoring its carved wood ceilings and cast-iron facade, right. ''The detail they put into this place was beyond anything I've ever seen in a restaurant,'' he said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILGRIM, LAURA REINA
description: MILGRIM-Laura Reina, Manhattan's lady of dignity and grace, joined peace on Friday, March 16, 2001. She was 68. She danced the Opera Ball in Vienna, toured with Bob Hope in the USO, explored the globe and loved the Yankees. Her laughter filled all rooms and she will again bless the world through her soon-to-arrive grandchild. She was a member of the New York Hospital Auxiliary, Nichibei Fujinkai club, and the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church. She is survived by her loving son, John Townsend Milgrim; former husband, Nathan Milgrim; brothers Richard and Thomas Reina; sisters Bonnie Kelley, Patricia Spradley and Marilyn Krone, and nine nieces and nephews. Raised in Kingston, New York, she has now returned home. Donations may be sent to The National CFIDS Foundation, 103 Aletha Rd, Needham, Massachusetts 02492.

title: The SAT Is  Good  Bad  Both
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, HARRY
description: ROSENTHAL-Harry. Age 79, of Valley Stream, NY. March 20, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth . Loving father of Richard. Loving Opa of Max. Loving father-in-law of Stacy Fischer Rosenthal. Born in Germany on December 18, 1921, Harry was a former president of Temple Gates of Zion in Valley Stream. He donated his time to Meals on Wheels and Winthrop Hospital. title: COMPANY BRIEFS

He was a skillful leader who served our companies with distinction for over 66 years, and was singularly responsible for our great success. He was a compassionate and caring person deeply involved with the welfare of our employees. We shall miss his judicious counsel in our midst. He leaves a void that shall deeply affect us all. title: Furnishings From a Guy Who Knows the Territory
description: Yes, you can buy it wholesale. The Curran catalog, (800) 555-6653, and Web site (www.curranonline.com; password, ''banana'') offer deep discounts on merchandise as diverse as custom-cut sisal rugs, at upper left in the photo below, and, clockwise from there, Barlow & Tyrie teak furniture, Egyptian-cotton towels and bedding by Hillcrest, and furniture upholstered in Rogers Goffigon fabrics. ''My catalog and Web site are like a high-end Costco,'' said the owner, Jeff Curran, who was a wholesale furniture and housewares representative when his friends began asking, ''Can you get it for me wholesale?'' His simple answer was yes -- and the catalog was born. Now, everyone can get Mr. Curran's wares wholesale. A queen-size set of 330-thread-count cotton sheets and pillowcases is $99. An 89-inch-long three-cushion sofa is $3,450 ($4,700 at retail, the catalog says). MARIANNE ROHRLICH

title: HOLLYWOOD ON THE HUDSON; For Two Designers, a Set That Won't Be Struck
description: ROBIN STANDEFER and Stephen Alesch live with a few obsessions: cabinets filled with laboratory glassware, preserved insects, recycled pieces of Parisian factories and early Scandinavian Modern furnishings. Ms. Standefer, a production designer, and her companion of seven years, Mr. Alesch, an art director, have worked together on films as disparate as the gothic ''Caveman's Valentine,'' which opened this month, and ''Zoolander,'' opening this year, which draws on 20th-century modernism to convey tongue-in-cheek chic. Alone, Mr. Alesch has worked as a set designer on such eye-popping science fiction films as ''Gattaca'' and ''Stargate.''

title: CANADIAN INFLATION WEAKENS
description: Weaker energy prices pulled Canada's consumer price index down another notch in February, as the annual inflation rate dipped to 2.9 percent from 3 percent in January and 3.2 percent in December. But living costs were higher than most economists had expected. Food prices rose a surprising 0.9 percent, offsetting a 0.8 percent drop in the average cost of oil, natural gas and electricity. Core inflation, excluding energy, was 2.4 percent in February, the highest annual increase since October 1995. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: An Aid to Head-Turning At an After-Oscar Party
description: If you can have a stretch limo why not a stretch sofa? There will be room for lots of luminaries on the 80 feet (as the crow flies) of serpentine seating designed by Basil Walter, of Basil Walter Architects in Manhattan, for the Vanity Fair Oscar party. Mr. Walter said that he and Graydon Carter, the editor of Vanity Fair, wanted ''something dramatic and sculptural in shape.'' Fabricated by George & Goldberg, a set builder and cabinetmaker in Los Angeles, the three sofas (two of them 30 feet long, and one 20 feet) are upholstered in natural canvas. Mr. Walter also designed the tables, with disk tops of uncolored frosted glass, perfect for parking an Oscar. Will the sofas and tables be sold after the Vanity Fair party on Sunday at Morton's in West Hollywood? No, Mr. Walter said, they will be put in storage for future use.

title: Hevesi's School Plan Includes Possibility Of Increase in Taxes

title: Mir Passes Point of No Return in Homeward Plunge to Earth

The fragments were expected to crash into a broad swath of Pacific between New Zealand and Chile around 1:30 a.m. Friday Eastern Standards Time.

title: PROFIT UP AT PIRELLI

Net income surged to 3.6 billion euros ($3.3 billion), or 1.8 euros a share, from 293 million euros, or 15 cents a share, in 1999, lifted by gains from the sale of two businesses. Pirelli also said it would pay a dividend of 300 lire per ordinary share, 88 percent higher than last year's dividend.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACQUEEN, EWAN CAMPBELL SR.
description: MacQUEEN-Ewan Campbell Sr. Born on January 19th, 1916 in Mendham Township, New Jersey, son of John Ewan and Margaret Winter MacQueen. After completing high school in Ohio, he graduated from the Georgia Institute of Technology and the Law School of New York University. He spent the majority of his working life with the International Nickel Company, where he headed its patents section. Before moving to Coral Gables Florida ten years ago, he resided in Piermont, N.Y. He served as a vestryman of Grace Church, Nyack, N.Y. and of the Church of the Venerable Bede, Coral Gables, FL. He was a member of the Country Club of Coral Gables and the 10th-Holers. He is survived by his wife of 59 years, Martha & their four children Julie D. Berlin, Coral Gables, FL., Ewan C. MacQueen, Jr, West Windsor, N.J., Michael C. MacQueen, College Park, Md., Molly MacQueen, Piermont, N.Y. and five grandchildren. Memorial contributions in lieu of flowers may be made to the Audubon Society or to the National Heart Association.

title: Heeding a Call Of the Faithful
description: Given how dynamic a force the church and religion are in African-American tradition and culture, it is somewhat surprising that no mainstream publishing house has devoted an imprint to black Christian fiction and nonfiction until now. Hello, it was as if publishing had suddenly awakened to the idea that African-Americans will buy great numbers of books if the stories or material are relevant to them.

title: Metro Business Briefing; REPAYMENT IN MORTGAGE SCHEME
description: A Rockland County mortgage lending company has agreed to pay $1.1 million in restitution to mortgage seekers who paid $500 application fees in what New York State officials called a mortgage scam. The company, Anvil Mortgage Banking Ltd., also agreed to surrender its state license, according to Eliot L. Spitzer, the state attorney general, and Elizabeth McCaul, the state superintendent of banks. They said Anvil collected about $7.5 million in fees from about 15,000 applicants, though it could not have expected to finance a significant portion of the applications, and fewer than 450 people received loans. The company has only $1.1 million left, to be given to the unsuccessful applicants who are found, a spokesman for Mr. Spitzer said. Joseph P. Fried

title: Technology Briefing
description: TELECOMMUNICATIONS LUCENT MAY PULL SHARE OFFER Lucent Technologies Inc. may shelve the $6.5 billion initial offering of shares in its Agere Systems unit, Lucent's vice chairman, Ben Verwaayen, said. The Agere offering, which had been scheduled for yesterday, was postponed early in the day as Lucent sought investors. Now a decision on whether to proceed at all will be made next week, Mr. Verwaayen said. "The week in which we will have a decision on the I.P.O. either way will be next week," he said. Agere is seeking to sell 500 million shares at $12 to $14 each. (Bloomberg News)

description: When Fujitsu introduced one of the Japanese corporate world's first performance-based pay systems, it was hailed as a breakthrough. Now, eight years later, the company is ready to forget the whole thing, or at least drastically modify it.

title: Hollywood on the Hudson: For Two Designers, a Set That Won't Be Struck
description: ROBIN STANDEFER and Stephen Alesch live with a few obsessions: cabinets filled with laboratory glassware, preserved insects, recycled pieces of Parisian factories and early Scandinavian Modern furnishings. Ms. Standefer, a production designer, and her companion of seven years, Mr. Alesch, an art director, have worked together on films as disparate as the gothic "Caveman's Valentine," which opened this month, and "Zoolander," opening this year, which draws on 20th- century modernism to convey tongue-in- cheek chic. Alone, Mr. Alesch has worked as a set designer on such eye-popping science fiction films as "Gattaca" and "Stargate."

title: Transcript of John and Sally McKenna's Visit to the Cooking and Recipes Forum
description: Alawyer and a cook by training, John and Sally McKenna are the authors and publishers of The Bridgestone Guides, a series of independent critical guides to Ireland's food culture, which they have produced to great acclaim since 1991.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARMON, HOWARD
description: HARMON-Howard, D.V.M. Age 77, died March 19, 2001, in Escondido, CA. Born in New Castle, PA, he grew up in New York City. After graduating from Pennsylvania State University in 1942, he received his veterinary degree (D.V.M.) from Cornell in 1945. Dr. Harmon owned and operated a successful veterinary practice in Rye, N.Y., for almost 35 years, and was a member of local, state, and national veterinary associations. Since his retirement in 1985, Dr. Harmon lived in Escondido, California, and was intimately involved in the conception, staffing, and organization of the Veterinary Specialty Referral Hospital of San Diego, located at the Helen Woodward Animal Center in Rancho Santa Fe, CA. He served for many years as a member of the Board of Directors of the Center. He is survived by Harriet, his beloved wife; his children, Kim and Robert; his daughter-in-law, Susan, and his grandson, Max, who was the apple of his eye. He loved his many dear friends and touched more people than he knew. Memorial contributions may be sent to the Helen Woodward Animal Center, POB 64, Rancho Santa Fe, CA 92067.

title: Death, Mighty Thou Art; So Too, a Compassionate Heart
description: Why watch someone die if you don't have to? That perfectly valid question hovers over ''Wit,'' Margaret Edson's tough Pulitzer Prize-winning play, now an HBO film, about a literary scholar's anguished last battle with cancer. Life is hard enough, and you don't have to be a yahoo to avoid what promises to be, despite many critical assurances otherwise, depressing. So let's not pretend that ''Wit'' is fun or necessarily soothing; frankly, it is depressing. But if you miss this version, you will also miss a rare experience.

title: AD AGENCY CITES DIFFICULT OUTLOOK
description: The online advertising company 24/7 Media, based in New York, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter loss widened, and it warned that its growth for the rest of the year could be much slower than anticipated as the advertising industry weakens. The company reported a fourth-quarter loss of $677.1 million, or $15.96 a share, partly because of investment write-offs, compared with a loss of nearly $13 million, or 58 cents a share, a year earlier. ''It is going to be tough this year in the media business,'' said David J. Moore, the chief executive of 24/7. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: McCall Confronts Questions on His Daughter's Arrest
description: State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for governor, found himself yesterday confronting questions about his daughter's arrest Wednesday evening on charges of larceny and issuing bad checks.
