description: Battered prices and fresh memories of a remarkable rally attracted bargain hunters today to pick up a wide array of the stock market's offerings.

title: China Says U.S. Scholar 'Confessed Her Crimes'
description: A government spokesman said today that Gao Zhan, a United States-based sociologist who has been held incommunicado since Feb. 11 for unspecified ''activities damaging state security,'' had ''openly confessed her crimes.''

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: NEW YORK CITY RESISTS SLUMP Statistics released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor show New York City with a jobless rate of 5.3 percent in February, up slightly from the 5.1 percent in January but still below the 5.6 percent in December, when economic jitters began to sweep the country. And the city continues to generate new jobs at a rapid pace. Employment at private-sector companies grew by 2.5 percent in the 12 months ended in February, while nationally, employment rose by just 1.4 percent. Manufacturing suffered its sharpest drop since January of 1996, according to Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi. But there has been a surge of demand for secretaries and administrative assistants.

title: Maryland Wins Beltway Battle; Stanford Is Next
description: Maryland's Terrapins barreled into their N.C.A.A. tournament game tonight knowing that they had not advanced to the Final Eight since 1975 and that a loss to their Washington-area rival Georgetown might make them consider waiting another 26 years to return home.

title: ADVANCED MICRO CHALLENGES PENTIUM 4
description: Advanced Micro Devices, the world's No. 2 maker of computer chips, behind Intel, announced two new fast processors yesterday at the CeBIT trade show in Hanover, Germany. The new Athlon processors will run at 1.33 gigahertz and 1.3 gigahertz. Now, Advanced Micro's fastest chip is the 1.2 gigahertz Athlon, which was introduced in October. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said the new chips would outperform the fastest chips made by Intel by up to 40 percent. Intel introduced Pentium 4 chips capable of speeds of 1.5 gigahertz last year. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

title: Bronx Crime Rates Fall After Personnel Shake-Up
description: For the first time in more than a year, crime rates in the Bronx are falling, with total reported crime dropping 12 percent so far in 2001 compared with the same period last year. That decline outpaced the 10 percent citywide drop in the same period.

title: NEW YORK LAW FIRM TO OPEN SILICON VALLEY OFFICE
description: Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, a large New York law firm, announced yesterday that it was opening a branch office in Palo Alto, Calif. The branch will open on May 1 with 10 lawyers from Milbank's existing offices and will then probably hire additional lawyers from other firms, Milbank said. It will focus on corporate transactions, intellectual property and bankruptcy work, said Mel M. Immergut, chairman of the firm. Jonathan D. Glater (NYT)

description: The White House today told officials of the American Bar Association that it was ending the organization's semiofficial role in evaluating candidates for the federal bench.

title: Late Bounce Keeps Dow and Bear Apart
description: After spending much of the day in bear market territory, the Dow industrials recovered somewhat in the afternoon, swinging from a decline of more than 380 points to close down less than 98 points, or 1 percent. But the Dow is fewer than a dozen points from officially entering a bear market. Technology stocks ended the day sharply higher, with the Nasdaq composite index rising 3.7 percent.

title: The Free Fall of the Australian Dollar Remains a Mystery
description: The Australian dollar has analysts baffled. It probably should be weak, they say -- but not this weak.

title: And the Oscar for the network willing to hold out the longest to sell costly spots goes to . . . ABC.
description: IN another sign of the effect of the struggling economy on Madison Avenue, ABC has become the reluctant star of a Hollywood cliffhanger called ''Crouching Network, Hidden Sponsors,'' completing the sale of commercial time during the 73rd annual Academy Awards a scant three days before showtime.

title: PROFIT WARNING
description: The British manufacturer, Invensys, said that profit would fall in the second half, forcing it to cut more jobs. Shares in the company, which makes factory controls and earns half its profit in the United States, fell as much as 14 percent yesterday. Invensys said it would cut 5,000 jobs, 6 percent of its work force, by the end of the year, 2,000 more than it had previously announced. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: The Big City; There's Profit In Demonizing Privatization
description: TWO years ago the Rev. Jesse Jackson, accompanied by the Rev. Al Sharpton, visited a public high school in Brooklyn and was appalled to find a total of two computers for 1,100 students.

description: Apicture caption yesterday with an article about the effects of the energy crisis on the economy of Imperial County, Calif., gave an erroneous name in some copies for a power company that has missed payments to suppliers. It is Southern California Edison, not Southern California Energy.

description: Offering their own solutions to the nation's energy problems, Senate Democrats introduced a bill today that would reduce the demand for fuel and increase the production of oil and natural gas.

description: The Coca-Cola Company will begin its first campaign in two years for Diet Coke, with commercials featuring the voices of celebrities.

title: Bush Says He Has Open Mind Over Changes to His Tax Cut
description: PORTLAND, Me., March 23  President Bush said today that he was open-minded about some of the proposals to amend his suggested tax cut that would not lock the country into the plan for a full 10 years, signaling more willingness to deal than he has at many points in the past.

title: Founder of Edison Schools Sells Some of His Stock in Company
description: The founder and chief executive of Edison Schools, the company trying to win the right to manage five low-performing public schools in New York City, sold nearly $16 million of his personal holdings of the company's stock this week as part of an offering of Edison shares.

description: Lawyers for Abner Louima, who was tortured by a police officer in a toilet stall in a Brooklyn station house in 1997, have reached a tentative settlement with the city and the police union in his lawsuit, lawyers involved in the case said yesterday.

description: WHEN automakers roll out concept cars at auto shows, they are inviting the public to take a peek into their crystal balls. Here, they say, is what we think the future may hold.

title: CHIP DEMAND SHRINKS AGAIN
description: The semiconductor industry association's book-to-bill ratio, a benchmark of demand for chip-equipment tools, fell to 0.77 in February. A ratio of 0.77 means that semiconductor equipment makers in the United States took in $77 in orders for every $100 in shipments. A ratio below 1 indicates a shrinking market. Orders were $1.8 billion, down 40 percent from October, when the industry hit its peak at $2.99 billion, according to Semiconductor Equipment Materials International, which conducted the study. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Some Evidence Of Overcharges
description: California utilities paid $6.2 billion above competitive prices for wholesale electricity over the last 10 months, according to estimates filed today by the operators of the state's power grid.

title: BELLSOUTH AND DELL IN PC DEAL
description: The BellSouth Corporation and the Dell Computer Corporation said yesterday that they would cooperate to deliver personal computers equipped for high-speed Internet access. BellSouth, the main local communications provider in the Southeast, is investing in high-speed Internet access using a technology known as digital subscriber line, or D.S.L. That service requires the use of a special modem. Under yesterday's deal, Dell will install D.S.L. modems in computers for customers in BellSouth's territory who want them. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Safety Belt's Originator Asks If There's a Better Way
description: VOLVO, the pioneer of the lap-and-shoulder safety belt now in common use, has begun to ask: If three is good, can four be better?

title: A Glut of Cable TV in India; A 'Wild West' Market That Overshadows China's
description: Hailing a taxi in this chaotic city can be a gamble in the best of times. When Cyrus Broacha is at the wheel, all bets are off.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MELAMID, ALEXANDER
description: MELAMID - Alexander. The American Geographical Society notes with sadness the death on March 19, of Alexander Melamid, a councilor of the Society since 1975, Vice President for many years, and long time Chair of our Honors Committee. We will miss the cosmopolitan range of his knowledge, his stalwart spirit, and his unflagging devotion to the Society. We have lost a good friend and a treasured colleague. John E. Gould, Chair William P. Doyle, President Mary Lynne Bird, Exec Director

title: Two Weeks in Borneo
description: Nobody will win $1 million on this trip, but then, nobody will be sent home early by the other participants, either. A 15-day trip to Borneo, the island that was the site of the first "Survivor" series, costs $1,699 a person, based on double occupancy, and includes round-trip air fare from Los Angeles. Stops on the smarTours Borneo Adventure include two days in Kuching, capital of Sarawak; the rain forest in Batang Ai National Park; Kota Kinabalu, in the South China Sea; and the orangutan sanctuary in Sepilok, where captive orangutans are reintroduced into the wild. The last two days are spent in Kuala Lumpur. The price also includes accommodations (most nights in Hilton hotels), local ground and air transportation, sightseeing and 23 meals, including breakfast each day. Departures are April 2001 through March 2002. Information: (800) 337-7773, www.smartours.net .

title: Creativity, Digitally Remastered
description: THE companion digital shows now at the Whitney, ''BitStreams'' and ''Data Dynamics,'' have a well-mannered air of decorous efficiency and cheerful modernity that encapsulates what you may regard as an ethos at large. Even some of the works meant to produce anxiety look clean, earnest and bland, like Starbucks. If this is the avant-garde, then the avant-garde certainly isn't what it used to be.

title: Bay of Pigs Enemies Finally Sit Down Together
description: Fidel Castro walked into a hotel conference room this morning and sat down across the table from men who had spent years plotting to subvert his government or to kill him for the United States.

title: Foreign Affairs; Markets Call the Tune
description: I was talking to a friend on Wall Street about what impact the plunging Dow and Nasdaq might have on U.S. foreign policy, when he stopped me and said, ''Look, the Nasdaq is America's Viagra -- without it, we just don't feel quite so potent.''

title: Williams's Offensive Prowess Lifts Duke Into Another Regional Final
description: For 26 minutes, it seemed the classic matchup of two dominant basketball programs might not materialize. Neither Duke nor U.C.L.A. had found a rhythm, and the game's tempo was at the mercy of knocked down bodies rather than knocked down shots. Then the Blue Devils' Jason Williams took over.

title: Bells, Beds And Bronzes In Asia Week
description: Imagine a musical instrument so old that no one knows what kind of music was composed for it. That's the intriguing part of ''Ancient China: Music and Ritual,'' a show of archaic Chinese bronze bells at J. J. Lally Oriental Art, 41 East 57th Street, through April 7.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COTTON FALLS. Cotton fell after a report showed an unexpected drop in exports to China, the biggest consumer of the fiber. In New York, cotton for May delivery fell 1.43 cents, or 2.9 percent, to 47.14 cents a pound.

title: After 53 Years, Fresh Kills Gets Its Final Load of Trash
description: Never has a pile of smelly trash had it so good: When New York City Department of Sanitation scow No. 123 passed by the home of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani early yesterday morning on the East River, his honor stepped out on his porch to salute it. When it passed by the Statue of Liberty, Fire Department water cannons fired into the air. Tugboat whistles screamed. News photographers angled for a close-up.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of a house in Westchester County on Monday with the continuation of an article about efforts to restrict the building of oversized suburban houses was published in error. The house was in the village of Pelham, which has not enacted new restrictions, not in neighboring Pelham Manor, which has.

title: White House Sets Deadline on Forest Rules
description: Under prodding from a federal judge, the Bush administration has said it will decide by May 12 whether to keep in place the Clinton administration rules that would prohibit development on 60 million acres of national forest.

title: SARA LEE IS SELLING ITS CHAMPION EUROPE BUSINESS
description: The Sara Lee Corporation agreed to sell its Champion Europe business, which markets athletic apparel and footwear, to a group of the unit's managers to focus on more profitable sales of food, underwear and household products. Terms were not disclosed. The transaction is expected to be completed by the end of June, a Sara Lee spokeswoman, Julie Ketay, said. Sara Lee said in January that it would sell seven units, including Champion Europe, and its majority stake in the leather-goods maker Coach Inc. Sara Lee, based in Chicago, is trying to bolster its profit and revenue by focusing on top-selling brands like Jimmy Dean meats and Kiwi shoe polish. Champion Europe is based in Campogalliano, Italy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Republican Senators Agree To a $60 Billion Tax Cut

title: Aide Ends Assembly's Inquiry Into Her Sexual Assault Charge
description: An Assembly aide who made a sexual assault accusation against Speaker Sheldon Silver's top lawyer has agreed to end the Assembly's investigation into the charge, the Assembly said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRIS, BOB
description: MORRIS-Bob, 49. Died of amyloidosis March 19, in Santa Fe, NM. He is the beloved son of Norma and Aaron, loving father of Rebeca Lidz, dear brother of Hal and his wife Lorie, and soulmate of Mary Kate Mendoza. His passing was as elegant and full of grace as his life. We don't bid him goodbye, we bid him bon voyage.

description: ATTRACTIONS

title: Spiritual High Notes From a Deep River
description: The last notes of ''Lift Every Voice and Sing,'' the glorious song known for generations as ''the Negro national anthem,'' were still echoing in the Mother A.M.E. (African Methodist Episcopal) Zion Church on West 137th Street as Karen Krieger, president of the Cathedral Vesper Choir, stepped forward and thanked the audience for turning out on a bitter, rain-swept February afternoon.

description: A selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: A Top G.O.P. Senator Hints At Soft Money Compromise
description: An influential Republican senator who had long been a fierce opponent of the McCain-Feingold campaign-finance bill offered the first hint of a compromise today, saying he was open to a ban on the unregulated political contributions known as soft money in return for higher limits on regulated donations.

title: 'Abstraction And Immanence'
description: Hunter College/Times Square Gallery

title: Piety at Kyoto Didn't Cool the Planet
description: President Bush met a barrage of criticism last week when he backed away from regulating carbon dioxide emissions, but he was only hastening the inevitable. A major shift in American policy on global warming had to come -- not chiefly because of the new administration's debts to campaign donors, but because of the sheer impracticality of the policy in place when George Bush took office. In the long run, Mr. Bush may actually have improved chances for slowing manmade changes in the world's climate.

title: Clinton Critic Is Bush Choice To Run F.T.C.
description: Signaling a sharp shift in the enforcement of the nation's antitrust laws, the White House announced today its intention to nominate Timothy J. Muris, a leading critic of the Clinton administration's antitrust policies, to become the next chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Issues of Distortions and Lies at Terror Trial
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has a policy not to tape-record most interviews conducted during criminal inquiries. That policy led to a quarrelsome and quibbling cross-examination yesterday at the embassy bombings trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Metro Business Briefing; EX-AIDE TO KOCH ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: A former assistant to Mayor Edward I. Koch was arrested yesterday on federal fraud charges, accused of bilking a former employer, Cathedral Healthcare System of Newark, out of more than $200,000, and of filing false tax returns. Investigators say Victor E. Botnick, 46, a former New York City health official and special assistant to Mayor Koch, stole money from Cathedral Healthcare while he was a senior vice president there in 1996 and 1997. Last year, Mr. Botnick was acquitted on federal charges of detonating stink bombs on two airline flights between New York and Paris in 1998. Mr. Botnick's lawyer, Alan Zegas, said his client was innocent of all charges. Mr. Botnick was released on $100,000 bail. Winnie Hu (NYT)

title: This Rebel Is Short Of Height, Not Desire
description: Jason Harrison wore a wristband over his biceps while Mississippi practiced at the Midwest Regional today, but, for him, it would be more accurate to call it a biceps band, because his biceps are the size of his teammates' wrists. His baggy red shorts drooped to his knees, even though they would probably fit many eighth graders. If Harrison ever wanted to donate a pair of his sneakers, he should start with the high school freshman team and work his way down.

title: Creative Executive Is on the Move Again
description: Gary Topolewski, one of the most peripatetic agency creative executives, is changing jobs again, leaving the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, where he had been executive creative director, to join Doner in Southfield, Mich., as one of five executive creative directors.

title: OPTIMISM FROM LIBERATE
description: Shares of Liberate Technologies rose after the maker of software that permits people to use the Internet on their television sets forecast better-than-expected sales for fiscal 2002. The stock rose 88 cents, or 12 percent, to $8. Liberate had fallen 90 percent in the last year because cable companies were slow to adopt its software, which permits users to play along with broadcast game shows and buy advertised products, among other things. Liberate said it expected as much as $80 million in revenue in the year ending May 31, 2002, more than the $69.8 million forecast by William Bao Bean, an analyst for Banc of America.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SAKS INC., Birmingham, Ala., an operator of specialty department stores, said its board had authorized a stock buyback of up to five million shares. Saks added it had already bought about 4.05 million shares as part of an earlier program that also authorized the repurchase of five million shares. The company has 141.8 million shares outstanding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, LOUIS R.
description: SLATTERY-Louis R., M.D. October 16, 1908-March 19, 2001. Loving father and devoted husband, in his 93rd year, at home in Manhattan, after a short illness. Survived by his children and grandchildren. Flushing High School '25, Columbia College '29, Columbia P&S '33. Veteran of the South Pacific campaigns of WWII, where he met and married Lela Hendry, his wife of 53 years, who died in 1997. Professor of Clinical Surgery at NYU School of Medicine, gifted surgeon, proudly affiliated with NYU for 60 years. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the S. Arthur Localio Surgical Research Laboratory, Department of Surgery, NYU School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016. A memorial service will be held in Farkas Auditorium, NYU School of Medicine, Tuesday, April 17th, 4PM. His friends, former patients and students, and colleagues may contact his son John at 12 East 97th Street, NY, NY 10029.

title: The Ad That Made a Campus Roar
description: To the Editor:

title: WAL-MART CONSIDERING ONLINE EXPANSION
description: WalMart.com, the Internet arm of the huge retailer, may expand its offering of online services, which can be delivered at a lower cost than merchandise and yield larger profits, a director says. Jim Breyer, a venture capitalist who sits on Wal-Mart.com's board, would not say what services Wal-Mart.com would add or expand. But he said financial, travel and photo services can be more profitable than merchandise sold over the Internet. ''The real high-margin future of e-commerce is electronic delivery,'' said Mr. Breyer, a managing partner at Accel Partners in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Judge Lets CalEnergy Sell to Any Buyer
description: Alternative energy providers in California got a boost today when a state judge released the CalEnergy Operating Corporation, which operates 10 geothermal plants in Imperial County, from its contract to sell power to Southern California Edison and allowed it to sell on the open market.

title: 'Informal' As a Work That Is Anything But
description: The title of Pam Tanowitz's new dance summed up its spirit: ''Informal.'' When her Open 24 Hours Dance Company presented it on Monday night as part of the Works and Process series at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum it proved to be an amiable romp for Anne Lentz, Rashaun Mitchell and Tom Gold, a guest artist from the New York City Ballet.

title: McDONALD'S INTRODUCES MENU FOR OLDER CHILDREN
description: The McDonald's Corporation said yesterday that it was introducing a new Mighty Kids Meal, a bigger version of its Happy Meals intended for older children. The new meals will offer either a double hamburger, double cheeseburger or a 6-piece order of Chicken McNuggets as the main entree and are geared toward children ages 8 to 10. The new meals will be available March 30, said the company, based in Oak Brook, Ill. The Burger King chain, owned by Diageo P.L.C., has been offering its Burger King Big Kids Meals for children ages 7 to 12 since 1999.

title: Eldredge Can't Spin In Front of Russians
description: The smooth Todd Eldredge skated with the deep old-school edges that the purists adore before turning himself into a twister on a mind-blowing final spin that defied physics.

title: Mir Space Station Sizzles to Ending Over Pacific
description: The Mir space station streaked back to Earth today as a molten blaze of metal and fire, harmlessly raking a swath of the South Pacific like a load of cosmic buckshot.

title: G.O.P. Chairman Under Republican Fire Back Home
description: As he commutes here to his new second job as Republican national chairman, Gov. James S. Gilmore III of Virginia leaves behind a scathing example of how rough politics can get within his party: A group of Republicans in his own State Senate have joined Democrats in forming a fund-raising committee to oppose him in a running battle over the party's signature issue of cutting taxes.

title: Mat Collishaw
description: Bonakdar Jancou

title: Sports of The Times; Not Fuzzy, But a Coach Who Wins
description: THE voice from Franklinton, N.C., was filled with pride and resolve. With almost everyone pulling for a Duke-Kentucky final in the East Regional, the Rev. Harvey Hartsfield said before last night's games that he was going to have his congregation do some serious pulling -- no, praying -- for the University of Southern California.

title: Album of The Week: Daft Punk's 'Discovery'
description: DAFT PUNK: "Discovery" (Virgin). The French electronic invasion has slowly crept up on popular music over the last few years, and now we are in the midst of a full-scale onslaught, with recent releases by Mirwais, Benjamin Diamond and Daft Punk, soon to be followed by the new Air album and Etienne de Crecy's first album for V2 Records. On its first album, "Housework," the French duo Daft Punk staked its claim as one of the best Chicago house bands not in Chicago. With its follow-up, "Discovery," the band members show they are not Chicago specialists but true generalists. Here, Daft Punk branches out into everything from pure club pop (a la "Music Goes Better With You") to Jean-Michel Jarre new-age journeys to imitation heavy metal guitar solos to Kevin Saunderson-style Detroit techno.

title: FINNISH PHONE COMPANY SLIPS
description: One day after the Finnish government used its position as the majority shareholder of Sonera Oyj, the country's biggest telephone operator, to dismiss most of its board, shares in the company fell an additional 11 percent yesterday. The government acted after Sonera stock dropped about 90 percent in the last 12 months as investors began to stay away, worried about Sonera's debt from the purchase of licenses for high-speed wireless communications. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: Shinjo's Hitting Wins Over The Mets
description: Tsuyoshi Shinjo has picked up one aspect of American baseball quickly. He understands the emptiness of spring training statistics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, SIDNEY
description: JACOBSON-Sidney. Age 88. Passed away peacefully March 20, 2001 after a long illness. Beloved husband of Lillian. Dear father of Elaine J. Cohen and Jerold D. Jacobson and father-in-law of Jerome J. Cohen and Gertraude Jacobson. Loving grandfather to Dr. Jonathan Cohen (Cori), Jennifer C. title: Technology Briefing

title: When East Goes West, The Twain Meet Here

In addition to the usual auctions, there is now a constellation of exhibitions, uptown and downtown, devoted to Asian work. Johnson of Seattle, WA, one sister, Mary Gray Harris Legg of Chicago, IL, two grandchildren, Jennifer Carley Chase, and Rebecca Darwin Chase, and nieces and nephews, Ivan, David, Sara, and Jeanne. For many years she was a resident of Great Neck & Port Washington, NY, before moving to Richmond, VA. in 1996. She was the widow of Raymond D. McCormick and was preceded in death by her son, Raymond S. McCormick, two brothers, Captain Joseph D. Lynch, Jr. and Valentine D. Lynch, and her first husband, Mortimer J. Gleeson. She is survived by two sons, William K. McCormick and his wife Jeanne and J. Burke McCormick and his wife Sallie; her daughter-in-law Stephanie D. McCormick; her brother, Col. John M. Lynch; 11 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A Mass of the Resurrection was celebrated in Richmond on March 20. Interment will take place with a graveside service Saturday at Nassau Knolls Cemetery in Port Washington, NY on March 24th at 10 A.M.

Legal challenges to insurance industry standards that determine length of hospital stay and whether doctors have the final say in those decisions are pending in several states.

title: Containing Foot-and-Mouth Disease
description: Foot-and-mouth disease has spread from Britain, where it appeared in mid-February, to several farms in France and now to Ireland and the Netherlands, where it was detected in a few cows and a herd of goats. The total number of cases is not large -- about 500 -- but the effort to prevent any further spread of this virulently contagious disease has brought the movement of livestock in parts of the European Union to a halt. It has also led to the slaughter of a quarter-million animals and to the almost incomprehensible sight of bloated and burning carcasses in an otherwise pastoral landscape.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOOG, CHARLES ''CHARLIE'' V., JR.
description: SKOOG-Charles ''Charlie'' V., Jr. For most of his life, Charlie was an advertising man. First, and probably last, as a copywriter. Over his 40 years at Hicks and Greist Agency, he advanced to Chairman of the Board. In fact, Charlie's 25 years as Chairman may be a record for that many years in office. His most memorable campaigns included ''Riunite on ice-so nice'', ''Beefeater-First name for the Martini'', Joe Namath's corn popper spot for Hamilton Beach, and the Little Mac Burger Maker. Born in New York on June 2, 1918 to Charles Vernon and Eleanor E. Skoog, he lived most of his life in New York City and East Quogue, Long Island, with the last 12 winters in Vero Beach, FL. Charlie attended Alexander Hamilton High School, City College of New York (nights) and New York University (nights), where he was a member of Violet Skull, Alpha Kappa Psi, Alpha Piu Sigma. He assisted the famed George Burton Hotchkins advanced copy classes. An ardent golfer, he traveled to England, Scotland and Ireland with a favorite foursome to play all the courses on which the British Open was and is featured. He was a member of the Garden City Golf Club, the Shinnicock Hills Golf Club, the Westhampton Country Club, serving as president of the latter. In Florida, Charlie played at John's Island and Bent Pine Golf Clubs. Starting in 1999. he instituted four Scholarship funds for the Volunteer Fire Departments of East Moriches, Eastport, Westhampton Beach and East Quogue that will continue in perpetuity. He attended St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, and will be interred at the Columbarium there. Charlie is survived by the Petersen family, Robin, Joel, Jamie and Chip, and the Rev. Bruce Rudolph of Patchogue, NY. Charlie served in the Army Air Corps during World War II from 1942-1946, with the 435th Troop Carriers Group in Africa and the European Theatre. He was awarded a Bronze Star and a Croix de Guerre and the Presidential Unit Citations for the glider and paratroop drops in Normandy Nothern France, Ardennes, Central Europe, Southern France, Rome Arena, Rhineland. He was honorably discharged as a Major in the Army Air Corps. Memorial contributions may be made to the charity of one's choice in Mr. Skoog's memory. A memorial service will take place on Saturday, June 16, 2001 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Westhampton Beach, Long Island, New York.

The desire, incidentally, is neither ironic nor metaphorical: she really does want to go to the seaside, mostly as a rest cure for her little girl, who has bronchitis. Dalibor Matanic, the writer and director, doesn't take things too seriously, and this slice-of-life film -- or rather, slice-of-working-life film -- has a cracked expansiveness, wafting off into magic realism like a feather on an afternoon breeze. Yet watching it is like being hit by a mellow thunderbolt: your enjoyment deepens as the movie ends.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIN, JANICE H.
description: LEVIN-Janice H. On March 23, 2001. Wife of the late Philip J. Levin. Loving mother of Catherine and Adam. Dear grandmother of Arielle Tepper, Matthew and Peter Levin. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, March 25, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral service Monday 11:30AM. LEVIN-Janice H. Congregation Emanu-El of the city of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Janice H. Levin. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary LEVIN-Janice H. Peter Martins, Howard Solomon, Chairman; Robert I. Lipp, President; the Board of Directors, dancers and staff of New York City Ballet mourn the loss of their dear friend and colleague, Janice H. Levin. A woman of great character and taste, she brought enduring passion and vibrancy to the art and artists she nurtured throughout her life. Her enthusiastic commitment permitted many to be the best they could be. Her keen eye and lively interest in young people shaped the careers of many NYCB dancers. The Janice H. Levin Dancer Award, created in 2000, to recognize promising talent will always remind us of her vision and belief in the future. The wit, insight, and generosity that Janice unfailingly shared with us as a Director, supporter, friend and fan are irreplaceable and will be treasured always. At this time all of our thoughts and sympathy are with her family. LEVIN-Janice H. The Trustees and staff of The Metropolitan Museum of Art mourn the loss of a generous donor and longtime friend, Janice Levin. She supported the Museum devotedly as an Honorary Trustee and Benefactor, and was an invaluable contributor to the renovation of the 19th-century paintings galleries, providing a major grant toward their renovation and pledging important Impressionist works by Degas, Pissarro and Sisley. One of those galleries now bears her name. She was a passionate collector and a generous friend, and we will miss her intelligence and her spirited wit. We extend our condolences to her entire family. James R. Houghton, Chairman Philippe de Montebello, Director David E. McKinney, President LEVIN-Janice H. The Trustees and staff of The Museum of Modern Art, note with sorrow the passing of their good friend, Janice Levin. With tremendous enthusiasm, an abiding interest, and constant generosiy, Janice championed the arts in myriad ways, from giving works to the Musuem's collections to supporting various programs and initiatives over the past four decades. Her foresight lead her to create a fellowship at MoMA to encourage the development of young scholars and curators. Her tremendous spirit and signature style will be sorely missed. Ronald S. Lauder, Chairman Agnes Gund, President Glenn D. Lowry, Director The Museum of Modern Art, NY LEVIN-Janice H. The School of American Ballet deeply mourns the death of our good friend, Janice Levin. The students, staff and faculty all join Chairman Albert Bellas, Chairman of Faculty Peter Martins, President Suzanne Davidson, and Executive Director Nathalie Gleboff in expressing their sympathies. Mrs. Levin was a long time Board Member and generous SAB benefactor who loved ballet and loved young people. She was a true individual-pithy, smart, glamorous, kind, no nonsense. Her scholarship recipients will never forget her and we all miss her tremendously. LEVIN-Janice. We are profoundly saddened by the passing of our esteemed client and friend, Janice Levin. She was a woman of great strength, integrity and compassion. Her decision to restore the old Paramount Building to its former glory is one that will be appreciated by all New Yorkers for decades to come. We extend our deepest sympathies and heartfelt condolences to her family and others who mourn her loss. Newmark & Co. Real Estate, Inc. LEVIN-Janice H. We are deeply saddened by the loss of a good friend, generous supporter and creator of the Janice and Philip Levin Music Center in Jaffa that has added so much to artistic life in Israel. Our sincere condolences to her family. America-Israel Cultural Foundation Vera Stern, President LEVIN-Janice H. The Trustees & staff of the International Center of Photography mourn the loss of Janice H. Levin, Honorary Trustee and long-time friend. Our deep sympathy to her family. Cornell Capa, Founding Dir Emeritus Willis Hartshorn, Director LEVIN-Janice. Our condolences to the entire Levin family on the passing of their beloved Janice. A truly remarkable and caring individual. Levien family

title: Martin Is Latest to Join Nets' Hefty Injury List

Before Walsh could check the injury, Martin told him his right leg was broken.

But the victory must come against the defending national champion, Michigan State.

title: DOWNTURN HURTS ENODIS
description: Shares in Enodis P.L.C., which supplies stoves to McDonald's and depends on the United States for more than half its earnings, dropped by more than one-third as the company warned of lower profits, ousted its chief executive and said it would cut 900 jobs, almost 10 percent of the work force, most of them in the United States. The company blamed the United States slowdown for its troubles. Enodis, formerly called Berisford P.L.C., said its chief executive, David Williams, had resigned and would be replaced shortly. Alan Cowell

Until this week, policy makers had cited concerns about rising prices in delaying a rate cut.

A 12-day itinerary begins in Nairobi, then goes to the Great Rift Valley and the Masai Mara National Reserve. Other stops include Tarangire National Park in Tanzania and the Ngorongoro Crater. Contact: (800) 223-6486 or www.unitedtouring.com .

title: F.D.A. REJECTS BRISTOL-MYERS CANCER TREATMENT
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb said last night that it received a ''not approvable'' letter from the Food and Drug Administration for UFT capsules plus leucovorin calcium tablets, a proposed treatment of advanced colorectal cancer. Bristol-Myers submitted a new drug application for UFT to the F.D.A. in February 1999, the company said in a statement. The company said it was ''very disappointed'' by the F.D.A. decision and remained committed to developing UFT around the world to its fullest potential. Bristol-Myers said it would consider all available options to obtain approval for UFT in the United States.

title: Informants Who Corrupt the Law
description: Law enforcement agencies have long relied on informants associated with criminal groups to provide information about illegal activities. But the value of these inside sources inevitably carries with it the risk that they might abuse their alliance with the law to enhance their criminal careers, making the government a partner in crime. The Justice Department recently issued rigorous new guidelines designed to prevent such abuses. The new rules, if vigorously enforced, should help ensure that the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Drug Enforcement Administration and other federal law enforcement agencies manage their informants properly.

description: Australia's auction of the high-speed wireless spectrum, or 3G, yielded just 1.17 billion Australian dollars ($585 million), which was close to analysts' expectations, but far below earlier estimates by the government. Prime Minister John Howard was counting on 2.6 billion dollars in revenue from spectrum auctions -- the bulk from 3G -- this fiscal year, which ends in June. Becky Gaylord (NYT)

title: Of Feminism and Slavery
description: The feminism of the 1944 musical ''Bloomer Girl'' is rather mundane by today's lights, and the show, set as the Civil War is beginning, links women's rights and slavery in a way that now feels politically correct rather than politically courageous. That's the biggest drag on the mostly charming but rarely rousing revival being performed at City Center through tomorrow as part of the popular Encores! series.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Democratic Senators Back An Immediate Tax Cut Plan

title: Garden Crowd Boos the Devil (No, It's Not Hockey)
description: Long before there was shock rock, there was shock gospel. Preachers traveled the country, setting up tent revival meetings to preach fire and brimstone. On Thursday night at Madison Square Garden it became clear just how far revival meetings had come when the singer known as Carman took the stage amid a shower of sparks and eight gyrating dancers in front of 18,550 fans. Eight hundred of those who attended were born again (not a statistic normally gathered at arena concerts) when Carman, who, for the past two decades has been one of Christian music's biggest stars, urged fans to step to the front of the stage and accept Jesus into their lives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HURST, MICHAEL
description: HURST-Michael. The trustees, faculty, staff and students of The Culinary Institute of America mourn the death of Michael Hurst, member of the Board of Trustees since 1994. Owner of 15th St. Fisheries in Fort Lauderdale, FL, Mr. Hurst has been a supporter of the CIA and culinary education for many years. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his family, friends, and colleagues.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SLATTERY, LOUIS R.
description: SLATTERY-Louis R., M.D. October 16, 1908-March 19, 2001. Loving father and devoted husband, in his 93rd year, at home in Manhattan, after a short illness. Survived by his children and grandchildren. Flushing High School '25, Columbia College '29, Columbia P&S '33. Veteran of the South Pacific campaigns of WWII, where he met and married Lela Hendry, his wife of 53 years, who died in 1997. Professor of Clinical Surgery at NYU School of Medicine, gifted surgeon, proudly affiliated with NYU for 60 years. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the S. Arthur Localio Surgical Research Laboratory, Department of Surgery, NYU School of Medicine, 550 First Avenue, NY, NY 10016. A memorial service will be held in Farkas Auditorium, NYU School of Medicine, Tuesday, April 17th, 4PM. His friends, former patients and students, and colleagues may contact his son John at 12 East 97th Street, NY, NY 10029.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSS, ALAN G.
description: ROSS-Alan G. Age 20, died suddenly March 22, 2001. Loving son of Michael and Leslie Ross and cherished brother of Christopher. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave, at 81 St, Sunday, March 25th, 3:30 PM. Interment private. Contribtutions in his memory may be made to the Alan G. Ross Memorial Writing Scholarship, given by the Alliance for Young Artists and Writers, Inc., attn: B. J. Adler, Exec. Director, 555 Bway, 4th flr, NYC 10012. ROSS-Alan G. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses profound sympathy to the family of Alan G. Ross. We reach out to all of his loved ones with compassionate understanding, hoping that some measure of consolation are to be drawn from a reservoir of memories that are beautiful but all too few from a life that was much too brief. Robert A. Bernhard, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary

title: Sports of The Times; Major-Major Overpowers Mid-Major
description: THIS is what Jud Heathcote might have told his colleague Mark Few over lunch if they had managed to keep their weekly tte--tte last Tuesday: ''My friend, you are about to run into a very major team from a very major conference.''

title: DEMOCRATS BACK IMMEDIATE TAX CUT PROPOSED BY G.O.P.
description: The idea of a $60 billion tax cut this year to stimulate the economy gained strength in Congress today, but new questions arose about whether a consensus could be reached on the details.

title: INTERNET COMPANY EXPLORES OPTIONS
description: The British Internet directory company, Scoot.com, said it had hired Merrill Lynch to explore strategic options as it reported a widening operating loss for the 15 months to Dec. 31. For the period, the company lost 12.2 million ($17.3 million) before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, compared with a loss of 8.1 million ($11.5 million) a year earlier. Sales for the period rose 19 percent, to 8.9 million. Suzanne Kapner

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about Senate negotiations on a campaign finance bill referred incorrectly in some copies to the state represented by Senator Chuck Hagel, who sponsored a rival bill. It is Nebraska, not Alaska.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday about a dispute at Brown University over an advertisement in the student newspaper denouncing the idea of reparations for slavery misidentified the man for whom the university was named in 1804. It was Nicholas Brown, a merchant, not his uncle John Brown. While John Brown and Nicholas's father were established slave traders, there is no evidence on the activities of Nicholas Brown himself.

title: PLANE MAKER'S PROFIT GROWS
description: The Brazilian jet-maker Empresa Brasileira de Aeronutica, or Embraer, reported a net profit for 2000 of $300 million, up 57 percent from $192 million in 1999. Embraer, the world's fourth-largest civilian aircraft company, posted sales of $2.4 billion, up from $1.6 billion in 1999. The company has received more than 200 orders for its newest regional jet, the 70-seat ERJ-170. Jennifer L. Rich

title: Compensating Abner Louima
description: New York City and its police union have reached a tentative agreement to pay $8.6 million to Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who was tortured by a white police officer in a Brooklyn precinct bathroom in 1997. Mr. Louima clearly deserves financial compensation for an unspeakable act of brutality. But his agony also requires another response: a firm commitment by the city to pursue recent reforms designed to improve the way the police treats the city's minorities. These reforms are the most important civic legacy of Mr. Louima's suffering.

title: Witnesses to Revolution Wrote History's First Draft
description: In 1777, during the American Revolution, a British Army officer recorded in his journal the aftermath of a brutal battle fought over terrain near Ticonderoga, N.Y. ''The wolves,'' he wrote, ''came down in numbers from the mountains to devour the dead, and even some that were in a kind of manner buried, they tore out of the earth; the great stench thro the country being the cause of their coming down.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, JOSEPH I.
description: WEISS-Joseph I., Rabbi. West End Temple-Sinai Congregation greatly mourns the loss of its beloved Rabbi, Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss. His strength, leadership, brilliance, compassion, kindness and sensitivity have been a blessing to all who have known him. He served as Rabbi at West End Temple for over 50 years. Generations of families have learned Torah and spent the most meaningful moments of their lives with Rabbi Weiss. Our special Rabbi was also our best friend. The immensity of our loss is overwhelming. He is survived his wife, Bath Ami, his son, Edward, his son, William, his daughter-in-law, Kathlyn and his new grandson, Houston Moses Weiss. Memorial services will be held at West End Temple, 147-02 Newport Avenue, Neponsit, NY on Sunday, March 25 at 1:00PM. WEISS-Rabbi Joseph I. The board and members of the Ladies Guild of West End Temple mourn the loss of our beloved rabbi, a friend and mentor for over 50 years. Judith Rubin, President

title: Night Life After Puffy: Frisks, but Not of Madonna
description: On a dead night for many nightclubs -- Sunday -- hip-hop became great business for Club New York.

title: You Can Take the Hat Out of the Country. . .
description: Downtown yesterday, signs of spring were blooming everywhere. On First Street, a graffiti writer whitewashed a mural to begin anew. On Second Avenue, a bar sign proclaimed, ''It stopped pouring outside; I'm still pouring inside.''

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OLD KENT FINANCIAL CORP., Grand Rapids, Mich., and Fifth Third Bancorp, Cincinnati, said they had agreed to sell six banks in western Michigan to satisfy antitrust rules affecting the $5 billion purchase of Old Kent by Fifth Third. Fifth Third announced shareholder approval of the all-stock purchase of Old Kent on March 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CURCI, MICHAEL
description: CURCI-Michael. On March 21, 2001. A retired Judge, New York State Supreme Court. Retired Lieutenant Colonel, World War II veteran. Retired Major General, New York State Guard. Practiced law with wife, firm of Curci, Clancy & Curci. Graduate 1949 St. John's Law School. Beloved husband of Angela Surace. Devoted father of Lucy Curci-Gonzalez, Anthony, Frank and Paula. Cherished grandfather of Angela & Monica. Loving father-in-law of Arturo Gonzalez-Alfonso. Reposing Scarpaci Funeral Home, 1401 86th St., Brooklyn until Mon., 9AM. Mass St. Frances Cabrini Church, Monday 9:15AM. Interment Calverton National Cemetery. Viewing Sat. and Sunday 2-5PM and 7-9:30PM.

description: NIEDERMANN-Ilse. Beloved wife of the late Fred. Loving mother of Ted (Ricka) and Norman (Helga). Cherished grandmother. Private services.

title: Kelly, 0 for 175, Is in Top Spot for Now at T.P.C.
description: Nobody has ever captured his first PGA Tour victory at the Players Championship. The T.P.C. at Sawgrass is so treacherous, the field is so stout and the pressure is so intense, even proven winners can become unglued at one of golf's most prestigious events.

title: Supporter Of Pardon For Fugitive Has Regrets
description: Abraham H. Foxman, a prominent Jewish leader who was a pivotal figure in the behind-the-scenes effort to secure a pardon for the fugitive financier Marc Rich, said yesterday that he was wrong to have lobbied for Mr. Rich.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GALFUNT, ABRAHAM
description: GALFUNT-Abraham ''Hap'' WWII veteran and POW, died suddenly March 22, 2001. He is survived by Kathy Dowsett with whom he shared his life, his sister Judith Brenner, his nephew Dr. Richard Brenner (Elizabeth), Marsha Gardner (Michael) and greatnieces Laura and Jennifer (Alberto), great-nephews Daniel (Caroline) and Alex. He is also survived by many friends whose lives he has touched and enriched. He was a Mason, Senior Past District Deputy of the 2nd Manhattan District. Donations can be made to the Masonic Medical Research Lab in Utica, NY. Funeral services Sunday, March 25, noon, at Plaza Chapel, 91st St and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC. Interment to follow, Beth Moses Cemetery.

title: NOKIA TO BUY BACK SHARES
description: Nokia, the world's largest mobile-phone maker, said it planned to buy back as much as 1.45 billion euros ($1.3 billion) in stock to finance acquisitions or to cancel the shares.

title: ENRON SALE OF UNIT TO SIERRA PACIFIC IS DOUBTED
description: The Enron Corporation said yesterday that its $3.1 billion sale of the Portland General Electric Company to Sierra Pacific Resources might not be completed. ''There's probably a 5 percent probability that Sierra Pacific's purchase of Portland General will be consummated,'' the chief executive, Jeffrey Skilling, said on a conference call with investors. Enron said in January that Sierra Pacific might not be able to sell a Nevada power plant stake as needed to win regulatory approval for the Portland General transaction. Enron blamed a California law that barred public utilities from shedding generators until 2005 because of an electricity shortage.

title: Pressed on Chechnya, Putin Cites Macedonia
description: The European Union said today that it had pressed Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, to find a ''political solution'' in Chechnya, but Mr. Putin defended his handling of the situation, saying he saw parallels with the problems developing in Macedonia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'NEILL, LOUISE S.
description: O'NEILL-Louise S. On March 22, 2001. Loving mother of Brian O'Neill. Sister of Eleanor Testu, Countess de Balincourt. Friends may call at the Abbey, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Sunday, 7-9PM and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St Joseph's Church, 371 6th Avenue at Washington Place, Tuesday, 9:30AM.

title: Russia Expels 4 Americans And Vows 'Other Measures'
description: Russia said today that it was expelling four United States diplomats for ''activities incompatible with their status,'' the diplomatic phrase for espionage, and added that it would take ''other measures to halt the unlawful activities'' of official American representatives, but did not elaborate.

title: Albanians in Macedonia Mourn 2 Killed by Police
description: Hundreds of Albanians came today to bury a father and a son, shot on Thursday by police officers at a checkpoint when the two men brandished grenades, as scattered mortar and heavy machine-gun fire echoed off the Sar Mountains that surround the town.

title: Op-Art
description: Opened in 1948, closed this week, 2,200 acres, taller than the Statue of Liberty, Fresh Kills is the largest landfill in the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, HAROLD J.
description: MILLS-Harold J. 77, of Glen Rock, NJ. Beloved husband of Aurelia De Felice Mills (Judy), adored father to Penny, Sandy, & Lanny; Happy grandfather to Courtney, Marc, and Sydney; loving fatherin-law of Lin Chu and Angela Mills; dear older friend to Ken Main; darling uncle to Susan Littman and Glenn Appleman. A World War II veteran, member of the Engineering Honor Society Eta Kappa Nu, and the IEEE. Proud electrical engineering graduate of CCNY. A committed citizen advocate in Bergen County. Funeral 1 P.M., Sunday, Louis Suburban Chapels, Fairlawn, New Jersey. 1-800-525-3834

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday with an article about a proposal to cut taxes $60 billion this year misidentified a House member who was walking to the Capitol. He was Richard E. Neal, Democrat of Massachusetts, not Dave Camp, Republican of Michigan.

title: WELLS FARGO TO PURCHASE H.D. VEST FOR $127.5 MILLION
description: Wells Fargo & Company agreed yesterday to buy H. D. Vest Inc. for $127.5 million to expand its financial planning business. Wells Fargo will pay $21.03 for each H. D. Vest share and option -- three times the Thursday closing price of $7 a share for the company, which is based in Irving, Tex. Wells said it expected to complete the acquisition in the next three months. The purchase is in line with the goal of Wells Fargo's chief executive, Richard Kovacevich, to increase earnings from trust, investment, advisory work and insurance to 25 percent of total earnings from 15 percent in the next three to five years, said Dan Goldfarb, who oversees financial services investments at David L. Babson & Company in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Baltimore Technologies Shares Fall on Forecast
description: Baltimore Technologies P.L.C., Europe's largest security software maker, today forecast first-quarter sales below what some analysts expected, blaming the economic slowdown in the United States. Its shares fell as much as 27 percent.

title: Rowland Evans, 79, TV Host And Conservative Columnist
description: Rowland Evans, a provocative newspaper columnist, commentator and author who antagonized liberal politicians and championed conservative causes, died yesterday at a Washington hospital.

title: AMOCO RESISTS RESOLUTION
description: BP Amoco has excluded from its April 19 annual meeting a resolution asking the company to reconsider drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge of Alaska. The resolution was sponsored by a group of American and British investors, some of whom hold their shares in the form of depository receipts. BP Amoco rebuffed a similar move a few weeks ago, arguing that foreign investors who hold their stock in the form of depository receipts could not initiate shareholder resolutions. The shareholders resubmitted the resolution March 8, believing they had recruited the required amount of registered holders of common stock. But a BP Amoco spokeswoman said the group did not meet its guidelines. Suzanne Kapner

title: Outrun Fate? Not for Iranian Women
description: One of the Iranian cinema's gifts to the world has been to demonstrate the primal power of simple stripped-down images of people, especially children, unself-consciously living their lives. In Marzieh Meshkini's stunner of a film, ''The Day I Became a Woman,'' the first of three related vignettes focuses on a little girl, Hava (Fatemeh Cheragh Akhtar), the day she turns 9. This isn't just any birthday but the end of childhood, according to Islamic law. Beginning at noon, she must cloak herself in a chador. The days of innocent fun and games with male playmates are over forever.

title: Delayed Justice in Argentina
description: Today marks the 25th anniversary of Argentina's last successful military coup, which brought to power a junta whose murderous repression of Argentina's peaceful left became known as the ''dirty war.'' It is a sign of Argentina's growing confidence as a democracy that some of the soldiers and mid-level military officers responsible for the abuses may soon be brought to trial.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, SHELAGH B.
description: RICHARDS-Shelagh B. Age 74. Of Sewickley, PA., formerly of New York, Wednesday, March 21, 2001. Wife of the late R.S. Richards, Jr. and David H. McConnell. Beloved mother of Stephanie Anderson McConnell, Constance McConnell Rush and Shelagh Kip Nicholas and her husband Rodney. Grandmother of Heather McConnell Rush. Stepmother of Leila Jones Richards and William Larimer Richards. Half sister of Peter Bertschmann. Mrs. Richards was a member of the Presbyterian Church of Sewickley, Allegheny Country Club, Duquesne Club, Greenbacks Investment Club and Litte Sewickley Garden Club. She attended Masters School, Dobbs Ferry. Visitation Monday, 10 AM until time of Memorial Service at 11 AM in the Presbyterian Church of Sewickley Chapel. Memorials may be made to Sewickley Valley Hospital, Oncology Dept., 701 Broad St, Sewickley, PA. 15143.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DIFRANCESCO, CHRISTINA
description: DiFRANCESCO - Christina (Teenie). Passed away on March 22, 2001. Beloved wife of Harry. Adored mother of Jennie and Mike Lardiere and Chris and John Bricker. Cherished sister of Charlotte and Dominick Natale. Dearest grandmother of Tony and Francesca Quinn and John Charles Bricker. She is joining her parents Jennie and John D'Antonio in heaven. She was an exquisite human being who leaves a legacy of laughter, warmth and strength. She will be missed deeply. In lieu of flowers donations should be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Leukemia Research, in her name. Services will be at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St. Saturday, 3/24 and Sunday, 3/25, 25:00 PM and 7-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian burial St. Ignatius Loyola Church on Monday at 10:00 AM.

title: Russians Find Pride, and Regret, in Mir's Splashdown
description: For all the anxieties it caused during its 86,330 laps around the planet, Russia's Mir space station executed its final program for self-destruction with a series of crisp electronic salutes that sent the 134-ton leviathan streaking out of orbit like a midday meteor shower over the South Pacific.

title: PROXICOM, AN INTERNET CONSULTANT, TO LAY OFF 227
description: Proxicom Inc., an Internet consulting company, said yesterday that it would lay off 227 employees, or 19 percent of its work force, and that its first-quarter results would be below analysts' forecasts because of weakening demand for information services in the United States and Europe. Proxicom will lay off consultants and back-office support staff, the chief financial officer, Kenneth Tarpey, said. Employees at the company's Reston, Va., headquarters and in other United States offices will account for 78 percent of the job cuts. Workers in London and Munich will represent 22 percent, he said.

title: Beliefs; Some surprising commonalities in the status of believers and nonbelievers in American society.
description: Atheism, it seems, has fallen upon evil days. Certainly, the sad demise of Madalyn Murray O'Hair, the American original who successfully challenged public school prayer in the Supreme Court, makes one think so. A woman who prided herself on being the most hated person in America, Ms. O'Hair did not even die for the atheist cause she had so vociferously defended. Instead, the remains found on a Texas ranch suggest that she -- and two of her family members -- fell victim to a kidnapping and murder.

title: St. Lawrence Surprises Dartmouth
description: Students at Dartmouth College are on spring break, and it certainly looked as if the Big Green were taking some time off as well. Dartmouth, the No. 1-ranked team in the country and seeded first in the inaugural N.C.A.A. women's Frozen Four, fell to fourth-seeded St. Lawrence, 3-1, in the semifinals tonight at Mariucci Arena.

title: Despite a Sluggish Start, Arizona Finishes Ole Miss
description: Arizona was bigger, Arizona was better and, even though it took the Wildcats until the second half to awaken and prove this against Mississippi, they eventually did it.

title: South American Trade Bloc Under Siege
description: In a more just world, the trade bloc known as Mercosur would be in a celebratory mood when its 10th birthday rolls around on Monday. Since its founding, trade among Mercosur's four members has tripled, to $15 billion a year; foreign investment has soared; inflation has been tamed; and the group has become the world's third-largest market, with more than 210 million people and combined production of more than $1 trillion a year.

title: Venus Williams Wins Easily, and a Lesson Is Learned
description: Venus Williams heard the relentless boos of last week replaced today by polite applause at the Ericsson Open.

description: HER official title is ''obscenity and pornography complaints ombudsman,'' which is quite a mouthful, she acknowledged. So Paula J. Houston has grown accustomed to the less formal ''porn czar,'' and she wears it proudly, even if with a laugh.

description: Along with all the other former presidents, I was a strong supporter of the North America Free Trade Agreement when it was initiated in 1994. Free trade among the United States, Mexico and Canada has, in general, been good for the people and the economies of all three nations.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary of the animation pioneer William Hanna by The Associated Press yesterday misidentified the animated cartoon character that he and his partner, Joseph Barbera, based on the television character Sergeant Bilko. It was Top Cat, not Yogi Bear.

description: The 18-year-old student seized in the shooting of five people at a high school here on Thursday had apparently suffered several recent disappointments, including rejection by the Navy when he tried to enlist two days earlier, and had come to his school hunting an assistant principal who had disciplined him not long before, law enforcement officials said today.

title: Supply and Demand Among the Faithful
description: Drive down 16th Street in Washington, and you will see evidence of the religious diversity that has struck visitors to America since Toqueville. Church after church will flash by: Grace Lutheran, the National Church of the Nazarene, Trinity A.M.E. Zion, All Souls Unitarian. And on and on. To a small group of sociologists, the reason there are so many kinds of houses of worship is no different from the reason there are so many brands of detergent or toothpaste at the supermarket: economics.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEIKIND, ELENA
description: LEIKIND-Elena. The members of the Forward Association and the staff of the Forward newspapers mourn the shocking, untimely death of our dear colleague, Elena Leikind. Assistant to editors of the Yiddish Forverts for the past decade, she was a patriot of the Yiddish language and a partisan of the Forward newspapers. A daughter of postwar Jewish Kovne, she moved with her family to a new life in Israel in 1971, and came to the US 12 years later. She brought to her work an engaging affability, fluency in five languages, and a constant concern for the people she worked with. To her dear friend, Stephen Dowling, her parents Israel and Raisa Leikind and sister Jana Goren of Raanana, Israel, and other members of her family in both countries, we convey our condolences. Zol di erd ir gring zayn. Dr. Barnett Zumoff, President Samuel Norich, General Manager

The other was to embrace his heritage -- his father's African-American roots, his mother's Judaism -- and to be just a California kid.

title: Overtaxed Mothers Need Relief
description: A tax cut seems certain this year, and many groups of taxpayers are scrambling for special favors. But no one is talking about the people who need tax relief the most: mothers. Married mothers are arguably the most heavily taxed workers in the country, even though they're often in the least desirable jobs, with low pay and few benefits.

description: Charles K. Johnson, president of the International Flat Earth Research Society since 1972, who stubbornly and cheerfully insisted that those who believed the earth was round had been duped, died on Monday at his home in Lancaster, Calif. He was 76.

title: Contortions of Psychiatry in China
description: The abuse of psychiatry to intimidate and torture dissidents in the Soviet Union was well documented and loudly deplored by the West. The practice in China has received less comment, but Beijing, too, imprisons nonconformists as mentally ill -- a policy that deserves worldwide attention and forceful condemnation from foreign governments, including the United States.

title: Catching the Beat Of Urban Life
description: ARTISTS debating whether or not to have a Web site should heed the current exhibition at Pelham Art Center here. ''City Rhythms'' includes the works of 24 artists and 8 of them were discovered on the Internet. Summing up her experience as what might be called a desk chair curator, Titia Hulst said, ''Search engines are wonderful things.''

title: Conflict Resolution, Made Simple
description: Workplace breeds conflict, and office politics makes for strange bedfellows. Sometimes, it seems, tense situations are resolved by good humor, by good sense or by letting fate take its course.

title: Tossing Out Old Magazines, by the Ton

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Glory That Was Penn Station
description: Peter Moore, who died in 1993, was known for photographing avant-garde performances. But he also documented the three-year-long demolition of the old Pennsylvania Station. More than 100 of his images are reproduced in THE DESTRUCTION OF PENN STATION: Photographs by Peter Moore (Distributed Art Publishers, $40), edited by Moore's wife, Barbara. As the sequence begins, in August 1963, one can almost hear the doomed station laboriously exhaling its last breath, its grandeur not wholly departed but long since compromised by the carelessness of the struggling Pennsylvania Railroad. By June 1964, the protective tarpaulins are in place. Behind them, Moore records the shocking evisceration of the main waiting room, a process that has also revealed the 20th-century steel framework underlying this stupendous recreation of the tepidarium at the Baths of Caracalla. October 1965 brings the final glimpses of the vast, faceted lightscape formed by the barrel vaults of the concourse ceiling. These have been rendered into skeletal, stub-ended fragments by March 1966, when the chronicle ends. Powerfully composed and richly tonal, Moore's photographs are in one sense an appreciation of the undeniable bravura of the demolition. But ultimately, by allowing contemporary viewers to experience freshly that slow-motion tragedy, they illustrate why New Yorkers' sense of loss endures to this day. David W. Dunlap

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORRESTER, WILLIAM RAY
description: FORRESTER-William Ray. A constitutional law professor whose six decade career included stints as Dean of three law schools. Died on February 16, 2001 after a brief illness. He was 90. Mr. Forrester was born in Little Rock, Arkansas. He graduated from the University of Arkansas and the University of Chicago Law School. His honors included Order of the COIF and the Law Review. After six years with a Chicago firm, Mr. Forrester took a teaching position at Tulane University in 1941. In 1949, he was named Dean of the Vanderbilt Law School in Nashville, TN. He returned to Tulane as Dean in 1952. He left in 1963 to serve for a decade as Dean of the Cornell University Law School in Ithaca, New York. During his career, he served as a visiting professor at Yale, Stanford University of Georgia and the University of London. He began teaching in 1976 at the University of California's Hastings College of Law where students three times voted him the outstanding professor. He remained on the faculty there until two months prior to his death. An early proponent of civil rights and a staunch defender of the rule of law, Mr. Forrester wrote extensively on federal jurisdiction and procedure and constitutional issues. He published several books in these areas. He was a member of several national boards and fraternal organizations as well as The Boston Club. Survivors include his wife Celine Penn Forrester; 3 sons William Ray Forrester, Jr. and Stephen Labarre Forrester, both of New Orleans and David Chalaron Forrester of Baton Rouge; a daughter Catherine Forrester Cleland of Kensington, Maryland; and four grandchildren. A private funeral and burial were held at the Lake Lawn Cemetery in New Orleans.

Over the next 56 years, using his inheritance from a family fortune made in banking and the silk trade, he sharpened his taste for serious literature, collecting some of the greatest books and manuscripts ever produced. His acquisitions included such rarities as, from Egypt, a second-century Greek manuscript of the Gospel According to St. John, a 14th-century manuscript of Dante's ''Divine Comedy,'' a 15th-century Hebrew manuscript of the Story of Esther, an illuminated Persian manuscript of the Book of Kings, also from the 15th century, and a broadside of Martin Luther's ''95 Theses,'' like the one Luther nailed to a church door in Wittenberg, Germany, in 1517.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUNDELL, ABNER JEROME
description: SUNDELL-Abner Jerome. Age 87, died Sunday, March 11, 2001. He was born in New York City on August 18, 1913, the son of Isadore and Molly Sundell. During World War II, he served in the U.S. Army in northern France. He wrote cowboy stories for pulp westerns and was involved in the early days of comic books as a writer and editor. He was a magazine editor, an artist, and founder and manager of Offset Color Separations. He grew up in Brooklyn, brought up his family in Freeport, Long Island, and then moved into Manhattan. After retiring, he spent summers and winters in San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, and worked full time on his multimedia canvasses, which were exhibited in one-man shows in New York, Mexico, and Hot Springs, Arkansas. He was preceded in death by his wife of 59 years, Thelma Gordon Sundell, & by his sister, Beatrice Irwin. He is survived by two sons, Eric Gordon Sundell and his wife, Milanne, of Monticello, Arkansas, and Jonathan Douglas Sundell of Winston-Salem, North Carolina; 1 brother, Sidney Sundell of Enosburg Falls, Vermont; two sisters, Zelda Simon and Marilyn Levinson of North Miami Beach, Florida; and three grandsons, Michael, Jack and Joe. title: SOAPBOX; A Bridge (and Tunnel) Too Far
description: TOLLS at the Hudson River crossings from New Jersey into New York City go up today to an outrageous $6, a 50 percent increase over what for a decade has been $4. Six dollars, which is more than the minimum hourly wage, is roughly enough for 17 toll stops on the Garden State Parkway, a Newark Bears baseball ticket, or two glossy magazines -- one, if it's the really fancy mag with the seven-figure suburban homes. Bet your E-ZPass you won't be settling into one of those abodes while shelling out a hundred and twenty a month to drive over a bridge.

title: Non-Hispanic Whites May Soon Be a Minority in Texas
description: After a decade of enormous growth, particularly among Hispanics, Texas may soon become, after California, the second big state in which non-Hispanic whites are no longer a majority.

title: African Safaris
description: African safaris are exciting, but expensive. One way to make them more affordable is to shorten them, which is what United Touring Company has done. Rates start at $2,495 a person, based on double occupancy, for a 10-day trip that stops in Kenya and Tanzania; the price includes round-trip air fare from New York. A 12-day itinerary begins in Nairobi, then goes to the Great Rift Valley and the Masai Mara National Reserve. Other stops include Tarangire National Park in Tanzania and the Ngorongoro Crater. The price is $3,095 a person, including air fare from New York. When booking safari trips, be sure to check which months are best for wildlife viewing in the regions visited. Contact: (800) 223-6486 or www.unitedtouring.com .

title: March 18-24; McCain-Feingold Gains
description: The Senate delivered a 69-31 rebuff to President Bush and a victory to Senators John McCain and Russell D. Feingold by rejecting a proposal to require unions and corporations to get permission from members or stockholders to use certain funds for political purposes. The vote was just one in a series that showed Mr. McCain, an Arizona Republican, and Mr. Feingold, a Wisconsin Democrat, holding firm in their drive for a bill banning unlimited and unregulated donations to the political parties. By week's end there was even talk of compromise in the air. Alison Mitchell

title: Racewalker Wins 2 Titles in 2 Days
description: KIRSTEN JORDAN of Rye High School accomplished a remarkable racewalking double two weekends ago. It took years of workouts and double workouts. It took the special weekend contributions of her family. It also took a scoop of frozen yogurt, a dose of her brother's antibiotics, a bunch of vitamin C pills, some echinacea tablets and a 9:30-to-bed evening.

Funeral service will be held on Monday, March 26 at 9:30 AM, also at Frank E. Campbell. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Gurdjieff Foundation, 123 E. 63 St., NY NY 10021.

title: Adolph Levis, Entrepreneur And Philanthropist, Dies at 89
description: Adolph Levis, the inventor of the Slim Jim dried meat snack, died on Tuesday in the Hospice by the Sea in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 89.

title: Megan's Law Backer Widens Her Sights
description: LAURA AHEARN, a leading proponent of Megan's Laws worldwide, the laws that require registration of sex offenders and the notification of their neighbors, is widening her scope. Ms. Ahearn, a certified social worker who lives in Stony Brook with her husband and two children, makes it clear that she is not abandoning her support of notification -- she is just expanding her advocacy. Ms. Ahearn, 37, helped write amendments that strengthened the state's Megan's Law, officially known as the Sex Offender Registration Act, passed in 1996. Two years later, she founded an advocacy group called Parents for Megan's Law in Stony Brook, and she now serves as the group's full-time executive director.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORN, CHARLES
description: CORN-Charles. Dearest friend, beloved client, writer and historian extraordinaire. Your charm, your wit, your brilliant mind were unparalleled. You were a gentleman in every way and you will be deeply missed. My heartfelt condolences to your longtime partner Rosalie Mullerwright and to your entire family. BJ Robbins, Literary Agent

title: March 18-24; Out, Out
description: A cold war-style diplomatic war broke out between the United States and Russia. In the wake of last month's arrest of an F.B.I. agent, Robert Philip Hanssen, on charges of spying for Moscow, President Bush ordered that four Russian intelligence officers working under diplomatic cover in Washington be expelled. They were given 10 days to leave the country. Secretary of State Colin L. Powell told the Russian ambassador that another 46 Russian diplomats -- all believed to be Russian intelligence officers -- must leave by July 1. The Russian government quickly responded in kind, ordering American diplomats to leave Moscow. James Risen

title: If the Car Fits, Wear It: Audi Leaves Its Footprint on Footwear
description: NO, a spoiler does not pop up from the heel if you run fast, but the Adidas Kobe basketball shoe aims to be as sleek and athletic as the Audi TT. Why shouldn't it? It, too, came out of the Audi Design Studio in Simi Valley, Calif.

description: A developer's hopes to put an Ikea in Brooklyn are coming closer to realization, and residents are stepping up their complaints.

title: Michigan State Depending on Inside Game to Defend Title
description: The workout is called the ''war drill'' and is a staple of Michigan State practice. Five players line up outside the 3-point arc, another five are in the paint and an assistant coach purposely misses a long-range shot. The players near the basket must box out the ones on the perimeter then rush back to grab the rebound and, ideally, begin a fast break.

description: After watching a puppet show at their Brooklyn school about child abuse, two boys told a counselor on Friday that they had been sexually assaulted last year. Yesterday, detectives arrested a 15-year-old boy and charged him with sexually abusing the two youngsters, the authorities said.

description: Tolls and fares at the river crossings operated by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey rose today at 3 a.m., and drivers who pay cash for tolls face the sharpest increases.

title: Rational Catholics
description: To the Editor:

title: Oscar Likes Writers. Typewriters.
description: AS I am a writer, someone who slumps in a chair and stares at a screen for a living, my life hardly makes a dramatic mise en scne. So I found it strange when I noticed recently, while reading the paper in bed -- as I do every morning for a Dr. Johnson-like four- or five-hour stretch of procrastination -- that there were some half-dozen films out featuring writers, real and fictional: ''Quills,'' ''Before Night Falls,'' ''Wonder Boys,'' ''Almost Famous,'' ''State and Main'' and ''Finding Forrester.''

title: Giving It the Old College Try. Twice.
description: In the next few months, thousands of high school seniors throughout the state will agonize over which college to attend in the fall. But for many of them, that apparently will not be enough. Of the 55,000 seniors who will head to the campus of their choice, more than a third will be making the same decision over again within two years.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELDER, ELDON
description: ELDER-Eldon. Memorial service will be held on Monday, April 2, at 5 P.M at the Yale Club of New York., City. Mr. Elder died on Monday, December 11, 2000 at the age of 79 from heart failure. Mr. Elder designed the Delacorte Theatre in Central Park of the New York Shakespeare Festival. Mr. Elder was a Professor of Design at Brooklyn College, a member of the United Scenic Artists, a founding member of the United States Institute for Theatre Technology, Inc. and an alumnus of the Yale School of Drama.

title: March 18-24; A Tax Cut, Even Sooner
description: When the economy stumbles, politicians cannot afford to be seen as doing nothing. So as stock prices continued to drop, Republicans and Democrats in Congress rallied behind a proposal for a $60 billion tax cut this year. But there is still deep division over the details. Which taxpayers will get what? Will they get a check from the government, less withheld from their paychecks? Will this year's cut be tied to the 10-year plan favored by President Bush? All that is yet to be worked out. David E. Rosenbaum

title: The World: The Middle East; Disillusionment With a Friend
description: PALESTINIAN leaders watched with shock last week as the Bush administration embraced Israel's new hard-line leader and distanced itself from the peace effort that Washington had sponsored for the previous eight years.

title: Avoiding Submerged Containers Test for Sailors
description: Surging toward the finish line of the Vendee Globe single-handed around-the-world race late last January, all was right in the British sailor Ellen MacArthur's universe. With her powerful sloop Kingfisher creaming upwind at 11 knots and with what appeared to be clear sailing ahead, MacArthur was in the final stages of a record- setting performance.
