title: Ideas & Trends: Fossil Find; The Family of Man Grows a Little Larger
description: IF it is hubris for human beings to presume they can solve the mystery of their ultimate origins, the punishment would seem to be that each gratifying triumph, each new piece of hard-won knowledge, introduces as many troubling questions as answers, usually more. One step forward, and still no one can be sure if the search is any closer to its goal.

title: Crossroads; The World Starts Getting in the Superpower's Way
description: THE world can be hard on a new president. John F. Kennedy acted early -- and reaped disaster -- at the Bay of Pigs. Bill Clinton got the same result by not acting in Rwanda, and by waiting to act in Bosnia. Both came to publicly rue their missteps.

title: A Neighborhood Restaurant in Larchmont
description: SNUG among the antique shops on the Post Road, Watercolor Cafe is a tiny eatery serving a neighborhood clientele. On the plus side -- a nicety more restaurants should offer -- a printed specials menu had prices, the date and an appealing selection of currently available wines by the glass. On the whole, food was prepared skillfully, presented attractively and, considering the quality, priced reasonably.

title: In Orange County, Surf and Sophisticates
description: FOR many Americans, even Californians to the north, Orange County lacks cachet. The prevailing image is of homogenized housing developments and strip malls built on former orange groves where conservative white-bread attitudes prevail, where the airport is named after John Wayne, and where oh-so-wholesome Disneyland is about the only attraction.

title: Jennifer Coleman, Peter Kohan
description: Jennifer Stacy Coleman and Peter Laurence Kohan are to be married today by Rabbi Rene B. Goldberg at the Rockleigh Country Club in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: March 18-24; Space, the Final Tourist Frontier
description: Dennis Tito is one of those people who have been seized by a longing for the ultimate high -- a joy ride to outer space. But he was able to take his fantasies a step further than most. A former NASA employee who made a bundle as an investment banker, he plunked down $20 million for a spin aboard the Mir, the orbiting laboratory launched when Moscow still ruled a mighty empire.

description: FRIED-Rose. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother of Arthur and Goldy Fried and Phyllis Trautman. Holmes, III, Colly Holmes and Nathaniel Holmes, III. Grandmother to six grandchildren and 3 great grandchildren. Mrs. Holmes was the owner of Mili Holmes' Studio and was well known for her ecclesiastical needlepoint designs, with designs in 40 cathedrals and churches including the National Cathedral in Washington, DC, St. Mark's Epsicopal Church in New Canaan, CT, and churches from Wassau WI to Columbia, SA. Funeral services will be held 11:00 AM, Monday, March 26th in St. Mark's Episcopal Church, Oenoke Ridge Road, New Canaan, CT. title: Six Crackers And a Challenge And a Life Lesson
description: WHEN I was 24, I realized that I had spent my entire life in school. I wanted to base my adult career choice on real-world experience, rather than just falling off the graduate-school conveyor belt. So I dropped out of the law and business schools at Harvard and started leading small groups on Outward Bound hiking trips in the middle of nowhere in British Columbia.

title: Emily Loft, Steven Wagshal

title: The Right 'Oklahoma!' The Wrong Actress
description: I am glad that G. H. Kanter [letter, March 18]enjoyed ''Oklahoma!'' in 1943 as much as I did. However, in order for him to see Charlotte Greenwood as Aunt Eller, he would have had to wait until 1955, when the movie version was produced. Ms. Greenwood was under contract to 20th Century Fox during that period and was busy making a host of wartime musicals such as ''The Gang's All Here.'' The actress he saw as Aunt Eller in 1943 was Betty Garde, who, along with Joseph Buloff as Ali Hakim the peddler, was in the cast for most of its run. But I am sure he fondly remembers Alfred Drake, Bambi Linn and Joan McCracken.

description: STEINBERG-Helen nee Gottschalk, March 23rd, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Myron. Loving mother of Michael and Diane, Alan & Jackie, & Leslie Endelson. Adoring grandmother of Alexis and Erik, Matthew, Jessica, Kimberly and Samantha, and devoted greatgrandmother of Jordan and Tyler. Service is on Sunday, 11:45 A.M., at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory to Parkinson's Foundation.

Jenny Yang, Kil Huh

title: Judging Evil That Was Banal
description: FEW people recall that not one but two rounds of war crimes trials were held at Nuremberg after World War II. The first (1945-46) was international and tried the two dozen senior surviving Nazis. The second (1946-49) represented a more ambitious, solely American attempt to try, in 12 separate cases, almost 200 high-level participants from all spheres of German society: political, Nazi party and SS leaders, arms makers and industrialists, generals, bankers, doctors and government ministers.

title: Scars Still Raw, Bush Clashes With McCain
description: President Bush and Senator John McCain, who fought last year for the Republican presidential nomination, are once again locked in battle, firing at each other across multiple fronts.

title: Breaking the Ice as It Melts for Spring Fishing
description: All winter, James Prosek and I kept making -- and breaking -- tentative plans to go ice fishing on Candlewood Lake in south-central Connecticut, and by the time we got around to doing it, the March sun was growing more assertive, the tulips were poking through on the median on Park Avenue in Manhattan, and our angling buddies were already feverishly patching waders and spooling new lines in anticipation of the opening of trout season.

title: Stephanie Verhoeff, Daniel Feigin
description: Stephanie Carolyn Verhoeff, a daughter of Lynn Williams of Branford, Conn., and William Verhoeff of Stonington, Conn., was married in Manhattan yesterday to Daniel Feigin, a son of Barbara and James Feigin of Manhattan. Acting Justice Brenda Soloff of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Loeb Boat House in Central Park.

title: Loyal, Two-Legged Lobbyists Raise Banner of Dog Rights
description: At a time when well-tended American dogs get braces for their teeth and antidepressants for anxiety and attend the church of their owners' choice, it may come as no surprise that a powerful political constituency has developed around a species once known mainly for chasing tennis balls in the backyard.

title: Going the Short Way to an Oscar Nomination
description: SOME might call it beginner's luck to have your first documentary film nominated for an Academy Award. And Peter LeDonne might agree, if it had not been for the 30 years he spent making some of the most memorable minute-long films -- otherwise known as commercials -- for Broadway plays, dance companies, recording stars and casinos.

title: Security Heightened as Bombs Kill 20 in 3 Russian Villages
description: Three car bombs went off today in towns adjoining the rebellious republic of Chechnya. One exploded in a market on a busy shopping day, and the others were set off near police stations. In all, the blasts killed at least 20 people and injured 90 others.

title: Macedonia Uses Helicopters Against Rebels for First Time
description: Macedonia used attack helicopters against ethnic Albanian rebels for the first time today, firing several rockets at their positions in the wooded hills above this town.

title: Another Balkan Battle: Higher Learning
description: A new Albanian-language university, sponsored and financed by the international community, was supposed to be a significant response to the grievances that have underpinned the Albanian rebellion now building in the hills above Tetovo and threatening the cohesion of the Macedonian state.

title: Leetch Among 10 Picked For U.S.
description: In its last visit to the Winter Olympic Games, the United States men's hockey team made a distinct impression. Along with losing three of four games, some players kept a busy social calendar at night around Nagano, Japan. After they were eliminated, some left a trail of vandalism in their living quarters. They went home without medals, but they sure did beat Belarus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, ADELE
description: SCHNEIDER-Adele. On March 24, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Loving mother of Evan and Susan, Mindy and Tim. Cherished grandmother of Rachel, Emily and Maxwell. Service Monday, 9:45 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISS, RABBI JOSEPH
description: WEISS-Rabbi Joseph. Beloved husband of Bath-Ammi. Devoted father of William (Kathlyn) and Edward (Coni). Cherished grandfather of Houston Moses. Fond brother of Rosalind Hemley. Services today, 1 PM, at the West End Temple, 147-02 Newport Ave, Neponsit. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss Memorial Fund at the West End Temple.

title: Business Diary: Viewing the First Bubble and How It Blew Up
description: Somewhere, Norton Simon, the pioneering industrialist who died in 1993, must be proud. In the 1940's, 50's and 60's, Mr. Simon turned a small investment in a failing orange-juice bottling plant into one of the first multinational consumer products conglomerates, with well-known properties like Hunt-Wesson Foods, McCall's, Max Factor, Avis and Canada Dry. Then he amassed a renowned art collection, with masterworks by the likes of Raphael, Cezanne, Picasso and Matisse, now housed in the Norton Simon Museum in Pasadena, Calif. In both pursuits, he was the quintessential value hunter, searching for undermanaged or underappreciated companies and art.

title: March 18-24; Taliban Explains
description: The Taliban explained why it demolished three priceless monumental Buddha statues over the last two weeks: they were angry at the world's failure to rank human suffering as high as threatened artifacts. They also opened the Kabul Museum to reveal empty spaces where other ancient artworks once stood. The movement's leaders say that some of the missing pieces have been hidden away, but will not say where or offer any proof. Barbara Crossette

title: An Italian Poet Of Prosaic Lives
description: NOW in his sixth decade of directing, Ermanno Olmi specializes in dramatizing undramatic lives. His psychologically acute character studies are as close as fictional films have come to showing real life in all its complexity and ordinariness.

title: POSTINGS: Among 19 Stores at Crotona Park East; Work to Start On Bronx Supermarket
description: Almost a decade ago residents of the Crotona Park East section of the Bronx had high hopes for a supermarket and retail stores on a 10-acre site that had been an industrial park. Yet because the project involved City Hall, community groups and the private sector, there was no way to get it done quickly. But finally, one week from tomorrow, April 2, groundbreaking is scheduled for a $30.7 million, 134,000-square-foot shopping center at the site, 174th Street and Vyse Avenue.

title: Streets Reclaim Names That Had Sense and Sensibility
description: Thirty-three years ago, when Julianne Hirsh moved into a house on East 24th Street in South Midwood, she noticed that her mail sometimes listed a street name that sounded as if it should be in Jane Austen's England, not Brooklyn, N.Y.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: The Missing World, by Margot Livesey. (Penguin, $13.) In this British novel, a young journalist awakens from a coma after a traffic accident to find she has no memory of the last three years; her creepy former boyfriend, seeing an opening, tries to marry her before she recovers her past. The result is ''intelligent fiction, vigorous both in its observation of human foible and in its speculation on the role that memory plays in underwriting our sense of choice and direction in our lives,'' Michael Upchurch wrote in the Book Review last year.

title: VERIZON CONTRACT WITH LUCENT
description: Verizon Wireless, based in Bedminster, agreed last week to pay Lucent Technologies $5 billion to expand Verizon's mobile phone network. The upgrade will enable Verizon customers to reach the Internet through their mobile phones, hand-held devices and notebook computers almost 10 times faster than they currently can. The new technology, called 3G for third generation, will be available by the end of the year. After the announcement, Lucent, which is based in Murray Hill, saw a slight upturn in its stock price, which has dropped 85 percent this year.

title: Film Listings
description: Opening This Week

title: Japan's Resurgent Far Right Tinkers With History
description: Hironobu Kaneko, a 21-year-old college student, remembers the powerful emotions stirred in him three years ago when he read a best-selling book of cartoons that extolled, rather than denigrated, the history of Japan's former Imperial Army.

title: Fast-Growing, Fast-Changing
description: WHEN the 2000 census figures for New York State were released two weeks ago, the numerical snapshot of Westchester County was not, at first glance, all that surprising to anyone who has lived or worked in the area: while the county's population grew at only a modest rate, it has become more ethnically diverse.

title: Free 800 Calls? Not Exactly
description: A COLLEAGUE who spent seven nights at the Sheraton Chicago Hotel and Towers last month discovered at checkout that his bill included $107.06 in telephone charges, mostly in $1.44 bites for dialing ''800'' numbers on his modem. Mark Pruner, president of Web Counsel, a Stamford, Conn., marketing company, was charged $149.70 at the Westin on Michigan Avenue in Chicago for two calls to Connecticut, 50 minutes in all. ''I practically fell over,'' he said.

title: Murphy's Law
description: To the Editor: We were there on that October day on the Intracoastal Waterway when Betsy Wade was experiencing the problems of a broken drive shaft aboard Charles Miller's trawler (''Murphy's Law, Strictly Applied,'' Feb. 11). My husband and I were aboard Courage, a trawler that offered help to Charlie, whom we know. To extend Murphy's Law further, a larger trawler headed south far ahead of us also passed Charlie's boat and offered to help. Later, the same trawler passed us, headed north, back to Beaufort, unceremoniously under tow.

title: First and Third for Kwan and Hughes
description: Michelle Kwan's coach had just watched his skater morph into a glorious vision on the ice tonight as she pulled off a soaring triple-triple, then remained as light and translucent as a hologram for the rest of her program.

title: The World: The Balkans; A One-Time Ally Becomes the Problem
description: THE United States and NATO are reaping what they sowed in the Balkans. Their war against Slobodan Milosevic's Yugoslavia, justified by humanitarian intervention, also justified their alliance with Albanian extremists who are now trying to do in Macedonia what they did to Serbian authority in Kosovo.

title: 3 Autistic Children, and Helping Even More
description: MATT AND DEBRA CODY seem like a couple who have it all. Married for 18 years, they finish each other's sentences, still look at each other like newlyweds, and call themselves soul mates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEWY, PAUL
description: LOEWY-Paul, 82. Died Thursday March 22nd, 2001, in Aventura Hospital, Hallandale, Fl., beloved husband of Anneliese, devoted father of Mark & John, dedicated father-in-law of Joi and cherished Grandfather of Laura & Katheryn. Paul, a holocaust survivor came to the US after World War II where he started a trucking business that he steered for over 40 years. His unique spirit touched all who came into contact with him because it was always evident that he was so grateful to be alive among us. His simple philosophy, ''Don't make problems out of problems and you won't have problems'' inspired those close to him to reflect upon the joys of living. Funeral service to be held on Monday March, 26, 1:00, at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale NY. Donations in his memory can be made to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum, Washington D.C. (202) 488-2642.

title: Appeals Court Reversal On Roosevelt Field
description: An appeals court last week reversed a 1999 decision by the Town of Hempstead Board of Zoning Appeals that denied an expansion application for the Roosevelt Field mall in East Garden City.

title: Racing for Dollars, Photography Pulls Abreast of Painting
description: FOR better or worse, photography is the New New Thing in the art market. Over the last two years, with fortunes being won and lost on bets about our digital future, the most searching visual invention of the 19th century has been charting upward like a 1999 Internet stock.

title: Warm in Quebec
description: To the Editor: Susan Catto's lovely article reminded me of the novel that introduced me to Quebec, Willa Cather's ''Shadows on the Rock,'' which magically evokes the city in the late 17th century.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Feb. 18 about an exhibition of Edvard Munch's work at the McMullen Museum of Art at Boston College misidentified a distant cousin of Munch's who was the husband of Munch's lover Millie Thaulow. He was the military doctor Claus Thaulow, not the painter and teacher Frits Thaulow.

title: Jill Oestreicher, Joseph Gross
description: Jill Alexandra Oestreicher and Dr. Joseph William Gross were married last evening by Rabbi Joel S. Goor at the Metropolitan Synagogue in New York.

title: Child Center Won't Have to Share Rooms
description: A proposal to move the Queens Children's Psychiatric Center to a nearby adult treatment center has been rejected by both the State Senate and the Assembly, which voted against financing the plan last week.

description: The organizers of the meeting had hoped for 50 livery-cab drivers, but only about a dozen showed up. One driver had an explanation.

title: The View From/Guilford; In Search of a Castaway: The 'u' in Falkner Island
description: IN 1891, when a misspelled word would lead teachers to slap students' wrists with their rulers, the United States government started misspelling the name of an island off the coast of Guilford.

title: March 18-24; Gone, Not Forgotten
description: Russia's Mir space station, scene of thousands of scientific advances during its 15-year life, as well as bedeviling and life-threatening malfunctions, was buried at sea after controllers steered the 134-ton leviathan out of orbit and sent it streaking through the sky over the South Pacific to a splashdown east of New Zealand. Russian space pioneers lamented Mir's demise as a symbol of lost Soviet glory. Patrick E. Tyler

title: In the Region/Westchester; Ex-Bank Tower Thriving as White Plains Arts Hub

Even an advertisement placed by the bank in a local newspaper more than 70 years ago seems timeless in retrospect.

title: Arteurs; Romance of the Chador
description: At a certain point not too long ago, American art became a division of the movie business. Or so it seems one morning in November as I gaze out across a desert in Morocco. The thin frame of Shirin Neshat is silhouetted against the golden sands, her red woolen shawl fluttering in the wind. She looks like an ancient prophet, but maybe deserts do that to everyone.

title: Madrid
description: The high blue skies over Madrid are rarely cloudy in any season -- this is, after all, something of a mountain town, standing at more than 1,900 feet and ringed by mountains. But the city is certainly at its most comfortable in spring, freed from the icy chill of winter and the searing heat of summer.

description: Before visiting Washington early this month for his first meeting with President Bush, the South Korean president, Kim Dae Jung, was bubbling with ideas about how to sustain the momentum in his quest to reconcile his nation with its long-hostile neighbor, North Korea.

title: Feel the Beat, 14 Times Over

But when the New York Pops introduces New Jerseyans to ''Concerto Fantasy for Two Timpanists and Orchestra'' by Philip Glass, no fewer than 14 timpani will be fanned out across the stage at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark.

They are ornate and stone-encrusted -- Grandma redux. For those who want the genuine article without the hassle of combing through flea markets, Clive Kandel, a specialist in vintage designer jewelry, has gathered a collection of one-of-a-kind costume brooches by Weis, near left, Kenneth Jay Lane, Ciner, Miriam Haskell and others (from $250 at Saks Fifth Avenue).

title: A Thinking Slacker's Rock Hero, Slightly Aged

By now, to those like me who have followed Mr. Malkmus's music over the last 10 years, it's a nostalgic expression, a little ironic reference to a time when little ironic references were de rigueur and the half-hearted try was the badge of the so-called slacker generation. At 34, Mr. Malkmus is still letting his slacker flag, if not fly, then at least flutter lazily.

title: RUTGERS COACH RELEASED

Mr. Bannon's record at Rutgers was 59-60 with two National Invitation Tournament appearances. The team was 11-16 this season. Three students sued the school over being made to run around the gym nude during a free-throw contest at one of Mr. Bannon's practices. Mr. Bannon had five years left on his contract.

Brouse, the president of the Sport Utility Vehicle Owners Association of America, sits in a cramped office here amid the beautiful, cherry-wood furniture from his 31-year career as the top lobbyist for Wisconsin's savings and loan associations. In his new job, Mr. Brouse sometimes fields phone calls at least as difficult as those he received during the worst of the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980's.

As a verb or as a noun, it denotes fake. And we're not talking of calling someone's bluff. Or about other contexts: ships, poker, cliffs. Jeffrey Sweet's play at 12 Miles West means to be multileveled in the manner of its name. Mixing the real and the unreal, Mr. Sweet is not putting a new spin on conventional theater devices.

title: Arteurs; Big
description: On a snowy night in Albany last month, 600 people packed a hall at the State University of New York for a screening of the movie ''Before Night Falls'' and cheered wildly when the filmmaker Julian Schnabel came onstage after the show. Schnabel was wearing a boxy gray jacket; he did not fit the image he had gained over the years as a painter in a sarong. He seemed ungainly, and the heavy black glasses he put on only emphasized the bluntness of his features. His beard stuck out like a shingle. His bright round cheeks made his eyes almost disappear.

title: March 18-24; Vermont Sheep Seized
description: Acting on the first possibility of mad cow disease in the United States, federal agents seized two flocks of sheep in Vermont. The sheep -- 359 in total -- were imported from the same stock in Europe in 1996; four in one of the flocks tested positive for transmissible spongiform encephalopathy, the family of diseases that includes mad cow. The sheep will be killed by lethal injection and tested for signs of T.S.E. Any affected brain tissue will be injected into laboratory mice. Scientists will determine whether the sheep had mad cow, or some less serious form of disease, only after they see what kind of disease the mice develop, which will take about two years.

Early this month, Congress voted to repeal ergonomics standards meant to protect workers from repetitive strain injuries. In an abrupt turnabout, President George W. Bush last week reversed a campaign pledge to limit power plants' emissions of carbon dioxide. And this week, the Environmental Protection Agency canceled a plan that would have reduced the allowable amount of arsenic in drinking water by 80 percent.

title: Working In a Coal Mine

Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren, far right center, painted models black for their all-black collection,  la 19th-century silhouette cutouts. At other houses, under black lights with 90 percent of the audience in black, the shows were nearly invisible. This somber palette relies on textures and details: a ribbon around the throat with a black orchid, top left; a scarf of crunched black roses; a collar resembling licorice jelly beans, bottom far right; pants cut extra long for both sexes to crush over shoes or spike heels. Three new French Vogue editors, top second from right, are the furies of this black moment: from left, Marie-Amlie Sauv, Carine Roitfeld and Emmanuelle Alt.

title: March 18-24; Abuse of Nuns Reported
description: Five confidential church reports by senior members of women's religious orders and an American priest allege widespread sexual abuse of nuns by priests in developing countries. Most of the examples cited in the reports, written over the last seven years, occurred in Africa, where about 12 percent of the world's billion Catholics live. Some involve priests who forced nuns they impregnated to have abortions. The reports say the church has not punished guilty priests. The Vatican responded that there were few instances of abuse and most were confined to small area. Chris Hedges

title: The Rural Life; The Logic of Pigs
description: For the past three months, I have been thinking about raising pigs. Ask anyone who knows me. Sooner or later, the conversation turns to raising pigs. I have a small shelf full of books whose titles include the words ''pigs'' and ''successful.'' I have even sold, as futures, the four quarters of a prospective pig to friends who have decided to humor me. At this moment in Montgomery County, N.Y., a sow is pregnant, or ''in pig'' as the pig farmers say, with a litter of piglets from which I hope to take two in May, when they should weigh about 40 pounds apiece. The sow and the boar who bred her are Tamworths, an uncommon, endangered breed, lean, gingery, bacon types, good foragers, good mothers.

You have to stare into the lens and give a look that lets them know what you've got.''

description: I was always a shy kid. I was in the right crowds, but I was the tagalong. I was the personality of the group, but when I looked in the mirror, I didn't see it. In 1966, when I was 15, I was walking downtown one day and I noticed a crowd taking pictures in front of the town hospital, and I went up to look. I noticed this handsome actor who people were taking pictures of, and it was Robert Goulet. But I couldn't pinpoint who he was; I just knew the face from TV. So my reaction was to run home and grab my Brownie Instamatic camera. I went back, and just the fact that I could make contact with this man, that I actually got a picture of him -- I was hooked.

description: Britain redoubled its already draconian efforts to eradicate foot-and-mouth disease after a report projected that the number of affected sites, instead of tailing off, would soon rise by 70 each day, and would top 4,000 by June. A government scientist said the disease is out of control because of a delay between discovering the virus's presence and the slaughter of infected and exposed animals. The crisis is threatening Prime Minister Tony Blair's plan to seek re-election.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Cambria Heights, Queens; An Uncongested, People-Oriented Enclave

The only one-way street is 234th Street where it parallels the Cross Island Parkway. Further underscoring the neighborhood's uncongested, almost sleepy, tempo is the plentiful parking on Linden Boulevard, the main shopping street, where parking meters are still nonexistent.

Loving and devoted mother of Susan and Brian, mother-in-law of Hope, and grandmother of Joshua Smick and Matthew and Courtney Schnee, sister of Helen Elkin and Selma Kanfer. A role model who through each stage of life conducted herself with dignity and great spirit. Loving, nurturing, creative, fun and beautiful. The funeral will be held on Sunday, March 25, at 3 PM, at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 175 North Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, NY. Her children took up a lot of time and she found it hard to stay disciplined and push her business, which offers facial treatments and a line of mail-order beauty products. title: Murphy's Law
description: To the Editor: The multiple problems of Betsy Wade reminded me of Adm. Thomas H. Moorer, former chief of naval operations and former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In 1942, then-Lieutenant Moorer, piloting a patrol plane, was shot down by the Japanese near Australia. A Philippine freighter rescued him and his crew, but it was sunk the same day. He assumed command of two lifeboats carrying his crew and the freighter crew. They were later rescued from an uninhabited island. He received the Silver Star.

title: Killings Tied to Graft Shock Atlanta Suburb
description: It seems incongruous that a gangland-style war, apparently tied to possible corruption in the sheriff's department, is now being waged in the cul-de-sacs of DeKalb County. Just east of downtown Atlanta, DeKalb fancies itself as one of the metro area's most diverse and sophisticated suburbs, a constellation of well-kept neighborhoods and bustling retail strips that is home to Emory University doctors and ambitious corporate climbers.

title: Fishbowl Fairies and an Alien in Exile
description: Picking up where ''Rugrats'' and ''The Ren and Stimpy Show'' left off, two new animated series will have their premieres on Nickelodeon Friday night: ''The Fairly OddParents,'' at 8:30, and ''Invader Zim,'' at 9.

title: Middle-Aged in A Boys' Game
description: As a long-suffering fan of the Boston Red Sox, I've always heard stories about the biggest mistake in the team's history: trading Babe Ruth to the hated New York Yankees for a pittance. I never really understood how that could have shaken Beantown fans to the bone until the Red Sox let Roger Clemens go to the Bronx Bombers, albeit by way of Toronto, of all places. Every time I see Clemens in pinstripes, I feel a knot in the pit of my stomach. He may be older now than when he helped the Red Sox to their 1986 World Series appearance, but he's just as potent and feared within the league.

title: Streetscapes/75th Street Between Fifth and Madison Avenue; Stately Limestone Mansions With a Sense of History
description: THE old limestone mansions of 75th Street between Fifth and Madison Avenue seem a bit less august these days -- some were broken up into apartments decades ago. But the stately mansions' history involves several famous players from New York's past. They include Thomas J. Watson, the chairman of I.B.M. from 1915 to 1956, and Irving Berlin, perhaps the most renowned songwriter in American history.

title: Opera in Translation Refuses to Give Up the Ghost
description: BY this point it's terribly hard for Puccini's enduringly popular opera ''Tosca'' to sound fresh. But a recording on the Chandos label, with David Parry conducting the Philharmonia Orchestra, makes ''Tosca'' sound so fresh it's startling.

title: Knowing What You Owe
description: THERE is little that I can be smug about, but when it comes to debt, I can be obnoxious. Except for my mortgage, I have no debt: no car loans, no credit card balances, no margin loans. Even my mortgage is laughable: 15 years at 5.625 percent; I hope to have it paid off by the time my daughter starts college in four years.

title: An Elegy for an Era, 'Follies' Itself Goes On
description: THE curtain rose on a towering showgirl, alone on a darkened stage. She was absurdly tall and pale, more a vision than a being. To music at once ethereal and eerie, she moved slowly across the floor. Another showgirl appeared, then more typical musical-comedy types -- high-kickers with hats, a pair of ballroom dancers, singers . . . all comparably pallid, each moving to his own rhythm in his own style, a silent cacophony. They were ghosts, haunting a theater on the eve of its demolition, when it was to play host to a reunion of show-biz veterans.

title: Who Pays For Repair Of a Flue?
description: Q: About three years ago I bought a co-op that I was told had a working fireplace. After two years, the managing agent sent a notice telling us not to use the fireplace until it was inspected by a company that specializes in flues and fireplaces. After the inspection, we were told that the flues were in bad condition and that each tenant-shareholder would have to bear the expense of putting in a new one. In my case, the cost would be about $9,000. I thought that the flues, being inside the wall like plumbing, were the responsibility of the co-op? Do I have any redress in this case? . . . Claire See Feldman, Manhattan

Mr. Buffett, in his annual report, complained that Mr. Rust's company had hurt Geico, Berkshire's auto insurance company, by absorbing losses instead of raising prices, as most other insurers did, as expenses increased. Courtly as ever, Mr. Buffett said that State Farm was a great company, but that ''Geico has the much better business model.''

The party was organized by the actress Arlene Dahl, vice chairman of the academy's New York events committee. And unlike the Oscars, where academy members who are not presenting or nominated for awards must enter a lottery for seats, the Le Cirque party was first come first served to those who answered invitations. They toyed with the $18 Stila eye gloss and sniffed at the tester bottles of $80 Jil Sander and $42 Versace White Jeans colognes that are stacked on shiny shelves in the vast black-motif emporium. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENTHAL, WILLIAM
description: ROSENTHAL-William. Educator, veteran, Hall of Famer. Of Pompano Beach, FL, and Becket, MA, died on March 23, 2001, in Natick, MA. He was 86. Dr. Rosenthal was Assistant Director of Health and Physical Education for the City of New York Board of Education from 1960 to 1972, an officer in the US Army during WWII, retiring with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel in 1974, and a member of the National Soccer Hall of Fame, inducted in 1972. Born in Chicago and raised in NYC, he was graduated from James Monroe High School, where he was elected to the Alumni Sports Hall of Fame, and received his bachelor's degree in 1935 from the City College of New York, where he was on the soccer, lacrosse and boxing teams. In 1936, he received his master's degree in education from New York University, and in 1954 his doctorate in education there. Dr. Rosenthal began his teaching career at Bronx Vocational High School, moved on to DeWitt Clinton High School, and, after passing his chairman's exam, to Christopher Columbus High School. He was well known for the coaching courses he ran to assist young teachers as they prepared for their chairman's exam. All of his career ''Bill'' was an active member of the National Intercollegiate Soccer Officials Association, refereeing as many as seven games a week, and served as president of the Association in 1967. He was for many years the executive director of the Association of Health, Physical Education, Recreation and Dance Exhibitors Association. He was presented the Silver Beaver award from the Boy Scouts of America. Since his retirement in 1972, he guest lectured to aspring physical education specialists in Singapore, Sweden and Israel, and was an adjunct professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst. Married to the late Frieda Allen Rosenthal, of Gloversville, NY, for 56 years, Dr. Rosenthal is survived by his daughter-in-law Marjorie Rosenthal of Needham, MA, his son Steven Rosenthal, his daughter-in-law Ruth Rosenthal, his granddaughters Caren and Debra Rosenthal, all of Natick, MA, and his brother Albert Rosenthal of Plainview, NY. The funeral will be Monday, March 26, 2001, at 2:15 PM, at Star of David Funeral Home, North Lauderdale, FL. Shiva will be observed Monday and Tuesday at 111 Briny Ave, Apt 2002, Pompano Beach, FL. Remainder of shiva at 12 Mark St, Natick, MA. A memorial service will be held this summer in Becket, MA. Donations in Bill's memory may be made to the ''Friends of the Becket Ambulance,'' 557 Main St, Becket, MA 01223.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Spikenard and Cesspit
description: Jean Echenoz's new novel, I'M GONE (New Press, $22.95), is very French. Echenoz combines a crime story, an anthropological study of Paris, a meditation on love and sex and a journey to exotic lands. ''I'm Gone'' won the 1999 Prix Goncourt and is now crossing the Atlantic in an agile, colloquial translation by Mark Polizzotti. The novel's greatest virtue is its rapid pace, which slows only for moments of cafe observation and philosophy. We follow Felix Ferrer, a recently divorced, sexually hyperactive gallery owner. Ferrer's assistant, Delahaye, tells him about the Nechilik, a small commercial ship that was carrying a fortune in paleoarctic art when it ran aground almost a half century earlier. The wreck was never recovered, and Delahaye dies a few weeks after telling Ferrer about the treasure. So Ferrer takes a sabbatical from his midlife crisis, his mistresses and his gallery to fly to Canada, cross the Arctic Circle by icebreaker and trek via dogsled to the ship's last known location. He finds the vessel and its antiquities intact and returns with the loot to Paris, only to have the collection stolen before he can insure it. Ferrer, a man without self-pity, bounces back. The plot continues swiftly to a surprising conclusion. Along the way, Echenoz delivers acute observations on everything from the Paris Mtro system to the problem with ill-fitting socks to obnoxious perfume. (''Brangre Eisenmann is a big-boned, fun-loving girl, highly perfumed. . . . The perfume issue quickly became a problem. Extatics Elixir is a terribly sour and insistent scent, which teeters dangerously on the cusp between spikenard and cesspit, which satisfies while it attacks, excites while it smothers.'') ''I'm Gone'' combines the policier, the cultural essay and the urban sex novel to create a vivid, entertaining hybrid. Paul Kafka-Gibbons

Two weeks later and a mere 15 miles from the convention site, two students died in America's most recent school shooting. Robert Schwartz, head of the nonprofit Juvenile Law Center in Philadelphia and the author of the A.B.A. resolution, says the murders in Santee, Calif., haven't changed his mind about zero tolerance. ''People ask, 'Are they still serious when they see a kid shoot somebody?''' he says. ''That's not what most school discipline cases are about, and that's not what the resolution is directed at fixing.''

title: TRANSIT EMPLOYEES' CONTRACT

The new contract allows them two additional sick days and includes pay for days taken singly. But for reasons that are part of the mystery of filmmaking, this pretty French romance, in which all the dialogue is sung, is a gem. It probably doesn't hurt that the star is a luminous newcomer, the 20-year-old Catherine Deneuve, or that Michel LeGrand wrote such gorgeous music. It's the story of very young, beautiful lovers, the draft notice that separates them, the girl's concerned mother, an out-of-wedlock pregnancy at a time when that was a problem and a handsome diamond merchant visiting town, capped with a ''Splendor in the Grass'' ending that could tear your heart out. It won the Cannes Film Festival's top prize, the Palme d'Or. Nino Castelnuovo plays Ms. Deneuve's young love interest; Jacques Demy wrote and direted - Wednesday at 12:45 p.m. on TM.

title: Gazing Into a Penholder
description: Why is it de rigueur for members of the avant-garde to try to stump us? Think of the Surrealists and the Dadaists, with their deadpan refusal to make sense; the authors of the French nouveau roman, with their poker-faced descriptions of trivial things; and the inexplicable mathematical games of Raymond Queneau. The present-day heirs of this tendency are conceptual artists, with their penchant for inscrutable brainteasers. When did ''experimental'' become synonymous with ''mystifying''? Mark Ford's smart new biography, ''Raymond Roussel and the Republic of Dreams'' (Cornell University, $35), hints at a novel answer: with Roussel (1877-1933), a strange and possibly mad French poet and fantasist whose following has included many of the most influential avant-gardists of the 20th century. Roussel's power is that for them he functioned as a kind of proto-Andy Warhol. They could never be sure if he was pulling their leg.

Such are the amenities available to you for the price of admission, which is to have cancer.

Still, its potential impact is hardly negligible, especially for active traders, since the fee at issue, in place since 1934, is nibbling at every transaction in this declining market.

title: Arteurs; The Ultimate Film Still
description: This is a photograph by Gregory Crewdson -- but he didn't actually snap the picture. He stood by on a sound stage while Rick Sands, his ''cinematographer,'' captured an image that took weeks of planning to create. (Sands was the chief lighting technician for ''Independence Day.'') Crewdson conceived the eerie scene, managed the creation of an elaborate waterproof set, chose the model and worked with a lighting designer to fine-tune the surreal atmosphere. Overall, his role was more akin to what Steven Spielberg does for a living than to what traditional photographers do. Appropriately, Crewdson says his primary influence is a Spielberg film, ''Close Encounters of the Third Kind.''

title: Private Sector; Ali and Frazier They Aren't
description: Nobody ever said insurance was exciting. But it is unusual to see two big-time players jibing each other, especially when they are gentlemen like Warren E. Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway and Edward Rust, the chief executive of State Farm. Mr. Buffett, in his annual report, complained that Mr. Rust's company had hurt Geico, Berkshire's auto insurance company, by absorbing losses instead of raising prices, as most other insurers did, as expenses increased. Courtly as ever, Mr. Buffett said that State Farm was a great company, but that ''Geico has the much better business model.''

title: Summer Rituals On Chincoteague
description: I SHOULD probably start by confessing that I did not go through a horse-crazy stage when I was growing up, and therefore the name Chincoteague had no particular significance for me. My family and I first stumbled on the island on a drive down the East Coast heading for Kitty Hawk on a Wright Brothers pilgrimage with a sixth grader who had spent the year researching Orville. As we drove, I had Jane and Michael Stern's book ''Roadfood'' open on my lap, cross-referencing the towns we passed. That's where I found Chincoteague, cited for the Landmark Crab House, and the write-up made mention of the famous Chincoteague oysters. It was getting to be dinner time, so we turned off the road and drove out along the causeway that takes you from the mainland to the island of Chincoteague. We triumphantly ate oysters and crab concoctions at the Landmark, and then spent the night at a nearby motel.

Last week, revelers in Gucci hats and Frankie B. hip-huggers embraced each other with exuberant greetings like: ''How long have you been living out here, girl?'' and ''I'm staying at the Standard, too!'' Donovan Leitch and his wife, Kirsty Hume, the model, who are based in Woodstock, N.Y., sipped cocktails on the patio with Sofia Coppola and Vincent Gallo, the actor and part-time NoLIta resident.

title: On Malaysian Menu, Cultural Crossroads
description: THE biggest culinary buzz on the Island is coming from Penang, the first Malaysian restaurant in Nassau and Suffolk. The foodies have found it; so have the 20- and 30-somethings, as evidenced by the cacophonous din and the crowd at the bar. . By 6:30 p.m. on a weekend Penang, at 4 Berry Hill Road in Syosset (516-682-0682), is packed. By 8 p.m. departing diners need a helmet and shoulder pads to plow through the waiting throng.

title: 'Exploited' Stage Troupe In Exploits of Its Own

They came there often to talk big, and dream of life across the Hudson River. Somewhere along the way, a name was coined that captured their sense of longing mingled with frustration. They called themselves Hudson Exploited.

title: Theater Plans to Give Refunds
description: Subscribers to the American Stage Company in Teaneck, which has canceled the second half of its season, can expect refunds within six months to a year, said Amie Gartenberg, president of the theater's board of trustees. But a number of patrons, she added, have already offered to donate the balance of their subscription in light of the theater's cash-flow woes.

title: Grace Note on the Outer Banks
description: THE tiny town of Duck on North Carolina's Outer Banks has always had something of a Nantucket fixation. The dunes facing the Atlantic were long ago dotted with wooden summer homes that feature cedar-shake roofs and long porches echoing the accents of the whaling island far, far to the north.

description: The 2001 Michelin travel guide for France was released this month, adding two restaurants to the three-star category. In one case, Alain Ducasse, who left 59 Poincar in the 16th arrondissement of Paris to move to the Htel Plaza Athne, took his three stars with him. But Marc Veyrat, who was awarded three stars for his year-old La Ferme de Mon Pre, a winter restaurant in Megve, kept the three-star rating for his Auberge de l'ridan in Annecy.

title: Exploring the Fault Where the Next Big One May Be Waiting
description: Alexander Gates, a geology professor at Rutgers-Newark, is co-author of ''The Encyclopedia of Earthquakes and Volcanoes,'' which will be published by Facts on File in July. He has been leading a four-year effort to remap an area known as the Sloatsburg Quadrangle, a 5-by-7-mile tract near Mahwah that crosses into New York State. The Ramapo Fault, which runs through it, was responsible for a big earthquake in 1884, and Dr. Gates warns that a recurrence is overdue. He recently talked about his findings.

title: A Little Begging, A Little Borrowing
description: KELLY CUTRONE, a liberally tattooed fashion publicist, was waiting for a call on Wednesday afternoon from a stylist who shares her name with an Edgar Allan Poe poem. Raven Kauffman, the stylist, had spent many hours -- about 172, in fact -- putting together an outfit for Courtney Love to wear to the Oscars today. Now, Ms. Kauffman was supposed to be calling to say whether Ms. Love, a guest again this year, would appear at the Shrine Auditorium, her clavicles supporting a billboard for Bulgari. Ms. Love was thinking about wearing a necklace from Bulgari, one of Ms. Cutrone's clients.

title: An Oscar for All the Ones He Should Have Got
description: SOME of us breathed sighs of pleasure when we heard that the Academy had done its job decently this year. I refer to the decision to award an honorary Oscar to the writer Ernest Lehman tonight. That means there will be at least one moment of gravity in this year's follies as ironware is handed out to the young, the restless, the naked and the lucky. An 85-year-old gentleman will step forward; he will probably be funny, dry and memorable; and he may say how lucky he was to have found screenwriting when he did.

description: They met at halfcourt moments after the buzzer sounded, the brash, cocky one with a spring-loaded shooting arm and the quiet, soft-spoken one with a face as clamped down as his defense.

title: Arteurs; Once, In The Jungle
description: Tobias Schneebaum did not want to go back. For one thing, he feared that his old friends might be dead. It had been nearly a half-century, after all, since the Manhattan-born painter abandoned his easel, hitchhiked south to Peru, walked headlong into the Amazon jungle and went native with an isolated Indian tribe. For another, Schneebaum knew that the fantasy that had long ago propelled him into the forest -- a desire to live somewhere untouched by Western culture -- was becoming impossible to fulfill. ''I worried that they weren't going to be naked anymore,'' he says wistfully of the Arakmbut people he lived with for seven months in 1956. ''I thought, I don't want to see them clothed.''

title: Only Fumes From Anger Fill New, Empty Garage
description: A parking garage in downtown Jamaica, built by the state to handle courthouse and police traffic, has been vacant since it was completed last year, and local business leaders are outraged. ''What has happened with the garage is a travesty,'' said Janet Barkan, head of the Jamaica Business Improvement District.

title: Dennis Ross's Exit Interview
description: There were moments this past year, Dennis Ross says, when breakthrough peace agreements between the Israelis and the Arabs were tantalizingly, almost maddeningly, close. This was especially true on the Israeli-Syrian front. A deal was just waiting to be sealed. With the Israelis and the Palestinians, well, that was always going to be a tough nut to crack. Ultimately, as everyone knows, peace negotiations broke down in an explosion of violence and a near-total exhaustion of mutual good will.

title: Harvard's Botterill Wins Top Award
description: Jennifer Botterill of Harvard won the Patty Kazmaier Award, which is given to the top player in women's college ice hockey. Botterill, of Winnipeg, Manitoba, is the first Canadian and the only junior to win the award. She was second in the nation in scoring with 77 points (41 goals and 36 assists), led the ECAC in points (64) and goals (35), and was voted the Ivy League women's player of the year for the second year in a row.

title: Personal Business Diary: Unhappy E-Shoppers May Punish a Store
description: When shoppers receive bad service online, they are not only less likely to revisit the retailer's Web site, they may also spend fewer dollars at its off-line stores, an Internet research company has found.

title: Falling for the Leopard
description: UNTIL last August, my heart belonged to lions. Brutish hyenas hold a grisly fascination for me and the elegance of cheetahs delights me, but when I imagined the ultimate game sighting, it always centered on a lion. Then I visited the Mashatu Game Reserve in eastern Botswana and saw my first leopard.

title: Henson Leaves Michigan to Accept Lucrative Offer From Yanks
description: The Yankees traded Drew Henson once, threatening his lifelong dream of playing in pinstripes, and Henson would not let the chance get away again. Henson has agreed to a six-year, $17 million contract with the Yankees and will forgo his senior year as the University of Michigan quarterback and a chance at winning the Heisman Trophy.

title: Staten Island Journal; A Connoisseur of Lighthouses by Any Measure
description: Joseph N. Esposito has 16 lighthouses to his name. Fifteen of them he built with his own hands. They measure from 1 to 35 inches. They are made of old baseball bats and pool cues and furniture legs, and are about as useful to sailors as the navigational aids that were aboard the Titanic.

BROUSE, the president of the Sport Utility Vehicle Owners Association of America, sits in a cramped office here amid the beautiful, cherry-wood furniture from his 31-year career as the top lobbyist for Wisconsin's savings and loan associations. In his new job, Mr. Brouse sometimes fields phone calls at least as difficult as those he received during the worst of the savings-and-loan crisis of the 1980's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE GIVE, PAUL DE BARSY
description: de GIVE-Paul de Barsy. In Newburyport, MA, of Newburyport, MA, formerly of NYC and Southampton. Retired senior vice president of Dominick & Dominick, Inc, where he was editor and publisher for 25 years of ''Technical Comments.'' Served as treasurer of St. David's School and Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, NYC. Graduate of St. Paul's School '30, and Harvard '34. Mr. de Give became captain of the Harvard hockey team and was awarded the John Tudor Cup for hockey in 1933 and 1934. He was elected to the Harvard Varsity Hall of Fame for football, hockey and baseball, and selected to be goaltender for the 1936 US Olympic hockey team. He served as a lieutenant in the navy in World War II. Mr. de Give is survived by his wife of 59 years, the former Eleanor Hoguet, children David, Ghislaine, Paul, Philip and Dominique, seven grandchildren, two step-grandchildren, and brothers Lawrence and Louis. A Memorial Mass will be held Saturday, April 7, at 10 AM, at St. Louis DeGonzague Church in Newburyport, MA.

title: Britain Deploys the Army in Foot-and-Mouth Battle

title: Mideast Fact-Finding Panel Angers Sharon
description: Prime Minister Ariel Sharon lashed out today at an American-sponsored fact-finding committee led by former Senator George J. Mitchell, calling its inquiry into the conflict here unjustified and saying that Israel made ''a historic mistake'' when it consented to the investigation.

title: Deadline for Belgrade
description: The end of March marks an important deadline for Yugoslavia. An American law requires President Bush to decide whether the government of Vojislav Kostunica is cooperating with the Hague war crimes tribunal, which Belgrade is obliged to do under international law. If the United States determines that Belgrade is cooperating, then Yugoslavia will receive $50 million in aid. More important, Washington will approve access to hundreds of millions of dollars in loans from the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

title: Publishers Join to Offer Books in Spanish
description: The Random House publishing division of Bertelsmann and the Italian publishing company Mondadori announced plans last week to merge their Spanish-language book publishing operations. Each company will own a 50 percent stake in the new joint venture, Grupo Editorial Random House Mondadori. Mondadori is controlled by the Italian financier Silvio Berlusconi.

title: Mr. Annan's Winning Record
description: Kofi Annan's candidacy for a second five-year term as United Nations secretary general is welcome and deserves the strong endorsement President Bush gave it on Friday. Since taking office in 1997, Mr. Annan has strengthened the U.N.'s management and moral credibility and repaired its once-frayed ties with Washington. Further reforms are needed to enable the organization to live up to its founding ideals. A second term would allow Mr. Annan to make additional changes and cement a constructive relationship with the new Bush administration and Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EASLICK, DAVID K.
description: EASLICK-David K. Longtime telephone company executive and civic and community leader, died Wednesday, March 14, in Naples, Fla., where he had wintered away from his Grosse Pointe Farms home for more than 20 years. He was 80. Mr. Easlick graduated from University High in Ann Arbor and then earned a B.A. degree from the University of Michigan in 1942. He was a Sloan Fellow at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1954, was awarded an honorary doctor of law degree by Butler University in 1972, and was awarded an honorary degree of doctor of business administration by Eastern Michigan University in 1981. His fraternity was Phi Kappa Psi. Easlick's career at Michigan Bell began in Ann Arbor in 1948. He rose through the ranks to become vice president of personnel by 1960 and three years later took a post at AT&T, at the time Michigan Bell's parent company, to be the AT&T representative on President Kennedy's national task force on integration and equal rights. He was with Indiana Bell Telephone Company from 1963 to 1972, leaving as President of the company. In 1972 he returned to AT&T as vice president human resources and negotiated the historic national agreement on behalf of the Bell System with the U.S. Department of Labor and the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission to facilitate the movement of minorities and women into better jobs. After this assignment, Easlick served as Michigan Bell president from July 1973 until September 1983 when he was named chairman and retired. His concern for social justice was recognized by the Detroit NAACP when he was appointed co-chairman of its annual Fight for Freedom dinner in 1978 and when he was named Humanitarian of the Year in 1976 by the International B'nai B'rith. In World War II he served in the army as an infantry officer and spent three years in the European Theater where he took part in the D-day landing and in the Battle of the Bulge. He was awarded the Bronze Star with Oak Leaf cluster and the Silver Star as well as the Croix de Guerre by the French government. He was discharged as a major in 1945. Mr. Easlick was a director of a host of companies and community organizations, including American United Life Insurance Co., National Bank of Detroit, NBD Bancorp, Inc., Economic Club of Detroit, United Foundation of Southeastern Michigan and International Freedom Fund. His community involvement including serving as a trustee of the Boys and Girls Clubs of Metropolitan Detroit, Interlochen Center for the Arts, HarperGrace Hospital, New Detroit, Inc., Citizens Research Council of Michigan, Diocese of Michigan, Grosse Point Farms Foundation, and the Rose Hill Center in Holly, Michigan. Survivors include his wife Lucy; son David K. Easlick, Jr., daughters Susan Easlick Heinen and Anne Easlick, and six grandchildren, Christoph, Alexander, Max and Marta Heinen and Sarah and David Easlick. His parents were Dr. Kenneth Easlick and Mercie VanAken Easlick. Dr. Easlick was founding chairman of Pediatric Dentistry of the School of Dentistry at the University of Michigan. A memorial service will be held at Christ Church, Grosse Pointe Farms on August 11. Contributions may be sent to the David K. Easlick Memorial Fund, c/o Goodman & Breen, Attorneys at Law, 3838 Tamiami Trail North, Suite 300, Naples, FL 34103.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUTNAM, WILLIAM A. III
description: PUTNAM-William A. III. Age 78, of Falmouth, MA, died of Alzheimer's disease on March 22, at the Cape Cod Hospital. He was the husband of Felicity N. (Koller) Putnam. Mr. Putnam was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, and spent his summers in the Adirondacks, where his family had a home in Ausable Club, NY. William attended the Berkshire School in Massachusetts and Cornell University in New York. He served in the US Army during the Korean War and then moved to Falmouth. In 1955 her opened Putnam Book and Music Shop in Falmouth. He owned and operated the business until his retirement in 1976. William was past president of Falmouth Rotary and was an avid golfer. He was a pioneer of Falmouth recycling. Besides his wife, Mr. Putnam is survived by his stepson John Rumery of Malden, MA, and his stepdaughter Sarah Heighton of Amherst, New Hampshire, and two grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. William will be dearly missed by his family and friends. For information contact Chapman Cole and Gleason Funeral Home, Falmouth. For guest book and additional information: www.ccgfuneralhome.com

Recent technical advances, howerer, have prompted cable companies to step up the marketing of their digital services. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHUSID, JOSEPH G., M.D.
description: CHUSID-Joseph G., M.D. Age 86, on March 23, 2001, of Brookfield, WI, formerly of Wantagh, NY. He was an internationally known physician, researcher, author and medical educator, respected and beloved by colleagues, students and patients alike. He had Parkinson's disease. He was born in Newark, NJ, 1914, and was a graduate of the Unviersity of Pennsylvania in 1934 and its medical school in 1938. He began his practice and research in neurology in 1940 while Medical Director at the Philadelphia Home for the Incurables and Assistant Instructor of Neurology at Penn medical school. He enlisted in the Army during WWII and was assigned to the Army Air Force Regional Station Hospital in Coral Gables, FL; he ultimately rose to the rank of major. During this time, he commenced his career as contributor, co-author and eventually sole author of the best selling medical textbook ''Correlative Neuroanatomy and Functional Neurology.'' Popular with medical students and others, the book sold more than a million copies and was reproduced in a dozen languages during the 40 years he was associated with it. Following military service, he pursued medical research at the University of Illinois and Yale and Columbia Universities. In 1947, he joined the staff of St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center in New York City, becoming Director of the Neurology Department in 1970; he retired in 1984. He served as a board examiner for the American Board of Neurology and was on the clinical faculty at Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons, New Jersey College of Medicine and New York Medical College. He was a member of many professional societies, including Alpha Omega Alpha, the American Academy of Neurology, the American Epilepsy Society and the American Medical EEG Society. His wife of 49 years, Anna Kathryn, died in 1991. He is survived by one son, Michael J., M.D., of Brookfield, one daughter, Joanna, of Alexandria, VA, and two grandchildren, Karen and Paul. Contributions to the Chusid Neurology Library at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center.

title: Metro Business Briefing; IDENTITY THEFT WARNING
description: The New York State Consumer Protection Board has issued a warning about what it called a new kind of identity theft scheme: selling phony protection against identity theft. In selling the false protection, swindlers gain information that can be used to steal buyers' identity. The board said it had found that a Toronto-based telemarketer -- the same company suspected of bilking people out of millions of dollars by selling debt and credit information that was available elsewhere -- was planning to sell identity theft protection to consumers in the United States. ''Consumers already have protection against credit card rip-offs, because by law they are liable for only $50 or less in fraudulent credit card charges,'' said the board's acting chairwoman, C. Adrienne Rhodes. A board spokesman, Jon Sorensen, declined to identify the Toronto company because the investigation was continuing. Joseph P. Fried

title: India's AIDS Crisis
description: Outside of Africa, India likely has the world's most worrisome AIDS crisis. India suffers the same virulent strain of AIDS that is killing Africans, its general health conditions are poor, and heterosexual transmission is common, putting the whole population at risk. In the last few years, the Indian government has begun to carry out a well-designed campaign to cut the spread of AIDS, but it has been spottily administered and will not show real gains for several years. India's experience is a warning to other nations that prevention plans are complex to carry out and take time to show effects -- all the more reason for governments to begin now. J. V. R. Prasada Rao, the director of India's National AIDS Control Organization, says that India had a total of 3.7 million people infected with the AIDS virus in 1999. Some outside experts believe the real number is double that or more. Many parts of India have a low infection rate of under 1 percent. But there are pockets where AIDS is far more prevalent, especially in Bombay, Calcutta and Madras. Some prenatal clinics in the state of Tamil Nadu report that nearly 5 percent of their patients are infected.
