description: WASHINGTON, March 27 -- The Senate handed a decisive victory today to supporters of a plan to overhaul the campaign finance law, comfortably defeating a rival proposal that would have capped but not prohibited the unregulated large dollar donations to the political parties that escalated to nearly $500 million in the last election.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a warning that someone had fooled VeriSign Inc. into issuing fraudulent electronic certificates -- encrypted messages used to verify transactions online -- in the Microsoft Corporation's name misstated the cause of a delay in canceling one certificate. VeriSign was waiting for a number of agencies to provide information verifying the transaction. It was not waiting for Microsoft to respond.

title: PMC-Sierra And Conexant Will Cut Jobs
description: Conexant Systems and PMC-Sierra said today that they planned to dismiss hundreds of workers and that sales this quarter would lag behind already reduced forecasts because demand for communications chips was falling.

title: A Reversal on Public Access to Chemical Data
description: Citing national security, the Environmental Protection Agency earlier this month rescinded a Clinton administration proposal to increase public access to information about the potential consequences of chemical plant accidents.

title: Of Nanotubes and Buckyballs: Atomic-Scale Building Blocks
description: Once, scientists knew of only two forms of pure carbon: diamonds and graphite. Then in 1985 came the discovery of soccer-ball-shaped molecules known as buckyballs, followed a few years later by nanotubes, cylinder-shaped molecules that look like rolled-up chicken wire.

title: Big Business of Cattle Theft Is a Growing Threat to Ranchers
description: Gunslingers brandishing pistols at dawn may be a thing of the past. Even in this wind-scarred outpost of the South Dakota Badlands, it is hard to imagine posses on horseback hunting down outlaws, six-shooters blazing.

title: In Youth, It's Not Just About Cholesterol
description: When it comes to fighting incipient heart disease in young people, just watching cholesterol levels is not enough.

title: Bush Contends Tax Cut Plan Will Revive Weak Economy
description: KALAMAZOO, Mich., March 27  President Bush gave Americans his detailed assessment of the country's economy today, comparing it to a great athlete who is "somewhat winded but fundamentally strong" and asserting that his suggested $1.6-trillion tax cut would enable it to pick up its pace.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions yesterday about the appointment of Han Seung Soo as foreign minister of South Korea included an erroneous reference from the foreign ministry on his past service as ambassador to the United States. He served during the Clinton administration, not the Reagan and Bush administrations. The article also misstated Mr. Han's age. He is 64, not 63.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Hollywood Slips Uneasily Into Something Fashionable
description: Sometime around 1:30 yesterday morning, as Melrose Avenue outside Morton's remained closed to vehicles that didn't approximate the length of the gardens at Versailles, a taxi driver was complaining about the mayhem that befalls the west side of Los Angeles on Academy Awards night every year. ''They run around with their Oscars,'' he said, the ''they'' referring to the celebrities who on this night seem to outnumber the lesser people without access to free Harry Winston jewelry. ''You can't go anywhere. And they're all in those nasty dresses. You can see their underwear -- yuck.''

title: The Toppled Chimney Mystery: Is It the Fault's Fault?
description: Against the musical backdrop of masons' hammers everywhere clink-clinking on brick, Dr. Derek Booth, a geologist at the University of Washington, is driving through West Seattle pointing out the curious excess of chimneys damaged here in last month's earthquake. Cruising past the modest bungalows and ranch homes, he points to a chimney with a stair-step crack down its bricks, another cockeyed from twisting and many others beheaded at the roofline.

title: Moundou Journal; Farmer and Herder Share Milk, and a Bit of Peace
description: As a herd of cows ambled by toward the river that runs through this unpretentious town, Ousmane Mahmat and Edmond Ngoinodji sat down over fresh goat's milk the other morning -- an unnoteworthy act if not for the fact that they represent opposing sides of this Central African nation's enduring divide.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ST. LUKE'S DOCTORS UNIONIZE
description: Nearly 450 medical interns and residents at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan have voted to join a union. On Friday, the doctors voted, 283 to 44, to join the Committee of Interns and Residents. In a separate move, 105 interns and residents at Our Lady of Mercy Hospital Center in the Bronx agreed Friday to join the same union after a majority of those doctors signed cards expressing support for the Committee of Interns and Residents. Steven Greenhouse

title: Corrections
description: An article on March 15 about the city's plan to reduce the size of the Sydenham health clinic in Harlem misidentified the previous owner of the clinic building at 215 West 125th Street and omitted an explanation of the arrangements for maintenance. The owner was Commonwealth Presidential Associates, not the Harlem Commonwealth Council Inc. The city was responsible for maintenance of the lobby, elevators and clinic under its lease. The new owner, a partnership that includes the Cogswell Realty Group, is now responsible for maintenance.

title: Harsh Words for Those Who Defy 'Do No Harm'
description: ''Culture of Death: The Assault on Medical Ethics in America,'' by Wesley J. Smith, Encounter Books, $23.95.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURNHILL, MICHAEL S., M.D.
description: BURNHILL-Michael S., M.D. The Council and Fellows of the New York Obstetrical Society records with profound regret the recent death of their LIFE Fellow, Michael S. Burnhill, M.D.

title: Macedonian Forces Consolidating Control of Hill Towns
description: Macedonian forces continued to move carefully through the hills above Tetovo today, consolidating their control of villages held by Albanian rebels for nearly two weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, GERALD, M.D.
description: FRIEDMAN-Gerald, M.D. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the sudden passing of Dr. Gerald Friedman. Dr. Friedman was a Gastroenterologist in the Department of Gastrology at Maimonides Medical Center for ten years. In addition, he did his medical residency at Maimonides. He will be sorely missed by all his colleagues, friends and patients. Sincere condolences are extended to his entire family. Salvatore DeGliuomini, M.D., Pres. Steven Farber, M.D., Pres. Elect Herbert Lehman, M.D., Secretary Ira Mayer, M.D., Treasurer

title: Long Odds for a Skater Out of Harlem
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  It is 7 degrees at the United States Olympic outdoor speedskating oval here. Just as the wind slices through the air and sends swirls of freshly fallen snow onto the ice, Jason Benta makes his move. He advances slowly at first, like a tiger eyeing his prey. But when his skates hit the black starting line, he explodes into a sprint.

title: U.S. to Face Honduras And Its Fans
description: Another challenging environment is awaiting the Americans tomorrow night in their World Cup qualifying game in Honduras. Coach BRUCE ARENA acknowledged that his team would face some adverse circumstances, but Arena also claimed that his team learned a great deal about tough crowds from the previous qualifying round.

title: Like Some Spinach With Those Fries?
description: When it comes to spinach, parents can be pretty crafty about sneaking it into food, many a child has learned. But mom and dad cannot compare to what researchers at the University of Arkansas have in mind.

title: AIWA PLANS JOB CUTS
description: The Aiwa Company, a struggling unit of the Sony Corporation of Japan, said it planned to reduce by half its group work force of 10,000 in a bid to step up its revamping efforts. Aiwa, an audio equipment manufacturer, which is scheduled to to report a group net loss of 37.2 billion yen ($302.9 million) for the year ending this month, will also receive a capital injection of 30 billion yen ($244.3 million), half of it from shareholders and half from Sony, to help absorb the costs associated with the revamping. Miki Tanikawa

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Baseball Fans to Be Charged For Internet Broadcasts

title: SPX SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE VSI HOLDINGS
description: The SPX Corporation, a maker of industrial and automotive products, said it will acquire VSI Holdings for about $146 million to gain VSI's Internet development products. SPX said it will also assume about $51 million in debt. Shareholders of VSI, which is based in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., have the option of exchanging their shares for SPX stock or a combination of stock and cash. SPX, based in Muskegon, Mich., has purchased businesses recently to reduce its dependence on sales related to the automotive industry.

title: The Fate of a Child, and of Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Contract Gains Ease Sting of Layoffs for Auto Workers
description: Joe Salazar, a machine repairman at the Chrysler engine factory here, has made one sacrifice as overtime has disappeared and layoffs have begun: he has postponed the purchase of a Dodge Ram pickup to replace his bright red Dodge Durango.

title: American Studying in Russia May Be Swept Up in Spy Case
description: An American student who was investigated on suspicion of espionage and charged with possession of marijuana may instead face more serious drug charges, Russian police authorities indicated today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILLESPIE, GARDNER F. JR.
description: GILLESPIE-Gardner F. Jr. Of Chester, CT, a retired insurance executive, died on Sunday at the Middlesex Hospital in Middletown, CT. He was 83. Mr. Gillespie served as President of Frank B. Hall, Westchester, prior to his retirement in 1983. He attended the Loomis School and was a graduate of Princeton University, Class of 1939. In World War II, he served in the U.S. Army's Cyclone Division in the Philippines. He was a resident of Rye, NY, for 37 years. In his later years, he was a devoted fly fisherman. A member of the Angler's Club of New York, he served as President of the Hammonasset Fishing Club in North Madison, CT. He also was a photographer, and collaborated with his wife, Mary Eliza, a portrait and landscape painter, on mixed media projects. He was on the Board of the Westchester Council of the Arts. Mr. Gillespie is survived by his wife of fifty-nine years, the former Mary Eliza Brown of Pittsburgh, PA. and their 4 children, Susan Howe Gillespie, Gardner F. Gillespie, III, Nancy Gillespie de la Selle, & Douglas Brown Gillespie, as well as his brother, Stanton Gates Gillespie. He was the devoted grandfather of his nine grandchildren and three step-grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to the Critical Care Unit of the Middlesex Hospital, Middletown, CT. Services will be held at the Congregational Church in Madison, CT, Wed., March 28, 11 A.M.

title: Committee Urges End to Bandannas
description: The National Football League opened its annual owners meeting in Palm Desert, Calif., yesterday with a review from Commissioner Paul Tagliabue and reports from the competition committee. The committee addressed, among other things, banning the wearing of bandannas and limiting the scuffling among players that often occurs after whistles have blown to stop play.

title: Jeter and Hernndez Work Out Pain Free To Lift Yank Hopes
description: Yankee shortstop Derek Jeter jogged on a practice field here today and felt no pain in his right quadriceps, according to General Manager Brian Cashman. And if Jeter comes through a Tuesday morning workout without any problems, he will probably have his first game action since March 18.

title: Palestinians Kill Baby Girl In West Bank
description: Palestinian gunmen shot and killed a baby girl today outside the family home in the divided city of Hebron, Israeli officials said.

title: Janice Levin, 87, Philanthropist of the Arts
description: Janice H. Levin, an art collector and philanthropist, died on Friday in Palm Beach, Fla. She was 87 and had homes in Manhattan, in East Hampton, N.Y., and in Palm Beach.

title: Article 2001032790951501748 -- No Title
description: STATE OF THE ART

title: State Groups Join Doctors in Suing Insurers
description: The state medical associations of California, Georgia and Texas joined individual doctors from seven states yesterday in a federal lawsuit that accused eight health insurers, including Aetna Inc. and the Cigna Corporation, of engaging in ''a pattern of racketeering activity'' to deny necessary medical care.

title: Cleaning: Right Thing to Do
description: To the Editor:

title: From the Movies to Sitcom, With Twitches and Ticks
description: Joan Cusack has a vaudevillian soul. Perhaps nothing demonstrated her slapstick gene better than her performance in ''Broadcast News,'' James L. Brooks's 1987 comedy about network television news. Ms. Cusack, playing a production assistant, hurtles like a pinball around a newsroom to get a tape on the air on time.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: Supreme Court Debates Copyright Protection
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Supreme Court wrestled today with a narrow issue of copyright law that carries major implications for a world in which electronic databases rather than back copies and microfilm are quickly becoming the standard for archiving and researching newspapers and magazines.

title: Accounts
description: * Sea and Ski, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a skin-care products brand, to Harris Drury Cohen, Fort Lauderdale, as the first agency to handle the brand since it was acquired by Faulding last year. Billings were estimated at less than $5 million.

title: It's Amazing What a Simple Piece of Cloth Can Do
description: Dancegoers greeted ''Adieu'' anew when Ballet Tech revived this 1984 work on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: In New Motion, Young Hearts, Limbs and Minds
description: Choreography for children may look simple, but the trick is to showcase their abilities without condescension. Eliot Feld has kept this balance in mind in Kids Dance, the children's group he established as a sibling to his senior troupe, Ballet Tech.

title: CHRYSLER RESTRUCTURES SALES AND SERVICE OPERATION
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G.'s Chrysler Group restructured its sales and service organization to create five regional business centers in the United States, giving them power to make decisions in local markets. The automaker will let the centers determine vehicle content, sales incentives and marketing because customer demands vary in the regions, the company said. The centers are in Detroit, New York, Dallas, Los Angeles, and Orlando, Fla. They will employ a total of about 110 people, all shifted from existing offices. Chrysler's 25 zone offices will continue to operate.

title: P.& G. Suit Against Amway Is Revived
description: For decades, Procter & Gamble has been dealing with a public relations nightmare: a false and harmful rumor that the company says was fueled in the 1980's and 90's by some Amway distributors who sell paper goods, soaps and other household staples in competition with P.& G.

title: Carrots, Pepsi and a Kidnapping Joke
description: I want to thank Danny DeVito for munching a carrot during Bob Dylan's performance, a snack that provided the second-best moment of Sunday's Oscar show. Thank you, Danny, for being unpretentious and a relief from the sight of all those other people chomping nicotine gum for three hours.

title: German Heritage, Americanized Future; Siemens Seeks Opportunities And Skills in the New World
description: Klaus Kleinfeld has a dream: he is returning from one of his myriad trips abroad, and a customs official at Kennedy Airport asks him where he works. ''Siemens,'' he answers.

title: MICROSOFT, COMPAQ AND OTHERS TO WORK ON TABLET PC
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it would collaborate with the Compaq Computer Corporation, the Intel Corporation and the Transmeta Corporation to create a tablet-sized, wireless personal computer. The computers will be about the size of a piece of notebook paper, and will employ the next version of Microsoft's Windows operating system; users will be able to enter data with a stylus similar to those used with hand-held electronic organizers, officials said. With PC software sales beginning to slow, Microsoft has said it plans to produce software that could be used in smaller, mobile devices. Leland Rockoff, director of marketing and planning for the Tablet PC at Microsoft, said, ''Our aspiration is that in three to five years, input with pen or with speech will be as ubiquitous as a keyboard and mouse are today.'' Mr. Rockoff said that he hopes the new product would give the company a chance to make inroads among people who are not using a PC now. Microsoft and the other companies have not said how much the Tablet PC will cost; it is expected to be released next year.

title: On Pro Basketball; Dunks and Epithets: Things Are Getting Ugly
description: Cheap shot after cheap shot, the boisterous man in the stands would not be quiet. ''He kept going and going and going,'' Latrell Sprewell said. ''After a while, you're like, 'Shut up.' ''

title: A Chinese-Born Composer and Her Own Long March
description: Chen Yi's training to write a symphony was anything but classical. There were the years she played the violin with the windows closed, so no one could hear. There were the rocks she carried and the rice she planted during the Cultural Revolution. And there were the eight years she spent learning ancient Chinese instruments in Guangzhou.

title: ROBERTSON STEPHENS TO LAY OFF 80 EMPLOYEES
description: The investment firm Robertson Stephens will lay off 80 people, or about 5 percent of its work force, this week, a spokeswoman said yesterday. The cuts come as other investment banks and brokerage firms are pruning staff and cutting back on expenses because of the stock-market slump and the decrease in trading activity. Once the layoffs occur, Robertson Stephens, a unit of the Boston-based FleetBoston Financial Corporation, will have trimmed its work force 11 percent since the beginning of the year. So far this year, the company has reduced employment by 6 percent through layoffs and attrition, said a spokeswoman, Courtney Weber. The firm employs about 1,500 people.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Companies Start to Warm Up to Restricted Stock
description: Restricted stock is finally getting some respect. Long viewed as a freebie thrown at senior executives who were already amply paid, it is now enjoying a comeback.

title: SULZER'S CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
description: The chairman of Sulzer, Ueli Roost, resigned to try to foil a hostile takeover of Sulzer, a medical and industrial technology company based in Switzerland. Mr. Roost said he was quitting ahead of a planned vote by shareholders on April 10 on an offer by InCentive Capital. Sulzer and InCentive, which is also based in Switzerland, have been locked in a takeover battle since February, with each side claiming the backing of shareholders. Elizabeth Olson

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TISCHLER, ROSE
description: TISCHLER-Rose. Of Manhattan. Beloved aunt of Kenneth R. Krechmer. Funeral services are private. For information call ''Wien & Wien'', 1-800-322-0533.

title: On Evil and the Citizen, No Answers Are Easy
description: It's rare to walk out of a play and wish it had been longer. But Abby Mann's post-Holocaust drama, ''Judgment at Nuremberg,'' which opened on Broadway yesterday at the Longacre Theater, is a bit too brisk and trim for its own good. This is not to say that the show's two and a half hours fly by but rather that Mr. Mann's famous story about Nazi judges on trial before an American tribunal doesn't shrink comfortably to stage time and space. The play feels edited, nipped and tucked, in short, adapted.

title: Corrections
description: The Boating Report article in the sports pages on Sunday, about the danger posed to transoceanic sailors by submerged objects, misstated the point of origin of a ship that recently lost 81 containers in the North Atlantic. It was Rotterdam, the Netherlands, not Germany.

title: The Beat Goes On
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Metro Business Briefing; INSIDER SENTENCING
description: A New York lawyer who tried to get inside information from a paralegal at a firm handling corporate mergers was sentenced last week to six months of home confinement and three years of probation, a federal prosecutor said. Robert C. Schuster, a sole practitioner based in White Plains, pleaded guilty last month in a New York City federal court to charges of trying to obtain inside information about corporate activities by bribing a client who was a paralegal at Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. Mr. Schuster was sentenced late last week, said Timothy Coleman, an assistant United States attorney. The sentences were concurrent and started immediately, he said. Mr. Schuster, who is in his early 30's, first asked the paralegal for inside information last September, when he represented her in White Plains City Court on a private matter, authorities said. She rebuffed Mr. Schuster and reported him to her superiors. She later began secretly recording conversations for the F.B.I.

title: Slow Lane Also Leads to Heart Health
description: Just walking for at least an hour a week is now associated with less heart disease in women. And it does not even seem to matter how fast one moves, researchers reported last week in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: BOLDFACE NAMES
description: Loose Buttons

title: Verniero Has 79-Page Defense On Eve of Testimony by Aides
description: Peter G. Verniero today released a voluminous, point-by-point defense of his record on racial profiling while he was state attorney general, just as his former top assistants prepared to testify on Tuesday before the State Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE CLIMBS. Coffee rose nearly 3 percent on buying by processors taking advantage of prices close to an eight-year low. In New York, coffee for May delivery rose 1.75 cents, or 2.9 percent, to 61.85 cents a pound.

title: Courtroom Gets Differing Views Of Videotapes In Park Attacks
description: For the last three weeks, testimony about the attacks after last year's National Puerto Rican Day Parade has centered on seven videotapes of women being doused, taunted, groped and assaulted. Yesterday, the lawyers' final arguments on both sides showed how ambiguous those tapes could be.

title: GlobalFreeloaders.com
description: Imagine having friends around the world ready to put you up for free in a spare bedroom. That's the idea behind www.globalfreeloaders.com . Don't be fooled by the name: it's not just for your in-laws. Anyone can apply, as long as they're willing to return the favor. There's no fee, and information about hosts is kept confidential; only general descriptions of the home and its location are posted. The hosts, meanwhile, can check on potential guests references and communicate with them through the Web site. And members are not obligated to be hosts each time someone applies.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We worked in those mines, waiting for our golden years. Well, now it's our golden years, and it's done nothing but cost us gold. This is no way to live.''

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT BALTIMORE TECHNOLOGIES WARNING
description: Irish security software developer Baltimore Technologies faces investigation by the British Financial Services Authority for a possible failure to disclose required information to the market, following a statement last week that led to a 30 percent slump in its share price in London. A British analyst at a technical briefing in Dublin reportedly misinterpreted comments made by Baltimore chief executive Francis J. Rooney as negative forecasts, and prompted a sell-off on the London Stock Exchange. Baltimore issued an earnings warning following the fall in the stock. Brian Lavery

title: Gilt Frame For Mozart, In a Revival From 1989
description: Some Don Giovannis exude stark, raw sexuality. Others are sexy because the production tells us that they are supposed to be sexy. David Pittsinger, the Don Giovanni in City Opera's revival of its 1989 Hal Prince production, was the latter: slim and attractive beyond a doubt, suavely crooning in a lovely voice, yet without that extra spark of magnetism to lift the character over the lip of convention into compelling believability.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MOAK, ARTHUR ALLEN
description: MOAK-Arthur Allen. Died in his home in Kingston, New York, on Sunday, March 25th after an extended illness. Originally from Brooklyn, NY he was graduated from Cornell University, 1939 and is survived by his wife Blanched (Hertzfeld) whom he married in April of 1941, his daughter Patricia Ann, his son Jeffrey, five grand grandchildren and two great grandchildren. Services and cremation Tuesday, March 27.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERMAN, SEBET
description: SILVERMAN-Sebet. Born 1906, Bristol, England; died 22 March, Westfield, New Jersey. A nationally known industrial designer, his seventy year career included a period as Chief Designer of the Nurre Mirror Company (1936-59). Sebet developed many patented processes which helped revitalize the mirror industry in the United States. Silverman is survived by his wife, Lillian Bookman Silverman, daughters Roberta Kaufman of Holmdel, NJ, industrial designer and environmental planner; and Sandra Souder of Skaneateles, NY, a criminal justice and environmental grant writer. Also grandsons Daniel Kaufman of NYC, a sculptor and designer; and Lev Kaufman of New Brunswick, NJ, a geologist and computer scientist. Donations in memoriam Sebet Silverman: Rabbi Kroloff Discretionary Fund, Temple Emanuel, 756 East Broad Street, Westfield, NJ 07090-2099 or Friends of Holmdel Open Space, 12 Indian Creek Road, Holmdel, NJ 07733-1208.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday and one in some editions on Sunday about the boxing match between Arturo Gatti and Oscar de la Hoya on Saturday night misspelled the surname of Gatti's trainer. He is Hector Rocha, not Roca.

title: Preparing the Heart for a Needed Jolt
description: Cardioverter defibrillators, which are implanted in some people with irregular heartbeats, are credited with saving untold lives.

title: Disbarred L.I. Doctor Is Charged in Firebombing
description: A disbarred dermatologist on Long Island was arraigned yesterday on charges that he firebombed the offices of an osteopath in Huntington on Sunday, setting a blaze that heavily damaged the chamber of commerce offices next door, the Suffolk County police said.

title: Circuit City Moves To FCB Worldwide
description: Circuit City Stores, the computer electronics and appliances retailer, said yesterday that it had named the Chicago office of FCB Worldwide, part of True North Communications, as the lead agency on its account after parting ways with its agency since August 1999, the New York office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $60 million to $75 million.

title: Political Memo; G.O.P. Billionaire Haunts a Democratic Race
description: For the last few months, the four Democratic candidates for mayor of New York have dutifully gone about the business of trying to win their party's primary: scratching to differentiate themselves, devising strategies aimed at different boroughs and ethnic groups, pursuing hospital workers and teachers and municipal workers and newspaper editorial writers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANCE, HARRY JAMES
description: FRANCE-Harry James. On March 23rd, 2001. Adored son of Dorothy (nee Cosgrove) and Richard. Darling brother of Sofia. Reposing Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM at Riverdale-on-Hudson Funeral Home, 6110 Riverdale Avenue (W. 261st Street, Bronx) Mass of the Angels on Wednesday 10 AM, at St. Margaret of Cortona Church. Interment Beechwood Cemetery.

title: A Potpourri of Percussion With Toy and Real Pianos
description: Emanuel Ax's explorations into new music have taken him on some interesting journeys in recent seasons, and he has apparently found the work gratifying. This season he is offering an adventurous two-concert series at Alice Tully Hall, ''The Art of the Piano and Percussion.'' In the first installment, on Sunday afternoon, Mr. Ax's collaborator was the Scottish percussionist Evelyn Glennie, and so sprawling and diverse was Ms. Glennie's stage setup -- mallet instruments in center stage, hanging cymbals and tom-toms at the back, more pitched percussion off to the side -- that Mr. Ax and his concert grand were sandwiched into a corner on the left of the stage.

title: SWISS CONCERN POSTS PROFIT
description: Socit Gnrale de Surveillance, the world's largest goods inspection firm, reported a 13 percent increase in profit, to $75 million, in line with analysts' expectations. Despite losing government contracts in the Philippines and the Ivory Coast, the company, which is based in Geneva, said it expected earnings growth to continue this year. It announced its results as a simmering feud between the current management and a former chief executive, Elisabeth Salina Amorini, broke into the open. The company's chairman, Max Amstutz, above, wants to remove her from the board, but Ms. Amorini refuses to resign unless the entire board leaves. Elizabeth Olson

title: Discovering the Tyranny Of 10-Year-Old Playwrights; At Student Workshop, Big Stars Quickly Get Smaller
description: Edie Falco was nervous. This wasn't some taped television show like ''The Sopranos.'' This was live onstage in Greenwich Village, in front of the playwright. Could she carry it off? Could she be Nayomi, a pigtailed teenage hip-hop star with a klutzy partner?

title: Village That Rebels Held Is Suddenly Almost Empty
description: Ethnic Albanian rebels appeared in this village 12 days ago and made it their headquarters as they advanced on the town of Tetovo. But today, the only sound coming from the village was the lowing of cows and sheep wanting to be fed. The streets were mostly empty, and the fighters were evidently gone.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GUAY, ELAINE T. (NEE ALICKI)
description: GUAY-Elaine T. (nee Alicki), 63 of Atlantic Highlands, NJ, March 26, 2001. Wife of Richard, mother of Lisa Marie Eckert and Richard Jr., mother-in-law of Steven, sister of Bernard P. Alicki, grandmother of Adam. Funeral Thursday 9:30 AM at Flynn & Son Funeral Home, 23 Ford Ave, Fords, NJ, followed by a 10 AM Mass at St. Mary's RC Church, Perth Amboy, NJ. Interment will be in St. Gertrude Cemetery, Colonia, NJ. Visitation Wednesday 2-4, 7-9 PM. Condolence messages may be sent to our web address at www.flynnfuneral.com

title: Westchester Journal; Among the Comfortable, Prison Issues Stir Unease
description: The setting, a sleek conference center in Westchester County, seemed more likely to be the site of a sales meeting than a gathering of groups advocating for society's forgotten two million behind bars.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: A Strange Waltz in Vienna
description: I am an American Jew, yet found myself in Vienna under attack by Jrg Haider, one of Europe's more notorious anti-Semitic politicians. I was in Vienna doing what I normally do, conducting polls and providing advice to political leaders and their campaigns -- this time for the Social Democratic candidate for mayor, the incumbent, Michael Hupl. I had provided similar services for Bill Clinton and Al Gore, Tony Blair, Nelson Mandela and Ehud Barak. As a rule, I keep to the background, offering my ideas privately and far away from the TV cameras. Vienna was to be different.

title: Ad Intended to Stir Up Campuses More Than Succeeds in Its Mission
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 19  The editor of the student newspaper at Brown University says he knew a tempest was headed his way and rose to open the door for it.

title: Answers for Doctors on Suicide Question
description: It is not uncommon for seriously ill patients to ask their doctors to help them commit suicide. But while it is a wrenching situation, the doctors often go it alone, a new study reports.

title: A CONVERSATION WITH/Elliot Aronson; No One Left to Hate: Averting Columbines
description: Social psychology, the study of how the social environment shapes human behavior, is not an ivory tower science; it is a tool for helping to solve real world problems, like bigotry and violence. Dr. Elliot Aronson, a social psychologist and author, always preached this philosophy to his graduate students, but one day a phone call from a former student forced him to prove it.

title: Police Union Head Named in Conspiracy Case
description: The president of the New York City police detectives union has been named as an unindicted co-conspirator in what federal prosecutors say was an organized-crime scheme to use kickbacks to union leaders and mob threats and violence to tap pension funds, inflate stock values and defraud thousands of investors.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

title: AFFYMETRIX SETTLES PATENT DISPUTES WITH OXFORD
description: Shares of Affymetrix rose as much as 18 percent after the maker of chips used in genetic research said it settled all patent lawsuits with Oxford Gene Technology Ltd. Shares rose $3.81, to $30.56. Affymetrix and Oxford, which is closely held, announced the settlement late Friday, bringing an end to nearly two years of litigation between the companies. In a filing today with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Affymetrix said it is recording a charge of $19 million for the quarter ended Dec. 31, and it may have to take a smaller charge in the first quarter because of a fee arrangement with the company's lawyers. Affymetrix, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said it did not transfer any of its patents to Oxford as part of the settlement.

title: Alberto Salinas Jr., Juanita Garza and Hilaria Garza, Edinburg, Tex., Nov. 20, 2000
description: Alberto Salinas Jr.: "I am a spiritual healer. I pray over people that need cleansing. The lady and her sister came to me for healing, for help. As it turns out, she was demon-possessed. In the picture, I was performing an exorcism. I placed my hands on her head and started praying -- and she tried to get away and struggled. The demon in her became enraged and yelled for me to stop. In those moments, I experience no fear at all. I am completely focused on my work. Nothing else comes into my mind, heart, soul. Nothing. But it's a horrible situation for those who are present. It's a fight, struggle and battle outright. It drains me totally. I am worn out completely. But we succeeded." -->

Reback, co-founder of the Voxeo Corporation, is stepping aside as the company's president and chief executive, but will remain as chairman of the board, the company said yesterday. Mr. Reback's replacement will be Nancy Faigen, formerly an executive at Digex and I.B.M., where she oversaw the E-Business Solutions Unit. Mr. Reback, a Silicon Valley lawyer who prepared the Borland Corporation's successful defense in a software copyright dispute with the Lotus Development Corporation, co-founded Voxeo in November 1999. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PUTNAM, WILLIAM A. III
description: PUTNAM-William A. III. Age 78, of Falmouth, MA, died of Alzheimer's disease on March 22, at the Cape Cod Hospital. He was the husband of Felicity N. (Koller) Putnam. Mr. Putnam was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, and spent his summers in the Adirondacks, where his family had a home in Ausable Club, NY. William attended the Berkshire School in Massachusetts and Cornell University in New York. He served in the US Army during the Korean War and then moved to Falmouth. In 1955 her opened Putnam Book and Music Shop in Falmouth. He owned and operated the business until his retirement in 1976. William was past president of Falmouth Rotary and was an avid golfer. He was a pioneer of Falmouth recycling. Besides his wife, Mr. Putnam is survived by his stepson John Rumery of Malden, MA, and his stepdaughter Sarah Heighton of Amherst, New Hampshire, and two grandchildren. A private memorial service will be held at a later date. William will be dearly missed by his family and friends. For information contact Chapman Cole and Gleason Funeral Home, Falmouth. For guest book and additional information: www.ccgfuneralhome.com

title: ICO TO SELL OILFIELD SERVICES BUSINESS TO VARCO
description: ICO said yesterday that it planned to sell its oilfield services business to Varco International for $165 million to reduce debt and focus on petrochemical processing. The actions will let ICO cut annual expenses by about $14.4 million in interest and dividends.

Shares of Scholastic fell $5.56, or 13.7 percent, to $35.13 at the close of trading yesterday. Late yesterday, Scholastic announced that after evaluating eToys's Internet assets, it concluded the assets did not meet with the goals of the company's own Internet initiatives. Etoys filed for bankruptcy on March 7. Catherine Greenman

title: LSI LOGIC TO BUY C-CUBE MICROSYSTEMS
description: The communications chipmaker LSI Logic Corporation said yesterday that it would acquire C-Cube Microsystems in a stock deal valued at $878 million. Under the terms, each outstanding share of C-Cube common stock will be exchanged for 0.79 share of LSI. C-Cube, with about 600 employees, makes audio and video processors and reported $265 million in revenues in 2000. The deal is expected to help boost LSI's role in providing equipment for the broadband entertainment market, including equipment for transmitting digital data to television set-top boxes. LSI executives said that they expected to close the deal by the end of June. Shares of C-Cube rose $4.94 to $13.75 on the news, while LSI slipped $2.65, to $18.04. Both companies are based in Milpitas, Calif. Laurie J. Flynn

title: NEW YORK COMMUNITY BANCORP TO ACQUIRE BANK
description: New York Community Bancorp Inc. said yesterday that it agreed to acquire the Richmond County Financial Corporation, a Staten Island-based bank, for $802 million. Richmond County shareholders will receive 0.68 share of New York Community for each Richmond County share held, or $27.91 based on its closing price yesterday. That represents about a 4.3 percent premium over the share price of $26.75 yesterday. For New York Community, the deal will add Richmond County Savings Bank to its growing lineup including Queens County Savings Bank, CFS Bank, First Savings Bank of New Jersey, Ironbound Bank and South Jersey Bank. ''The whole idea is to have a strong holding company that can operate community banks,'' said Joseph R. Ficalora, the chairman of New York Community. ''We're not looking to be like Citibank.'' title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIVES, WENDY, M.D.
description: RIVES-Wendy, M.D. Died on Saturday, March 24, 2001, at NYU Medical Center at the age of thirty-nine due to complications of breast cancer. Dr. Rives was the Director of the Comprehensive Psychiatric Emergency Program at Bellevue Hospital. Beloved spouse to JoAnn, mother of Hal, daughter, sister, niece, aunt, and friend, she was a compassionate physician, and an advocate for the disenfranchised. Dr. Rives was a dedicated teacher who was deeply appreciated by her students and residents, and an exceptional leader. She will be remembered for her wide-ranging intellect and provocative viewpoints. Wendy won the affection of those who knew her with her incisive wit and charm. Born in Decatur, Georgia, Dr. Rives received her medical degree at Medical College of Georgia. She trained in psychiatry at Temple University and served as Chief Resident. Most recently, she was an attending physician and assistant professor of psychiatry at NYU Medical Center. She won recognition for excellence in teaching, supervision, and academic scholarship. Dr. Rives is survived by her partner of eleven years, Dr. JoAnn Difede, and their son, Hal Difede Rives; her parents, Barbara and Hal Rives of Tucker, Georgia; her brother and sister-inlaw, Jack and Eve Rives of Roswell, Georgia, and her sister and brother-in-law, Drs. Cathy Rives and Lionel Corbett of Santa Barbara, California, as well as three nephews, Michael and Jeffrey Rives and Gabriel Rives-Corbett. Dr. Rives will be buried near her home in East Hampton, NY. The funeral service is private. A memorial service will be held on or about May 7, 2001, details to be announced at a later date. Donations in Dr. Rives' memory may be made to The Brain Tumor Foundation, c/o Patrick Kelly, M.D., 530 First Avenue, Suite 8R, New York, New York 10021. The family would like to express their gratitude to the medical staff of the NYU Medical Center MICU for their exceptional care of Dr. Rives during the last two months of her life.

title: STIMULUS FOR MALAYSIA
description: Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad of Malaysia announced a 3 billion ringgit ($789 million) fiscal stimulus package to offset the effects of a global slowdown on his country's export-driven economy. In addition to new spending to build schools and universities, Mr. Mahathir said his government would accelerate the construction of a controversial hydroelectric dam in the rain forests of Borneo, lower social security payments by workers and require banks to increase lending 8 percent a year. Stock-ownership regulations will be eased to encourage foreign investment, but the prime minister's decision in 1998 to peg the nation's currency to the United States dollar will stand. Wayne Arnold

title: E! Holds On
description: Cable's E! television network did a better job holding on to its audience on Oscar night than did ABC, whose ratings for the Academy Awards broadcast Sunday night were the lowest yet. E!'s outrageous pre-awards special, starring the comedian Joan Rivers and her daughter Melissa, drew a slightly larger audience than it did in 2000. Still, size is relative when comparing network audiences with those of cable television. E!'s ''Live from the Red Carpet: The 2001 Academy Awards'' was watched by 3.1 million people, up from just over 3 million in 2000. The ABC Oscar broadcast, on the other hand, was watched by 42.9 million people, down from 46.3 million last year. ABC, meanwhile, may in large part have HBO's ''Sopranos'' to blame for the Academy Awards' ratings decline. ''The Sopranos'' was watched by 7.4 million people on Sunday at 9 p.m., or by about 2 million more than watched ''The Sopranos'' on Oscar night last year. That could account for a large portion of the ceremony's defectors. JIM RUTENBERG

title: A Win for McCain-Feingold
description: In a triumph of good sense, the Senate yesterday rejected Senator Chuck Hagel's watered-down version of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance reform bill. The impressive 60-to-40 vote makes clear that a majority of senators favor an overhaul of the election fund-raising system -- a fact that President Bush acknowledged in saying privately he might sign the bill if it passes. But now the original McCain-Feingold bill faces two more formidable challenges. Most crucially, the Senate must turn aside a proposed amendment that would throw out the ban on ''soft money'' if a separate provision regulating financing of advertisements by independent groups is declared unconstitutional. A second potentially destructive fight over how high to raise existing limits on donations to candidates and parties could also fracture the reform coalition.

title: Jeter Plays, and Homers, But May Open on the D.L.
description: Derek Jeter's soft voice hardens when he speaks of the disabled list. He is nursing an injury, his manager seems to be thinking Jeter will not be healed sufficiently by opening day, and it may be that while his teammates are playing the Kansas City Royals in packed Yankee Stadium on Monday, Jeter will be here rehabilitating his right leg.

title: An East Side Sliver of French Pastry
description: Ptisserie Margot, a bright Gallic sliver at 1212 Lexington Avenue (82nd Street), is the new, more visible branch of a spot of the same name that Nacer Marcel Gacem owns in the Ansonia, 2109 Broadway (74th Street).

title: Commercial Real Estate; Benetton Plans Stores Big Enough for Whole Line
description: Benetton is moving to a larger size. The Italian producer of stylish clothing and occasionally outlandish advertisements is planning to change its stores' image by opening new, larger and highly styled stores, starting in Manhattan and expanding across the country.

title: A Job for the U.N.: To Ease the Pain
description: To the Editor:

title: Speeding Through the Troubles
description: Jean Racine needed a release valve on her mind. The heavy thoughts would start growing in her head, each concern rising up next to the other, with some strange Jiffy-Pop effect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REYNAL, ANTHONY
description: REYNAL-Anthony. On March 9, 2001 at age 61. Funeral services at Church of the Epiphany, 1391 York Avenue, at East 74th Street, April 9th, at 4:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to the Groton School, Groton, MA. 01451-0991.

title: Yearning Only for You . . . and You . . . and You . . . and Especially You
description: If not much else, Ilan Duran Cohen's sexual comedy, ''Confusion of Genders,'' offers the pleasure of watching attractive bodies in various states of undress entangling and disentangling in a tormented erotic roundelay. But although its opening nude tableaus hint that it might venture into X-rated territory, ''Confusion of Genders'' quickly turns into an earnest talkfest (spiced with flashes of nudity and sexually explicit dialogue) that feels stiffly programmatic and ultimately false.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LIMOUSINE WITH WINGS
description: Luxury tour operators, businesses with many employees to transport at one time, professional sports teams and other groups could charter a Boeing 747 if Voyager International Airlines is approved by regulators. Voyager, which would be based at Kennedy International Airport, needs approval by the Department of Transportation and the Federal Aviation Administration. Voyager plans to charter two 747-200's with up to 470 seats each for fees of $13,000 to $20,000 an hour, said Rob Kulat, a spokesman. Steve Strunsky

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORGAN, MURIEL (NEE PERL)
description: MORGAN-Muriel (nee Perl). On March 26, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Arthur J. Morgan. Loving mother of Tony & John. Devoted mother-in-law of Mercedes and Nancy. Dear sister of the late Dr. Ruth Kahn. Adored grandmother of Paul, Melissa, Jeffrey, Peter, Benjamin and Nicholas. Great grandmother of Jennifer, Mikaela, Esme & Sidonie. Former teacher at the Bank Street School and the Village Community School. She will be dearly missed by her family and friends and remembered for her wit, her warmth and her generosity. Service Friday 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to a charity of your choice.

title: New Hampshire Academy Tries a New Approach
description: If you ferried kids from any random classroom in America out to the middle of a lake and dumped them overboard, about a third of them would be natural-born swimmers and make it easily to shore.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KORN, HAROLD
description: KORN-Harold. Died March 27, 2001 of cancer at the age of 71. Son of Jack and Nettie. Husband of the deceased poet Amy Clampitt and the beloved professor to thousands of Columbia Law students to whom he was tirelessly devoted. He leaves no survivors. Lover of life, learning, work and the arts. He worked on his ground-breaking articles until the day he was admitted to the hospital. He had much to give & he will be dearly missed.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: EURO FALLS. The dollar gained against the euro after a report showed United States consumer confidence unexpectedly rose this month. In New York, the euro settled at 89.36 cents, down from 89.64 cents on Monday.

title: Advertising Veteran Is Named a Diplomat
description: President Bush intends to nominate Charlotte L. Beers, former chairwoman at J. Walter Thompson in New York, as under secretary of state for public diplomacy, the White House announced. Ms. Beers had been chairwoman at Thompson, part of the WPP Group, from March 1999 through the end of February, when her contract expired.

description: EUROPE

title: Long Odds for a Skater Out of Harlem
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  It is 7 degrees at the United States Olympic outdoor speedskating oval here. Just as the wind slices through the air and sends swirls of freshly fallen snow onto the ice, Jason Benta makes his move. He advances slowly at first, like a tiger eyeing his prey. But when his skates hit the black starting line, he explodes into a sprint.

title: Corrections
description: An inset map yesterday with an article about regional disputes in Chad misidentified the country's northwestern neighbor. It is Niger, not Nigeria.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the trial of three men accused of having sexually abused women last year at the National Puerto Rican Day Parade misstated the surname of the assistant district attorney who gave the summation. She is Maxine Rosenthal, not Silverstein.

title: Ad Intended to Stir Up Campuses More Than Succeeds in Its Mission
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 19  The editor of the student newspaper at Brown University says he knew a tempest was headed his way and rose to open the door for it.

title: Beijing Publishes Detailed Account of Bombings
description: In an attempt to quell fears and rumors about a series of explosions two weeks ago that killed more than 100 people, the Chinese government has published a detailed account of how it says one man -- arrested last week -- carried out the bombings.

title: Forest Service Chief Quits, And Asks Bush to Hold Firm
description: In a letter of resignation, the chief of the Forest Service urged the Bush administration today to ''withstand political pressure'' and leave in place rules that would bar road building across some 60 million acres of federally owned land.

title: Home Is Where The Party Is
description: FOR the moment, anyway -- while irrational exuberance feels like a distant memory and the prices in good restaurants are so high your meal ends with a punch to the gut -- it is probably time to recall an antidote to it all: home entertaining. Dinner parties where friends pitch in, where the food is good but not overworked and where the table is never turned.

title: Computer Associates Considers Severance for Some It Fired
description: Computer Associates is considering offering severance payments to some of the employees it fired two months ago, the company said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIANFORTONI, ELENORE
description: GIANFORTONI-Elenore, of Lake Worth, Fla., died March 23, 2001. She was born in the Bronx, February 22, 1912. For over 30 years she taught in N.Y.C. schools.

title: Indoor Lacrosse Team Coming to New Jersey
description: Professional indoor lacrosse is coming to the Meadowlands in December with a team owned by the former Nets center Jayson Williams.

title: Beijing Says Chinese-Born Scholar on Visit From U.S. Is a Spy
description: The Chinese government today accused a United States-based sociologist who has been held in isolation for more than six weeks of being a paid spy for ''overseas intelligence agencies.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCERBO, REVEREND JOHN A.
description: SCERBO-Reverend John A. Died on March 26, 2001 at the DeWitt Nursing Center. He was 71. Born and raised in Boonton, N.J. He attended Seton Hall University and Immaculate Conception Seminary. He was ordained to the priesthood for the Diocese of Paterson, N.J. in 1960. Father served as Assistant Pastor at several parishes in N.J. and retired from active service in 1973 due to illness. He moved to New York and was employed as Assistant Buyer for the Silver Department at Cartier's and as Office Manager for Bondanza Jewelers and Work Gallery. He is survived by his mother Michaelina Scerbo, brothers Alfonse W. and Frank J.; a sister Louise Carter, a devoted friend of William G. Smith and ten loving nieces and nephews and their families. A Memorial Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, March 31 at 11:30AM at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, Boonton, New Jersey. Interment will be private. Donations in Father's memory may be made to Covenant House.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VOLONTE, JOSEPH E.
description: VOLONTE-Joseph E. Of Madison, NJ, died, March 25, 2001. Husband of Joan Holmgren Volonte and of the late Eleanore Rheuby Volonte; father of Betty Miles, of Berkeley Heights, NJ and William J. of Hoboken, NJ. Career Naval Officer who fought in W.W. II. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St., Chatham, NJ. Thursday, March 29th, 6PM-8PM. Service at Grace Episcopal Church, 4 Madison Ave., Madison, NJ, Friday, March 30th, 11 AM. We love and miss you.

title: Gunmen Seize 9 Foreign Medics; Kill 8 Somalis
description: Six officials from the World Health Organization and Unicef and three representatives of Doctors Without Borders were taken hostage today by gunmen in Somalia, the United Nations spokesman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSENBERG, LOUIS
description: ROSENBERG-Louis, 95. Formerly of Bayside and Livingston Manor, New York, died Monday, March 26 in Boca Raton, FL. Photoengraver by profession, he enjoyed travel, adventure, fishing, photography, building and gardening. A fifty year resident of Bayside, he and his family were members of the Bayside Jewish Center. He spent seventy summers in his beloved Catskill Mountains. He is survived by his wife, Pauline, his brother, Ed Rogers, his daughter Helen, grandchildren Julia Cohen and Kenneth Applebaum, and greatgrandson, Adam Cohen. His was a life well lived and loved.

title: U.S. Vetoes Pro-Palestinian U.N. Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 28  The Bush administration cast its first veto in the Security Council late Tuesday night, ending a weeklong marathon debate and decisively scuttling Palestinian hopes for a United Nations observer force in the Israeli-occupied territories in the foreseeable future.

title: Lumber Dispute Threatens U.S.-Canada Trade Ties
description: With only days to go before an agreement limiting Canadian lumber exports to the United States expires, chances for quickly resolving one of the most contentious trade disputes between the United States and Canada have dimmed, and both sides are preparing for what could become a costly trade war.

title: March Survey Of Consumers Is Brighter
description: A crucial measure of consumer confidence rebounded sharply in March after falling for five consecutive months.

title: U.S. Court Bars Race as Factor In School Entry
description: A federal judge in Detroit ruled yesterday that the race-conscious admissions system of the University of Michigan's law school is unconstitutional, contradicting a December ruling in a parallel case that upheld the university's affirmative action policy for undergraduate admissions.

title: Fire Destroys Row Houses In the Bronx
description: A seven-alarm fire tore through a row of 18 wooden houses in the Bronx just before dawn yesterday, destroying at least 3 of them and leaving 27 adults and 23 children homeless, the Fire Department said.

title: Bush Names 2 to Panel Monitoring Energy Markets
description: President Bush named two new commissioners today to the federal agency that oversees electricity markets, a move that could lead to a shift in the agency's largely hands-off approach to California's power crisis.

title: A Torch Song by Miss Liberty? O.K.
description: ''Newyorkers'' is more of a cabaret act, really, than a theater piece; it calls itself ''a musical collage,'' perhaps to position itself somewhere in the middle. In any case, the show, which opened at the Manhattan Theater Club yesterday, is a themed spoof in which a handful of performers rotate appearances in brief, satirical skits, each set to a song with glib and usually prickly lyrics.

title: Soothsingers Look Ahead With Variety
description: The art song has become a rather self-conscious mode of expression in comparison with, say, the songs of Bruce Springsteen or Bob Dylan. Compounding this was the implicit tone of high seriousness in the assignment from the New York Festival of Song, which asked 20 composers to set texts that were somehow forward-looking to create a composite portrait of the music -- the classical music -- of the dawning century. The resulting ''Songbook for a New Century'' concert at the Kaye Playhouse on Thursday night presented 18 world premieres in a program that was, if not forward-looking, then certainly diverting for its sheer variety alone.

title: Political Peacekeeping in the Balkans
description: The Bush administration has made clear its desire for an early withdrawal of American peacekeeping troops from the Balkans. That is an understandable goal. But it cannot be achieved until sufficient stability has been brought to the region to allow the removal of outside military forces without risking a rapid return to armed conflict.

title: Supreme Court Debates Copyright Protection
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 -- The Supreme Court wrestled today with a narrow issue of copyright law that carries major implications for a world in which electronic databases rather than back copies and microfilm are quickly becoming the standard for archiving and researching newspapers and magazines.

title: Stride Rite Income Up
description: The Stride Rite Corporation, the maker of Keds and its namesake brand of children's shoes, said today that its earnings rose 4.4 percent in its most recent period, while sales fell slightly. Net income rose to $7.82 million, or 19 cents a share, in the company's first quarter, ended March 2, up from $7.49 million, or 17 cents, a year earlier. The company, based in Lexington, was expected to earn 18 cents by analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call. Sales fell to $151.1 million from $151.7 million. Sales of Sperry boat shoes fell 21 percent, while Keds sales fell 3 percent. Sales of children's shoes rose 11 percent. Stride-Rite shares rose 25 cents, to $7.40.

title: Too Afraid To Talk of Peace
description: A friend calls from New York. ''Where have all the peaceniks gone?'' he asks. It's Friday lunchtime, and I am making pasta for my daughters, who will soon be home from school. I am anxious. I hear a siren wailing in the distance, and I listen closely to hear if there are any others. More than one siren could mean that a car bomb has gone off or a bus has exploded.

title: Tribute to Teresa Sterne
description: A memorial tribute to Teresa Sterne, the pianist who became the director of the Nonesuch record label, will be held on Thursday at 4 p.m. at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway, at 95th Street. The memorial, which is free and open to the public, will include performances by the pianists Gilbert Kalish and William Bolcom, the sopranos Joan Morris and Lucy Shelton, and the New Jersey Percussion Ensemble.

title: Israel Hits Palestinian Targets, Retaliating for New Bombing
description: JERUSALEM, March 28 -- Israeli helicopter gun ships bombarded bases and training camps of Yasir Arafat's personal security forces tonight after a Palestinian suicide bombing this morning that killed two Israeli teen-agers in central Israel.

title: WILLIAMS SELLS CANADIAN UNIT
description: Canada's second-largest telecommunications company, the Telus Corporation of Burnaby, British Columbia, has bought the Canadian business service unit of Williams Communications of Tulsa, Okla. The price was not disclosed but analysts estimated it was less than $100 million. Williams Communications Canada, manager of 13,000 customer sites, mostly in central Canada, has 450 employees and annual revenue of $83 million. It was built on a division acquired from Nortel Networks in 1997, but industry sources said it had not grown as expected. Telus is trying to cut into Bell Canada's dominance in central Canada, and said the acquisition ''instantly provides a significant client base to grow our data, Internet and wireless services.'' Timothy Pritchard

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HALPERN, JOEL ALAN
description: HALPERN-Joel Alan. 20 years since your tragic, fatal accident. To live in our hearts and minds, as in those of your children and grandchildren you've never known is not to have died. We love you and miss you forever. Mother and Dad

description: Brasserie, With Cheese

title: Metro Business Briefing; GROUPS JOIN ON OTB BID
description: Churchill Downs Inc. has agreed to join the New York Racing Association and Television Games Network in their bid to buy New York City's Off-Track Betting Corporation, the company said yesterday. Churchill Downs said it would withdraw its separate bid for the 68 OTB parlors, which the city put up for sale in October. The nonprofit New York Racing Association and Television Games Network had been competing against Churchill Downs for the betting parlors.

title: House Passes Bush's Budget Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 28 -- President Bush's budget of nearly $2 trillion for 2002 cleared one obstacle this afternoon as the House of Representatives passed it by 222 to 205.

title: Mogilny Stars in Devils' Latest Victory
description: The new streak is two victories in a row for the Devils, who beat the Thrashers, 4-2, in Atlanta last night. And the goal total for Alexander Mogilny, who scored twice, is 39.

title: NATIONAL BRIEFING
description: WEST

title: With Focus on Playoffs, Devils Punish the Lightning
description: The Devils knew tonight that the Tampa Bay Lightning, out of contention for the playoffs but a winner in seven of its previous 11 games, would want to test the defending Stanley Cup champions.

title: A Wayans as a Father, Not a Brother
description: Damon Wayans has gotten middle-aged -- and that turns out to be not such a bad thing for him. This talented comedian, who made his mark 10 years ago on the irreverent sketch program ''In Living Color,'' is reappearing on television as the dad in a promising situation comedy modeled on ''The Bill Cosby Show.''

title: German Leader to Brief Bush on New Realities of Europe
description: BERLIN, March 28  A little more than a decade ago, George W. Bush's father played a decisive role in uniting Germany. On Thursday the President will come face to face with the consequences of that act as he meets a buoyant German Chancellor carrying firm, sometimes confrontational, messages from Europe.

description: The portable lockers had been removed, and the last one on the row in the distant corner of the clubhouse belonged to Mark Johnson. Seated at his stool last week, Johnson scanned the aisle.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday comparing Johnson & Johnson with a company it plans to buy -- the Alza Corporation, a maker of alternative ways of delivering medicine to the body -- referred incorrectly to Procrit, a drug for anemia. It is made by Johnson & Johnson, not Alza.

title: Brian Trubshaw, 77, Dies; Tested Concorde
description: Brian Trubshaw, a pilot who tested the British-French Concorde supersonic airliner and became its staunchest champion, died on March 24 at his home near Tetbury, in Gloucestershire, England. He was 77.

title: Positive Consumer Confidence Report Gives Shares a Lift
description: Stock prices climbed again yesterday after investors were heartened by an unexpectedly strong report on consumer confidence, raising some hopes that personal spending will revive the weakened economy.

title: Man Shot in Bronx Theater
description: A man was shot four times in a movie theater in Co-op City in the Bronx last night, the police said. Although the man was shot in the face and stomach, his injuries were not life-threatening, said officials at Jacobi Medical Center, where he was undergoing surgery.

title: At Lunch, Talk of Lieberman For President Is the Appetizer
description: As recently as this morning, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut scoffed at the idea that he would seek the Democratic presidential nomination in 2004 if Al Gore decided to run again, saying it would be ''very awkward.''

title: Metro Business Briefing; DINER TO GO
description: The managers of the Starrett-Lehigh Building, the huge former warehouse between 11th and 12th Avenues and 26th and 27th Streets in Manhattan, plan to open an upscale restaurant to replace a diner in the building that closed last week. The diner, the Starrett-Lehigh Coffee Shop, on the 26th Street side of the building, was offered an undisclosed amount of money to surrender its lease. Mark Karasick, a principal of 601 West Associates, the partnership that manages the building, whose tenants now include Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia and Hugo Boss, said several restaurants were looking at the space, and he hoped that one or two would open there within two months.

title: WEB CONSULTANT ANNOUNCES CUTBACKS
description: The Viant Corporation, which designs and maintains Web sites for businesses, said it would close its Houston, San Francisco and Munich offices and reduce its work force by 38 percent, or 211 employees. In addition to layoffs resulting from the office closings, jobs will also be cut in Viant's remaining offices, which are in New York, Boston, Chicago, Atlanta, Los Angeles and London. ''We're seeing an overall softening in the demand for our services,'' said Anna Svaldi, a spokeswoman for the company. Catherine Greenman

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  REICH, HY
description: REICH-Hy. Can it be 25 years? We love you still. We will love you always. Your Famil

title: Targeting the Status Quo
description: Ever since political parties learned in the 1980's how to circumvent the legal ban on corporate and union campaign contributions, organized special interests have been the central force of American political campaigns. In the 2000 election cycle, more than a third of reported campaign contributions came as "soft money" from a relatively small number of organized special interests. This group spent even more running so-called "issue ads" that happened to feature the images of their favorite candidates. This concentration of campaign finance is the evil that the McCain-Feingold reform bill seeks to cure.

description: To the Editor:

title: Nasdaq Falls 6 Percent as New Profit Woes Hit the Markets
description: Athree-day rally in the stock market ended today and many technology stocks gave back all they had gained after several new profit warnings reminded investors that a rejuvenation of corporate earnings remains uncertain.

title: Florida Has More Hispanics Than Blacks, Census Shows
description: Leading a shift in the ethnic and racial makeup of the country, Florida now has more Hispanic residents than blacks, 2000 census data released today show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, STEPHEN T. KLUTE
description: MURRAY-Stephen T. Klute, born September 14, 1981, beloved son of Dr. Virginia Klute Murray and brother of Thomas N. Klute Murray. Thank you to all of our friends & their families who have offered their love and support in this impossible time. Donations to either the Nature Conservancy or to your local youth support group in Stephen's name would be appreciated. Services will be held at St. Joseph's Church, Mendham, NJ, Saturday, March 31 at 12 noon.

title: A sales pitch tries to connect with fans as baseball season starts.
description: REMEMBER the advertising for Nynex that tried to sell telephone services by proclaiming ''We're all connected''? Major League Baseball is introducing a campaign that could well carry that theme as it seeks to strengthen ties with fans and build ties with nonfans who think the Tampa Bay Devil Rays and Florida Marlins might be menu items at Red Lobster.

title: Where You Can Have Your Steak and Take It Home, Too
description: TRAVELING along the main routes of Jackson Heights and Corona, Queens, is like taking a trip to the United Nations. Flags and cultures of disparate countries abound. While there are video stores and clothing shops, most of the storefronts are devoted to food. In a single block you can find a dozen different chilies in a Mexican grocery, an artist's palette of spices in an Indian market, and restaurants, endless restaurants.

title: Britain Reluctantly Considers Animal Vaccination
description: As Britain prepared to slaughter hundreds of thousands more healthy sheep that may have been exposed to foot-and-mouth disease, the government indicated today that it might reverse policy and use vaccination against the outbreak.

title: 'MALL' OPERATOR SETTLES CHARGES
description: Bigsmart.com, a company that promised substantial income for investors through an Internet shopping network, has agreed to settle charges that it operated an illegal pyramid scheme, the Federal Trade Commission said yesterday. The company must pay back $5 million to its customers, and post a $500,000 bond before engaging in other similar so-called multilevel marketing activity, F.T.C. officials said. Bigsmart of Mesa, Ariz., enabled investors to earn money from commissions on products purchased from Internet ''malls'' -- collections of links to retail Web sites. Shoppers were directed to the retail sites from personalized pages sold to Bigsmart customers for $100 apiece. But the arrangement, the F.T.C. said, was structured so that financial gains depended on continued, successive recruitment of other participants, and not simply on the sales of products and services. A spokeswoman for Bigsmart said the company was cooperating with federal regulators, although it had complied with state and federal laws; its Web site will continue to operate.

title: Article 2001032891841878151 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: INTEREST IN AUTO MAGAZINES
description: The British media group Emap said it had received several approaches from companies interested in buying Peterson Publishing, its United States magazine business. Peterson, which publishes Hot Rod and Motor Trend, has been hit by a slowdown in car-related advertising. Emap spent $1.2 billion to buy Peterson two years ago, but the acquisition has left the company weighted with debt. Analysts said the unit could now fetch about $700 million. Emap also said that it expected full-year results, which will be announced on May 29, to meet analysts' expectations. Suzanne Kapner

title: Seoul Is Cool To EU Move
description: SEOUL  South Korea's new foreign minister distanced his government Tuesday from a plan by European Union leaders to revive the stalled process of reconciliation between North and South Korea.

title: Senate Democrats Ask $300 Rebate for Taxpayers, and Further $150 Cut for Most
description: Seeking a political edge on the question of tax cuts, Democrats introduced legislation in the Senate today that would give all taxpayers a $300 rebate check this year and give most of them an additional $150 by withholding less money from their paychecks in the second half of the year.

title: Arizona's Timid Mystery in the Middle
description: Loren Woods steadied his beanpole body at the free-throw line, lifted the basketball above his shoulders, then heard a chant from the Illinois fans at the Alamodome in San Antonio on Sunday. ''C-B-A! C-B-A!'' The fans were offering the University of Arizona center a message about his future in the National Basketball Association by reminding him of the initials for the defunct Continental Basketball Association.

title: New Star Fills the Balcony, Doin' What Comes Natur'lly; A Familiar Face Can Rejuvenate a Musical
description: Last fall, when Cheryl Ladd was performing in the title role, ''Annie Get Your Gun'' appeared to be on death row.

title: American Rebuffs Pilots' T.W.A. Terms
description: American Airlines rejected demands from its pilots union today to provide pay and pension improvements and job protection as the carrier buys Trans World Airlines and integrates T.W.A. employees.

title: Effort Is Urged to Keep Women From Smoking
description: Warning that tobacco-related diseases are still a major cause of illness and death among women, a new report by the surgeon general is calling for stronger measures nationwide to discourage women and girls from smoking and to curb tobacco industry advertising and promotion.

title: Article 2001032893036842145 -- No Title
description: March 28, 2001

title: Health Care Lobby Leads List Of the Big Spenders in Albany
description: Special-interest groups poured more than $66.3 million into efforts to influence state legislation last year, and the biggest spenders were connected to the health care industry, according to a yearly report released today by the state lobbying commission.

title: 2 Members of Police Review Panel Criticize Plan for Expanded Power
description: Two members of the independent agency that investigates complaints of police abuse in the city yesterday sharply criticized the way the Giuliani administration planned to expand the agency's powers, saying that it would undermine the panel's credibility and independence.

title: New Questions On Nominee For Treasurer
description: Even as lawmakers here wrestle with accusations that Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's nominee for state treasurer, Isabel Miranda, was fired from a job at Citibank and accused of misusing an expense account for personal trips, Ms. Miranda's continued ties to her most recent employer have become the subject of growing scrutiny.

title: Arabs, Split on Iraq and Kuwait, Still Join to Attack Israel
description: Arab leaders repeatedly expressed support today for the Palestinian rebellion against Israeli rule, sometimes using the issue to camouflage a deep Iraqi-Kuwaiti rift that is blocking any joint effort to lift United Nations sanctions against Iraq.

title: BID FOR SIDEL
description: The French packaging equipment maker Sidel agreed today to a 1.7 billion euro ($1.52 billion) takeover by Tetra Laval, a private Swedish group that owns the packaging company Tetra Pak and the industrial group Alfa Laval. Sidel has attracted interest because of its new bottle-making technology but needs help to turn around its financial situation. Trading in Sidel's shares was suspended by the Paris bourse on Friday as talks between the two companies were under way. Tetra Laval had already acquired 9.75 percent of the company from the management. The company offered 50 euros ($44.82) a share, representing a 21 percent premium over the stock's recent price. Petra Kappl

title: Seafood Custard via Japan
description: A DISH I discovered in Japan reminded me how undervalued custards are. They're fine as desserts, but if you leave out the sugar and dairy, they make luxurious appetizers or light main courses. If you bypass the usual slow baking in a heated oven and do it on top of the stove, custards are even easier.

title: Reckonings; The Hostage Economy
description: George W. Bush's tax cut plan has never been distinctive for its content, which is standard-issue conservatism -- big tax cuts for the rich, a few crumbs for middle-class families with children the right age, nothing for the poor. What is distinctive is the way the plan has been sold. I can't think of any precedent in the history of American economic policy. Has any previous administration been quite this shameless about misrepresenting the actual content of its own economic plan?

title: RECORD RATE HIKE SET IN CALIFORNIA
description: California's power regulators approved the largest utility rate increases in state history today in an effort to avert more rolling blackouts and keep the state's principal electricity producers from collapsing in bankruptcy.

title: Giuliani Calls for Tightening Controls on Electricity Rates
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani called yesterday for the temporary imposition of more stringent price controls on wholesale electric power rates in New York State, saying that with last summer's surge in prices and the discomforting shortage of extra power supplies in the city, government intervention is needed.

title: Miami's Chief Rival Extends Best Wishes
description: There was genuine joy and concern but no surprise tonight in the Knicks' locker room. They expected Alonzo Mourning to return to play for the Miami Heat this season.

title: The Boss: I'm a Coffee Doctor
description: When I can't get a good cup of coffee (there are still some places in the United States and Germany where coffee is horrible), I drink Coca-Cola . People can be self- conscious when they're making coffee for me. Some people in the company are very careful because they know I can tell the quality from the color of the foam.

title: ROYAL AHOLD WILL SPEND $2 BILLION ON U.S. ACQUISITIONS
description: Royal Ahold N.V. will spend about $2 billion in the coming five years buying United States food distributors to reach its goal of a 15 percent market share within 10 years, Jim Miller, head of the company's United States Foodservice unit, said yesterday. The company, which is based in the Netherlands, spent $4.7 billion for U.S. Foodservice and PYA/Monarch last year to gain 7 percent. Food distribution is growing at twice the pace of supermarket sales in the United States, with the industry expected to grow to $220 billion by 2007 from $163 billion last year.

title: The President on the Economy
description: President Bush took to the road yesterday to assert his authority as the nation's economic helmsman and plug for Congressional passage of his unaffordable and regressive 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut proposal. ''It's the president's job to look for warnings of economic trouble ahead and to heed them, and to act,'' he told Michigan businessmen. ''I got elected because the people want the president to act, and that's exactly what I'm going to do.'' But of course he cannot award tax cuts unilaterally, and the political motivation for his foray into the hinterlands was to generate pressure on Congress to support a tax cut of the size, duration and distribution that he has proposed.

title: OPEL CHAIRMAN IS NAMED

His appointment has been rumored since January, when Mr. Hendry said he would resign by the end of March because of Opel's heavy losses in 2000. title: Scuba Diving in Grenada
