The hotel's seven-night dive package offers accommodations in a one-bedroom suite, five dives with Spice Island Diving, dive-equipment rental, greens fees at the nine-hole Grenada Golf Club, non-motorized water sports and one dinner. Through April 15, the price is $655 a person, based on double occupancy; after that, it's $478 through Dec. 15. Dive sites include the Bianca C cruise ship wreck; Isle de Ronde, a group of small volcanic islands; and the five-mile Boss Reef. Blue Horizons Cottage Hotel has 32 rooms set amid six acres of gardens. Information: (473) 444-4316; www.bluegrenada.com .

description: Revlon Inc., the cosmetics company controlled by the financier Ronald O. Judge Sidney Stein of United States District Court ruled on Monday that the plaintiffs' filing was adequate to pursue their fraud claim. He refused to dismiss the suit as Revlon had asked. Shareholders contend that Mr. Perelman and other executives overstated the New York company's financial results so they could refinance company debt incurred when Mr. Perelman gained control of Revlon in a 1986 leveraged buyout.

title: Targeting the Status Quo
description: Ever since political parties learned in the 1980's how to circumvent the legal ban on corporate and union campaign contributions, organized special interests have been the central force of American political campaigns. In the 2000 election cycle, more than a third of reported campaign contributions came as ''soft money'' from a relatively small number of organized special interests. This group spent even more running so-called ''issue ads'' that happened to feature the images of their favorite candidates. This concentration of campaign finance is the evil that the McCain-Feingold reform bill seeks to cure.

title: People
description: * Scott Lerman was named president at Enterprise IG, the brand and corporate identity consulting unit of the WPP Group, with primary responsibility for the New York office. He takes on duties that had been handled by Ron Cappello, who is being promoted to the new position of worldwide president, as well as assuming added duties for overseeing the Americas operations of Enterprise IG. Mr. Lerman had most recently been president at Siegelgale, New York.

title: Liberties; W. and John: A Love Story?
description: At 8 a.m. yesterday morning, John McCain was in his office, drinking multiple cups of coffee, giving multiple interviews to the media, and plotting multiple chess moves to keep the president, the ruthless Republican Sopranos in Congress, his two-timing best friend in the Senate, Chuck Hagel, and two-faced Democrats from crippling his quest to curtail legal bribery in politics.

title: TELENOR BUYING LOCKHEED UNIT
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation, moving to cut costs, said it had agreed to sell its Comsat Mobile Communications unit to Telenor of Norway for $116.5 million. Comsat Mobile, with annual revenue of more than $100 million, provides maritime, land and air communications services through its Inmarsat satellite network. The division of Lockheed Martin Global Telecommunications also operates two earth stations in Southbury, Conn., and Santa Paula, Calif. Telenor said linking the two stations with its existing earth station in Eik, Norway, would enable it to broaden its global satellite mobile communication services. Telenor owns 15 percent of Inmarsat, and is the satellite concern's largest shareholder.

title: Japanese-American Gloom on Canvas, Circa '42
description: Several months after the attack on Pearl Harbor, Henry Sugimoto, his wife and their 6-year-old daughter were interned with other Japanese-Americans in California and sent to an assembly center in Fresno. Mr. Sugimoto had been a rising artist, trained in France and known as a painter of the placid fields and lush landscapes of rural California. Almost as soon as he was interned he began sketching somber portraits of the Japanese-American families devastated by government policy.

title: Tastings: Pinot Noir, the Riddler
description: NO matter how you approach it, pinot noir is maddening. It gives growers fits because it is so difficult to maintain in the vineyard. Its inconsistency frustrates even the most experienced winemakers, while in the glass, it is a regular Lon Chaney, a wine of a thousand faces, alternately soft and seductive, then tightening into reticence before blooming again. It may be a simple fruity delight, or it may deepen into profundity, testing the vocabulary of wine writers, who grapple with similes and metaphors before smashing their glasses and retreating to, well, "maddening."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, ALAN G.
description: RUDOLPH-Alan G., died on March 24 at age 83. Urban planner, businessman, equestrian. Born in New York City on August 6, 1917, he was the son of Solomon S. and Helen Goldsmith Rudolph. He was a graduate of the Fieldston School, the University of Pennsylvania and Pratt Institute, where he received a Masters of Planning. He was an executive at Goldsmith Brothers Stationers, a business founded by his uncles. He later worked as an administrator at Pratt Institute, as a housing advocate at United Neighborhood Houses and owned the Hunt Valley Farm in Staatsburg, NY. He was the former Chairman of the Board of the University Settlement, where he served for nearly 40 years. He was the husband of Nancy Peirce Rudolph of Clinton Corners, NY; father of Lucy Rudolph of Oakland, CA, and John Rudolph of South Berwick, ME; stepfather of Dorothy Anne Driscoll, Darien, CT, Mary Ellen Schwartz, Forest Grove, OR, and John H. Driscoll, Jr., S. Glastonbury, CT; grandfather of Maya and Emma Rudolph and Isaac Lomprey. A memorial service will be held on April 1, 2001 at 1PM at his home in Clinton Corners, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the University Settlement, 184 Eldridge St, NY, NY 10002. Funeral being handled by Allen Funeral Home, 1605 Main St, Pleasant Valley, New York.

title: Providing Privacy, Prettily

title: DUTCH COMPANY BUYS AMEX SPECIALIST AND MARKET MAKER
description: Van der Moolen Holding, a market specialist on the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy 51 percent of Cohen, Duffy, McGowan & Company to expand its options-trading business in the United States. The purchase is Van der Moolen's second this month. No financial details were given. Cohen, Duffy, McGowan is a market specialist and market maker on the American Stock Exchange in New York, where it has a market share of about 12 percent of options contracts traded. The company had revenue last year of $85 million. The purchase is Van der Moolen's seventh in the United States since 1998. Two weeks ago, it agreed to buy the Big Board specialist Scavone, McKenna, Cloud & Company for $60 million.

title: Metro Business Briefing
description: PENALTIES WAIVED The New York State Public Service Commission voted yesterday to waive $25.8 million in potential penalties that Verizon Communications faced for service failures in August and September. Verizon had requested the waivers, saying that an 18-day labor strike in August and the backlogs it caused had been responsible for the company's inability to meet the commission's standards for repairs, installations and other activities in those months. Under the commission's regulatory system, penalties, returned to customers as rebates, are imposed if Verizon does not meet various monthly, quarterly and annual performance requirements, though the penalties may be waived when the company shows that the shortfalls resulted from circumstances beyond its control. The commission denied additional waiver requests that Verizon had requested for reasons other than the strike. Verizon's penalties for the regulatory year ended Aug. 31 now total at least $17.6 million, much more than the total in each of the three previous regulatory years.

title: Before Talks, Macedonia Tries to Keep Albanian Rebels in Check

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBAUM, SHELDON B., MS, PH.D.
description: GREENBAUM-Sheldon B., MS, Ph.D. Died of lung cancer March 25th at Hospice by the Sea, Delray Beach, FL. Beloved husband (53 yrs) of Claire, devoted father of Mark, Douglas (Lisa), Ron, and grandfather of Adam, Joshua, Todd, loving brother of Lowell (Gloria). Born Brooklyn, NY April 15, 1923, to Belle and Benjamin, BS, City College of New York, MS, University of Tennessee, and Ph.D University of Maryland, organic chemistry. Academic affiliations include Departments of Pharmacology, Western Reserve and Yale Universities. He was a pioneer in the synthesis of anti-cancer drugs which were forerunners of drugs in use today. 1956-66, Principal Investigator, Hooker Chemical Corp., 1967-82, Director of Organic Research, Nutrition and Animal Health and Manager Bioscience technology, Diamond Shamrock Corporation. Following his retirement, lecturer at Baldwin Wallace College, author of Dynamics of the U.S. Chemical Industry, holder of 31 patents. Member of the American Chemical Society for 53 years. He was an innovative and gentle person who moved young people toward his love of science. Above all was his love for his family. Suggested contributions to Hospice by the Sea, Boca Raton, FL, or your local American Cancer Society.

title: Scottsboro 70 Years Later, Still Notorious, Still Painful

Roy, who had never been away from home, was accompanied by his brother Andy, 19. Olen Montgomery, 18, almost blind, hoped to buy glasses with the wages he would find. The oldest, Charlie Weems, was 19. The boys were dirt poor and mostly illiterate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DE LESSEPS, TAUNI
description: de LESSEPS-Tauni, 86, SculptorPainter. A resident of Palm Beach, Florida, a well-known international artist, died Saturday, March 24, 2001, at Palm Beach Gardens Medical Center, Palm Beach Gardens, Florida. A Paris-born Countess, Tauni de Lesseps, was the granddaughter of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the famous engineer and designer of the Suez and Panama canals. She was the daughter of the late Jacques de Lesseps, a much decorated French aviator & war hero and Grace Mackenzie de Lesseps. Her sculpture and paintings cover a wide field, both in subject matter and media, and appear in many distinguished collections, embassies, banks, firms, museums and private clubs around the world. She conducted many ''one-man'' shows of her work in the best galleries of New York, Florida, Rome, Florence, Vienna and Old San Juan, Puerto Rico in the 1960's and 1970's. She has three bronzes in the White House and her work is included in the collection of the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, D.C. She is included in the Dictionary of International Biography and Who's Who in American Art. Countess de Lesseps was invested as Dame of Justice of the Order of the Knights of Malta for her work as a cofounder of the original clinic for rehabilitation of the disfigured in New York. She was a consultant to the National Art Museum of Sport and was honored as a Presidential Councillor of Cornell University. She was a member of the River Club in New York, the Everglades Club in Palm Beach, Florida, the Round Hill Club and Indian Harbor Yacht Club in Greenwich. She is survived by Lt. General Fletcher C. Booker, of Palm Beach and Tequesta, Florida, one son Michael de Lesseps, of South Freeport, Maine, one sister, Ki Ki Hicks, of Vancouver, Canada, two grandsons and two stepdaughters. A memorial service in Palm Beach, Florida will be scheduled at a later date. Donations may be made in her memory to the Alpha Omega Charitable Foundation, Inc., a nonprofit Florida corporation to benefit her favorite charities and projects, P.O. Box 3475, West Palm Beach, Florida 33402-3475.

title: Flat-Panel Monitor Takes Up Less Desk and Wallet Space
description: Undisputably cool-looking and decidedly tech-forward, flat-panel monitors have been around for years. But for most computer users a flat-panel display, which costs more than three times as much as a conventional monitor, has been a luxury item either hard to justify or just plain hard to afford. Now, Samsung Electronics America has a 15-inch, flat-panel monitor that costs $499 after a $50 rebate good through June. The new monitor, called the SyncMaster 570vTFT, requires a third of the space and less than a third of the electricity of a cathode-ray tube monitor. Samsung promises a crisp 0.297-dot pitch and a maximum resolution of 1024 by 768 pixels at 75 Hz. The monitor is plug-and-play, so it requires no configuration by the user. MICHEL MARRIOTT

The unit has about 5,600 employees. The failure of satellite-telephone companies like Iridium has resulted in less demand for satellites and launching services. Funeral services will be held at 10AM, Friday, March 30, at the funeral home, and the Reverend Jerry Bricker will officiate. Interment will be in the Orange County Veterans Cemetery in Goshen. description: Inspired by the successful unionization of New York University's graduate students, graduate students at Columbia University yesterday petitioned the National Labor Relations Board for permission to form their own union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'SULLIVAN, KIERAN HARFORD DANIEL
description: O'SULLIVAN-Kieran Harford Daniel, 72. Died March 23, 2001, in Kingston, NY. Xavier H.S. '47, Fordham '51, US Army, Fordham Law '56. Father of Marie, Donal (deceased), Doreen, Denis, Anne, Kathleen Pittman, Kieran, Sean and Christopher. Mass 10:15 AM, March 31, 2001, St. Joan of Arc Church, Jackson Heights, NY.

title: HOUSE COMMITTEE ACTS ON SPAM
description: The House Energy and Commerce Committee moved yesterday to curb unsolicited e-mail, known as spam, passing a bill that would require such commercial electronic messages to include valid return addresses so that recipients can easily request that their names be removed from the mailing lists. The bill would authorize the Federal Trade Commission to take action against senders of spam, and it would allow Internet service providers to sue in federal court for $500 a message, up to $50,000, if a person or company violated the law. The measure's sponsor, the Heather A. Wilson, a New Mexico Republican, said: ''Consumers should have the same power to stop junk e-mail from invading their home as they do with junk mail, telemarketing and junk faxes.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, RUTH N.
description: PRICE-Ruth N. On March 28, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Harry Price, loving mother of the late Fred Price. Services Friday 10am at ''The Riverside'' 76th St and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions in her memory may be made to U.J.A.-Federation, c/o Planned Giving & Endowments, 130 East 59th St, NY, NY 10022.

title: A short film during Women's History Month pays tribute to the leaders in the industry.
description: WOMEN'S History Month is normally associated with icons of the women's rights movement like Susan B. Anthony and Betty Friedan. But yesterday, the Advertising Women of New York held its first program to mark the month's celebration by honoring the experiences and contributions of women in advertising and marketing.

title: Ad Intended to Stir Up Campuses More Than Succeeds in Its Mission
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 19  The editor of the student newspaper at Brown University says he knew a tempest was headed his way and rose to open the door for it.

title: Defendant in Airline Rage Case Says He Acted in Self-Defense
description: NEWARK, March 29  An airline passenger accused of breaking the neck of a ticket agent testified today that he and the agent fell to the ground together after the agent pushed his wife, grabbed him by the neck and appeared ready to punch him with his fist.

title: Harold Nicholas Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to the tap dancer Harold Nicholas will be held tonight at 7 at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights. Mr. Nicholas, who appeared with his brother, Fayard, as the Nicholas Brothers in film and stage musicals, died on July 3. Among those scheduled to appear at the tribute, which is free and open to the public, are Fayard Nicholas, Max Roach, Annie Ross, Savion Glover, the Jazz Tap Ensemble and Jimmy Slyde. Information: (212) 316-3483.

title: With U.S. Pulling Back, North Korea Opens Up to Other Nations
description: With the Bush administration signaling a go-slow approach toward North Korea, that country has pushed its diplomacy into high gear in recent weeks, establishing ties with a wide variety of countries.

title: Knicks' Wild West Trip Has Just Begun
description: There is no predicting what the final three games of the Knicks' West Coast trip hold, but it will be difficult for anything to come as a shock. After what has occurred thus far, Mark Jackson soaring for the game-winning dunk over Shaquille O'Neal on Sunday in Los Angeles would barely raise an eyebrow.

title: The Most Private Spot Primps for Its Public
description: THE bathroom was once a place where people brushed their teeth, scrubbed their bodies and visited what Elsie de Wolfe coyly called the unmentionable (she hid it under flip-seat Louis XVI-style chairs). The room was small, 35 square feet, and designed for hygiene. But over the last decade, Americans have been transforming their water closets into the ultimate personal refuge, one decorated as carefully as any other room in the house -- and sometimes incorporating the same costly designer elements.

title: Bathroom Floor as Pebbled Beach
description: Inspired by Japanese stone arrangements and pebbles on the beach, the industrial designer Brett Stern covered the floor of this bathroom, left, with 2,500 glass marbles. The marbles, called sparklet gems, are generally used in flower vases, but their shape -- flat on one side, domed on the other -- works well for bathroom floors, walls, even sink pedestals. ''My work tends to be obsessive-compulsive,'' Mr. Stern said. ''I like patterns of repetitive details.'' He has used as many as 100,000 marbles in a grottolike bathroom. The marbles are available in many colors and in clear, frosted or iridescent, at $85 a square foot and up, including materials; (212) 696-9696. DONNA PAUL

title: The Graphic Designer's Budget Backsplash: 50 Square Feet, $2,700
description: TO get the most for his money (a mere $2,700) Paul Prejza, a graphic designer who lives in Hollywood Hills, Calif., put tile in his powder room where it was most needed aesthetically and functionally -- around the sink, left. He installed a checkerboard of dark green and white four-inch squares. Then, he added a bright red faucet and knobs as a playful splash of color. Deborah Sussman, his wife and partner at Sussman/Prejza, a graphic design firm, said she would have tiled the whole room. ''But it's his house,'' she said. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Spring Look: Thin Dresses And Blue Lips
description: Shivering on the shady side of the street outside Columbia University, Tanya Henry was protesting the spring that hadn't sprung, as if underdressing and thinking warm thoughts would hasten the season's slow arrival.

title: Bcom3 Postpones Initial Public Offering
description: In another sign of the effect of the slowing economy on Madison Avenue, the Bcom3 Group, the privately held agency company that owns shops like Leo Burnett Worldwide, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and Starcom MediaVest, said yesterday that its board had decided against an initial public offering this year.

title: A Country's Priorities
description: To the Editor:

title: Misjudgments by an Acting Governor
description: As the replacement for New Jersey's former governor, Christie Whitman, who joined the Bush administration two months ago, Donald DiFrancesco has rocketed from the relative obscurity of the New Jersey Legislature to political prominence. The question is whether he is ready for it. After Mr. DiFrancesco, the State Senate president, took on the high-profile job of acting governor in addition to his Senate duties, several lapses in judgment have been brought to light. These include two questionable financial transactions in which he participated and a mystifying blindness to the ethical missteps of his initial nominee for state treasurer.

title: Studying the Mind of the Teenus Horribilis
description: TO paraphrase F. Scott Fitzgerald, the young are not like you and me. Evidence: The other day, I found an orange light bulb in my daughter's bedroom.

title: Well-Oiled Party Machine Is Squeaking in Queens; Roiled by Term Limits and Ethnic Shifts
description: Another political fund-raiser took place Monday night at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan, this one for the Special Friends of Queens, whose fondness for the borough does not necessarily extend to visiting it. The bar was stocked, the ravioli stuffed and the pianist in the corner played ''Someday My Prince Will Come.''

title: Care to Try The Special? It's Beefcake
description: Ailey II, the junior ensemble of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, can always be counted on for eloquent dancing and the unself-consciously innovative programming of its longtime director, Sylvia Waters. The program presented by the company on Saturday afternoon at Aaron Davis Hall was no exception.

title: People
description: * Paran Johar was named general manager at the new Los Angeles office of Tribal DDB Worldwide, part of the DDB Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group. He had been managing director at the Los Angeles operations of Groundswell International.

title: Fix for a Foundation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ARMSTRONG, BOBBIE
description: ARMSTRONG-Bobbie. Me and the boys miss you. Diana

title: In Popular Vote, A White Room Cleans Up
description: A few weeks ago, NBC's ''Today'' show asked viewers how they would decorate a bathroom and got a surprising answer. A 120-square-foot master bathroom was part of a series in which the audience chooses the dcor for a house, bottom, being built over 12 weeks in Tampa, Fla. Some 120,000 people voted on four bathroom looks, three of which had colorful stone floors. The winner, with 38 percent of the votes, was called Cozumel: cultured -- that is, fake -- white marble counter tops, white fixtures, white shower surrounds and white ceramic floor tiles. (The show's host, Lou Manfredini, thinks that viewers thought stone floors would be hard to clean.)

title: Radar at Kennedy Airport Delayed, This Time by Wind
description: An on-again, off-again project to install a radar to protect planes landing at Kennedy Airport from wind shear is off again, at least temporarily.

title: For the Holidays, a Change of Settings
description: IT is time to check the china cabinet again. Passover and Easter are only a few weeks away. This year there are Seder plates without the traditional symbols and table settings that won't break the bank.

title: AIDS Obstacles Overwhelm A Small South African Town
description: The notice hangs on a drab wall in a remote clinic here, a symbol of this country's bold aspirations. It reads, ''AIDS treatment available here on request from the doctor.''

title: Man Accused of Killing New York Obstetrician Is Arrested
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The prime suspect in the killing of Dr. Barnett Slepian, a Buffalo-area obstetrician who performed abortions, in a sniper attack in 1998 was arrested today in France, authorities said.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER FALLS. Copper dropped on expectations of a prolonged slowdown in demand from United States manufacturers. In New York, copper for May delivery fell 1.9 cents, or 2.4 percent, to 77.3 cents a pound.

title: When Artificial Bids Hide The Only Winning Defense
description: Two major titles were decided on Sunday night at the end of the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals in Kansas City, Mo. Lynn Baker of Austin, Tex., won the women's teams with support from five players who had won world titles: Irina Levitina of Fair Lawn, N.J.; Karen McCallum of Exeter, N.H.; Kerri Sanborn of Stony Point, N.Y.; Jill Meyers of Santa Monica, Calif.; and Randi Montin of Napa, Calif. Second were five players from Manhattan: Gail Greenberg, Laurie Vogel, Lynne Tarnopol, Amalya Kearse and Jacqui Mitchell.

title: Firm Pays $240 Million For 9.8% Stake in Nasdaq
description: The Nasdaq stock market, in another step to bring in outside investors, announced a $240 million investment yesterday by a private equity firm in San Francisco, Hellman & Friedman.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a picture caption in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about efforts by Siemens of Germany to become better known in the United States misstated the company's financial results. The $16.2 billion figure represented revenue from American operations last year, not profit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Firm Invests $240 Million For Stake in Nasdaq Market

title: A Strong Vote Against Soft Money
description: There were harrowing moments yesterday when the fractious bipartisan coalition of senators supporting the McCain-Feingold campaign reform bill seemed in danger of blowing apart. Then in a dramatic turnaround, a compromise was reached raising regular campaign donation limits in the bill and swiftly approved by a lopsided vote of 84 to 16. It was nothing less than a historic vote for cleaning up the American election system. The higher contribution limits are less than ideal but modest and far better than the current system. We urge all supporters of campaign reform to protect the bill from being nullified if any part of it is deemed unconstitutional and to vote for its final passage. Rarely has there been the kind of day that unfolded in the Senate yesterday. The arguments were impassioned because the senators were really talking about dismantling a discredited system of campaign finance and moving to something new, unknown and healthy.

title: UN Rights Panel Assails Israel on 'Excessive Force'
description: GENEVA  Israeli security forces have used "excessive and disproportionate force" to quell Palestinian violence, a special inquiry team told the United Nations Human Rights Commission on Wednesday.

title: Aspen Festival Chief to Head Carnegie Hall
description: Robert J. Harth, the son of two concert violinists and the longtime chief executive of the Aspen Music Festival and School in Colorado, was chosen yesterday to head Carnegie Hall, which weathered a turbulent period under its outgoing leadership.

title: Juggling Pregnancy, Jitters, Soap Career and Regis
description: MIDWAY through her first pregnancy, Kelly Ripa, then recognizable to soap opera fans as ''All My Children's'' oft-victimized Hayley Vaughan (damaged goods! always bawling!) and currently enjoying heightened celebrity as Regis Philbin's vivacious new co-host (sole survivor of a grueling 67-contestant star search!), was out strolling, bloated but not freakishly so, when a passer-by zoomed in for an unsolicited Upper West Side eyewitness critique. Ms. Ripa always did project an aura of vulnerability (back in Berlin, N.J., she was the classmate everybody teased ''mercilessly'').

title: Alberto Salinas Jr., Juanita Garza and Hilaria Garza, Edinburg, Tex., Nov. 20, 2000
description: Alberto Salinas Jr.: "I am a spiritual healer. I pray over people that need cleansing. The lady and her sister came to me for healing, for help. As it turns out, she was demon-possessed. In the picture, I was performing an exorcism. I placed my hands on her head and started praying -- and she tried to get away and struggled. The demon in her became enraged and yelled for me to stop. In those moments, I experience no fear at all. I am completely focused on my work. Nothing else comes into my mind, heart, soul. Nothing. But it's a horrible situation for those who are present. It's a fight, struggle and battle outright. It drains me totally. I am worn out completely. But we succeeded." -->

title: You Have to Face Reality. It's on Every Channel.
description: Remember when it meant something to be a survivor? Now it means everything -- and nothing.

title: In High-Level Shake-Up, Putin Replaces Russia's Defense, Interior and Nuclear Energy Chiefs
description: President Vladimir V. Putin replaced his defense and interior ministers today and dismissed the country's atomic energy chief in the most extensive set of personnel changes in his year-old government.

title: Long Odds for a Skater Out of Harlem
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  It is 7 degrees at the United States Olympic outdoor speedskating oval here. Just as the wind slices through the air and sends swirls of freshly fallen snow onto the ice, Jason Benta makes his move. He advances slowly at first, like a tiger eyeing his prey. But when his skates hit the black starting line, he explodes into a sprint.

title: The Serbs' Choice
description: In the past several months, it has become apparent that the removal of Slobodan Milosevic has led to a willingness to tolerate both Belgrade's marked reluctance to cooperate with the Hague war crimes tribunal and the Serbs' refusal to confront the conduct of Mr. Milosevic's regime. I was among those who welcomed the overthrow of Mr. Milosevic, but I warned then, and I repeat today, that it is not enough that he is out of power. His policy of a Greater Serbia must go, too.

title: Bush Calls for End to Mideast Bloodshed
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  President Bush called on both sides today to end the bloodshed in the Middle East and said the United States stands ready to help achieve a peace. But he reiterated his stance that America cannot impose peace conditions on the region.

title: More Flights Are Canceled By Comair
description: Comair, the commuter carrier of Delta Air Lines, canceled its entire flight schedule through 9 a.m. on April 5 yesterday and said it would call off flights week by week until a contract is reached with its pilots, who are on strike.

title: Maude Rutherford, 104, Dies; High-Kicking Songster of 20's
description: Maude Russell Rutherford, a singer and dancer in the glory days of black theater in the 1920's who always said she was the one who really introduced the Charleston on Broadway, died on March 8 at her home in Atlantic City. She is believed to have been 104.

title: Chirac Refuses to Comply With Summons in Corruption Inquiry
description: President Jacques Chirac angrily rejected a summons today to give evidence in a corruption investigation, calling the request unconstitutional.

title: Man Accused of Killing New York Obstetrician Is Arrested
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The prime suspect in the killing of Dr. Barnett Slepian, a Buffalo-area obstetrician who performed abortions, in a sniper attack in 1998 was arrested today in France, authorities said.

title: Nominee Quits Treasurer Post In New Jersey
description: Five days after taking office as New Jersey's acting state treasurer, Isabel Miranda abruptly resigned today and removed her name from consideration as Acting Gov. Donald T. DiFrancesco's permanent choice for the post.

title: Trade Issues Will Dominate Bush Meeting With Brazilian
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil, March 29  With Brazil and the United States at odds as always on trade issues but increasingly driven together by growing political instability in South America, President Bush and his Brazilian counterpart will meet for the first time in Washington on Friday.

title: Administration Is Set To Back Yugoslavia
description: The Bush administration is prepared to certify that Yugoslavia is cooperating with the war crimes tribunal at The Hague, administration officials said yesterday. That would allow American aid to resume.

description: STRACHSTEIN-Harriet, Dr. A psychologist who practiced in New York City for many years, on March 28, 2001. Beloved mother of Marjorie Miller of Scarsdale, NY and the late Judith Davis. Loving grandmother of five and great grandmother of four. A graveside service will be held on Thursday at 2:30 P.M. at the Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, N.Y. Zion Memorial Chapel 914-381-1809 www.zionmemorialchapel.com

description: Instant replay received a three-year renewal and some player headgear -- specifically bandannas and stocking caps worn under helmets -- was banned by the National Football League owners here today as they completed their annual meeting.

title: While Senate Debates, It's Fund-Raising as Usual
description: The names of the 1,000 people on the guest list for tonight's huge political dinner were a secret. So were the identities of the large corporations and organizations that employ them. The party organizers refused to say how much money the wealthier guests had donated in exchange for their tickets.

title: GERMAN GAS STATIONS SOLD
description: Germany's biggest power company, RWE, said it would spin off its chain of gasoline stations and refineries in Germany to a new joint venture with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group. The new company will own 24 percent of the gasoline stations in Germany and be the biggest operator in the country. The deal appears to set the stage for RWE to leave the gasoline business and focus on its central business of generating and distributing electrical power. It also allows Shell to strengthen both its refining capacity and its retail sales network. Edmund L. Andrews

title: New Music Player Can Sing, But It's a Rare Bird
description: Extreme is the right word for Sonicblue's Rio 800 Extreme, which is, for the moment, the longest-playing MP3 player based on chip memory on the market. It has extremely large memory and an extremely large price, and it may become extremely difficult to get.

title: John Clarke Saunders, 82, Physician and Clinical Pharmacologist
description: Dr. John Clarke Saunders, a physician and clinical pharmacologist who won recognition in court for innovative use of biochemical drugs on chronic psychiatric patients, died Saturday at the New York Weill Cornell Medical Center. He was 82 and lived in Upper Nyack, N.Y.

title: A Severe Case of Sticky Fingers (and Tunnel Vision)
description: ''Black people need therapy, too,'' says Aunt Lily (Jacqui Parker) in ''Lift,'' a feature by the directors DeMane Davis and Khari Streeter that is filled with similar gems that drop out of nowhere. To be shown tonight at 6 and Saturday at 3 p.m. as part of the New Directors/New Films festival at the Museum of Modern Art, ''Lift'' focuses on Niecy (Kerry Washington), a sharp-eyed young African-American woman.

title: Rangers Even Series With Islanders
description: The Rangers may not be alive for a playoff berth, but last night they remained in contention for the inaugural LaFontaine trophy.

title: Soaked to the Chin
description: For the person who loves to soak in a bathtub, submerged up to the chin, Kohler has introduced the sok, a tub in which gently bubbling water eases over the rim and is recirculated without getting cold. The sok is 75 inches long, 34 1/2 inches wide and 24 1/2 inches deep. It comes in white ($5,790) or biscuit ($6,080), and will be available in April. The outside walls can be finished in tile, stone, wood or concrete; (800) 456-4537. ELAINE LOUIE

title: Panels by Day, Parties by Night: It's a Dance Music Conference
description: In the late 1990's electronic dance music spent a brief moment basking in the limelight as the next big thing, and major record labels suddenly flooded into the Winter Music Conference, an annual dance-music gathering here, to promote their new artists and strike deals with others.

title: Into the Loop Of a Daisy Chain Of Memories
description: When a naked body shows up during the astonishing new play called ''Mnemonic'' -- something that happens fairly often -- your instinct isn't to ogle or giggle or gasp in the time-honored responses to nudity on the stage.

title: Delphi to Cut 11,500 Jobs
description: DETROIT, March 29  The Delphi Automotive Systems Corporation, the world's largest auto parts manufacturer, said today that it would eliminate 11,500 jobs this year, mainly by not hiring replacements for retirees in the United States but also through some layoffs, and would close nine factories and distribution centers.

title: Mitsubishi Says Charges Will Double Expected Loss
description: Cost-cutting measures urged on the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation by its controlling shareholder, DaimlerChrysler, and a flood of recalls will result in charges that nearly double the large losses Mitsubishi already expected for the fiscal year that ends Saturday.

title: A Designer Dips Into the Big Boxes
description: BIG-BOX stores like Ikea, Home Depot and Home Depot Expo offer the renovator who isn't working with an architect or designer a decent shot at putting together a bathroom that is stylish as well as functional. As an interior designer in New York, I frequently go to Home Depot for basic supplies like paint and garbage bags and notice great options for the do-it-yourselfer. In fact, I think it would be fairly easy to outfit an entire bathroom there.

title: Suit Challenges State Aid to 150 Failing Schools
description: Riding the coattails of a recent court decision, the New York Civil Liberties Union filed a lawsuit yesterday accusing the state of not meeting its obligation to improve abysmal conditions in schools in nine districts that it knows are failing.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PENALTIES WAIVED
description: The New York State Public Service Commission voted yesterday to waive $25.8 million in potential penalties that Verizon Communications faced for service failures in August and September. Verizon had requested the waivers, saying that an 18-day labor strike in August and the backlogs it caused had been responsible for the company's inability to meet the commission's standards for repairs, installations and other activities in those months. Under the commission's regulatory system, penalties, returned to customers as rebates, are imposed if Verizon does not meet various monthly, quarterly and annual performance requirements, though the penalties may be waived when the company shows that the shortfalls resulted from circumstances beyond its control. The commission denied additional waiver requests that Verizon had requested for reasons other than the strike. Verizon's penalties for the regulatory year ended Aug. 31 now total at least $17.6 million, much more than the total in each of the three previous regulatory years. Joseph P. Fried

title: Corrections
description: An article last Thursday about the impact of the economy on home remodeling projects misspelled the name of the Pennsylvania hometown of Norm Abram, the master carpenter on the television program ''This Old House.'' It is Carlisle, not Carlyle.

title: Army Says Infantry Division Is Unprepared for War Duty
description: The Army has downgraded one of its 10 active duty divisions to the second-lowest rating for wartime readiness, citing a lack of training and personnel caused by peacekeeping work in the Balkans, Pentagon and Congressional officials said.

title: House Partisanship Kills a Bid for a Special Election Committee
description: An effort by the House to form a special bipartisan committee to examine election reforms collapsed today under the weight of fierce partisanship and divergent views between the parties about the value of reopening not-so-old wounds.

title: Economic Scene; Legal reform is what the old Soviet bloc needs to put it on the path to growth.
description: THE transition from Communism to a free-market economy is like changing the engine on an airplane while it is still flying,'' Gerard Roland of the University of California at Berkeley explained at a conference here. The challenge is to feed, clothe and house people -- and maintain their support for reform -- while overhauling the system of production and distribution.

description: The Bush administration cast its first veto in the Security Council late Tuesday night, ending a weeklong marathon debate and scuttling Palestinian hopes for a United Nations observer force in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: Court Rules Topless Bar Is Adult Business
description: ALBANY, March 29  If topless bars and adult video stores lose their struggle for survival in New York City, it will not be for lack of ingenuity.

title: New Hope for Community Gardeners
description: IT'S an old New York story. The snow melts, the crocuses are up and community gardeners start wondering if this is the last year the roses will bloom on their patch of land. Their fears are not unfounded. Over the last 15 years, 100 gardens have been leveled, and 80 are on sites singled out for development.

title: Troubles Are Piling Up at Pacific Century
description: First came the disappearing degree. Now come the disappearing profits.

title: STOCK SALE LIFTS CHIP MAKER'S PROFIT
description: ATI Technologies Inc. said it had a fiscal second-quarter profit, reflecting a $54.9 million pretax gain on the sale of its interest in the chip maker Broadcom Corporation. Net income at the No. 1 maker of chips that improve computer graphics was $607,000, or break-even on a per-share basis, compared with year-earlier net income of $51.1 million, or 24 cents a share. Sales in the period ended Feb. 28 fell 39 percent, to $232.4 million from $380.1 million. Excluding acquisition-related costs and the gain, the company had a loss of $26 million, or 11 cents a share, in line with a reduced forecast ATI made on March 1.

description: AFRICA

title: Arab Leaders End Meeting In Disarray Over Iraq
description: The meeting of Arab leaders billed as a step toward regional harmony pledged new financial support for the Palestinian government today, but the arguments on lifting United Nations sanctions against Iraq collapsed in bitterness.

description: ARKIN-Robert B. On March 28, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Isobel. Dear father of Rosalie (Barry) Gornstein and Michael Arkin. Cherished grandfather of Elizabeth. Adored uncle. Services Friday, March 30th, 11:30AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the discovery of mass graves in Burundi after fighting between ethnic Hutu rebels and the government referred incorrectly to the Hutu population. They are a majority, not a minority.

title: Getting There With Help From Above
description: IN the early 1970's, the Defense Department needed a navigational tool that troops on the move could use to pinpoint their location. The solution they developed required two dozen satellites, atomic clocks, microwave radio transmitters and some heavy-duty number-crunching hardware.

title: You Bet!
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: XFL's Ad Campaign Starts Tomorrow
description: The XFL's television advertising campaign, designed to prove that despite bad ratings it is not going away, will begin tomorrow night during the telecasts of the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. men's basketball tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANN, CAROL
description: MANN-Carol. The Board of Directors and members of the Quaker Ridge Golf Club record with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Carol Mann, whose many years of friendship, kindness and enthusiastic spirit will always be remembered. Beth Z. Post, President Roger H. Tulcin, Secretary

title: ARCH COAL RAISES ITS FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT FORECAST
description: Arch Coal has raised its forecast of first-quarter profit after coal prices doubled in the last year. Earnings for the quarter ending March 31 will be 10 cents to 15 cents a share, up from analysts' estimates of 4 cents, Arch said. The company lost $15 million, or 39 cents a share, in the first quarter of 2000. Coal prices have surged because of rising demand from utilities seeking alternatives to natural gas, whose price increased 300% last year. Arch's shares rose $1.15, to $29.05 a share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUNDIN, A. PETER, M.D.
description: LUNDIN-A. Peter, M.D. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of A. Peter Lundin, M.D., clinical professor of medicine at SUNY Downstate and director of ambulatory hemodialysis at Kings County Hospital Center. An alumnus of Downstate, Dr. Lundin was the first person to complete medical school on dialysis and the longest surving dialysis patient. He was also a pioneering patient advocate. We extend our condolences to his relatives and his many colleagues and friends. John C. LaRosa, M.D., President Eugene B. Feigelson, M.D., Dean of the College of Medicine

title: Vallone Seeks Big Rise in Schools Spending
description: Class sizes in grades four through eight would be cut to an average of 24 students, down from as much as 28. An extra $125 million would be set aside to buy textbooks and other critical instructional supplies. High school science labs would be modernized. School days at troubled city schools would be extended.

title: Arab League Belligerence
description: The last time the Arab League held a summit meeting was more than 10 years ago, a reflection of the bitter divisions engendered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Given the angry tone and virulently anti-Israel content of this week's gathering in Amman, Jordan, Arab leaders would have been well advised to delay a reunion until they could set a more moderate course. The message of the meeting was that many of the hereditary rulers and civilian autocrats in attendance seemed consumed by old hatreds while the economic opportunities and democratic trends of the 21st century threaten to pass their region by.

title: A New Source For an Old Favorite
description: Bathtubs are a dirty business. Pollution regulations make it prohibitively expensive to produce cast-iron claw-foot bathtubs in most countries. A large majority of the claw-foot bathtubs in the world come from just two companies, Roca and Valadares, both in Leiria, Portugal. Demand for the tubs is still high, said Barbara Sallick, the co-founder of the luxury bath store Waterworks. She cites their ''deep sit,'' vintage look and handmade, orange-peel texture. But the cost is from $2,000 to $5,000, depending on size. (Kohler's versions, made in this country, run toward the higher end.) Now, better trade relations with China have opened a new source. Lee Selkirk, the founder of Historic Baths in Toronto, said Americans will be able to buy Chinese claw-foot tubs this summer for $1,200 to $1,600; the tubs will be sold in Manhattan through George Taylor Specialties; (212) 226-5369. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

And for a man in mid-life crisis, it's a lot cheaper (under $50) than a red convertible; information (800) 243-3050 or www.norelco.com. TIMOTHY JACK WARD

title: Technology Briefing
description: INTERNET HOUSE COMMITTEE ACTS ON SPAM The House Energy and Commerce Committee moved yesterday to curb unsolicited e-mail, known as spam, passing a bill that would require such commercial electronic messages to include valid return addresses so that recipients can easily request that their names be removed from the mailing lists. The bill would authorize the Federal Trade Commission to take action against senders of spam, and it would allow Internet service providers to sue in federal court for $500 a message, up to $50,000, if a person or company violated the law. The measure's sponsor, the Heather A. Wilson, a New Mexico Republican, said: "Consumers should have the same power to stop junk e- mail from invading their home as they do with junk mail, telemarketing and junk faxes." (NYT)

The original N.I.C., as the New Internet Computer Company calls its Web-browsing and e-mail machine, was released in July 2000 as a low-cost alternative for people who did not need a fully equipped desktop PC but wanted more than the features offered by basic Internet appliances. The new version offers customers a choice of hardware colors and an operating system upgrade that makes it easier to connect through D.S.L., Ethernet and cable modems.

As part of the transaction, Hearst-Argyle sold its three Phoenix radio stations to the Emmis Communications Corporation of Indianapolis for $160 million. The closely held Imes is based in Columbus, Miss. Hearst-Argyle is based in New York.

title: JUDGE APPROVES SETTLEMENT OF WASTE MANAGEMENT SUIT
description: Waste Management, North America's largest trash hauler, has won a judge's approval for its $22.7 million settlement of lawsuits by shareholders who accused directors of mismanaging the company. Some shareholders sued the company, based in Houston, in mid-1998 in Delaware Chancery Court, asserting that officials had made statements between 1991 and 1997 that exaggerated the company's profits. The result, they said, was $3.5 billion in write-offs and a drop in the company's share price. The $22.7 million settlement includes a $15 million payment to the company by insurers of a subsidiary, Waste Management Holdings, and the resolution of payment disputes with some retired executives, which saved the company $7.7 million, according to court documents. ''We think it's an outstanding settlement,'' said David Bershad, a lawyer for the shareholders.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TOURISM PLANS
description: An effort to promote tourism in areas of New York City off Manhattan's beaten tourist paths was announced yesterday by the Conference Board, a business and research organization. The board said a subsidiary would work with community groups in areas ''rich in history and culture'' to produce strategies to attract both visitors from outside the city and city residents who live outside the target areas. Those areas include Hunts Point in the Bronx, Fort Greene in Brooklyn, Jamaica in Queens, Historic Richmondtown in Staten Island and the Mount Morris neighborhood of Harlem. The Lower East Side is also in the program because, though better known to those from elsewhere and attracting many visitors, it has the potential for attracting still more, said Gretchen Dykstra, a consultant to Business Enterprises for Sustainable Travel, the subsidiary. Joseph P. Fried

title: PUBLISHER'S PROFITS GROW
description: Bloomsbury Publishing, the British publisher of J. K. Rowling's Harry Potter best sellers and works by other authors like Michael Ondaatje, said net income more than doubled to $5.35 million last year as the latest in Ms. Rowling's series broke records. Sales also more than doubled, to $72.6 million. Bloomsbury said ''Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire,'' the fourth in a planned series of seven, had been the fastest-selling book in history and had driven further sales of the first three books. A movie of the first book is due for release at the end of the year and Bloomsbury said the series had become ''a long-term asset that will continue to generate significant earnings well into the future.'' Alan Cowell

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUDOLPH, ALAN G.
description: RUDOLPH-Alan G. Died on March 24 at age 83. Urban planner, businessman, equestrian. Born in New York City on August 6, 1917, he was the son of Solomon S. and Helen Goldsmith Rudolph. He was a graduate of the Fieldston School, the University of Pennsylvania and Pratt Institute, where he received a Master's of Planning. He was an executive at Goldsmith Brothers Stationers, a business founded by his uncles. He later worked as an administrator at Pratt Institute, as a housing advocate at United Neighborhood Houses & owned the Hunt Valley Farm in Staatsburg, NY. He was the former Chairman of the Board of the University Settlement, where he served for nearly 40 years. He was the husband of Nancy Peirce Rudolph of Clinton Corners, NY; father of Lucy Rudolph of Oakland, CA, and John Rudolph of South Berwick, ME; brother of Sally Ann Drachman, Mamaroneck, NY, stepfather of Dorothy Anne Driscoll, Darien, CT, Mary Ellen Schwartz, Forest Grove, OR, and John H. Driscoll, Jr., S. Glastonbury, CT; grandfather of Maya and Emma Rudolph and Isaac Lomprey. A memorial service will be held on April 1, 2001 at 1PM at his home in Clinton Corners, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to the University Settlement, 184 Eldridge St, NY, NY 10002. Funeral being handled by Allen Funeral Home, 1605 Main Street, Pleasant Valley, New York.

title: Metro Business Briefing; MILSTEIN PARTNERSHIP DISSOLVED
description: In the latest installment of the Milstein real estate feud, Seymour Milstein dissolved the family partnership that owns the Milford Plaza Hotel on Eighth Avenue and asked for a court-appointed referee to sell the 1,300-room property. Mr. Milstein and his children said in a suit filed yesterday in State Supreme Court that ''relations within the family are strained to the breaking point'' because his brother's son Howard Milstein ''has attempted to exercise unilateral control over the family's holdings.'' Seymour Milstein and his brother Paul had an amicable partnership for more than five decades, enabling them to build a multibillion-dollar empire. But in recent years wings of the family have been suing one another. ''This is just one of Seymour's publicity stunts,'' said George Arzt, a spokesman for Howard Milstein. ''He interfered with two transactions for $250 million at the top of the market.'' Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

title: DANA IS BUILDING A TEXAS PLANT TO SUPPLY G.M. PARTS
description: The Dana Corporation, a leading maker of light-truck axles, said yesterday that it would build a factory in Longview, Tex., to make frames and other structural parts for an undisclosed General Motors vehicle. About 450 workers will be hired for the 211,000-square-foot plant, which is expected to be completed in March 2002, said a company spokesman, Jeff Cole. The cost was not disclosed. The factory will supply a General Motors plant in nearby Shreveport, La., that makes pickup trucks. The company, based in Toledo, Ohio, has about 300 plants and other facilities and employs more than 75,000 people. Dana had sales last year of $12.3 billion.

title: Album of the Week: 'Discovery,' Daft Punk

The French electronic invasion has slowly crept up on popular music over the last few years, and now we are in the midst of a full-scale onslaught, with recent releases by Mirwais, Benjamin Diamond and Daft Punk, soon to be followed by the new Air album and Etienne de Crecy's first album for V2 Records. title: Espionage Is the Family Business, Even in a Fun Factory
description: ''Spy Kids'' is a notion-stuffed toy of a movie: ''The Treehouse of the August Moon,'' powered by a sugar-buzz filmmaking style, which the director, Robert Rodriguez, is, for once, using for the good of mankind. Or rather, the good of family-kind, since he obviously made ''Spy Kids'' so he could show it to his own children. Exposing them to the bleary-eyed blood lust of his previous features -- ''El Mariachi,'' ''Desperado,'' ''From Dusk Till Dawn'' -- might put them on the early road to intensive therapy.

title: Parallel Predicaments On a Collision Course
description: A high-minded what-if movie that sternly trumpets its moral gravity, Reza Parsa's ''Before the Storm'' is a timely if overly schematic meditation on the gloomier implications of the notion that indeed we're all connected. While that's hardly news these days, the film, torn from current headlines about the exporting of terrorism and about gun-toting teenagers who open fire in public schools, would still like to disabuse us of any lingering illusions of insularity.

title: COOKIE MAKER CUTS BACK
description: The world's leading cookie maker, Danone of France, announced measures to confront a worldwide glut of cookies by shutting six factories and cutting 1,200 jobs. Danone, which has been on a buying spree in the cookie world in the last 18 months, said the measures, which had been widely expected, will permit it to run factories at 57 percent of capacity instead of the current 43 percent. The moves will eliminate about 8 percent of Danone's 15,000 jobs in the next three years. Shares in Danone, best known in the United States for its Dannon yogurt products and Evian mineral water, fell almost 3 percent. John Tagliabue

Lufthansa has been raising its ownership in Sky Chefs since 1993, when it first acquired a 25 percent interest from Onex, an investment firm run by the Toronto businessman Gerald Schwartz. Sky Chefs has a 34 percent share of the airline catering market.

title: LAGARDRE SEEKS ACQUISITIONS
description: Lagardre, a French media, auto and aerospace company, is seeking media acquisitions that could double the size of the company, an executive said. Lagardre can spend as much as 10 billion French francs ($1.35 billion) for acquisitions. The company has been focusing on media since it traded its military division, Matra, for one-third of Arospatiale of France in 1999. title: The Bomber Speaks

The enormity of that act was so great that it is hard to believe anything Mr. McVeigh has to say could actually increase public outrage. But he has found the words to do just that. In interviews that form the basis of a new book by two journalists from The Buffalo News, Mr. McVeigh alludes to the 19 children who died in that blast as ''collateral damage'' and says of the victims and their families, ''I have no sympathy for them.'' Mr. Milstein and his children said in a suit filed yesterday in State Supreme Court that "relations within the family are strained to the breaking point" because his brother's son Howard Milstein "has attempted to exercise unilateral control over the family's holdings." Seymour Milstein and his brother Paul had an amicable partnership for more than five decades, enabling them to build a multibillion- dollar empire. But in recent years wings of the family have been suing one another. "This is just one of Seymour's publicity stunts," said George Arzt, a spokesman for Howard Milstein. "He interfered with two transactions for $250 million at the top of the market."

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUMMERS, MAURICE
description: SUMMERS-Maurice, in his 90th year, RAF Test Pilot. Maurice Summers, a former Royal Air Force Wing Commander and Test Pilot, director of E.F. Hutton, Governor of the New York Stock Exchange, and Real Estate Developer, died after a long illness on March 29 at his home in Bermuda. He was 89. Mr. Summers was born in Hull, England. His first flight was on January 15, 1930 at the age of 18. He served on active duty in the Royal Air Force and Fleet Air Arm until 1934 when he became a test pilot. Prior to World War II, Mr. Summers delivered aircraft around the world including two tours with the Chinese Air Force in 1937 and 1939. In 1940, Mr. Summers was placed in charge of Bomber Development Flying for Vickers Armstrong. In March 1941, he piloted the first B-24 ''Liberator'' Bomber to England setting the then Trans-Atlantic speed record of 7-1/2 hours. Twice during his flying career Mr. Summers' life was saved by parachute. In 1950 Mr. Summers became a member of the New York Stock Exchange, and was made a partner of E.F. Hutton in 1953. He later became a Director until his retirement in 1973. He served as a Governor of the New York Stock Exchange from 1970 to 1973. With his retirement from Wall Street he returned to flying and participated in the National Aerobatics Championships at age 62. Mr. Summers started his third career as a real estate developer in Florida in the 1970's building single family houses and rental apartments. Mr. Summers was a member of the Everglades Club in Palm Beach, FL, the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, NY, and the Royal Air Force Club in London. His wife of 52 years, the late Jean Ellis Summers, predeceased him in 1993. He is survived by his daughter, Mrs. Michael I. Gulden of Palm Beach and his son Mr. George E. Summers, also of Palm Beach. He has four grandchildren: Christopher and David Gulden of New York; Bliss Summers of New York, and Ellis Summers of Memphis, TN. He will be greatly missed by his immediate family, and their dogs. Funeral services are private.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CITIGROUP TOWER DEAL
description: Eric Hadar and his former partners agreed on one thing yesterday: Mr. Hadar's $725 million purchase of the 59-story Citigroup tower will occur at the end of April. The former partners, who have sued Mr. Hadar over a separate real estate deal, signed a stipulation in State Supreme Court yesterday allowing the Citigroup deal to proceed. Mr. Hadar, president of Allied Partners, and his joint venture partner, Boston Properties, are expected to take over the tower, on Lexington Avenue, by April 24. The stipulation also allows Mr. Hadar to sell the building at 1 East 57th Street to LVMH, the luxury retailer, for $200 million. Mr. Hadar, Philip Pilevsky, the Gindi family and the Chehebar family paid $51 million for the 17-story building a year ago. Mr. Hadar later bought out the partners for a tidy profit. But when the partners learned that Mr. Hadar was going to sell the building for $200 million, they filed two lawsuits, threatening the Citigroup deal. Allied Partners plans to use the proceeds from the 57th Street deal to buy the Citigroup tower. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

Travelers will save as many as six hours by no longer having to stop on the West Coast or in Japan.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEON, JOSEPH
description: LEON-Joseph. Age 82, actor and writer, died peacefully March 25, 2001 in Bradenton, Florida, surrounded by friends and loved ones. He was a resident of Saugerties, NY and wintered in Florida, and longtime Woodstock, NY area resident. He is survived by his companion of many years, Robin Litton, a sister Florence Tanenblatt of Delray Beach, Florida and a brother, Cantor David Leon of El Paso, Texas. He is also survived by several nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by two sisters, Anita Arroyo of Panama and Rose Shein of Florida. Joseph was born June 8, 1918 in New York City, the son of the late Morris and Bessie Leon. He enjoyed a successful career on Broadway and in films and television which spanned sixty years. In 1977, while understudy to the lead upon the death of Zero Mostel, he assumed the title role in Arnold Wesker's ''The Merchant'' which ran on Broadway after a successful preNew York tour. Among his credits of thirty New York productions he was seen in ''Bell, Book and Candle'', ''Glengarry Glen Ross'', ''Social Security'', and ''Cafe Crown''. Movie appearances include ''Vice Squad'', ''The Sweet Smell of Success'', ''Brewster's Millions'', ''Arthur on the Rocks'', and ''Daniel'', among many others. During the 1970's and 1980's, he was the voice-over spokesman for hundreds of radio and television commercials. He was also a Professor of Drama at Hofstra University 1966-1972. In 1989 upon his retirement, he moved to Aixen-Provence, France where he studied French and received le Diplome from Universite' Marseille d'Aix-en-Provence. While living there, he began his new career as a writer. His short stories have been published in ''Yellow Silk, II''. In October 2000, he was awarded First Prize in a national competition by the Eaton Literary Agency for his autobiography, ''Beneath the Tallis''. Memorial services will be held in the near future on Anna Maria Island, Florida, Woodstock, New York and Aix-en-Provence. Contributions in his memory may be made to Maverick Concerts, PO Box 102, Woodstock, NY 12498, The University Museum Endowment Fund, Indiana University of Pennsylvania, Sutton Hall, Indiana, PA. 15705, or the Actor's Fund, 729 Seventh Ave, New York, NY 10019.

If the film's gothically gloomy ambience recalls Tim Burton's ''Sleepy Hollow,'' its allegorical story of an Eastern European village where Jews and Christians compete for the soul of a half-mad visionary has the vividly fanciful quality of a Yiddish folk tale. Although the movie has hardly any singing and dancing, it's not all that far from ''Fiddler on the Roof'' territory. And its biggest weakness is a screenplay that has the stiff, cut-and-dried quality found in the sort of musical-comedy libretto that has to spell everything out in stilted, quasi-mythical anguage.

title: Armstrong Sales Fall
description: Armstrong Holdings, a maker of ceilings and floor coverings, said today that sales fell in the fourth quarter and its chief financial officer had resigned. Armstrong said sales fell 8.8 percent, to $659.1 million from $722.8 million, because of higher raw material costs. The company had an operating loss of $86.7 million, or $2.15 a share, from a loss of $185.9 million, or $4.65 a share, a year earlier. It said the executive, E. Follin Smith, would be replaced Monday by Leonard Campanaro, former president of the Harsco Corporation.

title: FEDERAL-MOGUL IS EXPECTING A WIDER LOSS
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, a leading maker of automotive engine bearings and seals, said yesterday that its first-quarter loss would be wider than forecast because lower production of cars and trucks reduced demand. The loss from operations will be about 65 cents a share, the company said. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast a loss of 37 cents a share. In the quarter a year earlier, Federal- Mogul had profit from operations of 86 cents a share. Federal-Mogul, which makes Champion spark plugs and Anco wipers, has been hurt by lower demand for heavy-duty trucks and by the slump in car and light-truck sales from last year's record.

title: Getting Into School: The Role of Race
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SCHERING-PLOUGH CORP., Kenilworth, N.J., and Medarex Inc., Princeton, N.J., both pharmaceutical companies, said they had formed a research alliance to develop fully human antibody therapeutics.

title: To Men, Losing to Judit Polgar Is No Disgrace : Tigress of the Chessboard Purrs Quietly and Pounces
description: CANNES  Judit Polgar, the strongest woman chess player ever, was one move away from checkmating Christian Bauer, a French grandmaster. He resigned.

title: John Lewis, 80, Pianist, Composer and Creator of the Modern Jazz Quartet, Dies
description: John Lewis, the mastermind of one of the most famous ensembles in jazz, died on Thursday. He was 80 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Purdue Stops Stiles and SW Missouri's Dream
description: Katie Douglas waved to the cheering crowd, lingering with a smile on the court that she would see again.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAGLEY, MILLIE
description: BAGLEY-Millie. March 29, 2001 at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Loving mother to Bennett and Vicki (nee Gorme) and Daniel and Gladys (nee Weinberger). Cherished grandmother to Felise, Robert and Spencer. Adored aunt to Nadine Hoffman. Services on Sunday 10 A.M. at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'', 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre.

title: Forced to Divest, Bush Aides Lose Money in a Bear Market
description: A falling stock market is spelling trouble for a number of wealthy Bush administration officials who are selling their multimillion-dollar investment portfolios -- and taking some losses in the process -- to comply with government ethics rules.

title: Baseball Is Trying to Limit How News Coverage Is Used
description: On the eve of opening day, Major League Baseball is asserting broad new powers to control the transmission and use of news photographs and play-by-play coverage of its games.

title: Unions Say Fire Dept. Ignored Concerns Over New Radios
description: The unions representing New York City firefighters and officers accused the Fire Department yesterday of endangering its workers by putting new hand-held radios into service even though, the unions said, the department knew months ago that some of the radios had not worked properly during tests.

title: Sports of The Times; 2 Coaches Who Share A History
description: It is ancient and little-known history that Muffet McGraw once called her old Philadelphia coaching crony, Geno Auriemma, and offered him a job as her assistant at Notre Dame, that great American collegiate sports cathedral.

title: The Times Will Publish Personal Ads
description: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that for the first time in its history, it would print personal advertising. The ads will appear in certain Sunday sections of The Times.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Saturday about Native Leather, a Manhattan shop that has revived the Outlaw, a style of cowboy hat favored by motorcyclists, misspelled the surname of an employee who makes the shop's leather sandals. He is Dick Whalen, not Whalan.

title: A University President Who Learns the Hard Way
description: MARCH has not been the kindest month to Lee C. Bollinger, president of the University of Michigan.

title: Study of Lobster Deaths Will Test Pesticide Link
description: Ever since Long Island Sound lobstermen began pulling up traps full of dead lobsters two years ago, they have blamed the pesticides used in the fight against the West Nile virus. But scientists have been skeptical, saying that pesticides may play a role but that more study is needed.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALACH, JEFFREY, M.D.
description: WALACH-Jeffrey, M.D. The Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart and the Medical Staff of Cabrini Medical Center mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague & friend who served our institution for many years. Dr. Walach was a dedicated physician who always demonstrated sincere concern for his patients and for Cabrini Medical Center. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his family. Lawrence Ottaviano, M.D., President, Medical Staff Bonnie Simmons, D.O., Medical Director Paul Candino, President and CEO, Cabrini Medical Center

title: Sports of The Times; More Hope Now Than Regret for Gooden
description: HE walked out sober, on his own two feet. After all the trouble Dwight Gooden has brought upon himself, this accomplishment was better than a plaque in the Hall of Fame.

title: North Dakota Effort to Ban Altered Wheat Is Set Back
description: A bill that would prohibit planting genetically modified wheat in North Dakota for two years appears headed toward defeat, legislators in the state said yesterday.

title: Arthur D. Hasler, 93; Deciphered Salmon's Homing Instinct
description: Dr. Arthur Davis Hasler, an internationally recognized authority on freshwater ecology who is credited with explaining the salmon's homing instinct, died on March 23 in Madison, Wis. He was 93.

title: SWISSCOM SELLS PROPERTY
description: Switzerland's biggest telecommunications operator, Swisscom, said it had sold a second large property package as it continued an effort to divest itself of noncore assets and focus on its main activities. The former monopoly, which is still 65 percent owned by the Swiss government, sold 162 buildings for $741 million to a Swiss property group, the PSP Real Estate Group. Earlier this month it sold 28 buildings to a consortium led by Credit Suisse Asset Management in a deal worth about the same amount. Swisscom said it would make a gain of about $300 million on the two deals. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)

title: The Irish Throw a Wake for Connecticut
description: In the ultimate tie breaker, Notre Dame rose in the second half to break Connecticut's heart in two tonight.

title: Peripatetic 'Don Carlo' Goes for the Gold
description: ''Don Carlo'' has a weight and ambition rarely equaled in the Verdi repertory. Long yet beautifully sustained and filled with characters rising high above Italian opera's good guy-bad guy Manichaeism, Schiller's play set to music demands vocal and theatrical resources to make most opera companies hesitate.

title: PURE RESOURCES MAKES DEAL TO BUY HALLWOOD ENERGY
description: Pure Resources Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Hallwood Energy Corporation for $268 million in cash and assumed debt to increase natural gas output. Hallwood, an oil and gas producer, put itself up for sale this month. Pure Resources will pay $12.50 for each Hallwood common share, 38 percent more than Hallwood's closing price Thursday. Pure Resources also will pay $10.84 for each preferred share and assume the debt of Hallwood, which is based in Denver. A Pure Resources spokesman, Jack Harper, declined to say how much of Hallwood's debt it would assume. Hallwood had $79.4 million in long-term debt in 2000, according to filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The transaction brings Pure Resources more oil and gas producing fields in Texas and New Mexico, where it currently owns most of its properties.

title: Corrections
description: Excerpts from President Bush's news conference yesterday rendered a word incorrectly in some editions in a comment by Mr. Bush on his reason for opposing limits on the emission of carbon dioxide. Referring to an energy crisis, he said, ''And that's why I decided to not have mandatory caps on CO2 .'' He did not say ''to now have mandatory caps on CO2 .''

title: A Life Retreats From Tragedy to Happy Beginnings
description: At the beginning of Lee Chang Dong's ''Peppermint Candy'' a well-dressed man, possibly drunk and visibly distressed, stumbles into the reunion picnic of a group of men and women who had worked together in a factory 20 years before. They remember him from the old days, but he seems to have fallen out of touch. After alarming the group with his erratic behavior, the man, whose name is Yongho (Sol Kyung Gu), climbs a nearby railroad bridge and, as the train approaches, screams into the camera, ''I want to go back.''

title: Free Speech That Threatens My Life
description: The news of James Kopp's arrest in France for the 1998 murder of Dr. Barnett Slepian reached me just as I finished performing an abortion for the last patient of the morning. My relief was tempered by the news of the previous day: A judgment against anti-abortion fanatics who want me and other doctors killed had been overturned by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, in California.

title: Yale Hospital Faces Inquiry On Fraud
description: Three months after the Department of Justice fined Yale-New Haven Hospital $1.4 million for knowingly accepting improper Medicaid payments more than a decade ago, federal investigators here, in Florida and in California are looking into more recent allegations of fraud against the hospital, according to federal officials and documents.

title: Article 2001033191286286278 -- No Title
description: Pardon me if I don't get out my handkerchief.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 4 about C. M. Woodhouse a Briton who led Greek resistance forces against Hitler, referred incompletely to a wartime episode involving Kurt Waldheim, former secretary general of the United Nations, who was a German officer in Greece. Mr. Woodhouse asserted in 1988 that Mr. Waldheim had signed a report naming a British prisoner as a resistance leader, thus assuring his execution. The article noted Mr. Waldheim's denial of the charge, but should also have stated that a British Defense Ministry investigation concluded in 1989 that Mr. Waldheim was blameless in the prisoner's death.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KROLL, DOROTHY NEE BECK
description: KROLL-Dorothy nee Beck. Cherished mother of Susan Kroll and Larry Kroll. Devoted daughter of Sophie (Emmer) Beck. Dear sister of Gertrude Dietch. Loving grandmother of Laura, Frances and Michelle. Graveside service Sunday at noon at the Mount Moriah Cemetery, Fairview NJ. For info call ''Wien & Wien,'' 800-322-0533.

title: Stocks End Gloomy First Quarter as Investors Look to the Next
description: One of Wall Street's longest winters ever finally ended yesterday, as investors closed a miserable quarter with a muted rally.

title: Journal; The Thrill Of It All
description: George W. Bush, earnest student of his father's one-term presidency, finally figured out that it is still the economy, stupid, that could do him in.

title: So Many Clocks, So Little Time
description: Each year when daylight saving time arrives, it takes me longer and longer to reset all the clocks in the house. It's not only that I can never remember whether the time becomes an hour earlier or later; the real problem is that there are too many clocks. Have you noticed? It used to be that you had to reset just your wristwatch and alarm clock; now there are clocks everywhere.

title: Corrections
description: Afront-page article yesterday about the 2000 census data for California misstated the percentage of the state's population that was classified as non-Hispanic white a decade ago. It was 56 percent, according to adjusted 1990 figures, not nearly 75.

description: To the Editor:

title: European Union Takes Step Toward Ties With Pyongyang
description: In a further measure of its commitment to bolstering the peace effort between South and North Korea, the European Commission said today that it was taking steps toward establishing diplomatic relations with the North before a visit there by a European Union delegation.

title: STEM CELLS YIELD PROMISING RESULTS
description: The basis of a possible revolution in treating heart attack patients has been laid by three reports of using stem cells from bone marrow to repair heart tissue in animals.

title: FOUNDER'S SON OUSTED
description: Chung Mong Hun, fifth son of Chung Ju Yung, the Hyundai Group founder who died on March 21, will give up his stake in Hyundai Engineering and Construction, said Lee Kun Young, chairman of the financial supervisory commission of South Korea. Mr. Lee said that Mr. Chung, the largest individual shareholder, with a 6.38 percent stake, had agreed to demands by the company's creditors, who now appear to have control of the company, that he sever his ties to the company and that other top managers resign as a condition of approving a $2.2 billion rescue package. Don Kirk (NYT)

title: Rebukes in Collapse of Maxwell Empire
description: A government report sharply rebuked Goldman, Sachs and other prominent financial institutions today for their involvement with Robert Maxwell, the flamboyant tycoon whose death a decade ago provoked the collapse of a trans-Atlantic media empire.

title: Giuliani Vetoes Bill Aimed at Sweatshops
description: For the sixth time in just over a month, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has vetoed legislation passed by the City Council, this time rejecting a so-called anti-sweatshop bill that would have required clothing and textile suppliers contracting with the city to show that they engage in fair labor practices.

title: In Between the Williams Sisters, Capriati Enjoys a Rout
description: Jennifer Capriati did not have long to savor her semifinal victory today in the Ericsson Open. The questions came in a torrent because another Williams sister loomed in Saturday's final.
