description: The New York Times: Reuters Technology Index

title: Eyes on Duke-Maryland, Spartans Slip Under Radar
description: They are the defending national champions, playing in their third consecutive Final Four, and still the Michigan State Spartans are often overlooked. Coach Tom Izzo does not mind. He rattles off the reasons his team is perhaps the fourth choice to capture the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHONBERG, JEANNE
description: SCHONBERG-Jeanne, age 82. On March 30, 2001 in Newtown, PA. Long time resident of New York City. She will be greatly missed by her nieces Judy & Ann Bardacke and Jean Marchildon and by her four great nephews and niece. Memorial contributions to the Employees Scholarship Fund at Pennswood, 1382 Newtown-Langhorne Road, Newtown, PA. 18940.

title: Terror Suspect Fails in Effort to Move Other Trial
description: Citing the unusual character of New York juries, a federal judge in Manhattan has refused to move the trial of a Sudanese man who was charged with stabbing a jail guard last November while he was awaiting a separate trial in the embassy bombings conspiracy.

title: 30 Villagers Presumed Dead After Paramilitary Raid in Colombia
description: A right-wing paramilitary group that terrorizes villagers began what might be its most audacious assault of the year by marching into a small southern town on Saturday and seizing 30 people, the governor of Nario Province said today. The villagers, who were accused of collaborating with leftist guerrillas, are generally believed to be dead.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOLISH, DOROTHY
description: KOLISH-Dorothy. Beloved widow of Teddy and sister of Rosalind Horowitz. Died in her 89th year at Hospice By The Sea, Boca Raton, FL. She leaves three generations of devoted and adoring nieces and nephews and many dear friends who will never forget her profound kindness, sense of humor and courageous spirit. We are grateful for her life devoted to others. Contributions in her memory may be made to the American Jewish Congress.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROZEN, LEONARD
description: ROZEN-Leonard. Age 50. Devoted son of Simon Rozen, loving brother of Sylvia Rozen, cherished uncle of Alex, beloved friend of Lori Fischer, loving nephew and dearest cousin. Services on Sunday at 12 P.M., at Shomrei Hadaas Chapel, 3803 14th Avenue, Brooklyn, N.Y., 718-436-8700.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-7

title: Blacks Split on Disclosing Multiracial Roots
description: When Milton Heard was filling out the census form for his family last year, he hesitated where it asked the race of his two sons, Jacob and David.

title: Defending Abortion Rights
description: An arrest in France and a ruling by a federal court of appeals in San Francisco should prod the Bush administration to crack down on violent elements within the anti-abortion movement. We do not question the sincerity of John Ashcroft, a fierce opponent of abortion rights throughout his political career, when he says he will enforce the nation's laws, as he reiterated Thursday. But the real issue is whether the attorney general will go beyond that, and place the defense of this besieged constitutional right where it belongs -- atop his list of priorities.

title: Gooden Concludes His Memorable Career
description: Having just heard that Dwight Gooden was retiring, the Yankees' pitching coach, Mel Stottlemyre, chatted with Roger Clemens on a practice field this morning about how great Gooden once was and how great he could have been. They agreed that Gooden should have had everything that Clemens has now: 260 career victories and an inevitable induction into the Hall of Fame.

title: Legal Sparring Turns Testy In a Baby Formula Dispute
description: The distributor of a generic infant formula asked a federal judge yesterday to force the maker of Enfamil, the formula fed to more American infants than any other, to stop distributing what it called misleading marketing materials to pediatricians' offices.

description: To the Editor:

title: Studies Find Scant Availability of Spectrum for Wireless Internet
description: Three government studies released today cast doubt on a plan by President Bill Clinton to find space on the congested airwaves, a move seen as essential to the future of a new generation of hand-held wireless devices capable of browsing the Internet at high speeds.

title: Butchers' Passover Lament: Yes, We Have No Brisket
description: It was 10 days before Passover and the brisket orders were coming in like so many plagues, but Steve Gilmer, along with most of the country's kosher butchers, had no brisket. Except for one little piece he was saving for his best customer.

description: The beef packer IBP Inc. announced yesterday that it was suing Tyson Foods Inc. for abandoning plans to acquire it for $3.2 billion.

title: As Definitions Change, The Moral Turns Trivial
description: Take friendship, both as a word and as a sign of the state of the social universe. A new little book called ''The Dictionary of Dangerous Words,'' compiled by Digby Anderson, contends that changes in the use of that word reflect changes in the nature of personal relationships, and a decline in the old virtues, identified in this book as ''honesty, especially frankness of speech, loyalty, trust, self-sacrifice and permanence of character.''

title: Santa Fe Journal; Uproar Over Virgin Mary in a Two-Piece Swimsuit
description: Compared with a photograph of a nude woman as Jesus at the Last Supper or a painting of the Virgin Mary with a dollop of elephant dung on her breast, a computerized photo collage of Our Lady of Guadalupe wearing a two-piece swimsuit of bright roses seems rather innocuous.

title: SINGAPORE WIRELESS LICENSES
description: Singapore said three local phone companies and Sunday Communications Ltd. of Hong Kong were eligible to bid in an auction next month for four high-speed wireless Internet licenses. The local bidders are MobileOne Asia, StarHub Mobile and Singapore Telecom Mobile.

title: In a Brave New World, Foreigners Do Quite Well
description: Three decades ago, foreign players were rarely seen at national championships. This was partly because they were barred from competing in the Vanderbilt and Spingold Knockouts, as a result of a regulation inserted by a leading playing-administrator who did not fancy being beaten on his home turf by touring Italian world champions.

title: Violence on South African Farms
description: Seven years after the end of apartheid, the depredations of white rule stubbornly persist on white-owned South African farms, where five million blacks endure deplorable living and working conditions, meager wages and precarious terms of employment. Frustrated expectations and insecurity have fueled disturbing levels of violence in recent years. More than 100 white farmers were murdered last year in 800 attacks on farms. Many hundreds of blacks, in turn, have been beaten, raped and murdered by white farm owners and managers and private security personnel. The violence reflects not just lingering inequality and prejudice but a failing system of criminal justice that is one of the most troubling legacies of South Africa's racist past.

title: France Will Not Extradite If Death Penalty Is Possible
description: Officials in the United States face a significant legal snag before they can bring to trial a man accused of killing a Buffalo doctor who provided abortions.

title: Sky Watch: The Northern Lights
description: Keep a careful watch on the northern sky during this week for possible sightings of the aurora borealis, or northern lights. This colorful phenomenon is produced when subatomic particles spewed from sunspots and solar flares collide with molecules and atoms of the earths atmosphere. These atoms are temporarily stripped of some of their electrons by these collisions or near collisions. The atoms absorb energy in the process.

description: Merck to Lower the Price Of Two AIDS Drugs in Brazil

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the international treaty on global warming referred incorrectly to a 1997 Senate vote of 95 to 0. The vote registered opposition to some provisions. It was not a rejection of the treaty, which has never been submitted for ratification.

title: Safety Flaws Found in Stores Selling Meat
description: As investigators pressed ahead with a safety crackdown at local meat-processing plants, federal officials said they had also uncovered serious flaws in the way safety checks are made at supermarkets and other meat distributors in the New York region this week.

title: Times Reporter Is Honored
description: A richly detailed account of an American wrestler's startling Olympic victory over a three-time gold medalist from Russia earned Richard Sandomir of The New York Times first-place honors yesterday in the Associated Press Sports Editors contest.

title: Zany Brainy Gains Some Time To Find a New Line of Credit
description: Zany Brainy, a chain of specialty toy stores that has been struggling with an unwieldy acquisition and a difficult retail environment, bought itself more time yesterday to right its finances.

title: Sports of The Times; Thomson's Shot Still Dwarfs the '51 Series
description: TOGETHER again, Bobby Thomson and Ralph Branca were sitting side by side at the same table, autographing memorabilia at the Marriott Marquis last night before a reunion dinner celebrating the 50th anniversary of the 1951 baseball season. More than 30 members of that year's Yankees (who won the World Series), Giants and Dodgers were signing their names at other tables.

title: Westchester's 10-Mile Strip Mall; Commerce Crowds One Corridor to Keep Suburbs Tidy
description: The ugliest 10 miles in Westchester County, Central Park Avenue, runs from the Bronx border to White Plains and is lined with indistinguishable strip malls, superstores and fast-food joints.

title: Spring Training Losses Don't Worry Yankees
description: Tino Martinez grounded into a double play in the eighth inning of the Yankees' exhibition game today, and in the private box of the principal owner, George Steinbrenner shook his head slightly, a small bit of exasperation. The Yankees lost to Minnesota, 6-2, clinching the league's worst record in exhibition play at 9-20 in what has become a rite of spring.

title: Company Faces I.R.S. Suit For Not Withholding Taxes
description: After months of ignoring several dozen business owners who boasted that they no longer withhold taxes from paychecks, the Internal Revenue Service has taken civil action against one of these companies.

title: FLEETBOSTON PLANS TO CUT $700 MILLION FROM BUDGET
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation plans to cut as much as $700 million in annual expenses by the end of the year as sluggish capital markets and a slowing economy sap revenue. A Fleet spokesman, James Mahoney, said the Boston-based bank wanted to reduce operating expenses $400 million to $700 million a year, largely by cutting spending on consultants, discretionary travel, marketing and advertising. ''We're trying to avoid expense reductions that would affect service,'' Mr. Mahoney said.

title: For Those Not Yet Free
description: To the Editor:

title: Tracing Anti-Abortion Network To a Slaying Suspect in France
description: He was calling himself Clyde Swenson at the time. He was living in Jersey City and working in construction, occasionally flashing hints of his keen intelligence and religious fervor. Most mornings he attended 7 o'clock Mass before lugging an ammunition box filled with carpentry tools to the job site.

title: JETS PURSUING COLMAN
description: According to General Manager Terry Bradway, the Jets are close to signing linebacker Doug Colman, who was the Giants' sixth-round selection in 1996 and who has also spent time with Tennessee and Cleveland. Colman would be a backup to Marvin Jones at middle linebacker.

title: No. 1 Fan Plays Host To Legends Of Baseball
description: He grew up wanting to be a professional baseball player, can instantly name the sport's most valuable players for just about any year and paved the path for his political career by partly owning and helping to run the Texas Rangers.

description: To the Editor:

title: City Employee Is Accused of Seeking Bribe
description: A city Department of Transportation employee was arrested on Thursday and accused of seeking a bribe during the Manhattan Bridge reconstruction project, officials said yesterday.

title: WARNING IS ISSUED ABOUT WEB BROWSER SECURITY FLAW
description: Microsoft warned consumers yesterday of a potentially dangerous security flaw in certain versions of its Internet Explorer Web browser. The flaw could allow an attacker to send a computer user an e-mail message containing a hidden program that could damage data on a computer or perform other functions. The security vulnerability, which affects Microsoft Explore 5.01 and 5.5, is particularly troubling because the illicit program could be executed on a victim's computer simply by trying to view a message containing HTML data. HTML, or Hypertext Markup Language, is the standard notation form for representing World Wide Web pages. The flaw could also be exploited by visiting a Web page that contained a hidden program that would be downloaded to a computer without the user's knowledge. In its bulletin, the company said the vulnerability could not be exploited if the file-downloads feature of the browser had been disabled. John Markoff (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: An article in the special Retirement section on March 21 about online medical information misstated the ownership of RxList.com, a Web site with data and message boards on prescription drugs. It is owned by HealthCentral.com, an information clearinghouse that also sells drugs online; Rx.com is a competitor.

title: PACIFIC CENTURY SHARES SINK
description: Pacific Century CyberWorks, the Hong Kong technology company, continued to bleed after reporting losses of $886 million on Wednesday. The company's stock fell 5.4 percent, to 39 cents a share, after declining 6.5 percent on Thursday. CyberWorks said it would scale back its video game division in Japan to cut $9.7 million in costs. It disclosed a bit of good news, noting that the Hong Kong Stock Exchange had exempted it from a rule that it must obtain the approval of shareholders for any deal involving more than 50 percent of its net assets. CyberWorks has negative shareholder equity so the rule could have frozen its ability to make deals. Mark Landler (NYT)

title: Arrests May Reopen Question Of Anti-Abortion Conspiracy
description: The arrests of two people in New York on charges of conspiring to ''harbor and conceal'' James Kopp are mark the first time that the government has alleged a conspiracy to aid someone accused of killing an abortion doctor. That action now seems likely to reopen a longstanding debate over whether there has been a conspiracy behind anti-abortion violence.

title: Ad Intended to Stir Up Campuses More Than Succeeds in Its Mission
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 19  The editor of the student newspaper at Brown University says he knew a tempest was headed his way and rose to open the door for it.

title: World Business Briefing
description: ASIA

title: SAP, A SOFTWARE MAKER, IS SET TO PURCHASE TOPTIER
description: SAP A.G., a leading maker of business management software, agreed yesterday to buy TopTier Software Inc. for $400 million to take control of the company, whose software it uses in its mySAPWorkplace product. SAP, based in Walldorf, Germany, said the cash purchase of TopTier, which is based in San Jose, Calif., will lead to a $50 million charge for some of TopTier's products that are not yet ready. TopTier had sales of $20 million last year, SAP said. SAP is making the acquisition after TopTier abandoned a plan to go public following a slump in technology shares. TopTier, whose technology is used by DaimlerChrysler and Universal Studios, filed to raise $105 million in April 2000.

title: Portage la Prairie Journal; Beavers' Dual Role: National Icon and Huge Pest
description: Down by one of Alex McKay's wheat fields, a trail of freshly cut wood chips and poplar stumps led to a clump of cattails where a beaver lay dead.

title: Bush Suspends Rule on U.S. Contracts
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  A Clinton administration regulation prohibiting federal contracts from going to bidders with a history of violating environmental, health, safety and other federal laws was suspended today by the Bush administration, angering Congressional Democrats and organized labor.

title: A Poet Whose Death Wish Eventually Comes True
description: The first time we see Rafal Woja czek, the subject of Lech J. Majewski's new film, he is throwing himself out of a restaurant window in a sudden and noisy shower of glass. Since the window is on the ground floor, Wojaczek stumbles home more or less unharmed, but the leap is a rehearsal for what is to come: a series of theatrically self-destructive acts that alternate (or coincide) with bouts of drunkenness, occasional sex (with a mental-hospital nurse) and spontaneous recitals of poetry, culminating in a suicide that seems less surprising than long overdue.

title: Parsifal at 60: Youthfully Rash, Vocally Rich
description: Otto Schenk's lushly traditional production of Wagner's ''Parsifal'' was mounted by the Metropolitan Opera in 1991 especially for Plcido Domingo, who was then 50, in his vocal prime and eager for the challenge of this touchstone German dramatic tenor role. Few people back then would have guessed that 10 years later Mr. Domingo would still be singing Parsifal. Yet on Thursday night at the Met the 60-year-old tenor returned to the role in a deeply affecting overall performance conducted by James Levine. And if anything, Mr. Domingo's portrayal is richer than ever.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROTHSCHILD, KARL
description: ROTHSCHILD-Karl. Passed away Thursday, March 29, 2001 in his 96th year. Beloved husband of the late Wally Rothschild; loved father of Herbert and Marie Rothschild, Bernette and Irwin Bernstein; adored grandfather and greatgrandfather of 14 grandchildren and fifteen great-grandchildren. He lived a long and fulfilled life. He will be missed.

title: Knicks' Bumpy Road Trip Becomes a Pratfall in Portland
description: There is a notion that the Knicks are at their finest when the competition is the most fierce, that while they may lose games to the league's duds, they raise their play to match an elite opponent. That theory was squashed tonight at the Rose Garden.

title: As Bid to Privatize Schools Ends, Supporters Second-Guess Effort
description: To those who have spent their lives in the hardscrabble Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bushwick and Flatbush, the meeting on Jan. 10 at the Jackie Robinson School told it all.

title: One Week in Bangkok
description: Aone-week package to Bangkok that includes accommodations in the deluxe Peninsula Hotel is $1,098 a person, based on double occupancy -- a price that includes air fare on China Airlines from Los Angeles or San Francisco, daily breakfast, two tours, airport transfers and hotel taxes. It is available from April 10 to June 1, a time when weather is generally very hot on Bangkok, and again Sept. 1 to 25, when it can be rainy. At other times of the year (December through February are the best months weather-wise), there is a surcharge of $77 to $252 a person. The package is sold by Natrabu Indo-American Travel, an Indonesian tour operator. Information: (800) 628-7228 or www.usindotravel.com .

title: The Adolescent's Poignancy As That Wedding Nears
description: ''Frankie's Wedding'' abounded in attractive bits and pieces of words and movements lovingly assembled by Gabrielle Lansner. She based her production on ''The Member of the Wedding,'' Carson McCullers's 1946 novel, which was turned into a successful play in 1950. Directed and choreographed by Ms. Lansner, this dance-theater adaptation was presented by Gabrielle Lansner and Company on Tuesday night at Walkerspace.

title: Article 2001033193560815522 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Kiss and a Warning on Campaign Bill
description: Just outside the Senate as the campaign finance debate wound down today, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, Democrat of Connecticut, spotted Representative Christopher Shays, the Connecticut Republican who is the lead sponsor of the bill in the House. He kissed Mr. Shays on the cheek and counseled: ''Be strong. You can do it.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVITT, MILTON
description: LEVITT-Milton. Congregation Kol Ami records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member and conveys sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Thomas K. Weiner Rabbi Shira Milgrom Ken Simon, President

title: Effective Nuclear Disarmament
description: Among the most cost-effective defense dollars America spends are those that pay for reducing Russia's arsenal of leftover cold-war weapons. The Bush administration began a review of these ''threat reduction'' programs this week, saying it wanted to make them more efficient. But there are troubling signs that Mr. Bush is planning to reconsider his campaign promise to increase overall funding for these valuable programs and cut them instead. That would be a serious mistake.

title: Long Odds for a Skater Out of Harlem
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  It is 7 degrees at the United States Olympic outdoor speedskating oval here. Just as the wind slices through the air and sends swirls of freshly fallen snow onto the ice, Jason Benta makes his move. He advances slowly at first, like a tiger eyeing his prey. But when his skates hit the black starting line, he explodes into a sprint.

title: Corrections
description: The Making Books column on Thursday, about travel writing, misstated the nationality of James Hilton, who wrote the novel ''Lost Horizon.'' He was British, not American.

title: A Reminder
description: Daylight saving time resumes at 2 a.m. tomorrow. Clocks are set ahead one hour.

title: Exuberant Quartet Refuses To Live Up Tidily to Its Name
description: The Mir Quartet shares with the works of its namesake, the Spanish painter Joan Mir, a taut, vibrant energy and sense of lightness. But the Surrealist painter was much fussier than the quartet. In its Monday night concert at Alice Tully Hall, this young ensemble, which won the 2000 Naumburg Foundation Chamber Music award, played with a kind of big emotion worlds away from Mir's tight tidiness. The players' concern seemed less with technical perfection for its own sake than with really saying something in the music, and a few bobbles along the way -- a hitch in the violin's bow, some flat intonation or the unevenness of expiring breath at the end of the ''Heiliger Dankgesang'' in Beethoven's Opus 132 -- were natural side effects of genuine communication, like throat-clearings from a compelling speaker.

title: China Holds American
description: Chinese security agents detained a Chinese-born American last month as he crossed the border from Hong Kong, where he works as a business professor, the American Embassy confirmed. The unexplained detention of Li Shaomin, a naturalized citizen, follows several other incidents in which Chinese-born scholars with United States ties have been held on vague security grounds.

title: Former Financier Declines to Take Stand at His Trial on Bankruptcy Fraud Charges
description: The defense in the bankruptcy fraud trial of the former financier Robert E. Brennan rested today after calling just three witnesses -- and Mr. Brennan, who said he had wanted to testify, was not among them.

title: Religion Journal; Reading Signposts on Church Unity
description: A question that could be put to leaders of America's Protestant denominations is, How does one read the signs of the times as regards church unity? Have Protestants entered a new period of ecumenical cooperation? Or is the prevailing tendency in the other direction, with denominations under such internal pressure, because of controversies, that they risk some fragmentation along regional or ideological lines?

title: A Menu of Plot and Intrigue Where Food Is Just a Show
description: If you didn't know any better, you might assume that the comic melodrama ''Dinner Rush,'' which is being shown tonight and tomorrow in the New Directors/New Films series, was the work of a prodigy. The camera floats through a kitchen where the chefs, busy as hungry bees, are hard at work preparing dishes.

description: MARSH-Burt. The Board of Governors and Members of High Ridge Country Club acknowledge with deep sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Burt Marsh. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife, Elaine, and their family. Richard J. Bornstein, President Leon Fassler, Secretary

description: KITTLE-Ralph W. Died Tuesday, March 27th, 2001 at his home in Keswick, Virginia. He is survived by his sister, Patti McMillen of Ringgold, Georgia; his three children, Connie Neer of Rochester, New York, Cary Williams of Chevy Chase, Maryland, and (Kit) Ralph Kittle, Jr. of Greenwich, Connecticut; and seven grandchildren, Tyler and Cary Neer, Ben, Alex and Tommy Williams; & Cody and Henry Kittle. The family will receive friends at the Hill & Wood Funeral Home at 201 North First Street in Charlottesville, Virginia on Saturday, March 31, from 4 to 6 P.M. The funeral service will be at Grace Episcopal Church in Cismont on Sunday at 2 P.M. with burial to follow. There will be a reception at the Parish House afterwards. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the National Parkinson Foundation, Inc. at 1501 N.W. 9th Avenue, Bob Hope Road, Miami, Florida 33136.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: OSHKOSH TRUCK CORP., Oshkosh, Wis., a maker of fire, military and concrete-mixer trucks, said it had won a five-year contract valued at more than $1 billion to build vehicles for the United States Army. The contract covers several heavy-truck models.

title: Most Likely to Succeed
description: To the Editor:

title: PG&E Warns of Possible Blow to Profits
description: The PG&E Corporation, the owner of California's largest utility, said today that it might take a fourth-quarter charge of $4.1 billion to write off power-purchasing debts that it will not be able to collect because of an accounting change.

title: Coming Home To Kennedy Can Get Ugly
description: GRANTED, his diatribes have a way of sailing over the top and into hyperbole's red zone. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani could fill many stadiums with people ready to cheer him on, a back-from-vacation columnist included, when his target is the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: After Sentence, Sheriff Says He Was Singled Out as Gay
description: Everything went according to plan today at the sentencing of Joseph L. Ciccone, the former Bergen County sheriff who pleaded guilty in January to campaign-related corruption charges: he expressed remorse, was placed on probation and avoided jail time.

title: Mr. Verniero's Faulty Memory
description: In a contentious 13-hour hearing on Wednesday, Peter Verniero, the former New Jersey attorney general who is now a State Supreme Court justice, gravely damaged his ability to continue serving effectively on the bench. When he was attorney general, under Gov. Christie Whitman, Mr. Verniero ignored and played down evidence that the state police were stopping and searching drivers based on their race, a practice known as racial profiling. Yet on Wednesday, when asked about key events or documents pertaining to profiling during his three years as attorney general, Mr. Verniero's memory repeatedly failed him. His display of amnesia and his insensitivity to a key racial issue will inevitably diminish his authority as a judge who is supposed to be perceptive and evenhanded.

title: Better a Cutting Word Than a Dull Bushel of Babies
description: It's quite the thing this year: rich Art Deco-era hedonists sitting around in expensive clothes and elegant apartments saying clever things about their disdain for the standard forms of marriage and family. Alan Cumming and company are, of course, doing it in the current Broadway revival of Nol Coward's ''Design for Living.'' Down on Bank Street, a lesser-known cast of 10 is having a go at Dawn Powell's ''Jig Saw,'' which hasn't been produced in New York since 1934.

title: Pet Sounds and Vibrations of Brian Wilson
description: The script visible on the teleprompter at the TNT Network's tribute concert for Brian Wilson, filmed on Thursday before a live audience at Radio City Music Hall, ranked the Beach Boys leader with Mozart and Bach. The filigreed gleam of Mr. Wilson's famous songs earns those kudos.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JERRY, DPM.
description: MILLER-Jerry, DPM. Dr. Jerry Miller of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Jamaica, NY. Died March 29, 2001 at the age of 82. The beloved husband for over sixty years of Jeanette. Father to Andrew and Richard. Father-in-law to Gail and Debbie and loving grandfather to Evan and Jody, Jarrod & Darren. Brother of the late Rose Caplan. A graduate of the New York School of Podiatry, he was the founder of Jerry Miller I.D. Shoe Company and retired as an executive officer of Gulf & Western which acquired his company in 1953. He was the past president of the Jamaica Jewish Center, the Boca Teeca Country Club and the B'nai B'rith Boca Teeca Chapter. A distinguished veteran of the U.S. Army; recipient of the Bronze Star and the Purple Heart; an avid golfer and gin player. Past member of Cedarbrook and Tam O'Shanter Golf Clubs as well as the Boca Teeca Country Club. He was a loving soul who brought happiness and smiles to everyone he met. Services on Sunday, April 1, 2001 at 10 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91st Street & Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DELUCA, JOHN J.
description: DeLUCA-John J., age 76. Of Lindenhurst, L.I. On March 28, 2001. Beloved husband of Lorraine, loving father of Lyn Eisen, Judy Brochhausen, Joe DeLuca and Lorrie Pilc. Devoted grandfather of Stephanie, Allyson, Adriane and Justin. Friends may visit at BoydSpencer Funeral Home, 448 West Main St, Babylon, L.I. Sunday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9:30. Funeral Mass on Monday at 10 A.M. Our Lady of Grace RC Church, West Babylon, L.I. Interment St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens.

description: Jeannette Gadson, the Brooklyn deputy borough president, will resign her post and, effective today, become a special assistant to Borough President Howard Golden, Mr. Golden said yesterday.

title: A Tribute to Nicholas, With Dance
description: Dancers, musicians and old friends paid tribute to the tap-dancer Harold Nicholas on Thursday night at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. But the star of the evening was Nicholas himself, who died on July 3 at age 79.

title: SECURITY FORCES IN BELGRADE STORM MILOSEVIC'S HOUSE
description: After a night of conflicting reports that Slobodan Milosevic had been arrested on corruption charges, Serbian special forces stormed his residence before dawn today, beginning the legal process that could finally imprison the man whose 13-year reign over Yugoslavia brought wars, destruction and poverty to his people.

title: Midtown Soup Kitchen Serves Its Last
description: Despite colorful streamers and balloons, and simple white vases holding red and white flowers, this was hardly a celebration. The Lamb's Manhattan Church of the Nazarene was serving the last meal from its soup kitchen yesterday.

title: Energy Crisis Dims Small-Business Hopes
description: The lights stay off at Espresso Bravo until well past dusk these days, and in the back of the cafe, where four refrigerators for soft drinks and juice used to stand, there are two. By next month, there will be none.

title: A Mining Company Suspends Operations in Zimbabwe
description: Because they must dig where the ore is, mining companies tend to be more inured than most to the vagaries of doing business in stormy corners of the world. They often calmly ride out political and economic crises that other businesses flee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WALDMAN, EDWARD
description: WALDMAN-Edward. Real Estate Developer and Philanthropist of Boca Raton, FL, formerly of West Hartford, CT, died Friday, March 30, 2001, at the age of 76 at his home after a valiant battle with cancer. He led a full and vital life. Edward Waldman is survived by his wife of 48 years, the former Ethel Haiblum, his four children, Maryanne Waldman and her husband Tad Connelly, Andrew Waldman and his wife Ana, James Waldman, Risa Rubloff and her husband Jay and 12 grandchildren. He is also survived by his brother Abe and his sisters Irene Cooper and Frances Schulberg. The funeral and interment will be held at The Star of David Chapel and Cemetery in North Lauderdale, FL, on Sunday, April 1 at 2pm.

title: Domi Douses Spectator but Not the Fire
description: In his 12-year career, Tie Domi of the Toronto Maple Leafs has often blended routine violence with unpredictable theatricality. Who can forget how Domi pantomimed ''putting on the belt'' after taking the unofficial heavyweight championship from Bob Probert? And the time Domi gave Ulf Samuelsson a concussion with a sucker punch? Or the wisdom Domi shared in his recent sermon against the management of the Philadelphia Flyers regarding the Eric Lindros trade negotiations?

title: Giuliani Makes Choices for a Decency Panel on Art
description: After promising for weeks that he was making progress on assembling a decency panel to review art in publicly financed museums, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has come up with a list that includes members of his administration, friendly clerics and his own divorce lawyer, Raoul Felder.

title: Shooting Victim Dies
description: An 18-year-old pizza deliveryman who was shot in the head while riding his bicycle in Brooklyn early Wednesday morning has died from his wound, the police said yesterday.

title: Harbingers Of Bad Times; The Ranks of Job Recruiters Are Thinning Out Rapidly
description: The job-recruiting business has been very good to Herb Deitz. Last summer, Mr. Deitz, who manages the recruitment business for Unitek, a technology consulting firm that works mostly with start-ups, had 35 people reporting to him, with plans to expand. So when business started to slow in December, he ascribed it to the usual end-of-the-year sluggishness.

title: YEN PLUNGES AGAINST DOLLAR
description: Currency traders in Tokyo interpreted remarks by Japan's economy minister, Taro Aso, to mean that the United States was willing to let the yen weaken, and they obliged by pushing its value down 1.9 percent, to 125.52 to the dollar, a level not seen since October 1998. The yen has lost 9 percent of its value against the dollar this year, and 2 percent against the euro.

title: Cuttings: A Bounty of Tulips Along Park Avenue
description: YOU know that spring is here to stay when the tulips poke their burgundy-green noses out of the ground. On the Park Avenue mall, in the 60's, there's a whole regiment of them, all two inches high last weekend.

title: When Treason Was Tolerable And Gossip Death
description: For years historians have been arguing about just how history should be written. Should it chronicle the actions of the high and mighty, who move armies, negotiate treaties and shape the destiny of nations? description: Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday named Neil D. Levin, the superindent of New York State's Insurance Department and a former investment banker, as the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Maker Agrees to Cut Price Of 2 AIDS Drugs in Brazil
description: Merck has agreed to cut the price of two AIDS medicines in Brazil, bowing to pressure from that country's government, which was threatening to develop generic copies of one of the drugs.

title: Investigators Search for Clues in Aspen Crash
description: A day after a private twin-engine jet crashed while trying to land in Aspen, Colo., killing all 18 people aboard, investigators said today they did not know why the plane missed the runway and slammed into a hillside.

title: Personal Spending Rises 0.3%
description: Personal spending rose in February after the biggest gain in almost a year, and rising confidence suggested consumers might help keep the economy out of recession, government and industry reports showed today.

title: LUMBER WATCH
description: Trade officials of the United States and Canada are looking at the establishment of an experts' panel as a way to resolve a long-standing dispute over Canadian lumber exports. In a telephone call Thursday night, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, and Pierre Pettigrew, left, trade minister in the Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade of Canada, agreed that experts with sufficient authority to act could develop a long-term solution if technical details could be worked out. The current agreement limiting the amount of construction-grade lumber that Canada exports expires at midnight Saturday and the United States lumber industry plans to file an anti-dumping complaint against Canada Monday morning. Anthony DePalma (NYT)

title: Anesthesia Drug Is Removed From Market After the Deaths of 5 Patients
description: An anesthesia drug, Raplon, is being taken off the market because five patients died while receiving it, the Food and Drug Administration announced.

title: Israeli Arabs Protest Peacefully; 6 Palestinians Are Killed and 100 Hurt in West Bank and Gaza
description: In the Israeli Arab community, life is divided into before and after October, when everything changed. In October, the Israeli police shot dead 13 Israeli Arabs during tense, raucous demonstrations. For many, hope then died that they would ever be accepted as full citizens of Israel with equal status and rights.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Brian Trubshaw, a test pilot for the Concorde, misstated the name of the biplane in which he trained with the Royal Air Force in the 1940's. It was the Stearman, not Sirman.

title: DoubleClick Privacy Lawsuit Dismissed
description: A federal judge in New York has dismissed a class-action privacy lawsuit against DoubleClick Inc., the largest Internet advertising firm.

description: The Public Utility Commission of California sought to block the shutdown of NorthPoint Communications 's high-speed Internet network yesterday, although it was not clear how effective the action would be.

title: The Senate's Moment for Change
description: For more than a decade, advocates of overhauling the campaign finance system have been waiting for their moment.

title: MUNICH RE'S PROFIT IS UP
description: Munich Re, a leading reinsurer, said 2000 profit jumped 55 percent after it raised prices and benefited from a tax gain. Net income rose to 1.75 billion euros ($1.54 billion), or 9.89 euros a share, from 1.1 billion euros, or 6.45 euros, in 1999. Analysts had expected an 18 percent increase in profit. Like other financial services companies, Munich Re benefited as Chancellor Gerhard Schrder cut German business taxes. Reinsurance earnings rebounded after catastrophe claims dropped last year. Munich Re said it had raised premium prices further in 2001.

title: Hemisphere Conference Ends In Discord on Global Warming
description: An international conference here ended in disagreement today after the United States declined to go along with a Latin American-backed call for industrialized countries to reduce their emissions of the heat-trapping gases blamed for global warming.

title: Disease Threatens an Ancient Flock
description: With British officials mulling a shift to vaccinations to combat the foot-and-mouth disease crisis, think for a moment of the Herdwicks.

title: Minority Legislators Urging Verniero to Quit After Hearing
description: The New Jersey Legislature's Black and Latino Caucus, dissatisfied with State Supreme Court Justice Peter G. Verniero's testimony in hearings on racial profiling, yesterday called for his resignation.

title: Clinton Energy-Saving Rules Are Getting a Second Look
description: The Energy Department is reviewing energy efficiency standards, issued in the last weeks of the Clinton administration, that would require new clothes washers, water heaters and central air-conditioners to use less electricity and natural gas.

title: U.N., in Shift, Moves to Save Art for Afghans
description: As recently as last year, Afghans, including members of the ruling Taliban, were imploring outsiders to help protect the country's cultural heritage by taking away portable items for safekeeping, scholars say. But international cultural organizations and Western archeologists blocked their removal out of a longstanding concern for keeping artifacts in their historical settings.

title: Hamilton Confident He Can Get Job Done
description: For a decade, Darryl Hamilton was a reliable everyday outfielder who usually hit around .300. Today, as the Mets left Florida for two weekend exhibition games in Pittsburgh, Hamilton could not even guess at how he will be used this season.

title: In Buffalo, a Reminder of a Killing's Impact
description: More than two years after the murder of Barnett A. Slepian, a doctor who lived in nearby Amherst, the arrest of an abortion protester in his death has underscored how the killing still resonates here.

title: A Biotech Future
description: To the Editor:

title: GE CAPITAL AGREES TO BUY FRANCHISE FINANCE
description: The GE Capital Corporation agreed to buy the Franchise Finance Corporation of America for $1.4 billion in cash, expanding its lending to Burger King, 7-Eleven, Midas Muffler and other franchises. GE Capital, the world's biggest nonbank financing company, will pay $25 cash per Franchise Finance share, 5.4 percent more than Thursday's $23.72 closing price. GE Capital will also assume $700 million of debt. Franchise Finance, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., has provided loans and other credit to 6,200 properties in the United States and Canada. It will operate as a separate unit within GE Capital's Commercial Equipment Financing subsidiary.

title: Well, Who's the Joker Now?
description: Fabin Bielinski's trickster of a film, ''Nine Queens,'' is the kind of movie that seduces you into becoming putty in its manipulative card-sharking hands and making you enjoy being taken in by its shameless contrivance. When the secrets of its preposterous plot are finally revealed, you don't mind the absurdity. What matters is that the plot makes internal sense as an elaborate self-enclosed contraption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FUHRMAN, PHYLLIS CANTOR
description: FUHRMAN-Phyllis Cantor, 62. Of New York, NY on March 30, 2001. Beloved wife of Lionel. Loving mother of Lynda, Gary and George. Devoted mother-in-law of Josh & Laura. Adored grandmother of Nicole, Stephanie, Allison, Melissa and Sarah. Services on Sunday, 12:30 PM, ''Plaza Jewish Community Chapel'', 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Abroad at Home; The Feeling Of a Coup
description: We are learning something these days about the power of a willful president. Without a popular mandate, George W. Bush is making radical changes that will have long-term consequences for this country and the world. He is making them in a hurry, and for the moment there are no checks or balances to stop him.

title: He Bore Up Under Torture. Now He Bears Witness.
description: Apologizing for lacking a fan against the oppressive heat, Souleymane Guengueng led a visitor inside his mud-brick home after church on a recent Sunday. He settled in an armchair, near a gray filing cabinet, inside which he had collected evidence of hundreds of cases of torture committed by the government of this Central African nation in the 1980's.

title: Judge Is Rebuffed on Request To End Stop-and-Frisk Inquiry
description: A federal judge in Manhattan tried to win a promise yesterday from the United States attorney's office that it would conclude its lengthy investigation of the stop-and-frisk tactics of the Police Department within 90 or 120 days, but a prosecutor refused, saying only that the government would continue to act expeditiously.

title: Pigs Pass a Foot-and-Mouth Test As U.S. Increases Precautions
description: Agriculture Department officials said today that while tests of four North Carolina pigs suspected of carrying foot-and-mouth disease were negative, they would accelerate training of dogs used to help prevent the disease from entering the country.
